description:
If you want the best burrito in SF, I can't PROVE it's La Taqueria, but it's the best I'VE had 
Get the carne asada  burrito.  So incredibly delicious.  Tender meat, well seasoned, homemade tortilla.  Homemade chips and salsa too.
There's a reason they are top-rated with thousands of reviews -- because it's good [period]
Stop reading, head over.
author: Loren B.

description:
Mexican food is probably my favorite kind of food, especially tacos. I love tacos. Ive actually heard of this place from bringme a while back and finally thought about coming here on a Sunday around noon, and I just knew it would be crowded. When I got here around 12:30pm, yup. The line formed to outside the building. Thank goodness I ordered to go. And let me tell you guys... to go, the food was still delicious!! It makes me want to try this place out while it's fresh.

We got the super carne asada burrito el dorado style (super came with cheese, sour cream and guac-which made it so much better). The burrito wasn't super large and probably would be able to finish it in one sitting. But I split half with my bf and got an additional 2 carne asada tacos and 2 chicken tacos. Personally, I liked all the carne asada orders. The meat was Smokey and tender. It wasn't dry. In addition to that, they did not skimp out on the meat! The chicken on the other hand was a little dry. I think it was actually shredded chicken, and I was expecting diced chicken. I'm not a huge fan of shredded chicken because it's usually dry. But that's probably why I wasn't a big fan of the chicken tacos. 

If you got the time to come and wait here, I suggest coming right when they open. If you don't want to wait, I suggest calling in to go. I live about 15 min away from here and came home with the burrito still warm. The tacos cooled down a bit, but I think my favorite was still the burrito.
author: Rosa N.

description:
La Taqueria boasts that they have the best tacos and burritos in the world. After all, they are a James Beard award-winning establishment. Unfortunately, I can't agree that it was best. I thought it was alright. Above all, an overpriced and overrated tourist trap. I came here around 1:30 on a Saturday afternoon, with plenty of cash in hand, ready for a true mission style burrito. The line at first glance seemed like a deterrent, but it actually moves pretty quickly. I ordered a super carne asada burrito and a horchata. Really liked the horchata. Refreshing when you've been standing in line for a while and it gets quite hot inside.

Finding a place to sit inside or outside was a matter of luck. Be prepared to swoop in like a hawk for an available table. We waited for our number to be called and for our drinks to be ready. Retrieving our order was a little confusing as it's so hectic inside, but it seemed like everything was correct. My friend had said that the burrito was "wet" and then I had told him that there's no rice in it. I would say if you want to eliminate some carbs and still get that burrito experience, this would be the place. Next time I'm in town, I'll opt for the less touristy, more reasonably priced mission-style burritos.
author: Augustina G.

description:
I FINALLY GOT TO COME HERE. YAAASSS!!!! I've been wanting to come here for years, literally, but the lines were always insane at any time of day so we always said "next time." We'll the time has come and boy do I have a review for you!

I ordered the super burrito with carnitas el dorado style, because apparently that's the best way to eat this burrito according to all the fellow foodies. I was torn between carnitas and carne Asada but I'm glad I went with carnitas because it wasn't chewy, on the contrary he meat fell apart in your mouth. I find that with carne Asada yo always risk the meat being slightly bland or not seasoned enough but the carnitas has so much flavor because they soaked up the juice of the broth they had been soaking in. GO WITH CARNITAS! 

El dorado style is a must. Not many other taquerias crisp up your burrito on the outside and I thought this was a great touch to add extra texture to your food. It really sets them apart from other Mexican food joints by focusing on this small detail.

The super burrito itself was so good! Not sure if it's worth waiting in like for 2 hours, but it was worth the 25 minutes I waited. They cake in the guac and the salsa is fresh and savory without being too spicy for those of you that aren't into spicy salsas. They add really fresh tasting beans and rice and everything is evenly distributed within the burrito, which is a big thing for me.

Lastly, we ordered true chips with salsa and guac. If you're debating whether to include the guac in this, JUST DO IT. They add a ton of guac to each order and it really gives the chips that extra creaminess and texture. I'm definitely coming back when the line isn't too crazy!
author: Alejandra A.

description:
Came here because I read an article on best burritos in America and this place came in at number #1. So how does it stack up? Pretty damn good. 

I wouldn't say it's the best burrito I've ever had, but pretty close.  This place gets really packed and we almost got into a fight over our seat.  We were waiting in line and someone saw that we had a baby and they told us they were leaving and they offered us their seat.  Right as we were sitting down a lady tried putting her purse in the seat to claim it despite us starting to sit down.  She said, that she ordered and had priority in sitting, but thankfully the lady backed us up and told her that she was giving us the table, especially since we had a baby.  Whew.  

Still, in terms of the quality of food here, it's top notch.  It gets really busy and you might have to fight for your seat, but overall one of the best burritos you can have.  Also try their mango drink.  So good.
author: Benny H.

description:
Showed up 10 minutes before closing, and La Taq was still busy, but there was no line out the door.

It's listed in the 'Business info' section, but don't forget that they're cash only!

Despite being from the bay, I'd never had La Taq before this summer. I luckily had friends who had, and following their rec, I ordered the carne asada el dorado style. The burrito was more on the wet side, so the crunch was a nice contrast, so I'd definitely recommend that. As a heads-up, it is a bit greasy as a result of the grilling.

At some places, the meat tends to be dry, lack flavor, or be too salty, but I thought La Taq did a solid job, and the carne asada was flavorful without being too salty. I also felt like the portion size is decent. Not Chipotle-sized, but definitely filling.

Would I go again? Probably? Not sure if I'd wait in a line out the door though as there are other good burrito places in the Mission.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Ah, yes. The most famous taqueria known for the best burrito in America.

I'll make this blow quick.

It simply wasn't the best burrito I'd ever had. Neither did it come grilled the way I had seen it over it's numerous press videos. It was so bland to say the least and the amount of gush that came out of it between the salsa and overload of unseasoned guacamole made the mouth feel of each bite a textural person's palette, like mine, a complete nightmare.

Scott and I tried both the steak and carnitas burrito and both were equally disappointing.

I was just disappointed and do not plan to make a second trip for redemption.
author: Alexys E.

description:
Some of the best tacos of my life, and a very unique food experience. If you are looking for the best California-Mex for burritos and tacos: this is it. Great seating indoors and outdoors, friendly staff, lots of mariachi music rolling through, and of course -- good food. The line is a constant, but it moves fast. Expect a 10-20min line to order, and another 10 before your food comes. 

Our group had super tacos: chicken, veggie, beef tongue, and beef head -- all crispy. Also two folks had carne asada burritos, and we got chips and avocado to share. Everything was incredible. The strawberry fresca was a bit too sweet for us, the jamaica was perfect.

Great for: casual dates, hanging with friends, foodies, casual colleague hang, families, and low-key parents. Atmosphere is casual. Building is wheelchair accessible and good for folks with mobility issues who can either wait in line standing or have a friend they can tap in to wait. 

All around: highly recommend!!
author: Molly H.

description: Sure this place gets a lot of hype, but boy do they deliver. It's been over 10 years since my first visit and the food is still great. I pretty much stick to the carne asada, b/c it's so good and the fomo is intense! If you feel disappointed about your experience, perhaps your expectations were a bit high. Or perhaps you're just a poor judge of Mexican food....
author: Randy H.

description:
Came here on my visit to San Francisco. I heard really great things from my best friend who lives in the area so we went for lunch. The line was insane but it went pretty quickly  

The location isn't super large but they have indoor and some outdoor seating. We got two burritos; one vegetable and one carne asada. There are two options for the burrito: small & super (super comes with sour cream, cheese, and avocado purée). It was very fairly priced (I believe the veggie was around $6 and the carne asada was around $10). 

The burritos were soooo good. They gave us green spicy sauce to go (we didn't end up eating there). It was a normal sized burrito but the flour was clearly homemade and amazingggg. It was so perfect.
author: Vanness B.

description:
Quick service. I did not have to wait long to place my order. I have seen the line spill out onto the sidewalk so no line was a pleasant surprise. 

I ordered a crispy carne asada taco and a small strawberry agua fresca. I spent about $12 for both things which is kinda steep. The taco is average size, but the standout piece is the way they make the crispy taco. It's fried on the grill with cheese melted on top and then they place that inside of an uncooked tortilla. The perfect balance of crispy and soft. The meat was tender and seasoned nicely. I got it piled high with all the fixings. One was filling and I was satisfied, I definitely wanted more but my wallet said no. The Fresca was perfect! Not to sweet had very small pieces of fruit inside. A nice refreshing way to top off your meal.
author: Ty S.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of burritos and tacos, but I can really get behind La Taqueria. TIP: CASH ONLY.

Environment: The place was pretty packed when I got there (12:30 on a Thursday). Most of the tables were already taken and the line was wrapping around the inside of the store and a little out the building. But the line moves so fast I don't know how their employees work so fast and efficiently while also being so nice and friendly. The restaurant has a nice hustle and bustle atmosphere to it, and really lively and energetic. Also pretty clean!

Food: I got the Carne Asada (beef) burrito + Avocado, Dorado style. Dorado style is an amazing invention everyone should get on that. They basically grill the outside of the burrito so you get a nice crisp bite with every mouthful. The burrito is pretty no fuss with just meat, beans, and pico de gallo, but the meat is so flavorful and fresh, and the pico de gallo adds a nice freshness to it. The green spicy sauce they provide on the tables adds a nice freshness and spicy kick! The whole thing came out to around $11-12. The regular burrito is pretty big, but I easily downed 95% of it.

Really great food and lively atmosphere and energy. Would definitely come back.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Got the carne asada super burrito dorado style. I didn't see dorado style on the menu but luckily my friend knew all about it. (Dorado style is a half deep fry, where they place the burrito in a small pool of oil on a heated surface and crisp up the edges for you.)

The burrito itself was really good. They pack it full of well seasoned meats, pico de gallo, cheese, avocaods, sour cream, and beans. I also enjoyed the dorado style (not quite as fried as a chimichanga). It was somewhat filling, that is I could have eaten maybe another taco and been at a good spot.

The base price was at $12.35, which is a bit high for the Mission district in my opinion. I'd still come back and try out the tacos, because after all the name is La Taqueria.

Expect a wait in line as well as a wait in seating!
author: Hongsuk S.

description:
Best burrito in the world? Don't believe the hype!

Being an SF native, I've passed La Taqueria countless times over the years and l thought I was missing out on the "best burrito" in SF (at least). So this morning, after running some errands in the neighborhood, I headed to La Taqueria excited to finally try one of their famous burritos. 

The Wait: It was 15 minutes to open time and there was already a line of people waiting. In addition to the hipsters taking selfies in front of the place, there were a few Latino folks waiting so I took that as a good sign. We ordered to-go vs sitting in the dining area which is cute, especially the patio outside. They have a great system and despite being about 15 people back from the front of the line, we ordered, paid and got our food fast.

The Burritos: I ORDERED a regular carnitas with refried beans. I GOT a watery, loosely wrapped burrito with carnitas and pinto beans (see pic). Ok, I can get past the wrong bean BUT Carnitas are usually super flavorful and my burrito was very bland, despite a lot of pico de gallo in there. I had to add a couple of shakes of Tapatio to every bite to amp up the flavor. My friend got a spicy super carne asada burrito. Immediately he called out the size as being more of a taquito than a burrito. Size-wise both regular and super looked the same. He also said flavor wasn't anything special either.

Sooo, back to our usual City spots where we don't have to wait in line with hipsters and tourists for tasty burritos that are better than those found at La Taqueria! 

The silver lining: I popped into Dianda's next door and picked up some yummy pastries for later.
author: Gelsomina L.

description:
Unpopular opinion -- burrito here is overrated. Got the carnitas burrito el dorado style, and it just wasn't that great.  I think the lady taking orders may have misheard my friend who ordered for me, so I ended up with a burrito without cheese. Even if I put that aside, I thought the carnitas were pretty bland; I just kept drowning it in the green sauce to give it some flavor. Was really hoping to be blown away by the meat at the taqueria known for the best burrito, but I truly don't think it delivered. Also wasn't a fan of the chips & salsa; chips were thicker than I like and salsa was more like bland pico.

As others have mentioned, the restaurant is cash only. We went during lunch on a Friday, and there was a bit of a line, but we waited no longer than 15 min to order. The place is constantly packed, but traffic flows relatively smoothly, so it wasn't too tough to get a seat for 4. 

My friend got a super burrito el dorado style; perhaps I'll try that rather than a regular el dorado, but it'll take a bit of convincing for me to go back...
author: Tanisha S.

description:
Step aside, Taqueria Guadalajara: you've got competition in my heart for the best Mexican food in SF, and it's on the corner of 25th and Mission.

The line began at 25th and Mission that fateful night. It looked endless; I thought I would starve before I reached meat heaven. However, it moves surprisingly fast, and it gives you plenty of time to scout the tiny tables for parties almost ready to give up their tables. There's also a lot of time to ogle the menu (which is really straightforward) and their countless local awards. 

Everyone says you should get the super carne asada burrito dorado style, so my co-workers and I did. You order from a woman with a notepad and take your slips to the cash-only register. What came out of the pick-up line 15 minutes later were three burritos that didn't seem massive at first. Once the salsa was on and the first bites had been taken, though, we knew it was game over. Man, that melty cheese and avocado is a game-changer for an otherwise ordinary burrito. I love the philosophy of not putting rice in there. We all know we're going to get burritos for the meat.

Just before the store closed up (I knew because a trio of musicians came in and stood at the very end of the line), I slid back in for two tacos to go. When I got home with my paper bag of bulging tacos, the steam had soaked through in just ten minutes, and the pico de gallo was threatening to spill through the foil. Everything here is jam packed with meat. The best choice you can go with is carnitas, honestly -- they're so moist yet griddled to crispy perfection. And there's just so much of it! One is more than enough for a small stomach. It's excellent with the salsa.
author: Gwen W.

description:
Go for the burrito- riceless, like it was meant to be. We personally love the chorizo and feel everything else is a little inferior to that but I'm sure that'll change.
I've been here a couple of times. Both times it's jam packed. Community style table sharing is a requirement. Best to get it to go. 
Tips- cash only, works well if you order over phone so you don't have to wait as long.
author: Sarmishtha S.

description:
Food: 3.5 | Service: 3 | Ambiance: 3

This is not the best burrito in SF and definitely not the best burrito in the the U.S*. Perhaps my experience was an outlier and I've heard I messed up by not getting my burrito dorado style but my carne asada burrito was soggy and sloppily made. It looked a bit sad so I didn't even bother taking a picture of it. 
I'm not saying its a bad burrito, I believe the ingredients were decent. I think maybe they are trying to serve such a large crowd they have rushed the process of assembling the burrito to where it's hit or miss on whether or not you get a poorly executed burrito. 
It wasn't worth the 45 min wait for me and I think it's overhyped for sure.

It can be difficult to find seating, so either take it to go or have a friend snag a table while you wait in line.  

Their salsa is great though, and so was their mango aqua fresca! 

* source: thedailymeal.com 2018
author: Kimmy T.

description: A do not miss burrito stop in the Mission district. I promise you its worth the line! I personally preferred the carnitas, but the carne asada was also great. And make sure to get it grilled or you won't be getting the full experience.
author: Virginia T.

description:
We swung in here to grab some quick food, and ordered the Carnitas tacos and a Beef burrito. 

Both were excellent, and we barely waited. Not much more to say other than swing in and get some cheap, excellent food!
author: Dave S.

description:
I LOVE their super quesadillas! I love how crispy they make them. I normally get beef or lengua and am rarely disappointed here. Its so cheesy and love the avocadoes. We also get the burritos. Those are also good. 

One of the cons for me is having to pay cash. And on weekends... The line! I would recommend going on a weekday or weeknight  to avoid the lines. It's a pretty consistent Mexican restaurant and it's one of SF's gems.
author: Lyra C.

description: I found this place while looking for the best spots to eat in SF, and they popped up as the "best Mexican spot" so i knew i had to drop in. First of all- the line was out the door and about 15-20 min long! The seating is limited but spots start to open while you're waiting in line. I ordered the Carme asada burrito, a chicken soft taco and a chorizo soft taco and made all three "super." I also had an agua de melon to drink. Everything was so good and fresh!
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Came here since I was in the vicinity and due to the place being way too packed they got my order wrong two times and a half. I ordered a super carne asada burrito, the first time I got a chicken burrito, the second it wasnt super. The guy was trying to guilt trip me into taking cheese, avocado and sour cream on the side, but I just wanted it in my burrito.

Ultimately, they added avocado & cheese, and they gave me sour cream on the side. I would definitely go to el farolito over this place any day of the week. The burrito was good, but not worth the long lines and wrong orders.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Thank the taqueria gods for this place! They weren't lying when they said best burritos around! The line gets crazy long no matter the time of day. Highly recommend you get here before 12pm. There are some tables inside and a few outdoor. They also have a live mariachi band that plays as you wait or enjoying your meal. 
The only reason to give it 4 stars is because they have limited choices of meat than usual but this doesn't mean the quality of their food is mediocre. I ordered the carnitas super burrito, no cheese and dorado style (they grill the tortilla). Dorado style burrito is a definite game changer! They're not stingy with their ingredients either. They packed the burrito with guac and meat, etc. Their agua fresca sandia was also bomb! A great combination! 

Definitely glad that I got introduced to this place. It's without a doubt worth the wait. You MUST get your burrito dorado style and you'll never want a regular burrito again! BRAVO!!
author: Jenna T.

description:
La Taqueria has been on my radar for a long while now, after winning the best burrito award from Grantland some years ago. We even passed by and powered on from Farolito to try out the hype. As expected, there's a pretty long line that's almost definitely going to take you 20 minutes to wait on as it goes out the door and winds around the tables inside. However, at the end you're be greeted with a super chill guy at the register who will ring you up. 

We got the carnitas and lengua. At $4.15 a taco it seems pricy, but it comes with two slightly toasted flour tortillas and enough meat for two tacos. The carnitas was good - lean, tasty, and paired well with the beans and fresh tomato salsa. The lengua could've been a little fattier and had some more sauce, but overall decent. Be sure to add some of the green salsa in the bottles around the restaurant to inject a little extra flavor!
author: Will X.

description:
Bring cash, place your order, pay at the cashier, and wait for your number to be called (and have someone secure a table). And don't forget to ask for a side of salsa verde when you order is ready!

La Taqueria has some of the best lengua I've had in the Bay Area. The flavors, texture, and heftiness of their lengua stand out among other restaurants. I order it in a taco with just cilantro and onion and it's delicious! I also enjoy their carnitas tacos supreme style -- it's almost like eating a mini burrito. The carnitas are flavorful and not over fried, which some spots do. I like how their tortillas have a slight crisp to them, which hold up all the taco fillings well. The salsa verde ties everything together nicely. Overall, one of my favorite taco spots in the Mission!
author: Edwina D.

description: Best burrito ever....love that there isn't any rice and a good amount of guacamole.  I've been coming here since I've been a kid and it's been very consistent. Love it! They're crispy super tacos are also amazing, especially with carnitas.
author: Izzy B.

description:
I've recently been on a burrito craze. My friend from SF said this was the best burrito in SF, so I had to try it out. Although I work in SF, I never really venture off anywhere off Market Street. It's located in the Mission, so it's busy. There's plenty of street parking available.

I tend to Yelp places before I go, so that's how I found out about getting your burrito "dorado" style. It's basically grilling the burrito so the tortilla is crisp. Do it. I got the carne asada regular burrito dorado style. It came out less than 10 minutes, despite how busy it was. Maybe I ate the wrong end first, but all the juices came out the burrito. I'm guessing it was from the pico de gallo. I really enjoyed the meat. It had a lot of flavor, tender, and I appreciated the large pieces of meat rather than the diced meat you get at most places. Halfway through the burrito, the tortilla gave up and everything just fell apart. Messy.

Would I call this the best burrito ever? No. Best in SF? I prefer Faralito. It wasn't bad. I ate the whole thing, but it definitely did not wow me as much as I wanted it to.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I was extremely ecstatic when I came to see that this place was open when I came because the first time around it was closed :(. 

The long was extremely long, extending all the way out of the door and was about a 20-25 minute wait. My friend had told me that they had a secret way to make their burritos which was called, apologies ahead for if I spell it wrong but I think it was "dorado style" which is essentially the cooks putting your rolled burrito onto the plancha and searing both sides until it is golden. It kind of reminds me of a quesadilla in a way. 

The wait was for sure worth it. I got a chorizo super burrito dorado style. The burrito was fairly sized and was filling. The flavors were blended extremely well and wasn't too strong in any one aspect.

Will be attempting to come back soon!

Tips: It is a cash only but there is an atm relatively close by.
Maybe this is just me but I thought there were two lines since it was so packed. I thought the people waiting by the cashier was also a line and almost lost my spot. Its ONE line.
The green sauce is pretty dank too, so put that on while you're eating.
author: Timothy D.

description:
Amazing food James beard award winner what can you say. Cash only closed on Monday and Tuesdays.

Best burritos I have had across the country
author: Michael L.

description:
Amazing place!

Came here yesterday during lunch time because a few friends of mine said this place had great burritos compared to other taquerias! the line was pretty long but it was quick.  there is a lady that takes your orders and she writes them down while you wait to pay.  

Got a super chicken burrito and it was BOMB! The whole burrito was really tasty and it was smooth compared to a lot of other burritos.  This place is in the heart of the mission but parking was pretty easy for me... not sure if parking will suck during night time because the mission really never has parking at night when I go.

I would definitely like to come back here to try out the rest of their menu.
author: Ben Z.

description:
Hands down best place to get a burrito. Just have to suffer through the line and cash only. The number of times I've forgotten to get my ticket for them to remember my face to give it to me blows my mind.

Dorado style is what to ask for if you want it grilled. Keep in mind that none of the burritos here come with rice. 

Also note that they take vacation closures during summer and winter! There have been countless times I wanted to visit but they were closed- very important to check ahead of time!!
author: Arezou A.

description:
Try the tacos dorados with cheese. They're best with cabeza or carnitas, but no matter which protein you choose, you'll be happy. 

Don't forget the chips with avocado on the side.
author: Wendy C.

description:
Yeah.... the hype is real! That's all you need to know lol. Seriously... if you want bomb.com Mexican food than check this place out. 

Cash only
Don't park in the loading zone like we did.
author: Nicole G.

description:
5-stars, done deal, lock it in. 3000+ yelp reviews is insane, even in SF.

I'm a big FiveThirtyEight fan, so naturally when I was out visiting for work earlier this year, I had to stop in. As many folks have mentioned, the line can get pretty long, and it is cash-only (but they have an ATM on hand). I came around 9pm on a Saturday night, and waited for less than a half-hour. The line moves pretty quickly.

Order the steak dorado-style if you only have one shot at this place. I was able to find seating outside to enjoy this delicious creation. Brings out a warm, spicy and savory burrito for you to cherish.

I think it's difficult to dub anything the "best" because foods like burritos depend on your preferences... some people like it to fall apart, some want it to stick together. Some like veggies, some don't. Regardless of this, I think anybody that's eaten here can say that the meal was enjoyable. Certainly one of the best burritos I've had, and I recommend it to all of my friends visiting / living in SF now.
author: Alex M.

description:
I'm not a huge burrito fan (yeah, I said it!) so I come here for the tacos. I usually order super carne asada or chicken with a crispy tortilla. One super taco is usually enough for me, but since I'm a fatty and I don't come here often I like to treat myself to two tacos. Both the carne asada and chicken are super flavorful!

Their aguas frescas are also really good. I'm a big fan of their cantaloupe flavor.

I wish the location were larger as it always full and some customers like to linger after they're done eating. Please be courteous to your fellow La Taqueria fans and leave as soon as you're done!
author: Marycruz M.

description:
Best tacos ever!  I drive from
Stockton To eat the best lengua tacos! Great staff , and the young male cashier is super friendly!!  Open Wed- Sunday and cash only.  You can also as for tacos Doradas at no extra charge. !
author: Ruth M.

description:
The line was long, the seating in this place is practically nonexistent, parking was ridiculous (as usual), they only take cash, but the burrito was worth all of it!!!! 

My friends and I came in on a Thursday during lunch hour, so the line was inevitably going to be long. We waited around 30 minutes to get to the front of the line, but all was worth it. The menu isn't extremely extensive, but there must be something you would enjoy on the menu! 

I ordered a carne asada burrito, nice and simple. My friend ordered a carnitas super burrito and my other friend ordered a lengua (beef tongue) taco. Food came out within 10 minutes and you can watch them make the food! 

My burrito was decently sized ($9) and although it was filled with such basic ingredients (pico de gallo, carne asada, and beans) it was probably one of the better burritos I've had in my lifetime. The tortilla was the real winner of this burrito! Super soft and damn, it was just a really fricken good tortilla. I never focus on a tortilla in a burrito, but this tortilla really made this burrito lol! 

My friend's taco was huge! She was able to make it into 2 tacos and it really filled her up. The other friend's burrito was also huge and she loved it! 

Seriously an A1 place, and I can see why the line is so long. Can't wait to return!!
author: Julie N.

description:
I don't want to say all hype but I was expecting a bit more. Super crowded and not a whole lot of seating. If you're a bit claustrophobic you probably don't want to eat here. The line wraps around the whole restaurant. I got the super carnitas burrito dorado style. It was super small and I actually thought they made a regular by mistake. Don't get me wrong it's good but not $13 bucks good. Felt like it was different than other taquerias since they don't put rice in the burritos.

Cash only but have atm inside.
author: James H.

description: Loved how the cheese was melted into the crispy tortilla! The tacos were pretty good but it didn't come dressed
author: Elizabeth G.

description: It's ok.  I got the cabeza regular burrito.  It looks big but it's actually not a lot of food.  The tacos look good though.  I'll probably try that next time if I come.  Lots of people.  Cash only.
author: J W.

description:
Man this place is packed! You normally don't expect much from Mexican food in the bay especially coming from so cal. But la taqueria knocks it out of the park. There's a reason people flock here. High quality fresh made ingredients is the reason. Good food done great. I ordered the super carne asada burrito dorado style. The burrito is filled with asada, beans, pico de Gallo , cheese, guacamole, and sour cream. Dorado style means they toast the burrito to make it crispier. The beans were so good! The meat sliced and grilled to order. I applaud them on a great burrito! One of my favorite spots for sure

Recommendation: super carne asada burrito dorado style
author: Andy N.

description: I think it's worth the wait! The tacos are very good. Very rich flavors and good tortillas. Line was out the door and gets crowded, so be prepared to wait. Also probably have someone scope out a place to sit, seating is limited (especially for large parties). My family and I had to go communal table to be able to sit down.
author: Aidan A.

description: West Coast tacos and burritos...requires a completely separate scale. Even if I give any of the places I hit out in CA 3 stars, it is 3 stars on top of the 5 it automatically gets over any of the "best" East Coast places I have been. With this calibration in mind, the tacos here were great. The line wrapped around the room and out the door along the sidewalk. It was definitely worth it though. We ordered two tacos and a burrito. Many of the other posted reviews mention the burritos, but my vote goes with the tacos being the best of the two. The combination of one soft and one crispy tortilla surprisingly elevates the experience. They are so warm and so fresh. The fruit soda is also a must. I had no idea I was missing those in my life. DELICIOUS! Although, when you walk around "sunny" CT you do not see as much beautiful, fragrant produce in abundance either. Adding to the experience are the long benches and tables at which different groups are spread. Some strangers sharing stories and engaging in friendly conversation, while others just smile knowingly at each other confirming their choice today for lunch was a good one!
author: Kasey B.

description:
Dos:
-Split up the duties: one person find tables, another orders the food
-Dorado Carne Asada Burrito is a MUST!!
-Pour, I mean, POOUURRR the green sauce 

Don'ts:
-Come with no cash. ITS CASH ONLY!!!
author: Ada L.

description:
This place holds a special place in my heart. 

Growing up, my grandma would pile all the kids into her van and we'd venture off to SF for the day. We'd always have lunch at La Tapatia and enjoy it on the grassy hill of the public library across the street. 

So when I flew into SFO from my weekend trip, I knew where I needed to go. 

It was just the way I left it many years ago. La Tapatia never disappoints. Their food is delicious and always on point. I got the super burrito to enjoy at that moment and took home some carnitas and plátanos. 

Gah damn! I love this place so much I can't stop gushing about them. Best burrito I've ever had in my life. 

Don't argue with me about this.
author: Rosa P.

description:
Another solid taco shop in the mission. The portion size for a taco is a little bigger than usual, especially if you go for the enhanced "super" option which adds in sour cream, cheese and avocado, (do it).  I ordered two for dinner and was pretty content with the amount of food. 

TIPS:
-CASH ONLY! They do have an ATM machine there.
-I didn't see any water machines or water cups.
-PS. Use their green sauce. It's bomb.
author: Grace J.

description:
Decent! Me and my buddy ordered beef head burrito on Cinco de Mayo. It was a good choice. Splendid mix of cow brain, cilantro and onions.

The seating options are always a plus at late night establishments like this one. Especially when the line is ~45 minutes long.
author: Jakub S.

description:
*** Cash only ***

ESPN's FiveThirtyEight named La Taqueria super / super dorado carnitas burritos as the America's best burrito in 2014 (https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/americas-best-burrito/) and La Taqueria's carne asada tacos dorados was featured in Food Network's "Top 5 Restaurants" (https://www.foodnetwork.com/shows/top-5-restaurants/episodes/best-tacos). La Taqueria started in March 1973 and this is an EXTREMELY popular taco restaurant. Our group came here at 1:45 PM and waited a total of 30 minutes (waited 15 minutes to pay at cashier counter and waited another 15 minutes to pick up our orders at the counter - talk about a total mad house). Tables are first come, first served and please pay extra attention when the staff call out ordering numbers.

Menu: First of all there is a secret menu, which includes the dorado style (taco with two shells - one soft shell on the outside and one crunchy brown shell on the inside), sirloin ends (supposedly only available about once every one to two weeks), quesaritto (burrito dorado with three cheeses), combination of multiple meats for burrito / taco / quesadilla, chilies (serrano peppers; you can add directly to burrito / taco / quesadilla or ask as a side), and red sauce (aka salsa roja with tomatillos, arbol chilies, spices and garlic; spicier than green sauce). On the regular menu, there are six meat options (beef or carne asada, pork or carnitas, beef head or cabeza, beef tongue or lengua, sausage or chorizo, and chicken or pollo) in the form of taco, burrito, or quesadilla (vegetarian option is also available). You can pay extra $ to upgrade your item from regular to super (cheese + sour cream + avocado) and you also have to make decision on whether you want corn or flour tortilla. Lastly beverages include aguas frescas (strawberry, pineapple watermelon, cantalope, mango, horchata, jamaica aka hibiscus tea, and tamarindo) and beers.

***

Horchata (small, $3.50): Very refreshing and not too sweet - highly recommended.

Super carnitas taco (flour tortilla, $7) and super lengua taco (flour tortilla, $7): I didn't get the dorado style because I only heard about it after I had left. I get it - $7 taco isn't cheap and the "super" style made these taco REALLY messy, but man I would recommend the "super" style because it made these tacos tasted EXTRA good. Oh not to mention that these tacos also tasted juicy and not dry at all!

Super carne asada burrito (aka Mission-style burrito = burrito with no rice; $12.35): Carne asada was made from USDA choice top sirloin steak. I was extremely impressed with its crusty flour tortilla. The melted cheese simply took this burrito to the next level.

Green sauce (you'll find them on most tables): Not too memorable and tasted pretty mediocre.

***

Overall a 4.5-star taco restaurant (knocked a half-star down due to hefty prices, chaotic lines, and not enough tables), but you have to make sure to get the dorado style (must request to the staff), the super style, and rice-less Mission-style burrito in order to make your La Taqueria's experience complete. Without considering how much these tacos / burritos cost, La Taqueria is just as good as the best taco shops in Southern California.
author: Luke L.

description:
I've always wondered why this place was so popular.. I found out why yesterday! 

I came in with babe because he knew I wanted to try out this Taqueria. We got here at 6pm and it was packed! He found a seat right away and I lined up to order. Remember to do this- or else you'll hold your food looking for seats! 

He got the carnitas regular burrito and I got the carne asada super burrito dorado style of course. 

Line moves quick and it's CASH ONLY!!

Babe thought his burrito was standard, but lacked flavor. I thought mine was crust, but not at all. Barely any color and the burrito itself fell apart easily. We both agreed that the burritos here were smaller than other taquerias. 

Why 3 stars? Because I had high expectations prior to my visit. Pricier for a smaller burritos than most taquerias. I'm sure there's other spots around the area.
author: Elaine C.

description:
Came here to meet some friends. Was told that this is the first Taqueria in the neighborhood and I had high expectations based on the line.

The burrito was a total disappointment, it was small, the meat was tasteless and it was made with no care at all. They just slap all the ingredients in to the wrap, roll it and serve it out. 

Completely not sure why this is as busy as it is.
author: Di H.

description:
Can you truly say you've lived in San Francisco if you haven't treated yourself to the tinfoil wrapped, meat packed beauty that is a La Taqueria burrito?

All walks of life in the city converge here, from neighborhood locals looking for a quick dinner with their family, to tech bros who just got dropped off by the latest rideshare and covered in branded swag, to local students looking for cheap eats, to long-term San Franciscans who know what they're about. 

Yes, there will be a long, awkward, snaking line, and you may be hit up several times for money INSIDE the restaurant. No, unless you like the thrill of stalking tables to see if you can squeeze in or grab an open spot, I do not recommend eating here. Yes, bring cash. A lot (not because it's expensive, but because what's better than a second burrito for lunch the next day?).

I'm getting hungry just typing this...excellent meats, sauces, and everything overall.
author: Claire S.

description:
Had there burrito was is pan fried and was really good. I did think it would be better but it was pretty bomb. Not to long of a wait
 Also next to a great bakery
author: kathryn s.

description:
Honestly. 
This place sucks. 
It's not worth the 30 min wait. 
I eat burritos like at least twice a week. I love burritos. 
This burrito is NOT the best burrito. 
If you guys want a GOOD burrito that DOESN'T cost $13 and you still get free chips and guac... hit up Taqueria San Jose in San Rafael. 
Their burritos have flavor... they're bigger than these ones... cheaper and bomb AF. AND they have grilled chicken. 
The only thing about La Taqueria is their hot sauce and their agua frescas. 
Not worth the money and not worth the wait. 
You'd probably have better luck next door with pupusas
author: Taylor C.

description:
The best taqueria in the Mission! I love having the carne asada super burrito. It's sooooo good and juicy. The meat is always perfectly seasoned. 

There was a long line but it went pretty fast. The food came out quickly also. Never get lucky with a table here, so always end up taking my order to-go.
author: Mary R.

description:
Burrito lovers gather 'round! A tour guide claimed La Taqueria had the best burritos ever and I'm not one to deprive myself of good burritos. It was packed and I get the feeling it is at all times of the day but it only took about 15 minutes to order and get our food. There are vegetarian options and the super burrito with carne asada was to die for. The beef was flavorful and juicy as well as the avocado was delicious and fresh. You could taste every component to the burrito and I will be craving another one in the next day. The chicken super burrito was also super tasty although much messier because I think the chicken had more juice. Didn't fall apart or anything just be ready for juice running down your hand.

May I offer you a piece of advice? Scope out the seating situation as you walk in. I was able to find a seat but I can see that being an issue for more than 2 people. If you're anywhere near Mission, go check out these burritos you won't regret it!
author: Cara H.

description: Again. I had higher expectations since it is branded as the best Tequiria in SF and maybe the whole country. It is solid, no doubt! but.....
author: Mohamed A.

description: GET A SUPER CARNE ASADE BURRITO DURADO STYLE. This was a holy experience for me. The crispy burrito exterior couples with the gooey cheesy, meaty inside. OH MY GOD. I love that you can see the whole process of your food because it is so fresh. The line goes by pretty fast. Make sure to get the burrito and some guac/salsa and chips! Ask the cashier for water if you need some because there isnt a self-serve station for water. Also the quesadilla are delicious!!! They stuff it with lots of meat! If you ever are in the area or go to SF this is a MUST.
author: Brenda H.

description:
3 separate strangers recommended La Taqueria to us and it did NOT disappoint. Definitely call ahead and pick up your order, because there are crazy lines. My husband and I both ordered the super carne asada burrito, dorado style. "Super" means it comes with avocado, sour cream, and cheese. "dorado" style just means the burrito is grilled. 
It.
Was.
Awesome.

The meat was tender, the pinto beans were well seasoned, and even the pick de Gallo was great. I hate pico, so this was doubly impressive. Definitely go eat here when in the mission!!
author: Ashley M.

description:
The burrito was good but overpriced for what it was.

Firstly there's a long line since this place was hyped up. It moved quickly and there wasn't a long wait for the food after ordering and playing.

The burritos here don't have rice, and honestly some rice would have done it good. It gets pretty wet without the rice. Getting a super burrito (avo, cheese, and sour cream) was good but I think these toppings should be included in the price considering how expensive it was. The pork itself was good, but the chicken and veggie options left much to be desired.

The size of the burritos surprised us. It was smaller than expected and the size was inconsistent. We had 2 chicken and 1 pork. One of the chickens was larger than the other two. Some consistency would be nice.

Honestly, I wouldn't recommend. There are so many other good burrito places in the mission that are larger/cheaper/tastes better. It's not worth it.
author: Victoria C.

description:
To sum it all up, this place is dank. No other taqueria in the Bay is as good, and is probably why it's won the many awards that it has hung up on its walls. I discovered this overly crowded joint back in 2016 after yoga. Burritos & yoga? Yeah, that should be a thing. 

Anyway, their burritos are fire, I ordered mine crispy so they pan fried it, opted out beans so they ended up giving me more meat without me asking them to (+1). Oh, and I met the owner, he gave me a free strawberry aqua fresca, definitely made my day considering how hot it was and the line was long and the amount of people in there, thanks man! Came back last summer and still delicious, their quesadillas are even better actually and their tacos are fat.

CASH ONLY, so bring ya dolla billz. Seating is a bit of a challange but eventually you'll find an open table, remember to always do a buddy system and have someone order and someone standing around looking for a place to sit, or eat in your car...if you do that.
author: Sabrina N.

description: Best burrito I've had in a long time. Maybe it's because we were starving when we got there or maybe because it's actually the perfect combo of meat, juice, beans, and pico de gallo, but probably both. Another small restaurant busting at its seems because it's so popular. We were probably 20 people deep in the line, but they moved us through like pros. It was fascinating to see the kitchen work like a well-oiled machine.
author: Sam R.

description: I come here often any time I'm on the Bay Area   Not sure why I keep coming back. Maybe because I don't know of anything else. This place always has a long line. Limited seating. If you cluster phobic, don't bother. No privacy. A lot of bumping into one another. Hot....
author: Rolando F.

description:
Been coming here since I was a teenager and ever since.
 I love the food!
 I am glad since my recent visit that they are still in business and the food is still high quality.
This place has been on so many tv shows because the food is that good!
author: C S.

description:
This was the best burrito I've ever had. On a Sunday, there was a daunting line out the store. All benches were full, and the shop was loud, crowded, and bustling. To my surprise, the wait was only 20 minutes. They work fast in the chaos yet craft masterful creations. 

I ordered a super chicken burrito with no beans for $12.35. Order yours dorado style to get a crisped, golden brown flour tortilla. Expect a glorified quesadilla. As soon as I sank my teeth into my bountiful bundle of joy, I was greeted by fresh, zesty, pico de gallo with a hint of cilantro, melty cheese resembling monetary jack, juicy chicken breast that pulled apart with ease, luscious, ripe guacamole, and a swirl of tangy sour cream. All of the ingredients melded together creating full bodied flavor without being too heavy. 

My quest to find the perfect burrito was a success. Consuming this burrito was a privilege and blessing. Tonight, I will dream of La Taqueria, and their heavenly food.
author: Cecily T.

description: One of the first things I had during my last visit to SF and it was so worth it. SF and La Taqueria sure do burritos right!!!!!
author: Cheng X.

description:
The line here can get pretty long and there aren't that many seats, but traffic tends to move through the restaurant pretty well so I was able to find a spot during the wait for my food to come.

I ordered the carne asada burrito, super style which means it came with sour cream, avocado and cheese. And I also got it dorado style, which means they brown the sides of the burrito in a bit of oil.

The burrito was pretty good, but it's not all that spicy even though we asked for it. Instead, if you put the green salsa on top, it has the right amount of spiciness which is great.

At about $12 for the burrito, it was a bit on the pricier side, but I guess this is normal for the Mission district. Overall pretty good and solid execution on most metrics, but not nearly as good as the line would imply.
author: Tyler T.

description:
When a business has over 3,000 reviews you know that it is a legit place to come to for Mexican food.  La Taqueria is a true orginal of the Misison and has been around for decades. There are other options in the Mission, but I prefer coming here.

The times that I come it was really crowded during the lunch and dinner hours, more so when the weather was good.  The line snakes inside making it difficult to maneuver around.  Seating is not reserved and can be difficult to get.  If you come with someone have that person look for seats while you wait in line to order. Seating options are inside or ouside.  

After you place your order, listen to your number to be called.  My to go order is the super burrito.  It is loaded with sour cream, guacamole, cheese, and your choice of meat ( beef, beef head, beef tongue, pork, chicken, and saussage). Note: super burrito = regular burrito with avacodo, sour cream  and cheese added. Although it doesn't look like much,  it is just right amount for me.

This is another cash only only business so make sure to bring cash or stop by the atm.
author: Peter C.

description:
Long lines but it goes pretty quickly. Cash only. It was very crowded during Saturday lunch hour although it had plenty of tables inside and some outside. We got two tacos, beef and beef tongue, as we were going around doing food tour. Definitely worth the short wait! 

Highly recommend! Juicy and fresh meat and toppings!
author: Shelly D.

description: Certainly lives up to the hype - though I'm not sure it justifies the line. More recent visits have been a little more underwhelming but I still recommend it for visitors. El Dorado style all the way.
author: Alex L.

description:
Came at 1pm on a Wednesday and somehow caught a lull when there was no line. Right after we ordered somehow 20 more people came in!

Send 1 person in your group immediately to scout out seats! And you have to be pretty aggressive.. stand awkwardly by a table about to finish. And make sure to ASK THEM if you can have the table next (and how many you are). 

As before - get the EL DORADO! Yes it's very fatty so don't make this a daily thing, but man it's good. They basically fry the burrito in butter to give it a soft chewy layer, with a layer of crips on the outside.

* Chorizo burrito, super (with guac + sour cream), spicy, el dorado - 4.5 stars
Still as amazing. My friend got the same thing and his burrito was much less spicy. Mine was almost too spicy. Just luck of the draw I guess.

* Carne asada burrito, super (guac + sour cream), el dorado - 4 stars
Great quality meat (soft, tender, fresh), but like the carnitas, a little more bland than the chorizo. 

Why don't they have Al Pastor???
author: Ziyan C.

description:
The pork burrito with sour cream , avocado and cheese was very flavorful and filling , will definitely go again next time I'm in the city

Very crowded for a reason
author: Regg C.

description:
All I'm going to say is that this burrito definitely lived up to the hype.

Was looking for good food to try on my visit to SF and the carne asada "el dorado" style burrito came up in 3 different foodie articles so I obvi had to stop and try it.

Between the flavor, the juiciness, the tender beef bites, and the cheesiness, this was everything I had hoped for and more. My only critique was that I shouldn't have asked for it to-go as the foil softened the crispness of the burrito after about 4 minutes of waiting to eat it. 

Know that this place is popular so expect a line around the restaurant and out the door (we stopped by at 1pm on a Friday). But rest assured, they BLAST through this line. It obviously isn't their first rodeo; we were out the door, burrito in hand, within 20 minutes. 

Def a staple for our next SF trip!!
author: Mikkel J.

description: This iconic establishment is famous for a reason! I watched with awe how the meat is freshly cooked in front of your eyes, and the cool generously offer me a piece of freshly cooked carne asada for taste, such hospitality! And get the incomparable guacamole too!
author: Kailin H.

description:
I think many people can be haters when it comes to cuisines of their own culture because we get the home cookin from our abuelitas and we expect that nothing else come close.

I had read about press saying this was the best Burritto in the United States...blah blah blah...(Charlie Brown Noise...) How good could it really be?? 

On social media friends posted about it...but come on now?? How good could it really be? 

Many nights in my younger days we ended up at El Farolito but I never had a desire to go to this spot because it felt ....perhaps b/c of the outside decor... too.. "hipster-ish"  or "touristy" for me.

Well let me tell you ....
This place is pretty LEGIT. 

The burrito's have a very consistent taste from first bite to the last bite which means they've mastered the craft/art of evenly distributing the guac/sour cream/meat throughout the burrito which may seem like it's easy but most places don't do it right. 

The salsa/pico de gallo/ green sauce in bottles is also very very good. 

Finally the tacos are hearty and also very good.

Throw in delicous tacos  and you have an almost 5 star rating. I just couldn't bring myself to do it however...maybe at a date TBD b/c I'm stingy with 5 stars like that...

Any WHY..for heaven's sake don't they carry AL PASTOR??? come on now....that alone should prevent it from having 5 stars.  It is pricey as well for a Taqueria but given increasing costs in the city I get it...


The world needs a San Francisco Taco ranking...so I'm here to provide my humble list/rankings. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top) is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen , Chicken and Waffles as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places.  

Rod's SF Taco Rankings:

1 El Gallo Giro Taco truck
2 Garajito
3 Belmar La Gallinita Meat Market
4 La Corneta
5 Chisme
6 El Norteno Taco Truck
7 Taqueria Los Mayas 
8 Garaje
9 Taqueria Vallarta
10 Little Taqueria
11 La Taqueria
12 Taqueria Castillo
13 El Farolito
14 Pancho Villa Taqueria 
15 Taqueria el Buen Sabor
16 Panuchos
17 Taqueria Gudalajara
18 La Palma Mexicatessen
19 El Tonayense
20 Tropisueno
21 La Espiga de Oro
22 Papito Hayes
23 Tacos San Buena
24 Los Compadres Taco Truck
25 Cochinita Mayan Cuisine
26 El Taco Loco
27 Gordo Taqueria
28 Nick's Crispy Tacos

Below is my top 10 for the Bay Area in case you were curious.
1 El Gallo Giro Taco truck
2 El Jaliciense
3 Taqueria Sinaloa
4 Garajito
5 Belmar La Gallinita Meat Market
6 Belly
7 La Corneta
8 Chisme
9 El Norteno Taco Truck
10 Taqueria Los Mayas
author: Rod M.

description:
It's not good.

It's not drunk good, it's not dinner good, it's not take my homies here good - it's just not good.  The salsa is chopped tomatoes, or a tomatillo vinegar-tasting green liquid (which you have to ask for for take-out, for some reason).

On burritos: Burritos should have rice.  Burritos should also have flavor.

On tacos: Taco-burrito is not a taco.

On the hype: The prices have raised a lot in the last 4 years, like whoa.  

On the quality: The meat is very fresh, which is why the second star.  

On what you're supporting: It's been sued (and lost) for unpaid wages to their staff.

Really though, I should be leaving a 5-star review so the better joints don't get crowded out like this place has.  Please keep coming here.  No better options within literally one square block, actually.  None at all.
author: Noah D.

description:
There isn't much I could say that probably hasn't already been said in a previous review about this place so I will try to keep it short, but I will say that it does live up to the hype! If you are begging for rice in your burrito or would rather have super processed sub par tex-max you can go somewhere else. It's hard to beat walking up to order and seeing the staff bring out fresh meat to grill and smashing batches of fresh guacamole in bowls as big as your torso while a James Beard Award hangs on the wall above you.

I recommend ordering the chips and salsa or if you are a part of the 1%, the chips with salsa and guac to start. Both are super fresh and worth the extra few bucks. Afterwards, order the super burrito with steak and don't skimp for the regular burrito. If you do and are disappointed it is your own fault. Even if it is more expensive than an $8 burrito that is because it is a lot better than an $8 burrito. When the beans and guacamole mix it is magic. The tacos are also very good as well if you are really in the mood, but the staple for me at La Taqueria will always be the burrito. Every time I am in SF, I will make a special trip out of the way to be here for at least one meal.
author: Brian E.

description: When I came on a Saturday night, the restaurant was packed to the brim. The restaurant feels uncomfortably congested and noisy, and keep an eye out for snagging seats while you wait in line. To its credit, the restaurant operates like a well-oiled machine, already separating the ordering and charging parts to optimize efficiency, so the wait was only about 10 minutes from the door. I ordered a super veggie burrito, which was $7, and feels like a steal compared to the other super burritos at over $12. The burrito was delicious, didn't feel lacking in ingredients even though there was no meat, and was the perfect size for one meal. The green sauce they have at every table gives it a spicy kick that I could not stop reaching for. The only thing that would have made me an even happier camper was if they had full plates with sides of beans, sour cream, and rice.
author: Naomi J.

description: Definitely overrated. Line was extremely long and it was difficult to find seating. Tables are the communal picnic tables. We had to sandwich ourselves between two families. Ordered a chicken burrito with avocado, the carne asada and beef tongue tacos. Meat was bland and had no seasoning. The worst type of taco/burrito is one where its meat relies on its neighboring ingredients for flavor. Had to drench my chicken burrito with hot sauce for seasoning. Meat was very tender though! Just bland. You can definitely get cheaper tacos that taste much better
author: Shirley C.

description:
Likely one of the best burrito experiences I've ever had.

I ordered a chicken burrito dorado style with guac. The burritos don't come with rice or lettuce -- no frills, just meat, beans and guac (extra) deliciousness on a grilled tortilla. Think minimalist burrito in the best essential way possible. It was everything I could've wanted in a burrito (save for extra jalapeños, which I didn't know they have apparently!). This meal definitely hit the spot and satisfied my burrito cravings!
author: Camille E.

description: Their carne asada super burrito is my favorite burrito in the entire world. The end.
author: Sara S.

description:
We went on a walk in the mission for this place specifically. We got a chicken taco and a beef burrito. Great food! The taste was very fresh, and unlike any other burrito, I've had. If you love Chipotle or Qdoba just wait until you see this place, they both seem to be like eating from a  garbage can lid in comparison. 

No rice at all but who cares!
author: Robbie P.

description:
Absolutely best tacos ever. I'm Mexican from LA, I've had good authentic tacos before, but nothing beats these tacos.
.
author: Merylin G.

description:
There has always been a lot of hype surrounding la taqueria and they match up to it every single day.  This is definitely one of my favorite Mexican spots in the city.  I've never come here without a line...but they move quickly and your wait time is minimal.  Stand in line, order your food with the staff member going up and down the line or at the register, whichever comes first, pay, grab a number, wait for them to call out your order.  

My usual order?  Super burrito, dorado style.  Most of the time, I get their delicious carne asada but that doesn't stop me from ordering other types of meat.  Is dorado style a must?  I think it's worth the extra moment for them to throw our burrito on the grill.  It's delicious and I absolutely love it.  

The burritos are large and never dry.  Super flavorful.  Don't forget the salsa.  Tacos, dorado style come in at a close 2nd.  This is what our mission area is all about!
author: Jen W.

description: Best burrito I've ever had. Honestly not sure what else to say. The enormous wait time at lunch/dinner speaks for itself.
author: Mateo K.

description:
This was my favorite meal on my first trip to San Fran and to the Mission ... it also was the cheapest.  La Taqueria knocked it out of the park yesterday! My taste buds were on a joy ride!  Everyone bring cash! CASH ONLY! There's also an ATM on the corner and one inside. 

Ordering was fast paced through sort of an assembly line way.  I ordered the super carnitas taco, my husband ordered the super carnitas burrito and we split an order of the chips and salsa. Out of the 3, I can't tell you which i liked the most! The salsa had the perfect amount of cilantro which made the tomatoes pop on the chips. Delicious! Their avocado was also fresh and tasty!

If and when we come back to San Francisco, this is at the top of the list to come back and enjoy again!
author: Margaret H.

description: Great time at Taqueria! Authentic Mexican made quick and fast. Located in walking distance of the 16th Bart Station stop in the Mission. I had a Carne Asada burrito  and it was awesome! This is a must visit spot, especially if you're hungry for Mexican cuisine
author: Rhett B.

description: Easily the best tacos I've ever had in my life, despite being an avid patron of Los Tacos No. 1 in NYC. While many restaurants in The Mission compete for the best taco/burrito title, La Taqueria truly lives up to its name. All of the reviews and awards make perfect sense, once you take your first bite. The carne asada is a must, all flavors blend stunning with the garnishes. They are cash only but it doesn't matter - everything is authentically prepared and delicious.
author: Colleen N.

description: This burrito, which is on the expensive side, was so sloppy and really bland. I had high expectations, but this is just like any other (or worst) burritos.  I had a chicken SuperBurrito, it was so sweet I couldn't finish it.  Use your money elsewhere...
author: Lisbeth H.

description: We got a couple super burritos "grilled" dorado style. They were good. Mine had just a few nice bits of char on the meat and some smoky flavor. They cook large amounts of meat on the flat tops for the large crowd so the amount of char you receive in your carne asada can vary.  Unfortunately, they still put sour cream in my husband's burrito when I specifically requested his burrito without it. I confirmed the no sour cream with the order lady once and the cashier lady once. Overall, it was good but the burrito didn't blow my mind compared to other places. The line was pretty long, but it did move along at an okay pace. It's cash only.
author: Thien H.

description:
Came here with some friends who were very high on it. As is often noted, the line here can be intimidatingly long, but it moves fast and should not discourage you. Don't plan on finding a seat easily though, other than being highly aggressive.  

I got the lengua super burrito (yes I have had lengua before and enjoy it). It was really good, certainly one of the best I've ever had. The meat was very tender and well-seasoned. Other ingredients were abundant, although sometimes a bit concentrated toward the ends. But I can't in good faith give a 5-star review for food that although good, is not unequivocally the best that I've had and that comes at a pricetag up to 3x as much of comparable food. It seems that prices keep going up - they are certainly higher than what you find through Google, and paying $12 for a burrito that isn't the size of my forearm is definitely over the top. Also, if you're high on ethics, which many Bay Area people proclaim to be, you should read the SF Chronicle article from 06/2018 on labour violations at this place.
author: B. G.

description: Decent food lot of cross contamination , being a vegetarian that was a big deal for me.
author: Arjun V.

description:
My first stop on my first trip to San Francisco was down to the Mission District to hit up a couple of burrito spots, the first of which was Taqueria.

My order was a regular carne asada with guacamole. I'm not sure how this gets to claim to be the best burrito spot in any listing.  I appreciate the classic style, the carne asada was great, and the guacamole was delicious, but the beans were ice cold, the size was lightweight, and it was so juicy that it leaked all over my luggage. 

Nate Silver knows politics, but he doesn't have a thing on burritos.
author: Ben C.

description:
I've heard other Yelpers rave about La Taqueria, so I finally had an opportunity this past weekend to check it out.  We were lucky enough to find parking fairly close, so I felt this was a good sign.  The line was fairly long and snaked into the restaurant and in front of the counter.  I liked that there were two ladies taking your order, so all you had to do was give that to the cashier and wait again to hear your order number.  As we were almost about to pay, I gazed down to a mound of Carne Asada that the chef was slicing and dicing.  I felt an urge to reach-over the counter and take a sample, but I didn't want to lose a limb.  

We snagged a table outside, so we waited till our order was called.  As my Carne Asada Dorado burrito lay in front of me, I almost forgot to snap a pic of it.  The meat was really tender and juicy.  My tortilla had a hole in it, so I lost some of my meat, beans and pico de gallo, but have no fear, I scooped it all up and devoured it.  These burrito's don't come with rice, so I did notice the burrito was a bit wetter than others, but that didn't take away from how good it tasted.  After seeing that pile of Carne Asada earlier, I was so happy I didn't choose anything else.  

Yes, the wait is a drag, but I thought the line moved fairly well.  Most of the patrons seemed to know the routine and I was with Tiffz, who has been to La Taqeria multiple times.  It wasn't a large burrito, but I could have been hungry, since it was almost 1:30pm by the time we arrived.  I also wanted to save some room for ice cream that was our next stop.  I really enjoyed my Dorado burrito, since it added a nice crunch to the tortilla.  I'd definitely recommend it.

It's cash only and people do glare at you while you eat.  However, we saw several parties who didn't care about those of us standing and waiting and continued to chat and had their noses stuck in their phones even after they were done eating.  Once we were done, we gave-up our table to another party, but only after we thoroughly enjoyed our meal.
author: Lon H.

description:
Food is great! I got the beef burrito ($9,50 medium) and my husband the super pork burrito ($12,50). It's the second time we come and we loved it. 
 make sure you have time to wait in line... ;) but it's not that bad. Food is delicious!
author: Leila C.

description:
What can I say about this place? It's been on the food network but I've been eating here before the food network blew them up on tv. 
One of the best places to get a good tasty burrito that isn't dry and doesn't have all that fillers. 

My favorite would have to be the super beef burrito which is very moist and tasty. They don't include rice in their burritos so if you're looking for carbs to fill you up with, this won't be the place for you. But if you're here for a  burrito with the marinated beef and fresh guacamole and fresh salsa in your burrito then come down for it quick because majority of the time the line in this burrito shop gets long and packed. 

Hopefully in the near future, the owner will open up another store to alleviate the congestion of his current spot. The line just gets ridiculous in the shop.
author: Lakeen W.

description:
Oh La Taqueria how I miss you, but I don't think we can see each other anymore. You have gotten too popular. When I come at 3PM on a weekday and the line is to the back of the restaurant, curved back to the front doors, and down the side of the place near Dianda's, I don't think there's every a time I can go and not wait less than an hour a hour any more. Your delicious and I want to eat you so bad, but the wait just  isn't worth it when it's that long. Not only that, your prices have gone up quite a bit. Spending over $6 per super taco dorado is a bit crazy.

What to say about the food? obviously it won best burrito in the US for the super burrito dorado with carnitas. The super tacos dorado are amazing. This place is just good, the reviews speak for itself. I could go into detail and go on and on, but lets be real, another raving review isn't going to say you, there's thousands of them.
author: Davide M.

description: Wow!! Quick service and delicious food! The staff is friendly and helpful and the food tastes amazing! El dorado style is a must for the burritos!! YUM!!!!!!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Bitter long time SF citizen here, sad to see changes to one of my favorite spots.

Yah so it's overrun with tech millennials, but I'm used to that now. At least they are tech millennials with good taste, right?

EXCEPT La Taqueria went and changed the food maybe in an attempt to cater to the huge masses which flock here now? Oh my god leave my vegetarian taco with avocado extra alone! It was the perfect food! It was going to be my last meal, washed down with their mandarin agua fresca.

Now not so much. They asked me if I wanted it crispy. I just sort of stared. I want it exactly the way it's been for the last 30 years...no improving perfection. So it came with a floppy raw tortilla stuck onto an over crispy (...uhm, burned-ish) tortilla. I think there's something sort of like this on the menu at Taco Bell. I hate Taco Bell. I'm pretty sure everyone who eats here is like-minded. 

Same taco maker for the last 30 years who has made me thousands of tacos...so I know he wasn't responsible for this sad travesty of a La Taqueria vegetarian taco with avocado. 

AARRGHH!!!  This is not progress!

PS. The jukebox is gone too, so no Los Bukis soundtrack while you're eating


PPS. Now that Zapata is gone (18th and Collingwood) can I suggest they open a new La Taqueria in that spot which could be exactly like the old La Taqueria? Please?
author: El B.

description:
What I got:
Chorizo Super Burrito (Dorado style)

What I thought:
I usually get the carne asada super burrito, but decided to mix it up a bit and try the chorizo this time. It was excellent! (Carne asada is good as well if you're wondering)

Making your burrito "super" adds avocado, sour cream, and I believe pico de gallo. Ask for "Dorado style" and they will pan fry the burrito. So bomb. Makes it so much better.

La taqueria is probably one of my top places to get Mexican food in SF. The burritos here are exceptional. Mest is always fresh and poppin with flavor. The chorizo was a bit greasy and the juices kept dripping from the bottom so make sure it's sealed pretty tight from the bottom so you don't make a mess and end up looking like slob like me.

It gets pretty packed here typically and rarely is there ever no line. Moves really quick though. Not a lot of tables so be on the lookout for anyone that's about to finish their meal and leave. People are vultures here and will snatch those open tables quick!
author: Tony V.

description:
Get the Durago Style - Carne Asada Burrito. I don't like the super, it kinda ruined the taste for me. So what I did was add extra meat and avocado.  Personal preference..

ALSO!!!! - They closed Monday and Tuesday now... Bummer... 

Currently in 7/16/2018
author: Ernest S.

description:
It's not cheap, not by any means. Realize that. Get your burrito dorado style. If you order anything basic and you're disappointed, you're to blame for not knowing what to order. Know that dorado style means that the burrito is grilled, and it is not on the menu. Don't look at the board/wall for verification - order it as if you know what you're doing. 

The burritos do not come with any rice. The basic is meat, beans and cheese. The super comes with sour cream and guacamole. The prices have definitely increased. 

There's always a line, and it's super busy. Cash only. Be patient. 

Also get the pina fresca! Not too sweet and super pineapple flavor!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I'm not entire sure what the hype is with this place. I was desperate for some local Mexican in the Mission and decided to eat at La Taqueria because of the 2000+ Yelp reviews and a nod from a local family member who said this place is as good as any other. Sadly it was a poor decision on my part. 
While the place is absolutely charming and has all the makings of a great, local joint the food fell short for me. 
The ingredients were actually just above average. I believe Chipotle may do a better job and that's not saying much. 
The tacos which get marks for being corn and not flour wound up being  disappointing because they disintegrated in my hands leaving a big mess on the table. 
All in all La Taqueria is a disappointment to me. I guess you can't always trust Yelp even if there are mega loads of good reviews.
author: David S.

description:
Ms.: ordered a flour super quesadilla with no pico de gallo and it was the best quesadilla I ever had!!!! The tortilla was cooked to perfect. A little pricey but worth it. I will definitely be going back again. Keep in mind that it gets really packed and is a little hard to find a table. 

Mr.: I got 3 Regular Tacos; 2 Asada,1 Carnitas (added Guac to all). I also told them "Crispy" when I ordered them. They were double wrapped. The inside tortilla being fried, and the outside being regular. Definitely recommended! The meat was fresh and the food was great. The tacos are really large so 3 filled me up well!
author: Isabel And D.

description:
I wish I never took BART down to Mission District from SFO just to get a burrito from La Taqueria. Not because I barely made it back in time to board my flight, but because I'm leaving SF and don't know when I can get my hands on this beaut next. I'm going to be having dreams about it for days...*sigh*.

I found my way over to La Taqueria around 30 minutes after they opened, and there was already a line (although not out the door like other reviews mentioned). I was debating between a cabeza/carne asada burrito and went with the asada on the recommendation of the lady going down the line writing down orders. Of course I had to try it dorado  style and add avocado.

Due to my time crunch I had to rush back to the BART station and I think that ruined my experience of getting it dorado style. The tortilla wasn't crispy, but nonetheless it was the best damn burrito I've ever tasted. In fact, I was so focused on getting a bite of baeritto that I hopped on the wrong train and didn't notice until I reached the civic center. I used up an entire container of salsa verde on just half my burrito - good thing I asked for two! It leaves your mouth with a delightful tingle and just enhances the whole experience. Also love that LT doesn't put rice in their burritos - who needs that filler when the star of the show is everything but?

Only downside is that this it was ~$11 for a burrito, but I find the quality and the fact that they did not skimp on the meat nor the added avocado makes it #WORTH.
author: Anna R.

description:
Located on Mission and 25th st this place is in the heart of the action. It's always got a line and seems to always be packed no matter the time of day. Don

Things to note: 
-Cash Only (like most things in the Mission)
-Dont just stand around if you see a line, make sure you're in the right one. Some people are waiting to pay, some people are waiting to order, and some people are waiting for their food. Ask and make sure as there isn't exactly an organized system here.
-Not a place that's great for groups because seating is not plentiful and hard to find it seems. if you are with a group make sure someone is staking a table while others are ordering.

I ordered the super burrito with carnitas, and a diet coke for $16. Honestly I was surprised how expensive it was. If could have saved 3 bucks if I wanted to skip the cheese, sour cream and avocado.

How did it fair up? Not amazing.
The Burrito didn't have much texture. It was pork, beans, sour cream, and avocado. Where was the lettuce?? Next time I'll give the tacos and chips/salsa a try, they looked more promising.
author: Alyssa A.

description:
So consistent, it's ridic. Not complaining though, because that's why it's a 5 star in my books!

Came here on 7/23/2017 with a group of 8, post SF Half Marathon (I didn't run it....)! All 8 of us ordered the same things:

-Chips & Salsa
-Super burrito, dorado style, carne asada

That's all you need to know.
author: Hurjane V.

description: So I was in the mission district for only a few hours and figured since I was in the area early I would come here for an early morning taco. I got one taco because I knew I would be having at least a couple more, but I really should have just sat down and enjoyed a whole meal here. It really was the better taco that I had on this trip to the mission district. Nothing flashy, just plain old delicious carne asada, tortilla, cilantro, onions and salsa. It is simply fantastic and worth a visit. The prices are decent and they seem to have a good selection. I'm sure there are times, as indicated in other reviewers photos, that it gets busy, but still worth it.
