There are other "popular" spots nearby where they usually have a line, skip the line and the hype, go here instead.
author: Daniel W.

description: The famed burrito joint. I had the legendary carne asada burrito. It just drizzled with the perfectly melted cheese, guac, beans, and meat. The steamed tortilla makes it all melt together in your mouth perfectly. It's so good you don't even notice the battle for a seat, or the soup nazi style ordering system. Oh the salsa and avocado is a must. Such fresh ingredients and perfect chips
author: Toby F.

description:
Was in town for a couple days close to this place so decided I had to go. First off, it's Cash only, but there is an ATM in the building you can use while waiting in line if you never have cash like I do. 

I got the beef burrito. It was amazing. Be sure to add the green hot sauce they have on the tables - it makes it. I also had the chips and salsa and they were kinda awful. Unsalted chips with not great salsa. Stick to the main dishes here. 

The cons: this place is widely popular and you as a customer will pay for it. Longgg lines (out the door when I went). Took maybe 15 mins to order. Not terrible. But then the wait for the food. It was about 30 minutes of standing room only as people came in and out to grab their food as their number was called. I had no where to be so I was fine with it, but just allow yourself enough time for this. 

Then if you are lucky enough to grab an open spot, you'll have people hovering over and bumping into you while you eat and they wait for their food. Basically I had a crowd watch as I pretty sloppily slammed the delicious burrito. Also they forgot my chips and I had to wait to get those before I left. It needs reorganized but it's one of those community staples that probably will never change because there's really no need for them to Bc people will still come. Gotta respect that. 

Anyway, it's great for food. Like really great. Try to go when it's not so packed (I went at 6:30pm on a Sunday), and it would be perfect. 

All in all, this is a super authentic Mexican place with amazing staff. Go just to say you did.
author: Alex S.

description: My boyfriend and I shared a regular Lengua and Carnitas burrito and it was so good! The meat is moist and flavorful and the burrito is thiccc. When we arrived at the restaurant we saw a line forming outside but that didn't stop us. It was a little confusing though because there's a line to order and then another line to pick up your order... and there's no clear cut distinction of which line is which (we had to ask the people in front of us). The tables were all full and people were standing every which way because there was literally no room to even stand in line... a little chaotic but what wouldn't you do for a burrito?
author: Sylvia L.

description:
Sure, the burritos and tacos here are good enough, but "best burrito in America" might be taking things a bit far. A super chorizo burrito (comes with sour cream, beans, pico de gallo, cheese, and avocado) was super tasty, but also super greasy, so much so that the aftertaste lingered for quite a while. 

Not only are the prices quite super-sized these days, but the lines are often ridiculous here. They wrap around the inside of the venue so that you're hovering over people who are trying to enjoy their meals. I mean, if it feels awkward for me in line, imagine how uncomfortable it must be for those actually sitting there. If anything, you'll have worked up such an appetite by the time you get your food that just about anything will taste good. Maybe that's worth an extra half star or so on the median Yelp rating.

It's certainly not bad stuff. If you live nearby and it's a neighborhood staple for you, then that's great. Not sure if it's really worth a special trek to get here, though, except if you want to chase the hype.
author: Vincent L.

description:
The burrito war in the Mission is real. I suppose it's like Pat's and Geno's (except both of those are really not that great, sorry PhiIy folks) It took me way too long to come here! 

My winner is El Faralito. I believe the burritos and meats are more flavorful. BUT I do want to note that La Taqueria is more expensive and therefore use better quality ingredients and its noticeable. That being said, FOOD IS AMAZING. The super burritos are good portion sizes. 

You are either a rice person or not. TBH, I prefer rice but even without it I didn't miss it. 

I came on a Thursday night around 8pm and it was packed. My co-worker and I waited a solid 45 minutes. We closed out the restaurant after 9pm. 

If you want damn good Mexican food, but for a more hefty price. La Taquiera is your place.'
If you want larger portion sizes, slightly greasier Mexican party in your mouth. El Faralito is the jam. 

Like I've said in my other reviews, we are splitting hairs. Go to the one that's closest when you're hangry!!
author: Priti K.

description: Amazing burrito!!!!  My husband and I got a super burrito with pork and split it.  Was delicious ... beyond delicious!!! Every bite was delightful.  A very simple establishment.  Not much seating.  Have to purchase over $10 worth to use credit/debit cards.  No bathrooms.  Does have a tv.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
As good as it gets in Mission, CA! 

The carne asada burrito was extremely flavorful with loads of meat, beans, and salsa. Unlike Chipotle which fills up their burrito with rice, I loved how many chunks of carne asada came with each bite. I also ordered the Super option, which added cheese, sour cream, and guacamole to the burrito.  The guacamole was the best part adding to the smoothness of the burrito. Make sure to add their spicy sauce on top of every bite. Another plus was my burrito cost at only $13!

It was around 2pm that my family and I visited and the restaurant was still packed with customers. With cozy wooden bench chairs and outdoor seating, La Taqueria was spacious with an open store front concept. It was the perfect late lunch setting on a sunny day! 

I highly recommend trying La Taqueria. If I ever visit San Francisco again, I would love to try one of their tacos!
author: Connie Y.

description:
Super crowded around dinner time but it's worth the trek to the mission for a burrito from here. The order line snakes around the entire interior and out the door. You have to be keeping an eye out for a seat while in line if you plan on eating in.

The carne burrito was a perfect blend of ingredients and the salsa available at the tables had a great kick of flavor to add.
author: Dani T.

description:
HANDS DOWN ONE OF THE BEST BURRITOS I'VE EVER HAD. I ordered the carne asada super burrito dorado style (grilled). I believe they recently increased their prices to account for the increase in ingredient prices, so it costed me $13 for the super burrito. It definitely wasn't the cleanest or cheapest burrito, but man was it good. 

Usually this restaurant comes into conversation with El Farolito being the other in regards to the best burrito in town. However, La Taqueria is like the slightly older more sophisticated brother to El Farolito. It can't stay out as late as its younger brother, El Farolito, but overall its a better establishment. El Farolito will cure you drunchies and the greasiness you desire. 

I went around a weird time (3-4PM) to La Taqueria, and there was a 25+ person line, so I'm assuming there's always a line. I will say the line is worth it, and I'll be coming back when I visit SF again. 


Taste: 5/5 
Bang for buck: 4/5
author: Lander L.

description:
Not being a local, I don't know if my voice actually matters, but I'll lend it to this debate. La Taqueria is da bomb. I haven't sampled enough burrito places to claim that it's ~the best~, but I can see why many argue that is the case.

Came here on a Saturday evening about 30 minutes before close with a couple of friends. I wasn't too hungry, but when you plan to spend an evening out on the town, you still gotta eat. I ordered, of course, a carne asada burrito, which I split with a friend.

If you aren't that hungry and think you can't stomach a whole burrito, this is the way to go. Half a burrito was the perfect amount, and you get the benefit of still being able to eat delicious food!

Seating was rough to come by, so we sat on the counter outside. It's sort of fun to watch them prepare the food, although I think we probably made some of the cooks uncomfortable with the amount we stared...
author: Angela C.

description:
Heard a lot of good things about La Taqueria (especially their burritos) and decided to go here yesterday after getting some drinks at El Techo. 
We got there and the restaurant was packed. The place was packed and the line was almost outside the door so it was a bit intimidating at first but they got in our orders super quick and we got our goods relatively fast! 
We ordered three normal tacos (as opposed to their "super" sized taco ) and I s2g it was one of the biggest tacos I've ever had in my life. We ordered the carne asada, chorizo, and carnitas and they were all delicious. They were stuffed with meat, beans, salsa, etcetc and it was just a great overall experience. 

IG factor: C+ for food and F for please don't take up space trying to take your perfect picture because people want to sit down and eat asap.
author: Yuuki O.

description:
I came to the Mission District on a mission for the best mission burrito.  Amazed by the amount of choices of options in mexican food restaurants, we decided to go to La Taqueria.  It was packed on Saturday when we came.  You want to bring cash as they only take cash only.  There is an ATM located inside the place if you forget your cash.  The line moves pretty quick and seating can be limited during busy times.  

As for the burrito, it is about is good as it gets.  I had a carne aside super burrito.  I loved the taste of the guacamole and sour cream along with all the other ingredients.   I would recommend getting the super version of their burrito (adds guac + sour cream)  It cost you about 12 dollars (yikes) vs 9 dollars for regular burrito, but it is worth it if you want a great tasting mission burrito.  One thing I wish I would have done was have the flour tortilla pressed (toasted)  I believe you have to request this option as my burrito did not come pressed.  

My only other suggestion would be to get an aqua fresca, we had a cantaloupe aqua fresca and it was good.  This is a place where if you're looking for a good place to get a mission burrito, I would recommend this place.
author: Garett S.

description:
Is there a lot of competition? Yes. Are there ridiculously long lines? You bet. Is it kinda expensive? Definitely. 

So why is it still 4.5 stars? Because even with the fierce completion, long lines and CASH ONLY expensive options, La Taqueria is just that good. It's definitely one of the best burritos in San Francisco and the surrounding area. They don't do rice burritos and use avocado rather than guac. 

On weekends, the line wraps around and even though it moves fast, you can easily spend 30minutes or more in it. Seating is tough, too. I wouldn't recommend coming with large groups if you plan on eating there. That being said, I've waited in those lines and even with all the cons, this place is the bomb! 

Can't say I would go out of my way to go but it is definitely a worthy stop for anyone in the area.
author: Mario B.

description:
Simply delicious burrito! Most of my burritos are eaten at 1 am after a night of drinking so the fact that this is delicious while sober is huge.

Carne asada burrito is a must, get it super(cheese, guacamole, sour cream) and Dorado style(grilled) because treat yo self! Love that there's minimal filler-no rice and just a small amount of beans. Wish there was slightly more meat but it would probably not fold up as well. 

Line wraps down the block and in the restaurant. If you can snag an outdoor seat, you're lucky. Otherwise ambiance is not as great but fine for inhaling your burrito in silence and then leaving quickly. 

Wait was around an hour, definitely not a quick in and out place. Don't be the a hole that parks their car in the middle of Mission St to grab a burrito and then locks their keys in their car. Seriously what is wrong with people! Although it was pretty entertaining to watch them get cussed at.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Hands down the best and cheapest food to get in San Francisco. It's fresh and served quickly. Usually there is a long line so be prepared to wait for a table but it's totally worth it. I've had both their tacos and burritos and they are recommended. Big restaurant. They have a lot of space. The cleanliness isn't great but it can be blinded with such great food.
author: Julia J.

description:
Memorable burritos, fast service, and super long line. 

I feel like locals appreciate this place, yet at the same time believe it's overrated. That being said, this is one of the first spots I visited when I moved to SF, and I still remember what that first burrito tasted like - it was one of the best burritos I had up to that time. Their meat is juicy and has great flavor. The avocado is ripened to perfection. And to wrap it all up, they are consistently very very good.

Wish they had an option for rice, and would like to have a different ordering system to accommodate for the long lines.
author: Michelle B.

description: I came here today, on a rainy day, thinking there would be no waiting line, but it was just as busy as a sunny day, that's how popular this place is. I just love watching the man making the tacos, he's super efficient and generous with his spoon. My friend and I each ordered two super tacos and they were pretty good, but ladies and gentlemen with smaller tummies, you can totally get away with ordering one super tacos, they are pretty big. I think they get super busy in the kitchen that they forgot to salt their guacamole, because it looked great, but guacamole needs salt. Two older men came in and sang and played their guitars, their voices rich, their faces kind, and their music a joy to hear, they are singing for their supper. And Trump says Mexico sends us their worst, what a sad president we have.
author: Andrea Y.

description: The BEST Authentic Mexican. Food place in the mission - I asked from what state, turns out b Jalisco.  If you'd u want fr st Mexican food - RUN TO THIS PLACE
author: Andy M.

description:
This place has been awarded the James Beard Award among many other accolades! Trust me, you have to be pretty damn good to get this high honor. 

We visit family in San Fran from central Cali, and when we do this is a must go to place to visit. 

Only thing that stinks is finding parking in the Mission District, but eventually you will. 

Second thing that thinks is coming in and battling the crowds in this place, ordering and finding a place to sit. 

But once your number is called and  your food arrives, you ll see it was all worth it!!!!

Simply AMAZING!!!! Everything, I mean everything is fresh. 

This is a must come too place for great tacos and burritos! It's worth the initial headache at first.
author: RJ V.

description: I love their burritos and tacos! Their carne asada beef has a great smoky flavor. There's no rice in the burrito but that's how I like it. The emphasis is on the yummy meats and beans. Definite must to stop by here when in SF!
author: Rissa K.

description:
Cash only, vegetarian options, crazy busy! The line moves pretty quickly despite the size of the crowd. We were in line outside of the restaurant initially at about 30 minutes before closing on Labor Day but we were able to order and get our food within about 30 minutes. I had the vegetarian taco and the vegetarian burrito. I would order both again. The food seemed really fresh and it was flavorful. I didn't have any of the stereotypical symptoms you would expect after eating beans. 
We ordered our food to go. The taco was really messy but sooo good I didn't care.
author: Nicole F.

description:
The burritos were tasty, but they have shrunk in size and increased in price significantly. 

The wait times aren't too bad but there will always be a line. The line wraps around the seats so you'll most likely have a waiting customers butt in your face as your seated to your meal

Service was adequate. Limited seating means you're hounded by people eyeing your table as you eat. 

A lot of compromises for a smallish burrito
author: RJ H.

description: After reading all of the stellar reviews, we tried the burritos tonight...they were so incredibly salty, they were practically inedible...made us regret not going to our usual places, La Corneta and Taco de los Altos...
author: Joan S.

description: I've been coming here since 1980! Best ingredients, best guacamole, best beans no rice & that is what I think is the difference between other wants to bez absolutely delicious & because it's extremely fresh "" they use quality meats " it's shows every time you take a bite !! Bomb!!
author: Sean K.

description: I don't know how they do it, but the turn the simplest ingredients into a super yummy burrito. I would go this route or with a taco or quesadilla. Chips and guacamole are average so go ahead and skip them if you're trying to decide.
author: Laura K.

description:
I visited this place while in town. I am originally from Houston Texas and when I was told of this "taqueria" that I "must try" while in SF I figured it would be worth the trip. 
I was very disappointed to say the least. Perhaps it was all the hype and I had imagined something more fantastic.
This place is definitely a hole in the wall. Bring cash as this the only form of payment they accept. The prices are $$$ compared to what taqueria's are usually priced. The food is a solid OK. 
This may be the best damn taco you can get in the Bay Area but definitely not the best taco I have had. Very average at best.
author: AZadeh A.

description: There is only one thing you need to order. The carnitas tacos extra crispy with guac and green sauce. Never have tacos been so good! Each bite better than the one before.. Sweet baby Jesus these are the best tacos evahhhh! You may be distracted by the heaps of mouth watering carne asada on the grill.. not a bad choice either..  but oh my the carnitas...  I just can't...
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Our local go-to restaurant when we are craving really yummy burritos and tacos for the past decade+. Although it's changed with the increase of popularity and now slightly smaller burritos, it is still very very satisfying and their quality hasn't changed. 

Carnitas and Carne Asada are so good and fresh! Their lengua is always very tender and fresh. 

The order/ 
Carne asada or carnitas burrito
Lengua tacos, only with cilantro and onions 
If we are want some sweet, a strawberry agua fresca. 

Oh so good. Usually there is a wait but if you go when they open then it's shorter. If there is a wait, someone takes your order, writes it down, then you continue to pay, and then you get a number for your order. Either grab a seat at a smaller table or long table and enjoy the smells and atmosphere. 

Sometimes we can see the flats of strawberries being delivered or them cutting it. Or avocados which is really nice to see. 

As long as the quality stays the same, we will continue to enjoy their food for years to come. 

Of all the Mexican restaurants out in the city, it's our favorite and to us, is the best. 

Tip: cash only 
Tip2: metered parking near by or off street non-metered
author: Amanda C.

description: Please be entirely specific and check your to go order before you leave. The food tasted great once I picked all the pick/salsa off it. The hard shell tacos get soggy after a while so I was happy to have a fork to finish it off.
author: Tashawa W.

description:
Maybe you're like me, and you read the 538 Burrito Bracket. You scoffed at the method as being totally ridiculous and not rigorous. You knew it was a sham. Then, you were super-proud and vindicated as a Bay Area local to see that yeah, the best burritos are here. You have been eating Bay Area burritos for a long time and have your favorite local hole-in-the-wall. You don't know any Spanish, but you know what all of the meats are. And you have had so many burritos but actually never QUITE got around to La Taqueria. How much better can it be? It's probably just like every other burrito you have had since you live in the land of great burritos.

Well, yeah, it really can be that much better. You should really try it.

After I got over the excitement that comes with any sated hunger, I ate the rest of my Carne Asada super burrito. A lot of burritos would be fine unrolled and turned into a rice bowl. This burrito was juicy and well-blended throughout into delicious bites through. And although it was on the small side, it wasn't full of filler and well-worth the experience.

The others in my group got the chorizo burrito and a quesadilla, both of which also looked delicious. And a lot of people were ordering tacos with a soft corn tortilla and a freshly fried tortilla, so that's gotta be good, too.
author: Kevin L.

description: We stepped in to this place and were immediately overwhelmed. It's packed and there's so much noise. After maneuvering through the chaos, we sat down at a shared table and got our burritos. It was so so good. I had an asada super burrito. It had those burnt pieces that make carne asada so good, and the sour cream was amazing. It was somewhat smaller than i was hoping. And it's quite expensive ($12). But it was GOOD. The salsa was also delicious.
author: Doug M.

description: Good wholesome burrito. Had the beef super. Decent size. Beans n all. Quick dinner fix
author: Jeremy K.

description:
Good value. Good food. 

Small, concise menu, just what you need and nothing more. The burritos didn't stay warm too long but still tasted good. I really liked my chicken taco and their salsa is delicious. 

Fast service. Long wait for a table if you come during a rush.
author: Katy F.

description:
The best burrito of my life, I think. I was depressed halfway through knowing I might not be in San Francisco to experience this burrito again for a while. I got a super burrito with carnitas (no sour cream), and it was just perfect -- the tortilla, the meat, the avocado, the perfect amount of spiciness... I was blown away. If I have any regrets, it's that I didn't also get to try one dorado style -- next time.

The chips and salsa were good as well, although next time I'd want to try the guac.
author: Shawn H.

description: Finally checked out this place after seeing many articles labeling it a must try! I love mexican food and could eat a burrito everyday. This place did not disappoint on flavor. Got the carne asada burrito. The meat was tender and the guacamole was delicious. The only downfall...at the end of my burrito, I found a hair in it. Needless to say it ruined the experience, and lost my appetite as soon as that happened.
author: Melissa Z.

description: My boyfriend and I were visiting a friend in the area and she insisted that we try this local restaurant. When we got there, it was busy, but we had quick service. I ate the Veggie Burrito and it was amazing. I wish I could have fit two in my stomach! My friend ordered the Quesadilla and my boyfriend had a Carne Asada Burritto. All three food items that we had were excellent.
author: Hannah C.

description:
Had the grilled carnitas super burrito. Good flavor, not superb. Super small super burrito, disappointing. Over priced at $13. More like a $8 or $9 burrito. For $13, I except a super burrito to be super. 
-1 Star for portion size. 
-1 Star for being overpriced.
author: BD C.

description:
I was so, so, so, SOOOOOOO excited when I finally got to try this place!! I'd read an article about how La Taqueria was in the running for the title of America's best burrito, and I wanted to see if it was really as good as people made it out to be. The line was very, very, verrryyyyyyy long. But that wasn't enough to scare me away. I stood for a while, and finally, I was where they took your order. When I got my order receipt to turn in and got to the front to pay, I saw a "CASH ONLY" sign and was overcome with sadness because I only had card on me...I walked out disappointed, and as I crossed the street, I saw a Chase bank!! I immediately took $10 out and ran back to La Taqueria, turned in my order receipt, and eagerly waited for my food

I ordered a vegetarian super burrito dorado style. The difference between the regular and the super is that the super comes with everything in the regular (meat if you got a meat burrito, beans that are whole refried or pinto, and pico de gallo), as well as sour cream, cheese, and avocado). The regular vegetarian burrito just comes with whole beans, cheese, and fresh salsa

HOLY MOLE. This burrito. Amazing is an understatement. I come from SoCal, where there is pretty good Mexican food, but omg. So much flavor in one floury pillow. And I don't think it was just because I was super hungry...I think I was such a huge fan because they don't add rice to their burritos, and usually, the rice kinda takes away from it all

Bottom line: Amaaazing burrito! Best burrito I've had in SF. Seating may be difficult to find (they have indoor and outdoor). Don't let the long line scare you. Pro tip: ask for your order "DORADO STYLE" (they put your order on a grill and brown it). The GREEN SAUCE is really good (get it!!), but if you want more of a kick, ask the workers for RED SAUCE! CASH ONLY!! Don't make the same mistake I did. Now I need to go try El Farolito and see if it lives up to its hype too!
author: Kithumini J.

description: The lengua was really tender, the carne Asada was really flavorful but $12.50 for a burrito???  Also, the line of 20 minutes is crazy.
author: Patricia N.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots in all of SF - there, I said it!  Yes, sometimes it's loud and chaotic, sometimes I'm asked for change by a homeless gentleman while waiting in line, and sometimes I don't have enough cash in my wallet to buy everything my heart desires - but it's always worth it when they call my number.  

La Taqueria is so so so darn good.  Is it the best burrito in SF?...in the state?....in the world?  I can't answer those questions.  What I can say is their carne asada is amazing, their guacamole is always fresh, their food is consistently great, and I'm a sucker for their strawberry aqua fresca.  

Tips for La Taqueria:  When ordering a burrito, always ask for it to be grilled (you need to ask), Tacos can be cooked extra crispy (though this is not my jam), and you have no business ordering the corn quesadilla, it's tiny and not worth the ~$2 they charge - go flour or don't order anything.  Oh, and the strawberry aqua fresca tastes like you're drinking a strawberry flavored fresh fruit popsicle - it's amazing!  Just make sure they add some crushed ice so the pulp can blend amongst the ice.  

Overall, this is a must try if you're a tourist or resident of San Francisco - you're not likely to find a better taco or burrito in the city (perhaps CA)...after all, La Taqueria earned a 2017 James Beard Foundation 'American Classic' award for a reason!
author: Tom G.

description:
$17 for two tacos and a drink...what a racket! Adding that to the long line, long wait, and not enough seats...it would be okay if they were worth it but I wouldn't go through all of it again for the tacos. They weren't greasy and they were relatively big for tacos, but they were pretty bland. I got two different kinds of meat and they were almost interchangeable. I preferred the carnitas slightly more because it felt like it had the tiniest bit of flavor, while the steak felt like it had none.

Watermelon Agua Fresca was pretty decent, but if there are other places around that have frescas then I'm not going to wait in line at this one!
author: Diana W.

description:
HOLY OH MY GOODNESS. BEST BURRITO EVER. Or should I say Baerrito?!? 

BOMBDOTCOM THE SUPER BURRITO IS A MUST TRY.

I decided to take my friend who was visiting me from Santa Cruz to this fine establishment, and we both enjoyed it so much. 

I loved how there was no rice in the burrito, so my tastebuds could focus more on the way the pico de gallo and guac blended with the beef. Everything was just so magical. 

The line can get especially long during peak hours, so tread with caution!
author: Tiffany H.

description: Super busy at lunchtime. Hopping vibe and was so excited to order my burrito supposed to be best in US. Oh well it was ok but not spicy enough or tasty enough for me. Washed it down with a Pacifica. Maybe I should have tried the tacos instead.
author: Mark J.

description:
Cheap and tasty Mexican food!

A friend and I stopped by from dinner around 7pm, and this place was bustling. The line starts from the inside and moves towards the street as you order. You're given a slip of paper that you bring to the register, you pay, and then wait for your order to be called.

We were lucky enough to snag some seats. I "supered" my burrito, and got a heaping pile of chips and salsa to share. Everything was pretty good and I really appreciated the lady that was walking around wiping tables and setting chairs back in place.

Overall, super efficient and fast place to get Mexican food (possibly to go if you can't find seating). There's bike parking right outside the taqueria!
author: Gina L.

description:
My friend is from the Mission, SF area and we were craving burritos, so she put me on to this place. It was my first time, and it smelled so good from the outside. There was a long line to place your order and to pay, it was also lunch time. I ordered a carne asada super burrito which came with rice, beans, cheese, salsa, and avocado. I opted out on the avocado though... Usually I like my burritos with refried beans, but this place only had whole. The burrito was cheap, and even though I ate it later on once me and friend got to the park, it was worth the wait in the line. 

Whoever is in the area and/or lives by this place, be sure to stop by and check out their food. Almost everyone I know has been to this taqueria and it has never failed them either!
author: Adrianna T.

description:
Pre-Yelp, this spot was the spot.  Post-Yelp, this spot is still the spot.  

Not sure if it was the weather or Taco Tuesday but everyone and their mama was here.  Once you approach the entrance, don't be fooled by the line.  Keep walking inside and make your way towards the back next to the prep area as that is where the line actually starts.  And don't forget to thank the person letting you know that the line by the door is actually people waiting for their food, you're welcome.  

Taco w/ Carne Asada - the meat was bland
Super Taco with Carnitas - mouthful of flavored crispy meat topped with a heaping amount of sour cream and guac
Small Cheese quesadilla - Bueno
Quesadilla - not sure what kind of quesadilla my friend ordered but the crispies on the tortilla elevated the quesadilla to 10 to 11.  I like plain cheese quesadillas but this is definitely a winner

Be aggressive when it comes to seating.  CASH ONLY
author: Linda N.

description:
If I had to describe my experience at La Taqueria for y'all, it would have to be: FIVE MINUTES OF ECSTASY THAT YOU WOULD BE WILLING TO WAIT MUCH LONG FOR.

When I moved up to the Bay Area for college, one goal that I had in mind was to find the very best places for Mexican food. After discovering amazing food trucks like Tacos Autlense and Tacos Sinoloa in Albany and Oakland that had orgasmic tacos and holy sanctuaries like El Farolitos that had the creme de la creme of quesadillas, the only place left for me to uncover was the absolute best place to go to for a burrito. 

It may have been that I was hooked on El Farolitos and their quesadillas, or that I was too loyal to burritos in San Diego, but I never took the opportunity to go to La Taqueria. And boy did I regret that decision. Immediately after numerous sources pointed to this gem as the world's best burrito shop, I decided to pay this San Francisco taqueria a visit.

For those of you who are not familiar with the Mission District, this is the LIFE blood of San Francisco - in my opinion. The Mission has all things food, culture, and life in the city. But mind you, it also has horrendous parking. So if you are coming here, I advise walking, or get ready to spend an hour finding parking... as well as another hour for food. But we'll get there.

I guess I came at the worst possible time on the Sunday after Cino De Mayo, but the line was WAYYYY out the door when we got there. If you don't want to wait, I recommend either coming on a weekday or just ordering togo. It pretty much took us an hour and a half to get to the front of the life. Luckily though, they have a nice system going where you order before you pay and once you find a seat (if you do find one), your food will come out pretty quickly. So on a bad day, I'd say you wait an hour and a half to pay, then wait another maybe 10 minutes before food comes out?

If you think I'm crazy to wait that long. You're right. I'm crazy ABOUT FOOD. Because damn, this burrito WAS AMAZING! I can guarantee that it was magnificent not because we were hella hungry (which we were), but because of several defining features of this burrito.

1. The steak was perfectly cooked. I could tell because, as I was waiting in line, I saw how juicy that meat looked. I wanted it in my tummy and in my tummy it went. I recommend getting carne asada x100. It was crunchy, juicy, and delicious.

2. The portion of ingredients is spectacular. This place does not skip on anything. My burrito had a healthy portion of steak, beans, sauce, guac, and salsa. 

3. The green sauce on the side is a must. If you love spicy food you will love their green sauce. In my opinion, it's not hot, but it adds an extra layer of juice that will make an amazing burrito x100 amazing. 

4. The best part about this burrito is honestly that it doesn't go beyond what it is: a burrito. There's nothing extra in here that will overpower the taste and the sauces aren't overflowing to the point where your hands get wet. And for most people, it's big enough to satisfy your hunger, but not massive to the point of heart burn. 

The only regrets I had about this glorious burrito was that I didn't get it El Dorado Style (meaning it's extra fried I believe?). And that I didn't eat it slower. To be honest, I don't think I've ever eaten a burrito this fast before- a testament to how good it was. 

Overall, I have to say that La Taqueria is definitely one for the record books. Personally, I've had a lot of good burritos in my life, and theirs is clearly one of the best I've had. In terms of carne asada burritos, this was probably THE BEST. The only con was that the size could have been bigger. If you are really hungry, you can probably eat 2 regular sized burritos. And the price is on the higher end for its size ($10 for super, $12 for El Dorado). 

But despite the massive wait time, I will definitely come back. Not just for the food but for how gregarious and awesome the owner was. You may have seen him virtually through Eater's video on La Taqueria (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ajcJTpIh44o), but I recommend talking to him. He is so generous and sweet. For example, he will hand out roses to all the ladies (and men ahem). And if you are nice, he might even undercharge you (sometimes). For the burrito and for the friendly culture at La Taqueria, you get an experience of a lifetime. This hype is worth it, for I have to give this place an "Omg, I'd wait two hours for this," BECAUSE I DID. AND IT WAS WORTH.

Eat well and prosper friends,
author: Bryan W.

description: Tacos are good and they are generous with the meet. Place is really crowded because the food is really good. Staff is friendly and they keep up with the cleanliness of the business. I recommend this place if you're in San Francisco looking for a taco.
author: Jorge A.

description:
My second time here.. 
I love the Burito here it has the distinct taste of freshness.. we order super steak burito and boy it did not disappoint! everything taste fresh you can really tell! 
if u come here make sure to try their fresca especially the cantaloupe   watermelon is second and 3rd fave is horchata!
author: Prinxez L.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of burritos (I prefer rice bowls) but this place has changed my mind. This place is known for their burritos and specifically without rice!
When we arrived, there was a line out the door. We waited about 30 minutes to finally place our orders. To be fair, the workers were working really FAST. It was evident but there were just so many customers and orders.
I ordered the Super Carne Asada Burrito. It was phenomenal. I was skeptical of the lack of rice but it actually was even better. The burrito is filled with your choice of meat, beans, pico de gallo, as well as guacamole, sour cream, and cheese (which makes it a "super").
The tortilla was grilled perfectly! It was crispy yet soft and nothing leaked out of these massive burritos.
It was amazing! My only regret is not getting another one but that just means I will be back!
author: Aya E.

description:
Ay caramba! Burrito here is outta this world!

During my SF trip, we met some strangers who told us "you guys need to try the Mission burrito before you leave SF." So we did.

Things to note:
-Cash only
-Line is cray cray, especially on weekends
-Seating is limited. Good to have your friend save you a seat while waiting in line!
-Wear elastic pants

We ordered the burrito with carne asada...WOW. Burrito came packed with guac, pinto beans and meat. It was the best burrito I ever had. It blew my mind that I forgot to take a pic of it. I literally had a dream about it that night too (woke up drooling). 

Must visit in San Francisco!
author: Manami S.

description:
I've been eating here for decades. I admit their carnitas burrito is amazing and I find myself craving it a lot. Having said that, it's totally overpriced now and at the same time as the size has decreased. You have tons of other (almost) equally as good choices nearby. 

Additionally, they're so busy that they don't pay attention to the cleanliness anymore. If you find a seat, you need to bus your own table. Staff is overworked and management is sadly in it for one thing these days: money!
author: Sandy G.

description:
Super tasty Mexican food! The wait was long around lunch time (about 50 minutes around 1 p.m.) but so worth it! It was the best Mexican food I've ever had. 
The place is tight and not very clean, however the people are friendly.
author: Ece K.

description:
The best super tacos. Honestly have never had them better anywhere else.

Not even Mexico. These are the bees knees.
author: Gonzalo M.

description:
This place had a line out the door when we arrived, which was annoying, but a sign of how good the food is. The line moved very quickly, and even though the seating was packed, we managed to snag a table for three.

First off, the quesadilla on flour tortilla is amazing!! A must try. The crisp, buttery outer layer and gooey cheese were fa perfect combo.

The portions are generous, especially for the price. I had a burrito with carnitas. So much delicious meat inside of a flour tortilla.

The chips were freshly made with a huge pile of pico de gallo on top.
author: Ariana R.

description:
No, no, no! For a few years now, I've passed this spot on Mission street. Always saying 'I want to try that place one day'. There's usually a line on the weekends, so I assumed this meant the food was worth getting. Pulease!

Truly it takes a special kind of person to to ruin a taco. But this place did it on an epic scale. Look at the photo of my taco for proof. The tortilla is literally disintegrating! There was no way for me to eat my taco is the usual fashion, without everything inside falling out. To make matters worse, I'd ordered a super vegetarian taco. Which meant that it was supposed to include avocado and cheese along with the salsa and beans. No avocado, a smidge of cheese. Their chips taste like oil, as in way to much used. Whatever tomatoes are used in their salsa are flavorless, I might as well have put water on my overly oiled chips. 

Now I know to keep on walking when I see this joint on Mission street. Wish I'd known beforehand.
author: Jaylena P.

description: Very good tacos only thing the line is out to street I was their at 230 pm I was hoping it was a dead time  but was out to street  good service and food is great
author: Frank S.

description:
You can find better pollo asado (La Corneta), and you can find better Al Pastor (because they don't serve it), but you'll be hard pressed to find a more delicious carne asada taco than here at La Taqueria. There's almost always a line out the door during peak hours at this traditional taco spot and for good reason. The flavors are fresh and well seasoned without being overly salty and the tamatillo salsa is aggressively spiced but bursting with awesome acidic punch. 

Also worth noting is the tacos are MASSIVE. I'm usually a three Taco and chips kinda guy, but here two tacos will do you just find. Part of that is the generous portion of meat, and part of it is the inclusion of beans, which you don't see too often in tacos. 

It's cash only, so come prepared, and have yourself a wonderful fantastically authentic mouthful of Mexico.
author: Sean S.

description:
La Taqueria has been on my radar since forever ago, and I'm embarrassed it took me this long to finally try it out.

My friend and I came after work on a Thursday around 5:30, and the wait wasn't too bad, maybe just 10-15 minutes. I've never been here before, but my friend said it was the shortest line he's ever seen here, so this seems to be a good time to visit.

I wasn't too hungry, but I had to order their carne asada burrito as that's what they're known for. As with other taquerias, you order at the counter and then find a seat and wait for them to call your number. It's not a big restaurant so there isn't a ton of seating, but luckily my friend and I grabbed the last table inside.

I was super excited to try my burrito, but a couple bites in I was already kind of disappointed. For one thing, for the price you pay it's actually a pretty small burrito. I've gotten burritos at many other taquerias that were not only cheaper but also bigger. But that can be excused if the burrito itself is bomb. However....this burrito was not. I was okay with the lack of rice in the burrito since that's what La Taqueria is known for, but I did NOT like how wet and soggy it was inside. I found myself having to suck up the extra liquid from the burrito on multiple occasions because it was getting to be too much.

I'm glad I finally got to try this place out once, but I don't think I'll be back.
author: Dianna H.

description:
TLDR: Place is hella hyped but i don't get it

Had a burrito from this place and had 3 bites before saying wth am I eating. It's not bad per say but not a good burrito either. Was soggy and falling apart, with not well flavored asada neither. The line is impossibly long and like idk. just a tourist trap i feel.

do yourself a favor and go around the corner to el faralito.
author: Samraaj B.

description:
45 minutes in line and I was able to get my hands on my food. Finally. When my boyfriend mentioned he saw this on tv the owner gave him the strawberry Fresca and chips and salsa for free. We ordered a carne asap burrito. Two carne asada tacos and a quesadilla  carne asada. With a large pineapple fresca. Everything was so good and the portions were huge. I was only able to finish my Taco and took my quesadilla home. My bf ate half his burrito and the taco. This place was featured on the food network channel and that's why I took the trip out to try it myself. I love trying new food and this was definitely worth my $43 and the 45 minute wait!
Will be coming back in the future.
author: Emily L.

description: I'm so confused why this place has such great reviews.  My boyfriend and I are huge fans of Mexican food and we sampled every type of meat taco offered here and couldnt even finish our meal we were so disappointed.  We are from NYC and try out the Mexican food everywhere we travel to. The meat is very under seasoned and is overwhelmed by the taste of oil.  It tasted a bit burned but it might just have been that it was drenched in poor quality oil.  I left feeling full and nauseous after only tasting tacos. $45 wasted.
author: Nicole L.

description: I had the carnitas tacos and the chips with avocado and salsa. It was delicious and the service was really fast. The portions were pretty big for the value and tasty.
author: Traci S.

description: Stopped here and got a super Burrito and a super taco. This place is totally worth it. Make sure you get the fried burrito. Its not really fried but baked or else the tortilla seems a bit raw. I give this place a 95/100.
author: Manuel A.

description: Too many hype over nothing that special. The carne asada doesn't have much taste. The super burrito is smothered with sour cream which masks everything else. The carnitas burrito is same thing.  Lessen the sour cream so we can taste the meat.  The burrito is also soggy.  The line is too long. You got people in line watching you eat. It's annoying.  Also cash only place. Doesn't accept credit cards. Kinda shady.
author: Adam L.

description:
We show up to this place on Saturday night about an hour before they close thinking the wait shouldn't be too bad. Well I guess by this places standards it wasn't. The line was just slightly out the door instead of down the street. The first thing I noticed was everyone there was probably between 21-35 years old. Very young hipster crowed, which is not always a bad sign but in my experience, when it comes to Mexican food, you want a little more diversity in the customers, otherwise it's likely more hype then substance. 

So we wait...when you get close enough to the register they take orders while you're in line so when you get to the register you just pay for your food. It's a good system. The employees here HUSTLE! They are movin', chopping and wrapping they have a great system. They're just small and the amount of people that come here is insane. Its just a little hole in the wall with maybe 10, two people tables and three larger community tables. If you're vigilant you should be able to snag a seat somewhere either inside or outside. As far as parking...I mean it's the mission so parking is not impossible but you're gunna need a little parking karma to get a spot close by. 

Now for the food! Is this the best burrito in the world?????? Nah, but it's good. It's just not wait in line for 35-45 minutes and wait another 20 for your food good. 

The good: The meat is delicious! The burrito is well mixed so you get a bite of all the goodies inside every time. The ingredients taste very fresh even at the end of the night which is a huge win I think. 

The meh: No rice :( 
The burrito is on the smaller side. Not tiny but for my husband it fell a little short (lol)
The tortilla was really soft...like taco bell bean burrito soft. I like my tortilla with a little more of a bite. They do have a grilled burrito option which might help with this. 
Finally the line. The wait is just not worth it. I would try it once to say you went but i would not wait in that line again for a burrito that I could get at another equally as good spot. If you go, know la taqueria has been hyped up to the max.

Happy Munching!
author: Talia D.

description:
If you're in San Francisco in search of amazing Mexican food, look no further than La Taqueria. I ordered the Carnitas Burrito - make it Super and El Dorado style; you'll thank me later - and it was delicioso. The carnitas were simmered to perfection and the salsa verde (you'll find these at every table) gave it the perfect punch that didn't take away from the flavor of the burrito. 

The only problem I had is that the establishment is rather small and usually busy so leave your extended family at home.
author: Brenda A.

description:
Home to one of best burritos in SF not sure what or who gave them that rating. Several awards on the walls state best in bay, multiple awards stating zagat rated( mind you if it says zagat rated I sadly laugh because zagat recently rated KFC best fried chicken in the nation!!! Thats a big wtf???? Lol) so let me break down what was sampled, and how it faired to some other taqueria's I have visited over the years.

If this is your go to for fresh authentic mexican food, sure i'll bite and say it is good; but not best in the bay! So this is what I ordered, the super burrito with carne asada /carnitas (steak&pork). So the meat carne asada is good fresh made daily you literally see them cutting chunks of fresh beef and sectioning them into the trays to be provided for your order, same is to say about the chicken. The carne asada was tender, juicy, but for me lacked seasoning(salt) which is ok, just add green sauce for a kick and it is well worth it, the carnitas in my burrito was close to none, maybe one bite and half diced pork was in that bite so I can't comment on how good the pork was. If your looking for flavor and a good mesh of rice, guac, sour cream, pico de gallo, rice and beans this place serves it up quick but again not as good as some other spots

Wife tried two super carne asada tacos which came with crunchy tortilla, slice of cheese, meat, pico de gallo and sour cream, she did say taco wife it was good but not I have to go back good haha

My son ordered the chips and guac, the chips he was happy with but the guac he stated had no taste. He's only 7yrs old so that says allot haha

For best burrito in the bay, again sadly don't know how they got this rating, quick, fast, good after club or after drinking sure definite place to hit up, but for a meal without inebriation probably not the best you've had

Burrito's *** yep sadly hard 3
Tacos ***.5 good; but not if not in the area not gonna drive out of the way to get
Price $$
Service **** very helpful staff
Ambiance *** narrow seating meant for small groups or just couples, one large table in the back all other tables are small for 2 people or squeeze 4 people
author: Clarence A.

description:
As a first time visitor to the SF area... everyone recommended us to visit here. It didn't disappoint.
The service. The atmosphere. The food.
Everything is amazing here.
We were able to speak to Michael (owner). It is obvious when you see this man that he loves doing what he does.
He gave my friend and I a mango drink to try and roses. The drink tasted like real mangos. If I'd known, I would've tried other drinks too.
I had the regular tacos and my friend had the beef head and tongue. Everything was delicious, especially the beef head !! The meat is so soft and so many toppings !
author: Sung H.

description:
This place is really good to be honest, the only problem is the location is really small and get crowded inside with basically no place to sit and people pushing each other. 
Tip.. just order and leave
author: Uknow U.

description: This place was recommended by a local. We went on a Sunday at about 3pm and the place was packed. There was a line going out the door but it moved very quickly. The menu is small, but everything is delicious!  If you are looking for great food, casual style, and good prices then this is the place for you. If you love tacos you won't be disappointed.
author: Marla G.

description:
La Taqueria is a Mission classic. For me, it's the up there in the top burritos I've ever had. 
You got to go with the classic carne asada super burrito and chips and salsa. Major cravings!

Personally I prefer when the burrito is grilled on the outside which La Taqueria does not do. If you're looking for the grilled tortilla I would check out El Farolito which is right down the street.
author: Sam A.

description:
This was a disappointing and strange visit. This was our first lunch in SanFran and it was a few blocks from where we were staying.
We ordered the Carne Asada burritos and I also ordered a chorizo taco. They have an interesting system of placing your order and then calling out numbers deli style. 
They said chorizo taco after a few minutes and I said I ordered one, and they said it wasn't mine. Fine. Our burritos came out five minutes later, and still no taco yet that chorizo taco was still waiting there. After another five minutes, they asked what I was waiting for and I said a chorizo taco. He then said oh ok well take this, and I said no way. I asked ten minutes ago if I should take it, you said no, and then want me to take this old one? I asked for a new one to be made and I get a disgusted look. 
I wasn't even a fan of the chorizo taco, because it comes with a glob of sour cream which was too much. Burrito was nice flavored, but I would never come back.
author: Nick D.

description:
Ah, La Taqueria. What else is there to say that others have not? It is absolutely amazing. 

I always order a super carnes burrito dorado style. The steak is always fresh and they chop it up right in front of you. I recommend ordering chips and salsa with your meal as well. I would skip on the side of avocado for your chips, because it's not guacamole, just chopped up avocado.

The lines are usually super long and it can be difficult to find seating, but people use dine pretty quickly and leave, so you should be able to snag a seat! If you need some quick and tasty, definitely visit La Taqueria.
author: Mallory L.

description: Came here while visiting San Francisco, the line is long but it goes pretty quick...by the time you to get the front someone will probably get up. I had the vegetarian burrito and all I can say is amazingggg!! The burrito is extremely filling and flavorful plus the sauce gives it the kick. I would recommend this place as a must try if you're in San Francisco.
author: Chan K.

description:
A friend recommended this as one of the oldest and destination spots in mission district to have tacos/mexican food.  And she was right!

The chicken had an amazing smokey flavor to it, like nothing I've had in the past. After i devoured my taco, I wanted to go back for more but they had closed down for the night! Arghhhh. 

This place definitely lives up to its name and will be there for a long time to come.
author: Christine J.

description: La taqueria on mission one of the best taqueria in San Francisco . Great food love it !!
author: Juan J.

description: i was introduced the juicy "super" carne asada burrito last year and i fell in love with it ever since. i revisited this place a few days ago, and i made a mistake by ordering a "regular" carne asada. the "regular" burrito does not include the amazing avocado and sour cream. nonetheless, the "regular" burrito was still juicy and delicious! this place only accepts cash and they seem to always have a line. i was able to beat the lunch rush by a minute or two; the line to order was wrapped inside the restaurant and out.
author: Allison C.

description:
Amazing burritos. Carne saus was flavored well and allowed to shine. Carnita burrito was super moist and flavorful. 

The owner was there and super friendly. Gave my wife (and every woman there) a rose.
author: Christopher O.

description:
I've been coming to La Taqueria since the taquero with the gold chain (Miguel) wore his hair in a pump.  That's way back in the days.  The food was always consistently delicious.  The meats seasoned, cooked, and chopped to perfection.  The tacos and burritos always put together with care.  Customer service was a joy, especially when Don Jara was at the register. He gave out flowers to the pretty girls and greeted everyone with much respect.  In the past few years business has obviously boomed.  It can get super crowded with out-the-door lines.  Unfortunately,  long lines of customers means the taqueros have to move faster and when they move faster meats are not cooked, chopped, or arranged the same.  Sadly, it's lost some of its quality and it's been hit and miss. 
 
I haven't given up on La Taqueria, but porfavor Don Jara, que regrese la calidad y el cuidado con que hacian la comida antes.  

PROS: 
Good food*
Friendly customer service
Diandas is next door
Get to see peoples cute dogs

CONS
*Food is hit and miss
Can get really crowded 
Parking hard to find
Not open Monday and Tuesday
Have to walk around peoples cute dogs
author: Manuel C.

description:
I have to preface this review by admitting that I am an incorrigible Mexican food snob. As the native San Diegan that I am, I have exacting standards for what constitutes really good Mexican food. 

I went to La Taqueria on a recent, sunny Saturday afternoon--mistake #1. The place was packed to the gills. I understand that it always is, but a nice Saturday in the Mission wasn't doing us any favors in the line department. I ordered a carnitas burrito especial (aka The Works) dorado style (meaning that the tortilla is grilled on the plancha). 

The meat was really tender and flavorful without being overly fatty and greasy as so many carnitas are. The other fillings were forgettable and the tortilla was standard at best. My date ordered a steak burrito, and again the meat was clearly good quality, but everything else about it was kind of whatever. I did order a mango agua fresca, which was the highlight of my meal. 

Overall, if you're from somewhere that doesn't have the luxury of good Mexican food, you're going to love La Taqueria and think I'm insane. For those of us who know what truly great American-Mexican food is, though, this place is pretty overhyped.
author: Adrienne K.

description:
Don't be fooled by the long wait line. We especially asked someone else for cash (and obv. venmoed them!) just so that we could enjoy the best mexican food in Mission! Futile effort I would say! 

Dint enjoy the mexican flavors at all. The corn quesadilla had no flavor, burrito was okayish. The aqua frescas were great and the cashier was sweet enough to help us in deciding with the order- so a 3 star! 

Try La Corneta instead!
author: Parnika B.

description: I can honestly say this was the best burrito I've ever had in my life. If you take really great individual ingredients like a juicy tender steak, fresh yet rich avocado, and great hearty but not overwhelming beans and then mash them all together of course you're going to have a hit on your hands. The burrito was so good I closed my eyes and leaned my head back as I took each bite. The burrito was so good I opened my eyes and I felt like I was in a bad dream when I saw that my burrito experience was over. I got the burrito durado (I think it's spelled like that) style, and it made the outside of the burrito nice and crisp which really added another layer of depth to the experience. I also ordered a small cantaloupe agua Fresca, and I was expecting water with a slight cantaloupe after taste, but when I took a sip I was transported to a new cantaloupe universe. I was on a planet made of cantaloupe floating on a cantaloupe river on a cantaloupe slice gondola. The flavor was so pure and delicious it was the perfect compliment to the ultimate burrito. Great experience and great food. My only regret is I didn't order more.
author: Andrew H.

description:
The line can be long and parking can be tough -- but it's all worth it. 
This is some high quality Mexican food. 
Outstanding flavors. 
Super good.
author: Ran D.

description: I came here for lunch on a Wednesday. The line and the wait was about 30 minutes so be prepared. They move fast it's just a lot of people. I had a super carnita burrito. The flavors were great. I was shying away from the pork but asked for a recommendation and that's what the staff told me and I was very pleased when I tasted that nicely seasoned pork . My only complaint is I got beans although I said no means. Welp that's just the casualty of going to a popular place during lunch. I would eat here again.
author: Tramaine W.

description:
Super disappointed.... 
I went there on a week end, it was busy so I waited in line ( it wasn't too long! ) 
We managed to got a table! Yay 
But..... the burrito itself... it wasn't that good, not much flavor. The worst was that it was super runny ( from their salsa? And beans?) and messy to eat... 

I will not go back!
author: Laure D.

description:
La Taqueria? 

More like La Overhyperia, La Tonteria, La Tragedia. 
La, la, la like La La Land winning best picture at the Oscars. Not!

Sorry San Francisco, but your Mexican food is nothing compared to Los Angeles or even LOL, Mexico.

No way Jose. 

Overpriced and overrated, La Taqueria is Mexican food done que lastima wrong. It's as if all the glowing reviews are by people that think Jack-in-the-Box tacos and Taco Bell chalupas are the real deal. SMH. 

Honestly, all the rave reviews appear to be more often than not by gringos that have never had tacos in East LA or TJ. Zagat dares to even call them "true original" and "traditional". Whatevs because Zagat suxorz.

Sure, my vitriol would have been tamed a bit had La Taqueria not been so "hella" overhyped. But a nearly $4 taco with factory-made tortillas that jumps to $6+ when you add sour cream, guacamole, and pico de gallo is ridiculous. Just the presence of sour cream is the sign of sell-out Mexican food.

Both the carnitas and carne asada lacked flavor. Even the taco meat at the carniceria section of my local supermercado tastes better. It's as if the meat was deliberately under-seasoned so you would have to pay more for the guac and pico. Also the carnitas was dryer than Chapelle Show's Tyrone Biggums' cotton mouth. Sidenote: Go check out Chapelle on his two-part Netflix special!

Alas, I should've known better when I saw their full-of-themselves neon sign that proclaimed themselves as the best tacos and burritos in the whole world. That's right, whole world. What a [insert profanity] joke.

From my experiences, when people or businesses have to tell you that they are the best, they usually are far from it.  

On top of their high prices, La Taqueria is cash only. Not comfortable carrying so much cash around the Mission since 4 tacos cost me nearly $30...

In my opinion, La Taqueria is a total Meh-xi-can't restaurant.
author: Richard K.

description: If you're going to get a taco or burrito in San Francisco, I highly recommend this place. It is cash only but this place has the best beef tongue I've had. The beef tongue taco was super moist and was fresh. I actually saw them cut the recently cooked beef tongue in front of me. A lot of people who have had it may have experienced dry beef tongue but I'm telling yall this beef tongue is bomb. The cuts are big so its super yummy.
author: Anna D.

description:
I came here around 3pm on a Sunday for a late lunch, and I was taken aback by how busy La Taqueria was. But hey, why wouldn't it be busy since its claim to fame is the "Best Burrito in America?" I liked that the turnaround rate for orders was lightning speed, but you have to do the awkward table stalking for the next available seat. 

As for the "Best Burrito in America," yeah... well, it's way too overhyped. The carne asada had a nice flavor to it when I could taste it, but I could hardly distinguish it from the blandness of the entire burrito. I had to use the green house sauce with every bite to add some type of flavor to it. Furthermore, the burrito is messy as hell (dripping all over the place) because of the refried bean juices.

I had the side of chips, pico de gallo, and avocado. I liked the chips. They were crispy and tasted like they were made in-house. The pico de gallo and avocado tasted super fresh as well. The avocado especially tasted made-to-order as if someone had just literally scooped out an avocado and mashed it right then and there. Would have been nice if the pico de gallo and avocado had some salt, however. Since these components were also part of my burrito, they definitely attributed to the overall blandness of it.
author: Katrina C.

description:
What a disappointment. 

Honestly, I came in to La Taq with high expectations based on hype from friends, Yelp, as well as Eater's review video. Unfortunately, everything about the experience was mediocre, starting with the food and moving to the customer service. 

I had a super carintas burrito with chips and guac. The burrito was nothing special at all, and dare I say, that I've had better at the big nationwide Mexican food chain stores. The meat was decent, cheese wasnt special, and the tortilla was soggy. 

Overall, if you want good Mexican food in SF, there are at least 3-4 other spots that are much more deserving of your hard earned cash. I might label this in my tourist trap folder.
author: Patrick P.

description: Awesome.  I ordered the super burrito with carne Asada.  Just ridiculously good.  No seats, so be prepared to fight for seats and 30 minute wait....so worth it
author: Chris C.

description:
In my experience, if you see a place that's packed and with a line coming out the door, it's usually really good and worth the wait. 

That is certainly the case here. It's not just a taqueria. It's LA TAQUERIA. 

A taco will never be the same again. Order a Crispy Taco (not on the menu) 
It's a fried tortilla with melted cheese and a soft tortilla on top with heaps of meat, beans, sour cream, fresh avocado and salsa. 

It's CASH ONLY and the communal tables are first come first serve. 
ATM inside and CHASE is across the street. 

For dessert, walk to 
Dianda's: Italian Bakery 
Mission Pie
King's Bakery
author: Mitzi G.

description: Was it a good burrito and taco?  Yes.  Was it worth $7 per taco and up to $12.35 for a burrito?  Not really.  A regular is just meat, beans, and pico so would definitely need some of that green sauce to give it more flavor if you go this route.  To make it a super (not in size) with the addition of cheese, sour cream, and avocado, it is almost $3 more each item which seemed like highway robbery for what should already be included with these prices.  I can understand a surcharge for avocado/guac but cheese and sour cream is pretty basic especially for a burrito.
author: Joyce Z.

description: I got here right at 11am on a Saturday when they opened and was able to snatch a table. I ordered a regular burrito with beef and pinto beans. The burrito doesn't include rice and is actually on the smaller side compared to a lot of jumbo ones you see nowadays, but the flavor is amazing! I honestly think the best part is the Pico de Gallo; the tomatoes taste so good! The tomatoes do turn watery though, so be careful of any drips. Prices are steep (~$9.50 pre-tax for a regular burrito with no add-ons), but what can you do, La Taqueria is in a prime location next to the Bart station and is now a try-before-you-die spot for tourists and locals too. Other than that, I'd say La Taqueria is a standard burrito/taco/quesadilla joint with a simple menu that gets customers in and out in no time.
author: Winnie Y.

description:
They don't call Mission District Little Mexico for no reason!

This was one of my first ever Mexican food place in San Francisco, and OH MY GOODNESS, do I have high expectations after this. Going in on a weekend for lunch, this place had lines OUT THE DOOR. Quick services, with a little amount of tables, you have to use your eagle instincts and scout out which group of people are about to leave before you sit on the chairs.

We got a regular pork (carnitas) burrito for $8.50 and a chicken taco for $4. If you're able to get seats, get it for here, cause burritos can get pretty messy! The wraps weren't wrapped super tightly, but the "SPECIAL SAUCE" that the meat is made with just makes all the delicious goodness come all together. Especially when it's mixed with beans, tomatoes and all these things that I usually don't eat, I'm surprised of how good it can be.

In addition to this all, La Taqueria has won several awards - as you will probably be able to see if all plastered across the walls of the store!
author: Kristy N.

description:
Yeah. 
A well earned rep. 

The food was speedy, filling, and delicious. I love that they didn't cheap out and gave you two tortillas. That was a great touch. 

I ordered two of the super carne asada tacos, with avocado. The meat was perfectly cooked, but could have been a little more seasoned. The flavor was a bit meh. I saw there was onion in it, but maybe they were counting on the pico de gallo to jazz it up? (I'm not a pico fan.)

They went nutz with my avocado though. An incredibly generous portion. Definitely helped. But you still need tasty meat every day of the week!

At two tacos I was stuffed to the gills and filled with regret. I should have stopped at one. 

My other half had the burrito, he's had better in Tucson & L.A.  But for the Bay Area, you can't miss.
author: Lea S.

description:
The tacos I found here would change the way I would think about a taco. I now judge all tacos by what was sampled on that day. I walked in expecting a quick in-and-out taco, with it being such a gamey neighborhood. The guys behind the plancha are working. I don't mean they're at work - I mean they are building dreams with hammers and anvils.

The food looks so simple, and the process looks so remedial. Pile of chop meat. Mix Pico. Crunchy taco inside flour tortilla. No beans. No bullshit. Hands down the best, most flavorful taco I have ever had. I bought a chicken and a beef; I don't know their names, I just said chicken and beef. I also asked for a cup of their tomatillo verde sauce - mind twice blown. The sauce was like the spicy soul of a tomatillo mixed with the sweet blend of a Jalapeño - with some magic in between. I nearly would fly back to San Fransisco just to get a few more right now. The meat tastes strongly like meat, no adulterants. The pico was the most powerful garden salsa I've ever had on a taco. And the Verde just finished me off. 

The parking is horrible, so I jumped from the car and my lady drove around the block a few times. We ate like thieves in some parking lot down the street, but it was revolutionary. This is real Mexican food, in every since of that moniker - so be ready for everything that comes with that phrase. I also really appreciated the open-air style seating arrangement. Hands down, the best taco I've ever had in the United States thus far.
author: Matthew C.

description: Amazing tacos and excellent service! I should have spent all of my time in San Francisco eating through the Mission District. I ordered the regular pollo, carne asada and chorizo tacos and I can't pick which one was my favorite.
author: Chris M.

description:
Kinda like Chipotle, without the rice, but cost more.
So, I was in SF for a couple days and decide to try the famous burrito.  Since I came during a weekday, the line wasn't super long.  It did get crowded, but it moves quickly because they have a good system of someone taking the order and then you go pay (cash only)
I tried the regular burrito with carnitas, which I think was a little bit overpriced at $10.33 (with tax).  The carnitas was a little bit too salty and had to use the salsa (which was good!) to make it better.  I was totally underwhelmed.

I might willing to try again because I didn't know about the "dorado" style until I was reading the other reviews just now - they should've mentioned this in their menu!
author: Dian K.

description: I have to come here on every SF trip I take just for the super carnitas taco with no beans and sandia agua frescas.Don't forget to put the green sauce they have on the table tops all over the taco.
author: Christine J.

description:
I ordered a beef taco with a side of guac, and it was super filling for dinner! The guacamole was amazing and seemed very fresh. I downed my taco in a few seconds, and I think the ensuing heartburn was worth it. 

There was a huge crowd inside Sunday evening, and a guitar/singer playing in the restaurant. Super fun experience!
author: Rosey L.

description:
Definitely a step up from Chipotle. At 1:30, the line extended around the room and out the entrance. We waited for a while in line and ended up seeing another classmate too, which goes to show the centrality of the restaurant.

The lady who took our order recommended getting pork. So I ordered a pork burrito. My friend got that too, but with grilled tortilla. Definitely recommend that as a move - it adds much more texture and warmth. 

The burrito was rich with pork flavor and didn't prove too salty. It had some liquid, but wasn't too messy to eat. A nice meal to eat with friends at Dolores Park!
author: Nathan C.

description:
Had carne asada super burrito. 

Pros:
* Good amount of guacamole in the burrito

Cons:
* $13 for a small "super burrito" -- half the size El Farrolito burrito, 75% of Poncho Villa burrito size
* Lack of rice in the burrito makes it very flimsy
* Long line constantly

Verdict:
Not worth it. So meh! Paid 33-50% markup from regular super burritos and honestly did not taste any improvement in quality of ingredients. Thought lack of rice was a detriment to the burrito experience.
author: Katherine Y.

description: I came here for lunch one day because I heard the mission district was the place to come to for a good burrito, and they were very right! I got a steak burrito that was filled to the brim with steak, rice, beans, guacamole, and cheese. It comes with a side of chips and was overall very filling!
author: Carly S.

description:
This place had been very hyped up to me before my first experience. I had been told by some that it was bar none, the best burrito in the city. Having lived and eaten quite a few burritos in the mission, I guess I had a certain expectation of what constituted a burrito in this neighbourhood. 

The al pastor was tasty, but it wasn't enough to redeem the whole burrito. The actual burrito itself was small. Might be a little hyperbolic, but it felt like half the size of other mission burritos but cost about 1.5x. There is what feels like a lack of seating, but most busy taqerias suffer from this same issue so I'm not docking any points for that. 

I guess what I'm saying is that the burrito was just an okay experience and I'd probably try the other shops in the area first.
author: Rajeev S.

description:
Best and freshest carne asada I've ever had. Enough said! 

Long line and wait times for food on a Sunday, 15 minutes in line and about 20-25 minutes for food so plan for that, have your friend hunt for a table while you wait in line to order, you'll be lucky to get one. so many tourists here! 

You have to come to mission when you're in SF, so much good food here!!
author: Tony D.

description: Tried the vegetarian burrito with beans, salsa and cheese. Huge portion size, cheese was delicious! Went at 2.30pm and it was really crowded
author: Wan Qing Z.

description:
This was a pretty good burrito, but not one that I would say is the greatest burrito I have ever had.  More than anything else, I'm not certain Nate Silver knows what a great burrito tastes like. 

I mean the burrito was good.  I had the carnitas, in line with "The Best Burrito in America".  It didn't jump out at me with any sort of amazing flavors or anything that made it better than other burritos I've had.  

So the burrito was fine.  Was it oversold by Nate Silver?  Yes, yes it was.  But it was fine.  

Side note: Cash only, so make sure you bring $ or you're going to the ATM in there.
author: John L.

description: One of the best burritos I've ever had. Chicken Super Burrito, the chicken was tender, white meat, so much flavor. The verde sauce is a great addition and adds some spice, too.
author: Bryan S.

description:
We still love this place! 
seriously, they're always consistent and as good as ever.
I never had a bad meal here.
although it's not my number one choice.  
but if I have to take a first time visitor to get a Mission style Burrito, this place is a safe bet because of their consistency.
author: Rudy H.

description:
Good "for norcal." Decent tacos and burritos, but much more expensive than I'm used to seeing in LA. Like 2x more expensive. That being said, I don't know the going rates for Mexican food in the area. 

Super burrito has significantly more guacamole than southern variants of the super.
author: Ricky L.

description:
Phenomenal. I go here whenever I'm in SF.  Get the pig face or lengua tacos with the crispy shell.  It's a little expensive (~$7+ a taco) but they load it up.  I ate three tacos the last time I went, but I was rolling out.  Be prepared for a long line, but it goes pretty fast.  If you go before noon, you should be golden.  

Pair it with a strawberry agua fresca and its perfection.
author: Peter G.

description:
There was a long line when we arrived with a big group on a Saturday afternoon. Line moves quickly and they take cash only.
The burritos were huge and delicious. So are the Tacos and salsas and chips!
Definitely worth the line and wait!
author: Melissa T.

description:
This restaurant is deserving of all the accolades and the recent James Beard award. Delicious fresh Mexican food! 
We arrived on a Sunday at 4pm with a bit of a wait. The staff is quick and accommodating to everyone. The patrons are mostly locals and we felt like one big family!
author: Madelaine K.

description: I've been here twice while living in the SF area. The first time I ordered the beef head tacos with a cantaloupe juice. SO GOOD! Now I rarely eat meat but I'm not gonna lie, if someone gave me one I'd happily accept it.   Recently I tried the chicken taco and it was pretty good. The chicken was slightly dry for my liking and I totally regretted not ordering it with guac so I added the green sauce but it was SO spicy. Luckily I had a juice (some random type I forgot the name of) to counteract the spice. Honestly, after that experience I don't feel the need to go back, especially as a plant-leaning eater. I do love the up-beat atmosphere and the older man who played music on the guitar inside.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Riceless burritos ftw! I always ask for little to no rice in my burritos but La Taqueria doesn't put rice in any of their burritos. Perfect for me but sucks for others who want the filler.

The food here is amazing! All the ingredients that go into the burrito are quality ingredients. The carne asada was delicious and the guacamole was fresh and thick (unlike some places that serve water-y guacamole). 

The service was fast. Lines may look long but move fairly quickly. One person takes your order and you pay with another employee. By the time I sat down, our order was called shortly. Speaking of seating, there are plenty of tables and benches to sit at. Because it's fast food, most people leave by the time you are ready to sit.

*CASH ONLY*
author: Love K.

description: This is a must-stop for anyone in the SF area. I went on a Saturday night and the area was BOOMING. The place was packed with a line out the door, but I moved pretty quickly. The burritos were great!! The pork was delicious, fresh, juicy. This puts chipotle to shame!!! Make sure you ask them to grill your burrito.
author: Chanelle H.

description:
We stopped at this spot on our food tour throughout SF and it did not disappoint!
