The lines were incredibly line and easily took over 40 minutes just to get a burrito to-go but... OMG, it was amazing! One of the best burritos I've ever had in my life (and I've tried many burritos)! Months later, my friends and I still talk about how great this place was.

Definitely check it out if you're in the area! I'd recommend calling ahead with your order in mind if you can though. Also, good luck finding a spot to sit at to enjoy your meal because the place was jam-packed and the line was way out the door!
author: Heather N.

description:
Visited this place for lunch on a Wednesday. 

My order - Vegetarian super taco

Service - Pretty fast

Taste - Worst- It the taco had meat flavor may be because the grill had meat also cooking. As a vegetarian, I could not take the meat smell. 
The taco had beans, cheese, avocado, cream, and salsa nothing extraordinary.

Vegetarians and Vegans out there - please avoid this place. This mainly caters to meat eaters. I got fooled by Yelp's 4 star 3000+ reviews. Disappointed. Beware!

Ambiance - Strong meat smell. Super crowded with people pushing you in all directions when you place an order and wait for your number to be called to pick up. 

Cost - ~$6 for a tasteless meat flavoured taco.
author: Dee S.

description:
How, how, how, how in the world is this place a one $ for a burrito? It's $13 for a burrito, are you serious? For a quesadilla is $6. Wtf. Chipotle is bigger, tastier, and just overall a better value. Good lord. 

I've been to Mexico, Spain, South America. The burrito is a joke. The taste is so boring and nothing special. The taco is $7.50 and it's tiny. Just make your own burrito and tacos. Yikes. 

Aside from the boring taste where I had to add cilantro myself to make the fish taste better, the paper they put the burrito, taco and chicken on is so cheap the paper will come with your food as you eat and basically you're eating paper and your food at the same time. What a scary suggestion from my wife's coworker. Terrible.

Look elsewhere.
author: Kyle M.

description:
Pretty pricey but very delicious burritos and tacos. My super taco cost almost $7! That's almost enough to get me a Chipotle burrito. That said, it was decent size and fairly filling. 

We came around 3:30 pm on a Sunday and it was still quite a wait. I don't think I'd come out of the way to return but would mind stopping by again if I'm in the area. I'd also definitely go with the burrito next time.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Amazing tacos and you pay the price for them $$$$!

We pay $7 for a taco when in Georgia they are $2.50. However, we do have to admit these are better. 

The place is ONLY CASH and seating is limited. 

Bathrooms are dirty and need some serious attention.
author: Leandra D.

description: I had the carne asada quesadilla... and it was amazing. The flour tortilla was cooked to perfection... a light crunch. We got in during a perfect time. As we sat down, we soon realized how popular this place really was. They were able to get the line moving pretty fast though and even though there weren't a lot of tables, they were always cleaned up right after someone else. They were on it. Great service and even more amazing food!! HIGHLY RECOMMEND.
author: Taylor M.

description: Loved this place. Well worth the 15-20 minute wait. This place had been on my list for a while so really happy to have a chance to try it while visiting the city. Live in San Diego and get plenty of Mexican food. Didn't expect it to be so good. Left wishing we had one of these in San Diego because La Taqueria would give most of our places a run for their money.
author: B C.

description: Literally, my most favored burrito spot.... ever. Get this they don't put rice in the burrito because they believe it's just a filler. Meaning more room for the meat. I think I've tried everything at this place but to let you know my favorites here are the chorizo super burrito, the langua super taco, and the carne asada quesadilla. The chorizo has such a rich greasy taste, the langua melts in your mouth just falls apart because it's so tender, and the carne asada is jam packed with flavor. There's green salsa at every table which I love. It's pretty spicy so if your up for the heat I say try it. If you're in the Mission District of San Francisco you have to try La Taqueria. There's usually always a line but worth the wait and money.
author: Kiana W.

description: This was the best Mexican food I've had since living in Sacramento. Food was delicious and every single bite had so much flavor. I love the food. My husband and I travel to S.F just to eat the here. The food is worth driving from Sacramento just yo eat the best of the best. Wish I could give this place ten stars it's worth it.
author: Tyria Q.

description: Best Mexican I have ever had. I ordered chips and guacamole with salsa along with a pollo taco and I made sure to order that "super." The tacos were full of flavor and the chicken was delicious. I was surprised at how large the taco was and very impressed with the serving of ingredients they garnished my taco with. The line never dies down in here but don't get discouraged and go elsewhere because the wait is worth it and they do get your order out within 7 minutes or less! Awesome, awesome, awesome place and I am so glad I stopped through here on my west coast road trip.
author: Lexie O.

description:
SOOOOOOOOOO GOOOOOOD. You have to get the SUPER burrito DORADO style. The super burrito isn't terribly big, it just has cheese, sour cream, and guacamole. I'm not sure why you'd get the regular, cuz wouldn't that just be meat and beans? Yes this place doesn't put rice in their burritos which would be alarming at first but actually makes it taste much better, as rice doesn't have much taste. It's just a volumizer. So La Taq's burritos are perfectly assembled: thin layer of cheese melted INTO the tortilla, lots of meat (eh, could be more flavorful, i could barely taste it), but the perfect amount of sour cream, beans (I like pinto more than refried), and the GUACAMOLE just made it perfect. Dorado style warms the burrito and toasts the tortilla to be slightly browned and crispy. It's on the secret menu so you have to ask for it! They have spicy green sauce on the tables which is a nice addition. 

La Taq is in the Mission District, just a short walk away from 24th and Mission. The place is really cramped and kind of dirty. We got here at 5:45 and waited in line for 5 min, and found a seat easily. The burrito came in around 10 minutes. However by 6 pm the line just kept growing and it got packed real fast. By 6:30-7 pm the line's out the door. So I suggest just coming a little bit before the dinner rush if you can! No wifi.
author: Shannon W.

description: Great place to eat at! The environment is awesome! Parking can be tough on some days but thankfully it was easy to find a space during my visit. I had the Vegetarian options here and it was solid! But my friends had their meat tacos and enjoyed all of them! If you're visiting SF, it's a great place to eat at outside of the tourist spots
author: Anthony U.

description:
Tourist trap - not the best Mexican food not even in my top 20 for good Mexican food in sf.
It is OVERPRICED. $12 for a burrito half the size of the ones at chipotle.
author: Daniel V.

description:
Ok this place is worth every hype it gets! It lives up to the amazing reviews. I ordered their crunchy taco with carne asada and they definitely pack your taco with a lot of meat. The meat was marinated SO WELL. I'm from LA and there's no place around in LA that's close to what La Taqueria offered to my taste buds! 

Get ready for a long line and therefore a long wait! All of it is worth it. The line actually moves pretty fast, the line was out the door and I went to the restroom real quick and we were about 5 people behind the register. 

Give this place a go, it's worth it. 

PS. their salsa verde is too good!!!
author: Gielliane D.

description: The best burrito of the city. But just cash and rude guy on cashier. Probably so busy there.
author: Fernando P.

description:
5 Words: Cabeza Super Burrito Dorado Style

It might not get as much love as carne asada and carnitas but cabeza is so f*cking delicious.  The meat reminds of an extra soft, extra rich short rib.  It's flavorful and tender and sort of melts into the other burrito ingredients.  This is especially amazing with the sour cream and guac of the super burrito.  I love that their burritos don't have rice.  That just means more of the stuff.

It was packed on a Saturday afternoon but the line moved fairly quickly.  The whole process is a little hectic and the waiting area situation is a bit awkward and there is a lot of personal space invasion.  They forgot our chips and guac and drinks and remedying that was discombobulated to say the least.  We took our food to Dolores Park to enjoy the beautiful weather.  I told myself I wouldn't finish my burrito...thirty minutes later I had finished my burrito...such a sad moment...
author: Alexandra K.

description: I have been coming here for over 30 years and I have gotten many of my friends and family hooked on the burritos and tacos.  My all time favorite is the carne asada burrito super.  This the only place where I can eat the whole thing and want a taco.  Their fresca drinks are the bomb (strawberry).
author: Prima M.

description: We took and Uber from our Air B & B. I was prepared to stand in a line and to bring cash. I ordered the Super Carne Asada Burrito dorado style. It was amazing.We ordered to go because the seating was filled. I only regret not trying the green sauce everyone was smothering their burritos with. This was one of the highlights to my SF food crawl. Will be back!
author: Amber H.

description:
One of my favorite burritos in the city! 

I almost always order the carne asada super burrito, dorado style. Flavorful, juicy steak, with the right amount of beans and guac and cheese. I appreciate that they do not add rice; it's too much for me to eat in one sitting. The crispy tortilla (the "dorado" element) adds the perfect contrasting texture.

Also try the carne asada super quesadilla, which is similar to the burrito, but omits the beans.  Also order dorado style - delicious!

I love to sit at the outside window while I eat and watch the workers inside. 

Note: If you sit at one of the tables on the sidewalk, keep your belongings close.
author: Wolfgang C.

description: So freaking good. It's on all the lists of places to go when you visit SF and for good reason. You HAVE to get dorado style--it's so worth the hype.
author: Alyssa R.

description: Got the super burrito carne asada and regular carnitas and both were good but not sure if worth the hype (and the wait). Went around 2pm on Sunday and still had a line almost to the door. Probably should've gotten the dorado style for at least the carne asada one cause that one wasnt all that special. Carnitas was juicy and the horchata was bomb though!
author: Praisella Y.

description:
First off, the food is delicious. 
The chicken taco got a little dry as we continued to eat it but the carne was very juicy as well as the burrito. 

What bothered me was how the workers handling the food would not use gloves. They used their bare hands for everything. From placing raw meat on the grill to assembling tacos and burritos. They would grab the portions of each ingredient and slap it in the tray. The food was really good but it made me feel iffy seeing the food handled that way. The food is very authentic though and I got a good family vibe as the staff had old to adult aged people and women and men. The horchata was delicious too! There was a big line and you can see the food being prepared!
author: Helen N.

description:
The famous burrito bracket winner is a must try for those visiting SF/local to the bay area (like me). Expect a 30 min wait in line on weekends, and expect a war to get a seat. They mostly have indoor seating, which the line snakes around, and a few bar seats outside in the blazing sun. Plus side to the long wait, is you'll get your food quickly since they prepare food efficiently and quickly. In summary: prepare for a stressful time in order to get their scrumptious foods.

The flour tortilla here is amazing, so totally delicious especially when crisped up by oil - ingredients are quality quality quality at La Taqueria. I love the chorizo burrito more than anything else, and don't know how they get that chorizo so good! My order always consists of:

-chorizo super burrito with no sour cream ("super" adds on cheese, sour cream, and avo)
- pina aqua fresca (so fresh and light!!)
- chips + salsa
= $15 + tip

Chips and salsa are an additional cost, but worth it! Especially for chip eaters like me.
For those out of towners, the area is a bit grungy.
author: Sarah W.

description: This place was recommended by a few different people. I've stayed in the Mission a few times but had never bern. Decided to treat myself, and what a treat. Beef quesadilla, chicken taco and beef burrito. OMG Everything was fantastic. I don't normally like salsa but this, I could not stop eating. Chips are literally fresh. Tacos w beans and quesadilla the best I've had. I will definitely be back.
author: Zeynep D.

description:
Not going to lie pretty good burrito but really expensive for the small size. Meat is nice and soft with good flavor but almost 13 bucks for a small burrito not really sure if it's worth it. Also tried their chips and guac. Guac needs a little more seasoning but can't complain. 

They have both inside and outside seating but is very limited. They are crazy busy but the line moves pretty fast. Reason for only giving this place 4 stars instead of 5 is because their food comes in small portions and is really pricy but it's good... Not amazing good but still good.
author: Candy M.

description:
So what is all the fuss about? Simply the best mission burrito I have ever had..... 

In this case believe the hype surrounding this packed nondescript Mecca of the folded tortilla arts. 

I had the Carne Asada Super. The super comes with pinto beans pico de gallo, sour cream, cheese, and avacado.  Nice size and perfectly rolled. Each ingredient was in just the right amount and perfectly complimented each other. The carne was filet tender and I can still taste it! Other in the party tried the chicken and carnitas and had similar ethereal experiences. 

The only major downsides are the parking may take a while, the line (to be fair it moved fast), cash only, and they only have so many tables so if your there at peak times you may wait to eat.  

This is a game changing place that has stood the test of time.
author: Fred T.

description: One of the best burritos I've ever had. Get it derado style and you won't be disappointed. I had the pork burrito and my fiancée had the chicken and both were 5 stars. A must visit if you come to San Francisco!
author: Michael B.

description: Awesome tacos! I came here the first night I arrived at San Fran. My friend told me they had the best tacos and burritos in the US so I had to try it. The wait was long about 30-40 minutes but it was definitely worth it. I had gotten the beef & pork taco and underestimated how big each were. One of them filled me up quickly and I had to save the other one for later. Great experience! Soda was very gross though, avoid getting their fountain drinks if you can.
author: Ivy C.

description:
Apparently this is one of the most famous taco joints in the Mission District. And the owners seem to know it because the tacos are $$ and so I ended up getting a burrito upgrades to the super burrito, which meant avocado, sour cream, and cheese added. 

Overall my super burrito still cost $11, the most expensive burrito that I've had ever had....I think. And though the lengua burrito was soft delicious and stuffed full with meat, beans, and all the extra stuff (no rice in it, though), it was still considerably small for the price. For that reason, I'd rather go to El Farolito down the street which have much bigger burritos.

Service was kind and they were quick to whip up 3 super burritos despite the long lines on Saturday. There are seats inside and out but they were hard to snag.
author: Ivy C.

description:
Literally ate the burrito in 5 minutes.

Came here on a whim with two friends around 5pm. Damn the line was popping out the door. This also means that if you want a table you're going to swoop in like a hawk and stand your ground.

Based on yelp we kept on seeing everyone ordering their tacos and burritos "el dorado" style. Even though we had no idea what that was we were going to yolo.

Note: regular burrito has like nothing inside. Get the super burrito with that guacamole and pico de gallo.

The lady who took our order told us that they don't do "el dorado" style on Saturdays. Bummer. BUT when we got to the check out guy we asked what was "el dorado" and basically it meant they fried the tortilla and make your burrito or taco crispy. We asked why they can't do el dorado style on Saturdays and he said, "What?? Yes we can" and proceed to make it el dorado for us.

Bless you check out man. 

Another note: the size of their burrito is smaller than your average burrito. I'm so used to El Farlito size, so I thought 1/2 would be enough for me. I split one burrito with a friend and my half was the size of my palm. I gulf that burrito in 5 minutes! The size for $13 was not worth, BUT I have to admit their meat was soooo good. La Taqueria uses better quality ingredients so its up to you if that justifies the cost.
author: Grace Z.

description:
Dangeroussssllyyy good! My family and I stayed in San Francisco for a week one street behind the La Taqueria. 
After 4 days of walking by and seeing a huge line, we finally decided to give it a try. 
Who on earth decided to make burritos that good? 
We all got burritos with chips/salsa/guacamole. And it was perfect street food for lunch. Burritos are pretty good but didn't feel too heavy!
author: Olivia K.

description: Grew up eating the Best amazing authentic Mexican food at La Taqueria. The consistency and high quality fresh ingredients, since I was a kid has never changed. Sooooh Delicious!!!! My favorite is the burrito Dorado - grilled crunchy tortilla with savory and tender carnita meat or carne asada meat, or mixed meat with pico de Gallo and guac. The meats are grilled to perfection, tender and juicy authentic flavor makes you want more! For vegetarians, you will love the fresh veggies, and can customize to have your onions and bell peppers grilled. Seating availability is limited and a line forms out the door, but it's worth the wait! Can't wait to try again!  Cash only accepted, have your cash ready!
author: Miriam S.

description: Average food with a high price tag. Super Burrito is not all that super. Long and thin with a soggy tortilla. I had the lengua super burrito, it was flavorful.although very skimpy on the filling. Maybe I came on a bad day. Restaurant was not overly busy when I entered although by the time I finished my meal it was packed. The best thing about the burrito is that they dont use rice. Super nice staff and very quick to make sure everything is clean.
author: Manny G.

description: Had a lot of ppl tell us on various uber rides this was the spot to eat Mexican food . The lines were gut busting long and the food took a good 20-25 min to come out . I thought it was a nice large portion but nothing extraordinary outside of your typical Tex mex fare . Generous amounts of guac and sour cream were stuffed into their super quesadilla and then fried crispy on a flattop stove. Seating is very limited so be prepared to stand for many a whiles . I also tried their tamarindo which was overly sweet and didn't taste like it had a lot of fresh pulp in it .
author: Thang S.

description:
One word...YUMMMMMMMMMMMM!!!
This restaurant is NOT in the tourist area of San Francisco, but soooooo worth the trip!!!
This restaurant is the poster child for "hole-in-the-wall" resturants...it's small and was packed from the moment we walked up until we ate and left back out.
They had a line literally flowing out of their door.

The food was AMAZING!!!
The prices were great and the staff was FAST, but very friendly!!! The older gentleman at the register was super sweet and talkative, even though it was busy.
We had the a regular steak (cane asada) burrito and super burrito (which comes with chips, guacamole and salsa)
Again, the food was AMAZING!!!

We will DEFINITELY be making the restaurant a "must stop by" place the next time we are in San Francisco!!!
author: Nikki C.

description: Definitely one of the best burritos I had in my life. The carne asada was very juicy. I regretted not getting another one on my way back.
author: Jun K.

description:
Can't lie, the burritos and tacos were delish! The place was packed so they are doing something right. We barely were able to find a seat it was so crowded (saturday afternoon/evening). Just don't plan to come if you are in a rush. 
We walked around the corner after eating to check out the Balmy alley street murals which were pretty cool too.
author: Rick C.

description: Today was the last day I will come to La Taqueria. Prices are way of out of the roof. I know it's the city but 12.35 for a burrito that is gone in 4 bites.. They are taking advantage of everyone and everything. Plus cash only? Come on now, it's 2018... This place can't be original anymore..  very disappointed after tonight's visit.
author: Cesar S.

description:
This place was popping! The line looped around and was out the door on the sidewalk - apparently this is the norm though. Loved the whole ambience of the place; how it seemed like a little hole-in 
-the-wall restaurant but everyone and their mothers' seemed to have heard about it. Note that it's a bit hard to find seating so while you're in line you might want to keep a lookout for open seats and grab them while your friend orders for you. I read the Yelp reviews and got the Carne Asada Super Burrito  El Dorado Style. The El Dorado style (which is hidden from the menu I think) just means the tortilla is fried so it has a nice golden and crispy touch to it. The difference between regular burritos and the super burrito is that the super burrito comes with more toppings - which i highly recommend. Personally, I don't think it's the BEST burrito I've ever had. Maybe I expected more from all the hype? It was good but not sure if it was something so amazingly delicious. All my friends enjoyed the burrito a lot more than I did. They appreciate the absence of rice and liked how it made the burrito a bit more wet. So I guess the title of the "best burritos" might be disputed from person to person. One of my friends got the chicken quesadilla, but she didn't like it as much. The chicken came in huge chunks in the quesadilla and she said everything was pretty bland. I also tried the salsa and chips and it was really good- everything tasted homemade and fresh. If you can, I HIGHLY recommend getting the fresh juice drinks. I tried the tamarind, mango, and horchata and all three were so delicious! I would get the large as well (only 50cents more than the regular but twice the amount!).
author: Gina B.

description: Bring cash! Long line, but it went fast. I am impressed by the horchata, and to me, that means this place has legitimately delish Mexican food. I wish they had pollo asado, but the shredded chicken was so juicy and delicious, this burrito was totally worth the wait. Make sure you also order chips and a side so you have something to munch on while you wait for the food. Overall, I'm a happy camper and would come back again!
author: Sharon S.

description: Place was amazing. Went after the marathon. Long lines but move quick. The Carne Asada Burrito Doroado Style is the must have.
author: Steve G.

description:
The quality has gone waaaaaaaay downhill. The kind of degradation that only occurs when a great small business gets acquired by a giant conglomerate and undergoes serious cost cuts and"process efficiencies." The kind that sucks the life out of the business and its employees. 

I stood at the counter with no one in front of me for ~5 minutes before someone finally deigned to take my order. 

The tortilla was not steamed or heated in any way. It still smelled sour and raw. I asked for refried beans and got whole pinto beans. I guess I should be grateful to get anything at all. I had to ask for salsa. 

Either fame has gone to their heads or they've become a corporate casualty. Either way, there are so many great burrito joints on mission st that I won't be returning to this one.
author: Ashley S.

description:
Where do I begin? I loved everything about this place! 

When we entered la taqueria, it was crazy busy and people standing everywhere but the line moves fast so don't be put off by the swarm of people!

I ordered two carne asada tacos - super, with a little bit of picante. I recommend super as you get the full shabang with pico de gallo, guacamole and sour cream. I also ordered the strawberry aguas frescas which was delicious!

You line up and order in one line and then you pay in another, then you pick up your food when your number is called. 

We got a table quickly as people don't hang around too much. The food was super delicious and tasty - i highly recommend it! 

P.S Cash only.
author: Angeli Y.

description: Cash-only is annoying but the burritos are worth it. Got the vegetarian burrito with avocado and it tasted amazing -- the tortillas were especially fresh. The food also came out pretty quickly, which was surprising for how busy it was. Very loud and crowded environment, though, so get ready to stand around for a while.
author: Kate J.

description: The asada tacos were super good and filling. The burritos had little beef, but they were ok. I would prefer ordering the tacos!
author: BilMar R.

description:
Disclosure: I'm originally from Austin, Texas and have grown up eating TexMex/Mexican food for a solid 24 years of my life. Whether my experiences add or detract from my ability to judge Mexican food is your opinion :) On to the review!

My sister and I visited La Taqueria after a whirlwind of adventure for the Memorial Day Weekend. Needless to say, we were STARVING. I knew there would be a wait, but she lives in Seattle and couldn't go any longer without Mexican food in her life. The line went out the door, but it moved quickly because there are a few employees who take your order before you get to the register. I would recommend one person grabbing a table while the other person waits in line to order/pay because I don't see how there is any other way to get seating in this place! The competition is stiff.

My sister and I each ordered a super burrito with Carne Asada, but I wish one of us got tacos so we could try more items. Nevertheless, the burrito came out (riceless, as has been known), and I swear we downed them in less than 10 mins flat. They were delicious and satisfying (though they weren't the best burritos I've had in my life)! 

Why didn't I give them 4 stars instead of 5  if this was not the best burrito of my life? Because, the next day, my sister and I went to El Taqueria Farolito, and we preferred La Taqueria. Overall, highly deserving of the 5 star rating.
author: Alice L.

description:
I love this place; the meat is so tender and juicy:) the only I can really knock off was the price...over $10 for a burrito....wth. Mexican food is supposed to be bomb and cheap:)  I spent $30 bucks for 2 burrito a nachos and a small drink. In L.A. I could've  bought 5 burritos for that price.

The nachos was awesome; it was topped with homemade salsa and a large scoop of guac on top.
author: Daniel L.

description:
La Taqueria has stood the test of time. Open since 1973 this is arguably the best burrito you can buy anywhere. If the gods of any religion were still around, you'd likely find them in line waiting on a carne asada burrito and taking selfies. Behind the dense crowd of gringos and tourists you'll find a bustling staff cranking out hundreds (if not thousands) of burritos a day. Don't like lines? There's plenty of other crappy options in every direction. Choose one.

I've given this some careful thought. What makes La Taqueria so special? My answer: its simplicity. Beans, meat and salsa. That's what you're getting and they have truly perfected every ingredient. You can taste the freshness with every bite. Add some of the house salsa and you got yourself a mouth party! 

I love my burritos and can easily pick out bland or mediocre flavor. You really pay for what you get. It's definitely a little pricey but well worth it. I walked by this restaurant yesterday after having a big dinner. I almost got in line for second dinner after catching a whiff of grilled meat. The burrito struggle is real.

Tip: Do yourself a favor. Order two burritos and take one home.
author: Ralph A.

description: Huge line out the door around 8, but it's really not a long wait at all. We waited about 8-10 mins for our food. Dining in can be hard if you find a empty table to sit, take it! Lol. Food was great! Huge super tacos! Super burrito was smaller than other places, but was probably the best burrito we've had. Three tacos was too much food for me. Awesome guacamole! The green sauce bottle they have on the table is so yummy! They accept cash only
author: Jeannette C.

description:
The weight time at 4 wasn't that bad about 20 minutes but this was also a Wednesday so the days may vary. 

I got a carne asada super burrito. The meat was extremely fresh and smokey, which was the star of the burrito. I thought for a super burrito the size was smaller than expected and the price of 11.70 tax included seemed a bit on priced end.
author: John A.

description: Line literally out the door, no room to sit but gave it a try. Being a vegetarian the only choice was a burrito with beans, sour cream and cheese. They don't have rice. It wasn't bad but I judge a place by its salsa and theirs was not very good. A little pico with not much flavor and a spicy green salsa with little flavor. I guess if you eat meat you get more in your burrito but for me wasn't that great. My daughters quesadilla was good although she did a big greasy. If you take it to go it's probably more enjoyable than fighting for a cramped spot.
author: Francine B.

description:
I hate to exaggerate. But this was the best burrito I've had in my life. Hands down. No argument. 

Had the carne asada burrito and it was a journey in and of itself. Stop by this place yourself!
author: Charles M.

description:
I have to admit I've been avoiding La Taqueria for years and for many reasons. It seems like every year, La Taqueria makes it on every top 10 list for its institution-like following of its burritos and tacos. With its never-ending notoriety, you can expect the lines at La Taqueria to be long; morning, day and night.

This past Saturday, I decided to brave the crowds and skip my favorite taqueria and give La Taqueria a try - at last. The line wasn't as bad as I anticipated and ended a little before their door and didn't stretch onto Mission Street like I've seen in the past. The combination of the line and the small dining area made this place packed beyond belief. There wasn't one table empty as everyone got down on this warm Saturday afternoon.

As the line crawled towards the front, the menu became more visible, and is as simple as can be: tacos, burritos, quesadillas, extras, and your choice of beverage, which includes a selection of soft drinks, aqua frescas and beer. I chose to go with my usual order and that's two tacos, one carne asada and one pollo asado. I decided to go with the regular taco, which is simply the protein, beans (refried or pinto) and pico de gallo. If you choose to super your taco, it adds sour cream, cheese and avocado for an additional $2.50

It didn't take long for our number to get called which is typically standard at most taquerias. Once I set eyes on my tacos, I was impressed with the size, which correlates directly with the higher price point. The tacos were hefty and must of had a good 4 or 5 ounces of protein stuffed inside of them and topped off with pinto beans and pico de gallo.

The pollo asado was lean and moist and and grilled perfectly. Even with the cilantro, pinto beans, and pico de gallo, it still lacked a little flavor; however the carne asada managed to save the day. The meat was juicy and had the flavor that was missing form the pollo asado. The taqueria does have a house sauce available at all the tables, which was a nice add on but be careful because it does pack plenty of heat. 

Overall, I enjoyed my tacos but given the higher price, and the crazy lines, I'm not prepared to make this my go to taqueria in the Mission. I do admit that their food is above-average and will satisfy any Mexican cravings, but it does come with a few flaws. I personally love the simplicity of a taco that is nothing but a tortilla, your chosen protein and topped with cilantro and onions. Regardless La Taqueria is a strong contender when it comes to choosing a taqueria when eating in the Mission; you simply can't go wrong.

Ambiance/Decor: 3/5
Food: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Price: $$
Overall: 4/5

Pros:
+ A Mission District institution 
+ Small and simple menu
+ Lean and moist pollo tacos
+ Carne asada tacos are a must try, packing plenty of favor
+ Higher prices but larger portions
+ Selection of aqua frescas and beer
+ Fast and friendly staff
+ Patio seating 
+ Tacos dorados are a must try if you're from out of town

Cons:
- Limited seating
- Lines at all times of the day
author: Alexander E.

description:
You know you've made it on the Mission burrito crawl when you've made it to La Taqueria.  It's has inviting wooden benches where you can rub elbows with both locals as well as large groups of students looking to get a taste of their first Mission burrito.

I had a large burrito here as well and ordered a Horchata (cold cinnamon drink) which was not available at other burrito places.  

Long story short, the burritos here were definitely more tasty.  Horchata was easily the best part of the meal, as it was both refreshing, with a milky cinnamon taste that was just right for the time of day.
author: Alex L.

description:
Meh. That about sums up how I felt about this burrito. It had glowing recommendations from anyone and everyone, winning awards and everything. I was ready for my trek to the Mission to pay off with a burrito-shaped party in my mouth.

The place was packed, even at 2pm, which was a good sign. There was, however, no seating available and hardly any room to move. The cashier was talking to some guy standing near her instead of taking orders, so the line went slowly.

I got the super burrito with carnitas and hot sauce. It was incredibly unremarkable. There was zero heat from the sauce whatsoever, no interesting flavors, it wasn't a fantastic deal, really no redeeming qualities. It wasn't *bad*, but it was severely underwhelming. I've had far better burritos in the Mission, I don't see any reason to come here over any other place.
author: Shawn W.

description:
Hype aside, this was an amazing burrito. This was the first place I wanted to try on my trip to San Fran, and it was well worth it. It's not a huge burrito, but it hits the spot. I wouldn't say you'd be as full as you had something like a different Mission style burrito, or even Chipotle.

I got the Carne Asada Super Burrito Dorado style. GOTTA GET THE DORADO STYLE. It had this buttery flake to it. The salsa was out of this world, and although people here said it's really spicy, I didn't feel that at all. It had a slight kick to it, but I've had hotter. The one thing I wish with this burrito was more meat. It had a good amount, but after watching the Eater video on this Taqueria, I expected it to be bursting with meat and that didn't happen.

I came at 11am on a weekday and there was a nonexistent line, but mostly all tables were taken.

One last thing.... THE PINEAPPLE JUICE WAS The BOMB . It was sweet, but the pulpy pineapple sliced right through that savory burrito.
author: Michael D.

description: All burritos are created equal...right? Wrong! Listen, a burrito is far from my favorite food, but this is hands down the best one I ever had even after considering I had great Mexican food in Mexico, Arizona, and SoCal. Some people bitch about the price, but you get what you pay for, and this is SF, a place where you pay $20 for a mojito.  The wait sucks, but some things are worth waiting for. Recommendation: Super carnitas burrito (yes not carne asada) dorado style. Thank me later.
author: Alex P.

description: This place isn't fancy yet this place is super crowded and seating is hard to come by. We visited when visiting San Francisco and my husband and daughter didn't love their lunch, but my burrito was really good. I think the reason why is I ordered my burrito El Dorado style and the flavor they produce from pan frying the burrito is delicious! So if you go, try to avoid their peak times or expect a wait, and make sure you order your burrito El Dorado style. Also for owners, I think they should highlight this option on menu so everyone sees it and knows what it is.
author: B G.

description: This place is world famous for one reason: they make bomb mexican food. We got the chicken burrito "Dorado" style - which means its grilled on the outside, the only way to go. I read about La Taqueria before my visit to SF and it was worth the ride to Mission. One of the best burritos of my life. The meat was so juicy and flavorful. The chips were just ok, but it didn't matter, I still have dreams about this burrito.
author: Paul L.

description: This is my favorite burrito in the city and probably ever. Don't be fooled by the line; it moves quickly and they work *fast* here. Make you're you order it "dorado" (grilled on the outside) and spring for the "super" style.
author: Gareth G.

description: I thought it was just good.  Simple menu.  I got the super chicken burrito and thought the chicken was good.  The only thing I didn't like about it was it was wet = messy.  They need to drain the chicken or beans better before rolling it up.  It just got all over the place.  The size was kinda small and pricey here.  I think there are better places in the area.
author: James L.

description: Get the super carne asada taco with hard shell (inside shell fried, outside is not). It'll be around $7 for one. Best thing there. Two tacos is like eating a burrito or maybe even 1.5 burritos xD. Best tacos in the mission, maybe. Not best tacos I've ever had, though.
author: Deborah C.

description: Well worth the wait & price!    the line was out the door and to the main light but it went by fast. The order wait time was less than $10 minutes.  Finding seating was a pain but the turnover was quick. I noticed a lot of tables sharing seats with other parties.  Definitely not a have a long conversation and catch up on life kind of setting.  Get in, eat and move on!
author: Melissa C.

description: HmmmMmm the burritos here were good but I'm not sure they lived up to all the hype that they get. My boyfriend and I had chicken and carnitas burritos, along with mango and pineapple aguas frescas which came out to be almost $30. The aguas frescas were goooood and I wish I ordered a larger size. The burritos were pretty good- the super burritos have meat, beans, pico, avocado, sour cream, and cheese. I had mine without sour cream and cheese so the burrito honestly felt kind of light, but the carnitas were yummy and complemented the rest of the burrito well. My boyfriend thought his burrito was also pretty good, but the two of us agreed it probably wasn't worth a trip to SF all the way from east bay and then almost $30- we have a spot in Berkeley that we felt was at a similar quality for much cheaper.
author: Jess L.

description: I finally made it here for a Mission burrito, the style without rice.  An incredibly long line, but it was worth the wait.  Next time I will ask for a crispy burrito - one toasted on the grill.
author: Stuart C.

description:
YUM YUM YUM. NOW I KNOW WHY IT GOT VOTED THE BEST BURRITO IN AMERICA.

finally made it to the Mission District after wanting to go here for soooo long. came here on Saturday for an early lunch and there was no line with lots of tables available! 
I ordered a carne asada super burrito dorado style and O M G it was so good. the tortilla was grilled on the outside and I love how they do not put rice in their burritos. It was stuffed with meat, cheese, beans, sour cream, and guac.  so tasty!

I heard that people compare La Taqueria to El Farolito down the street so I ended up getting a super burrito from La Taqueria and El Farolito to compare. El Farolito has nothing on La Taqueria!
author: Kelly C.

description:
This is a great Taqueria and one of the best i've been to in the Bay Area. I'm a taco guy so always get the prawn tacos whenever I come here. The prawns are seasoned perfectly and the taste doesn't get drowned out by beans or anything else you add. The tacos are a decent size and two regular tacos fill me up every time, plus you get a free basket of the house chips.

Overall the place is great and I highly recommend it, but the knock on it is the dining area is small and it can be hard to get a table and they are cash only.
author: Steve H.

description:
Best burritos and quesadillas in town! Honestly, I haven't have had anything better than this. 

Little crowdy but worth the wait! Try it yourself.
author: Bhargav S.

description:
The best in the world 

It's the best in the world. Get el dorado style (they fry the outside like a quesadilla)
author: Sam K.

description:
Burrito is BOMB diggity. Chips & salsa not so much, as well as the taco. Their specialty is their burrito, so get that! If you're really hungry get 2 burritos & split the second one.

Also their green hot sauce is perfect!
The staff is friendly & constantly mopping the place up. 

This place always has a line but they move so fast.
Worth the wait, the drive.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Hands down my favorite taqueria in the city, hands down one of my favorite Mexican spots in the entire Bay Area!

Food: Super Burritos are perfection! Your choice of meat, beans, pico de gallo, sour cream, cheese & avocado come together to form the perfect balance and plethora of flavors! The carne asada is always charred to perfection, yet the meat maintains a nice soft texture that allows the juices of the meat to seep out with each bite. The beans are pretty average, but the interesting part is that they don't add rice to their burritos, I personally think this is a benefit as you're able to get more meat and you're able to taste the meat a lot more than you would if a ton of rice was stuffed into the burrito. The addition of cheese, avocado and sour cream provide a creamy and rich component to the burrito, they also cut through all of the oils from the meat and refried beans. Finally, because they grill all of their burritos, it's rare for the burrito to fall apart due to all of the juices that usually tend to make burritos fall apart easily. The perfect burrito, seriously. The chicken is good, but can be a little bland at times. I highly recommend on of their other red meat options! If you're not feeling a burrito, the quesadillas are really delicious as well.

Price: Above average food deserves above average prices!

Service: Quick and friendly.

Ambiance: Usually a long line, but it moves pretty fast and is worth waiting for. Cash only! Plenty of indoor seating, but not always clean seating area as people tend to not bus their own tables when they finish dining.

Overall: Definitely the best burrito I've had in the Bay Area, likely one of my favorite Mexican restaurants. Exceptional and authentic Mexican food, great service and fairly nice ambiance!
author: Astrid Z.

description: This establishment has been around for decades! There were locals and tourists the day we went. The line was out the door around lunch time on Friday but the line moves quickly. Tables for customers to sit but people are quick to grab spots as soon as someone leaves. Ordered the supreme beef burrito to split - can definitely feed two. Beef was soft and juicy and they put a lot of avocado in. Everything was warm and melted together. Super flavorful but my friend personally though it was a bit too "wet" because the sour cream and everything melted into each other. Decent prices and cash only. There is an ATM in the restaurant.
author: Alyson Y.

description: A local recommended La Taqueria as the number 1 place we had to visit in San Fran and it did not disappoint! We got there right at 11, and already a line was forming. We were served quickly and everyone was so friendly. It was nice to visit a place that you could tell was full of locals and regulars. My husband got the carnitas super burrito and I got 1 chicken taco super and 1 carne asada taco super. The chicken was excellent, but the carne asada and carnitas were even better. Making them super was a great choice and made the entire experience so flavorful. We didn't have a single bite left! I would definitely recommend stopping in, so worth it! Hands down, way better than any Chipotle or Qdoba style burrito place we have back home.
author: Ciara D.

description: Overrated but it was worth a visit. Not the tastiest taco I've had but to each his own.
author: Jason J.

description: Best Burrito in town! The meat inside (chicken) was perfect and the salsa they put inside (medium) wasn't too salty (as other places are) and it all blended together perfectly! The line gets long so be sure to get there before you are starving and it takes a bit to navigate around the people and tables but so worth it!
author: Mars P.

description: This is the Taqueria of all Taqueria's in the Mission district. It's not uncommon to see 30 to 50 people in a line wrapping out the door. The tacos and burritos are absolutely delicious and its been consistent for many years. Prices have skyrocketed over time so don't expect it to be a budget place. But if you want good tasting Mexican fare you could do a lot worse than La Taqueria.
author: Robert C.

description:
Honestly, it's pretty good. Probably a little overhyped, but that doesn't make this burrito mediocre! Got the cabeza regular burrito w/avocado "Dorado" style. Dorado style REALLY makes a difference, it's sooooo good. 

I'm particularly impressed by how quickly our order was received and delivered! Only waited probably a half hour to order and get our delicious burritos. Satisfied :)
author: Lilian K.

description: My wife and I visited La Taqueria after receiving the recommendation from a friend. I was hesitant to have dinner at La Taqueria as i was really looking forward to a sit down style restaurant. With that being said, i am extremely glad that we went because La Taqueria served me the best taco that I have ever had. We will definitely be returning next time we visit the city!
author: Austin H.

description: Aww, a sf staple.  Used to here back in the early 90's, haha. Good memories. Good food.  Always packed.
author: Keriena T.

description:
Holy smokes! This is what my burrito dreams are made of. Everything is top notch: the tortillas, the salsa, the beans, the meat. I've had the carne asada burrito twice, and it was flawless both times. 

This place gets busy and moves FAST, so keep your eagle eyes scanning for a free table so that you won't be left standing. The competition out there is HOT to get a table. As you move through the line, you get to peep behind the counter at the fast hands preparing the glorious food you're about to consume.

Fast, cheap, and delicious. You can't go wrong.
author: Fiona F.

description:
The owners of this restaurant are treating their employees horribly. Violating labor laws to the extent that they settled with five employees for $500,000. Don't eat here. Here's the article:

https://blog-sfgate-com.cdn.ampproject.org/v/s/blog.sfgate.com/inthemission/2018/07/03/former-la-taqueria-workers-describe-conditions-that-led-to-500k-settlement/amp/?amp_js_v=a2&amp_gsa=1&usqp=mq331AQECAE4AQ%3D%3D#referrer=https://www.google.com&amp_tf=From%20%251%24s&ampshare=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.sfgate.com%2Finthemission%2F2018%2F07%2F03%2Fformer-la-taqueria-workers-describe-conditions-that-led-to-500k-settlement%2F
author: Kckc C.

description: Went here after taking a stroll at Dolores Park.  This was my second time being here and thankfully I wasn't starving which put my mind in equilibrium, so I ordered a normal asada burrito.  Bland...and wet, like leaking from the tortilla.  The inside of a burrito is supposed to blend with all the other ingredients, but I felt this burrito was layered, almost in the same texture you get when you order a Chipotle burrito and the employee was having a bad day.  I can respect that this taqueria has been here for years, but to be voted as having the best burrito is in America is ridiculous.  Who hyped that up?  Some kid who was born and raised in the midwest and got a tech job in San Mateo?  Having never eaten Mexican food and thought this place was a god send?  Please.
author: Conrad B.

description: Made a take out order of a delicious vegan burrito with tortilla chips. Greta price, perfect serving size, correct order, quick process, professional and friendly employees. Highly satisfied. Definitely recommend trying this place out!!
author: Anna A.

description: I had the carnitas super burrito dorado style. It was okay not extravagant. I felt like the burrito tasted like a cross mix of a burrito from Chipotle and Taco Bell. The pork was a little over salted. A friend had the carne asada super burrito dorado style. I tried some of it the beef was seasoned very well, but again nothing special. I agree with another yelper, definitely not a $13 worth burrito more like $8-$9.
author: Jayna W.

description: The team at FiveThirtyEight named their burrito the best in the country. I haven't tried as many contenders as they did, but it's certainly my fave. And yet the prices and wait have remained reasonable, at least outside peak times. A not-so-secret reason for their superiority: no rice. I like rice. I like burritos. I like them apart.
author: Carl B.

description:
Listen to all the reviews and order yourself a carne asada burrito- dorado style. We did and were not disappointed. I also got mine without beans. They charge extra for this since you're getting extra meat instead. 

We went on a Sunday, not even 20 minutes after they opened, and the place was already pretty crowded and line long.
author: Therese M.

description:
Couldn't have been more disappointed in the food quality. As a Southern California native, I've been told that La Taqueria rivals San Diego and Los Angeles in terms of Burrito deliciousness. The rumors could not have been more wrong. 

I ordered a chicken super burrito and have a few complaints:
1) It was, by far, the most liquidity burrito I've ever had. The pinto beans and pico de gallo must have been completely unstrained, to the point where water was pouring out of the bottom of my burritto with each bite
2) In almost every bite of chicken was a chewy ligament (and in a few other bites I found bones). Not what I'm looking for in my dinner. 
3) The chicken itself was pretty flavorless - just your classic poached chicken with little/no spice. 

Don't bother settling on La Taqueria. Go find one of the many other great spots in the mission that doesn't charge $13 for a sub-par burrito.
author: Roff S.

description: This place truly has THE BEST tacos and burritos EVER!! We came here after a giants game to get our fix of tacos n burritos since they no longer have their San Jose location . I left one happy person!! I'm also happy to know they finally sell their salsa verde as it is the best!!
author: Talissa M.

description: Super affordable, great tasting. Stumbled across La Taqueria and loved it. It's a great no-frills mexican place that's definitely worth checking out. Definitely a standout, even in the mission.
author: Emily L.

description:
La Taqueria? No. La Decepción (Disappointment).

This place seems to have unbelievable hype--almost 3,000 reviews at the time of this writing and lines that go out the door.

Pero, me costó contener la desilusión y frustración que sentía (I struggled to contain the disappointment and frustration I felt).

It's a decently sized place but even then, way too cramped because of the people sitting and because of the ridiculous line. 

It's pretty confusing how to order, but eventually you get up to the front and someone takes your order. But wait! You don't pay yet. You get a receipt and then you get to the register and THEN you pay.

Now, you wait for your food, but the super confusing part is where you even go to get it! It's super difficult to hear your number, and there's one area where they're giving out food but also ANOTHER one that totally throws you off your game. Maybe it was because I was a newbie here, but I totally looked like an idiot at the wrong place to get my food.

I got a carne asada burrito, and I found the carne asada to not be as tender as I'd like; in fact, my teeth started to hurt because the meat was kind of tough. The burrito was kind of mushy and got pretty boring after three bites. I didn't have that super satisfying feeling of freshness from cilantro, onions, nicely grilled meat...I only really got a smorgasbord of mixed-up flavors.

My friends and I also got the chips and salsa. This was pretty big, and I have to say that while the salsa was pretty good at first, it also did get kind of boring after a while simply because it didn't have much kick or depth to it. Some more tanginess and spice would have done wonders.

All in all, was it a satisfying meal? Well, Mexican food is usually suuuper filling, and this was no exception. However, I wasn't able to finish my burrito not because I didn't have the stomach capacity, but just because I wasn't super crazy about it. 

I don't feel like this place is worth the long lines; for much cheaper and even better options, I would even visit your local taco truck instead.

¡Qué lástima (What a shame)!
author: Tremaine E.

description: Legendary Taqueria, has never failed to satisfy my cravings for delicious Mexican food. Their burritos are unique as they are significantly more moist than burritos from any other location. The moisture is a side effect of the liberal usage of delicious salsas. In my opinion they are the gold standard for burritos, and one of my favorite places in San Francisco.
author: Stanley W.

description:
I've been attempting to try this place several times, but each time the line has been too long and my hunger wouldn't allow me to wait. This time around I made sure to get here earlier (5pm) and the wait was quite short. I went with 2 carne asada tacos with guac and they were quite sizeable. One thing I realized after receiving my tacos was it was a double layer of soft taco! Apparently, "dorado" style must be specifically ordered, which is a hard taco inside a soft taco. Did not know this, but they were kind enough to remake the taco dorado style. 

Reading other reviews, it seems like you can get dorado style burritos, which I will most definitely have to try next time. The first dorado taco I had wasn't quite crispy enough, so it was kind of chewy. The second taco was a bit better and much easier to eat. The carne asada meat wasn't too oily and each taco had plenty of meat.
author: Edward W.

description:
NATIONAL TACO DAY

About two years ago I ate here for the first time due to an SF Gate article that polled voters who voted this place as the best burritos in the country. When I ate here it was late night after dance class. Due to that article the line was long. I wanted a carnitas burrito but La Taqueria ran out of it and I ended up having a lengua burrito. Maybe it was because my dinner was late at night or I was waiting for about an hour for the burrito I didn't enjoy my meal. Due to my experience that night I never thought about eating here again. However there were times I thought about eating here again during a time when this place wasn't so packed. My first visit I initially wanted to order the cabeza tacos but La Taqueria was out of cabeza so I never had taco my first time here. 

Since today is National Taco Day I decided to come here again for only the tacos. I've read Yelp reviews that you can order a crispy taco. I knew what I wanted. I ordered two tacos - one crispy carnitas taco and one soft cabeza taco. The portion of both tacos is bigger than most tacos I've seen at other taquerias. The crispy and soft tacos provided different textures of the tortilla. The deep fried taco matched well with the carnitas. Surprisingly the carnitas wasn't oily. Also the soft taco matched with the cabeza. Due to the portion these tacos were filling. The two tacos I had were more delicious and tasty than the burrito I ate during my first here. 

Even though La Taqueria is known for its burritos I highly recommend ordering the tacos. To delve in your taco experience order one taco crispy and the other soft. Since the portion of the tacos at La Taqueria is huge two tacos are more than enough. I'm definitely glad I came back at La Taqueria for National Taco Day.
author: Gerald R.

description:
After living in New York City for 7+ years I learned that just 'cos a restaurant always has a line out the door, gets glowing 5 star ratings on Yelp, and is written up as the "best", does NOT mean it's gonna live up to all the hype. Seeing as I hate to wait in line, it took me several weeks to sample a veggie taco at La Taqueria. And, actually, aside from the ever-present line, La Taqueria's steep prices turned me away more than once. 

I'm a SF native and live for the kind of food La Taqueria serves up. Whenever I leave the Bay Area, I crave our delicious burritos and tacos. However, in this so-called "sucka free city," I try to not let myself be bamboozled.

I just spent $6.85 for a taco and chips! It was the smallest and most expensive veggie taco I've ever purchased and chips were not included. [I also went back later to sample a veggie burrito - for $6.31. It was the same size as what other taquerias refer to as a "baby burrito." Great if you're a light eater like me, but why pay top dollar for a half-size burrito?!]. 

The food was good but I refuse to join the ranks of stubborn locals who insist that this is the best of the best or ill-informed out-of-towners, who must read about La Taqueria in their tourist guides, and pay close to twice what I'd pay at any other Mission district taqueria.

If you're reading this and debating whether or not La Taqueria is worthy of your $$$ and time, I'd suggest you go elsewhere (La Corneta, on Mission near 23rd St. is a good option - with lower prices, shorter lines, and chips and salsa included). 

Then again, if you're someone who likes to follow the crowd, equates a long line with reputability, and can handle high prices and small portions, go get in line at La Taqueria!
author: Beau W.

description: Long line - great smell of fresh tortillas and grilled meat. Service is quick and efficient, but it is SO crowded. The food is quite good and portions are huge. I had a taco with about 1/2 pound of lengua. Very tender and flavorful, but the burritos are the star here - filled with your choice of meat, beans, and deliciousness. I can easily recommend this place for a decent bit of Mexcian yum.
author: Deb S.

description: Talk about OVERRATED!!!!  Finally visited this Saturday and had both super tacos and burrito, 30 bucks later and a near by trash can and I just don't get it. It's greasy, lacking flavor and just underwhelming.  The tacos lacked salt and even though they had cheese it was just flavorless grease.  The burrito which costs $-1-3, was tiny and also lacking flavor. The emperor has NO CLOTHES PEOPLE!!
author: Eddie H.

description:
(CASH ONLY; no bathroom)
Recommended: Lengua (Tongue) Tacos, Pollo (Chicken) Tacos, anything really.

La Taqueria has the BEST tacos in the Mission District (and pretty much all of SF). Because it is so famed, there are long lines wrapping around the corner of the block. The wait is worth it though! One doesn't have to wait long after ordering to get the food. Because of its immense popularity, there is limited seating. I recommend taking your food to go and have a stroll around the Mission.

What makes this place stand out is the sense of community. This place has a family feel to it- the owner even comes out and talks with the customers! You can understand why many return weekly to get their taco-fix.

Having went to school in San Diego, I am quite snobby when it comes to the quality of tacos/Mexican food anywhere north of San Diego. I set the bar very high, but La Taqueria met the abnormally high expectations. I took my college roommate here and we both agreed that it is hard to find quality tacos in Northern California. Thus, La Taqueria seems like an oasis in a desert...a taco-less desert.

Rating Breakdown:
5=Great food and/or service
4=Good food
3=Meh
2=Not so good food/service
1=Terrible food and/or service
author: Felix T.

description: Long line warning, be prepared to snake your way about dining tables and people gathered around the area. Forget about your previous conception of what tacos are, these are not your run of the mill, fast and cheap $1 tacos. In fact these are some of the most expensive tacos i ever had. After eating the carne asada, carnitas and the lengua tacos with the carne asada as super taco, i am convinced this place is not worth the hype. Simply put, the best thing here is the lengua and its the only taco im willing to shell out $5 for. However, thats if im in SF, compared to the streets of east LA, this would be no contest. I find it hard to fathom why anyone would be willing to wait in line for overpriced tacos.
author: Ji T.

description:
Disclaimer: CALL IN YOUR ORDER TO AVOID INCREDIBLY LONG WAIT TIMES!! 

I didn't bring lunch one day and was craving Mexican food.  My co-workers raved about this place and how "this place stomps on other local Mexican places in the area." Dang bold words. So I thought, hey, let's give it another try and get what they get.

I got two super carne asada tacos for $6.40 each plus tax. My first thought was, dang that is crazy expensive for a taco! An ugly looking one as a matter of fact. However, upon my first few bites I realized that this is not your ordinary taco and you do get a lot of bang for your buck. The crispy taco shell wrapped in a soft flour tortilla is genius and adds amazing texture. They serve generous amounts of juicy large chunks of carne asada. Also, don't be cheap add the extra few bucks and make it a super since the guac, cheese, and sour cream marry well with the meat. This is also a huge taco, the biggest one I have ever had. Two tacos filled me up perfectly. Granted as I was eating it, a lot of it was smeared on my face, but hey it was that good!

In the future, would I come back yes! However, I think I'll order the carne asada super tacos rather than the burrito (which has no rice) and the quesadilla which wasn't that impressive last time.
author: Melissa N.

description:
The best Mexican food I've ever eaten. Be prepared to wait. The line goes out the door and stays there. 
You won't be disappointed. It's worth the wait. 
You may get a bigger burrito some place else, void of flavor
. You have to salsa it up to taste like something.nor here. Lots of flavor. Quality over quantity. And it's still a good size burrito.
author: Karal K.

description: Very delicious place, but be prepared for a line and wait. I ordered 1 lengua taco and 1 super taco, with a side of chips and salsa and guac to share, and left very full. The meat was very tender, and they are generous with the cheese and sour cream. I'm so glad that this spot is only 2 blocks from my place as I'm sure I'll be back often. It is cash only.
author: Ken W.

description:
Best burritos and tacos in San Francisco! 
Always busy with a line out the door. These tortillas have a distinct La Taqueria flavour different from other Mexican places....perhaps it's the crispiness or the queso? Very authentic and reasonably priced. Big stuffed and delicious?
author: Kitchen Witch W.

description: Finally went to this spot! Came here with some co-workers for lunch and it was an overall very positive experience. Is it the best Mexican food I've ever had? Nope. Is it super super good? Oh yeah. We arrived here around 12:00pm on a Tuesday afternoon and the place was packed. we waited in line around 20 minutes to order and had to kinda hustle to find seating. I ordered a super burrito with carne asada and also got a strawberry fresca. We had to wait another 10-15 minutes for the food and when it came we chowed down. The burrito was very good. Meat was nice and juicy. The drink was nice and tasty and the fresh strawberries were great. This spot is a little out of my way, but I would definitely recommend coming down here to check it out. it's some very solid Mexican food!
author: James R.

description: Way too long line for a subpar burrito. The lack of rice makes for a soggy burrito and the chicken was super dry.
author: Joanna L.

description:
I'm giving la taqueria 4 stars cuz the food is f**** delicious!! Straight up MEXICAN food!!! At its finest like comemos alla en Mexico DF. 
The only reason It's not 5 stars is bcuz there's little to no customer service, I mean they're so damn busy that there's no time for anything else 
Even tho I don't go there for customer service it's still nice to be greeted and such. That's far from happening cuz they're too busy making that delicious burros and tacos!! 
This was my first time at la taqueria and won't be my last, in fact I already have another trip with my lady set to go straight from the airport to la taqueria with NO stops in between. The food is really good there 
La salsa tambien todo tastes fresh and you csn taste the love they really put into the food. 
Place is super busy but it's super busy for a reason, for the ones complaining about the price, go to damn Mc Donald's and get a meal that tastes disgusting and you pay 7 bucks for it!! There you have it 

If you enjoy comida mexicana auténtica!!! Look no further this is the place to be!! Plain and simple 
Delicioso
author: Nando D.

description: Really good!! This is CASH ONLY which is unfortunate but it was so worth it to me! The place was packed but worth it!! I got the carne asada taco and it was a 10/10!!
author: Alyssa J.

description:
This spot is our favourite burrito place in the mission and it helps that we only live a couple of blocks away. We always bring out of town guests here and it's always a huge hit. 

My recommendation is the carne asada super but you know what? Everything is good. Always a toss up between the carnitas and carne asada. Try the lengua (beef tongue) for a different texture, if you want to try something new but really, can't go wrong with anything else on the menu. 

Okay great, now I'm craving a burrito!
author: Eunah T.

description:
Probably the best burrito I've ever had. Every ingredient in their food tastes so fresh and is yummy. Their horchata with their super burrito is a MUST HAVE.  

Although the lines are always long, it is definitely worth the wait. I also am infatuated with the fact how their burritos don't contain any rice which not only allows me to actually finish a burrito, but to enjoy all the other flavors without the rice absorbing it. For sure my number one taqueria.
author: Payal R.

description:
I finally tried this place a few weeks ago and I'm glad I did!
I read all the great reviews and knew this was a Mission staple so I'm glad I finally got to experience it first hand.

I will say that service could have been a little better and it was also sort of unclear where we were supposed to order and pick up our food from. Seating is also pretty scarce but I guess that's because the place is always so busy.

The food however, is authentic, fresh, flavorful and best of all, cheap.
I took the advice of other Yelpers and got my tacos 'El Dorado style', where they wrap the soft taco shell around a hard inner shell, and it was indeed good! 

I'll definitely be stopping by this place again next time I'm in the Mission.
author: Sahil S.

description: By far the best carne asada burrito and carnitas super taco I've ever had!
author: Jessica P.

description:
I knew coming to San Francisco that I needed to go to La Taqueria. There were so many online reviews for this place and it just caught my attention and I don't regret it! I love authentic Mexican food and this really hit the spot! It drove my taste buds crazy with how delicious every single bite was! The atmosphere is great and the people there are friendly and prepare every single plate with love and perfection! 

I recommend the Carne Asada burrito!
author: Javier F.

description: This packed place with a long line is worth checking out. The line moves fast and the employees are working even faster. Simples menu without many options. We ordered 4 tacos, carne, carnitas, cabeza, and pollo. Regular with corn tortilla, with a side of chips with salsa and avocado. The food is delicious and each taco is made with a generous amount of meat. My favorite was the carne and carnitas. Would definitely go back and try more items!
author: Gabriella H.

description: Among the best tacos I've ever had. Good chips and salsa too. Pretty touristy, which was what I was expecting.
author: Evan L.

description: Great vegan burritos and tacos. Add the chips & salsa for amazing pico de gallo.
author: Joe M.

description: This place serves some good authentic burritos and tacos.  The line was long and seats were hard to come by, and I didn't understand until I took my 1st bite of my burrito.  In that moment, I realized that the food was authentic and delicious.  I devoured the burrito, and everything that was used in it tasted fresh.  I would definitely eat there again.
author: Bradley S.

description:
San Francisco's Mission District started it all - those Mission-style burritos, known for their ginormous size overstuffed with ingredients.  Somewhere on Mission Street, there's a glowing logo in bright neon lights that reads: La Taqueria - The Best Tacos & Burrito in the Whole Word.  That's a very bold statement to live by.  But their name consistently makes the lists of top taquerias, even winning ESPN's FiveThirtyEight NCAA-like burrito bracket.  There are no offal selections in their tourney so it really didn't interest me that much.

La Taqueria has been in our radar ever since our older daughter read about their carnitas burrito being crowned by FiveThirtyEight as America's Best Burrito.  Just like everything that's popular and hyped, line was out the door, wrapping around the tables inside.  When it was finally our turn, we chose the carnitas and carne asada burritos plus the lengua, cabeza, and carne asada tacos.  A mango and watermelon aguas frescas completed our cash-only order.  Prices were on the steeper side, but the burritos and tacos were loaded with lots of meat.  Finding a table was the next challenge.  Luckily, we were able to find a vacant spot in one of the shared tables.  There wasn't much elbow room which was expected.

The texture and flavor of the carnitas were good, but it was the carne asada that was the true frontrunner here.  I thought it was skirt steak, but it was top sirloin.  It's not marinated; they just add some salt before grilling then brush it with their secret seasoning while on high heat.  Burritos didn't come with rice which they said was typical of traditional burritos, saving my wife the trouble of telling them to exclude it.  We had ours Dorado style, i.e., griddled to a golden brown giving that crispy exterior.  The lengua and cabeza were tender, moist, and tasty.  We were fortunate to have one of those bottled green salsa nearby and I got a bit carried away squeezing it on my tacos.  Good stuff!

It can't be the best if they don't have tripas, buche, or even al pastor.  However, the carne asada was outstanding which made me round this review up to a four.  Add to that the option to have it Dorado style.  So good!  Also, the quality and freshness of the meat and everything else were very noticeable.  There's too much publicity over the carnitas; if the article featured their chorizo as the winner, then everyone would be raving about it too.  Just get the carne asada - there's no bracket required to proclaim it as the real champion.
author: John L.

description: This is probably the best Mexican joint in the city, it's everything that anyone had ever said it would be. Ordered the famous Super Burrito with steak, it was truly amazing and the hype is real. The place might look really busy, but honestly the line moves really fast so it's worth the wait. If you haven't tried this place out you must!
author: Roman L.

description: This place is a fraud. Heard about it through multiple websites claiming it to be one of the best mexican restaurants in the country, far from it. There's definitely a lot of hype to this place (as the prices reflect). I know food is SF is more expensive than others, but this place is just rape. $13 for a super burrito no where near the size of my forearm and $7 for a super taco is just loco. There are way better cheaper alternatives in the mission. I still prefer Oakland taco trucks, but I cannot recommend this place if you have a craving while in SF. Also, cash only.
author: Peter L.

description: Yes, believe the hype. This place is that good. Lines get long, but totally worth it. The tacos have huge portions - so order accordingly. Carne asada and beef tongue were so good!
author: Steven W.

description:
This a great mission district taqueria. The flavor of food here is outstanding. I always get the steak super burrito and it's tasty. The portions are decent, they would fill up a normal person. Tacos look amazing. Definitely a must try.

Cash only here
author: Kevin S.

description: Omg! The burrito was amazing! The cheese really added to it. I got it -dorado- so the tortilla was lightly toasted and the cheese beautifully melted One was not enough . The super tacos looked amazing too ! Will deff try them next time I'm in the area . New go to place for a burrito  in the mission
author: Luz- V.

description: Good burritos but not worth the $13. Coming from Stockton where Mexican food is everywhere a burrito like that can be easily found in most taco trucks for half price.
author: Albert A.

description:
What to write that has not been said in the previous 2700 reviews?
So... The tacos: @ 3.75 are a great value. But do them "super" style (cheese, guac & sour cream) they inflate to 6$. Pricey? Yes!!! But they are stuffed with quality protein, and 2 will suffice or three to fill your fat stomach full.
The pollo tacos were the low point... More flavor can be found with the cabeza or the greasy chorizo.. And the carnitas was a real crowd pleaser.
I'd say that at 85% of the tables peeps were grinding on the burritos. They offer the best value, and apparently one of the best in the city... I have buyers remorse and burrito envy, shoulda done my homework.
author: Ari J.

description: As always, this place rocks. I particularly enjoy the carne asada burrito. The vegetarian super burrito without sour cream is so delicious. The tacos are good but not like Baja tacos . They have red salsa. I prefer just onion and cilantro. Still, it's always been my favorite burrito place in SF.
author: Rude G.

description:
Be prepared to wait in line at peak hours because La Taqueria is super popular! We got there around 6 PM on a Sunday and the line was out the door. We must have waited for at least half an hour to place our order, and then another 5-10 minutes for the food to come out. Seeing how ESPN's FiveThirtyEight dubbed La Taqueria's burrito as America's best burrito a couple years back, the wait is not a big surprise.

Since seating is limited and hot food is best enjoyed hot, we had to watch tables like a hawk to try and snag one as a group finishes. We got lucky and were able to grab one--there's no pushing or anything but you definitely can't be shy if you want a table! One of us waited while the other one continued waiting in line. 

Since we were still a bit full from lunch, ordering two burritos was out of the question. We decided beforehand that we would get a super burrito (ordering "super" adds sour cream, cheese and avocado) to share and an order of chips and salsa. However, standing in line gave me a lot of time to peruse the menu and make side plans with my tummy so by the time I made it to the register, I was convinced we should leave with no regrets xD I ended up ordering a super chicken burrito, a super carnitas taco, chips with salsa AND guacamole, and a large watermelon agua fresca. Needless to say, my "go big or go home" attitude towards delicious food on this trip occasionally proved problematic...

The super chicken burrito was good but we were surprised that the chicken, although juicy, was not grilled/did not come packed with more flavor. We were actually more impressed with the carnitas taco, which was tender and delicious. Tacos come wrapped in two tortillas--one crispy and one soft. The crispy one really gave our carnitas taco its oomph. Chips with salsa and guacamole were standard, although the chips were slightly harder than I am used to. The watermelon fresca was super refreshing on a summer day..highly recommend!
author: Kit W.

description:
Im no a racist but this was a bland touristy meme worthy white people unseasoned meat burrito. It's weirdly popular for no reason I can fathom. The ambiance is crappy and the service is crappier and they're arrogant for some reason. It's astonishingly price for shit food because all the yuppie dumbasses flocking to the mission are buying into it.  Contrary to their claim its the WORST BURRITO IN THE WORLD!!!!!!! WORST BURRITO EVER. BLAND BLAND BLAND.

I don't remember tasting anything during the meal. Also my FIRST BITE WAS A HUGE PIECE OF FAT. I had to get up and spit it out into a trash can. Ordering was a pain in the ass because there's no line. I recommended trying this place with some out of town friends and it was an embarrassment. I highly recommend never ever going here. Also they tried to not let me have the chips I paid for.
author: Bryan D.

description: So my wife did her research and found out that La Taqueria is one of the oldest Taquerias in the Mission district.  Well oiled machine.  Quick and easy to order.  Almost too quick as I didn't grasp how to order.  My fault totally.  I didn't realize that if I wanted things like lettuce, cheese, sour cream,etc. on my burrito I had to request it and pay for it.  Pork was amazing.  Chorizo good too.  I had a burritto and taco (wanted both couldn't decide... WAY TO MUCH FOOD TO GET BOTH.)  Wife had a delicious quesadilla.
author: Adam B. J.

description: The best burrito areound! The green salsa was delicious! Cheap and delicious!! Don't try other place!
author: Veronica M.

description:
Simply, this is where you eat tacos in San Fran. 

Authentic, buzzing, welcoming, tasty. 

I try and not get nostalgic about eating at restaurants, but sitting outside enjoying my crunchy carne asada tacos, looking out at the iconic mural painted on the facade of The Mission Cultural Center was, well... right.
