Chow down.
author: Sam J.

description:
This is my all-time favorite taqueria, amazing food! From their burritos to their quesadillas..

HOWEVER, as I bought a burrito to-go today and unwrapped it at my office, I found a glove.. literally. 
What I first thought was maybe cheese; was a worker's glove. 

Love this place, everyone makes mistakes, but come on.. a glove in my food...
author: Karan K.

description: It has been said countless times on Yelp, and on many food blogs: La Taqueria's carne asada burrito, dorado style, is the best burrito in the country. Ask for extra green (hot) sauce on the side, and bring your cash.
author: J. B.

description: Like they need more positive reviews! I live a block away and sometimes the delectable smell of the carne asada roasting away just drives me to distraction, and I brave the deservedly long lines for some succulent burrito goodness, ignoring the confusion of figuring out where to order, and with the pleasant option of getting take out which I can eat very soon at my own kitchen table. Nom nom nom.
author: Tim P.

description:
BOMB diggity, can't go wrong with the best taco joint in SF! I came here on a Sunday night at around 6pm and the place was hella buzzing. It took us around 15 -20 min to line up to place the order and to get the food, and a tad of a struggle to find seats.

I got two tacos, one asada and one carnita. I didn't want cilantro which they noted, but then they took out the pico de gallo completely T__T I pretty much just got meat and beans but it was delicious nonetheless.

I'll be here PRETTY often, and will definitely get a super taco for next time yass
author: Ivy W.

description:
Suffice to say: once you've had the burrito here, Chipotle will never taste the same to you ever again. 

Fantastic burrito and quick service. The lines are long since this is a popular place so keep that in mind. The price is decent for what you get.
author: Taimur A.

description: There are a ton of taquerias to choose from in the Mission District. My wife and I received several suggestions from friends on a recent trip to SFO. However, La Taqueria was rated the best on most lists/apps. So as proper tourists, we couldn't resist. It. Was. Worth. It. The line was to the door and then some, but the wait wasn't bad at all. About 20 minutes to order and another 10 or so to get food. The burritos were delicious! Definitely a dining experience you must try when visiting.
author: Jason W.

description: I FOUND YOU!!! you were in Downtown San Jose and u left me decades ago! No notice no nothing but now i found you and the taste is the same!! Oh made my toes curl! The asada was juicy, perfect! Lengua tacos were very flavorful! My sister in law got chorizo she said it was amazing. The horchata ga damn its good! The only thing is that i took to-go for the husband and they didnt taste the same. The integrity of the tortilla doesnt last. If u go u have to eat there. Service was fast! They havent changed their ordering style quick and easy. DONT LEAVE AGAIN!!
author: Gloria M.

description:
If you happen to be strolling along the Mission District in San Francisco while craving Mexican food and are on an empty stomach, do yourself a big favor. Go to "La Taqueria". Enough said. As crazy as this sounds, I actually came here for the first time back in the mid-90's when I was still living in the Bay Area (before relocating to Sacramento in 2001). And back then, it was not nearly as busy as it is now. 

Jump forward to 2016 and you will find an eclectic variety of gentrified hipsters, musicians, techies, tourists, and families that keep the business here alive and kicking. Since it has been over a decade, I remember it being one of my go-to spots for real-deal no frills Mexican food. The menu is basic; tacos, burritos, and quesadillas. And simple is better since the flavor and quality is ridiculously legit.

The inside of this place is small; especially if there's a line that snakes around the restaurant. Therefore, seating is extremely limited. There are very few seats on the outside so my best recommendation is to take your food to-go. However, even on the most busiest days, you are able to walk up, order your food, and get out within 10 minutes. My lady and I came on a Sunday afternoon around 5pm and since we ate only a few hours prior, one taco each would carry us over. Therefore, we both chose their "Carne Asada Taco" (priced at $3.75). The price is a little steep but they give you generous portions + you're in the heart of the tourist trap Mission District.

Our food arrives in less than 5 minutes. However the bag only had our two tacos. So we basically had to go back to the counter and ask for salsa. Not a big deal but we like to spice our tacos up for flavor. Since it was jam packed with people running like chickens with their heads cut off, we luckily found nearby seating outside of a laundromat! And the weather cooperated with us as it was still sunny and mild, even after 5pm.

One bite of these tacos and I was in absolute heaven. I can't quite pinpoint the seasonings that "La Taqueria" provides but my oh my, each succulent bite was bursting with flavor. And I have to say, I've had some killer tacos in my time (especially being born and raised in California my whole life) and "La Taqueria" is definitely in my top 5 best taco places I've ever eaten at.

One surprising thing is that when I ate here years ago, they had VERY late hours; even open past midnight at times. I only remember this because this was my spot after my share of bar and clubhopping back in the 90's. However, they do stay open until 9pm on most nights. Overall, the quality of food paired up with decent prices and quite, attentive customer service gives this place a unanimous five-star rating. So do yourself a favor, go to "La Taqueria". It truly is real-deal Mexican food!
author: Donovan H.

description: We like the crispy vegetarian tacos. The chips and guacamole are fresh. Also they have the drink horchata. Super yummy!
author: Yovana M.

description:
El Farolito is good but La Taqueria is amazing. I didn't think I liked Mexican food, until I ate here. Get the super burrito grilled. It's the best thing on the menu! 

The horchata is standard.
author: Becca U.

description: I had been waiting to go to this place the entire time I was in SF and it indeed did live up to the hype! I had an al pastor Dorado style as everyone has recommended and it was excellent.  And the size of the burrito was wild!  Definitely go here if you have the time!
author: Maurice O.

description:
Saw a FB ad for this place and decided to check it out on a lazy Sunday.  It was super crowded with a line snaking through the tables, menu is simple.  While standing in line a person takes your order and gives you a ticket. You make your way to the register to pay them wait for your number to be called. As busy and crowded as it is their system works well. We ordered 2 carne asada super burritos, chips n salsa, a small soda and 1 beer, 35.00
The food was ready quickly, the burritos were not huge but they were perfect. Well marinated good quality carne, no gristle. You could taste everything in every bite. 
I did have a person decide I was their best friend and I should buy them cheese while I was in line, not sure what that was about but it was a little uncomfortable until security asked them to leave.
author: Samantha H.

description: I can only comment on the veggie burrito and it was lacklustre at best. There is no rice (boo) and while everything was fresh and the salsa on the tables had a great kick, it just didn't quite come together right. It wasn't awful by any means but it was hardly the best burrito I have ever had. I'm not really sure why this place is so popular.
author: Ada C.

description: I went here today and ordered a super beef taco. The wait was long and there weren't any open tables, but by golly that taco was worth it!!! Sour cream, guacamole, salsa, and very tender steak. This place is always packed because it's so delicious and affordable - if you have the patience for eating your food standing up, it's totally worth it.
author: Chelsey B.

description: I'll be brief: hands down, the moist delicious Burrito I've eaten in my life. The line is a bit long, but for a change it's for a good reason.
author: Erez E.

description:
We came the second they opened their doors at 11am on a Sunday. Immediately, a line formed inside. After trying El Farolito for the first time just before coming here, there was such a clear difference between flavor and meat quality! It's way better here, and I could see why lines formed more quickly here. Locals know their mexican food out here in the Mission. 

The burritos are smaller here for the price and no one wears gloves while handling the food (lol) but I'd return in a heartbeat. The meat was so tender and juicy, and everything was made fresh. Large cuts of meat are cooking on the grill at all times, dripping with natural juices. They're like a well oiled machine, the way everything is ordered, cooked, assembled, and wrapped in an efficient assembly line. Inside is quite nice too, with plenty of tables and benches for both small and large parties alike.

If you're ordering to-go, be sure to ask for salsa because they dont give it to you unless you ask.
author: Ivy C.

description: Definitely not the best burrito, maybe their just rushing and and that takes a toll on the quality and taste of the food. The prices are  expensive. Seating is limited and its a small place. I tried it once will not go back. Save your money and go to taco bell. Theses folks need to go elsewhere for great tasting mexican food cause this place is not that good.  I can honesty say this place is overrated.
author: Miguel R.

description: If you want to fill your tummy, come here :) But come before you are really hungry, because most of the time, there will be a line. This is our 3rd time here. Even though we wait not only for ordering but also for the food, we are happy :) Only problem can be sitting. They accept only cash, keep in mind, but they have ATM machine too :)
author: Angela K.

description:
I'mma be real with you. I'm hella confused now. I used to run around screaming that El Faro has the best burritos in the world but my stomach and heart have found its match with La Taqueria. But I'm going to lay out some facts right now - you cannot compare the two burritos. La Taqueria's doesn't have rice and while I was originally skeptical, I have been somewhat converted.

Here's the thing: LT is amazing in its simplicity. It is proof that you don't needa be making things complicated to have a delicious meal. Amazing carne asada, fresh ingredients, and hella avocado. It's food in its purest and tastiest form.

Here's what your meal should consist of:
1. Super EVERYTHING. You need the guac, you need the pico. 
2. El Dorado whatever super thing you ordered.
3. Carnitas is borderline life changing.
4. Chips and guac
5. Every. agua. fresca.

Bring cash. Scope for tables. Do not expect to leave without one of the happiest food comas.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
SUPER BURRITO- BEEF TONGUE 
HONESTLY ONE OF THE BEST BURRITOS IN THE CITY! Everything about this burrito is amazing! The amount that they give of everything is perfect. The tongue I can say is one of the best. Definitely would recommend getting it for sure!
author: Tiffany C.

description: Despite the fact the gave me the wrong burritos & wrong tacos, it was still pretty damn good I must say. I came all the way from San Jose just to try this place. & it was the BEST I ever had. The carne asada was so delicious, even though I had ordered lengua. The agua frescas were BOMB. & the tacos de cabeza, oh my god The long line was worth the wait. I definitely will be coming back here again, let's just hope they get my order right next time
author: Airiana R.

description: Went there on a Sunday afternoon with my lady. Was busy but not crazily so, and they have a good system of ordering in one line, paying up front (cuidado: cash only!) and waiting by the front. Our burritos were amazing - fresh ingredients, really tasty, and this is key, our burritos were perfectly folded and not overstuffed, hence there was no mess when eating it. I can't tell you how many times I've bitten into an overstuffed burrito and it rips open and becomes a slimy mess. Anyways, La Tacqueria is as great and legendary as it's always been. Highly recommend.
author: Bob C.

description: With the vast array of taquerias in the mission district it's hard to narrow down the right one to go to. I will start off by saying that there are definitely better ones out there but it's still very good. I went around 3pm on a Saturday and it was crowded! I managed to find a place to sit however. I got the super chicken burrito which I would recommend and the chips and salsa which were also pretty good. The burritos are HUGE. Another note is that this place is cash only - which can kind of be an inconvenience. I would definitely come back here but I'm not sure it's worth the long lines.
author: Nuzhat K.

description:
Best tacos I had so far - in my life! Ordered tacos with "carne asada" and a corn quesadilla with chicken - and both were absolutely delicious. Little did I know about how juicy plain shredded chicken could be. This place is a must if you are looking for fresh, tasty and simple food and don't mind the wait in line and eating at a very busy restaurant. We waited around 20 minutes to place our order and then another 15 minutes or so to get our food. Not too bad in my opinion, just be aware that the place can be VERY busy. The service was very friendly and the lady who took our order explained the menu options and gave recommendations although she had lots of work to do. 

Bring enough cash, as you can't pay with card! If you're still hungry afterwards, head to nearby Mission Pie for dessert.
author: Silke H.

description:
La Taqueria is strictly business!

Basically, you order at a counter to a lady with zero personality at such a staccato pace you almost fall over. Not the nicest greeting you'll ever get, but when you pick up your food from the kitchen window (when they call your number) all of that fluff doesn't mean a hoot. The food is soooooooooo good, you don't need smiles and niceties to bowl you over. All you need is the food to be this good to bowl you over, and it was and does.

Our burrito's were as good as any burrito we ever had and we had a Latina with us who is an authority on this stuff.  
There is no rice in their burritos which was just fine, but these creamy smooth beans and great meats to choose from.
The chicken was my favorite. 

We got one "Super" and one regular burrito and I loved the "Super" style. There was so much shmutzik in this baby, I could have used a straw to eat it. You needed a chisel to wipe the smile off of my face I was so happy.

The green chile salsa was scorching hot which I also loved.

This restaurant was a real find. I doubt I'll ever come to S.F. and not come here for a burrito, ever!
author: Sidney Z.

description: Best burrito ever! Came here on the recommendation of a friend who stated this place is known to have the best burritos in the Mission. It sure did not disappoint! I love how you can get it "crispy". I ordered the super burrito and it was amazing. Perfect portions of all ingredients, fresh, and well-seasoned carne asada. I also got a horchata which had just the right amount of sweetness. Chips and salsa taste super refreshing too! Definitely will be back for more burritos :)
author: Carolyn L.

description:
Food:4/5      Price: 2/5        Service:4/5     Ambience:4/5

*** Food Network ***

La Taqueria is a bit over-rated. Okay I admit that it's pretty cool to see their famous Carne Asada (beef) being grilled at the back, but it honestly just taste like any other beef. I have to say I've had way better burrito, quesadilla and tacos at much cheaper prices.

La Taqueria is over-priced AND small. A small hand-sized burrito for more than $10? It's not even gourmet and served on a plate, just wrapped in foil on a plastic tray. The flavors were just like any other burritos.  Next, a meat quesadilla for $8.50 is just too much. I went with chorizo which turned out to be minced pork in red oil....blah. The flour tortilla was fried and oily too. If I order quesadilla again, I will probably go with beef or some other non-oily meat choices. or simply not order this overpriced thing. Lastly a $4 small taco with basically a few chunks of meat and some beans? 

Over rated, over hyped, mediocre taste.  

Favorites:
* Carne Asada super burrito ($10.90) - beef with beans, pico de gallo, sour cream, cheese, avocado

Others:
* Chorizo flour quesadilla ($8.50)
* Carne Asada taco ($4)
author: Victoria L.

description: Don't listen to the negative reviews this place is amazing. Try the super tacos but make sure it has the soft and crispy tortilla! Get the mission style carne asada burrito as well!
author: Jesus V.

description:
FOOD: The sheer volume of reviews speaks for itself. This is my favorite burrito in San Francisco because there is no RICE in the way obstructing my flavor experience. Get the burrito super (you NEED the guac) and get it "el dorado" style (sizzles on the grill for a bit so it's "dorado" = golden). The first time I came here, I was not that impressed, but I did not know the golden secret. Now I crave that glorious first bite, when your teeth sink into the crispy layer of the tortilla, then the chewy, then the flavor-packed meat and fresh avocado. 

- I personally always get the chicken super burrito and every friend I've taken here for some reason buys the carne asada super burrito. Both are fabulous. Tacos are solid as well, but I would rather go to a taco specialty place for those. I find the corn tortillas here a little too large (2 tacos feels like too much food, but 1 will not hit the spot) and the ratio of filling:tortilla too small to fulfill its flavor potential.

- Veg warning: I have found the vegetarian taco I ordered here to be bland. The La Taqueria flavor fairy doesn't wave the wand over the beans (if at all) as he/she does over the meat. 

PRO TIP: call to order ahead and then skip the line. Do check your bag to see what you receive--I walked out with one carne asada super and one carnitas last time instead of one chicken. 

SERVICE: Do be aware this is CASH ONLY. There is a Chase across the way, but if you are coming solo you don't want to be crying tears of frustration as you walk it to the ATM. Friendly cashier who hands out roses to lucky ladies (you should have seen the face of the 4 y/o in front of me light up!).

AMBIANCE: Frenzy of prep cooks calling out orders, all the sounds of excited tourists and locals yelling over it, and mad frying happening in the kitchen. This is not a place for an intimate conversation or to work (HA!). Though it is always packed, if you are diligent you will find seating for your party, but do be friendly enough to share the bigger tables with others :). I liked the old menu board better, but they now use a lot of flat TVs lined up continuously. Flashes with reviews/tweets a bit too much for my liking.
author: Helen W.

description:
Maybe I just had a overall terrible experience... but the food was still delicious. First off, they only take cash and only have signs of that INSIDE. There is a order line, a pay line, and a wait time line, along with the waiting for a table line.

The taco although was super delicious I wouldn't come back to look for parking, withdraw cash, and wait for a spot.

No thank you.... gtg!
author: Crystal C.

description: Several months back, we came across La Taqueria's Instagram page. Yesterday we made the 1.5 drive up north to San Francisco. We HAD make a pit stop at La Taqueria! We had a crispy super taco, a regular taco, flour quesadilla and the chips with avocado and salsa, all with Carne Asada. The food was delicious and worth the struggle of looking for a parking and the wait in line. Definitely a place worth stopping by when in San Francisco. We left La Taqueria fully satisfied!!
author: Nicole G.

description: This is my second visit to this place and its amazing! First time I had a quesadilla, really good. Second time around I had the crunchy tacos, ommmgggg! I have recommended coworkers to this location and they fell in love!
author: Nancy M.

description:
This place has the best tacos hands down. No one can compete with them. Everything here is spectacular. I am a regular here and probably my twentieth time here. Carne Asada tacos are the best. There's a reason why they are expensive because of the QUALITY QUALITY QUALITY. I wanted to try something a bit different today so I got the cabeza and by was it good and gelatinous. Their aguas fresca are A1. Strawberries were super fresh. Horchata is A1. Pineapples are amazing. 

TIP: If you get a burrito tell them you want it dorado style where they pan fry both sides so it's crispy
author: Brian C.

description:
Came here as our first stop for a mission taco crawl that a friend put together. Super delicious tacos but there were some issues getting our order correct. They gave us an extra taco and realized the entire order was incorrect. They already took my ticket stub so I wasn't able to prove that I had picked up the order. They ended up giving us another taco which again, was not what we ordered.

Poor experience overall but the tacos were tasty.
author: Jasper L.

description:
The place was relatively empty on a Thursday afternoon at 2 pm, and I was glad to find seats outside for my brother, fiance, and me to enjoy our food together. I had an amaaaazing lengua burrito with horchata here. Tip: Ask for your burrito to be grilled -- the tortilla becomes crispy and is absolutely thrilling to bite into. 

A+++++ to the gentleman behind the counter who is a non-stop meat-chopping MACHINE. I watched you, mesmerized, the whole time I was wolfing down my burrito. Whatever they're paying you, it's probably not enough.
author: Amy W.

description: Yesterday I woke up at 4AM, and flew across the United States. The only food I consumed during that entire time period was a pumpkin donut and a handful of popcorn, so I was ravenous. A girl from my school recommended that we come to La Taqueria to eat. The Mission District of SF is so beautiful and colorful! La Taqueria was super crowded when we arrived at around 12PM. It is a cash only establishment, but they have an ATM in the back. I ordered two lengua (beef tongue) tacos, which was a good amount of food for lunch for me. These tacos were STUFFED to the brim with tender, juicy, savory, incredible lengua. There was salsa verde on the table which was a delicious addition to the tacos. I cannot describe the satisfaction my lunch at La Taqueria gave me. It was a fabulous meal.
author: Anne S.

description:
I NEVER order crane asada from most places cuz I know it's been sittin there for a while in a heated pan and I can always do better at home. I heard by word of mouth about this place so when I happened upon it by chance I eagerly went in. The most expensive tacos I have ever paid for but, WAS WORTH EVERY PENNY!   

I didn't pay too much attention to the menu. I got 2 tacos. One al pastor & one carne asada.  The guacamole and the steaks were so freshly made!  I was watching as the steaks were being chopped up as they came hot off the grill to be filled in everyone's tacos!  THE BEST TACOS I've ever had from a taqueria!  I couldn't stop thinkin about them the next day!  I will be back every chance I get when I'm back in SF!  Thank you all for being so awesome La Taqueria!
author: Aureliano C.

description: During my visit to SF, I was told by five different people that I needed to go down to the Mission to get tacos, and most of them recommended I come here. The line was long, wrapped around the building, but it went pretty quickly. I ordered two beef tacos and a carnitas taco (my go-to), which was good because my friend poached one of the beef tacos from me. The tacos were really big, so it wasn't too big of a deal. I thought the beef taco was pretty good, but honestly I thought the carnitas was much juicier and more flavorful. It went really well with the green salsa as well! Overall, everything was well worth the wait!
author: Kristin W.

description: Crazy busy and crazy delicious. Make sure to ask for "dorado" style. Burrito or taco grilled on the outside which adds a nice crunch. The salsa on the tables is yummy, the meats are so tasty. It's loud and messy but it's a taqueria, so you expect that.
author: Becca F.

description:
First burrito I've had where rice isn't the main star. The meat is seasoned beautifully. And everything is super balanced. This burrito is on the wetter side be cautious with tearing Open the foil wrapper. (Mines bursted open a little). 

4 stars because everything was perfect. -1 star because a super burrito costs $12.35 before tax. 

Super burrito just adds Cheese. Sour cream. And avocado. 

Regular is Meat. Beans. And pico de gallo. 

Ps parking is also difficult.
author: Shawn M.

description: Amazing tacos! The line and crowd is very deserving. Cash only, so be prepared. Bank at corner helps. Great experience!
author: Joy M.

description:
As Beyonce says, I'm Texas forever like Bun B (felt appropriate to quote Queen Bey today- twins!). Tacos aren't just food in Texas; they're a religion, a way of life. We practically live on a taco diet, so my standards are higher than Snoop Dogg at any given moment in time. 

I got lucky on a Tuesday when the line was short and moved quickly. I ordered the carnitas taco (dorado style- crunchy tortilla wrapped in soft tortilla), and added avocado, of course. My life motto is to eat as much avocado as possible, and it seems especially crucial to take advantage now before the potential price hike. 

It only took me four minutes flat to INHALE this taco, which might be a strong indicator of how delicious it was. I know everyone's all about carne asada, but seriously, the carnitas were so flavorful, I wanted to cry tears of joy. I'm not sure if they gave me extra meat because I passed on the beans, but it was really filling. You have the option of upgrading to "super", which comes with sour cream, cheese, and avocado. 

I'm confused as to why they close at 9 PM on most nights. Midnight taco cravings are a regularity for me, and the legit taco shops in Texas definitely stay open late. But I can't complain too much, since I live within walking distance and can pop over any time (and buy extras to save for later). 

I was really skeptical about the hype surrounding La Taqueria, but I'll admit that it's legit. I'll have to stop trash talking the Mexican food in SF now.
author: Karen S.

description:
Yes, they are nice burritos and tacos, however I can't imagine them as being best in the USA. 
I went on a Saturday around lunchtime, it was quite crowded but the line moved quickly and I don't think I waited more than five minutes to place my order and then another minute or 2 minutes to pay.
The burrito was actually quite bland I had beef with beans, cheese, sauce and the usual contents. 
Seems that because it is famous, everyone is in a massive rush to get in get served and get out.
Would I come back? No, I'm probably more likely to try some of the other smaller places in the vicinity.
author: Michael L.

description:
Bring cash! Bring cash! If you take anything away from this review, let it be to please bring cash! 

We only had $10 which didn't allow us to get everything we wanted. We opted for the carne asada regular burrito and it was great. Can only imagine how everything else would've tasted if we had more cash! This place is a well oiled machine, it was packed and finding a seat was tough (we ate outside). Great place when in Mission, burrito was on point!

They do have an ATM but just bring cash.
author: Caitlin B.

description: First bite of the carnitas super burrito... 100% guac, next, 100% decent pork, then, 100% sour cream.. I tried to smush it together to get a mix but it ate like a wet soggy burrito.  It needs more texture or something and maybe that's the rice element that's missing, but it isn't even that it's just a lot of decent ingredients but not mixed very well.  The portion is quite small for a $15 burrito and the amount of meat is not too substantial either, and the worst part is one large piece of the pork was entirely gristle.  The green salsa is good.  two stars because there are plenty of other restaurants in the area who are competing price wise that make flavorful burritos that check all of the boxes of greasy taqueria deliciousness.  As a first timer merely making a guess here... they've gotten very greedy.
author: Patrick O.

description:
Mm... not sure if these tacos are worth the hype.

Bunch of our friends and I were in SF for a wedding and we came here because it was recommended as one of the best places to eat Mexican food. 
I'm pretty sure I had better tacos in Texas and NYC. 
The meat was a little dry and too chewy. Mid way through my meal, my tacos were falling apart and my hands were getting dirty because the tacos were too liquid-y. The sauce? or the juice from salsas and meat were making the taco soggy. It wasn't a pleasant meal.
It's also very packed at this restaurant. The line moved fast and the food came out fast, but finding seats were hard.

Also, there was a guitarist?musician? they gave us nasty looks when we didn't give her money after her "performance". Wasn't a pleasant dining experience.
author: Susan L.

description:
Three things:
1.  Get the super burrito - it is the regular + cheese + sour cream + avocado. 
2.  Grill the burritos. The extra crispy tortilla and melting cheese makes it taste so much better! I forgot to ask them to grill the burrito and it wasn't as awesome as the grilled ones. 
3.  The cantaloupe agua fresca is a MUST. I would go back to La Taqueria just for the agua frescas.
author: Margery W.

description: Solid taqueria in the mission with quick service. Despite a line of dozens of people out the door during the carnaval parade this past weekend, they churned through customers efficiently. Overall the regular burrito ~$9 could have been a little bit spicier in my opinion, but I made up for it by adding plenty of their delicious green salsa. The chips and salsa were middle of the road IMHO
author: Clayton B.

description: Crazy busy because of CarnivalSF 2018 but still was seated and servwd delicious food very quickly! Really great authentic Mexican food. Six coronitas for $11! Will be coming back for sure.
author: Keith M.

description:
Grossly overrated and overhyped. After making a special trip to try the "best burrito in America" I was so disappointed with this place. 

The service was trash. I asked for jalapenos and chips and was ignored straight to my face. The staff member made me feel like I did not even exist.

The burrito was average. At over $12, it was a ripoff. The tortilla was flimsy and not even heated. The rice and beans were so bland, straight out of a can. They were generous with the avocado, I'll give them that. The carne asada was the only thing that stood out because they added some spices, but it was far from the best burrito I've had, let alone the best in America. The green sauce at the tables was good too.

After reading so much about this place, I feel cheated. I feel bad writing this review because I seriously expected to be blown away.
author: Jawad E.

description: It's sad that an establishment that makes so much money has to be sued by employees to be paid and treated fairly. Disappointed!
author: Arnaldo A.

description:
I wish I had taken a photo of my taco (that sounds perverse), but seriously all kidding aside.  This was by far the best carnita super taco I've ever had.  My husband got the super burrito (super includes cheese, sour cream and guacamole).  We went on a Tuesday at 2pm and this place was packed!!  There was a line of about 8 people and not an available seat, but things move quickly here.  Cash only business, and $7.00 for a super taco seems a tad steep but you only need one (well I only needed one) and it's worth the price.  If you don't have cash on you there is an ATM inside the restaurant.  

Okay, update I have removed a star (would do 1.5 stars) due to seven hours later the beans from my taco and my husbands burrito was not terribly pleasant.  So be sure to either take some Beano or make certain that you will be in a well ventilated area or not on a first date. I have kept faltering between 3-4 stars since I couldn't do 3.5, but I would definitely give it a 5 still if it weren't for those darn yummy beans.
author: Christina K.

description:
Good burritos.  The prices however are way too much($12+ for a deluxe burrito) for mexican food. Make sure you get some of that sauce that they have, that's what makes the food there really stand out.
Be prepared to stand in line for about 10 minutes with little to no seating areas.
author: Andrew V.

description: Today I learned that dreams do come true... La Taqueria is absolutely dreamy. Fresh and delicious. We got the carne asada and chicken tacos. And the strawberry Agua fresca. Highly recommend it all! This place has been hyped up to me and lived up to the hype.
author: Bryce Y.

description:
$50 for two burritos and a quesadilla. And they weren't good at all. Don't listen to people with no taste buds this place isn't good, sorry. And my friend couldn't even finish the quesadilla without spitting it out! 

Okay. They have excellent horchatas so I gave them one more star.
author: Porshea L.

description:
Perfect burritos. You line up, order, threaten people for their seats, pick up your order, go back to your seats that you bullied someone out of, and then enjoy some perfect burritos. Kidding aside, this place is just packed to the brim; it's like organized chaos. Also, you can order other things and it will all taste great while the prices are still average. 

Go for: some very nice fast food mexican food

Don't go for: if you are scared of people (i.e. it's crazy busy)
author: John V.

description: La taqueria is one of the "famous" taco and burrito places in San Francisco. They differentiate by not putting rice in your burrito (only meat and beans inside) and they give you the option to toast the burrito (called al dorado). I highly recommend getting your burrito al dorado because it gives the tortilla a better taste. I was a little disappointed that the prices were higher than the other really good burrito places ($12 vs $9 for the super burrito). Since there is no rice its not as big or as filling. The one good thing is that the line moves really fast so wait time is not bad.
author: Karim I.

description: I totally recommend La Taqueria for anyone looking for some good tacos/burritos in the Bay Area. Están deliciosos!
author: Gabriela R.

description: Want to preface this by saying that the 1 Star has has nothing to do with the service but has everything to do with the "tacos" and the hype. Last meal before heading back to LA and I thought "3,000 people can't be wrong and look at these pictures, this place is legit!" No way. Everything, and I mean everything was bland, blah, bleh, meh. Asada was poor, chicken was worse, the guacamole had no flavor and the beans were barely worth mentioning. The tortilla was ok I guess. Maybe this place used to be really good but at least not when I went. How is it possible that so many people rave about these tacos? I consider myself somewhat of a taconnoisseur but I'm also very easy to please. Just have good meat, good salsa, cilantro and I'm set but this spot couldn't even nail that. Seriously man, Taco Bell and jack in the box are better and I take NO pleasure in saying that.
author: Hector G.

description:
Line is crazy long - 45 minutes and no where to sit either.

Tacos - were pretty good but Idk the line may not substantiate the long wait, I have had better tacos, seriously people look elsewhere. Now, I'm not saying the food wasn't great cause it was pretty friggin good BUT the line is just too long.

Strawberry fresca - HOLY COW that was absolutely phenominal.

If I visit again I would order just that and if the line isnt long some more lamb, cow tongue and beef tacos.
author: Bonnie P.

description: This is one of those SF locations that you have to experience at least once in your life, simply because it's iconic and pretty popular. I usually bring friends who aren't from the Bay here. It's usually pretty crowded, but the line moves fairly quick. Prices are average. Also, it's cash only!
author: Breanna D.

description: Honestly. The flavor was there but my food was cold, i came when they opened and got my food as soon they called my number. I really enjoyed the Mango aqua fresca! ill def come back... it was def worth trying!
author: Jonathan M.

description: Ok fine. This is some gringo Mexican food but I love it. Just short of 5 stars because I know there are better burritos in sf but I still love this place.
author: Jason P.

description:
Hate the lines, love the food. Burritos are usually too much for me to handle (I'm a diehard burrito bowler), but La Taqueria's claim to fame with their carne asada super burrito is well deserved. Inside a 13-inch flour tortilla is jam packed with smoky pieces of carne asada, slow cooked pinto beans, thick pieces of avocado, sour cream, pico, salsa, and cheese. I like that there's no rice, because my stomach real estate is precious. 

One burrito was just enough to fill me up. It was definitely worth the long line on a Friday night, though I probably will go on a weekday afternoon next time - The grilled El Dorado burritos look phenomenal!
author: Denise L.

description: Everything was so fresh! And the restaurant can handle an army in no time. They move that line quick. Don't be scared, make that line
author: Junior P.

description: Don't let the long lines and massive crowd of people turn you away from this place- the wait is so worth it. My favorite thing I tried here was the beef burrito- super style. So delicious and one of my new go-to places when I'm craving burritos or tacos in the Mission. The staff works hard to get your order done fast and they are very friendly. Just remember that it is cash only so you don't feel silly with your card ready to go when you get to the payment counter.
author: Maggie F.

description: Very good burritos! Tacos are ok! Long lines but they are surprisingly quick! Would def go back again when visiting!
author: alexandria f.

description: Best burrito in the mission. Go off hours for shorter lines and bring cash
author: Robert D.

description: This place is good and ingredients are definitely fresh. Don't get items togo cause they'll get steamed and turn soggy and soft. Lines are usually long and you need pay attention to when they call your number. Not a huge fan of the tacos but definitely get the burrito dorado style as recommended by all the yelpers. When your in this area there are also many other selections as well.
author: Larry L.

description: Oh geez. Crave this place on a weekly basis. I'm born and raised in the Bay Area and didn't come here till last year, I'm 29!!! So happy I've finally taken the trip to visit! If you're in the city or even in Oakland/Berkeley area and don't mind 20 min Bart ride and short walk, go to LA TAQUERIA! Best damn tacos I've had. I get the carne asada taco "dorado style" which means it's a taco with 2 shells. One soft and one Crunchy. The vegetarian tacos are also amazing. Go, you won't leave disappointed nor hungry!
author: Jordan H.

description:
I accidentally Lyfted here thinking it was another Mexican food place I originally wanted to go to but noticed that the line was super long and saw the large amount of Yelp reviews and figured "Why not, life is too short," and stood in line with everyone else. 

First off I want to say that my review is probably biased because I love rice in my burritos. I didn't realize that their burritos didn't come with rice until I was already close to ordering but just went with it and figured it may change my life. 

Wrong. I was so wrong. If you're into having lots of meat and beans wrapped in a tortilla, this will probably hit the spot for you. But, I love rice. And hate beans. So I basically just got meat wrapped in a flour tortilla. I also paid $.60 for queso.. That never came into my burrito. So basically what I received was a really salty meat burrito. For over $9 I definitely don't think it was for me. 

So yes, after eating only half of my burrito I headed to where I was actually planning on going - Taqueria El Buen Sabor, and got myself another taco.
author: My N.

description: Ummmmmm! Yeah......No! How is this place even considered to have "the best burrito" in the country? Obviously the "judges" have no clue what they are talking about nor do they know Mexican food. Absolute fail!!!!!
author: Vero V.

description:
Good bye El Farolito, Hello La Taqueria!! 

So I have a new favorite authentic Mexican place! This place is so good! Thank God I live only 10 mins away!!

Beware! Cash only! My husband and I were .56 cents short, however the lady at the register said it was okay. We thought $40 bucks was enough for the 2 of us, apparently it wasn't! 

We came for an early dinner around 4ish and there was still a long line! We ordered a lot of food! 

My husband ordered a Carne Asada Super Burrito Dorado Style and a Carne Asada Super Taco Dorado Style. He really enjoyed his dinner! He actually ate both items in 10 mins!

I couldn't decide on chicken or carnitas so I got a Carnitas Super Burrito Dorado Style and a Chicken Super Taco Dorado Style! OMG that was delicious! My food was very flavorful and hearty! 

You're probably wondering what Dorado style is about? It's when they make your burrito, then grill it on the outside so your burrito has a nice crunch to it! 

I love the burritos, but next time I come to this place I'm going to order 3 Chicken Super Tacos Dorado Style! This place has the best tacos ever!!
author: Darlene M.

description:
Yum! You want good, cheap, Mexican food? This is the spot to go!

I got my burrito half chorizo and half carnitas and also got it fried on the outside! That's what the cashier told me to do and I'm so glad I followed his advice. 

Definitely a staple location that you should stop by!
author: Yotam I.

description:
La Taqueria. You may remember this place from such accolades as FiveThirtyEight's Best Burrito Alive. Its clientele certainly do. Even on non-peak times, this place is pretty packed. On our visits to San Francisco, we usually do a 3-and-out pickup in the Mission before the drive back to South Bay. (1) Some baked goods at Tartine. (2) Some ice cream at Bi-Rite. and (3) A burrito at La Taqueria or El Farolito. It's a triumvirate of epic proportions. And to accomplish the third, it's best to call ahead and get your burrito upon entry.

Let's get this out of the way. La Taqueria's burrito is better than El Farolito's. Yes, it's more expensive. Yes, it's smaller. And yes, it tastes better. And when it comes to Mission-style burritos, quality over quantity is a good mantra to live by. I actually like the smaller burrito size, because it turns singular bites into a better medley of all ingredients. (This is the Chipotle vs. Freebird's corollary.) As such, every bite of La Taqueria's super burrito is fantastic.

If I could have it my way, I'd actually pick up some of El Farolito's legendarily good green salsa on the way out to pair with the burrito. La Taqueria's salsas (both the verde and the rojo) are good, standard fare, but nothing I'd go out of my way for. El Farolito's green sauce is. But alas, the burrito is the star of the show, and La Taqueria's is hard to beat. Perhaps the only way it'll be topped is if I get it Dorado style (grilled on the plancha), which is kind of a waste when we're always taking it to go. One day.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
I read many great reviews on this place, so I decided to give it a try. Luckily it wasn't too long of a wait at 5:30pm on a Saturday; however, it was a little overwhelming and confusing in regard to ordering and paying (MAKE SURE YOU HAVE CASH). 
Also, I found the prices to be in the pricey side considering if you want a burrito or taco with anything besides meat, salsa, and beans...it costs extra *gruff*
The food definitely tasted great and they had it ready in a timely manner, but I wish they didn't have all the other fix in food items at an extra price.
author: Courtney W.

description:
Good: Everything is fresh, hello avocados. Patrons are nice. Lots of fresco options and you can meet lovely patrons as you sit in long benches.

Bad: Not full of flavor. Limited waiting room.

Final Verdict: Come for a low key night and bring cash.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
I came to this place with a couple friends for dinner on a Thursday night, and it was PACKED! There were no tables available, but some opened up within a few minutes after we ordered.

I got a carne asada burrito, and it was super delicious. There is no rice in the burrito--what a revelation! The flavors of all the other items in the burritos really shines through with no rice. Quite possibly the best burrito I have ever had.

They only take cash, so be prepared!
author: Ayesha A.

description: This place is amazing. Secret to it is off the menu twist to burritos and tacos, dorado style.
author: Robert R.

description: Best burrito we ever had! Got the Super Burrito with carne asada spicy & split it with my girlfriend it was that big. We also go the chips, salsa and avacado. The chips were thick, crispy and not too salty. Although the line was long - the service was quick and the workers polite. Totally recommend this place and will be sending friends far and wide here when they visit San Francisco!
author: Casey N.

description: Their carne asada burrito is excellent, however a bit greasy and pricey.  Also, remember to take cash if you give it a try!
author: Frank S.

description: Cash only! Delicious. Super carnita burrito includes meat, beans, pico, cheese, avo, & sour cream. Got the salsa & avo with chips to go. Dang near perfect.
author: Parker P.

description:
Arguably the best burrito I've had in the city. I've been here a handful of times already and each time I want to try something new, but I always end up getting the burrito. As others have mentioned already, the burritos here don't come with rice which was a welcome change to me and definitely something I now prefer. I will admit I've never had authentic burritos in the past (I'm more used to rice + lettuce and other fillers). They don't do anything crazy with their burrito besides that, but the ingredients are freshly prepared (you can see them cooking pound after pound of carne asada and other proteins right in front of you). Also, if you are new to Mexican food like I am, try the horchata (sweet rice drink)!

What I liked:
* Delicious burritos. They keep it simple with the ingredients and just deliver solid burritos.
* Fresh ingredients. You can see them preparing the proteins on the stove while in line.

What I disliked:
* Pricey for a taqueria. The super burrito (basically regular, but with cheese, guacamole, sour cream) is $13. However, they have hella demand, so it's understandable that they hiked up the prices. This place is more like $$ instead of single $.
* The lines are long and seating is very hard to find here since it's basically a tourist attraction at this point.

Overall, 4.5/5. I really enjoy the burritos, but the prices are on the high end for me, so can't come all time.
author: Michael M.

description: Best food you can't go wrong with anything you eat here! Perfecto! My family has been going here since I was a kid even since we moved out of SF!
author: Regina M.

description:
The hype about this place is real, with good reason. You've got cooks crushing it behind the line serving up some delicious tacos. When I came on a Friday afternoon their were 20 people in like and I only waited 7 minutes to get my order through, and only one 10 more to receive my food. I ordered two Super Steak tacos and let me tell youuuu, these tacos were pretty damn delicious! I had a great experience at La Taqueria. Summary/tips:
*Expect a short wait.
*Bring cash as they only take cash.
*Seating may be limited.
**!!!Delicious food!!!*
*The hype is real.
author: Sami M.

description:
Food is great and worth the wait but a few ground rules for you first timers:

- Only tourists save a table
- Wait until your entire party has ordered to sit down at a table. Trust in the taco gods, they will provide a place to sit when your food is ready.
- Don't go in a big group because they don't have the seating for it.
- Bus your own table
author: Anne F.

description:
FOOD IS SO DAMN GOOD! Best of the mission IMO. Worth the wait in line. 
Pro tip: Ask for the secret menu (dorado).
If only had they had a bit more seating and accepted card.
author: Roshan G.

description:
Carne asada Taco extraaa crispy with everything and  strawberry drink please !

Quality meat in their tacos.
author: Feuy P.

description:
This is a good place to get a taste of San Francisco's Mexican food scene.

We ordered a carne asada burrito, a pollo super burrito and a quesadilla. Both burritos were good but a bit wet for my preference.

As your 50 person long line snakes around the dining area, take the opportunity to look at the operation they have going in the kitchen. While the cashier is busy taking orders in either English or Spanish, there are usually two or three folks making burritos, tacos and quesadillas by hand. In the back will be one guy grilling 50 lbs. of carne asada. Another two people will be running around keeping supplies in stock.

Come here with a friend or two so one of you can be on the lookout for table that opens when a diner finishes up.
author: Beethoven C.

description: We wanted to get some food and head to Dolores Park since it was so nice out. Thankfully we called ahead and didn't have to wait long to grab our order as the place was packed at lunch. It took like 15 tries to even get through to order. One of my tacos was missing when we got to the park but not sure if I was charged for it or not. The tacos are very big, not like the L.A. style I'm used to. The chicken quesadilla was solid, especially fully loaded. Chips and guac are worth getting too.
author: J. Karim A.

description:
Without a doubt one of the two best burritos in San Francisco. The tacos are super legit and I'd put them at the top of the list too. Just remember these few things and you can't go wrong...

1. Always order it "super", because it would be a sin to deprive yourself of the guacamole and pico de gallo. 
2. It's a cash only joint and not cheap Mexican food, so bring at least a 20 spot. 
3. After your order, act like a hawk and snag a near impossible outside seat (weather depending). 

I've had the esteemed pleasure of trying all proteins (pollo, carnitas, asado) in taco and burrito form and there is no wrong way to order. They are all delicious! I would also highly recommend getting a side of chips and there amazing salsa (which is more like a pico de gallo). 

There's a rivalry between patrons of "La Taqueria" and neighboring restaurant "El Farilto" and  the way I see it, you can only have one favorite and I choose the former. It's ability to transform me into the happiest version of myself post burrito consumption is the true mark of great Mexican food.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Heard about this place for awhile. A little too overhyped for me. The burritos tasted great, definitely get avocado or the regular burrito will be just meat, rice, and beans. Meat was like your average carne asada would taste. 

Definitely recommend for the experience
author: Patton N.

description:
La Taqueria is truly overhyped and a tourist trap. While I must say the food, particularly the meat is some of the best marinated I have ever had at an SF Taqueria, it doesn't make up for the poor use of space in managing the long lines and crowd flow, rice-less burritos which I guess just isn't my style, the fact they are cash only, and their sorry excuse for an horchata. The two times I've been here, I always leave this place bewildered as to why so many folks come here.

I'd say try it once just to say you did and to taste for yourself but there are much better and less crowded alternatives if you are looking for good Tacos, Quesdillas, and Burritos. 

A final redeeming tip I will add is that the folks working here sure know how to keep up the hospitality and their cool even when there are 30+ folks in line. Customer service does not fall flat even with the crowds.
author: Alejandro T.

description: An excellent writeup from EaterSF and FiveThirtyEight led me here, to my complete and utter disappointment.  Everyone else (I mean, EVERYONE, as the line was out the door and around the corner) was lured there as well, so try to find this on an off-peak eating time if you're going to do it.  I ordered the carnitas burrito and my partner the carne asada.  Review of the carne was, "Fine," with an eyeroll.  My thoughts on the carnitas were that the tortilla was fridge-cold, and the guac was freezer-cold, leaving my burrito overall kinda room-temp at best.  It was incredibly soggy and the tortilla was ripped when I unwrapped it, so it was a logistical nightmare to eat with individual beans falling out the entire time.  The carnitas meat had a good texture, was moist and soft with crispy edges like you'd hope for, but the only detectable flavor was salt.  I give this 1 star, 4 S's (Sad Soggy Salty Situation).
author: Cassandra R.

description: My wife and I stopped at La Taqueria during a recent trip to San Francisco. The restaurant was busy when we visited around 6pm, but we were able to still order quickly and find a place to sit. The restaurant is cash only, which thankfully we knew ahead of time. My wife had a super carne asada burrito, dorado style. I had a super carne asada burrito, dorado style. Dorado style means that the burrito is grilled and crispy. Both of our burritos were tasty, but nothing really out of the ordinary. Super style adds cheese, sour cream, and avocado for $3 more which I feel is a pricey. The burritos also seemed a little on the smaller side to me. We enjoyed our meal, but I've had better burritos elsewhere. My wife is from the Chicago area and the burritos I've had there are significantly better.
author: Larry H.

description:
For such a mediocre taco joint, this place sure is crowded and prices comparably high. Tacos do not come with any guacamole and there's no complementary salsa on the side. I've had better back home in NYC without the ridiculous wait. This place is the definition of a Tourist Trap. 

For a better Mexican dining, head to Farolitos.
author: Susan N.

description: Burrito expectations met, reputation not lived up to. Famed as being one of if not the best burrito is just not accurate. It was good not great. The wait is long and quite honestly not worth it, there are better burrito places and cheaper too. No rice
author: Chris A.

description:
This is my go to burrito spot when I'm in SF and the Baaaayyyy Aaaaareeeaaaa. 

I always get the carne asada burrito, super with guacamole. The burrito is big, has plenty of fresh meat that they make in front of you, and delicious. I also get the Horchata to wash it all down.

They do have other items on the menu and other meats for burritos, but I just get the same thing each time.
author: Tim R.

description: The burrito is amazing! Get here early and cash only. The family owned business is a must stop for a taste of burrito heaven.  Don't miss this place!
author: Julie D.

description: Oh yumm! They have this down to a science. You know the chips are good when you can smother them with salsa and guacamole and they still crunch
author: Marisa K.

description:
While looking for Mexican food in San Francisco, I quickly came across the notorious La Taqueria. It's not everyday that you get the chance to try the supposed best burrito in the country so I had to stop by for lunch.

First off, let me start out by saying the service is PHENOMENAL. The man at the register (who I'm assuming is the owner) was incredibly kind. After making some small talk about where we're from, he decided to throw in some freebies for us. He gave us two free ordres of chips and salsa and two free fruit drinks (watermelon and strawberry; both are delicious). He also gave each of my sisters a rose, which was random, but nice. He made us feel incredibly welcome and comfortable.

I tried the carne asada burrito with guac and cheese. The burrito is excellent! I really haven't had meat in a burrito as good as it was here. I wish I had gotten less things in the burrito (i.e. no guac and no beans) so that I could enjoy more of the meat. The guac and beans hold back the burrito in my opinion, but it's still good! I'm just being super critical because it's supposed to be the best. 

Overall, I'm definitely a fan of La Taqueria. They make some darn good burritos!
author: Naeem B.

description:
A couple things... Cash only, no black beans apparently, you have to order chips separately, and a rather small burrito. 

Despite all of this, la taq still managed to win me over. I came here well aware of the hype and cannot deny my carne asada burrito was really damn good. I got the carne asada burrito, chips and salsa (should have also asked for guac, but that's my bad) and the tangerine agua fresca. I had never had an agua fresca so good before. I wanted to get more before leaving but didn't bring enough cash. 

I've gone to a fair amount of hyped burrito places around the city now, only to leave thinking they were "meh" but la taq held up in terms of flavor (not so much in quantity). I will absolutely be back to try other things from their menu such as the tacos and will be getting another carne asada burrito in the near future. (If you want hot sauce, you can ask for it when ordering. I only saw the fine print on the menu after already being seated. 

The moral of the story is if you are looking for a deal in terms more food for your buck, maybe go to the place down the street. But if you are aren't hangry then by all means you should definitely experience the burrito here.
author: Thielson D.

description: Having never been to San Francisco, a stop at a Mexican restaurant was a must on a recent trip. La Taqueria was mentioned a number of times by various websites and reviewers for having the best burritos in the area so a stop here seemed to be the right choice. I visited for lunch and the place was pretty crowed but not unbearable. The line to order wrapped around the entire interior of the restaurant and those who had already ordered stood around awkwardly between the tables waiting for a seat to open. It took about 10 to 15 minutes to place my order and about another 5 minutes to get the food. I ordered the Chips & Salsa and a Burrito with Carne Asada. The Chips & Salsa was a little disappointing. The Salsa was a little soggy like it had been sitting around for a bit but still had a decent flavor. The burrito was enjoyable and filled with freshly grilled chunks of Carne Asada, tender pinto beans, crisp lettuce, creamy avocado, and sour cream.
author: Nicolas L.

description: Damn.  That's all I have to say. Lines are long but it moves. They are efficient, so don't be intimidated.  You will get a table as well, not a place people hang so a lot of turnover. Don't get discouraged. Get your burrito crispy, no matter what ingredients you choose. Damn, it's really good.
author: Jack R.

description:
OMG the carnitas or carne asada super burrito dorado style is so money, as is the dorado style taco.  Often I can't resist and just pig out with one burrito plus one taco.  Geez I'm getting hungry just writing this review!

Seriously, just get one of each and wash them down with a nice Mexican beer or fresca.  You won't regret it, even if you have to go back to work and take a nap!
author: Mikey L.

description:
The absolute BEST tacos/burrito I've ever had in my life. 

Visited La Taqueria in April with my boyfriend, and over our 6day SF/Bay Area trip we went to La Taqueria twice and it honestly wasn't enough! Between both trips we had: Carne asada tacos, chorizo tacos, carnitas tacos, chicken tacos, and the lengua burrito. All. Were. Delicious. 

There's a reason this place is constantly ranked in SF's best restaurants. Just do yourself a favor and GO!!! 

PS it's cash only, and there is a Chase Bank right across the street!
author: Nairee B.

description:
If you  want to  taste the best tacos in San Francisco  you are on the right place!!
I have visited this taqueria for couple years and as always, my wife and I have enjoyed  this tacos. They have a loyal customer for life.
author: Bora Jesus G.

description: This place is cash only!!! there is an atm in the back corner that we had to use.  There was a decent wait and this place was so crowded!!  People were stalking out tables for a long time while another person in their party stood in line.  We each got a burrito (i got carnitas and my husband got carne asada) and they were both amazing.  We also had the watermelon fresca which was so fresh and delicious.  the only down side of this place is the neighborhood and the fight for a table, other than that it was a very authentic experience and great food.
author: Geena G.

description: Food wasn't bad, but wasn't amazing. This restaurant is very overhyped. My husband had been talking about this place for years, he had seen it on tv etc. we ordered a carne asada burrito. For all the hype you would think the tortillas would at least be home made. Very obvious store bought flour tortilla. Killed the entire experience for me. Not worth all the awards. Just another Mexican restaurant except with long lines.
author: Michelle L.

description: LONGGGG lines. If youre craving this place or have a hankering to check it out be prepared to wait. The wait times can be ridiculously long. We got there and 30 minutes later we ordered and got our food. Also be prepared to vulture a seat (circle around and swoop down for a seat as soon as someone leaves). This place can get packed but I think there are better Mexican places here and honestly dont get the hype.
author: Navdeep D.

description:
meh....

I went here because of the reputation for having the best burrito on the planet. 

Was it?

I have to say that out of all the burritos i have had this was NOT the best one i have had. I mean, it was good and all but it didnt rock my world.

I like my tortilla slightly crispy and these are straight up soft.

it was good. I will go down the street,
author: John C.

description: There's usually a line here but they get it moving pretty quickly. I recommend any of the burritos, with all the fixings and make sure to as for it "al dorado" where they toast it! Overall the burritos here are above average and good, but I like El Farolito more. I missed the rice in my burrito, and the sauce bar. They did have a tomatillo sauce on each table which was good. Also I found this place to be pricier than most taquerias. By the way it's *CASH ONLY*
author: Jenine G.

description:
So.... the other night I had some time to kill before a concert, so my best bud and I decided to have a Burrito Showdown in the Mission. We stopped at El Farolito, and then at LA TAQUERIA. We cut both in half and had a little bit of heaven from both...

We ordered the super carne burrito at Farolito, and the Carnitas at La Taq. We ate both side by side, and hands down La Taq was the victor... Their carnitas were without a doubt, the best I've ever had. I prefer rice in my burrito, and La Taq does not put it in, and it did not matter one bit. 

I will say, the free chips was a nice perk at Farolito - and their burrito is much bigger.... but size doesn't always matter - right ladies??? The flavor at La Taqueria was unmatched. La Taq was definitely more crowded too. 

El Farolito - 4.75 stars
La Taqueria - 5 stars!
author: Joel V.

description: The best. My favorite mission burrito place. The only line I will stand in to get their tasty, always fresh mission style burritos and tacos.
author: Dani B.

description:
EL DORADO STYLE. It's basically a chimichanga. 

Whenever I come I usually take my food to go since parking is tough in the mission. They do take your orders quickly and get you your food fast so you don't find yourself waiting too long. 

I usually get the Carne Asada Super Burrito El Dorado Style. At first this place took some getting used to since they don't have rice in their burritos. I thought this would affect how full I would feel afterwards but I was wrong. Having the burrito fried made the outside perfectly crispy while ensuring that the inside ingredients melted and mixed so well together. It can get messy so be sure to have extra napkins with you! 

I accidentally forgot to get my burrito fried last time and I prefer el dorado style. I definitely think that's a big appeal for me because otherwise, it didn't taste too different than other burritos in the area.
author: Keizzel C.

description: Best burrito I've ever had. Seriously, I dream about this place sometimes. Too bad I'm all the way across the country. We split the steak burrito because we wanted to try another place in the area on our short weekend trip. Bad idea. The other place was meh and we should have just split 3 here between the two of us instead. SO SO GOOD.
author: Tania S.

description:
We were in San Francisco and carving some delish Mexican. We had a carne asada burrito, 1 carne asada taco and a carnitas taco. Overall the food was great it had nice favor. Finding a spot to eat can be tricky. The place was packed. We were also caught off guard that it was cash only. Totally understand the financial benefit of this to the business, but come on it's 2017! 

Went down to 4 stars instead of 5 because they didn't take credit cards. I felt my experience was limited to the cash that I had on me.
author: Rose L.

description: I can't give this place any negative feedback. Food is consistently perfect. The super burrito with Asada is TDF. Ok of the best burrito places I've ever been to
author: Julio V.

description:
I won't deny that this is probably the best burrito I had in terms of taste, and my review is based on taking my burrito to go.
I came here on a Sunday with some out of town guests around lunch time and the place was completely packed. I was lucky enough to find a parking spot only 2 blocks away. It's funny because I'm the local, and this was my first time coming here as opposed to my guests who have come here before.
The line starts outside and wraps around in the inside of the building.
There was a lady who wrote down my order and I think she handed it to me to give to the guys making my burrito.
It's a bit pricey for a burrito, a bit over 11 bucks, but damn, it was the best burrito I had. For the overall value though, I'd probably still go to my local Gordo taqueria because it's easier to find parking and about 3 bucks cheaper, but I would definitely get a burrito here if I'm in the area.
What separates La Taqueria from the rest is that they just don't use any rice at all, it's pretty much an all meat burrito, and they press it like a Panini for a grilled outside finish.
The owner is a nice guy. I'm not sure if he always does it ,but he was giving out a rose to all the girls and my friend from Japan got one. She said it was the first rose she ever received.
I hope I get another reason to be in the mission district some day soon so I can get another great burrito!
author: Mike O.

description: Great tasting burritos, tacos, and nachos. They don't give fillers (rice) so it doesn't make you feel heavy just a satisfying fullness. I knocked a star down with there raising prices...
author: Pineapple P.

description:
The fiance and I finally dropped off her mom at SFO and we went to my jeweler to get her ring resized.  They said it'd take 1.5 hours, so it was time to find some food.  The driver from Pink Ladies Tour Co was raving about La Taqueria after I told him how disappointed I was about Mexican food in the Bay Area, so it was on today.

After backtracking a little southbound, we reached La Taqueria with no problem.  We lucked out with parking on this day after Thanksgiving and walked right in.  The line (as expected) was a bit long.  My first gripe about this place was that it was at first difficult to determine who was waiting for food vs waiting to order.  Anyways we were pleased to see that they had the right mix of meat choices.  We both like carnitas (my benchmark meat) and lengua.  In the interest of saving space for Bi-Rite Ice Cream later in the day, we ate somewhat light :)  I ordered a carnitas burrito and the significant other ordered two lengua tacos.  We split an horchata as she's never had one, but always wondered what it tasted like.

I could tell that these tacos are more homestyle/street style than what I've seen in the East Bay.  Though at the same time, they have a bit of the gringo side of it too.  The carnitas burrito I ordered had pinto beans, carnitas, cilantro, and onions.  Her tacos had the cilantro/onions w/ the lengua.

The quality of my burrito was really good.  Best so far in the Bay area.  I've had better down south, but this will definitely do.  I ate about half of it without the chile verde sauce so I could taste all the ingredients better and with each bite, I appreciated it more.  I had a bite of her lengua tacos, but I was not impressed too much esp the tortillas.  They were a bit stiff and overcooked and had a chalky/limey aftertaste.  

My biggest gripe was the cost of the tacos.  Welcome to the Bay area, I know.  The burrito was fairly priced.  Oh, not once did I see any staff cleaning the tables.  Big negative.  And lastly, a guy came in and played music and asked for tips.  Not a big fan of that.  Doesn't add to the ambiance and it only seemed to make people shout over him while they were having lunch.

For me, this was a 4.5 and I do intend to return again if I'm in the area.  The cost of the tacos dragged it down a full star as well as the convoluted line / waiting area.
author: Bob K.

description:
Cash only! atm in the restaurant.

Not a lot of seating, and not the cleanest looking restaurant. But it does sell some mean burritos and tacos. The burritos are $10ish dollars each. and imo you get more food if you order three tacos (and each are around #3).

For burritos, you can get the "super" version, which doesn't mean the burrito itself is a larger size - they just add sour cream, cheese, and avocado to it, and the answer is always a yes. There are a lot of types of meats that you can put in it, but chorizo is always my fav since it has so much flavor!

When there is a long line, someone will come down the line and take your order and give you a slip. You hold onto it, and give it to the cashier when you pay. Then they'll call your number (in both spanish and english) and you navigate through the crowd to pick up your food.

The green sauce on the tables aren't too spicy, so feel free to be liberal.
author: Grace P.

description:
After my first night visiting a friend in San Francisco, I had the biggest hangover. But that was not going to stop me from going to La Taqueria. 

I took an uber 15 minutes, ordered 2 tacos outside and ate by myself, and it was worth it. This place has a line and it took me about 5 - 10 minutes for seats to open up on Saturday morning. I had steak and lengua tacos, with watermelon juice. There is salsa available if you want your tacos spicy. These tacos are to not be taken lightly. Writing this review makes me want to eat one right now.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Whoa this is not the best taco place. These people need to go to LA. No flavor and you have to add cheese or sour cream to make it yummy. Gross and it's odd how these tacos look. Meat is not flavored like LA. The onions are not on the taco but from the salsa. Super bland. Would not get in this super long line for this place. Taco trucks would taste better for tacos. Maybe their burritos are better but tacos here were not famous. And they also put beans on here. Super odd.
author: Est K.

description:
You can eat here if you want white-washed mexican food. The guacamole is better at Chipotle. The chicken tasted boiled with no adobe. The Carnitas tastes like someone cooked pork. Horchata wasn't sweet.

The sour cream wasn't even crema.

And I didn't even get bones in my food unlike my friend who picked out 3 from a single burrito..

DO NOT GO HERE unless you to pay $10 for a tiny burrito which tastes less authentic than Chipotle. Cash only and 20-30 minute wait.
author: Alex R.

description: The place was awesome and food was really good. I recommend this to people who really likes mexican food. I really like the Burrito it tastes really good.
author: Jejo M.

description: Was an amazing burrito, but it took 40 minutes to get and they gave us the wrong one. We ordered carne asada and got chicken instead. Still giving four stars because this was literally the best chicken burrito I've ever had, I just dock a star because of the operation.
author: Megan H.

description:
Hi Friends, the hype is real. Gotta say I was pre-tty skeptical, especially since I hate lines and there was a decent-sized one on Wednesday evening (Yes, there was a line here on a Wednesday evening). But this place was definitely better than El Farolito (both of them), and also better than El Metate.

For my patience, I was rewarded with a burrito of legends. I chose a carne asada burrito, and the tenderness of the meat almost brought me to tears. The avocado that they put in the burrito was super fresh, and you could easily taste that distinct avocado flavor that is sometimes drowned out by lesser taquerias. It was nice and saucy, but didn't drip a bunch of liquid out at the end... in short, pretty much the pinnacle of mission burritos (although maybe the dorado style is even better, haven't tried that yet!)

Also: the chips + salsa you can buy as a side come with a ton of chips.
author: Alexander L.

description:
Meh. Overrated restaurant...
We got a Carne Asada and Carnitas burrito. Carne Asada was pretty good. Love the smokey/grill flavor in it.
The Carnitas however, was more like pulled pork. Not crispy like how "deep fried" pork should be. Burrito size/portion was pretty small for the price. Small because no "filler"/rice, so understandable but still does not warrant $12 for a burrito! I've had many better burrito for ~$8.

Would not come back. Over hyped with crazy line. Not worth the price for the portion. Only good thing is the Carne Asada.
author: Alex L.

description: There's a lot of hype around this place and while the food is good it's not amazing by any stretch of the imagination. I got the burrito and there was no rice in it which made it pretty soggy but the flavors were good and the service was very fast
author: Naveed N.

description:
I was trying to figure out what exactly made the burrito at La Taqueria better than any other burrito. The real answer is probably a bunch of small things all added together, but I want to focus on one aspect in particular: the beans and lack of rice.

In a lot of burritos, the rice and beans increase the size, increase the fullness of the person eating it, but are generally bland and filler. As a test, the next time you get a burrito from some other place, ask for a little bit of burrito rice on the side. And prepare to be disappointed. The beans are similar, sometimes worse, sometimes better.

But that's part of the genius of La Taq. No rice and the beans are really good. I'm not sure what special stuff they do to the beans, but they're delicious. And they add to the flavor of the whole instead of detract from it. Add in the really high quality meat and fresh vegetables and you have yourself a fantastic burrito.
author: Adam R.

description:
Great tacos, great food and it does get very busy,
However the prices are outrageous. Expect to pay $12 pe taco. They charge for everything. Expect to pay Berwyn $22 to $30 per person.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Their tacos and burritos are very delicious. Have a try at their Dorado style tacos/burritos (not on the menu)

All the ingredients are fresh. I appreciate how the flavors mix to create a very authentic taste.

Their lines are long (most of the time) but fast moving.
author: Francisco D.

description:
I've eaten a lot of tacos in my life, and I would say these are the best!  Its the usual simple ingredients, but these guys make it amazingly fresh and tasty!  We sampled chicken, pork and beef, all were fantastic.  Don't let the long line put you off, it moves quickly!
Also, try the chips smothered in salsa with a side of guac--awesome!
author: Eric L.

description:
Let's taco bout it.

Insider tip: call ahead and order (takes 15 minutes), then show up and skip the line. You can still sit and eat there! Don't leave your food sitting though; keep those tacos crispy and be there in 10 minutes to listen for your number. 

You really can't lose, but my go-to is the carne asada one crispy/one soft taco and my husband always gets a carne asada super burrito.
author: Celie H.

description: If you're in San Francisco, you HAVE to try the classic la taqueria! The line was pretty long but I definitely think it's worth it. Also note that this place is cash only, someone was waiting in line in front of us for awhile and unfortunately had to turn back because no cash. When I went, they unfortunately ran out of asada so I ended up trying the carnitas. I got a supreme carnitas taco for $6. The taco was HUGE. I overall think the taco was pretty good. The only downfall I had was with the shell. The shell held the taco really well, but I thought the shell was meh and it wasn't anything special.  While enjoying my taco,  a mariachi band played and it was a great experience! However, I highly recommend this place and if you're visiting San Francisco this place is a MUST.
author: Kaitlyn S.

description:
I could go the easy way here and give it a solid 4-star review.  I mean, I've given several places that are nothing to be excited about a 4-star review.  And, this IS a place where you probably should at some level be excited about.  I feel obligated to grade this place in the context of what you are seeing and hearing about it.  This place is not all that.  It's good, and based on the quality of the food coupled with the experience, and with a hint of the expectations, I'll say that A-Ok is a fine review.  3-stars is fair, particularly if you really grade it in context.

Hey, this place doesn't shy from the mantle of "Best Burrito in the Country".  That is pretty high praise.  If I were them, I'd be like... Nah...  We just do our thing and try and stay humble.  They don't take that approach at La Taqueria.  They eat up the accolades.  Fine.  Perfectly fair.  But, if you want to play that game, I am holding you to that standard.  And, by that standard, La Taqueria is incredibly disappointing.  The food is far from spectacular.  The waiting is long and is not done well.  There is even a limited means to sit and eat, because the whole thing is just silly.  It's like they have the greatest thing ever from a ownership standpoint - people will wait forever, pay a ton, wait even longer, and you don't even have to host them.
