Then, they thank you for the pleasure.  Because:  "They ate at the place that has the 'Best Burrito in America'".  

It's not.  It's not even close.  It's good, I won't say it isn't.  It is not the best burrito in America.  Here's the deal.  They don't add rice, you get lots of meat (which is good) and pretty solid pinto beans and pico.  Not bad.  Add another $2.50 for Cheese, Sour Cream and (bad) Guac.  Pretty rich.  Of course, it isn't cheap.  You are at about $12 for a dressed burrito, and more if you go no beans.  The tacos are plenty spendy, especially if you get them Super-style.  Super-style is a great thing for the owner.  I'd prefer a better base.   Beans in tacos?  Ehh...  You really think this is the "Best in America"?   I also had one of the most mediocre Chicken Quesadilla's of my life for $5.  I think this place is altight, but it's damn expensive.  It should be very good.  Plus, you already came to The Mission, and you are in the freakin' Mission in SF, and you better be getting good Mexican food.  I can definitely name at least four places you should hit in The Mission alone that are better.  And, cheaper.  AND, don't require a 15-20 minute wait once you've already waited 10-15 minutes.  I can probably expanding that list by trying the next 10-12 places at least once.  

Let's go back to the experience for a moment.  They must have a low opinion of their audience here.  What a poor experience.  You wait in line for ages.  It's just packed.  Many people are not regulars so they have no idea what is happening.  Then you order, and you wait in another line to pay.  Then you wait forever for like 10-20 minutes.  They don't move fast.  They don't have a good system - which, hey, would make sense.  Then you finally get your food, and are no longer in the mood and wish you would have just went, well, anywhere.  There isn't a seat.  By then time you figure out where to carve out a niche, your Mexican food is cold and Mexican food is better warm.  If this place truly had a good product, they could take a lot of other approaches.  Here is an absolute kicker for how they could be better - Their one really good burrito is much better when it is grilled, which is called Dorado-style.  You wouldn't know it on the menu, because it is "secret".  I knew how to get it, and that added even more to the wait.  I had one without the extra grilling they other day and it was half as good.

I think they are willing to play the game.  They at best deserve a 3-star.  If I didn't know that someone else called it the Best in America, I don't know if I would ever go back.  I doubt I'll be back soon.  I'd be very careful when you are approaching popular places that have celebrity.  Sometimes famous and good are not the same thing.
author: Adam S.

description: We came here with high expectations after seeing the reviews but were quite disappointed. Line was not too long, but ordering was confusing and service low grade. We had a chicken burrito and a sausage burrito, which were merely average. Size was not as large as other places and taste loses even to Chipotle. Minus also for cash only. No free parking usually, prepare to search for metered slots.
author: Jani T.

description:
Carnde asada fries to go. Hands down, they do not cheap out. Always ask to replace chips with fries. Great service. 

Parking is okay, price is average but you definitely get for what you paid for.
author: James K.

description: When we got here the was a decent line and a wall plastered with plaques for the best Mexican years in a row. We knew right then that this was going to be good and it did not dosap. The atmosphere is filled with delicious smells of authentic Mexican. The portion sizes were large. We ordered a chicken a beef burrito and the chips with salsa. The meals were amazing. The meat was filled with amazing flavours. It is definitely a must when coming to San Francisco!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Okay let's start off by saying the obvious. The food here is amazing. Literally the best ingredients are used here. 

Sadly, the customer service here is shit. I've been here multiple times and the soup nazi (Seinfeld reference) bullshit has to stop. A group of 6 of us got there 15 minutes before closing only to have the gates close in front of us. Luckily we knew Spanish so we cajoled the worker to let us in. Only to have no guarantees of tortillas for us which was bullshit. Bullshit because it was a lie and because this place charges almost $5 per taco so they damn well better have tortillas. 

Others after us were shut out before closing time. 

The food was great. The carne asada and carnitas are amazing. However the customer service is bullshit. I get it la taqueria you have achieved a status most restaurants would die for and rightfully so. Just dont be assholes about it. All of a sudden this place has come resemble the worst of sf: a delicious place overshadowed by pretentious assholes. 

Oh and two people from our party decided to leave instead of dealing with your assholerly. 

Food:5 stars 
Customer service : minus 3 stars 
Overall:2 stars
author: Daniel R.

description:
This place is super overrated!! It was a huge let down. I got an asada and chicken taco. The asada was super dry. It left a horrible taste in my mouth. I could not finish my order.  I had to throw it away. I even got a side of guacamole and it was the most bland guac ever. No flavor at all. 

If you're thinking of coming here because of the good reviews, don't. So not worth it. I seriously cannot understand what the big hype about this place is.
author: Araceli S.

description: Crispy park taco is awesome!!! Beef was great too but I really liked the pork one. Worth the subway ride from union square.
author: Stacey D.

description: Great burrito! Not as filling as other burritos I tried in other places, which is a good thing I guess!
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
Amazing food. Carnitas super burrito is juicy and beautiful . Anything you get from here will be fireee. This is a business i don't mind spending my money on. 
This place is hands down my favorite restaurant in San Fransisco
author: Ham B.

description: I was really excited to try this place due to all the raving reviews. I ordered 3 tacos - beef tongue, beef head, and carntias. The beef tongue was good, but the overall taco was dry. The beef head was very fatty and the taco was also dry. The carnitas was good, but it came with pinto beans which was not listed on the menu so that ruined it for me. But the pico it was topped with was good. They only have one salsa selection which I wasn't a fan of - it was too spicy. This place was a complete miss for me.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Come on now...how is this place rated one of the top burritos places in the US??? 
It's good but my mind wasn't blown when I finished. Maybe I'm jaded because I live in Southern California but really...
One thing we didn't have is the Tacos, those look to be tested, they looked pretty good with their double tortilla and cheese.
The Carne Asada Burritos were good, meat was above average but really lacked some kick or something to make it standout on top.
author: Mark N.

description: One of the best burritos I've ever had. I'm craving more. The strawberry agua frescas was also bomb and the authenticity of the whole operation was icing on the cake. Will definitely be back after I try some of these other burrito places too!
author: Kunal M.

description:
Before you visit this overpriced tourist trap, please check out La Corneta, Cancun, El Farolito or even Taqueria San Jose. 

Long lines for these mediocre, expensive burritos and hardly any seating. Never again!

Real locals know better.
author: Jeff S.

description:
I just had a overall terrible experience... but the food was still delicious.

There is a order line, a pay line, and a wait time line, along with the waiting for a table line.All this is a big headache
author: James M.

description: PACKED on a Wednesday evening. The tacos are quite large, be warned- I got two and had trouble finishing them. Burrito is also pretty huge. Great food, well priced, so definitely splurge on the extra guac! The mango aqua fresca was sweet and refreshing.
author: Saachi G.

description:
Probably the most delicious burrito in the city but definitely on the smaller side - on a hungry day I could put down two. I stick to the carnitas and carne asada super burritos, but I have tried the tacos and they are equally delicious. Either way, this is a line worth waiting in.

And do NOT forget to ask for your burrito El Dorado style.
author: David K.

description: Hands down - best taco I've ever had. Hole-in-the-wall-ish place, long line for food, but lots of locals and friendly staff. The pork taco supreme was incredible. If I wasn't so full, I would have gone back to seconds. I might have to make a trip back to SanFran just to stop here.
author: Nicole M.

description:
I've been eating burritos since I could walk, and to add to that I live a hop, skip, and a jump away from our hombres down south. I know good burritos. 

Check that. I thought I knew good burritos. La Taqueria came in and ruined everything I thought I knew. The symphony of flavors that were playing in my mouth made sure nothing will ever be the same.

The lines may be horrendously long but it's an absolute must to go here. In fact, I joined yelp for the sole purpose of telling everyone about this place because, well, it'd be an absolute shame for you to go somewhere else.
author: Jake S.

description: It's a great place coming from a Latino, one thing I wish would change would be the fact you have to pay extra for all the toppings that should already come on a burrito. It's still a great place.
author: Underrated V.

description: We came at around 1 on a Saturday afternoon, and it took around 20 minutes to order and get our food.  I got a super Dorado carnitas burrito, double meat, no beans.  The meat was generally pretty flavorful (although there were some burnt edges that were a little tough to chew), and the tortilla was great.  The burrito tasted great, probably one of the best I've ever had, but it was a little heavy on the avocado, which suppressed the saltines of the carnitas too much.  I'll definitely be coming back here to try the other meats in taco form, which look huge and delicious.
author: Simon L.

description: This is our favorite taco and burrito place in SF!we love their lingua burrito dorado style and their lingua taco with a side of avocado and their green sauce ,with a Fanta drink and it will be perfect.its a cash only place,don't forget to have cash and enjoy!we just love it!the best lingua in SF!they close at 9 pm,don't miss it if you visit SF!
author: Khatereh M.

description: The best and cheapest food we at in San Francisco. The only downside was that the line was out the door and there was no where do sit when we got our food. The line went fast enough and we were fine to eat in our car outside.
author: Austin N.

description: We came in to eat the carne asada burrito based on all the hype around it. I must say, it was better than most burritos I've had. Why? The flour tortilla was soft. The beans were "de la olla" and not refried. The meat was well cooked. I opted to add avocado to it which makes everything better. We got the regular size and split it but one person could easily eat one. They do offer a larger size burrito but we weren't that hungry. I would recommend this place.
author: Veronica V.

description: The line can get quite long but it is usually moving pretty fast. But there's a reason this place is always packed, the food here is wonderful.
author: Sawyer D.

description: Take cash. Steak taco is delicious. Fresh guacamole on it. Other hits were the chicken quesadilla and steak burrito. Line moved really fast.
author: K A.

description:
Dinner review. 

Carnitas taco - 3/5 - 7x7
Carnitas Dorado burrito - 5/5 - 7x7
Chorizo quesadilla - 5/5 - Very good. 

Overall, best taqueria in SF is "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
The food is *very* good, probably the best tasting burrito I've ever had. Quality ingredients. That comes at a cost, though: Compared to similar places in the surrounding area, the size of the burrito is smaller, and it was more expensive. The place is also cash only.

It's a very small space, with little seating or room to stand without getting in the way.

Overall, I totally recommend you give this place a shot, assuming you're ok with a smaller meal.
author: Matthew P.

description:
The carne asada is still strong in this place.

La Taqueria is not the cheapest taco/burrito joint in the city, but you do get what you pay for.

And what you get is delicious carne asada - in a burrito for me please with sour cream, and guac.
author: Bono B.

description: This place has been a staple in the city for as long as I can remember. Anytime of day there is a line and a lot of people. They have the freshest ingredients and the green sauce is out of this world delicious. Every chance i get we stop by.
author: Teresa G.

description:
Their lengua taco is the best taco i've ever tasted in my entire life. 

I write long reviews, and their tacos are so good i don't have anything else to say. My mouth is watering just thinking about it.
author: Jessie W.

description: Little hole in the wall with really good fish tacos. I could have 5 more! I wasn't too crazy about the spicy shredded chicken. But, generous amount of toppings and quick service. Sitting in may be a challenge during busy hours, more of a quick bite to eat type of place than a sit-down. I'll be going back.
author: P S.

description:
One of the more iconic burrito spots in the city. Street parking can be a bit difficult depending on the time of day you decided to visit. Inside has plenty of tables to accommodate different sizes of groups. There are also a couple of small tables outside. You place your order on the far end of the restaurant and pay near the door. The menu is pretty big and has many different items.

I decided to try the super burrito with carne asada. One my be surprised that it doesn't include rice. There was plenty of meat and cheese and the portion size was just right. The sauce and the guacamole blended well with the meat. Safe to say, this was one of the better carne asada burritos I've had in the city.

A couple of gripes about this place. I would love it if it would stay open later than 9 pm, as this would be a great spot to go to after going out. This is also cash only, so better bring some cash, but they do have ATM inside. Nonetheless, this is a good spot to try if you're really craving Mexican food!
author: Jason P.

description: I just fucken loved this place. You want tacos???? This is they way to go 100% delicious
author: Lupita R.

description: FANTASTIC FOOD. Very fresh, limited menu but lots of food. Line out the door but no one minds waiting. Limited seating but shared tables with much conversation. Everyone happy.
author: Rhonda K.

description:
This is probably one of the most consistently frequented spots in the Mission that I've been to besides my fav taco place a few blocks away near some ice cream shop w Vietnamese Coffee ice cream. ;)

The rating of three stars is based on:
-Service
-Food taste
-Food pricing 
-Wait time for ordering, receiving food and finding seating
-Cleanliness of seating available

While the tacos here are hearty with beans, meat, and salsa & other toppings like cheese, sour cream, guacamole optional and pricey, I'm not loving them more than the SoCal street taco type place with just meat, salsa, maybe radishes, lime, and cilantro.  The strawberry and pineapple frescas are really sweet but pretty good here, just expect pulp/natural fruit bits.

Unlike one of the other taquerias a few blocks away, they charge for chips and salsa here, a few $'s but still.

Guess if I were to stop back, I'd consider off-peak hours or takeout.

Like fellow Yelper Adam S. says, the food is far from spectacular.  BUT, if I'm at Dianda's or want a filling taco around 24th with no walk further and it doesn't appear too busy, this'll definitely be my go-to. :)
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Super expensive, not worth the wait, soggy tacos, and the carne asada wasn't good. Was super excited to try this place was very underwhelmed. :(
author: Alejandra A.

description:
BIG DISAPPOINTMENT, after all the hype and promotion seen on the facebook post/video...I RATHER BE EATING A BOWL OF CEREAL


 https://www.facebook.com/eater/videos/1849934631699514/
author: Alexa P.

description: Went here for the first time for a burrito craving. To my surprise I got sticker shock looking at the price of a super burrito which was over $12. I placed an order for a super chicken burrito. Although tasty, the burrito was short of being super. All other taquerias I go to their super burrito is big and fat full of ingredients. This one was small and not so fat and for a price of over $12, I expected it to be SUPER!!! Not going back again.
author: Bob D.

description: Me and my boyfriend went here when we were on vacation. Maybe it's because we are from San Diego where you can get an amazing burrito every ten feet but we weren't that impressed. I had the carnitas burrito and the carnitas was very flavorful and tender. However, the overall taste of the burrito wasn't anything special.
author: Courtney L.

description:
Their carnitas super-style dorado burrito ($9.40) took my hand and swung me through the gates of Burrito Heaven. Every bite. Heaven. I thought that it honestly could not get better, especially with the crispy-crackly tortilla exterior. But then I hit these lil pockets of carnitas meat juice mingling innocently towards the bottom of the burrito.. mind blown. Bf ordered a carne asada super taco ($6.45), which we liked, but I had eyes only for that burrito. Deserves nothing less than 5 stars.

Drank their horchata (pass) and tamarindo (yum).

Also noteworthy- burrito did not leak (pet peeve)
author: Jen J.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Friday. not I've passed by multiple times but the crowds were just too crazy for me to join the lines, but this time it was a bit more manageable so I got in line. Despite being a 'slow' day, the line was still super long and the wait in line was about 20 minutes before my order was taken. The wait for my super burrito was a bit long but it was definitely worth it!

Pros:
Food, food, food ... ordered the beef head super burrito, the most flavorful burrito I've ever had in San Francisco. The size of the burrito was perfect too, not too big or too small. Ordered a cataloupe drink to wash it down, absolutely delicious too!

Prices, for such a busy place, the prices are not crazy.

Cons:
The lines and wait times can be long, but worth it in the end I think.
Crowds can be crazy, alot of tourists.
author: Simon C.

description:
The carne asada is really good! I checked this place out after seeing reviews and hearing how delicious it was so of course...I HAD to check it out. A bit expensive but really good flavored steak. As far as the "best in America"; probably not. 

Side note: Cash only -- don't forget it.
author: Mo M.

description:
TL;DR: Does it live up to the hype? Yes. Is it worth the wait? Yas. Are dorado style tacos actually tasty? YAS. Is it at bargain prices like all other taquerias in the Mission? NOPE. Is it still worth it? YASSS!

Despite its modest, easily overlooked name, La Taqueria is the only place in Norcal I've come across serving Mexican food that would rival SD Mexican food in a blind taste test. It's something to do with the cooking technique and quality of the ingredients that I don't know enough about to be able to pinpoint like real food critics. But I can attest to the fact that La Taqueria's carne asada straight-up tastes like steak, that their al pastor is as succulent as the pork belly in my ramen, that the soft tacos taste like homemade pressed flour, that their crispy tacos have that extra savory fresh-off-the-grill overtone, that the mind-blowing deliciousness altogether makes Taco Bell look inedible. 

I ordered one al pastor and one carne asada taco; one was regular and one was super because my limited budget and limited stomach space can only afford me one super taco. The tacos were humongous and stuffed to the brim, with two La Taqueria tacos amounting to a satisfying lunch. You could tell why their food is so good just by watching the food prep--with the high turnover, mounds of carne asada slabs are always piled on the grill and are quickly sliced to meet the demand (makes Mediterranean places look subpar with the mostly untouched shawarma on the rotating spit).

They conveniently wrap half the tacos in paper for dining convenience. You don't have to choose between eating with hands that will inevitably smell like food, versus eating with a fork layer by layer and sacrificing the taconess. The paper wrap is quite ingenious, but if you are a nonsensical obsessive food porn Yelper like me, you will feel obligated to take off part of the paper for the picture and attempt to put it back on. It doesn't work too well, but it is my own undoing that I prioritize food pictures over practical aspects of eating.

Service was efficient thank God, because it's always packed--by 11:30am the line was already so long it had stretched the length of the restaurant and looked like it would have to go into the bathroom. Note that there are two people taking orders; I stood by one of them and was beginning to get frustrated why they had skipped my number, then realized that my tacos were sitting on the other counter ready to be devoured :v

At over $11 for my one regular and one super taco, they are definitely bouge tacos (minus the square ceramic plate). In SD $11 would get you a king's feast of hearty authentic Mexican food, but at the end of the day there are never regrets when splurging at SF's La Taqueria, quite appropriately named THE Taqueria.
author: Edna C.

description:
tl;dr - Good, but not worth the wait nor price.

Scene:  Weekday lunchtime.  Mostly locals, some tourists, and a sprinkling of "like, OMG Becky, I totes gotta get this on my Insta" girls, a few brogrammers, and "I'm so edgy and urban since I'm in The Mission now and am 'in the know' for this sick burrito joint, but I'm totally not a hipster" hipsters.  5-10 minute line to order, another 10 minutes or so for food prep.  Open seats a bit scarce, but not horribly so.

Food:  Since it got ranked "America's Best Burrito", I'm going to be a bit more judgemental here.  

Presentation - Burritos aren't rolled very tightly, nor is their foil wrapping.  This is the first time I've ever had a burrito where you could cleanly take off the foil and have it still look uncrinkled.  What's wrong with that?  Since the foil's ends aren't closed off well, you get meat juice all over the place, which particularly sucks without rice to soak it up, and especially sucks with orange chorizo oil.  A loose burrito just feels sloppy.  Maybe I've had bad luck of the draw here.

Taste - Being riceless is a nice change of pace.  The meat is well seasoned, tender, and juicy, although the carnitas could've used a little something something...not sure what - it was well salted, but maybe a smidge watery?  The times I've had it, it was missing the crunchier fried bits you get at other places.  The chorizo is more flavorful, but tends to be a bit messy and you can end up with a shiny neon orange burrito (and hands) due to the aforementioned oil leakage.  The off-menu dorado style ~sounds~ like a great option, but it tends to end up more greasy than crispy.  Looks purty though.

"Value" - It's on the smaller end of the burrito spectrum.  Still plenty of food for an average meal, but not forearm sized like other places.  Scarfing down two wouldn't be a crazy possibility on a construction worker appetite.  Keep in mind though that it doesn't have rice to bulk it up.  At $11 for a super burrito, it's on the higher end of the spectrum.  I get that rent in the city has been shooting up, and a price bump after all the "America's Best Burrito" publicity is sort of expected, but that's considerably higher than other burrito places around here, and a decent jump from just a few years ago.

That said, it's not remotely a bad burrito.  But "America's Best Burrito" should blow your mind the first time you have it, making you go something like  "Hnnnnggh" or "Wow, this is REALLY good".  "Hey, this is pretty good" doesn't cut it.
author: T C.

description:
My boyfriend and I had the greatest worst idea: let's compare quesadillas.  And we did.  We bought one from La Taqueria and one from El Farolito and split them. We got the same type of meat so we could do a fair comparison.

Each were great although La Taqueria won out on the meat department.  You should try it. 
Once is about all your heart can take before calling it quits though.

I've only ever come in the late afternoon before dinner so I don't know about the lunch line. Even so, I think it'd be worth the wait.
author: Ashley I.

description: I've been coming to La Taqueria for years and years, over 25 years to be exact, the food is fantastic, I always get two tacos, with a small melon drink, the service is fast, and sometimes NOT so friendly, but Jesus has it gotten expensive.  $18 for two tacos and a drink is ridiculous.  I know I'm sending their kids to Stanford or they must be living in mansions!
author: Marvelous Margaret M.

description: I read an article about top burritos in America and this place was number 2 on the list. All I can say is they do deserve to be the best! I highly recommend their super burrito which is crispy from outside the ingredient is very fresh that melts in the mouth! I met the son of the owner he is very polite and friendly as well as all other staff.
author: Ellie T.

description: I have been many times before, and usually have a good experience. But today - not do much. 2 Super Burritos (both chicken) - both were unbearably soft, wet and flavorless. Took them home to eat and realized they weren't put on the flat top at all. Sigh.
author: Paul H.

description:
In theory, the stretchiness of mission style burrito tortillas kind of grosses me out. And the tortillas here are stretchy. But not in a gross gummy way like what I have had other places/was expecting. Just in a soft, delicious, normal tortilla way.

And that's the foundation for a great burrito. Which is what I had here, in the form of a veggie burrito, with hot sauce. I also tried the carnitas burrito, which was good, as were the chips and salsa and guac. Sure, there was a huge line, and my group of 4 had to throw some low key elbows for a seat on a cloudy and cold Sunday morning. But I'd totally do it again if I lived closer! Definitely worth the hype.
author: Gabriela L.

description:
We have wanted to try this place for a while and we finally did. We simply loved it!! 

We waited for our food around 20-30 min as the queue was quite big (Sunday around 5-6pm) but it was worth it! My burrito was really excellent, tasty, fresh and very well balanced. I ordered the pork carnitas and added avocado and sour cream and it was sooo good! There was no rice inside but I honestly did not miss it.

We were told that it is the best taqueria in the country, we are willing to believe this :-)
author: Caroline P.

description: My favorite taqueria is Taqueria Cancun. This place is also very good if you get th burrito grilled. No rice on the burrito, though. Prices went up after this place got named the best burrito in America. Long line but wait is short.
author: Karl K.

description: Bland and boring chicken enchiladas. The meat wasn't seasoned, the tortilla was soaked in a pool of chicken broth and it doesn't come with any sides. Chipotle serves a better meal at a better value.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Food: 4.0/5.0
Service: 1.5/5.0
Value: 3.5/5.0
Decor: 2.0/5.0
Overall: 3.5/5.0 

La Taqueria is always delicious and always crowded, and I'm glad its a Mission staple.  Preference is definitely to opt for the souped-up tacos and get a mix of meats.  The salsa that comes with the chips is honestly pretty meh.  This place is not quite #1 on the list for me, but it's way up there.  Cash only, and be calm about the line if it's your first time.
author: Damian W.

description:
Seriously one of the best burritos I have ever had! Not to mention you get to enjoy nearby Dolores Park afterwords. I have been a lotta places and had a lotta burritos in my day and I can definitely say the quality of burrito here is really high. I love the fact that they don't put rice in the burritos and instead they put extra meat. Also, they have this spicy chilli verde sauce that's pretty damn good as well!

Go stop by and show them some love!
author: Sam B.

description: La Taqueria making it to the "top burrito" places in SF is well deserved. I never had a more delicious super burrito and that beef-- ohmahgah it was like little pieces of steak heaven. Definitely get the SUPER burrito's.
author: Eden W.

description:
We stop here every time we are in San Fran as we always get off at the Mission & 24th St BART stop. It's only about a block away so perfect to quickly fill your belly after your flight. 

They're not the cheapest tacos you'll ever get but the flavor makes up for it. I always order the "Supreme" taco which includes sour cream, avocado, and cheese. Order them crispy and they griddle some cheese and wrap it around the first tortilla. 

It's always tasty, it always tastes good, and it's a block from my BART stop. What's not to love?
author: Adam R.

description:
The older man at the register is such a kind person, homeless man was walking around and was hungry and gave him some food.
Exceptional customer service, attentive to everything happening around him.
If you sit outside on the counter he will ask what your number is and get it for you.
Gave him a tip and he gave my lady a flower!
author: Mark H.

description:
If money were no object, perhaps I would rate La Taqueria much higher. I ordered 1 taco, 1 quesadilla, and 1 bottle of beer. Total damage? ~$23! I thought the cashier had miscalculated the cost and I went back to her to confirm that it was correct.

The carne asada dorado taco was huge. But come on ladies, we know it's not all about size. If it's too big to fit into my mouth, then it's uncomfortable. And the carne asada? A bit chewier than I usually like.

Now the quesadilla was fantastic. The tortilla was just crunchy enough and I loved the fresh guacamole inside. Also, the carnitas were much better than the carne asada.

Finding seating can be challenging but I've been practicing the art of making awkward eye contact with people who are almost done eating since I was a child in China.
author: Yi Z.

description:
So... the tacos were some of the best I've ever had!

My friend and I explored the Mission District on a Tuesday, so naturally we wanted to find a spot for Taco Tuesdays. We popped into La Taqueria mid-afternoon for our 3rd meal of the day, and the place was still busy and crowded. It's self-service, so you wait in line at the cashier to order your food and they'll call your number when it's ready. Seating is limited, but they are shared communal tables or high chairs if you want to enjoy your meal indoors. 

We shared the carnitas and chorizo super tacos and they were both AMAZING! Each taco was filled with pico de gallo, guacamole, sour cream, and other toppings.  The tacos were BURSTING with flavor and the meats tender and well spiced. The food tasted so fresh and authentic. I absolutely loved it!

I would have loved to go back La Taqueria for another meal, but we weren't close to the Mission District during the rest of our time in San Francisco unfortunately. If you love Mexican food, definitely go here. Everything is so tasty! You will not be disappointed.
author: Syyu C.

description: seriously the best burrito ive ever had. no exaggeration. carne asado super burrito. the salsa is on point, the avocado is creamy, the carne asado is juicy, and the service is quick. i can't imagine how it could have tasted any better. If you're just visiting SF and have to chose just 1 places to try a burrito... it's this place!
author: Hayley Z.

description: Pretty good place, decent food. The grilled burritos were great. It might seem a bit pricey, but the portion size is great. The staff is friendly.
author: Camila S.

description: My first choice for taquerias is El Farolito, but La Taqueria is sometimes nice for a  change of pace - but usually I don't find the long wait at all hours worth it. And the "specials" (dorado) always seem more appealing than they actually are. And it's usually so crowded! I don't know, I'm glad I've gone, but I just don't think it's worth it.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I LOVE IT HERE!! So far I've come here two times during my stay in SF..that sure does mean something. The Mexican food here really blows it out of the ballpark compared to NYC. I really liked this spot because they offer plenty of seating and everything is overall really good. If you're a first timer here you gotta go SUPER! Also, I recommend the carne asada burrito or tacos, they're both bangers. I tried their pork the second time and it wasn't as good as another place that I also go to, so you can't go wrong with the carne asadas'. As for drinks, I had the mango agua fresca and it was SO GOOD! I couldn't stop drinking it. It basically tasted like a thickish yummy mango juice, trust me on this one and go for it. 

I totally recommend this spot if you're around the area or just visiting SF because it's necessary to make your trip complete.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
I've been going to LT, since it opened. Always for a Super Carne Asada Burrito. The tomatillo salsa, in one hand. My burrito in the other. Bite, put some salsa, etc...
Still the best place around, for a burrito. Their food is always consistent. In 40+ years, the  prices have changed, but not their consistency in delivering a good product. 
Afterwards, it's next door to Dianda's, for a cannoli.
author: Anthony L.

description:
What in the damn hell....I just now realized I never wrote a review for La Taqueria...how did this completely fall off my radar....

Anyways, in the handful of times that I have dined here I would say my opinion has remained unchanged. From the tacos, burritos (both dorado and non) to guacamole and chips its decent but not something I would rave about nor would I wait more than 15 minutes to order. 

The elderly gentlemen (owner is my best guess) is super nice. He will randomly give out flowers to the ladies and sweet talk with them. In my case, I was wearing SF Giants gear so he gave me a free mango drink.

Price point is expensive, wait time can be lengthy, portion is lacking, and flavors are very flat

Overall Thoughts

I am more perplexed as to why all the hype than the fact that I haven't written my review for this place until now
author: Eddie W.

description: Also I wanted to say that this is one of my all time favorite taquerias. If I'm in sf I try to make it here!
author: Astrid I.

description: Keeping this real simple - burrito and quesadilla were the best I've ever had, tacos were top three.  Get the carne Assad burrito and get it grilled.  Don't mess around here and get cute - order the basics and you will be blown away
author: Kel V.

description:
The best the best the best. Hands down.

There is always a long line and for good reason. The burritos here are unbeatable -- juicy, fresh, flavorful. I always order the chicken and when I want to treat myself extra I'll get the guac and chips too (lol I always treat myself).

The staff are super nice as well and they keep the line moving as quickly as they can. It's hard to find a seat sometimes so if I'm with someone we try to have one person in line and the other looking out for a table opening up.

Cash only (if I remember correctly there's either a citibank/chase around the block and an ATM inside La Taqueria)
author: Vivian Y.

description: This is bar far my most favorite place here in The Mission. I've been to La Taqueria before it got famous, and I am still loving their comida! Whether you're visiting SF or a native, you HAVE TO come through here!
author: Alex W.

description: Very unimpressed with their burrito. The meat was bland. Felt like a bean burrito more than anything. I would highly recommend walking the extra block down to El Farolito if you're looking for a tasty burrito.
author: Christy C.

description:
If you're reading this right now, I would strongly urge you to take an uber through the hot mess that is San Francisco and stand in line for a damn BURRITO EL DORADO right now. I stood in line for about 30 minutes on a Sunday afternoon, but it was well worth it since I was in the area for food and hanging out with my friend and I had a red eye to catch. 

I'm from the East Coast and omg what I would give to have such an amazing burrito again. Now that I say that out loud, I realize my view may be a little skewed since there aren't a whole lot of burritos here and I'm really just deprived. Nevertheless, I got the carnitas burrito el dorado ($8something) with added guac (extra $1.25), the el dorado meaning they grill your burrito which gives it a slightly different dimension. I ate it right away without hesitation 25 feet away from the store an hour after having had breakfast just like Louis CK did in his Bang Bang episode. 

I'd come back!
author: Annabel T.

description:
Tip: Order the burrito "dorado" style. 

Only downside to this place is that sometimes it can be really unorganized in terms of the order / pickup line. But that's more on the customers than the establishment themselves lol
author: Greyson S.

description: Lives up to the hype. This really may be the best mission style burrito on the planet. Secret #1: Order dorado style. Secret #2: if you can find their phone number, they take phone orders. It's often faster to order by phone from the back of the line than to wait.
author: Matt M.

description:
ok this place is busy busy busy and don't stand in line unless you know what you want!   Got the carnitas burrito dorado style and was not disappointed! The chili salsa they have at each table made the burrito not only have a good kick to it but made all the flavors come together.  
I wasn't able to finish my burrito so it was my meal on the  plane!  Even cold and no chili sales it was so good.  Going to have to try the taco next time but if you go try the dorado style burrito it will not disappoint you.  Helpful hint - listen for your order number, service is fast and seating is limited but worth the it.
author: debi k.

description: Good burrito, just way to much ! Also no where to eat inside of taqueria . Because it's usually to packed
author: Charles G.

description:
Incredibly long line even on a weekday. Voted best burrito in the state/county w/ numerous placards and news clippings to attest to this.

Only 1 type of tortilla to choose from and a few select meats. The chicken is a rotisserie type style and the mouth feel is underwhelming. Not a whole lot of flavor and it just didn't add any textural elements to the already mushy mass. They don't provide rice so the overall burrito doesn't feel heavy. The cheese is melted directly on the tortilla which adds an oomph to the wrapping. They char and grill the crust of your burrito if you ask for it. Asked for spicy and it wasn't.

Would I come back? I doubt it. Compared to Corneta, they have better burritos and more variety sans that wait. This is also the most I've paid for a burrito...almost $12.
author: Julie L.

description: Meh. I'm not sure what the fuss is about. The line was long but decently fast, but the place was so packed I was literally physically uncomfortable from the second we got there. There's nowhere to go to not be in everybody's way. SO squished. Like you can smell everybody. A man was panhandling AT the tables. Even if there had been open tables, I couldn't have sat at one because we would have continued to get pushed there just as much. I'm uncomfortable just writing this. The menu isn't particularly easy to follow which is dumb...it's not like I'm new to burritos. The only bean option is pinto whole or refried. No thank you. The spicy salsa was NOT spicy. Just all around very meh. I'd much rather hit up El Farolito down the block. #overrated
author: Laura S.

description: I got the carne asada taco amd horchata.  Very good, but there were some grissles in the beef.  Besides that the taco was great and had just enough taste and food comes out pretty quick.  The horchata was sweet,  but somewhat powdery..
author: Stacy G.

description: Super popular place. When you go expect to wait in line and possibly not get a table right away. There is one type of burrito with diff meat options. You can make it "super" to add things like guaq (recommend doing this). I ordered chicken and they put a whole breast with out shredding it. They also don't use rice. It's a diff spin on a burrito, def makes the price worth it.
author: Alex M.

description: Love love love this place. I make it a point to stop by every time I visit San Francisco. I'm vegetarian, and I alternate between ordering the veggie tacos and the veggie burrito. Both are delicious. The people who run this establishment are extremely friendly and really care about the quality of their food and the customer experience.
author: Gabriela H.

description:
I've been going here for 20+ years & love their vegetarian burritos.
Simple, no rice, just beans.

However, since winning the James Beard award, the lines were to too long. Went yesterday, lines were not long. However, I ended up with
bad stomach ache, food poisoning. BAD! Perhaps the
cleanliness is lacking. Sorry this happened to one of my favorite
burrito stops.
author: skipper a.

description: Every time I visit SF I have to stop by and get a burrito from La Taqueria. My favourite is a super carne asada el dorado style.
author: Jane S.

description:
The food here is not worth the wait, the price, the tourists or the hype. It's not even worth writing a longer review.

So meh.
author: Clare C.

description:
La Taqueria was the first place I ate tacos in the city. I've only recently started eating Mexican food, and I couldn't have been more excited to try out La Taqueria. When I hopped into my Uber, the driver was so excited that I was going to La Taqueria. He said it was the best. 

Located in the heart of the Mission District, La Taqueria definitely exudes its own cultural vibe. I loved the architecture of the restaurant and I really felt I was in the Mission community. On a Wednesday at 2:15 PM, this place still had a small line for their food. I guess one could never get enough tacos or quesadillas or burritos right? Anyway, I wasn't sure what to get so I opted for what was recommended.

Carne Asada Tacos: 5 stars

I really liked the Carne Asada tacos. The meat was perfect. I'm not the biggest fan of beans so I actually picked off what I could, but this taco had plenty of meat & toppings on it. I saved it for last because my friend had told me it was the best out of all the tacos he tried.

Cabeza Tacos: 5 stars

I loved the Cabeza tacos as well. It had cilantro and onions on top. It was just the perfect combo together. 

Carnitas Tacos: 4 stars

I was really excited for the pork tacos, but they were just ok. They have the same toppings as the Carne Asada I believe, but for some reason it just didn't taste that great. I think it might have been just the texture of the meat since it's a lot more soft with the pork.

Carnitas Burrito (Super): 4 stars

This burrito was huge. My brother ordered it for his meal, and he was definitely stuffed after eating all of it. This burrito was stuffed with pork, beans, avocado, sour cream, and cheese. It did not disappoint. However, when my brother tasted my tacos, he said he wished he ordered the Carne Asada Burrito instead. Nonetheless, the burrito still tasted really good!

For around $25 for all of this, this wasn't bad at all. Considering that their tacos and burritos were stuffed and we all left feeling extremely full, we were extremely satisfied!

The only thing that was hard was finding seats. Although it didn't take too long for a table to clear up, I can definitely imagine that perhaps during lunch time or when it's an extremely busy hour and La Taqueria is extremely packed, it'd be hard to find a seat and be comfortable while eating these hands-on foods.
author: Marissa W.

description: I purchased a super carne asada burrito dorado style. It was only fried on one side and was extremely small for the price I paid. The place was overly packed, but they try to keep the line moving pretty quickly. I can tell that I caught them on an off day and that generally the food is good, but I was disappointed in my experience. I paid $15+ for one burrito, some chips and salsa and my food wasn't properly prepared, quantity was small and the wait was long.
author: Shanee' D.

description: I'm working in SF so I chose to have Mexican food and found this place on line. People have bad taste in Mexican Food. This place charges $13.00 dollars for a Super burrito! Soda and chips $6.00 dollars it is In SF I get it it should be more then other places but the burrito is like a Kids burrito with half a cup of Meat!!!!! The burrito was soggy no flavor in the meat. Over priced for what you get. Won't be going back here....
author: J R.

description: This is the gold standard of all Burritos in the known universe, and has been for the  25+ years I have been coming here. That said, I have to dock them a star for their total disregard for any kind of seating management. There is nothing more stressful than standing in line and watching the folks behind you grab all the seats, leaving you standing there with your burrito in your hand and nowhere to enjoy it.This didn't used to be an issue before the food networks picked up on the place, but now it has reached a point where I've turned around and left a few times, not even at peak times.
author: Loudon F.

description: The decor is dated and it may even be the original look but the food is phenomenal! The owner was very nice and offered us a sample of beef and chicken with some chips to help us decide what to order. We finally ordered the super chicken taco with guacomole and a beef burritto. My daughter couldn't finishe the burritto and they offered to cut it and wrap it for us. The food was great the second day. I would return again and again.
author: Maria M.

description:
CASH ONLY FYI! There are banks nearby and an atm machine in the restaurant as well. Lines will always be long (although they move quickly), you will always be on the look out for a place to sit, and that will not change.

I've grown up with La Taqueria, coming into the city and getting the same order every time. Even now, living on the East Coast, I come back for their burritos. I've seen this place get renovated with clearer menus, tech savvy tvs with rotating images from customers' photos on their Insta.

And while I still love their burritos, it's unfortunately not the same as what I remembered. Within the last two years, my burritos weren't what I remembered and my high expectations weren't met. With so much publicity now, and tourists learning about La Taqueria along with Mission District becoming much more popular with newbies moving into the neighborhood, La Taqueria will still be a go to destination for many, hence why their prices have gone up a bit.

I still love you La Taqueria, but please bring back the carne asada burrito that I remember!!
author: Alexa T.

description: I have been coming here since a kid with my dad and even though it's more commercialized now, the quality of the food has not changed. I was disappointed in the size of my burrito for the expensive price of 10 bucks I expected to get a burrito bigger than taco bell size. But the taste of the carne asada and the hot salsa is well worth the crazy prices.
author: Cortni T.

description: Tried the tacos, quesadilla, and burrito and I have to say the quesadilla was by far my favorite. Once the crispy, golden exterior is stuffed with guac, meat, and the rest of the goodness, the quesadilla is heavenly-- truly one of the best I've ever had. The taco was delicious as well, but I'm not sure if the slight improvement in flavor is worth double the price. With the abundance of taquerias in the Mission, I don't think this one distinguished itself enough to justify the steep prices.
author: Amy C.

description: Great place. The food is very delicious and filling, 2 tacos were more than enough. The prices are fair and the staff is friendly.
author: Jaime H.

description:
Super Burrito. It's good. Not sure that it's "the best meal in all of California" like you see on a ton of different websites when you google that, but it's a solid burrito. 

The wait isn't all that bad. We went on a May Saturday and it's probably 20 minutes but that's reasonable. The worst part is the parking. SF is giving me nightmares with the parking and traffic headaches. How does anyone WANT to live here.
author: Connor J.

description: GET THE CRUNCHY TACOS. Delicious and mouthwatering - just pair with a mango agua Fresca and you cannot go wrong. Colorful murals on the walls and friendly employees are a plus. A little pricey for a taco, so you won't see me there everyday. Worth it. They're the best!
author: Grace L.

description:
I've only been here once, and rarely do I give an establishment 5 stars on the first pass.  But this place is an outlier in all senses of the word.

After being told by a coworker that lives in the Bay Area about the greatness that is La Taqueria, I'll admit was a bit skeptical.  Sure, San Francisco has great food, but when I think of San Francisco, I generally think of the bakeries and dim sum of Chinatown, the seafood of Fisherman's Wharf, and (of course) the wonderful Italian food in North Beach.  Plus, I live in Texas.  As the Bowling for Soup song "Come Back to Texas" reminds listeners, "...the Mexican food sucks North of here anyway."  This is generally a mantra that I've lived by.  And it's damn near always true.

So, the first time I was told about it, I bookmarked it on Yelp, and figured I'd get there someday.  Then, I totally forgot about it.  

Fast forward to this week.  I was staying in Oakland and commuting all the way to the SFO airport on the Bart.  When I asked around for a good place to eat, I was reminded by the same coworker that La Taqueria was not far from the 24th Street Mission district BART station.  Having only spent a very little amount of time in the Mission district on a bus tour years ago, I remembered the murals and thought, "hey, how bad could it be?" and decided to give it a go.  If nothing else, I could get a good feel for the local culture.

I jumped of at the proper BART station, and headed up the stairs (no operable escalators, bummer...) and got to the surface, and started checking out the surroundings.  Things were colorful and diverse, as one would expect in the Mission.  A short walk down the street found me in front of La Taquiera, where I was greeted with an incredibly long line (At 1:30 in the afternoon!)  I almost thought I may skip it because the line was too long.  Thank goodness I didn't.  

I got in line, and started looking around.  Everything looked marvelous, but my coworker had previously talked me into getting 2 tacos - one chicken, one beef (carne asada), both supreme (with cheese, sour cream, and guacamole.)  I settled on sticking with this plan and waited for about 20 minutes.  I had a bit of a freak-out moment when I saw that they accepted cash only, but I checked and had plenty.

Eventually I got to the front of the line, ordered the aforementioned tacos, and ordered a Negra Modelo to go along with it.  After a brief wait, I got my tacos and beer, and wound my way across the restaurant (carrying a briefcase-suitcase, along with it) over to one of the picnic tables, where I fought for a place to sit.  I managed to cram my suitcase under the table between my legs while I chowed down on the tacos. 

And let me tell you.  What tacos they were.  DELICIOUS.  Especially the chicken taco surprised the crap out of me.  These were fantastic.  They were moist, tasty, and wrapped in a soft tortilla which had a little crunch to it--cooked to perfection.  The "super" aspect of the tacos made them very messy (I did manage to get it all over my shirt AND my suitcase), and the napkins on the table didn't provide much effectiveness or solace.  The carne asada taco was great as well, but I just loved the chicken taco so much.  It may well be the best taco I've ever had.  It is without question in the top 5.

I will be back...  this place is incredible.  I can provide a lot of negative feedback from the experience--crowded, long wait, no silver (or plastic) cutlery, cash only, no private tables, and getting the food literally all over myself and the items that I was carrying.  But friends, it was ALL worth it.  I'd go so far to say that for tacos that good, I'd gladly put on my best suit and bathe in a vat of pure, messy taco.

For first timers, I'd get the same thing that I got.  (Though the quesadillas, nachos, and burritos look equally great.)  The agua frescas looked great also.  I'll probably do one of those next time.  This place is great, and worth a detour.  I'll probably come here each time I take the BART from SFO to downtown San Francisco.
author: Joe K.

description: Went to the Giants game the other day and I found a posting for "the best burritos" in CA. Easy to find in the Mission district, look for the place with a long line. The line did move and I didn't mind since I'm a people watcher. Everyone was just having a good time. The burrito was good but I couldn't see what all the fuss was about. Not big, not that much meat, and where's the rice? Would I go out of my way to go back, NO, I could get a regular burrito anywhere. Try it once just to say you've been there. It did not compare to El Tepeyac in East LA, now that's a burrito.
author: Gilbert D.

description: Amazing super tacos and agua fresca de fresa! Worth the price and the wait, as you can taste every rich flavor of deliciousness! Cash only always limits the amount that I buy, which is a good thing. So i guess I'll just have to come back to try the super burrito during a future visit.
author: Belle S.

description: Giving this place 3 stars for a couple of reasons. First, it's cash only, which is kind of a bummer in today's world. Second, it's a bit pricey. Ordered 2 burritos, a quesadilla and 3 small tacos and the total came out to a whopping $60.00!!!! Mind you, their burritos are of average size (not like the super size offered at some other Mexican restaurants) and lastly, My order was to go (because the place was packed and there was no where to sit with my family), so we decided to walk down to McDonalds, which was only about a block away to order the kids a Happy Meal and sit down and eat there and by the time we started eating (which was probably no more than 5 mins from the time the order was ready), the burritos and tacos were extremely soggy from all the water from the pico de Gallo and excess fluid from the meat. On top of that, they forgot to give me sauce (even though I asked for it) and no chips is included :( overall, I would say this place is not worth the hype, so unless you live in the Mission area, I would suggest finding another local Mexican restaurant.
author: Anwar H.

description: Hands down the best burrito in SF. Fresh ingredients, great taste, and friendly staff. Would recommend to anyone visiting or an SF regular who is looking for their go-to burrito spot.
author: Rashi K.

description:
I have to say I was a bit disappointed with a place that claimed it had the best Mission style burritos. I got a Carne Asada super burrito and it was OK. Nothing wrong with it but nothing that wowed me as well. Plus, the size of the super burrito wasn`t that big, which left the hungry me wanting  for more. 

I have to say, the chips and salsa were amazing.  Took an extra order to munch away while lazing in Dolores Park. 

My final verdict would be that I prefer the burritos from the nearby El Farolito. But hey, thats just my opinion :)
author: Pranav B.

description: Big disappointment. Very overrated in my opinion. I got the carnitas super taco. It was extremely bland. No bold Mexican spices or seasonings. Was way over stuffed with toppings that made the taco wet and drippy. My husband had the carne asada burrito, it was average sized, not big. I tasted the carne asada and it was bland as well. Being tourists we won't be back. But I will make it a point to tell people Not to go there.
author: Julie R.

description:
It's a bit of a madhouse when you step into La Taqueria but it's definitely worth a visit.

1. Take the Bart to 24th St Mission because parking is difficult to locate
2. Order: Carne Asada Super Burrito Dorados-Style (cash only!)
3. Grab a seat & wait for your order
4. Chow down

The Carne Asada super burrito is not as massive as the one in El Farolito so you can eat it without fearing for food coma. I like the dorados-style option (fried on the grill so the burrito has a nice crispy texture). The burrito was good but it was a bit messy to eat since the salsa had too much liquid and the skin starting ripping towards the end.
author: Ruby C.

description: It was my first time trying this place. I usually like going to 24th and mission. But I love the  wrapped in a tortilla. And the best thing for some people is that they don't have rice; which means more meat. But I didn't seem more meat in replace of the rice. But still pretty delicious and filling. Will definitely want to see how the burrito it.
author: Bonnie C.

description: Super tasty authentic burritos. The pico de gallo made my tortilla a little soggy but the chicken was so fresh and well seasoned I barely noticed. The chips and salsa with avocado stole the show though and it would be worth going back just for those!
author: Marlee B.

description: Asada was on point, along with the lengua, good size portions! Avocado and sour cream is extra, a bit too much quesadilla will be just fine without it. Consistently busy so that tells you people love this place.
author: Enrique J.

description:
You have not had good Mexican food until you have had food from La Taqueria! It's amazing that on Mission, which is lined up with Mexican restaurants, everyone goes to this place cause they know where is best! 
We went at 3:30 in the afternoon, which is a weird time to eat, but it was packed!! I was amazed at how crowded it was but once I took a bite of my taco I knew why!! 
Everything about the taco was awesome! From the carnitas to the "to die for" guacamole on it, it was THE BEST taco I've ever had! 
If you are ever in the area, take the BART to the Mission Station, walk up Mission and you will not regret it one bit! I honestly dream about this meal!
author: Reimy K.

description:
awesome spot to hit before you drink or maybe after. Their burritos are on the little expensive side and it is cash only. I went with 3 other friends and we only got 4 burritos and 3 drinks and the total came well over 60. Make sure to get your burritos with crispy tortilla. 
I say in terms of my whole burrito experience I would give it a 4 star because the burritos in San Diego are still my favorite.
author: David J.

description:
Out of my entire existence in SF (25 years) I have been here maybe 5 times, and I live close by. Not that the tacos are not good. Some of the best in the city. Mainly because of the meat. No other taqueria (authentic) even comes close the quality of meat that they use here. Overall, this place possibly has some of the best burritos and tacos in the planet but... the burritos are tiny. They cost over $10 and if you go at the wrong time, there is a line out the door at this place. 

Overall, I find that there are many other places, nearly as good, if not better in ways (e.g. El Farolito or Las Palmas for tacos) where the portions are bigger and the prices are nearly half. That said, this place has become the superstar of taquerias in SF on a global level. They are doing something right. Though is the hype over rated? It always is. If this place only had rotisserie al pastor served Mexican street style, w pina, than maybe I would change my mind.
author: H K.

description:
After deciding to do a taco crawl in the Mission, my friends and I figured we should start with the most heralded spot, La Taqueria. We arrived fairly early, but found ourselves waiting in line with a very eclectic mix of clientele. It was fine though, because it gave us a good amount of time to make our decisions. The place overall is pretty well-kept, and new and improved TV screens as menus is a pretty modern touch on the place. The cashier was very friendly and gives out roses to all the ladies. Not bad.

I was a little hesitant at first at the prospect of paying $6 for a super taco, but it proved to be worth it. The mix of a flour tortilla with a chewy, yet crispy corn tortilla is effing genius. And to be fair, they definitely pack in the meats, cheeses and avocado. Went with the lengua (tongue) and the carnitas. Definitely a must-order. All the meats were tender and juicy, and even though it was very messy, it was quite satisfying.

Overall, a pretty great experience, and La Taqueria more or less lived up to the hype. I can't say that I would be willing to wait in the long lines for it every time, but for the most part, you know you're getting a good product when you come here, and that's really all you can hope for some times. I will definitely be back if I'm in the area during off-peak hours.
author: Eric J.

description:
After researching and asking where the best burrito in SF is, La Taqueria won out. Then you stand in a non-line where a Spanish speaking customer repeatedly attempted to cut us by... speaking Spanish. You pay the extra exorbitant fee for a super burrito, cause you're in the city and splurging. Then you shut your eyes and order the chips with salsa and guac because you don't want to know how much it'll cost at this point. Pretty sure the cashier just bumped us to the large horchatas without asking too. So don't forget to mention the size you actually want! $40 for two burritos, chips, and two drinks?! They forgot our chips btw and *threw out* the slip already. Didn't want to give them to us! 

Didn't realize that they only use pinto beans beforehand--would've asked for no beans. Also, if you're expecting the El Dorado to deliver on a crispy promise? I've done better at home with microwaveable burritos! The meat was lack luster and I didn't have access to the green sauce that might've made it a little more enjoyable. At that point I was making myself finish this insanely expensive meal. Could've gotten a shrimp burrito at my usual spot for the same price! 

Oh right, they somehow dosed our dining companion by mislabeling a meat filled burrito and ruined almost a decade of vegetarianism!!! Unless you have x ray vision, be sure to somehow check!
author: Dee L.

description:
Each time I have come here I release a sigh of disappointment, but I do recommend trying.

Overall the super burrito el dorado style (I have tried the carne asade, lengua, carnitas) is good but not great. The "watery" texture is not worth $12. But enough people have raved about this place that I admit my taste buds may be different from many others. So I recommend coming once to try.
author: Stephen K.

description: Go Dorado style all the way. These people know what they are doing and our carnitas burritos was soo good!
author: Viviana B.

description: Having read all the hype about this place, I went in with great expectations, and La Taqueria exceeded them all.  I ordered a carne asada burrito dorado style(which is key).  I only added cheese, cream, and hot sauce.  It was incredible.  The steak was tender and plentiful, but the star is the beans.  They have a great green hot sauce on the tables too.  My wife ordered the carnitas burrito dorado style and with everything (super style).  We had planned on splitting two burritos among the four of us, but they were so good I waited through the line to order two more.  Overall this is the greatest burrito I have ever tasted.
author: Jeff S.

description:
The much anticipated La Taqueria, awarded best burrito in the country. And boy oh boy was I disappointed. I was really looking forward to this and wanted to like it a lot. Still wish I did!

First off, none of the staff use gloves while cooking. The chopped meat was hard and chewy- lots of fat and cartilage. And while some might argue that this is all part of the authentic experience, I argue that it is disgusting.

The burritos were soggy and dripping wet, which required the second halves to be eaten with a fork and knife. The meat itself (we had the carnitas and chicken) tasted mediocre at best, nothing special and even slightly bland. I couldn't bring myself to finish mine, but still ended up with a bad stomach afterwards.
author: Christina W.

description: Drove to SF to try this place it was delicious ! However they really do need to expand bigger place and more seating. It was very busy and crowded. The line was wrapped out in the street. The workers were extremely nice. I would come back again only if in the area.
author: Judy M.

description:
THIS PLACE IS CASH ONLY!

We arrived on a Sunday afternoon around 1230pm and waited about 30 minutes in line. It was out the door. It gets packed and there is very limited seating.

I got the regular chorizo burrito and my friend got the veggie supreme burrito. We also ordered a side of chips and salsa. It was all delish. Some reviewers commented on how one burrito served as two meals but I was able to polish off the whole burrito in one sitting without any difficulty ;)

We regretted not ordering the guac to go with our chips but did not want to wait another 30 mins in line!

As we were getting up to leave, the live mariachi music started :)

This place is authentic and in the heart of mission. Reasonably priced as well -- 2 burritos + chips and salsa + a drink for about $20!

Wish I lived in SF so I could get a weekly burrito fix! I would definitely recommend it.
author: Nehal P.

description:
I'm
From San Diego and Mexican food sucks everywhere to me because of I.T haha but I came here and actually had a very very good super steak burrito. Glad to have found a spot i can go to in Nor cal.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
Wow getting close to 3k reviews already. Not sure if me writing this review even matters, but oh well. Solid 4 stars. Felt like eating tacos so we yelped to see what was best and picked La Taqueria based on rating. It was pretty bomb. I got a loaded carne asada taco and a normal pork taco. The steak one was great. I may just be a sucker for sour cream and guac, but it was really delicious. Cheese was melted into the tortilla too. The pork one was alright. A little dry for me so I kept adding green sauce. Also got a large horchata which is what you would expect.

Food was delicious but it can get a little pricey. I think I paid around $20 for 2 people. Not horrible though. Have to come back sometime and try a burrtio or a quesidilla. I saw other people's meals and it looked delicious.
author: Thomas T.

description:
I'm converted- the Mission has the best burritos in the world and this place convinced me. I was in town for a weekend and I was told this was a must visit. I got a super burrito dorados style. They're huge, and I was told that you could eat it in two meals- it was so good I finished in one sitting. I was craving these burritos for the next week.

The seating inside is limited and crowded, but you come for the food, not the dining experience!!
author: Jacqueline D.

description: So good and uniquely SFPride. Carne asa burritos are juicy and delicious. Cheese quesadillas are a good pairing with their unique salsa and guacamole.
author: Christia M.

description:
I came to La Taqueria on an off-peak hour (4:00pm on a weekday) so I managed to spare myself from the long lines and competitive seating scene. 

My order consisted of the super carnitas taco, super carne asada burrito, and the mango / pineapple agua frescas and I basically wolfed everything down. My taste buds were probably dancing for the whole half hour I was eating everything. I am from NYC and we're not particularly known for our Mexican food, but this was the best Mexican food I've had. 

Totally recommend a pit stop here if you're in the area for a casual lunch or dinner!
author: Claudia C.

description:
Alright. So countless people have told me that I needed to make the pilgrimage to LaTaqueria. From Anthony Bourdain to friends and family that have visited San Francisco I've been told repeatedly "You must go".

La Taqueria, well, it just wasn't that great. It was good. I wasn't upset with the food, and it tasted fresh, but at no point did I receive that "wow" moment where I could say "this is one of the top taco/burrito places in the world".

It's likely I'll be murdered for saying this, but, frankly, I like Chipotle better. Maybe I don't have taste buds or I'm an idiot, but it really wasn't that great. Try it for yourself and see what you think. I hope for you that it tastes much better than it did for me!
author: Eric M.

description: James Beard Award Finalists for 2017 -- San Francisco2017 America's Classics winners. Enough said!
author: Sonya B.

description: Any of their burritos dorado (grilled) are amazing. You have to ask for it. I got the veggie and it was super yummy, but I take a point off as the ingredients are way too basic for their veggie. But I'm sure the meat options are 5 stars. Always get grilled burritos.
author: Crystal Y.

description: Best burrito in town. Everyone goes for the carne asada, but I love the lengua. Prepare for long lines. The chips are not that great.
author: B. Y.

description: I now understand why this place is so amazing! We arrive at this place a little before it open and there was a line, but we were disappointed when my friends and I tried their tacos. Very filling and tasty. Need to find a place in NY like this place
author: Guy H.

description: Way overrated. Not worth standing in line for an hour and a half. Yeah you got me this time, but I will not be back. As an Angelino, I find it offensive for this restaurant to make such bold claims as being the best tacos and burritos. I ordered several burritos (Beef, chicken, and pork) along with tacos, and I did not see anything extraordinary about it. I could have made better food at home. Don't fall for the hype.
author: Meme F.

description:
One of the best tacos in SF I've had so far.  Unfortunately, it's not consistent. 

The first time I had La Taqueria was several months ago. I was really impressed with the food. Although I hated the wait and the lack of seatings in the restaurant, I recommended it to everyone because the food was amazing. If you get the super size tacos, it's huge! I usually get 2 and my bf gets 3. The salsa in the bottle will add a kick to the tacos if you enjoy spicy food. The strawberry agua fresca is delicious! 5/5 (for SF standards, not comparing to TX)

However, I went back a few weeks ago and found the quality wasn't the same. Maybe they were having an off day but I didn't think the taco meats were marinated long enough. I ordered the exact same things as before (carne asada, lengua). It was still pretty good, but wasn't bursting with flavor as before. Strawberry agua fresca is still delicious. Although I wish they would use a bigger straw so the strawberry bits won't get stuck. 3/5

Overall, it's still the best taco place I've found in SF so far, regardless of the inconsistency in quality. I'm gonna average it for a total score of 4/5.
author: Anny T.

description:
I live for places like Taqueria - lively, local joints with amazing food. And the hype is right, you haven't had a burrito until you've eaten one from the Mission. La Taqueria certainly gets the job done and more. 

First, however, make sure you have CASH on hand, as I'm almost certain it's cash-only. The place gets crowded quick, so have your friend snag a seat while you wait on line. Also note that the burritos here are famous for NOT having rice. Admittedly, I found that strange at first, but it does help the flavors of the meat, beans, and cheese really come to the forefront.

The burritos here are truly worthy of song, and you MUST get it "super" (aka with cheese, guac, and sour cream). Each burrito is of ideal size - filling, but not too big. The guac tastes fresh, the beans rich, and no matter what meat you order, it's cooked and flavored to perfection. (I recommend carne asada.) These were so good that I gabbed on and on about them with my friends long after the meal. On top of that, the chips are nice and crispy, and a good selection of Mexican beers is always a plus.

La Taqueria is a legendary for reason, and a must- visit when you're in San Francisco.
author: Charley K.

description: My sisters grew up eating at this taqueria with my mom. It's their absolute favorite! I'm talking like for more than than 30 years. My mom and I happened to be in SF yesterday so we went out of our way to eat here for lunch. The line was out the door, which looked a little discouraging, but they really have their assembly line going like a well oiled machine. we ordered 2 carne asada super tacos and 2 variants super tacos. YUM!!!!! If I knew how big it was I would have just ordered one but at the same time it was so good that if I DID only order one I would have said man I should have ordered another!! Can't wait to take my husband here. They really should think about expanding
author: Katie M.

description:
By far some of the best tacos I've had outside of Mexico. Stopped by on Taco tuesday and got 3 of the carne asada tacos and a beer. AMAZING. 

Totally random stop as well after recommended by a friend. Line is long and cash only, but totally worth it.
author: Michael P.

description: Best Tacos In The City. You must try it, but be careful it might be addictive.
author: Levon K.

description: The best carne asada I have ever had the pleasure of consuming. Parking is a challenge, but be patient because it is well worth it. Seating is very limited, so also use patience. Orders to go are always welcome. My favorite Mexican go to spot in the city.
author: Lynette T.

description: Not sure about the hype. Good was a-ok. Not worth the line at all.
author: Duy N.

description: Best Of The Mission..!! This place has the best steak I've ever had in my life.. So I eat Nowhere In San Francisco Unless It's HERE..!! I DRIVE FROM OAKLAND AN 30 Min To An Hour Depending on Time Of Day .. PAY TOLL AND METER.. Just To Get My Steak Burrito , Chips And Salsa And Please Don't Ever Forget Your Strawberry Drink That I Can't Even Pronounce.. But When I Say It They KNOW Exactly What I'm Talking Bout..!! Oh By The Way.. I was there for Carnival.. LINE WAS AROUND THE CORNER DOWN 25th Street.!!
author: Tywain W.

description:
I had a carnitas burrito and a chicken taco-el dorado style. 

I thought the burrito was okay. I'm a heavy eater, and Chipotle burritos usually fill me. This unfortunately seemed like a small burrito, and it felt pretty disjointed, with contents that might spill out. The guac was mostly on the bottom of my burrito and although I requested a spicy burrito, it didn't seem like that had been the case. The carnitas itself was excellent. If I ever come back, I am certain to go with El Dorado, because otherwise there didn't seem like anything super unique.

The taco was very hefty and filling for what I was expecting. The chicken was really juice with some excellent texture. I enjoyed it very much, and probably would pick the tacos over the burritos, based on my visit today.
author: Michael Z.

description:
So I know i was freakin' hungry but this place is on point!

Never realized that when other places use rice or other fillers (lettuce?  ugh!) in their burrito that it takes away from the meat being the star of the show.

Regular carne asada burrito with hot sauce?  The bomb!

Super carnitas quesadilla including sour cream, guac and cheese?  Awesome.

Will be back again.  I think I'll tell my other burrito places to go light on the rice from now on.
author: My best mea l.

description: OK I don't know where to begin with this place. Let's start with the food. Oh my god oh my god oh my god oh my God is all I can say about this food. I would bath myself in anything with these guys made. I had the beef tongue taco and the chorizo burrito and both of them were out of this world. I also got a Fresca which to this day I still dream about. The only bad thing about this place is that it has ruined other Mexican restaurants here in Hawaii (where I now live). Every restaurant here that claims to be a great Mexican food only makes me dream that I wish I was back in San Francisco. I love this place I love this place I love this place. Oh yeah it's cash only so bring a lot of cash.
author: Marcus S.

description: Our all time favorite!  We have eaten here for years and it is finally time to write a five star review.  Their pico de gallo, carnitas, and carne asada are so good with either a burrito or quesadilla.  Love their open air seating right outside where you can see the business of the Mission.  Definitely come here when it is not lunch or dinner time when the lines are way too long.
author: Gab T.

description: I LOVE la taqueria! Best burrito in nor cal by far. I've had carnitas and carne asada burrito and I personally like the carne asada more. Make sure to ask for el dorado style if you want it crispy. The one thing it doesn't come with is rice. I'm okay with this but I do know some people who think rice in a burrito is a must.
author: Samantha G.

description:
Hmmm. I'm missing something. 

My coworker hyped this place up for me, so I was excited. However, what a M A J O R disappointment.

Let's get one thing straight. I grew up in the heart of the Central Valley. To be specific, Delano. I grew up with tried and true Mexicanos from Jalisco, Guadalajara, Michoacan, Zacatecas, and so on. I'm not trying to say I'm a Mexican food snob, but...okay. Well. Forget it. I'm a Mexican food snob, okay? Mexican food is my comfort food. 

With the exception of San Diego and Los Angeles, most major cities get Mexican food W R O N G.

Let's get into why La Taqueria wasn't the best and why I left thinking I ate seven tons of food:

1. $6 for a "super" taco and almost $4 bucks for a regular taco. Uh, no. Where I come from, a super taco is $1.25 ($0.85 on Tuesdays) and a regular taco is $0.75 ($0.50 on Tuesdays)

2. Why in the world would ANYONE mess up a TACO by adding beans, guac, sour cream, and everything but the kitchen sink?! I was NOT impressed by the super taco, nor was I impressed by the regular taco! I enjoyed the semi-crispy tortilla, but I did not enjoy looking like an ogre while I ate. I had food oozing out from the taco, and it was just a terrible eating experience for me. My coworker was just smiling and so happy, and I was sitting there shaking my head wishing I was in Delano or Earlimart getting me some bomb tacos (like, three, for $5). Just give me an unadulterated street taco!!!!!!!! Two mini tortillas, flavorful asada, cilantro, onions. That's it!
