3. Ummmm. The meat wasn't that flavorful, guys. Sorry. My meat needs to be seasoned to perfection. I think they pile all those extra toppings to hide the fact that the meat isn't flavorful.

Sorry, not sorry. La Taqueria is just another SF place that's been hyped up, and allllll these people who don't know a true taco or burrito if it hit them in the face congregate here just to say they ate at the #1 Taqueria in the nation. Whatever.

Ya'll have been duped! 

I'm not that cynical, so I'll leave you with some pros:
1. Fairly fast
2. Food was fresh and hot

Just remember: don't believe the hype!
author: Chandra D.

description:
La Taqueria is an excellent casual Mexican joint in the heart of the Mission. My friends and I arrived for lunch on a weekend to a line out the door; while there was a bit of a wait, we could tell that the assembly line putting together the tacos/burritos was extremely efficient, and there was even someone who took the orders from people waiting in line and wrote them down on a slip of paper, so that everyone could pay right away without wasting time pondering choices in front of the cashier.

My friends and I got two regular burritos (carne asada and carnitas) to share as well as one taco of beef head (cabeza). We also got chips and salsa, sour cream, and avocado (guacamole) on the side. The regular burritos came with beans (we got pinto), a generous amount of pico de gallo, and the meat of choice. Interestingly, no rice is included, which for me at least, was not a bad thing (much more focus on the meat and taste of the fresh ingredients). Out of everything we tried, the carnitas was probably my favorite--the flavor was distinctively porky, the meat was fall apart tender and very, very juicy. All the burritos went so well with the avocado and the green salsa verde that came on each table. In general, there's something very home-y about the food in this restaurant--perhaps it has to do with the Mexican grandmother figure dolloping up the avocado and sour cream for us, or the freshly fried crisp-yet-chewy tortilla chips with freshly chopped tomatoes and onions. Overall, this was a very satisfying meal and a perfect representation of the SF Mission-style taqueria.
author: David K.

description:
If you like to wait in line, then make sure to wear comfortable shoes.  It's always packed.  And if you're going to wait that long, make sure you get your burritos grilled.  If not grilled, why bother waiting in line.  : )  They are delicious!

I would give 5 stars to this place if not for the sanitary conditions of this place.  During my last visit, I told the guys who were working the counter that they need to use gloves to touch the food.  They were using their hands without gloves to touch meat, cheese, vegetables and then proceed to grab the dirty towels to wipe the counters.  It was disgusting.  I told the cashier too but no one cared.  I even spoke to them in Spanish and they didn't do anything.  If they can't follow a simple food safety procedure, then I won't ever go again.  I shouldn't have paid and threw the burrito away.   And that's why I will never go again to this place.  Unless they change their cleanliness, no one should patronize this dirty restaurant.  I am not making this stuff up.  I love the taste but if it's so dirty, than I am not going to risk my health over it.
author: John L.

description: WHAT THE HECK. Crispy on the outside & a soggy ass mess on the inside. Soooo overrated. Thx Diners Drive Ins & Dives for nothing
author: Lynette C.

description: Had the mission style burrito here on a beautiful Saturday afternoon. The flavor of the meat and tenderness is absolutely amazing. The fresh guacamole and salsa add great flavors. Very generous portions. My kids enjoyed their tacos, this place definitely lives up to the hype.
author: NO' L.

description: The food is delicious. I love their lengua tacos and their burritos are great too. The extent of their inconsistency however is absurd. The last three times I came they ran out of several proteins. Even calling ahead and checking doesn't help... they'll lure you in and still, not have what you want. I ordered my food and only after placing my order did they tell me they didn't have lengua... like wtf. Communicate with the people who are taking orders/answering phones. I wouldn't be surprised if these long lines get shorter... haven't we all seen great restaurants fail after staff become overly confident/cocky/lazy? Fuckin pissed.
author: Wajdi F.

description: Omg, their super tacos are literally mini burritos.  I swear they're like maybe a quarter the size of their burrito?  Anyway, I got the chicken, and it was this awesome chunk of juicy, stewed chicken, covered in some melted white cheese, beans, a generous helping of guac and pico.  All of this was wrapped in a fresh, warm tortilla.  So, so, so good.  At 2 pm on a Sunday, there were no tables available.  It's cash only and a bit pricey, but it's well worth a visit and a personal favorite.
author: Lily N.

description: The super burrito carne asada was okay, but the carnitas was really good. Lots of flavor. Super burrito has meat, beans guacamole, sour cream and cheese. Good portions, line was out the door on a Saturday during lunch time. Very little seating as it was packed.
author: Eric M.

description: We are from NY and this was prob the BEST FOOD we had in all of San Fran. I don't think any burrito can live up to this one.
author: Manju M.

description: Yummy, cheap food, a hole in the wall but great place for locals to eat. Friendly staff, quick service and ability to customize meals. Good place!
author: Grace C.

description:
I have a not-so-secret tip for y'all: "Dorado" is THE STUFF. Dorado means "golden" in Spanish, and when you ask for your burrito "dorado" at La Taqueria, they'll grill it on the hot plate after it's wrapped up. This puts a good burrito over the edge to definitely in the top two burritos (if not THE best) that I've ever had.

I ordered a super carnitas burrito (dorado, obviously) and watched as they assembled it to glean their secrets. I loved how they laid the strip of cheese on the tortilla before warming it up in the warming oven--this made the cheese an even layer of melted gooiness and is something that far more taquerias need to do. The carnitas were superb, the beans were perfect in seasoning and texture, and THERE IS NO RICE! HALLELUJIAH for a more authentic burrito! Really, it's a great burrito top-to-bottom, and having it dorado really takes it over the top. If I had one complaint, it would be that the guacamole was a little underseasoned for my liking, but they're purposely on the more-avocadoey side of the spectrum.

The salsa is great. The tacos are huge, from what I saw. I was so tempted to drive to the city the next day just to get another burrito here. It was that good.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Great late night taco joint. Fast service. Good Mexican food with usually large portions at reasonable prices. Gets really busy after hours on the weekend. Friendly staff.
author: Mark F.

description:
(bird lawyer voice*)
Now I may not be a big city, fancy burrito eater. I'm just a simple Australian who is new to this here burrito scene. But I think a good burrito is still a good burrito whether or not it is filled with rice, is a bit smaller and costs a little more.
BA-GAWK!
(/bird lawyer voice)

Alright, now that I have got that odd reference out of my system. I came here on a Saturday at lunch time, pretty much because the burrito has been given some award about being the best burrito. I haven't tried all that many burritos, so who knows, my rating may change at some point in the future.

When you come, expect a wait, expect to pay in cash and grab a table when you can. I got the super chicken burrito and had a taste of a super beef burrito. Both tasted great, the meat was really tasty and they nicely loaded up the super-ness (sour cream, avo and cheese). The chips and salsa were tasty but nothing fancy. By the end I was full but not "I shouldn't have eaten that whole burrito" full, which was a nice feeling.

* The hyper-chicken lawyer from futurama
author: Tristan L.

description: This place is amazing!! We went to San Francisco yesterday & I ordered the carne asada burrito (crispy) with avocado. Has to be by far the best tasting burrito I've ever had. This place never disappoints me. They have some of the very best Mexican food I've ever had. The only problem with this place is that it's far from where I live. After eating their food it's difficult for me to go elsewhere, because nothing compares. They do have long lines & seating can be a challenge, however it is well worth it. Lastly they are a little pricey and it's cash only so be prepared to pay about $30 for 2. I will definitely be back. I love this place
author: Evelia A.

description:
What we ordered
*Four Supreme Fried tacos (sour cream, guacamole included) fried tortilla is wrapped in a soft Tortilla -$6 each
-two carne asada tacos: meat had a smokey flavor and was my favorite out of all the tacos
-one lengua taco: meat was stringy like carnitas, not what I usually have in texture but still good
-one carnitas taco: my mom ate it but she said it was good 

Drinks
-Large horchata and Coke ~$3 each

Service
-expect a long line bc the food is good. Service is fast
-owner could tell I was HANGRY and gave me free chips/salsa while I waited for my order #SoNice #fivestars

Tip
-I'm a spicy food fan. But beware of that green salsa I was dying. Like no joke. 
-loved the red salsa. It has a smoke flavor too. Owner called it tomato sauce haha
author: Joy M.

description: Best taco spot in SF, hands down! I'm always here for lunch and the food never disappoints. Great service, clean and the carne asada is the bomb!!!!!!
author: Aaron J.

description:
My favorite taco place in the city!! No rice in the tacos, just meat and beans! Get the super taco w/ all the fixings of guac and sour cream. One taco is expensive, but enough to fill a small girl like me. 

So sad that the lines are so freaking long these days!!
author: Cynthia X.

description: I despise lines, and the line here sometimes goes out the door. But with that being said, I'd happily wait in that line for another carne asada burrito.
author: David M.

description: Best Burrito that ive had in a long time. I ordered pollo sasdo, and also a vegetarian burrito, both were very very good. To bad its so far, but its good enough to make the trip and endure the waiting for food this good.
author: karal k.

description: Super huge portions I got three tacos and my wife got a burrito, we could not finish all of it. Great food quality and fresh. Place is extremely small and hard to find seating so plan on taking it to go or standing around until you get a seat. The line to place an order is long as well so if you go plan on spending some time there.
author: Chris A.

description:
If you want good Mexican food in the San Francisco, you won't find any fancy modern restaurants or family friendly chains, but instead, a crowded hut on Mission St called La Taqueria. At first glance, it's not very impressive looking, but it's not unclean. The crowds are intense during lunch and dinner hours, but the food definitely speaks for itself. As a Los Angeles resident, I generally look down on Mexican cuisine in Nor Cal, but I can vouch for this place. They have a big menu, but you can't go wrong with their tacos or super burritos. When you order, they make it for you as you go along so you can customize your burrito with different kinds of tortillas, meat, beans and salsa. 

Of course, the portions are way to big regardless of what you order. Unless you're really hungry might want to split your order. This place is always crowded, even late at night. But once you order, it's really quick. They also serve churros and variety Mexican beverages like horchata. 

This place is cash only, so remember to bring some if you plan to order a lot of food.
author: Steve N.

description:
Let's start off by saying, I wanted to give La Taqueria the benefit of the doubt by the 4 star rating and 2400+ reviews. More often than not, I agree with my fellow Yelp reviewers and come to the same collective rating for restaurants. However, that wasn't the case this time. 

My long time taqueria go-to spot in San Francisco is El Farolito..and it will always and forever stay that way. I kid you not. There's nothing more satisfying than a Super Shrimp Burrito packed with rice, avocado, sour cream, salsa, and some juicy succulent shrimp. Ok, I'm going to stop right there. I'm not reviewing El Farolito's burritos. 

Back to my review on La Taqueria. I GET IT. I understand why most reviewers rate this place so high in the star count. It's pretty good..... The meat is tender, well seasoned, and the menu offers this really cool "dorado style" option for burritos. This is pretty unique, i must add. Dorado Style consists of a burrito that has all of its fixings wrapped in and then pressed down to give a nice crunchy and toasted crunch to the tortilla. It tasted great and I love the concept! However, it wasn't something so out of this world that knocked my boots off. 

Moving on, I wasn't a fan of the tortilla chips and salsa. I know, it's such a small component of this authentic Mexican meal, but c'mon now.. I think La Taqueria could create a better crunch on their tortilla and flavor to their salsa. 

Also, I found the "order" and "pick up" layout to be quite odd. I'm not a Feng Shui Master by any means, but I couldn't help but notice the flaw! Why is it that you have to squeeze by fellow patrons just to pick up your order? The pick up location is smacked in the middle of the line. There isn't a flow to the restaurant and it just seemed rather awkward.

All in all... I'm going to stick to my favorite La Taqueria, El Farolito.
author: Briana H.

description: Love the burritos here!! Get the super (with guac) and you can even get it grilled a little bit so the outside is warm and slightly crispy. The key here is NO RICE in the burrito which makes it awesome. Gets a bit crowded but it's worth!!
author: Jeana Y.

description:
First time in SF and found this taqueria on thrillist. I love tacos and was extremely satisfied with this place. There was already a line 15-20 min before they even opened. That's a good sign! You order at the register, pay and you'll be given  a ticket for pick up. They have an assembly line of making the food behind the counter and there is a full visible view for the customers to watch them. 

I ordered the carne Asada tacos. Juicy, seasoned right, tender, and the taco was packed with a lot of  meat. They don't skimp out on the meat which is a win win for them! Their salsa was the bomb! Spicy and full of flavor. 

This is a place that I am going to come back to when visiting SF again!
author: Vy N.

description: Best tacos in the Mission. I love this spot and would go every weekend except it has become so popular it's hard to find a time when there isn't a crazy long wait!!
author: Jasmine D.

description:
I know La Taqueria got voted best burrito in America, and I hate to disagree with it, but I've eaten here several times and now I feel like they are just resting on their laurels. Yes, there's a line out of the door pretty much all the time and they have secret things on the menu, but I've just found the meat to be rather tasteless & the burrito a bit dry. I prefer Pancho Villa (16th and Mission) over this place, plus they have a killer salsa bar.

Location: 25th & Mission - easy to get to via BART or the 14.
Food: Tacos, burritos ($8.50), quesadillas.  You can get a super burrito ($10.90) which includes sour cream, avocado, and cheese (perhaps this is less dry than the regular one)
Meat selection: Carne asada, pork (carnitas), beef head (cabeza), beef tongue (lengua), sausage (chorizo), or chicken. The vegetarian option is beans, cheese, and salsa.

Burritos: I've gotten both the carnitas and pollo burrito. They don't put rice in the burritos, so just beware if you like this in your burritos. I find it a bit bland with just the meat, beans, and salsa. Maybe I need to get the "Super" burrito, but I find the meat to be lacking in flavor / spices as well, so not sure how much of a better option that is. It's also $11, which is much pricier than other burrito places in the Mission offering something similar. There's no salsa that comes with this if you get it to-go, which is disappointing to me. There's one salsa option on the tables if you dine-in.

Secret Menu: You can get the burritos grilled -- "Dorado" style -- just ask for it when you order.

Payment & Seating: Cash only, so be prepared. Wait in line (typically ~10 min, the line moves quickly), then pay for your food and try to snag a table. It gets quite crowded in there, and coming with a group of more than 4 people may be hard to get a table unless you're there really early or late.

Overall, I still come here because it's convenient, but I don't think it's my favorite burrito. If you want something cheaper, faster, and with more salsa options, go to Pancho Villa.
author: Christina L.

description: Very simply the greatest burrito I've ever had in my life. We split a carnitas and Assada and both were amazing. Long line but it moves quickly. Cash only and an absolute home run experience.
author: New J.

description: Oh my, how many ways can you say yum?  So reasonably priced for a burrito that is just what you need when hungry.  Burrito carnitas was meaty, tasty and large.  Loved the "super" vegetarian burrito...pinto beans, cheese, fabulous guacamole rolled up...perfection.  Can't go wrong here.
author: Mia S.

description:
Loved the vibe here! Burrito (regular, $8ish) wasn't pan-roasted like we saw the other burritos were, so it resulted in a sloppy, soft burrito *sad face*. However, the chicken (albeit slightly bland), was really fresh and juicy. The pinto beans were soft but intact, seasoned lightly. Delicious! Not exactly the overload-me-with-spices burrito, but it tasted especially fresh and made with attention! 

The taco was also simple and straight-forward. Corn tortilla was soft and fresh, really delicious. At $4 it was a bit over-priced though.

Next time- the super burrito, or whatever it takes to get my tortilla toasty and crunchy :P Oh and definitely need to try the lengua too
author: Maggie G.

description: So, the wait to this place was a bit ridiculous and the fact that there was nowhere to sit was a bit frustrating. We were in town visiting some friends and they suggested this place for lunch as we were walking down the street. We were hesitant at first upon seeing the line, but in the end we are glad we decided to check it out. The burritos are huge and very good. They kept us full well into the evening. Once we placed our order, everything came out fairly quickly.
author: Rossy A.

description: This place was great. Amazing vibe and energy and delicious food! The no rice burrito was superb! will be back!
author: Heliana M.

description:
Ate: 3 tacos - 2x carne asada, 1x chorizo - both with guacamole.

Very very busy taqueria - for a reason. These were delicious, stuffed tacos - same sized tacos as elsewhere but stuffed full with meat, and the price reflects it (i think it was ~$4/taco).

Delicious carne asada, though not piping hot. Chorizo was also delicious but a little fatty.

Guacamole was fresh as it comes and they weren't shy about serving size.

This place is up there for best taqueria in SF.
author: David J.

description:
This place was rated one of the country's best burritos, and I never bought into the hype and favored El Farolito's until I came in the other day and had a burrito "Dorado" style, with guacamole and everything. It was absolutely amazing and magical.

Other than their burritos though, I feel like everything is still a little overpriced for what it is, and I would stick with other nearby choices like El Farolito, but I definitely have a new found respect for this place after having their Dorado style burrito.
author: Andrew T.

description: This place is amazing! One of my favorite places to get burritos. I definitely recommend the super carne asada burrito. The only problem is that the lines are super long because the burritos are so good. The agua frescas are super good too. I recommend this place if you want some great Mexican food. The "El Dorado" Super Burrito is also amazing because they fry the burrito on the grill to create a nice crispy outside. The salsa is also very good because of the spicy tangy flavor.
author: Griffin L.

description: This place got crazy hyped up to me from the reviews, YouTube vids and what I had researched online. Honestly everything is alright, but you can definitely get much much better Mexican food elsewhere. I got the carne asada super burrito, for $12.50, that better be freaking dank for that price and it was just ok. I was pretty disappointed, the carne asada was dry and really didn't have much flavor. They say they don't put rice so you can taste the quality of the meat, I did not taste the quality. The pinto beans broke through the tortilla from the BEAN juice they had in the burrito(yuck). Everything just seemed bland to me. I got it Dorado style and it seemed they put it on the grill for a second. My girl got the carne asada tacos ($4.50 per taco and $7 if you want guac in it??) She didn't seem too happy. I also got a cabeza taco (reg style to taste the meat quality) and it was very dry meat with no flavor. When I had asked the guy if this was my order when they called my number for pickup, he simply looked at me hella smug and didn't say a word, excuse me MY GUY. Paid over $35 for two people. I feel like this place is a tourist trap, looking 30 minutes for parking and going through this was definitely not worth it. Check out El Rancho Supermercado in Castro valley or Tacos Sinaloa in Oakland for smacking food. Also get that triple threat burrito or any at Papalotes in SF. That is all, won't come back.
author: Alan B.

description:
After hearing so much freaking HYPE about this place.  My gf and I were like F*** IT, we are gonna try this place.  We walked out and paid for a round trip ticket for the BART.  La Taqueria here we come!

Walking right up to the entrance, we immediately knew we were at the right place.  It's freaking chaos up in here.  People everywhere and the line is so long it wraps around a set of tables and out the door!  The line moves fast BTW.  There is seating both inside and out, but it's very busy and packed - good luck getting one.  Stand in line and a lady will take your order.  She gives you the order sheet and you take it to the register where you pay.  Then you get a number that they call once your order is ready.  CASH ONLY CASH ONLY CASH ONLY!

First and foremost, YELP please change this place to $$ not $.  Don't believe me, take a look at the photo of the menu.  It's not your typical cheap Mexican food joint.  Some lady ended up spending +$54 dollars here for 3 people.  We spent $24 for 3 items.

I had the regular burrito with chorizo and a regular beef taco.  The chorizo is not spicy and very messy - greasy.  It's good, but I've had better.  The burrito is a good size, comes with meat, beans, and pico de gallo.  A super burrito has the regular + sour cream, cheese, and avocado.  The taco meat was also very good - super tender.  Overall, the food NEEDED the hot sauce, because there's not a whole lot going on here.  The food here is very meaty and lack depth to be honest.  Everything here all kind of taste the same.  Hot sauce made things better.

My gf had the flour quesadilla with carnitas (pork).  The quesadilla was very disappointing, mainly because of the pork.  The pork is really nothing special, it's just cooked.  No special seasoning or sauce with it.  We are used to greasy orange LA pork with loads of flavor and depth.  

Overall, this place is just A-OK 3/5 stars.  The food is pricey, come on guys, it's Mexican food.  We all know Mexican food is not that expensive...  Yeah, I know, it's SF, but I've been to other places where the prices are no where like this.  We would not come back, but are glad to finally find out that the HYPE...is just really... HYPE =).
author: Kevin N.

description:
Stop 1 on the Mission Burrito/Taco Taste Test Tour...La Taqueria. Hype was justified. Tacos Dorados were on point (preferred the Carne Asada over Carnitas, but both are tasty).  Dorado style is A La Plancha (Grilling) the tortilla with melted crisp cheese; this is key.  Heard you can request your Burrito Dorado Style (#nexttime). Green Sauce was awesome.  I do wish they had Rice though.  Service was efficient and friendly.  Got there ~12noon on a Friday afternoon and line was only 3 ppl deep; but line started to grow and wind through the restaurant around 12.30pm.
Next on the List: El Farolito, Papalote, Taqueria Vallarta...am I missing some place?
author: Brandon S.

description: I remember when their burritos were $2.50 each...it's over $8 bucks now!But I do their carne asada burritos..just meat, pico and beans...yummmy
author: Cecilia D.

description:
Definitely a good burrito but I was expecting "best burrito in the country" (thanks 538) and that it wasn't. It's a simple burrito--beans, meat, salsa, avocado, cheese--all of which were very good. For me, I think the burrito was too single-flavored and single-textured. It was a good flavor/texture for sure, but lacked any interesting variety. 

Overall a good burrito, but not one I'm rushing back to.
author: Peter M.

description:
My company and I were in the city visiting and were meandering around the Mission district without being ready to eat yet. We scopes out this place around 1:30pm and the line was out the door so we figured we come back later. That was a good decision. We came back around 4:30pm, there was still a line but much shorter. And it continued to further empty out as we were eating.

We got a vegetarian burrito and chips with pico de gallo. Both were solid dishes. The burrito was juicy and flavorful, especially with the green sauce available at the tables.

It's worth the hype.
author: Pam H.

description: Visited last night we got 2 burritos and a chicken quesadilla. We were in and out in only 10 minutes (and they were busy!!)  We were very impressed. The food was awesome!
author: Elaina T.

description: My go to is Pancho Villa, however, I only get burritos there. With that being said, I think this may be my go to for tacos from here on out. I ordered two carne asada: one soft and one hard and the meat was so flavorful. I've never paid $7 for a tack but I believe it was well- worth it! I plan on returning.
author: L. W.

description:
The first thing you will notice is that the super burrito here is smaller than the super burrito at El Farolito a couple blocks away. There is no rice so the entire burrito feels a bit flimsy. Most of the ingredients in the burrito have some moisture which makes the entire burrito pretty wet but tasty. 

The line wraps along the entire inside of the restaurant and almost all seats are taken.
author: James S.

description:
I've noticed La Taqueria definitely inspires some love/hate feelings. I imagine this happens because it frequently appears in local and national lists of best Mexican Eats in the country.

I'm afraid I have to come down on the "hate" side of things. La Taqueria is definitely on my bottom list of burrito proprietors in San Francisco and with so many tastier options in the city I don't think I'll ever be back.

Really it comes down to two things: the food is really flat on flavors and you usually have to wait a pretty long time to obtain it. 

Carne Asada really lives or dies on the marination and here the meat is more comparable to the marginal taste of chains. When you get a San Diego style Carne Asada burrito (yes, I know this is the Mission, just keep reading) where the meat has been prepared just right you don't need a bunch of other ingredients clouding up the mix, and that's why people love those foot-long solid meat torpedoes. Otherwise, you really need to balance out inferior meat with other dynamic ingredients so that the mix brings out the taste and texture of combination rather than just concentrating on the lower quality beef. Here you get flat flavors with boring meat wrapped up in a mushy, uncooked tortilla.

Personally I think nearby El Farolito and Taqueria Guadalajara both destroy this place.
author: Matt M.

description: This is the best Mexican food you will ever find. I've been going there for over 25 years and they have never disappointed me. The owner is the salt of the earth with a personality to match. He makes you feel at home and that my friend is a rare quality !!!!
author: Janice H.

description: What can I say that hasn't already been said before? I consider myself to be picky when it comes to mexican food being that I was raised on it and to me it's "just food"... I worried that maybe this place was just living off its hype but let me assure you that's not the case here.. I have come here day and night and each time it's always packed and for good reason.. the line moves quickly as they are always staffed appropriately. We have always managed to find parking although it is the Mission so it can get crazy.. I wish this last trip I wouldn't have been so sick because I ambitiously ordered 2 super tacos and I could barely scarf it down. Yes they are $7 which is pricey but well worth it. Thankfully my babe was more than willing to help me out. I don't care who you are, if you have been sheltered and never tried authentic mexican food but once you come here please don't ever go to Taco Bell ever again! It would be the worst thing you could do your body after you have introduced it to this heaven... and don't forget to visit Diandras bakery next door if you manage to still leave a little room for dessert!!
author: Celena G.

description: Great food even thou burritos are little soggy. Generous amount of meat. Only downside is long line to get food and very limited seating. But definitely one of favorite Mexican food spot.
author: Amrit S.

description: Ok so I had to try it. I am a Dallas transplant from San Diego and I MISS MEXICAN FOOD!!! Mexican food in Texas sucks. Sorry Texas. Nothing is better than a good California burrito in San Diego by the beach. So when in San Francisco I had to try a mission burrito and was told this is the place. I was not disappointed. It took forever to order because people know but it was worth the wait. What really made it was the carne asada. The other ingredients were great but the meat was perfect and shined through.
author: Brandon W.

description: Best Lunch Time Burritos for a VEGGIE Burrito with Black Beans, No Rice, Guacamole and Pico De Gallo
author: Dianne A.

description: Waaaaay to pricey for tacos lol. I've had ones 100 times better for 3.50 max. I loved when they were in San Jose and now coming out here the taste isn't the same and the prices are ridiculous.
author: Marissa M.

description:
There was a lot to expect from a place that claims it has the world's best burrito --but yes, it truly is! There was a good 20 minute wait to order, but there was a lady taking down the order down the line to make it go by quicker.

I wasn't too hungry, but my friend told me that it would be a crime if I came here and didn't order the burrito. So I ordered the Carne Asada Super Burrito ($10), Mango Agua Fresca ($3.50), and Corn Quesadilla ($3). To start off, the quesadilla was extremely disappointing. It was nothing but a tortilla and some melted cheese that even a toddler can make. Maybe I really need to make it super with the extra guacamole, cheese, and sour cream. On the other hand, the burrito was truly amazing. Be sure to get it Diablo style and Super. I've never had such a stuffed and tasty burrito. The fried outside gave it such a crisp texture and made sure my burrito was warm all around. The flavors of the meat and ingredients was overpowering enough for me to not hate the fact that there were beans inside my burrito (I forgot to ask to leave them out as I don't like beans at all). Finally, their agua fresca was delicious as well. It was full in flavor and you truly taste the mango used to make it.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
This is THE most overrated and overpriced taqueria in SF. By far. No competition! I specifically ordered my super burrito non-dorado style, because I like to compare apples to apples. If I'm going to compare this place to El Faralito or Vallarta or Cancun (the big 3), I'm going to compare a super burrito to a super burrito, not a dorado-style burrito to a super burrito. 

The result: an oppressively average burrito. Had the feeling of a home-made burrito or one that you put together at a cafeteria from pre-made ingredients. AKA, a lose aggregate of ingredients jumbled together in an uninspired way, without the correct proportions or execution. Did I mention the burrito is small? For $12, I would expect this burrito to at least make for a decent meal, but it sure doesn't. I swear I had to go hunt down a post-burrito slice of pizza - that is not something I've ever thought I'd have to do after eating a BURRITO. 

Worst of all, is you get to wait in one of the most disorganized lines I've ever encountered, not just for a taqueria, but any food establishment. The line snakes around tables and gets in the way of people accessing trash bins and employees accessing the tables. The pickup zones are completely erratic and totally mixed up with the order-line, creating a total circus. 

Did I mention the food sucks? There is nothing, and I repeat, nothing, special about this burrito. The tortilla is average. The beans are average. The carne-asada is below-average (taste is okay, but it is not thrown on the grill, it is just steamed for hours and thrown on the burrito, cafeteria style). That is not the mark of "the best taqueria in the US". There is NO RICE. Which is okay, in principle, but then you have to ask yourself the question: "does the rest of the burrito make up for lack of rice?" The answer is an emphatic "NO". Unlike well-executed San Diego style burritos (which usually have no rice or beans), there is not copious amounts of ridiculously tasty carne-asada or french fries. There is simply NO RICE, with nothing to make up for it. That is one of the reasons the burritos are so small - rice is used as a filler ingredient and takes up like 25-30% of a normal Mission style burrito. The should rename these burritos to "rolled-super-tacos". And change the price to $5. Now that I could understand! 

Until that happens, I suggest you do your schedule and your wallet a BIG favor and go down the street to Taqueria Cancun, Vallarta, or El Faralito!
author: Leo G.

description:
I probably had one of the best burritos of my life at La Taqueria. 

You have two options here: regular ($7.00) or super. The super is $2.50 more expensive, and you get: guacamole, sour cream, and cheese. I usually prefer the super version, because it is much easier than adding extras one by one to my regular burrito. 

I have only tried their carnitas and carne asada. They are both very well seasoned, tender; however, carnitas is my favorite because it is just so flavorful, and it melts in your mouth. 

There is not much to say about this place, as people who are big fan of Mission burrito scene are already familiar with this place. But, my recommendation to you first timers here is: go dorado or go home. With dorado, they grill your burrito at the end, so that the tortilla becomes golden and crispy.

During lunch time the place gets super crowded so be aware of that, and also this place is CASH ONLY.
author: Ashkan H.

description: Stumbled upon this taqueria for the first time and ordered a carne asada burrito. The burrito could've been a lot bigger for the price, but it is San Francisco, so I guess I'm lucky it wasn't like four inches and 28 bucks... THE CARNE ASADA WAS SO GOOD THOUGH, shout out to the guy on the grill!!! It tasted like a tru Sunday afternoon with la familia. My burrito kept leaking juices, but it's OK 'cause I finished that thang in like 3 bites anyway :-)
author: Nancy H.

description: Hands down the best tacos I've had in my life!!! I live in LA but I'm from SF and I've eaten more tacos than you could imagine from all over the world and these are still the absolute best EVER!!! You absolutely must order them El Dorado style with errrrythang!! I also like to pour the homemade hot sauce on every single bite
author: Leah B.

description:
This real Mexican the taco by far the best I ever had I will never come to SF and not come here ..
Long lines lots of people moves fast ..
Lots of awards here 13 bucks I'm so full
author: Mike P.

description: Touristy and crowded. I judge by their tacos - the meat was dry and the tortilla was meh. Quesadilla and grilled burrito at the table looked better. Not worth it given allllllllll the mission taco places.
author: Adam C.

description: These tacos are actually life changing! The people are so friendly and nice and the veggie taco was actually super cheap unlike in restaurants where the vegetarian option costs as much as the meat one although meat is more filling and expensive. The line is fairly long but the tacos are worth it!
author: Hiyanthi P.

description:
Sooooooo good! Usually I dislike all the Yelp hyped places, but this one was awesome! The line sucked, yes, but the food was well worth the 30 minute wait! 
My burrito was so delicious! Yes, it is not large by any means. If you have a gigantic appetite I think you would need at least another taco to go with it, but it definitely filled me up!
I forgot what I read in the other reviews about getting it fried on the griddle afterward, but it was still bomb and I can't wait to go back. 

PS. The man at the cashier gets a gold star. He was so nice!! I saw him giving out roses to women. What a cute thing to do! He also gave me the most delicious strawberry agua fresca to try!

2PS I went back and saw they significantly raised their prices! $11 for a burrito is pretty damn steep.
author: Jen B.

description: Great food and it was fairky quick even with 13 students and 3 adults worth of food.  Close to bart is a plus!
author: Maria H.

description: I don't know what the hype is all about: I had a super carne asada burrito that was good, but not worth $12!!! This "super burrito" was small and didn't have a lot of meat!!! I also purchased an Horchata and it was disgusting!!!! They should be ashamed of themselves to call this watered down drink with sugar "Horchata"  I would definitely not go back or recommend this place to anyone!! Not worth the wait for the long lines or price for the food!!
author: Natalie A.

description: The best taqueria in the city. Long lines and only takes cash. Went there just the other day and it is still as good as it gets. Stop by next door at Mission Pie for a slice before heading out.
author: Kelly H.

description:
I'm incredibly impressed with the wrap-around lines here but also by how efficiently the lines move!

Had the Super Carne Asada burrito and horchata (the combo of champions). I liked it, but my friend loved it. Love is an understatement. Infatuated? Obsessed? Devoured in literally 30 seconds.

Will be back for the corn / steak quesadillas which looked dreamy.
author: Linda X.

description:
Staying in SF for a week and, well, we couldn't leave without trying a burrito from this spot. We were staying literally right around the corner from it and I don't know how I resisted its pull for so long. We went in around 6pm on a weeknight and it was busy but not overwhelming -- I feel compelled to warn you, as I was warned from Yelp reviews, that this place only takes cash, BUT I will also mention that they have an ATM inside the restaurant.

We already knew what to order and how to order it (again, thank you Yelp), and both the ordering process and waiting in line were relatively painless -- just a few minutes of waiting and we were able to sit. Food came out quickly and OH MY GOD IT WAS SO GOOD. I would have waited so much longer for this level of deliciousness. I am drooling right now just thinking about it. So much hot, cheesy goodness... siiiiigh. And the cantaloupe agua fresca? TO DIE FOR. Basically just liquid cantaloupe, and such a perfect pairing with this perfectly portioned burrito. GO HERE. NOW.
author: Justine J.

description:
BEWARE: CASH ONLY

Best burrito I have ever had. Probably big enough for two people but we all finished our own anyways because we couldn't stop eating them (the 10 miles of walking sort of helped too). The carnitas were amazing! 

Will definitely be craving this place.
author: Jaime R.

description: This is my favorite Mission burrito place.  Their food is so good!! They have this thing called Dorado style where they will insert a crispy taco in the soft taco or fry the burrito making it extra crispy!  They also have this Habanero sauce that they provide all over their restaurant so you can have unlimited sauce!!! Love it!!!!!
author: Julia W.

description:
4.5 stars!!

First time here got the regular carne asada burrito and it was absolutely delicious!!! We were able to get a seat and although there was a long line, it was pretty quick to order and get our food. 

I loved everything about the burrito. The burrito was wrapped in a tortilla that was the perfect level of sogginess. The carne asada was so flavorful and juicy without being oily and greasy. Would love to learn their secret! The burrito doesn't look huge but is filling enough. My tummy wasn't upset or anything afterwards meaning the ingredients were all high quality. Can't wait to come back. Cash only!
author: Yin H.

description: What is all the buzz about? Hmmmm. Not the best mexican food I have had. Line is long and food was just ok. If anything, I had to keep adding hot sauce to make it more palatable. I had high expectations for this joint. However, I was let down. The taste was very bland. The cheese quesadillas were so oily! Anything oily will taste good, but these were downright bad. My kids did not enjoy them. I also ordered two agua frescas and it was more ice than agua fresca! Booooo!
author: Wajma Z.

description:
By far my favorite spot in SF for good authentic mexican food. La Taqueria is amazing!

I usually get a chorizo super burrito extra crispy. Their ingredients are perfectly fresh, they make the tortilla extra crispy on the side upon request and they have a good hot salsa if you want a kick. Their burritos are pretty unique because they don't have rice (only beans and the rest of the works) but they're to die for.

They're also known for their tacos which are sizeable and come with guac, pico, etc. I love the burrito too much but the tacos are as popular.

Place is always packed and there's usually a line but it moves relatively quickly. That said, expect to dedicate at least 20 minutes whether you're eating there or taking out. Totally worth the wait!
author: Farid V.

description:
best burritos in san francisco.

*******Hey everyone saying "NO RICE WTF":*******
Traditional mexican burritos aren't overflowing with rice, you sound like a douche
author: Sergio P.

description: So mediocre. Carne asada had a nice charred flavor but lacked the right amount of seasoning and was pretty gamey. For roughly $14, this tiny super burrito barely delivered. Mind you, I skipped lunch yesterday and was starving when eating this burrito at 4 pm and it didn't even remotely hit the spot. I almost wanted to throw it away but it was too expensive to waste. I've had burritos all over SF and this is one of the most epic letdowns in terms of burritos found in the city. I only came here since seeing that Facebook video on how awesome the meat quality was here and then I couldn't believe how I've never eaten here before after living in SF for 32 years. Scammed by hipsters yet again.
author: Ivy Z.

description: I don't understand what all the hype is about. The asada was super dry and difficult to chew. The guac, bland. For the high price and this many reviews, I had higher expectations for this place. Won't be coming back.
author: Kyle H.

description: Make sure you have cash!! This place is cash only... make sure you get the Supreme Burrito!! Try the Aguas Frescas.. I had the pineapple one and it was delicious!! I loved this place and I would definitely recommend it.
author: Bruna B.

description:
If you are a Latino this is the worst place you can go. It is over priced and barely has meat on their burrito.
Si eres latino es el peor lugar para ir, los precios son altos y un burrito casi ni trae carne, un súper burrito  del size de un breakfast burrito from McDonalds. El peor burrito q he comido en la mission!!
author: Evelyn M.

description: Really really good. Hype is really worth it in my opinion! BUT idk how many times i can go here bc of how many ppl there are. If u dont like crowded places dont come here. Super long line and just too many people
author: Jessica S.

description:
THE HOLY GRAIL OF BURRITOS. 

The carnitas burrito was so juicy and succulent. There was no rice, which highlighted the flavor of the meat. and there was a mariachi band in full form in the background. the place is packed, be ready to take it to go or eat standing up. I wish I tried their horchata. Next time! 

Another plus - it's right across the street from a store, that has hanging donald trump pinatas. Awesome.
author: Christina S.

description: I drive all the way from Richmond to eat this food. People think I'm crazy. I've been going here for years and the manager is a sweetheart! I always get the crunchy steak tacos they are so bomb! During the week you have to get out there before 12:00pm cuz the line is out the door. This is my favorite authentic Mexican restaurant and you will not be disappointed!
author: Leesh A.

description:
Some time last year I was on a burrito hype.  I came across a list of the top 10 best rated burritos in the states and La taqueria was rated #1. I have had the pleasure of trying 4 of the 10 best rated and personally I think #5 Surf taco surf shop (San Diego CA) should be #1 but to each their own. This place "La taqueria" is pretty damn good, well worth waiting in the long line, For sure one of the best burrito in the bay. I can see why this place is so raved about, besides the burritos being good overall all their food is good. They also have hand made tortillas made to order for their tacos that look like heaven on earth... Super loaded. Check this place out!

This burrito has Zero rice :)
author: Aselicia S.

description: Best burritos in the city! Great vegetarian options too! Awesome staff and service and good prices.
author: Agnes L.

description:
Well this was a bummer. I had really high expectations for this place, and may have to come back again as it may have been a fluke.

Good Mexican restaurants have 2 things in common, there is usually an indirect relationship between the food and service.

Typical taqueria service involves only 2 interaction  points with the staff: (1) ordering & paying for the food, and (2) picking it up. 
"Your total is 14.80." 
I hand over $15.00. She gives me 2 pennies. 
I smile back at her and say: "The total was $14.80 right?" 
She looks at me blankly.
With my palm facing up towards the pennies, "I think you meant to give me dimes."
She did not seem to find my humor very funny. 

Anyways, they call my number and...
that super carnitas burrito was TASTY. But as the pictures show, they're about half the size of what most taquerias serve (especially for $11!!). 
In fact they appear rather 'flat'. All that being said -- I was strongly considering ordering a 2nd burrito. :)

In terms of flavor & texture - it's a solid 9.0/10. 
For reference Chipotle chicken burrito w/ guac when it was at its best would be a 6.5/10.


I'll deal with getting nickel'd on my change (it usually goes in the tip jar anyways). But there's not much you can do when they dime you on the food.

Great ingredients, but I don't like feeling ripped off.
author: Sargon J.

description:
This place won Fivethirtheight's best burrito bracket (http://fivethirtyeight.com/burrito/#brackets-view), but there must be a better burrito.

Agree with other reviewers that the burritos are a bit watery and rice would help.  Not a lot of cheese in ours, so construction seems inconsistent as well.  That said, the carne asada was great as was the carnitas.  The chicken seemed to be nice breast meat and the proportions were good.  Tomatillo salsa was also good and was the savior of a fairly sad burrito.

In spite of good meat, overall, the super burrito was just sloppy.  Sloppily presented, sloppily assembled and ate like a Taco Bell burrito with too much sour cream.  Seems like so many other options locally that this place will head to the bottom of the list.

Chips and salsa was disappointing as the salsa was a bit bland and they dumped it on top of the chips which basically made them soggy - came with some seriously hot grilled peppers too.  Don't make a mistake and eat one of these.  Kids loved the quesadillas, so these are clearly a standout.

Place is mobbed - probably about 100 people in there on a Saturday afternoon which made sitting a challenge and overall not an enjoyable eating experience.

El Farolito won Esquire's burrito fan vote.  Will have to try there next.
author: Bob K.

description: 538 Nate Silver says this is the best burrito in the country and I can not disagree.  My super steak burrito was delicious.  I don't know what made it so good but it was excellent.  We got our burrito grilled.  It had meat, cheese, guoc, and tomatoes.  The tortilla was excellent and so was the meat.  There were some tables inside but not much place to sit down.
author: Abbas B.

description: Me and my friends came here after landing at SFO. I highly recommend the beef tongue on...literally everything! Tacos, burritos, anything! The meat is very tender, juicy, moist and flavorful! The tacos are pretty big, and you can always add guac and sour cream for the super size.  We tried the carne asada also, but that wasn't as good by far. Our whole group agreed that the beef tongue was the best! Definitely worth it!
author: Esther T.

description: Excellent food. This was a great surprise and a little gym that I found on my way to my travels in San Francisco. I was hunkering down when I need it to have a little bite of food. And accommodating location with quick and excellent food. Great service for flavors and reasonable pricing.
author: Steve Y.

description: Ordered taco with carne asadas. Meat was decent but lacked flavor. The service and food was okay. Loved the location and live music.
author: Esther W.

description: Lived up to the hype, got a dorado style super carnitas burrito and it was the best I've ever had. Perfectly proportioned ingredients and the crisp tortilla was a great compliment. My only tip would be to ask for salsa on the side if you get chips, they slop it on top and by the time you are halfway through they are a soggy mess.
author: Chris N.

description:
Last summer during my road trip in California I finished the road trip in the lovely city of San Francisco. I did my first visit to the Mission district in order to watch street art and try La Taqueria which is kind of a Mexican fast food restaurant.

When I got to La Taqueria I have to admit I has hungry, angry and way annoyed by the long waiting line. But I head that this place had the best tacos in town so I had to try it.

Exterior looks Mexican and clean. A nice exterior and sign I have to admit that. However the interior really isn't anything special for a kind fast food place but it work.

It's true, everything you've heard about this place. The tacos is the best tacos in the world. World can't describe how good they where I went from this place happy.
author: Niclas C.

description: I can't say enough good things about La Taqueria. I've been coming here since college, which was a very long time ago, and they have never disappointed. I usually get the lengua burrito, which is the freshest I have had in the city. They cook it just right. I've also had nachos, quesadillas and pretty much every single meat they sell and it's all delicious. But that Green salsa though! That is the best stuff to have hit my lips ever! It is cash only, which is a bummer, but totally worth paying the ATM fee. Be prepared to wait, especially on the weekends and you won't be disappointed.
author: Crystal K.

description: Yes, best tacos I've ever had. Definitely get the "super" tacos/burritos which adds guacomole, sour cream, and cheese. If you don't do that, then what's all this been about? I mean, forealz
author: Dwight P.

description:
My wife and I came here on a recommendation and I am hooked, line and sinker. I love tacos, and I can't say I have had better elsewhere. 

Parking can be tricky like nearly everywhere in the city. I recommend the street or the lot down the street. 

The restaurant accepts cash only. They do have an ATM machine or Chase is across the street. 

The restaurant is always clean and well maintained.

I have tried a number of things but my go to is their carne asada burrito or tacos. The tacos aren't cheap compared to many other places, but they don't skimp on anything and everything is of very high quality. The carne asada and chicken are always juicy and perfectly seasoned and cooked. 

Good luck finding a table, and be prepared to wait, particularly at peak times, or if there is a San Francisco Giants game. It's worth the wait. Don't forget your cash, and bring enough for one for the road. You'll thank me later.
author: Joshua N.

description: Went to have dinner here after work, it is a bit pricey, but the quality is there. Not very filling, but no other burrito place in the Mission is better. Seating is limited, but very attainable.
author: Jackson T.

description: The best burrito in America is at La Taqueria, if you read Fivethirtyeight.  I tried it and enjoyed the burrito but prefer when they fry it to be crispy on the outside, you may have to ask for that.  A good place to take out of town visitors.
author: Brent S.

description: Simply the best burritos in town. I'm not a fan of loading half of pound of rice into my burritos, but some do. If you like without a rice, then this is the best place.
author: Brian J.

description: Best most delicious tacos and food you gotta try. The line wraps around inside and goes outside. That's gotta say a lot!! A must try when in SF!
author: Laura O.

description: Not up to my taste standards..I think it's for out of the country tourist..I was disappointed..coming from LA where we have amazng tacos I expected more..I did not get to try carne asada tacos as they had run out so my review is only based on chicken tacos
author: Melanie G.

description: I came in and ordered a Super Quesidilla. I asked them to add rice and they replied "We don't do that here...!!!" I was shocked, I only wanted to add rice to a quesdilla and they repeated they don't do that here.... never coming here again,
author: Antonio H.

description: Really good burritos. The burritos aren't heavy as usual burritos cuz they don't put rice in their burritos. A bit pricey is the only downside.
author: David S.

description: I WILL LOVE LA TAQUERIA MORE THAN MY FIRST BORN. So here's the deal: my hipster boyfriend and I would frequent Taqueria Cancun in the Mission. So when we broke up I needed a new burrito spot where I didn't have to run into him and his rebound (ouch!). I decided to try La Taqueria due to all the hype and the only thing I regret (besides dating that SCRUB) is not coming here sooner. La Taqueria is. literally. everything. Do yourself a favor and order it dorado. Yep, like the Disney animated film.
author: Crystal P.

description: How did I find this gem? Quite luckily. Nothing (talking about mex food here) in the bay seemed to come close to the junkiest spots in sd. This place is a decent contender for good carne burritos and supreme veggie burritos.
author: Jessica W.

description:
"You're in SF? You have to go to La Taqueria!"

La Taqueria is a Mexican taco spot in the Mission. Check Yelp to make sure you're going to the right one - "La Taqueria" is a pretty generic name. 

The line was long and out the door but it didn't take any longer than 20 minutes. I've waited much longer in NYC lines. However, you might have to fight for a seat at one of their many cafeteria-like tables. My friend and I sat on the end of a packed table.  

I ordered the vegetarian burrito "dorado style", meaning the burrito was fried crispy on both sides. Very filling and flavorful. Try the spicy salsas on the table!
author: Susan A.

description: First time in SF and walking around hungry after flight got in pretty late. This place is so tasty and definitely authentic! Got the carne asada taco and lengua taco and both were delicious. The spicy sauce is definitely spicy but sooo good! For my introduction to SF street food it was very nice!
author: Cassandra T.

description:
What's good fam, it's Teddi Portuano ya boy here. Let me lay it down for you on La Taq. The food is legit. Easily one of the best Mexican joints in da city unlike "tacoliscious" which is an imposter taqueria frequented solely by white boys on their way to black out in the Marina. La Taq gets a bit of this too because of their prestige and can therefore charge a lot for their food - like 10 bones a burrito or something. But the food is worth it.

Here's a couple tips- when getting a burrito you are whack AF if you don't order it "Dorado" style, which means "golden" for those of you who don't espekko la español. After rapping it up like a nice blizzy, they throw it back on the grill and crisp that boy up. Lastly, they be cash only but that ain't neva a problem when you rollin wit ya boy Teddi P cuz we always got mad stacks on us.
author: Teddi P.

description:
One of the best taquerias in the city. Easily. 

Now, there are people who will fight to declare their favorite taqueria in the city (El Farolito, Cancun, etc) but honestly each wins in their own regard. Where El Farolito exceeds with their super quesadilla suiza, the winner at La Taqueria is their carne asada burrito. The tacos are also popular if you're looking for a lighter option, and the carnitas are no slouch as a carne asada meat alternative 

Make sure you come hungry (and ready to wait in line). If you've got the appetite, feel free to make it super so you get that guac and sour cream (though I opt out of the sour cream, personally)

Also, just a note, but with most places in the Mission this place is cash only so come prepared or go to the Chase bank across the street before heading on over.
author: Jay P.

description:
WORTH THE LINE! 

Despite the line far out the door that curled inside without much place to go and the few tables for which everyone is huddled on top of, it's still one of my favorite experiences of visiting SFO.

Carne asada super burrito will change your life. Not exaggerating. Hands down the best burrito that I have ever had. My friend had the Lengua super burrito and agrees.

And the owner / man behind the register is the sweetest thing you've ever seen! He greeted each person at the register as if they were a cousin and I personally bore witness to him giving two women roses out of the vase next to the register.
author: Jayci G.

description: Best Guacamole and salsa in San Francisco.  Simple, cheap, and incredibly delicious. I've been back here over and over.  In fact I've come back here more than any other place in the city besides my work.
author: Kallen R.

description: The hype is real!!! Upon arriving the line was out the door but moved fairly quickly. Dorado style is a must, and their strawberry water is delicious  (might be too sweet for some). Average complete meal for 1 is about 20$. Cash only
author: Magali R.

description: We ordered two regular tacos and they were both very hearty. Carne asada was really fresh and chorizo was very tasty. The regular tacos come with pinto beans and salsa for about 4 dollars each. Their " super" tacos have quac cheese for $3:75 more.
author: Ghazal P.

description: The carne asada taco was fantastic! If you're going to order the chips with pico and avocado, order dine in - not to go.
author: Steve B.

description:
I decided to try out this place as I was told it is *the* taqueria. And I wasn't disappointed!

The atmosphere was 5/5 and the food was 5/5. You could tell it was going to be amazing before you entered. The restaurant was packed with locals. I had a burrito with a Pacifico beer - standard but delicious.

I would definitely recommend it. I also heard (unfortunately afterwards) that they have an option to fry the inside of the tortilla for burritos and that it's worth getting!
author: Michael C.

description: As NYer's visiting California, we were told over and over that this place had THE best burritos around. We trekked our way there from Union Square, waited about 20 minutes for our piping hot burritos to come out and thoroughly enjoyed them. Not quite what we were used to, but good nonetheless.
author: Adrienne L.

description: Worth the wait. Every time I go back my meal is more incredible than the last time. Go if you have an hour in the city. Go if you've lived your whole life in the city.
author: Kaley H.

description: So many sauces and toppings to choose from at the salsa bar, great sized portions for food, free chips, fun and busy atmosphere and don't let the long lines fool you because the wait is not as long as it seems. The dishes are very much affordable ($3 - $7 for a dish.) I ordered the taco salad and chicken burrito and they are so good, especially the guacamole inside! I've been going to this place for the past 2 years, mostly as a night cap after being out with friends.
author: Carley H.

description: When in to try this place everyone keeps talking about not happy at all try for yourself
author: Mario A.

description:
4/5
Cheap. Filling. Tasty. Unhealthy.
I got the crunchy super-tacos, chicken and carne asada. The crunchy taco is actually soft taco on the outside and crunchy taco inside, so go for it even if you dont usually like hard tacos that break off on first bite.
Do NOT get this to-go, it'll ruin the meal. The tacos are filled with lots of junk which makes it tasty. Also try the green hot salsa sauce they have on the tables.
The line runs fast, but the place is usually packed! I went there on a saturday night but it was raining so expected less of a crowd, but nope!

Also if you stand in line and observe the cooks, you might feel the place is un-hygienic, maybe it is, but Yelp health score is 92/100 so I think I'll live. Oh wait my roommate did get a mild case of food poisoning the next day, maybe it was the tacos.
Tip: dont go for more than 2 super tacos, and get the crunchy one.
Chips and salsa were OK, but this is a cheap restaurant so expected.
author: Arjan N.

description:
Solid burrito, it reminds me of SD because there's no rice and its all meat and fresh guac. I like it better than el farolito in that sense because its not heavy on rice. The burrito was a decent size, very soft and loosely wrapped (at least the one I got). I recommend the el dorado style where they grill the outer tortilla because it gives the burrito a nice crunch and taste. 

Long lines, cash only!
author: Stephanie C.

description: My definition of a perfect taco. After many visits over the years I have been coming here it is just as good as ever. My go to order is a carne asada and a carnitas super taco, both crispy. Prices have gone up over the years, but to date the food has always been worth it--value in its truest form. Well done.
author: Daniel B.

description: Must get their strawberry Fresca! Was visiting San Fran for 4 days and ate here twice because it was so good.
author: Lauren J.

description: I read some articles and watched a few videos about their famous asada burritos($14)so I had to try it myself. They're weren't kidding. Those burritos are sooo good. Make sure get it dorado! I also had a carnitas quesadilla($14), wow, so juicy. A bit pricey compared to other local Mexican restaurants but so worth it.
author: Jose M.

description: The line is always out the door during rush hour times lunch and dinner so make sure your meter has enough quarters unless it's after 6pm your good to go. This place has been known for its steak burritos with avacado not guacamole since it's crushed avocado but it's amazing. Become during the day make sure you bring quarters so you have money for the meter or park a few blocks away for free two hour parking. All the tacos here great as well as the burritos. Again cash only so come prepared and if you don't there's a chase across the street and multiple banks in the area you can walk to before hand.
author: Ella P.

description: All my life I've been told that California has great Mexican food, so I had very high expectations, and this place did not disappoint me. I don't like standing in long lines or sitting in crowded spaces, but this place was so worth it. Personally, I would recommend skipping the burritos and sticking with the tacos. They have lengua tacos here, and there are super moist, tender, and flavorful.
author: Sarah R.

description: I can't quite figure out the hype about this place.  It's is utter chaos inside with limited seating and their food is just ok.  I ordered a burrito with chicken and a taco with meat.  Overall just pretty bland.
author: Mike R.

description:
This place has the best taco's that I have tried so far in SF. I don't want to get ahead of myself, but DANG do they satisfy cravings! People love the burritos here, they will rave about it, and wait on line forever, but I think the taco's are where it's at! 

If you're new, like I was - here is a small breakdown of the lingo for this place (Tacos):
Regular = 2 soft shell tacos with meat - pico de gallo and beans
Super = all of the above plus avocado, cheese, sour cream 
Dorado style = crispy inside shell with soft outside shell (try it, it's good!)

I tried the Carne Asada (beef), Carnitas (pork) and Lengua (Beef Tongue) and a side of avocado - which brought me to about ~$13. TOTALLY WORTH IT. They were huge and I'm sure I would have been fine with 2 because they are seriously sizable! Highly recommend all of them! Each one was flavorful, different in taste but all the flavors blended so well, I literally could not stop stuffing my face. My favorite was the Lengua (which btw only comes with cilantro and onion instead of the regular ingredients!). It was almost melt in your mouth how soft the lengua was. ABSOLUTELY delicious and reminded me of one of my favorite taco places in NY! I like that dorado style adds a little crunch for texture in every bite so I definitely enjoyed the crap out of all my tacos. All the ingredients taste fresh and they make to order(and will call your number when it's ready!). I left so incredibly satisfied - and honestly, that's probably the first time that I've felt this way about SF food! If you're ever in the Mission area - this is definitely the mexican spot to go to and you can hit up Clarion Alley to check out the cool artwork (because you will definitely need to walk this amazing food off!).
author: Deanna S.

description: I've always love the tacos here been coming here since the  late 1980s always had really good tacos and burritos they don't put rice in the burritos FYI some of the best tacos I've ever had in the Bay Area ...usually really crowded but the line goes fast tough to find a seat don't remember so crowded in the past...their steak always taste good....... very popular place
author: Frankie L.

description:
What a great burrito spot. The burrito is big and it doesn't have rice! I was fooled by Chipotle apparently and when I was here, I realized Mexican don't put rice in their burrito! Nonetheless, the burrito is a pleasant surprise. It comes with beans, asada carnes, veggie and if you ordered it Super, you got cheese, avocado and sour cream. 

There was a short wait but it was worth it. I would recommend coming here!
author: Athena C.

description:
My honey and I come here almost every time we visit SF! Due to it being well known there's always a crowd here, and the line is usually out the door. It's also best to grab a seat while you can or you may have to wait until someone leaves. 

The food is amazing, and very flavorful! My boyfriend usually eats burritos, but one bite of my taco and he was hooked. STILL, the burritos are just as good. They are famous for not putting rice is them because the owner believes it'll take away from focusing on the flavor of the meat (if that makes sense?) so no worries about eating a burrito full of rice. 
Now, we both order crispy super tacos, and they are bomb! They come with a crunchy tortilla with melted cheese inside, along with meat of your choice, sour cream, pico de gallo, guacamole, and whole beans. 
The portion size is pretty big so two super tacos is enough for someone who eats about four to five regular sized tacos. The agua frescas are amazing as well, and very refreshing. 
This will always be our favorite taqueria in the city!
author: Angie S.

description: WOW. Simply... WOW! This place lives up to all the hype. Line is always out the door. This place is never empty. No matter what time you come. Right at opening or the end of the night. They have a system and it works. Which leads to the line moving fairly quickly. I always love a quality carne asada burrito but you must try the carnitas here. Everything here I've been told is made from scratch and you certainly can taste it in every bite. From the house made guacamole or pico de gallo. You'll enjoy every bite. Make sure to order your burrito el dorado style. (Grilled). When you do come, don't be steered away from a long line. The wait is never too long. A must try to and local or visitor to San Francisco! Will be back again soon!!
author: Chris K.

description: Read about this place on TripAdvisor and decided to give it a try! Make sure to ask for El Dorado style which is flash grilled. So freaking amazing!!!! The line was a bit long but went super fast! I could not stop eating my Carne Asada Burrito, even though I was stuffed! If I ever come back to the Mission area, I will definitely stop in again!
author: Alissa J.

description:
It seems like ever since the FiveThirtyEight declared La Taqueria's carnitas burrito the "Best Burrito in America," it's spawned a bunch of hater reviews (there's no rice; there's no al pastor; it's NOT greasy enough...seriously). Hey, not every place is gonna have everything you want guys. And guess what? I don't like rice, I don't like beans, and my favorite burrito from San Diego only has pollo asado, guacamole, and pico de gallo. Simplicity is king!

All the hater crap notwithstanding, I certainly had to take my shot at the alleged best burrito in America. Given my pedigree in San Diego burritos (where my top 10 Mexican places in the world are from), I shudder at the thought at any best burrito not hailing from SD.

So I managed to come here to dodge the now-infamous long ass line that's spawned from La Taqueria's new found fame. Made the call on the carnitas burrito El Dorado, sans beans...so carnitas, guacamole, sour cream, and cheese (see what I meant about simplicity?). Definitely some of the best carnitas I've had, although every bite with guacamole enhanced the flavor. My only gripe was that the guacamole wasn't spread evenly across the burrito. There were definitely times when I ate all carnitas and thought it was a bit on the salty side.

All in all, I was pretty impressed with the burrito and have no problem declaring it SD-level. For what's it worth, the carnitas here are unquestionably better than the carnitas from my favorite Mexican spot in the world. Best burrito in America? Nah, I can think of at least 5 burritos in San Diego that I'd take over it.
author: Alexander Y.

description: After reading other reviews we decided to check it out. Omg I couldn't be happier that we did. The carne Asada was amazing. I had my burrito super and it was so tasty. The hot sauce on the table had just the perfect kick to it. Food was prepared super quick. We would be regulars if we lived here.
author: Michaela M.

description:
Probably one of the most famous places to get burritos in SF (and maybe the nation, thanks to Thrillist), it definitely lives up to the hype. 

Located in Mission aka where all the good Mexican food in SF is, expect a line. The service is pretty quick though. Finding a seat may be hard, unless you're really lucky. 

I got the carne asada super burrito with no sour cream and with hot salsa. I love that they don't put rice in their burritos, because I'm not a huge fan of rice. Their burritos weren't massive - definitely finishable - but we're pretty large. And it was delicious. The guac was on point and the carne asada was tender but chewy at the same time. What made it great, though, was the salsa. It was one of the best salsas I've had. 

I really wish I lived close by because I would  love to try their tacos. They aren't the skimpy little tacos that you usually see. These tacos are packed with meat. One of my friends got a quesadilla, and they didn't skimp on the meat there either. A must try if you're in SF.
author: Nancy C.

description: The best in the city!! Worth the wait!! Everything on the menu is good!! You can also call your order in ahead of time if you arent patient.
author: king x.

description: Always been the best place for tacos. Have been coming for years and have never been disappointed with service or food. Definitely a must-do on a visit to the area!
author: Rakel M.

description: One of the best burritos in the city.CASH ONLY! Very busy just buy some extra time for you and really hard to find parking so be prepare.All the sauces are awesome,must try burritos in SF.
author: Abhishek P.

description: Long lines and limited seating for an overpriced average sized & bland tasting burrito make this place a pass. Nice staff though.
author: Eric H.

description: Best burritos I've ever had! My fiance and I waited in one line for two minutes, then were persuaded by other customers to move to another line, only to be told by the cashiers that our original line was the line to order from. Despite the confusion by us and many other customers, a fairly long wait, and having to walk down the street to find a spot to sit because the place was so packed, I still couldn't be happier with the experience. We ordered one carne asada and one carnitas burrito. The carne asada burrito was the best burrito I've ever had, and the carnitas was second. Seriously, the meats were perfectly cooked; everything was fresh...I have absolutely no complaints. If I lived in San Francisco, I hate to think about how many of these bad boys I would inevitably eat.
author: Jared W.

description: I love this place! I come here every time I visit SF. Be prepared to wait in line but it's worth the wait! The vegetarian burrito is filling and the hot sauce is delicious. Their agua frescas are also way too good! Try the strawberry and mango mixed!
author: Sarah L.

description:
Ok... so, we landed in SF from NY and had not eaten in some 10+ hours but still, this Mexican food is banging. Quite possibly the best burrito I've ever had, except it's still neck in neck with Anna'a Taqueria in Boston. Anyway, west coast Mexican is definitely a lot better than what we have out east and this seems to be THE place, in MIssion at least. We came around 3pm and yes the line was long but it moves fast and have your partner grab a seat upon arrival.  We both got burritos- I, the pollo and my fiance the carnitas. Both meats were very well braised and tender but I'd argue the pork was a little better just because it was better seasoned. But the tortillas and the way everything came together was awesome- steamed, warm tortillas, awesome rice, sour cream, beans, guac & plenty of it (you have to ask for it "super") for the fixings.  Portions are big here.

Perhaps the most underrated but best things were tortilla chips, salsa/guac. They were handmade, thick and super authentic. Their hot sauce is also really good too- the green stuff.

Service is quick, fast and prices are cheap.  I got some horchata to wash everything down too and it was really good- sweet and cinamony.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
La Taquería is debatable with San Franciscans. Some say it is overrated and overpriced (the bill can rack up depending on how many fixings you add to your order) while others are the polar opposite and swear by it. 
Many people note burritos being the thing to eat here, but I say tacos.
La Taquería has been on many food lists but was especially popular on one particular list, most notably for the carnitas taco. 

I'm all about the cabeza tacos here. While La Taqueria is indeed pricier than others, the tacos are HUGE and you get your moneys worth. Cabeza here is tender and juicy. I don't even put any sauce on it!

Things to note: THERE IS ALWAYS A LINE, AND IT IS ALWAYS LONG. But have patience, it goes quickly and you'll be rewarded with a tasty taco. They close at 9pm!
author: Susy C.

description: Awesome food, didn't really enjoy the buritos but everything else was insane, we would recommend this place
author: Kerry B.

description: Underwhelming. My chicken burrito was very wet and lacked flavor (even with hot sauce on it). I won't go back.
author: Katya F.

description: This has been my favorite since the mid 90s.. I loved these burrito since el toro on Valencia was competition. Kinda pricey for the size but that's why I get 2, one for the walk to the car and another for dessert. Just get burrito and keep it simple asada. Oh man, that last bite........
author: Francisco C.

description: I might have ordered the wrong item.  I had a super chicken burrito.  It was ok, the tortilla was a little gummy and the flavor was not that great.  As a matter of fact, it was a little bland.  We ended up at this spot because our Uber driver overheard us talking about a Mexican place near our hotel.  He claimed that this place was the best.  The line was a little long, so I was saving a table while my husband ordered the burritos.  It is CASH ONLY, so it was a good thing we stopped by at the beginning of our trip.  I probably won't come back since there are so many places in this town and I don't come here often enough.  I might have to try the other places mentioned.
author: Marisa S.

description: Sorry but all the publicity this place has gotten has not improved the food. If anything it's gone down hill. Too much fat on the meats and poultry. That's not cool. I prefer El Burrito Express in my neighborhood. Their Expresso Burrito is excellent. It's so large it  lasts a couple of meals or I share it with my grandson or daughter.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I don't have the right to say this place has the America's best burrito; but at least it serves the best burrito I have ever had!

Came here at around 6:45pm on Friday night, the line already extended to the  restaurant's entrance. Should I have come 30 mins later, I would be almost the 30th person lining outside the place - that gives you an idea how much traffic this place gets.
