So here's how it works. You go and get in line, then a waitress will take your order and give you an order slip. Then you stay in line and pay at the cashier. After you pay, just wait for your order. It took me around 30 mins from getting in line to pay, and another 15 mins for the food to come.

-) Pork Burrito Super Size: A. It wasn't like any burrito I have ever tried. So memorable. Reasons:
1. Juiciness. Lots of juice from the ingredients; super moist.
2. Crispiness. This is the magical part. Make sure you ask for extra grill time when you order it - it totally worths the wait because it makes the tortilla semi-crispy; and together with the juicy ingredients, you will totally feel that's the perfect match right there. And the extra grill time make the sour cream even better with its cheesiness type of feeling!
3. The Braised Pork was WOW. Super tender, and it's actually a bit towards the salty side but that was perfectly fine because of sour cream and guacamole balance it out.

Don't worry about the super size, it's not that super but it does fill you up without you knowing it because your brain and mouth will be busy enjoying the great taste of it.

It totally worth the wait. There are quite a lot of seats actually but no doubt it was fully packed during peak hours. Man, that was very good. I'm gonna try their tacos next time! Can't wait!
author: Simon C.

description:
My introduction to this 25th & Mission taqueria did not go smoothly. The guy behind the register interrupted us mid-order to take other patrons' payments (O.P.P. How can I explain it?!) Then insults me (unwittingly, I assume) by saying, "In 43 years, this is your first time here?!" *grabs heart* I don't look a day over 29 (in my dreams) & I was carded just last month! To clarify, he was surprised I'd never eaten there in the 43 years they've been in business, but obviously he struck a chord with me. After this comical/tragic misunderstanding, his buddy-buddy banter was unwelcome.

Lucky for him, strawberry and cantaloupe agua frescas were sweet & fruity, and carne asada taco was a giant hit! The large pieces of chopped-up steak were tender & mostly lean. The other two tacos weren't as praise-worthy with chicken being bland & carnitas being not adequately crispy. Expect big prices to accompany generous portions (we paid $25 for the above), & to pay extra for guac, sour cream, & cheese. 

Looking forward to trying their burritos & tacos "El Dorado" style (fried & crispy.) Until then I'll be slathering my face in anti-wrinkle serums, creams, & potions so as not to be mistaken for a 43-year old again (at least until I am 43.) I'm kidding. I'm over it.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Best burrito I've had in my life! Definitely the original mission style burrito closed on mondays so don't make the mistake of heading over on a monday! I usually call ahead on my way and pick up there, way faster but always super burrito carne asada best in the city! For my vegetarians the vegetarian burrito is fire too!! If I'm not in the mood for meat I usually just do bean cheese sour cream never let's me down!
author: Joshua M.

description:
All the reviews and hype about this place is spot on. They say their burritos are the best and I honestly feel that they are. I ordered the burrito with the beef head (Cabeza) with avocados. 

The burrito was amazing. We had to get it to go and it was still better than any burrito I've had. The Cabeza was so tender and juicy. All the ingredients were spread out very evenly which is always appreciated. 

There was a small wait but well worth it. It was really cool to watch the people create the tacos because it was fast and really systematic.
author: Colin F.

description:
D**n. I thought I was going to leave San Fran without eating at a place that wowed me but I was wrong.  La Taqueria was worth the taxi ride over, and my $11.80 for two tacos (price current as of 9/16/2014).

I came here at 7PM on a Tuesday night, and it was pretty crowded (at least 10 people in line in front of me), but my tacos were 100% worth the wait. I ordered the Tacos Dorados with cabeza and lengua, and paid for cheese and avocado to be slapped on as per recommendation by the nice lady in back of me. I love that woman and wish that I could send her a postcard professing my appreciation because I friggin loved my meal. The meat is so dang soft, so flavorful, and the crunchy+ soft texture at once is something ALL taco places should adopt. The avocado and cheese portions go so perfectly, and the only thing I regret was not ordering soda, chips and salsa because that would've gone so darned well with the meal too.

There are tons of minuses. No parking, it's not climate controlled (as there's not really a door), it's crowded, loud, it's hard to find a seat, the seats are just these tiny individual benches, the tables aren't super clean, they don't take credit cards,  $12 for two tacos is absurdly expensive, but the food at this restaurant makes up for its shortcomings.

5 stars for the food, 2 stars for everything else, but I'm feeling good today (due to those great tacos) so this place gets 5-stars anyways.
author: Andrew H.

description:
If you are looking for a fresh, tasty, authentic place to eat tacos or burritos, then this is your place. I highly recommend the super burrito. If you are a meat lover like me get the meat, it's some of the tastiest steak I've ever had, with only the best cuts of meat. I'm sure with the high quality of food anything you order here will be great.

I don't recommend going between 12 and 2 during the lunch hour rush, especially if you are hungry because you will definitely be waiting a while. Also, if you have never tried it order the horchata drink, they have some of the best I've had in the states not too sweet but super refreshing.
author: Cam P.

description:
Got there a few minutes before they opened on a Saturday morning and there were already people waiting.  Menu is kinda small when compared to El Farolito, but they have all the basics.  I ordered one carnita taco and one carne asada taco with everything and my boyfriend got their carne asada burrito, dorado style.  Our bill was $22; a bit expensive, considering our normal Mexican food bill is less than $15. 

Got our food and we couldn't wait.  Carne asada taco with everything was good, but fairly comparable to the tacos I get at my local taqueria.  My carnita taco was too dry and I barely ate half before giving it to my boyfriend.  Both tacos were loaded with meat, but they weren't exceptionally tender or flavorful.  My boyfriend liked the dorado style, but overall, he thought it was just okay.  His tortilla ripped halfway, so that a no no and their burritos are definitely smaller than El Farolito's. Overall, he thinks El Farolito is better and I agree with him.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Burritos in the City are a serious thing. If you asked someone where is the best burrito served in the city, chances are you would get multiple answers. In any case I finally got here and gave it a shot. First impression for me is that its got to be amazing. They have a long line, they got someone serenading folks while they gorge on tacos, and don't forgot that trademark of CASH ONLY. Just looking around makes you eager for you to get yours. They have a pretty good system here and that system means its organized. They have someone taking your order on a paper and once you get the register you just pay, and they serve your food out pretty quick. 

So I got my burrito to go because I had somewhere to be. I also order chips and salsa on the side too. TBH I felt like i got cheated with the guac and pico because they only gave me one of each in the small sauce containers, while others who dined in got mounds of that stuff. Maybe i ordered the wrong thing? Any who, thats not my I came. So I finally get into my burrito. I ordered a carne asada super burrito. The burrito is a smaller than I anticipated... the meat was good, I can tell the guac was fresh but it was more on the bland side. The burrito was cool, its not bad, but it wasn't memorable. It didn't have spanish rice? The only upside I can think to myself while eating this burrito is that it wasn't greasy and it has a lot of meat. So for me the burrito here gets the job done, but I probably won't order another burrito here.

So if you're headed here to grab a burrito just consider these things.
If you like big burritos, not in here
If you shrimp and steak at the same time, not here
Spanish rice inside, not here.
Not open late.

They also don't have a full menu of Mexican food here either. Everyone has their personal preferences for burritos, but for me its El Farolito down the street. Parking sucks here too
author: Arron E.

description: I was skeptical of this place and wondered how it got a JBA for their street food. Well, believe the hype! IMO best thing on the menu is the steak tacos wit the works. Got to find a way to get over here one more time before I move out of the 'hood next week! YUM.
author: e w.

description: I am a burrito loved and usually eat at papelote but I wanted to try la taqueria. Worse experience possible. Crowded, disorganized, rude cashier and meh food.
author: Fer R.

description: You cannot visit the Mission and not visit La Taqueria. This is a bone of contention in our house as we constantly argue where the best Mission Burrito exists. Don't look anywhere else, it's here. The lines can be long on the weekends, but it's worth it for a burrito that could feed a small village. The tacos here are decent, but stick to what they're known for.
author: Dee R.

description:
I love this place. It's quick, delicious, and traditional. The carnitas burrito is excellent, as are any of the tacos!! 

You order at the counter. 

There's plenty of seating, but it can be hard to snag a table. 

I highly recommend, if you're looking for good, non-hipster influenced Mexican food.
author: Enrique F.

description: I've lived in SF my whole life & somehow I forgot about this place after my Mom took me when I was a kid. At 37 I came back & was blown away. You gotta do a Tacos Durados (that's a must) & my favorite the Quesadilla. El Farolito (was my favorite & still is for the authenticity, value & freshness) but if you don't mind spending the extra money La Taqueria is the Cadillac of Mexican restaurants in SF!
author: Everette R.

description:
To be honest, all that hype about that place made is so mediocre when I got there. They also overcharge for everything. 
Their burritos cost a lot if you want to add cheese , guacamole or other items that might be already offered at other places.
The meat was so soggy that it dripped and went all over for all 4 people that were eating.

It is a good place, but I would prefer to try some other place in the area
author: Jad A.

description: This is by far my favorite place to get a burrito in the bay. Specifically the carne asada burrito. Most of the time wait looking for parking and waiting in line is worth it. I'm not a big guy but to get fully satisfied usually I get a carne asada burrito and two tacos. My only complaint was that last Saturday (around 6pm) the food was kind of cold :( It was still great, but not as it should be.
author: Brian J.

description: Definitely a solid taqueria place. I'm not a HUGE fan of Mexico food, but my boyfriend loves it and we were going to a comedy show close by so we decided to grab food here. I got a carne asada burrito dorado style, and it was really bomb. I would definitely recommend getting it dorado style.
author: Jenna G.

description:
The burritos here are pretty damn good. They are different here than your local taqueria. Instead of a super stuffed burrito, it is somewhat skinny and has a lot of sour cream and guac. This makes the burrito pretty tasty in my opinion.

The line gets pretty long and the space gets pretty crowded. Make sure to bring your own cash since it is cash only and you probably don't want to be charged by the ATM here.
author: Marco C.

description:
Positives: meat is good, not the best beef. Beans are good and avocado/guacamole is ok. 
Negatives: no rice, no ac,  pico de gallo was not fresh, totally overrated.
The vegetarian burrito was very plain, i've had flavorful veggie burritos elsewhere. 
I would rather eat at Chaves supermarket or El Torito. 
This place is NOT great mexican food.
author: Celine G.

description:
Okay so honestly I was a little bummed here. I order a chicken taco & it was filled with beans that pretty much ruined it :(
My husband had a burrito which was good & we had a strawberry fresca which was great.
Next time I will not order a chicken taco!
I think it's worth another try.
author: Ashley G.

description:
4.5. Carnitas burrito dorado style was awesome as was the chorizo taco. Loved both. Big fan of the crispy taco wrapped in a tortilla. 

Carne asada burrito didn't have nearly enough meat. 

Chicken burrito (non dorado) was gross. Chicken is so wet/juicy that it just made for a giant glob of mush. It would have been an upgrade (just bad instead of gross) if this was dorado style. 

Expensive and cash only. $11 for a burrito that won't fill you up on its own.....$6.50 for a big taco....but $6.50!.

Felt dirty cheating on El Farolito.
author: J A.

description: We've been customers at La Taqueria for years.  Today, I ordered 2 corn Quesadillas.  The menu board displayed $1.75 each.  The cashier charged me $2.25 each.  When I inquired, she said, "Oh, we haven't updated our menu".  That's not my problem.  I should have been charged what the menu shows!!  This place is a gold mine and they don't update their menu.  Well, goodbye La Taqueria.  You lost a loyal customer.
author: Victoria M.

description: Burritos were a bit too wet for my liking. Fast service was great! Also their chips and salsa were phenomenal.
author: Caleb S.

description: This might be the best burrito I've had so far. Ordered the carne asada super burrito which was about $13. I thought I wouldn't enjoy it as much because they do not put rice in it but I loved it. The meat was juicy and there was so much flavor in every bite. They don't skimp out on guacamole either which is a plus! The only downside is that it is in the pricier side but I will definitely go back to get their tacos and quesadillas.
author: Allison L.

description:
amazing carne asada and their tacos dorado are the best.  if the mission has the best taquerias in the city then la taqueria is the best of the best.  

sorry pancho villa.....you've been replaced
author: Robert S.

description: I'll start off by saying this was indeed one of the best burritos I've ever had, but there is room for improvement here. I'll start by saying I am a bit of a burrito snob; disclaimer. The burrito itself was good. I'm a vegetarian so I rely heavily on spices, salsa and guac to add necessary flavor to my burritos. The only criticism I'd have to say is the salsa although fresh, was lacking in spice. I expected this place to have mind blowing salsa! so it just needs a bit more spiciness. The employees were nice, and the line moved quickly. More seating would be a plus but other than that I loved the food and will definitely make it back to try it again.
author: Melissa M.

description:
A neighborhood favorite. Go with a dorado-style burrito. That's all you need to know!

Watch for early close-times!
author: Steffan P.

description:
Great little spot for some burritos or tacos. I heard that their burritos are great, but I prefer to go for the classic tacos. 

The place isn't too big and only takes cash! so be ready to snatch a table if you see one. Once you place your order you can sit and they will call/yell out your number.

The food itself is simple but good. The tacos have a good portion of meat and beans inside. I tried carne asada and chicken. You can add guac and a few other things as extra. 

It's a good and cheap meal if you are looking for something quick. I would come back on a late night!
author: Hansel B.

description: I love this place & can eat once a week here. Unfortunately I live over 50 miles away. But you can bet any time I get close to SF I push to eat here. Depending on mood I don't know which is better: carne asada tacos or bean & cheese, pico de gallo burrito & always with a Modelo. Tried & true tradition that services the tastiest Mexican food in the Bay Area. Half the fun is to try find some place to sit. My happy place that never lets me down.
author: Dori B.

description: Delicious. My friend and I shared the super burrito (with half carne asada and half carnitas), a super taco (with carne asada), and chips with guac and salsa. No rice in the burrito, so no unnecessary starch filler. My only criticism is that the salsa made the chips soggy. I may suggest asking for the salsa on the side. The restaurant is extremely crowded and has picnic table style seating. We were lucky enough to find seats pretty quickly and everyone was in good spirits. Eat fast and make room for other people. Live music which can be a little loud especially when they're trying to maneuver between the seats and the line, but it provides a festive feel. TLDR: Get the super burrito. Cash Only.
author: Annie L.

description: Worth the hype! We got there right as they opened and didn't have to wait in any line. Love the simplicity & authenticity.
author: Melina M.

description: I finally ate here and I was not disappointed. I at first thought there was a limited menu but changed my mind. I had a very tasty, juicy and flavorful taco. I did not miss the rice in my burrito. They serve beer and fresh juices. I can't wait to go back.
author: Infodiva B.

description: I was told to try this place by an Uber driver and I am so glad that I did! There was a long line but they move very quickly. I ordered the super carne asada taco and a chicken taco. Both of them were delicious! The carne asada had a lot of flavor and the chicken was juicy. I also had the Jamaica drink and it was very refreshing and delicious! This place is definitely worth the wait :)
author: Vanessa R.

description: Had the head burrito and was amazing! The tacos look delicious, so I'll be paying a second visit soon. They don't take credit card, that's the only downside.
author: Hugo G.

description:
This joint is not bad. Decent burritos just very tiny place. My friend and I went here cause everyone was raving that the mission burrito must be had here. I've had decent burritos elsewhere. This place is ok. Not sure that I can give it four or five stars tho... it's a decent burrito that has lots of fillings. I'd rather not have all that stuff, just some black beans, meat and a few condiments. That just me. I'm not into all the rice.

I got the carne mission and it was huge and fresh. I thought it was just too cluttered in there with the salsa bar (really not necessary when your main dish is the burrito). It wasn't very neat looking probably cause people just serve themselves and you need someone full time just cleaning up after us. 

They do have a bathroom that is in somewhat ok working order.
author: Nektaria R.

description: This place, hands down, has the best taco I've ever had.  We drove here from LA, basically for these.  I had these tacos once a few years back and haven't stopped dreaming about it since, so my fiancé and I decided to take a weekend trip up to SF for a food vacation.  I got a chorizo taco and carnitas taco, both super, both dorado style.  My fiancé got the carne asada burrito, super and dorado style, and we shared chips and guacamole.  I can even begin to tell you the joy.  This is such an authentic experience, with good quality and expertly made Mexican food.  My mouth waters just thinking about it.  The dorado style option is a game changer, as it's make your tacos and burritos a crunchy but soft and cheesy delight.  The tacos are huge and loaded with salsa, guacamole and sour cream.  Everything is so fresh.  The only downside here is the exceptionally long line and seating, which you have to circle like a hawk waiting for someone to get up, but I'd never take stars away for it because this food is worth any amount of patience and seating headache, it's THAT GOOD!
author: Haley H.

description: This is a good mom-and-pop type place for burritos. We read about it online and gave it a shot. It is cash only, so come prepared. The burritos are pretty simple. I believe mine just had chicken, cheese, and pico de gallo. You can add other toppings, but each one is extra. Tables are long and community style.
author: Nicole D.

description: Place was absolutely delicious! Top 3 in SF. Must get the burrito with asada and a taco of chorizo! It was so tasty
author: Missi B.

description: The food was very good!!!! Burrito and Tacos where excellent and hey do give you large portions. Get there early though as the line for lunch and dinner can get very long- we had to fight for a seat inside.
author: Anthony R.

description:
Excellent spot. La Taqueria offers quite possibly the best Mexican food you'll have in your life. 

After reading its raving reviews, and confirming its popularity among the locals, I knew I had to come try it. And the verdict is positive: you'll have dreams with this food for days to come.

I suggest having the Super Burrito. It comes with sour cream and guacamole, and the carnitas one was particularly great. 

Even though it's a long wait, you'll find yourself talking about La Taqueria to everyone - even yourself. It's that GOOD!
author: Yaniv K.

description:
Ughhhh... This is the type of taqueria that you eat at and then think about every single day until you eat there again.. AND I am a vegetarian so I can't imagine how the meat-eaters feel. This place is amazing. Their tacos are huge with the best beans, spicy salsa, sour cream and cheese that I have ever had.. inside not only a hard taco shell but also a soft one! 

Oh and their meat tacos looked amazing.. Need I say more?
author: Harmony H.

description: Awesome burritos, not awesome lines and seating. If you have time to kill, it's definitely worth a go... if you're in a hurry, don't count on getting in and out that quickly. I did the vegetarian and my friend did the steak - both were great options.
author: Nico D.

description: Come get your delicious tacos at La Taqueria!! And of course, don't forget to add the agua de jamaica to your order
author: Eloisa A.

description: Good but not authentic as I expected, el grullense or Gordos is a much better alternative. Especially for the price.
author: Alex O.

description: I just moved to the bay from LA and have been dying for some decent Mexican food. I finally found the special place!!! This is beyond decent and worth the wait and the drive to get to. I love the vegetarian options! A bean, cheese and salsa taco in a hard shell that's wrapped in a corn tortilla. Genius. So much flavor and so simple. I usually don't eat meat anymore, but heard the carnitas were amazing here so I gave them a go. Holy Shit! Some of the best I have ever had. A bit greasy, which is to be expected, but just so savory and full of flavor. Even my basic cheese quesadilla was amazing. Perfectly grilled. My mouth is watering for this place right now. If you don't believe me, the Travel channel was there when I walked in doing a special on this place. Must go to in the mission.
author: Emily M.

description:
Came here twice after doing a Google search for best burrito joints in the mission. Lived up to the hype! I got the super burrito the first time and a super quesadilla the second.

- Lines look extremely long but the service is fast.
- Seating is sometimes hard to find, but within a 10 min wait usually you can find a spot.

Would definitely come here again!
author: Michael H.

description:
OMG so glad they're back open. They were closed for a couple weeks for the holidays and just reopened this week. I've been craving for tacos since before Christmas! And today my friends I finally fulfilled that craving!!!! Halleluja!!!  Praise you La Taqueria Gods! The Dorado Style Carne Asada Tacos are my favorite of all time. And I've been to TJ and in other cities in Mexico several times and have Mexican friends that cook authentic Mexican food and these tacos are still my favorite! The meat is just....MmmMmmMmm  let's put it this way... when I die you can bury me in it!!!! Lol I wanted to take a picture for you guys but all that's left are empty wrappers! Lol anyway I'm full now and very satisfied! 

Tips: 
*call in ahead to order line can get looonng 
*bring cash 
*dorado style (hard shell in a soft shell) tacos are the bomb
*green salsa is HOT (imo)but still good in small drops-gives it a kick
author: MONICA G.

description: The best taqueria in SF. This is obviously the most debated thing you could discuss in San Francisco, but La Taqueria gets my vote, hands down. 1. you don't need rice in a burrito, that's just filler. 2. Dorado style - always dorado style. 3. The crispy taco is basically the best version of a cheesy Gordita crunch you could possible ask for. 4. Their carnitas is basically perfect, which is the true hallmark when it comes to Mexican meats.
author: Aaron A.

description: This magical place is the Disney equivalent of tacos. You could go here 5 days a week and still want more tacos. Definitely order the carne asada.
author: Mike F.

description:
Ever wish you could eat a tortilla that tasted like a cloud of joy?  Head to La Taqueria.

I ventured here since it was named the best taco in America by The Daily Meal website - http://www.thedailymeal.com/50-best-tacos-america/5114

I ordered the beef burrito and it was freaking amazing.  A few piece of beef were a little tough (perhaps too much connective tissue or whatever), but my burrito just melted in my mouth.  I'm making La Taqueria a part of my San Francisco itinerary every time I visit the city by the bay.

It's cash only, so have your Washingtons and Lincolns ready.
author: Ben B.

description:
Been here 2 times and got the same thing: Carne Asada Super Burrito.

The damage? $10

What did I get? A burrito small than a plastic water bottle.

Now, I agree that the burrito was delicious and all, but for $10, a very long wait(most of the time), and most likely no seats. It's not worth it.

You can walk 1 block north to El Farolito and get a bigger burrito for $9. And it's not an quantity over quality thing. It's still good. 

And they're not even open late! Why not? You can make the money! El Farolito opens til 3:30am! (I just want you guys to be open so the line at El Farolito would be shorter)
author: Da X.

description:
Given all the hype around this place I was a little underwhelmed, but a good burrito nevertheless.

La Taqueria is a veritable institution, ranked by some as the best burrito in the United States (see Nate Silver's burrito bracket http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/san-francisco-burritos-really-are-better/). The crowd is always spilling out the door, and even though there's lots of seating it can be difficult to get a spot. Get in line, order at the register, burritos are made assembly-line style, and they'll call your number when its ready. I went for a super burrito with carne asada (rice, pico, cheese, sour cream, guac). 

Here's the part where I analyze a burrito in excruciating detail: excellent tortilla wrapping technique. Any burrito aficionado understands that this is crucial. Ingredients were standard. Guac was on point, obviously fresh avocados and they didn't skimp slathering it on. The steak was really juicy and flavorful, but I had quite a few tough/fatty bites which always sucks. Didn't ruin the otherwise strong burrito for me, though. Portion size is a little small. 

If you're a regular burrito person checking this place out is a must. But if you've only got one meal in the Mission, my fave burrito is still up the road at Taqueria Cancun.
author: Bud P.

description:
Maybe it was the hype? I was a bit disappointed. Also, living in San Diego for a few years probably doesn't help and has given me a higher than normal bar to rate with. We ordered the Super Carne Asada Burrito for almost $10 and the size of the burrito was very underwhelming- skinny and small. I will say that the carne asada meat was tasty but that was pretty much it- everything else in it was just trying to fill up space. The line was long and I wouldn't choose to come back here as my number one choice. Though maybe if I did, I would try the tacos next time- they even looked more filling than the burrito.
Cash only!
author: Grace L.

description: Really wonderful experience. Burritos are delicious and music performances made the waiting a happy memory
author: Alice L.

description: They use flap meat the best cut for tacos this guys don't cut corners. The price on the tacos is about right for the amount of meat they put and guacamole. Ranchera meat is about $5.99 a pound which is flap meat in English ,but I'll definitely go again. This spot and fisherman's wharf street food in San Francisco it's all u need for ur weekend in Frisco
author: Gabriel R.

description:
My favorite place to eat Mexican food! I love it. The people is super nice! 
Love, tacos dorados, Burros and they have vegetarian options which is a great option for people who wants to try Mexican food with out meat.
author: Melisa R.

description: Really amazing tacos! Worth the wait and it's not a cheap taco place but definitely one of the best tacos and quesadillas I've ever had! Vegetarian option too!
author: Tina L.

description: Great tacos, fair prices, and the ingredients seemed to be moderately reliable quality as well. I know the reviews here indicate that there are always endless lines, but I haven't found that to be the case -- as long as you don't go during prime lunch and dinner hour. Staff were somewhat friendly and a pleasant band came in to play for the customers (and ask for tips) as we dined.
author: Joni W.

description: Overall my experience & food were good. Staff is excellent. There is a lot of hype in regard to this place. Another long line in San Francisco.
author: Michelle M.

description: This is my favorite casual taco and burrito joint! It's great any time of day or night! Perfect place to bring visitors, parents, or a date! Open late night and often have a mariachi band playing! It's a must try when in the mission district!!
author: Caleigh H.

description:
I'm sorry to say it San Diego, but I think that San Francisco makes a far superior burrito.  This has always confused me, because one would think there would be a correlation between distance from the border, and quality of Mexican food.  Perhaps it is because burritos aren't actually Mexican food, or maybe it is because San Francisco tends to do food, in general, better than everyone else.

I am a huge fan of the Mission style burrito.  I have tried several locations, and I think La Taqueria is the best of the bunch.  The ingredients taste a little more quality here than some of the other joints around the Mission, but you still get a good layer of grease to satisfy your late night cravings. 

The super burrito (avocado, cheese, beans, sour cream) is the way to go here.  I'm a big fan of their carnitas.  They manage to make them  juicy and crispy all at the same time.  What makes La Taqueria stand out, is that they have the option to grill your burrito.  This gives it a slightly crispy shell, almost like a chimichanga.  I highly recommend it.

The prices are high here, but you can't fault the business for neighborhood gentrification.  It's San Francisco, $10 burritos are the unfortunate norm.  At least they're tasty!
author: Mark A.

description: Food was very overpriced for the amount of food they provide. I came here after hearing all the hype about how amazing it is and finally after waiting in the 30 minute line I get my incredibly small $10 burrito and my expectations fell flat.. I think I finished my burrito in about 4-5 bites... overall the food is tasty and the green salsa is ok I guess but I can get a much better experience down the street.
author: Tim S.

description: No taco compares to La Taqueria's taco dorado with carnitas. Super fresh and flavorful every time, totally worth the wait and the trip to the ATM.
author: tura s.

description: It was super pack and limited seating area. However, the food manage to come out at a good time and was yummy!
author: Keothanh H.

description:
Overhyped. 
Went back for the first time in a while and there was (as usual) a line out the door. 
Got my usual super carne asada burrito... they raised the prices and made the burrito smaller.  Ok??
Flavors were good but for the wait time, prices and amount of food they give you, I won't be back unless I win the lottery and am not that hungry.
author: George P.

description: Dude, this place is f*cking bomb. It's sooo good. The best authentic mexican food I've ever had. It's a little pricey but the portions are a decent size. It's literally packed open - close. Chances are there's no where to sit and the lines are long. But definitely worth the wait and I'll definitely be back when I'm in San Francisco.
author: Jennifer N.

description: The food was pretty good nothing special but nothing horrible either decent service will probably go back
author: Joshua S.

description:
-1 star because of the rude lady who was cleaning the bathroom. She didn't put a sign on the door. We were all waiting for the ladies bathroom for a good 15 minutes (maybe more). We knocked a couple of times, you know, trying to give the person inside some hints that people are waiting. Some of the people behind me even went to the men's bathroom. Finally some were impatient and tried knocking again, I happen to be at the very front of the line this whole time. The person inside, who happens to be a worker there, banged on the door really hard (mind you, I  was 5 inches away from it) opened it, with an exasperated face said, "Im cleaning, ok? Cleaning." And closed the door again. I was shocked. If you were cleaning, shouldn't you put a sign? And secondly, you don't bang the door and give attitude bc you were mad cleaning the bathroom. One lady behind me even said "you should report her to the manager. you don't treat customers like that."

I couldn't agree more. I was in a happy mood back then. If I was angry, I would've reported her to the manager.

Other than her, everything else was great.
*Get el dorado style for sure. It's 2 tortillas, 1 crispy (the inside).
*Super taco the size of your face. Order 2 and you'll be full (for a girl).
*Super : cheese, sour cream and avocado.
The lady who takes your orders just asks if you want avocado, cheese and sour cream. I wasn't aware of what super taco entails so I just said yes and ordered 3. They were $6 a pop!

*The green salsa is bomb.
*Most of the tables are communal, meaning you share it with other ppl so if you come by yourself you could probably get a seat.

*Cash only
*Bathrooms and atm at the back.
author: Inez J.

description: Best in the City. Go early . Excellent Food and a San Francisco Mission Original. I hope it doesn't get taken over-
author: Siobhan M.

description:
Alright, so, let me give you a little background first about my experience when it comes to burritos. I've been on a burrito diet more or less since my college days. Most of the burritos I ate before moving to the San Francisco area were from Fresno or Los Angeles/San Diego. It wasn't until a year ago that I tried my first ever burrito here, in The Mission. Sadly, I was not impressed.

I've only had the super carne asada burrito at La Taqueria (the same type of burrito I order just about anywhere). It's okay. It's not bad, but just not great. Also keep in mind that while I'm not a fan, there were people in my group who still stick to their guns that La Taqueria crafts the finest burrito they've ever had. This isn't a MONSTER burrito like the kind you'll find in San Diego, and that's not a bad thing. A burrito shouldn't rely on being over-sized to achieve greatness. What this burrito really lacks is: 

1. flavorful carne asada. You barely notice it while eating the burrito 
2. a stickier tortilla. A great tortilla can really save the day. These are fine, but lack character. Not sticky, not particularly fluffy, not charred in just the right way, just meh
3. pinto beans are an unwelcome addition to a burrito in my book. They take up prime tortilla real estate and leave a huge dripping mess out the bottom of the burrito (messes are fine for certain things, not pinto beans)
4. spicy salsa. The salsa they have on hand has zero kick to it. It's a sad day when I feel like I should have brought my own bottle of El Yucateco.

Other Mission style burritos I've tried have been similarly okay. La Taqueria is also a mad house. Every time I've been here there's been a line around the building and a very long wait for tables (usually about 30 minutes). For this long of a wait, in my opinion, the burrito just isn't worth the effort.
author: William P.

description: This south Floridian found the tacos to be a little pricey and just ok, nothing spectacular. The carnitas burrito though? It's out of control. Hands down second best burrito of my life. You have to wait a bit, but the patience pays off. Don't mess around with the tacos, go straight for the burrito.
author: Lauren J.

description: Just as good as everyone says! I got the vegetarian burrito and tamarind agua fresca and both were delicious. Definitely a must-have in SF.
author: Allegra G.

description:
Cash only!  Food worth 5 stars but minus one for no seating and I think a bit pricey.  

Line was out the door and around the smaller restaurant.  Lots of people saving tables while their party ordered.  I think you should only be able to sit if you have your food!  It took about 35-40 minutes to get through the line and get our food. 

Ordered the Super Carnitas burrito $6 for carnitas, beans, pico de gallo, guacamole and cheese (comes with sour cream and hot sauce if you like, but I didn't order those) and a mango aqua fresca.  

As I mentioned above, lots of people save tables when they haven't even received their food, so we asked to sit at the end of a table... ate a very yummy, kinda crispy taco with softer shell on the outside with cheese between the two tortillas, messy, flavorful taco and  absolutely wished I had ordered 2 tacos!   We finished eating and left before the people hogging the table even got their food!

I would go back in a minute and order a taco and something else and take it to go!
author: Kauionalani P.

description: Pretty delicious food for pretty delicious prices. I tried a chicken taco (super) and a cheese quesadila, as well as the chips and salsa + avocado.  The chicken was juicy and flavorful (but got the odd bite of gristle), and the chips were perfect and not greasy. It was quite crowded, and the queueing situation was a bit of a mess, but this is a great pick for a cheap and tasty meal in the mission.
author: Jillian K.

description:
Overpriced hipster white bred food,a lot better places exist in the Mission 
Not authentic Mexican by any means
Caters to the no taste US consumers
author: John R.

description:
Clean place, simple menu for two stars.  Meh flavor, hipster prices, and no free chips makes this place a sucker's bet for those looking for a traditional taqueria.  

For a more authentic and better experience, check out Pancho Villa, La Corneta, or El Faro Lito.  

Sorry, I really wanted to like this place as it won the award of best burrito in America  but now one must consider the source of such an award.
author: Frank C.

description: Just try this place. I don't even have to write much.... if you're an SF native you already know what's up.
author: Sasha M.

description: SF born and raised here. La Taqueria makes my favorite tacos (crispy, please....drools).  But all you SF transplants ruin everything! Long lines, jacked up prices, busy phone lines, etc!  This place can be a zoo, so over the years I've resorted to placing phone orders.  Nowadays no one even picks up the phone, especially in the evening a couple hours before closing.  I know business is great, but come on, La Taqueria!  Look out for your long-time SF native customers!  5+ stars for the food, but 3 stars for service.
author: Mrs. F.

description:
I heard about this place on man vs. food, and while it does not have any large portion size items, the food is pretty tasty and the line is out the door. Burrito and chips around $7-9 depending on the ingredients you add in to your burrito.

There are a few spots to sit outside. Friendly staff, pretty fast service considering the long line. Their system is a little chaotic for pick-up, you have to pay attention to what food is yours and which drinks are yours, can easily be picked up by the wrong party.
author: Keith A.

description:
Honestly this place was all hype. Came here recently, and ended up spending like $16 on a conservative economy-sized burrito and a very basic horchata. I was actually in the mood for some tacos, but they were like in the $4+ range. I mean, I was in the mood for some cheapy simple street tacos, and I guess these are gourmet tacos with like guac and cheese and other shit, so i guess, whatever. The food wasn't bad or anything. Kinda messy. Ended up getting burrito juice on my thighs. (hehe story of my life :P) 

The line was incredibly long, so don't expect to eat immediately. In the future I'll be hitting up a the more low-key Mexican hole in the walls down 24th street. Not to discourage anyone from coming here. People really seem to like it.

Good luck finding a place to sit!

Also, lots of "The North Face" wearing customers. Just an observation.
author: Sergio R.

description:
Raaaage! I waisted so many calories eating "America's best burrito." Go down the street to Farolito if you truly want something epic. The burrito here was terribly basic, with nothing special or high-quality flavors. If anything, it was bland, cold and mushy.

Stars added because the service is quick and cashier/folks behind the counter are really friendly. But as a self-proclaimed burritophile, I wouldn't ever recommend this place for a burrito.
author: Sarah G.

description: Okay so I'm Mexican and where I live (East Bay) we are spoiled with amazing authentic Mexican food. Now I'm not saying this place isn't good but it's not line around the building good....I enjoyed my taco and burrito but unless the line is short you won't find me here again.
author: Nichole N.

description:
It's super crowded, and a super burrito comes out to over $10. However, it's still pretty damn good.

So I've only tried two things here -- the carne asada burrito, and the carnitas burrito, both done "dorado style", which means they griddle the burrito after they wrap it, giving it a nice crispy outside. It's different, and the crispiness of the tortilla means it cracks and leaks out its contents so you may have to fork-and-knife it, but it's absolutely delicious.

Is it the best burrito in the world? I'm not sure about that, especially considering I spent 7+ years down in San Diego (El Cotixan's California burrito is probably my absolute favorite of all time), but for SF, this is pretty damn good. I wouldn't drive in from out of town for it or anything, but if you're in the area, it's worth trying.

I also appreciate that the ownership here seem like friendly people. I hear that they shut down around the holidays and give all of their employees a paid vacation. I also saw a man at the register who yelled at a customer who had her head down at the table, looking rather tired... "Hey! You can't sleep here!" When the girl looked up at him, he cracked a smile, and said, "Just kidding! Here, take have some candy! It'll wake you up." Like I said, friendly people!
author: Kazu O.

description: Just wanted to downgrade my review for two reasons, one prices just went up again so expensive now which I dont mind paying for good food like this but the parking and especially the seating is sooooooo terribly bad, line is out the door around the corner which is fine but once you get in there, there is nowhere to sit last time I went in I practically ate above the jukebox because it was so packed and unconfortable, especially with a family and kids, if your going to raise the prices provide better seating at least for the families that come in. Havent been back since.
author: Abel M.

description:
Super great, as always! Here's the deal: find the end of the line and join the queue--it moves quickly. Survey the menu and figure out what you want (don't worry, you can't go wrong) asap because a waitress may take your order before you reach the front of the line. Remain in the line and pay when you reach the cashier. Try not to ask complicated questions and always tip extravagantly. Credit cards are not accepted but there is an atm at the back of the restaurant on the left hand side. After you pay for your food, take your receipt, note the number and have a seat. Be patient, your number will be called in 5 or 10 minutes. 

Because the owner personally oversees the restaurant (he's the gentleman with the moustache, wrapping your tacos and calling your number), you'll always experience friendly service, fast-moving lines and the fantastic food that makes this THE place to get your Mission-style burritos and tacos. 

I usually order chicken tacos with avocado and whole pinto beans. Don't expect deep-fried corn tortillas--they're steamed and soft, not crispy, unless you order crispy tortillas (a special not on the menu). Ask for some pico de gallo (finely-chopped fresh tomato and onion) and douse your tacos (and everything else) with La Taqueria's spicy salsa verde (green sauce), which appears to be tomatillo-based. This dinner is my idea of comfort food heaven. When I really want to go wild, I get the carnitas (shredded pork) tacos, which are savory, salty, porky and addictive. My husband gets the carne asada burrito with black beans and avocado and a melon drink. La Taqueria's burritos are big, but not the gigantic log-like burritos served up in other taquerias because they're pared down to the essentials, not loaded with rice and gloppy sauces. 

If the line is out the door, simply walk to Mission Pie (the Mission's best-kept secret), a few feet away at the corner of Mission and 25th Streets, and have a beer and a very different and delicious lunch or dinner, such as pork with green chile over brown rice, with steamed greens, followed by banana cream pie. Or try Old Jerusalem, a middle eastern restaurant across the street, one block down, between 25th and 26th. You can't go wrong in this part of the hood.
author: Julie B.

description: The best burrito I ever had -- The meat is cooked perfectly and ingredients distributed evenly. Make sure to get the super el dorado burrito for a crispy tortilla with moist filling. The place seems pretty packed, so prepare to wait a while.
author: Michael Y.

description: The burritos here are amazing! I would not go anywhere else in San Francisco for that. No rice is the way to go! Be preprated for the huge line outside. They could be doing square cash in the line to speed up things. It took me over an hour in line. Keep in my that this is cash only!
author: Candy Girl S.

description: Burritos are simple and delicious- truly mission style and a step above the rest! I think lives up the expectations I loved the food even going into it with all the buzz around the burrito.
author: J K.

description: My favorite tacos in SF... if there's parking u might as well stop by any time they open and you have cash. Line goes quick, also worth the wait
author: John O.

description: I think they can make the portions a bit bigger. The price for a small burrito was about 1-2 bucks more than what I am used to. The Meat didn't seam very fresh. Overall I am sure people would enjoy going here but there are a few things they can improve like presentation of ingredients and portions.
author: Kas M.

description:
Not the safest burrito to eat in your car. 

Hearing this was allegedly home to the greatest burrito in America, we made the journey here with mixed results. Time, the first, we came while visiting during the holidays only to discover the place shuttered with a sign saying they'd given their employees a week-long-or-so Christmas break. 

Not deterred our second visit, which involved having to try again later in the day due to a street festival in the morning and no parking for miles, we went ahead and stood in the half-hour-long line to order. It was the Sunday before Memorial Day, and they had signs they would be closed for that as well. We were leaving town Monday, so it was now or never. 

Here's some tips about them so far: 
- They are CLOSED during holidays. 
- Plan to take public transit to get here if you have terrible luck finding parking.
- Lines to get in are fairly long.  
- CASH ONLY. Be prepared. 
- Do NOT expect to find a seat. If you do manage to snag one, understand that you will have about 200 strange butts hovering around your food and face, as they idle around the room.  

We each got super-sized burritos, dorados-style. Mr. D got chorizo; I got carnitas. They were actually fairly small (roughly the same girth as a Del Taco epic burrito, if not slightly bigger.) Making your burrito "super" just adds sour cream, avocado, and cheese and knocks the price per burrito up over $10. 

Making your burrito "dorados" style is something you have to specially request, in which they throw your made burrito onto the griddle to crisp some more, thus warming and liquifying the insides. 

Eating in the car, to keep warm in the frigid evening, my super carnitas dorado burrito erupted in juices from both ends and the sides, bukkakeing all over the place, unable to contain itself. Oddly, though, I think I'd still have preferred the beans were mashed and not whole, as they were. Flavor-wise, it was OK. 

Worth trying, but both Mr. D and I agree we've had better burritos in the Mission, let alone the rest of America.
author: Christine A.

description: I expected this place to be overrated, but could not possibly have anticipated exactly how overrated it would be. Crowded, long lines, and overpriced with very average food. I absolutely would not under any circumstances recommend that anybody eats here.
author: Andrew T.

description: Honestly, what can I say that hasn't already been said.. Hands down the best Taqueria this side of the upcoming "wall" The wait is worth it because the food is that good! Now If I only lived closer so I could go more..
author: Drea V.

description:
There's nothing I can say about this place that hasn't already been said. It is renowned, and accrues more than just a cult following. La Taqueria doesn't need any more reviews. But here I am.

Some advice: 

There will be a line regardless of the time of day
You will need cash
You will not find a seat 
Drink the agua fresca (I am partial to strawberry and watermelon)
At the bottom of the cup, don't even think about using a straw--how are you supposed to eat the fruit chunks with a straw? 
To those who complain about the guacamole being supbar, that's because it's listed as "avocado". Read the menu, dummies. 
To the naysayers--you WILL eat cow tongue and you WILL like it
Despite being a Mexican joint, the food is light (how??)

Just do yourself a favor and eat here. You are not a true San Franciscan until you have.
author: Nicole C.

description:
My friend has been recommending La Taqueria for a long time and I finally tried it out the other day. I went here after dreaming about burritos when I was at the pride parade for 5+ hours. 

It's a block away from the BART Station (and El Farolito) so the convenience of burritos on the way home is always a plus. However, I think I like El Farolito better because the burrito portions over there are bigger. And they have rice in them. 
 
ORDERED: Carne Asada super burrito (with sour cream, cheese, and avocado) and a small soda. I think it was around 11 or 12 dollars in total.

PROS: I really liked the fresh avocado and the decent amount of seating. The restaurant is very clean.They have bottles of chile on the tables. 

CONS: My tastebuds started with a biased taste from El Farolito, so I automatically compared their burritos with them. With roughly the same price, you can head over there for a bigger burrito. 

Overall, I liked the amount of seating and the  cleanliness of the restaurant. The burrito I got was okay, but I heard the best thing to get here are the tacos! I'll try them next time!
author: Nadine T.

description:
The best TAQUERIA in San Francisco, CA!!!  We have been going to this restaurant for over 20 years.  A LITTLE PRICEY BUT QUALITY / GREAT TASTE / GENEROUS!!!

- Soft Tacos (Carne Asada, Cabeza, Carnitas) - EXCELLENT!!!
- Quesadilla - FANTASTIC!!!
- Burritos - AWESOME!!!  Very simple - Carne Asada, beans and salsa.
- They have the BEST Green Tomatillo sauce!!!
author: E J.

description:
This may be one of the best Mexican restaurants I've been to in the Bay. I came here on a Sunday night with a friend who was visiting from our of town. When we arrived there was a line that stretched out the door, but luckily the crew inside worked fairly quickly, so you were able to place your order and wait on the side for your food to be ready.

Finding a seat in this restaurant is hard. You're almost better off ordering the food to go and eating in your car or back at home (if you don't live too far). But the food is amazing. Out of all of the meats on their menu, my favorite by far was their carne asada. It doesn't matter if you order it in the form of a burrito or a taco, the carne asada at this place is cooked to absolute perfection.

Maybe it's the way they smoke the meat or barbecue it, but whatever it is, when you actually bit into it, it gives a distinct smoky taste, while at the same time accentuating the meat flavor from the beef. It is by far the best and most well made taco meat I have had in San Francisco.

Combine that with a Mexican Coke or a Modelo and it makes for one amazing meal. Definitely recommend this spot, just beware of possibly having to wait and also the possibility of not getting a seat.
author: Derek C.

description:
Wow, so this is what a burrito should taste like. We showed up around 2 pm on a Thursday and the place was packed. The service seemed rushed, but let's be honest, you're here for the burritos and the rushed service means the line goes faster. 

We ordered 1 regular carne asada burrito ($7) with extra meat (extra $1.20) and 1 veggie burrito (~$3.50 for a huge burrito!) for roughly $13. Once we ordered, we were handed a ticket and waited in the sitting area. The burrito collection process was a hectic one to say the least. They call out numbers in a seemingly haphazard order. I was number 8 and I heard 2, 3, 11, 12, 13, 4, 5, and then finally 8? Note: pay attention to the numbers they call out.

We were planning on taking the burritos to go, but once we got our food that plan went out the window. It was a massive burrito packed with meat, beans, and pico de gallo in every bite. They also had a green jalepeno sauce of some kind which added a nice kick to the burrito. If I had to list a con, it would probably be that the beans were a bit watery and that made the bottom of the burrito kind of soggy. This was a bigger problem for the veggie burrito since the main ingredient in those are the beans. Being nitpicky aside, this was an awesome burrito and one that I will definitely come eat again!
author: Jimmy C.

description: Yes, the line will be out the door and down the block. Stand in the line (it moves quickly), because this may be the best burrito you'll ever eat. I typically go for vegetarian burritos, but at La Taqueria, my favorite is the carne asada. The meat is lean and flavored perfectly. I've also tried the vegetarian and carnitas burritos, which were good, but didn't meet the excellence of the carne asada. Not on the menu, but order your burrito El Dorado style (grilled), for some added crunch. Don't overlook the salsa verde on the tables!
author: Melissa G.

description: Our great mexican friend took us here, we couldn't be happier! I had two beef tacos and I could eat more! So I got sussages and that was amazing! I took beef tongue to go!
author: Shahrzad M.

description:
Best Mexican in the USA!
This place is a "must visit" if you are in San Francisco. It is in the Mission District surrounded by several other Mexican restaurants, so make sure you are at the right place! My husband and I have been coming here for years and never had a bad experience. The homemade pineapple drink is to DIE for. The other flavors are delicious too. We both got the carnitas burrito with guacamole and cheese. Yum! You can order the burrito crispy too, if you aren't watching your girlie figure:) There is often a long line; however, it moves very quickly. Seating is limited, but if you are friendly you can share a table and make a new friend. Who knows, you may meet your soulmate over a delicious meal. There is a variety of AMAZING items on the menu to enjoy!
author: Stella K.

description: Great food I always get the steak burritos. The food is authentic but the lady in the register is rude I asked for an extra salsa and she gave me attitude, whatever happened to coustomer service?
author: Olga K.

description: Traffic was awful which is pretty usual in SF. Parking and finding a table was also difficult. It's a crowded small restaurant; but none of these obstacles will stop me from returning. The food is absolutely amazing! The best tacos and burritos I ever had.
author: Mansour P.

description:
It feels awkward writing this review. There are so many fans of this place, my life-long friend included. They all swear by its amazingness. Even my lead at work, a fellow Mexican, says this place is legit. Yet, I left disappointed after my visit.

What happened? I don't know! The flavors just didn't come together properly like I'm used to in Mexico. Everything tasted fine, but none of it reminded me of Mexico, and none of it was worth me coming back for another visit.

I ordered:

- Carnitas taco (regular): definitely the best out of the 3 tacos I got. They add pinto beans to the taco, which actually worked pretty well with the carnitas. The meat was juicy and tender (not fried to hell, like some other places) with good flavor.

- Asada taco (regular): OK, but that's it. The meat tasted like it had no marinade at all. Actually, I tasted the char more than I tasted the meat. But at least the meat wasn't overcooked and chewy.

- Lengua taco (regular): OK. Meat was very tender and juicy, but lacked any flavor. This is the only taco to come out traditionally, with just onion and cilantro. All the other tacos I ordered came with different non-standard fillings (e.g. pinto beans, pico the gallo, etc).

The salsa verde you find on every table was good and strongly recommended for your tacos. My tacos did not come with lime (an insult), and I did not bother asking for any for fear of losing my table. Also, the tacos are BIG (filling-wise). 3 were enough for me.

None of the tacos reminded me of my childhood or any of the flavors I grew up experiencing over my summers in Mexico. Were they bad? No. But, did they satisfy my taco craving? No. These tacos just left me reminiscing for Mexico.

A few notes to readers:
- I spent most of my summers in Mexico City, so I can't speak for regional taco differences (e.g. tacos in Northern Mexico may more closely resemble what's sold here).
- Everyone ordered a burrito, and everyone else ordered quesadillas. Very few people were eating tacos from what I could see.
author: Karl R.

description: As an El Paso raised Mexican-American, the Super Burrito at this place tasted very authentic and reminded me of home. The ingredients are much the same as those of surrounding Mexican joints, but the taste was still unique and delicious. The price could be better.
author: Hugo R.

description:
Possibly the best taco I've ever eaten. We shared the steak, chorizo, and carnitas. The super taco was amazing because they fry one of the tortillas to make it crispy (like a hard taco) and then sandwich it underneath a normal small taco. The combo of flavors was simple yet so, so good. Puts all the Chipotle tacos I've eaten to shame. 

The space doesn't excite, just small tables scattered about a very casual place. Kind of the Mexican equivalent of a casual corner pizza shop. Great for grabbing food and eating quickly.
author: Lily A.

description: It's too bad I live 45 minutes away from this place; I'd come more often! The tacos here are the best and I highly reccomend the strawberry agua fresca. Definitely coming back for more!
author: Michelle P.

description:
La Taqueria is one of the places you have to check out if you're visiting San Francisco. You won't be getting super authentic Mexican food in the city, but there are a few hidden gems here and there. When you talk to most of the locals they'll usually point out La Taqueria in the Mission. 

My friends and I made the line and were able to snag a table before putting our orders through. You got a few choices to make when you look at the menu. Either you're getting a burrito or a taco with a side and drink. I actually had the vegetarian tacos with a side of tortilla chips and fresh pico de gallo. 

What I found amazing about this joint was the fresh salsa and sauces they use on their dishes. You can tell everything is fresh and it's actually a bit more flavorful then some of the other places out there.

I'll definitely be going back to try one of their famous burritos and share my verdict. 

Tip:

- Get there early, as there are usually long lines on the weekends. 

- Seating is extremely limited. Try to catch a table as soon as people get up (sad but necessary).

- The place is CASH only so make sure to either take out money before you get there or go to the ATM inside.
author: Denisa R.

description:
I first want to say that I have had tacos from California to Florida and everywhere in-between. I personally believe that if you want to get a perfect taco you have to go to the right taqueria, usually in the sketchy side of town, or the one with the most landscapers outside.

Pulling up too La Taqueria I did get the feeling of sketchy-ness ( this is good when choosing a taco joint) but as I got closer i noticed this place was PACKED (this is a good sign as well) but I hate lines. hate them, but I have heard nothing but good things so I decided to wait it out. I ordered the burrito( i didn't go super, i just went basic old burrito) Ok, this is the part where all the foodies start crying into their i-phones but I wasn't really that impressed. I mean don't get me wrong, it was good but it wasn't like HOLY FUCK! YOU GOTTA TRY THIS! NOMNOMNOMNOMNOM!   No, it was more like "Its ok." but i did like their hot sauce, not usually a fan of green sauce, (always go for the red sauce) but theirs was pretty good.
author: Rick S.

description: Super bomb Mexican food . A little pricey but definitely worth it. Extremely flavorful and well made.
author: Andrea M.

description:
Didn't think it lived up to the hype. Got the super carne asada. Below average tortilla, average meat, and burrito started falling apart. 

High points were the guac and the salsa verde. Live Mariachi band helped save my burrito experience.
author: Tom F.

description:
Their burritos do not come with rice.  Sans rice. Yup, they do Not have rice here.  However, they do have some amazing pinto beans and carne asada.  And I'm not even a fan of pinto beans!  

The first time we came here, which was a couple of weeks ago, they gave us a sampling of their taco with our order.  He ordered the regular burrito with chicken but he was not happy with the chicken and found it to be boring.  He also had a side of their pinto beans, which he loved.  I had the regular burrito with carne asada and we were both delighted with it.  The carne asada was full of flavor, juicy and addicting.  

Last evening was our second time, and we ordered their tacos--I had two regular and one super (sour cream, avocado & cheese) taco with carne asada.  Their tacos are unique... hard shell inside, and then wrapped with the soft shell outside.   (I did request crispy, just in case.)  And let's just say that I barely got through 1 super taco and 1 regular taco before I gave up and took home the remaining 1 regular taco (which was reheated for lunch today and still delicious!!) 

He ordered the super burrito with whole pinto beans (they offer refried beans) and carne asada with spicy salsa.  He was much happier with the carne asada than the chicken from the first time.  He also had a regular taco with carne asada. 

The green sauce on the tables and throughout the place = spicy.  Delicious but it's got a lot of heat.  

Drinks = fountain sodas, beer, agua frescas, hot tea and milk.  I tried the tamarindo, which was delicious but not as tart as I'd like it.  (Can't help my tastebuds!!)

Prices = moderate.  We ordered 3 regular tacos, 1 super taco, 1 super burrito, 1 large Coke and 1 small/regular tamarindo and the total came out to just under $34.00.   Bring CASH.

Their burritos don't have rice so it's not as huge as most of us are used to in SF, but it's worth a try.  Their tacos are hearty, so make sure you've got the appetite, or you'll end up with leftovers.

Honestly, it's worth the money, as their carne asada is high quality, full of flavor, has very little gristle/fat, juicy, and great seasoning! (I know they have other meat offerings but we're sticking to what they're great at--carne asada!)

Seating = they have indoor and outdoor seating.  We've only been here around dinner time, so it gets packed but you can find a seat or two. 

Parking = street parking.  It's in the Mission.  Plenty of bike parking and the buses do stop nearby, and it's about 1 block from 24th Mission BART.  

My only complaint is the way they organize the line... it's a bit messy when they're busy.  Just ask where the line is. And stick around to hear your number.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Quite possibly, one of the best burrito's I've ever had in my life.

My wife and I met up with an old college friend ans his wife...place chosen due to business analytics research performed by the website FiveThirtyEight (http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/americas-best-burrito/).  If you're gonna win best burrito out of something like 64,000 joints across the US, why not give it a try?

I chose the carnitas burrito (served dorado [i.e. fried] style) and we also got some chips and salsa.  The chips and salsa were good, but O.M.G...that burrito was totally killer!  It was grilled to perfection have this nice (slightly) crisp outer skin to it.  On the inside, the simple ingredients melded perfectly creating one of the freshest Mexican dishes I've ever eaten.

This was a great dinner choice, would love to come here again.
author: Evan F.

description:
I had a super carnitas burrito! I will say the food is good but for the price it is not worth it. Especially to those who are traveling from an area with lots of taquerias in the area and where tacos range from 1.50 to 2.00. I understand that the cost of living and produce is more expensive in this area and that is why the food is priced so high. Possibly one of the only authentic Mexican food places here.

The restaurant is adorable and has a rustic Mexican feel. Great customer service! Overall good experience!! 

The only reason I am not giving it a 5 is because the price is so ridiculously high.
author: Siomara M.

description: Although this is CASH ONLY, I would highly, highly recommend this place. It is a big open space with lots of tables and stools. The tacos are a great size for a snack or multiple for a meal. I got the beef taco and the veggie taco. Both were delicious. Perfectly cooked beef and the ratios of salsa, avocado, cheese, beans, etc. were perfect. If you are in the Mission, you HAVE TO GO TO THIS PLACE. The people behind the counter move very quickly, so the wait is barely anything. Absolutely worth it. Go here.
author: Hanna C.

description: The wait was long especially for a foodtruck. I ordered all meat regular burrito i said add a little spice but it was too spicy. I only ate half of the burrito.
author: Hazel T.

description: This place was pretty busy for a weekday. I ordered the Super Carne Asada Burrito Dorado Style. The carne asada was fresh and the steaks were grilled right in front of you as you order. The burrito was on the smaller side and contained beans, sour cream, guacamole, cheese and pico de gallo. The carne asada was juicy but lacked seasoning and with the addition of sour cream and guacamole made the burrito very soupy. This place is know to be the champ at purist carne asada burritos but my experience was far from memorable. The place was pretty pricey and was $11 for a burrito.
author: Dustin B.

description:
Not sure what the hype is but it didn't deliver let's put the hype aside and review what's in front of us. Located in the historic mission district rumored to be one of the best if not the best burrito in San Francisco and the United States La Taqueria is a true staple among the people from the bay. 

Burrito de asada, burrito de Carnitas and quesadilla de Carnitas are the items we ordered and to be honest they weren't bad. Not the best not great but good. The biggest turn off wasn't the burrito in itself but the inflated price of $10.50 I'll gladly pay that price for a burrito that's worth it but the undersized little guy just wasn't worth it. Maybe I'm missing something maybe the asada was Kobe beef and the Carnitas were Spaniard raised swine. 

I'll save you the headache and suggest you go next door to the Salvadoran pupusa joint that serves up crazy good cheese pupusas.
author: Tino H.

description:
It's been awhile since I've been on the west coast and may have forgotten what a good burrito tastes like but dang! These were amazing. Pico, crema, carne asada, fresh guac and refried beans= yum. No orange cheese or lettuce in sight. 

The quesadilla was bland and couldn't really be salvaged either with the salsa verde so I don't recommend those. I'll try the pupsas next door instead.
author: Kat S.

description: Very popular local Mexican spot. I ordered a burrito and enjoyed it, but it's definitely not the best I've ever had. The flavor was authentic and the ingredients were legit, so I can tell why it was popular.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Supposedly the "best burrito" in all of America - which is surprising cause I wouldn't expect it in SF. But walking through the mission, its just small eateries of Mexican food. La Taqueria looks quite similar to the other ones on the street, except when you walk in, it's quite packed and there are fancy screens to show the menu (different..?).

I got the super carnitas burrito which came out to be almost 10 dollars with tax - pretty good deal with everything that's included - guac, sour cream, cheese. I wasn't blown away by the burrito in general - perhaps my expectations were too high. However, the meat was superb - so flavorful and juicy (which made the burrito slightly "wetter"). The green salsa on the table was SO GOOD though - I like wanted to steal a bottle for myself. The burrito was filling but not like "I'm so full, I'm going to die" (which is good cause that usually happens to me). 

Definitely worth a visit since it's a "famous" place.
author: Irene H.

description:
So, so delicious.

I'm a total burrito noob (full disclosure), having just moved out here from the East Coast and having little prior experience beyond Chipotle (which I hate).  Furthermore, I don't love the general concept of burritos, as I don't like food filled with rice.  However, when I heard that this place has won all kinds of "best burrito" accolades AND doesn't put rice in it's burritos, I was sold.  I had to try it.

I stopped by at around 8pm on a Tuesday night and was able to order, get my food, and sit down to eat in about 3 minutes despite the place being packed - wow!  This burrito is the dankest of the dank.  Again, I don't know a ton about burritos but I just can't imagine that I'll find one I like more than this.

It's really solid and tightly wrapped and is full of the best ingredients.  It may not be the biggest burrito ever, but it's not full of lame filler either.  It's like getting a small but high-end bouquet of all lush flowers versus getting a huge grocery store bouquet full of baby's breath...  

The flavors are awesome.  I did the carnitas super burrito and there was so much meat, pinto beans, guacamole, salsa, cheese, and who even knows what else.  I loved it.  I also added some of the spicy green sauce they have on the table to every bite and that was ah-mazing.  Perfectly spicy and a little smoky.

I think the size of this burrito is totally sufficient and I was actually able to have it for dinner and lunch the next day because it was really big, at least for me.

The only downside is the cash only thing.  I just wish that would be against the law...
author: Tay H.

description: Not the worst but not the best burritos. Over priced. $31 for two burritos and two aguas frescas.  Not worth the hype and definitely not worth me coming back. Agua de horchata was too sweet and customer service is mediocre.
author: KD C.

description: Burritos super style- worth the wait. And it WILL be a wait so don't go with someone you don't enjoy talking to. The line moves fast and staff members are totally on their game. Tables move quickly so don't worry if you don't see one available when you arrive. If you like things a little crispy, ask them to grill your burrito.
author: Chris S.

description:
I have family who right by here so I started coming when I was really young. I think it was the first place I tried horchata. It hasn't changed that much apart from the long lines and the stickers at the front of the door. You can avoid lines by planning well and avoiding peak weekend hours.

The regular carnitas burrito is always the best. I'm not the biggest fan of pork but I 100% approve of the flavor and juiciness of theirs. It's kept simple with only meat, beans and pico de gallo. Thinking about it makes me hungry ahh
author: Hana S.

description: Rode Bart over for a Father's Day treat only to find out its CASH ONLY.   Have to find someplace else for today (didn't bring ATM card - Chase bank I'd across the street if you have your debit card). Good excuse for us to come back another time and remember bring cash.
author: Deborah L.

description:
Definitely disappointed by the chicken burrito. No flavor to the chicken- wasn't seasoned at all and seemed slightly undercooked. The tortilla shell was soggy at first bite, almost raw tasting. There was a long line so maybe they had a hard time keeping up with grilling the burritos, but if you are already waiting 40 minutes, what's 5 more. 

My husband had the carne Asada and that was very  good, well seasoned and good temperature. 

Pro tip: call ahead, they put you in line as soon as they take your order so your wait probably won't be more than 25 minutes. Not worth $25 for 2 burritos, I would personally go back to chipotle before I go back here.
author: Kate O.

description: Best tacos ever!!!  Visit at an off-peak time, or you will stand in line.  This is the first place I visit when I come to town! Cash only -- go next door to dianda's for a napoleon after!
author: Lisa L.

description: Four years later and La Taqueria is still my favourite burrito place in San Francisco. I always get the carne asada burrito with everything. The chips are fresh and so is the salsa. Love!
author: Jiwon K.

description:
Lines out the door all evening long on a Sunday. 

Excellent tacos!!! 

Price is high but food is well proportioned. 

Seating is extremely limited.
author: Ish A.

description:
Overall: Cheap, easy, amazing Mexican street burritos and tacos. The reputation did not disappoint!

The good: Cheap, nothing over 10 dollars. The burrito that I had was fantastic, something I imagine just like in Mexico. Tacos are good sized as well. The sauce is the bomb, and everything is fast and fresh. 

The bad: Limited seating, don't expect a comfortable seat (or any) during prime time. Cash only, which could sway some. Small space

Atmosphere: 7/10
Service: 7/10
Food: 9/10
author: Kyle D.

description: Super tacos are HUGE and so good the burritos are not as big as the other taquerias near by but the flavor is pretty damn good I definitely recommend this spot to anyone looking to have a great fresh tasting burrito or taco really good spot, and there aguas (fresh fruit juices) are really good and fresh also the melon and pineapple ones are my favorite.
author: Claudia R.

description: Excellent spot in a dodgy part of town but well worth the BART ride out of immediate downtown SF. I didn't quite understand how ordering worked when I got there because there were so many people standing and sitting in no straight order. Eventually got it, you will too. Just observe! I got the Carnitas Burrito (SUPER, not regular) and was very impressed. Very delicious and the pork was outstanding, grilled to perfection! I only give it 4/5 stars because I wasn't thrilled with the seating situation. Would be a much better use of space to do a standing bar along the back wall rather than small two seaters. Also the salsa containers at each table were nearly empty. Once I found one that was full, I figured out why they were empty - AMAZING.
author: Edwin R.

description: Really solid burrito here. What stood out was the flavor in the meat and beans - so good even without that yummy green sauce that they have on the tables. I didn't miss the rice at all and enjoyed the layer of avocado in the super burrito. Dorado style is a must have, although don't expect the tortilla to stay crispy from the grilling because the filling is super juicy.
author: Cathy S.

description: Did not disappoint. They only take cash but the food is really good. Generous portions. Had a chicken burrito and taco topped with everything and it was delicious!!
author: Eva B.

description: This place truly IS the best Taqueria in the Bay Area! Line was outside when I came in and all the tables were all taken. I ended up getting my order to go. Line moves pretty fast though. I ordered 2 super tacos with carne asada were pretty good. Pretty pricey for tacos but well worth it. I will def be coming back. Maybe to try the burritos.
author: Melissa S.

description: Burritos taste amazing, but way too overpriced for the small burritos you get. Also it is ridiculous that they do not take credit card. I've been in the area many times wanting a good burrito, but have had to go somewhere else because I don't normally carry cash.
author: Leslie K.

description: Great food, but a little overrated for the price and the line. I'd recommend going in off-peak hours and not expecting a seat. Try the carne asada super tacos Dorado-style (crispy). If you like extra spice, ask for a side of chiles.
author: Mary K.

description:
Their entrance seems to always be busy with people. Inside it is pretty small, crowded, and loud. In San Francisco that's pretty common for small places, but hey that's just the city. The line went around and toward the outside, they do an okay job of managing it and taking your order before you pay. 
Sitting there isn't always possible since it gets full. I managed to get a table sitting next to some college kids and across from a friendly older couple.
