Taking a step back from my crushed burrito loving soul, I will say the few ingredients I DID receive were well prepared. I didn't LOVE the carne asada, although I could tell it was of high quality, and did not care for the beans, but the grilled dorado tortilla was fantastic. Also the free quesadilla was ridiculously good.

I will definitely give La Taqueria another try, albeit with a little caution and more backbone. From now on, I vow to stand up for my burrito rights.
author: Rachel L.

description:
So so good! They are always super busy with really long lines. (Expect a little wait) 
 Every time I'm in SF I HAVE to go here and get my taco fix on!! 

I always get the soft/crunchy taco.. They're really messy, however oh so delicious...so be prepared. Lol 

They also have really amazing soft drinks made from real fruit juice!! Such as strawberry, cantaloupe, watermelon.. And more (I can't recall the fruits) I had the strawberry and my boyfriend had cantaloupe they're both amazing and so refreshing!! Writing this out I'm getting really thirsty! Ha! 

They Also have beer for purchase! 
I love love love coming here and I often crave it at home in Seattle!! 
I'll definitely be back in January when I go back to SF!!
author: Gabrielle M.

description:
Came here last Thursday with my friends cuz the photos of there grilled Burrito's look good..
We ordered our food .. it was very expensive about 12.00 after tax. Per Burrito. When we got our food it didn't look anything like the pictures.  I went up to the handsome man name Jesus.. asked him why my burrito wasn't grilled...he said you have to ask for it grilled... WHAT ?!  So I asked him to grill it.. he said No.. you already touch it ! WHAT ?! No I didn't I only unwrapped it a little and saw it was not grilled...Jesus said I'll make you a new one but you have to pay for it!  WHAT?! THAT'S JUST CRAZY   Very Expensive Very Bad service. My friends ate there Burrito and said it was nothing special, too expensive .  I got my money back from Jesus and went a few doors down to EL Farlitos Were they grill all there Burritos.. you don't need to ask them .. oh yeah El Farlitos was also cheaper and they give complementary chips and salsa bar.
My Burrito from El Farlitos was delicious
author: d d.

description: Best Taqueria in SF. Always recently grilled, flavorful asada. If there is no line, always a good bite of food.
author: John R.

description: Eh, this place isn't worth the hype. We came here because we heard that had life changing quality of food but after eating here, I don't agree with that. It is very congested in the restaurant and you will not find parking easily. We decided to order our food for to-go. I ordered a super burrito with steak and a chicken taco. First, when a Mexican restaurant does not have re-fried beans, it bums me out, so that was the first thing I was disappointed in. Second, when I opened up the food, it was very sloppy and made the food not look as pealing.The first thing I noticed was there was no rice in the burrito and after taking the first bite it was dripping leaving the tortilla very soggy and hard to eat. Also for how much they charge they give VERY little, the quantity is small. The chicken taco was a huge disappointment. It was a small piece of non marinated chicken on soggy tortilla with a couple of pinto beans sprawled around. Waste of money. Seriously would not make the time, effort or spend money at this place. You're better off going to Chipotle.
author: Jenn M.

description:
My friends and I came here before a concert in Oakland.  We were super hungry and heard about this place from another friend. 

The line was pretty long but we got the food relatively fast. Their carne asada burrito (plus guac) was bomb. The only thing was that it's cash only and I forgot to bring some. 
I'd definitely come back!
author: Brit C.

description:
The best mission-style burritos and tacos in San Francisco.  La Taqueria consistently makes every list of top places to dine in the city and was recently named one of the essential 38 San Francisco restaurants.  The place is tiny so time your visit outside of peaking lunch and dinner hours or you might be in for a wait.

My order is always a spicy, carne asada burrito with guacamole...  Be warned, you won't be able to go back to Chipotle after a burrito here...
author: Lance W.

description:
Delicious! The ingredients come together perfectly and it is soggy in the right way. We were almost turned off by the line and the crowd, but it actually moved quite quickly and all 8 of us were able to find a seat by the time our food came. Indoor and outdoor seating and doesn't feel cramped!

I gave 4 stars instead of 5 because the prices are so expensive - I ended up paying $12 for a burrito with guacamole. Delicious but you can get similar quality for almost half the price elsewhere.
author: Brooke R.

description:
After moving to the city, I was recommended the burritos at La Taqueria so many times that eventually I HAD to go for myself to see what the hype was about. 

If you decide to come, be prepared for the long line. I got here around 6pm on a Friday and had to wait about 20 minutes to get to the front of the line. The place is quite crowded -- it'll be difficult to find a table, so have one of your friends scope out somewhere to sit while you wait in line, or take it to-go. 

I ordered a carne asada burrito: the meat was tender and flavorful, and the whole burrito itself was so juicy (not the word I'd use to typically describe a burrito)! I was actually pretty disappointed in the size of the burrito, though -- probably because they have some kind of no-rice policy. If you tend to eat a lot, you might want to "supersize" your burrito. 

My verdict: Best in the country? Nah, but it's definitely worth a try. If you come at the right time, the wait isn't ridiculously long... And you can brag to all your friends that you ate FiveThirtyEight's "America's Best Burrito"!
author: Christine L.

description: Extremely overhyped and overpriced cash-only tacqueria producing sloppy burritos of disappointing size.
author: Nick A.

description:
This place is overrated and over priced! Born and raised in the mission this is NOT the best burrito in town!

The beans are soooooo bland...is it too much to ask for the chef to throw an onion, garlic, & salt into the pot???? My abuela would be ashamed!

The boiled chicken was flavorless too! 

The pico de gallo (salsa) needed a hit of acid, salt, & a jalapeño. (Not super spicy jalapeño but the bright, crunchy, not too much heat kind...yes, they exist)

Overall this was the most boringest, blandest burrito I have ever eaten in my life!

Let's talk about price. Hey people...$7 dollars for a small, flavorless burrito is a rip.

The tacos dorados were good. Typically anything fried is good especially when it's a fried tortilla. Once stuffed with meat & topped with too much goop...how could you go wrong. Oh & $4 bucks for a taco is a rip...if you think this is cheap, you obviously have not eaten at any other taqueria!

Long story short...this place sucks
author: ada l.

description:
Get the vegetarian tacos if you want something filling but mild. ($2.50 each, but you'll want two.) The service is conveniently fast - no time for dressed up enchiladas here. They do traditional tacos, quesadillas, and burritos. Lots of aguas frescas and horchata. Their menu prices range from super affordable to affordable which is great for the family. 

Their meat and beans are bland by some people's standards (including mine), but it's really good nonetheless. Mexican food is diverse and so I can understand that when everyone comes in with different expectations, some will be disappointed. And it'd be nice if La Taqueria wasn't cash only. But I'll still be going back!
author: Chris Z.

description: If you want the most authentic Mexican food AND experience, you must try La Taqueria located in the Mission District in San Francisco. You can't go wrong when ordering, but I recommend the tacos as the best thing on the menu! Seating is limited (and competitive) so be prepared! Also note this is a cash only restaurant.
author: Annie W.

description: Once again, the hype lived up to the food. This was hands down the best burrito I've ever had. Im sure youve heard of the tip but get it el dorado style. Fried a little on the grill and keeps all the ingredients in better. Love this burrito!
author: Angel R.

description:
What kind of burrito doesn't have rice?! 

My boyfriend and I came here on a Friday night and it was probably the most packed I've ever seen a Mexican establishment.. ever. Seriously, the place literally had 30 people in line, so my boyfriend and I thought that it *had* to be good! After waiting about 15-20 minutes, we ordered the carne asada super burrito, a carnitas super burrito with a mango agua and it took maybe 10 minutes for our numbers to be called out. Since the prices were more expensive, I thought that naturally, the burritos would be bigger than most. Unfortunately, I was proven wrong when I saw burritos maybe a hand size and a half, which was disappointing! 

Despite the size, I thought the burrito was pretty good, but soon realized that it was missing something. After reading reviews, I now know that they don't add rice in their burritos. The horror! Also, the menu can be quite confusing since they add when you subtract some ingredients. I believe they charge extra if you don't want beans in your burrito, which doesn't make sense at all? I'd also like to mention the chips and salsa also cost money if you're into that. My boyfriend was actually surprised that I didn't have a basket of chips in my hand since he likes to try every Taqueria's chips. At that point, I looked at the line and said "sorry honey, not today"

La Taqueria has been on a couple of food blogs and even dubbed as "one of the best burritos in SF" It was good once, but I think there are better locations to get your burrito craving satisfied at a much cheaper price, too!
author: Joyce E.

description: Absolutely amazing, and I loved the crispy carnitas tacos.  The line was incredibly long and never ending, but it moved quickly.  And totally worth the wait.
author: Joanna S.

description:
I've been going to La Taqueria for years and have always enjoyed their delicious food, both tacos and burritos.  One of things that has always set La Taqueria apart from other places has been the quality of the meat.  That is, until yesterday.  This is the second time I've been since they were named best burrito place in San Francisco.  It's been a zoo both times, with the line snaking around the inside of the restaurant.  

Yesterday I ordered a chicken burrito to go.  When I got home I wanted to cut the burrito in half - but the knife wouldn't cut it - there was a chicken thigh bone in the middle.  Okay, kind of gross, but I'm still going to eat the burrito.  So I'm munching on the half of the burrito when I hit another bone (this time half a wishbone).  Uh, now I've had enough.  No more chicken from La Taqueria for this kid.  

I think their new popularity and higher volume has led to a decline in quality, which is too bad.  I'll likely still go back, but I'll stick to carnitas and carne asada from now on.
author: Tom D.

description:
Really busy spot right at noon but the employees here are machine like plowing through orders  relentlessly. Grab a seat outside by the window and watch them do their work.  

Huge portion size for the price. However, they get you on the extra, ie don't order cheese, sour cream or avocado. I spent $3.60 on a couple dollops of guac that were not needed.

The tacos themselves are outstanding, huge size, flavor, and great moist meat. I had a carnitas, chorizo, and chicken. All were recommends.

This is a must stop, despite a hefty price for tacos.
author: Trekforbeer B.

description: If you're going go with the simple, classic name like "la taqueria" for your establishment, you better know tacos. 2 of asada and one of carnitas for me. With the simple toppings of onion, cilantro, & salsa verde, good to go. A bit pricey but the portions back that up. Washed it down with an agua Fresca of melon and I was set to hit Mission and walk it off.  Would have given 5 stars, but the carnitas were a little dry for me.
author: O M.

description: Delicious. Cheese on crispy tortilla,  tender pork,  guacamole,  Pico de gallo, cream fresca, whole beans. .only reason not a 5 is because of the fat left on the pork and the price! $6.40 for a taco. Oh forgot. This is San francisco and not manteca!
author: ruth f.

description:
Look, I know everyone LOVES this place. Here are my issues. 
1. No Al Pastor. I love to order Al Pastor (marinated pork) because each taqueria makes their own so it is unique to the taqueria. I ordered carnitas. 
2. No black beans. Seriously?! I am sure some burrito purists would say pinto beans are the benchmark for burritos, but I don't subscribe to that. Black beans taste better, simple as that.
3. The burrito was "loosely wrapped". When I consumed the burrito it was an absolute mess. Tons of liquid pouring out dripping all over the place. This might be a good thing to some people, but not for me. 

If you are in the area I would suggest El Farrolito just down Mission. They have everything you could want including a line to wait in!
author: Alex C.

description: This is my favorite place for tacos and burritos in SF, (I'm Mexican), absolutely worth the line. I've met Don Miguel (the owner) and he is a sweetheart, always with a smile on his face. I've taken an Uber from the Marina just to get a burrito, they are that good!
author: ana g.

description:
Have you ever had a quesadilla and thought..."dang I bet this fried tortilla skin would taste great as a burrito"

Well..look no further!

Here at La Tequeria you can order a fantastic carne Asada burrito (get the super) and get it with FRIED tortilla. Game changer. 

Heads up, it's always crowded. Place is relatively clean, not great for large groups!
author: Sean S.

description: This place is wildy over-hyped, somewhat overpriced, and ridiculously overrated. The food is good enough, but the gushing reviews claiming that La Taqueria has the best burritos in the bay area (or in America? Seriously?) are absolute nonsense. Their burritos are good, but they're not even the best burritos within a five-minute walk in the Mission, much less the entire neighborhood. There's nothing unique enough about this place to make it deserve half of the attention it gets. All the over-the-top (and obviously paid for by the business) marketing hype means there's usually a very long wait to get tacos and burritos that are good, but not really above average for the Mission. It's become a super-popular hotspot for tourists and trendsters, but unless you're dying to spend an extra 20 minutes in line with either of those types to get a $6 taco, you can get better Mexican food for less money by walking a few minutes in any direction.
author: Jose P.

description: Awesome tacos. My favorite in the Mission. (Burritos are OK, but seriously, it's called La Taqueria, get their tacos.)
author: Mike S.

description: One of the few places that lives up to the hype. Amazing. Every ingredient is amazing. Including the salsa on the table.
author: Adam W.

description: We were hungry for Mexican food this afternoon and thank heavens, we decided on La Taqueria.  We walked and BARTed across town and came home with the best burritos one could find anywhere.  Absolutely delicious!
author: Beryl V.

description:
Meh.... Don't see what the hooplah's all about.  I was raised on Gordo's so a burrito without rice is something else. It was *tasty*, don't get me wrong, but for the price and the noise and the jerk who wandered in of the street to hassle the seated and otherwise content customers... He was escorted out after we told one of the staff..... But we shouldn't have had to point him out at all....

Oh, wait.... The jerk just came back to mess with me... Did he follow me all the way out here to BART?

Is this supposed to be ambiance or something?

Anyway the food was tasty but nothing to write home about.  There are other places that hold more sway than whatever's going on here.  I'm glad the place has a healthy clientele as the staff is quick, personable and generous with both portions and hospitality....they just don't strike the notes with me that seem to have rung true with so many others......
author: E G.

description:
I know as a tourist my review will never quite match up with what a local would say, but for all the other tourists out there...

I really enjoyed a quick lunch at La Taqueria. I was full for less than $10, ate some authentic (to my estimation) Mexican food, and got to experience a San Fran neighborhood with a bit of a different vibe. 

And for what it's worth, this place won Nate Silver's burrito bracket. And that guy is a genius, so...

Cash only.
author: Danielle G.

description:
What's the first things that come to mind when thinking of a burrito?  Maybe an affordable, satisfying heavy carbed and meat filled comfort-food.  A combination of fresh ingredients that mix perfectly together.

Well what La Taqueria serves as a burrito doesn't meet any of the expectations mentioned above but maybe freshness.  In fact I left slightly offended by what they tried to serve me. La Taqueria totally struck out in my book, it's the flipping Jose Canseco of burrito joints.

Strike one: its hella expensive.  And I'm just gonna say it because this is the truth, it's a hipster Taqueria.   I expect to see at least one Latino representative to patronize any Taqueria I go to in the mission, but no, if you look at the clientele you would think the zip code here is 90210.

Strike Two:  El Burrito is hella small. Or should I say "pequeño!"  I finished it in 8 bites.  Thats right ladies and gentleman, I'm not Joey Chestnut but watching me eat this burrito, you guys would have sent me on the next flight to Coney Island next 4th of July.  I left hungry and a little annoyed.  

Strike Three:  the taste was average.  I paid for an over - priced,  small burrito.   At least they could of blew me away with the flavors of the ingredients but no.  It was mediocre in that category as well.  As T.I. would sing: 

I mess with bad burritos.
I don't want no mediocre
I don't want no mediocre
I don't want no mediocre
No
Bad burritos only!

NEED A BEAT?  Here you go:   Watch "T.I feat. Iggy Azalea - No Mediocre (Clean) (Lege..." on YouTube
T.I feat. Iggy Azalea - No Mediocre (Clean) (Lege...: http://youtu.be/ktLUar0e_xM
author: Michael L.

description: Amazing burrito cooked to perfection. Fresh delicious and worth the trip. Get it cooked derado style.
author: David M.

description:
Don't understand the hype surrounding this. The burrito was incredibly wet and had a slightly rubbery consistency. Salsa was pico de gallo that was clearly made days in advance (soggy and mushy). Beans lacked any true seasoning. Overall a disappointment. As a vegetarian, I expect more. 

One can easily do better than La Taqueria. An overall lack of flavor and a disappointing constancy of the burrito made for a poor experience.
author: Ben S.

description: This is one delicious carne asada taco.  It's all I ever get here because I love them so much.  The carne asada is perfectly seasoned, and as fresh as can be each & every time I visit.  The salsa is fabulous, basic the way it should be and perfectly complements the meat.  Next time, I am trying a burrito, they looked fantastic.  This isn't a place to sit down and yap for hours.  This is a place to sit down, enjoy every bite, and split so that the next people can sit down and enjoy.  And I don't mind.  It's small, it's authentic, and I love it.  And to top it all off, it is a GREAT VALUE.  No one stuffs their tacos with as much meat as La Taqueria.  Period.
author: Chris H.

description:
My second time here and I am very pleased. First time I had a super burrito with carnitas and this time I had a super quesadilla with carnitas and I can say their carnitas recipe is delicious. Also as a drink everytime I always measure a place by it's Horchata recipe, which is great as usual.

Meal: 5 stars
Ambiance: 5 stars
Service: 5 stars

I recommend this place.

-Ravi G.
author: Ravi G.

description:
After reading an article that claimed La Taqueria served the BEST BURRITO EVER, I had to give this place a shot. It's hard to give a verdict, bc I didn't eat a burrito... but that seems to be a farfetched claim. 

I will say, this place beats El Faro, by far. The dorado (soft shell and hard shell) taco was good for extra crunch and texture, but I prefer the plain soft tortilla taco. The carne asada was tender and juicy. The carnitas, however, was not my personal favorite, but I only selected that given al pastor was not an option. The chips and salsa were a good addition. 

So far, this is one of the better Mexican joints in the city. Probably even more delicious late-night. But it's no LA Mexican food.
author: Suji C.

description:
SO of course I wanted to go here because it was given the #1 burrito award but honestly.. 

I won't come back..  It was $30 bucks for two burritos and a taco supreme and a drink.  $30. 

I would much rather go to a place where I didn't have to wait so long in line where there was room to sit and where the food was good. 

I've had far better burritos in the mission.  I wouldn't recommend coming here.  Pick another place on Mission.
author: Jennifer F.

description: The best beef burrito I've ever had. The meat especially was exceptionally good.
author: Umer M.

description:
Growing up in the city,  hubby and I have tasted lots of taquerias.  This place is overhyped. Disappointing.  
Ordered regular tacos with carnitas.  I believe a way to taste tacos is without all the other stuff.  Hubby ordered super burritos carne asada.  
Tacos are ok.  Why it comes with beans I don't know why.  Meat lacked flavor.  I prefer Taqueria Vallarta,  that reminds me of Mexico. 
Burritos were small and hubby was ok that it didn't come with rice.  Meat was dry and lacked flavor.  Preferred El farolito,  guadalajara in Onondaga or Vallarta.  
We both agreed it needed the grease that those other taquerias have.  That's where the flavor is.  We debated if we would come back to give it another try.  Maybe.  But I miss my grease.
author: Claire J.

description:
James Beard -Congratulations! No one deserves it more. One of my fondest memories of SF is getting off the plane after a year abroad and having my brilliant friends take me directly to La Taq. I honestly used to ask my Paris visitors to bring non-vegetarian refried beans (& conditioner, but that another story...) because the horror of Tex-Mex could no longer be endured. (*Sidenote:* The only worse thing is French Chinese food.)

All burritos and tacos in my life are measured by La Taq. One, my friends, only one, (Nick's) can compare in SF at least, and that's only for tacos. And yes, LA tacos are 1.clearly superior and 2. frankly more exciting perhaps due to their size and variety of unknown to gringos meats, but SF has the best burritos fo' sho and I'm from San Diego. Speaking of which, because I can hardly not mention it; I don't know what clown thought adding fries would make SD's rice burritos into California burritos but I think it's a load...

However, as for beautiful glorious La Taq after 20 years I know better than to try and sit. Call ahead only now.

Also, rice is for suckers.
author: Smelly S.

description: Believe the hype. La Taqueria exceeded my expectations and then some. Order anything you get "super" - it adds sour cream, cheese, and avocado. I had the carne asada super burrito and I never wanted it to end.
author: Donna Q.

description:
The owner is really friendly, "OK boss!" when you let him know how you want your burrito cooked.  Hubby wanted to come re-try the burrito again even 'tho we've been here over the years.  Since winning the nation's best burrito award, the place was flooded with people and the TV folks were there interviewing customers.
We waited in line for a total of 45 mins before we got our to go order and could go home. 

We tried the chicken and carnitas burrito, "Dorado style".  It's not a big deal to pan fry the burrito until the tortilla is a little crisp, they do that with quesadillas.  The burrito is "good" according to Hubby. I thought it was OK but give me a Gordo burrito any day. I think the meat flavor is better at Gordo's but they are stingier with the guacamole and sour cream.  La Taqueria does not offer grilled chicken, only boiled.
Also tried the lengua taco and it was bland and lacked flavor.  

A lot of foodies who've never been there before were waiting in line after reading the front page newspaper announcement about the burrito winning the prize.  Such hype is always good for business but it's all a matter of taste.
author: Ry T.

description:
The best tacos in all of San Francisco! I love the super tacos loaded with beans, cheese your choice of meat and pico de gallo. This place has great food there chips and salsa are delicious and come covered in pico when served the Agua de horchata is perfect combination of sweet and refreshing. I come here at least twice a month from the east bay. Please make sure to try the house salsa its green typically on every table in a squeeze bottle you'll regret no tasting it. 
Ya it's that good!
author: Based O.

description:
This review is for tacos only - the carne asada super taco is expensive but super filling. I thought the chicken taco was going to be pollo asada but it was actually larger chunks of chicken which was a bit disappointing. Definitely will be coming back to see what the burrito hype is all about.

Also, the green sauce is very spicy so watch out!
author: Amy Y.

description: Most Known Taqueria in SF. Been eating here for 20+ years. In the past couple of years price has increased and its hard to get a seat, good for them. Everything is great on the menu. Burritos are super tasty and filled. Super Lengua taco and super chicken burrito are my favorits. Cash only
author: dee s.

description: Late post:  I think everyone hyped this place way too much.  Sure the tacos were good, but I think it's over priced.  $6+ for a supreme taco?  You get sour creme and guacamole, they just give you healing soon of it.  Not too appealing, IMO, but apparently everyone likes it.  We came at a busy time, so there was a line and we had to hunt our seats.  Instead of a monitor for menu signage, it couldn't been a board because it was so small to see!  Waste of a monitor.  It was my first time there, so I was trying to figure it what I want.  While in the line, the staff came up to us and asked what we want...kind of ordering ahead of time like In n Out.  I felt a little rushed because I didn't know what I want.  Nonetheless we ordered and found a seat.  Now this is why I gave it a one star - I found a piece of hair in my taco!!!  It definitely gross me out.  For a place with alllllll these reviews and so many stars, it should not have hair AT ALL.  I know it's a taco place blah blah blah, but still.  I didn't say anything because I knew not much would've Happened, get me another taco?  No thanks.  As long as my friend enjoyed it, he's the one who wanted tacos.  Found the most talked about place and of course, it disappointed me.  :(.  Go if you're taco fan.
author: Lisa V.

description: Amazing Tacos and burritos! My favorite is ordering a burrito el Dorado style, then they grill it on all sides for you! It's a thrill just to watch them work. This place is always crowded and busy but they churn out the food pretty quickly so the wait is actually surprisingly short. Love the house salsa verde that they have on all the tables too.
author: Heidi K.

description: Love the tacos dorados de carne asada!! Best tacos in the Mission!
author: Alejandra S.

description:
There was some online blog that rated this the best burrito in the country, which I'd have to agree the food was quite tasty. In fact, that's the only thing that saved it from getting a one star review. 

See, the problem is that place has gotten so much attention recently that they have huge crowds. I'm talking line all the way around the store and out the building to order. Now that's not inherently a bad thing since you know the food will be fresh. However, they haven't really gotten the hang of dealing with lots of people yet. Specifically dining room management. There are a limited number of tables and seats that is probably JUST enough to handle the amount of customers they can cook for at any given point in time. The problem is, customers don't trust the turn and have someone in their party squat a table as soon as they enter the joint. Which means that customer like me who waited in line with my party have nowhere to sit when our food is actually ready. Seriously? About a 3rd of the tables were taken up by people just sitting there waiting. We ended up having to eat our burritos standing next to the trash can which was quite unpleasant. 

The business needs to recognize this problem and either put up signs to wait for your food before sitting down, and/or train the dining room attendants who are clearing and wiping the tables to make sure customers who already have their food have a place to sit above those who have not even ordered yet. 

There is a burrito joint I go to in NYC all the time that has this policy down to a rhythm and I've always found a table there when my food was ready. This place needs to take a lesson from them. 

Gotta trust in the turn!
author: Mike W.

description: I've been to better taquerias in the area.  This review is in comparison to the other taquerias.  The food wasn't that good, wasn't a lot, and a little over priced for what you get.
author: Cory F.

description:
Just read http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/san-francisco-burritos-really-are-better/ and you'll know that you have to head down here *immediately* for their carnitos burrito.

That's exactly what I did.  The burrito in question ($8.95 for a "super") was delicious.  As fivethirtyeight tells us, it was technically perfect.  On the other hand: (1) it was extremely salty; (2) it was on the small side; (3) it got ordered only after a very long wait in line.  We figured that a 1PM arrival would allow us to miss the lunchtime rush, but we were off by about 45 minutes.  (When we walked out, there were plenty of empty seats.)

I'd come again, but maybe only around 2PM on a weekday.  Meanwhile there's still Taqueria Cancún and El Castillito to try!
author: Kenneth R.

description: Certainly not the world's best, but not the worst.  San Fran overpriced average eats.  Got a super carnitas burrito, dorado carne asada taco, and a water for $17, ouch.  Burrito is undersized, thank goodness they lightly salt the underseasoned basic carnitas.  Taco was very satisfying, I like the crispy tortilla shell inside the soft tortilla.  All said and done, I don't plan to return.
author: Troy T.

description:
It has been said that a burrito without cheese is like a day without sun. Well, okay, there is cheese in the burritos at La Taq, but some people have preferences for their morsels of Mexi-Cali goodness, and don't want beans in their burritos. Let's just say you don't want beans, there's an actual upcharge of $1.20 to make the burrito without beans. And you like guacamole? Think again, folks. It's an additional $1.30 for a measly squirt. 

So, okay, sometimes you just have to bend over and take it, you're already there for goodness sake. But an extra charge for chips and salsa as well? What is this, the Financial District?? The Mission is certainly in full gentrification force when you are charged over $10 for a single burrito.

La Taq boasts "Best Tacos and Burritos in the World", which is giving me the thought that they have a Kanye West complex. Maybe all that media hype (7x7 mag / Food Network exposure) has them thinking it's effective to raise their prices and be complete dicks to their (now former) customer base. 

I must have been elated by the extra jalepenos in my burrito, and the fact that it was bought for me and brought to me at my house when I wrote my first review last year. I just can't hang with them prices, especially not for mediocre Mexican IN THE MISSION.
author: Crystal C.

description: This place is pretty good! I like coming here late night with friends for some nachos to share. Service is fast. It can get crowded at times and difficult to find seating, but that's how a lot of these joints are like in SF, so I don't mind it. Price is very, very fair!
author: Rebecca J.

description: Super good, super fresh, and super busy. Everything you would want and expect from a taqueria located in the mission.
author: Susan A.

description: Made a mistake  in order and manager took care of mistake . Great service but always crowded, so make time like 30 minutes. Chicken burrito you get a whole chicken breast in instead of shredded chicken which are usually thigh meat at other places. Guacamole  is freshly made and is great.
author: Li L.

description:
went here for the first time last month. don't understand what all the hype is about. the food is good, but seriously overhyped.

and $12 for a burrito? only in SFO...
author: H M.

description: I feel like my neighbors dis this place because it's gotten so popular.  It's more crowded and more expensive these days, but they deserve it.  The tacos are so good.
author: Lukas B.

description:
This place is awesome. Authentic Mexican food, Great customer service! Try the SUPER crispy tacos, first shell fried crisp with cheese on it wrapped in a second softer shell, hella good with their green sauce. WOWzers.

On the expensive side but since I'm not from SF, it's kinda worth it!
author: Sam Q.

description: Favorite of all time!!   Sooo good! Quality is always great!! No one compares. (Besides my mom and grandma)
author: Jovanna A.

description: Had the "super" carne dorido style. Good burrito goes down like water. It could use more filling for 12 bucks. With so many burrito spots in the mission im sure you can find a better overall value for the amount you pay and the amount you get without having to sacrifice great taste.
author: Sugi s.

description: Best Mexican Restaurant on Mission!! I would suggest the Super Taco- carnitas s/ Guac & Chips And Salsa w/ Guac!!
author: Jules C.

description:
Awesome staff! they helped me with an order of 18 Burritos, 2 Tacos and a quesadilla - nailed it! and very quickly too, The line moves at a decent pace and they are friendly.
The burritos Probably the best in that area, can't give it the national title though. The hype did disappoint some of my friends, but no burrito was complained about or left un-eaten.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Stopped in for a quick bite with the family. Took as assortment of tacos and quesedillas aas well as the nachos. All very fresh and the guac was excellent. Busy place though so you have to be on the lookout for a seat. Cash only.
author: Charles W.

description: One of my favorite taquerias in the city. Tacos dorado is the way to go. This place is bitter sweet for me because growing up in the city the area has changed drastically. the mission has changed and the vibe is very different but this restaurant is on point and clearly the crowd that eats here knows about this place because of Yelp. Nonetheless this place deserves the 5 star rating and I'll keep coming
author: Justin W.

description:
La Taqueria burritos are definitely worth the wait. 

The mood at La Taqueria is decidedly upbeat thanks to it brightly lit dining area with ubiquitous, loud mariachi music. The autentico atmosphere is furthered by the brick floor and big Mexican mural on the wall. Communal tables with benches abound and there are a few two-tops with stools with braided leather seats. 

As at all real burrito joints, La Taqueria is no-frills, counter service, and cash only. The line can get long at peak hours, but it moves quickly as the cashiers are quite adept at capturing orders, even from late night drunks slurring their words. 

A regular burrito ($6.75) allows your choice of meat (carne asada, carnitas, chorizo, pollo, cabeza, and lengua), refried or pinto beans, and fresh salsa. Super ($8.95) adds sour cream, cheese, and avocado. 

Decidedly more diminutive than its counterpart at El Farolito, the contents of the carne asada super burrito were a little runny. Drips aside, the burrito was quite flavorful with big chunks of steak. Ingredients were well distributed, providing a good mix in each bite. A large side of chips and salsa ($1.30) is sufficient for at least two people. However, there is no salsa bar to complement the chips. 

The regular array of drinks is available: your choices include aguas frescas ($2.50/$3.00) and sodas ($1.30/$1.70), as well as domestic ($3.00) and Mexican ($4.00) beers. 

All in all, La Taqueria lives up to its tag line: "The best tacos and burritos in the world."
author: CJ G.

description: The line is the size of a railroad. I don't understand what the hoopla is. My friend wanted me to try a crispy taco, so I had beef. It was good, but not amazing. I'd come back again to try more items like burritos. Really the long line only works against this place to me.
author: Denise C.

description:
Probably couldn't have ever lived up to all my hopes with all their recent accolades... but it was pretty close. 

Nearing my destination, I was almost thwarted by a parade down Mission street. Undeterred, I spent the next hour and a half driving around the parade, finding parking, and hiking nearly a mile with my less than enthusiastic toddler. I tried both the carne asada and the carnita super burritos. If this review was based solely on the taste of the burritos, it would have been an easy five stars. They were both completely delicious, full of meat, sour cream, and guacamole. I doubt it would possible to make a more flavorful burrito. On top of the burritos, the service was quick notwithstanding the crowd the cashier was excellent and friendly. 

The loss of a star is for several reasons. First is the value. I realize there are no beans or rice fillers, but in comparison they are smaller mission style burritos and at more than 10 bucks a piece they are also pricey for the size. Second, I found the chips and salsa good but not great and I'm not a fan of scooping the salsa directly on the chips. I ended up throwing away more than half the basket of soggy chips. Last, I hope the outdoor trash bin in the hallway to the bathroom has found its way back outside.
author: Greg L.

description:
What can I say about La Taqueria... A few weeks ago, my friends from Toronto came to visit. One was in search of the "best burrito in town", and this place showed up during his research. Funnily enough, I have NOT had any tacos or burritos in SF yet (I KNOW, WHAT'S WRONG WITH ME). I would only get them at work when we get catered food.

We jumped on an uber, and the driver agreed. Best place for tacos and burritos. We got in, and the line moved pretty quickly. Got myself a carnitas taco and beef tongue taco (added avocado on top). Carnitas was good, but definitely messier. Beef tongue was probably one of my favorites.

I have now become a huge fan (like everybody else). Warning: Might be pretty difficult to find a seat. You might have to sit with a stranger - but don't worry, I'm sure you will bond over the deliciousness of the tacos at La Taqueria.
author: Joanne W.

description: I love this place, the chicken burritos are to die for. This place gets crowded easily so prepare to eat in your car or walk the streets of SF with food in hand. Place is cash ONLY so hit the ATM prior to heading here. Chips are not free btw, when you do purchase chips there is a pico de gallo plopped on your chips.
author: Arasi H.

description: Well, I've been coming here for years, ahem decades, and the staff all know me by now. That in itself is a testament of the goodness going on here. Most of the staff have been working here longer than I've been coming-- they must be doing something right on both ends! I hear the lines can get long at times, so I usually head on down around 8:50p on Monday, moments before closing, and there's always a table for me, unless they win another award and then it's lines for a few weeks.  I often get the same thing, one or two tacos, sometimes a veggie, sometime a chicken or asada, and I have been known to venture off into the cabeza or even lengua realm, although the latter is still a tad tough for me mentally. I've also tried their "world famous" burritos, but for me the namesake is my general preference: tacos! Often with avocado, sans sour cream. Sometimes I opt for the spicy red house sauce but often the pico de gallo (always the same) is perfect. And even the green sauce in canisters on the table has grown on me as of late. I guess I'm the Yelp Duke now and I even have scores and scores of visits before Yelp or even smartphones existed, but nonetheless I know I'm just one of many people that make this magic happen. Sure if you are drunk and somewhere else is open late you may think it's better, but once reality settles back in, it's always, ALWAYS La Taqueria or bust for me. Period.
author: Brian J.

description:
My wife turned me onto this place over 10 years ago. At the time, you could get there and expect to line up just about in front of the bathroom entrance which, at the time was a long line. Well, the secret is out + the changes with the city have made La Taqueria a take out only place most of the time. The line now loops around the entire place and out the door. No fun to even sit and eat anymore with all of these peoples butts right next to your face.

Now, that's all sour grapes because the food is the same. Two tacos, dorado, avocado, cheese. There really is nothing like a La Taqueria taco. It's an awesome delight.

I would recommend finding the right hour to go when it's not crowded because it is much better to sit and eat there... I would have given an absolute 5 star but this crowd problem has ruined the La Taqueria experience as the tacos aren't the same when you get them home as they are right off the grill.
author: Matt T.

description:
The burritos were needle sized and there was no rice.

I shared a super carne asada burrito with my food partner and it felt like I really should have gotten one for myself. It was definitely a tasty burrito though but on the pricier side of things. 

The wait to order was 45 minutes and it circled the whole room. There were some hipster guys that cut in front of us too. Jerks. The time it took from ordering to receiving food was really short. At least this place has that going for them.

It was a good burrito but the size was dismal and the wait was excruciating.
author: Anh T.

description:
Holy cats, as the saying goes.  This place makes a damn fine burrito.  I first tried La Taqueria after hearing about the burrito bracket on 538.  If Nate Silver says it's the best burrito in the country, that seems worth a try.

I can't speak to it's supremacy in the entire US, but it is one mean burrito.  Everything is seasoned perfectly and sort of mixes together in the tortilla so you don't get bites of just one thing at a time.

My current favorite is getting half carne asada, half chorizo, dorado.  You gotta get yours dorado'ed.  Meaning "golden" in spanish (I think) they put your assembled burrito on the flat-top and get it all crispy and... wait for it... golden.

The tortillas are tops, so amazingly delicious for such a simple thing.

The moment you approach the building you realize just how popular it is.  The line is epic.  They work fast though, so usually you order and pay in short succession.  I wish it were a little more organized in the waiting for food to be ready arena, but it's a small space.

I also wish they had a black bean option.  The pintos are tasty of course, but sometimes a girl needs some black beans.

It is a glorious day indeed when it's my husband's turn to go pick up burritos for lunch.  Amazing lunch and I don't have to leave the house?  Priceless.
author: Rachel S.

description: Brest burrito and carne asada in sf that I've had.   I also love there salsa. Lines are super long.  Cash only.  So come prepared
author: M S.

description:
Apparently this place won some online bracket for "Best Burrito in the West"--according to a friend of a friend of mine. Or something like that. Well, the carne asada burrito was really good, but I'm not quite sure it was a bracket-winner. 

But who really cares? 

Come here for really good burritos and tacos with fresh ingredients. Dab a little hot sauce in there to take it up another level, then sip some horchata to cool the mouth down. If I'm in the area again and craving a burrito, I'll be back.
author: Jon S.

description: Their food preparation process is very simple, but yet their quality is more superior and food is definitely above average comparing to other Mexican joints in the City.
author: Matt L.

description:
I've been to a LOT of taquerias, especially in the mission. A friend of mine told me to try this place out, so why not. 

It's a nice, warm evening in the city and we decided to take a trip to La Taqueria. Apparently, this place is always super packed. The line spews out the door and to the street. It's a Zagat rated place, so I guess that's suppose to happen. We arrive at around 4:30 pm and it's pretty empty. SCORE! Don't have to wait in line. I ordered my usual taqueria order: a super burrito. I awaited patiently for my food. 

Guess what. SMALLEST FUCKING SUPER BURRITO EVER. Do you know how disappointed I was? Whatever. I took a bite. It was okay. Took another one. Didn't get any better. I ate half of the burrito in 5 minutes. Nada. I just stopped eating it and threw it away. It kind of reminded me of those microwaveable frozen burritos you buy at Safeway. Definitely never coming back.

But their agua de sandia is good.

Side note: now my friend's stomach hurts after eating two tacos. And he's the one that's always talking this place up. Sooooo....
author: Betsy G.

description:
Dios de madre this place is tasty.

Carne asada burrito lived up to the hype. May try quesadilla next time for more texture

Highly recommend
author: Sean C.

description: Love it! Best place ever to eat real Mexican tastes! Try tacos and burritos dorado style, are the best!
author: Carolina L.

description: Best Mexican food to date! Haven't eaten in 2 years due being from and living in NY all my life. However, moved here to California (SoCal) one year ago and haven't made my way up to the bay yet but it is on to do list! Best burritos EVER!!!
author: Sean R.

description:
The search for the best burrito in the Mission District has been undertaken by far more experienced reviewers than this one.

As a card-carrying member of the millenial generation, I came ready to rank this place below El Farolito and Papalote simply because of the massive hype surrounding it.

The first bite changed all that. The carne asada was perfect, and the combination of flavors was sublime. A perfect burrito experience.

If you can only have one Mission Burrito, make it this one. BUT PLEASE DON'T HAVE JUST ONE, THEY ARE ALL SO GOOD.
author: Andrew E.

description:
This is one of the best taqueria I have been to. 
I found this place on Yelp and decided to give it a try. I went on a Sunday and this place was packed! the line was all the way out the door and all the tables were taken. My boyfriend ad I are patient and a long line doesn't scare us.. plus we were intrigued by how long the line was. 

While we were waiting in line i grabbed us a spot to sit down, its like a music chair game lol but you are bound to find some seats by the time you receive your order. 

We both had a Super burrito de asada "frito" omg! this is seriously one of the best burritos we have tasted ! Its a bit pricey but completely worth it! And that green salsa is to die for !! 

If you guys are ever in the area and want to have some bomb burritos this is the place!
author: Azalia G.

description: First trip to the mission - wonderful atmosphere. Staff was quick, friendly and ready to help me get through making my order. Tried the cabeza and chorizo taco (super on both) - best I have ever had. Will definitely be back.
author: John W.

description: Don't come here expecting to have rice in your burrito. They have a unique way doing their own thing here. Burrito is all meat and beans and you can go for the super for the usual guacamole and sour cream. But it's actually very refreshing coz it's not the typical rice, beans and meat. You get to enjoy the taste of Meat. It's filling too. Go for the dorado style for your burrito for a crunchy texture. I had tacos which is huge. There's always a line and it's difficult to find a table but it'll be all be worth it.
author: Ruth R.

description: Hands down the best tacos in the city. The line has gotten crazy but it's still worth the wait. Make sure you add cheese. The burrito has gotten a lot of press but it's still all about the carne asada and carnitas tacos with liberal helpings of the salsa verde on the table.
author: Connor P.

description: One of the top five taquerias in the mission and 100x better than El Farolito.  Nice steak used for carne asada and nice big chicken pieces for the pollo. No al pastor which is my fave . They lose a star for their higher than average prices ($4 regular taco , $6 super ??) , limited menu (just tacos burritos and quesadilla ) and limited hours - not open late nights . But it's in a much better area than crackhead infected 16th street where Pancho Villa and Los Coyotes are located . If you are a tourist or SF visitor trying mission street Mexican food for the first time and are debating between this and El Farolito , come here , el Farolito is filthy and cheap and overhyped .
author: Gmo G.

description:
For a place that's been featured sideways in all sorts of travel books and shows....it's, uh, ok. Not spectacular, not eye-popping. Just a bunch of mashed stuff mixed into a fairly soggy tortilla. Chicken was pretty decent, though, so that definitely redeemed the rest of the affair. Guacamole is always 10/10 though, and they have this ENORMOUS bowl of guac they just sling like snowballs in Norway. I also had one of those agua frescas, the watermelon one - it was, admittedly, quite good. That being said, I am not likely to get another one. 

If I recall correctly, it was maybe 7 dollars or so for the usual burrito with all the works (except rice, because rice is apparently faux pas) , and they're rather small. I definitely think I have been spoiled by Chipotle....eeps.

On an average day, if I just popped in based on the fact the line was going out the door, I'd have been intrigued enough to try one with no expectations attached. The fact that I did though, is kind of bumming me out since I didn't enjoy LaTaq nearly as much as the general populace seems to have. 

On the bright side, I explicitly came to Mission District because I wanted to try La Taqueria. This place is really, really awesome, and I spent more time than I planned for walking around the area. I'm surprised I've never been here before, given that I know (or at least I think I do) SF's in and outs pretty well. Also, the owner/manager of the store is the physical manifestation of the words "Kind elderly grandfather."

overall, 6/10. Probably won't come back again, but I hear there are comparably good burritos in the same area, and I love mexican food so....to quote the guv - I'll be back.
author: Rohan Y.

description: No wonder this place was voted best burrito!!! The carnitas super burrito is FANTASTIC. Be warned, the place is PACKED and has minimal seating, but the burrito is totally worth it. Chips and salsa are a let down but we also ordered an amazing carne asada quesadilla which was great. Definitely give it a try!
author: May B.

description:
This place lived up to the hype for me! Definitely one of the best burritos I've had. I got the carnitas and wow, I think that was the highlight. The meat was super juicey and flavorful and I just HAD to finish it even though I was full after half of it. I asked for no sour cream or beans so they filled it up with even more meat (they charge $1.20 extra though). I had a bite of a carne asada burrito but definitely the carnita one trumps. 

Aside from the delicious food, I'd say the place is a little tight with all the people lining up. However, compensates with simple ordering and nice service. We actually even got to catch a performer inside the restaurant! I'd recommend coming for a real good bite if you're craving burritos or they're other food (I saw their quesadilla and it looked delicious). 

And last thing I want to add is that their sizes are pretty good! I wouldn't say they're enormous, but I only got a regular and I am suuuper full!
author: Holly P.

description:
As a Mexican, I can say that this is the most authentic Mexican taqueria I've been in the city. It even smells like a Mexican taqueria. 

The place was crowded, I don't know if it's because it was a Friday night. They have an efficient system so the line went by fast, and the order didn't take much to be ready. They stuff is friendly, while on the line, they let us try the carnitas and the carne asada. I had a taco de carne asada with all the extras. My husband had the "award winnîng" burrito dorado de carnitas. The idea of a burrito dorado is awesome!!! I rarely order burrito because of the texture of the tortilla but this tasted delicious. The horchata was delicious as well. 

The place is neat even when crowded. 


Highly recommended. So far the best Mexican tacos in SF.
author: Cristinita C.

description:
La Taqueria Adventure

Obviously there are many great reviews about this San Francisco original. Our experience was very positive and we highly recommend the super burritos (beef and chorizo), chicken quesadilla, and the awesome green sauce.  

We heard the taquerias in the Mission district were the inspiration for the nationwide burrito chains including Chipote. We were told La Taqueria was the best, and we welcomed something different from the restaurants north of Market Street. 

To get to La Taqueria, we used public transit. We started from Union Square, and took the cable car to California Street. Then we transferred to the California cable car to the end of it's line (Van Ness). We then caught the bus (#49) that runs south on Van Ness Avenue to Misson Street. The point of describing our route is the cross-section of the city that we experienced first hand. Within an hour we saw the transitions of neighborhoods from the wealth of Nob Hill, past city hall, through the struggling Tenderloin district, and then the early signs of gentrification in the Mission district. One minute we were riding with tourist and business professionals and the next we were with the working class and even some homeless. A fascinating look at the city and it's people.

La Taqueria was great, and the experience getting there was uniquely San Francisco.  If you have the time, this is wonderful adventure and built-in tour of this special city.
author: Paul C.

description:
Well known taqueria that even tourists line up for.  The food is good, but I do think that they are smoking a bit too much of their own hype.  

Why do I say that?  I had two tacos here, and both were a bit inconsistent in terms of their presentation.  The carnitas taco came with some meat that did not taste fully cooked.  And the chicken taco came with bones.

So why do I still give it 4 stars?  Because the flavors were right on.  And I loved how they put a hard taco shell on top of a soft tortilla.  

With the flavors spot on, who am I to give 3 stars to a place with over 2,000 reviewers?!  But expect inconsistency here...
author: Mark M.

description:
Best burrito I've ever had. Carne asada super burrito el dorado style. Get it, it changed my life. 
A little pricey for a burrito, I think it came to like $12 but it was worth it for sure. Remember, cash only!
author: Jason L.

description:
Whoa this place is good. Waited in line for what felt like a hundred years but the reward was definitely worth the patience. 

It looks like people were concerned about the burritos being a bit pricey (~$10) for what it is, but I have to say, with how tasty it was and how fast I devoured it, I think it was definitely worth the price.

I had the super carnitas burrito and I would definitely come back again. They can make it spicy, which in hindsight, I should have done, but they provide sauce at the tables. The carnitas are divine and the guac gives it just the right buttery kick. 

The space is tight, but people rotate fast. While you wait, you can also sneak a peak at the line cooks working furious to make all the meats and guac. Super fun.

Definitely come in with a sense of humor, grab a space when you see one, and enjoy yourself.

Oh, and it's cash only.
author: Jumi Y.

description:
After many burrito adventures I finally returned to La Taqueria because of Nate Silver's Burrito Challenge. When I'm craving a burrito Taqueria Cancun is my usual choice but the BC has pushed me to try out some new (and forgotten) places.

I got the carne asada burrito. It used to seem pricier than other places but now I'm used to burritos being $10 (inflation!) so i didn't think things were out of line here. It's a skinny burrito though. Pretty wet too. Turns out that's because they don't put rice in the burrito - fine by me, great idea! You get a nice long burrito with yummy meat and beans. No more trying to find that bite with the good stuff. It's all good! 

My only complaint was that the tortilla was a little gummy. I think I prefer the way Taqueria Cancun grills up the tortillas. But apparently La Taq can do that too if you ask. Next time.....
author: Jean K.

description:
Tip: Ask for it el dorado and don't look back.

I have no idea what el dorado means but I assume it roughly translates into "make my taco god-given and heavenly". They do two corn tortillas for this, one on the outside is soft, and the one inside is fried and super crispy. I also got guac on mine, all in all two amazing tacos with perfectly cooked shredded chicken and carne asada. 

It's basically in the heart of the mission district, so you're gonna be hard pressed to find parking if you're hitting it up during peak hours or anytime not right before closing. If possible, take BART as the station is right around the corner.

Oh, expect lines, and if you're trying to eat there, make sure to have your cat-like reflexes going cause you're going to be hard pressed finding a table.
author: D.J. N.

description:
Lines can be obnoxiously long here... which discourages me from coming. So I've learned to either come on a week day or call in and place my order to go. & some might hate me for saying this but El Farolito (one of my favorite Mexican spots) is just a block away and can move a lot faster!  

Chicken or Steak Burrito is my fave- but it has to be Dorado Style!!!
If you want something lighter, the tacos are wonderful and hefty for the size of a taco! And if you're getting a taco, you might as well go for the crispy taco or you're missing out on life.
Also, do not forget their guacamole! It's incredible and extremely freshhh
author: Michelle L.

description:
This was my first time experiencing a mission burrito. My Bay Area friends had set my standards high even though I moved from San Diego... so perhaps it was inevitable that my hopes were crushed. The $10 super burrito was so tiny... tasty but tiny. The "regular" burrito only comes with meat, beans, and pico de gallo. The "super" burrito adds sour cream, avocado, and cheese to that. Way too expensive for such a small serving. However, I'm glad that there were hot sauce bottles all over the place. YUM!

Logistically, the line moves fast, the food is prepared fast, and it's cash only. (So what is there REALLY to complain about?) Of course I will come here again because the food is delicious, but it is definitely NOT on my list of top tasting Mexican food places.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
So this place was names one of the best burrito places so I had to give it a try on my trip to SF. You can take the BART there and it is just a short walk from the station. We arrived just before lunch and grabbed a table and only had to wait about 10 minutes once we placed our order. The place quickly filled up around 12:30 pm on a Saturday so it is best to go before or after the lunch hour. 

I got a super carne ascada burrito. The burrito was delicious. I was glad that the burrito wasn't super in size, just in flavor! Definite a must try if you want a burrito in Mission while in SF.

P.S. It is cash only.
author: Courtney D.

description: Best tacos in the city! Little pricy but full of flavor and generous size. Small sized place and always crowded! Good luck finding a seat best to order to go! However service is fast and friendly. You are sure to leave full! Can't be let down here!
author: Davon F.

description:
There's always a line out of the door of this place -- and all over the restaurant, as you'll see if you peek inside.

It's a chaotic environment that's a bit tough to navigate if it's extra crowded, but the line moves fairly quickly; you'll wait longer for your order than you will queue. The food was very good, but it didn't blow my mind. I had a good experience here but probably wouldn't go back, as I don't personally think the wait is worth it. If you have some time to kill, however, it's worth checking it out and forming your own opinion.
author: Al I.

description: Over priced & overrated! I grew up in the mission & this place used to be good until it sold out to cater to the hipster movement in the mission. I'll take my business to el farolito who by far have a way better burrito than these guys! Don't believe the hype
author: Miguel G.

description:
One of the many taquierias in the area. The tamales are really good! The outer "shell" is crunchy, sort of like a "tart", and yet it's also juicy instead of dry--not really sure how they managed to make this unique taste! 

As for the non-tamale items, the burritos and tacos were ok, nothing fancy. Overall the food portions are huge--I was not able to finish most of it.

There's always a line at this place, so there's usually a wait even if you only want take-out. Not a bad place to visit for a late-night taco run
author: Henry L.

description: Had the best burrito of my life here . Line was long but moved pretty quickly and definitely worth the wait ! Now I'm not from California and this is the only burrito I've ever eaten in San Francisco so I can't compare it to other California or San Francisco burritos, but compared to any burrito I've had in my life this was incredible. Definitely deserves a visit on your trip to San Francisco. I'll repeat : best burrito I've ever had in my life !
author: Alissa T.

description:
I'm just gonna go ahead and give La Taqueria five stars, since that's pretty much what everybody else does. :)
The only downside is the crowd, which can make it hard to get a table, but actually the few times that I've been there it's always worked out, so maybe it's not actually a downside. Ha!
Well, anyway. Just go ahead get some tacos, they're damn good. They have all the regular taqueria fare and they're not expensive.
author: Erin A.

description:
Came here because this and El Faro are always on the top of the best burritos lists.

Got the carne asada burrito.  First things first, no rice.  Nice.  Rice rarely adds that much flavor and is just a filling for filling's sake.  But boo, beans.  I'm not a fan of beans but I thought since there's no rice, I got to get them.  They were way way too watery, made the burrito soggy.  It might've been from the salsa though.

But the meat was great, the carne asada was very well seasoned and had a great char on it.  Really good green sauce at the table too.

It's good, but there's better burritos else where in the city. Not worth the hype or wait.
author: Tu T.

description: Ok I know this place has won awards and all but I'm only mildly impressed. An $11 Pollo Super Burrito should not be able to be eaten in one sitting yet this one easily was. A lack of rice is their trademark but this burrito needed rice. The chicken portions were plentiful but not very flavorful. Also got a regular carnitas to go for the girlfriend who just advised me that it's beef instead. $22 w/tip is just too expensive for a lunch with no leftovers. However if you're in the neighborhood you might want to at least give it a try but I wouldn't go out of my way to get there.
author: David G.

description:
Bought a generic burrito here. Just a generic burrito. No frills, nothing special. But this was THE BEST G.D. BURRITO I HAVE EVER EATEN. 
I know a lot of people say stuff like this. But I mean it. Let me tell you how good this GD burrito was. First bite, instant mouthgasm. Before I knew it, half the burrito stuffed down my gullet. Had to slow down, savor this GD burrito. Never want it to end. Suddenly, out of the corner of my eye, something falls from the ceiling. It's a cockroach. Gross? No. Illustrative of a point. The cockroach falls right onto a lady's plate. She screams of course. But this burrito was so good. This GD burrito was SO GD GOOD, that SHE BRUSHED THE BUG OFF HER PLATE AND KEPT EATING. If that doesn't tell you how good this GD burrito stand is nothing will.
author: Frank G.

description:
The hype was strong with this meal. Clearly too strong. As I waited for my chicken burrito to be prepared, I had a feeling it would become one of my favorite foods in the city. 

Ultimately, that didn't happen. Here are the main reasons why:

-The chicken was moist. Perhaps overly so, as the 'wetness' quickly made the tortilla soggy.

-The overall flavors were somewhat bland, between the chicken, beans, salsa, and avocado. In fact, the avocado was probably my favorite part, since it was simply crushed and fresh.

-The salsa verde on the table didn't add much heat, but it did add a lot of saltiness.

Maybe I should've gone with the steak or carnitas? I've also heard great things about the tacos. However, the chicken burrito fell flat, and I don't think my standard are that high. I mean, I'm perfectly content with a Chipotle burrito, and both Taqueria Cancún and El Farolito left me feeling happier.
author: Sam H.

description:
The Carne Asada burrito is out of this world!  Juicy, tasty, not overly salty.  Perfectly grilled with crispy tortilla skin, avocado, cheese, salsa and pinto beans inside.

There is a wait of 20 minutes or so when we went late on a Sat night but it was so freaking delicious that I did not mind.  

Tacos were just ok.  But get that Carne Asada burrito ASAP.  I'm hungry just thinking about it.
author: Yue L.

description:
The Platonic ideal of a Mission-style burrito.  I got the Carne Asada Super Burrito, filled to the brim with juicy meat, cheese, sour cream, beans, and guac. Make sure you order your burrito grilled as well.

The lines for this place are LONG, but it's popular because it's so good. A must-visit spot if you're visiting SF.
author: Seth G.

description: Love this restaurant! The food was fresh and delicious. It will definitely be a go to spot when I'm in the City.
author: Yutonya C.

description: Tacos were the best I have ever had and very substantial.  The line was out the door but moved reasonably quickly and we were able to find a table by dividing and conquering.  As a newbie, we found the biggest issue was that the messiness of the food and great taste caused us to eat too quickly but that's probably just an amateur mistake.  If I lived in SF, I'd be back.
author: Kevin Y.

description:
Finally had a chance to try this place after all that I have heard. The line on a Saturday afternoon was ridiculous, but as the other reviews had mentioned it goes by pretty fast. We took our food to go so in and out of there within 20-25 minutes which is totally fine since the line was like a maze. 

We ordered the carne asada super burrito, carnitas super burrito, and a soft and crispy carne asada super taco. Also ordered a melon fresca. I never order burritos so I was a bit skeptical- I'm not a huge fan of tortilla. But I took one bite and I was pretty amazed. The tortilla was really soft and it was like a substitute for rice in my case. The meat itself was very flavorful. And the pico de gallo, guac, and loads of sour cream was just right. Not a fan of carnitas because I guess I've never had any that tasted good but the carnitas they serve here will have me ordering carnitas next time I come by. Taco was great too! Only item that was not very pleasant was the melon fresca- it was too sweet. Way too much sugar in it. I like it more on the natural sweetness flavor. 

This place is expensive though. About 30 bucks for two burritos, a taco, and a drink. Worth it for the flavor.
author: Dara S.

description: I completely forgot that La Taqueria has a spot in SF since closing their San Jose doors, years ago. Now that I'm in SF, it's ON!!!
author: Ricardo X.

description:
I had the carne asad a and carnitas tacos. I think the carnitas taco meat was especially flavorful. It was very good even when cold(don't ask me why I didn't get to eat it while it was still hot). 

The tacos here actually really beat el farolitos by far..I guess you just come here for tacos and go there for burritos. 

The line and wait for food was very long even when I came pretty early at 5pm. This place is also way out of the way from where I was heading...but needed to drop by for authentic Mexican food. I guess I got it. I just don't like how they charge for any toppings....and it is pricier than I would anticipate.....adding on the wait that was not pleasant. Overall, the food is decent but don't know if I would come back if I am back in sf.
author: Shushu C.

description:
I don't think this is the world's best burrito as its sign says, but it's pretty good.  I think what distinguishes La Taqueria burritos from others is mostly the meat. The carne asada is smokey and flavorful, and the carnitas is soft and delicious as well.  La Taqueria also uses fresh avocados instead of guacamole, and more cheese and sour cream.  I love each bite of a La Taqueria burrito.

1 star off: The "Super Burrito" is disappointedly small.  I definitely have had much bigger burritos from other burrito places in the Mission. I am a petit gal, but c'mon, I'm hungry!
author: Ally W.

description:
CASH ONLY!!!

The super tacos here are bomb!!! They're kind of expensive being $6.25 a piece, but they are really filling. It comes with your choice of meat, beans, cheese, avocado, sour cream, and pico de gallo. It's so good!! Chips aren't free which sucks. 

The line does tend to get long so be prepared to wait, but it moves pretty quickly! Parking is also hard to find as it is in the Mission. Seating is also hard to find so swoop when you can and don't be afraid to share a table with strangers! (:
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I heard this is one of the best for getting a burrito in San Francisco so I came by to check it out.  I was hoping it was a full Mexican restaurant where I could get it all, but  this is more of a taco truck flair.  Perfect for a quick snack or food after late night drinking binges.

I got the carne asada burrito with avocado and cheese.  It was really good and the verde sauce at the table perfectly complemented it.
author: Gary W.

description: Amazing food! It's recently become a very trendy burrito place so the line is pretty long but goes by fast. Not a lot of places to sit because it is packed but it's so good and worth the wait! Very inexpensive and a good place to eat while in the mission district
author: Monique C.

description: The food here was amazing. You must get the carnitas, and some chips and salsa. Then sit at the outside counter and watch the magic in action.
author: George S.

description:
The lines are long right now. As I was waiting in line I thought: "unless you're waiting for your monthly retirement check, no line should be this long" ( if you have southamerican roots you'll get the joke) 
But I stood in line for over an hr. The melon water was to die for. I ordered 2 beef burritos (if you're gonna do it, do it right)
Then I headed towards Alamo square, because if I am going to be that idiot who stands in line for long periods of time, I better go all the way and eat my burritos at the most cliche place in the city. 

I regret nothing.

I had the second burrito for lunch the next day. Still good.
author: Pony R.

description:
I do not know how the reviews got so high for this place. We ordered a chicken burrito, a lengua taco, a carne asada taco, chips and salsa, and a horchata. 

The chicken was not seasoned at all. It tasted like simple boiled chicken and they stuffed the burrito with beans for filler. The salsa on the chips were minimal and there was no salsa bar. The tacos were just ok. For $3+ for tacos, you would expect more. I'd much rather go to El Farolito and get my dollars worth.
author: Marlene T.

description:
Got all the tacos: 

Carnitas
Carne asada
Pollo
Lengua

They were all juicy and legit, the meat was good on its own and they know it, they don't try to dress up the tacos too much here
author: Tina A.

description:
Worth the wait. Since having won the 'burrito bracket' at FiveThirtyEight (website of political genius and stats guy, Nate Silver), this place has had a wraparound, 20-60 minute line at peak times like weeknights, lunch, and weekends. But it is worth it.

The reason is three words:

SKIP. THE. RICE.

This place's burrito doesn't come with rice. As a result, you can really really taste all the ingredients. The burrito that won the bracket was the Carnitas, so I highly recommend you get that here. It's so good that you should bring people who come to SF and want some "Mission Mexican" or some cheaper "SF food" to.

But, I should mention TWO CAVEATS:

1. This is a "premium taqueria." 

One burrito is nowhere near as big as you will be used to getting at most good Bay Area taquerias, which are like 2 pounds. So you probably want a burrito and taco to get that amount of food. As a result, you can think of La Taqueria as 1.5x the price of many taquerias. Or, if a typical burrito is too big for you, maybe this is the perfect diet solution you have been looking for. Because the lack of the white carbs-the rice- does add to the flavor at this establishment.

2. The other meats are not "breathtaking."

The other meats leave something to be lacking. The chicken and lengua could truly be mind-melting, but at some other establishment. Given this establishment has mind-melting carnitas, it is just easy to define what "not mind melting" is by eating the carnitas side-by-side with another meat here. They may be good, but they are not divine. The chicken may be a bit overcooked. The asada may be a tad chewy. The lengua could be seasoned a bit better.

But these caveats can't dock this amazing experience. it's the type of burrito you drive an hour for and wait an hour for. I do.
author: Aakash G.

description: Super Taco Dorado Style - Flour tortilla wrapped outside a crunchy taco shell and filled with meat, beans, sour cream, and guac. So good! Quite pricey at around $6 but it's SF after all. Two of these babies and I was stuffed. I still prefer Los Coytoes though - mainly due to the fact that I personally prefer rice over beans. If La Taqueria had the option to use rice instead of beans, I think this would be my new favorite taqueria.
author: Venus L.

description: Delish!!!  The chicken burrito was awesome.  All the ingredients are super fresh, especially that avocado.   The best ingredient is their hot green jalapeño sauce on the side...AWESOME!  I didn't get the quesadilla but that will be next time because they looked so good when other customers were ordering them.   Make sure to bring cash only.
author: Hania A.

description: My boyfriend and I are going vegetarian, so today we decided to go here to eat our last meaty meal. We had their chorizo tacos.... Most definitely never ever disappoints! It's ALWAYS busy here so be sure to come with a friend if you want a seat in the house! :)
author: Carlyle M.

description:
In my opinion, tacos are the ultimate fast food. Fresh, hot and prepared on the fly, wrapped and ready to eat. As fast as any drive through, you can get in and out and on your way with a real meal.

Sure La Taqueria is popular, but there is a reason behind the line. The tasty food that awaits you. I waited for no longer than 2 minutes before I ordered and another 2 minutes before my taco was on my table and ready to eat. 

I order my carne asada taco accompanied by a Modelo Especial. Extra Jalapenos on the side, free of charge. Perfect dinner before heading out for the night.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
This place is delicious! The meat has really good flavor. And they pack their tacos and burritos with meat. I've gone here twice: once I got a burrito and tacos. Both are excellent. They have the option of both soft and crunchy tacos. For the crunchy tacos, they partially fry a tortilla, fold it and put a soft tortilla on the outside. You have to try it. Also try their green hot sauce.

The place is small and have to wait to for a seat, but it's worth it.
author: Nick N.

description:
best tacos. period. 
Dorado comes with soft corn tortilla and one crispy one with melted cheese. the carne asada is flap meat which is better quality, most places use round chuck which can be chewy and flavorless. all the ingredients are very fresh, and you can taste it. Also their green chili is unmatched as far as flavor. Any time friends or family come out of town, this is the first place i take them and ive never had a dissatisfied customer.
author: Alex R.

description:
One of the best authentic Mexican joints in the entire Bay Area! The staff works quickly to get the orders out as fast as possible despite the constant line wrapping around the small restaurant. I have tried their burritos and tacos and I don't have a favorite because they're all delicioso! I always order my burritos and tacos "super" (with sour cream, cheese and avocado) and I would suggest you do the same. What makes their tacos unique is that they do the typical double tortilla, but the inner tortilla is crispy fried to perfection, adding a crunch to every bite. Their burritos aren't filled with rice like other places which means you get more meat!!! What other place do you know of that sacrifices a cheap burrito filler, such as rice, to pack in more meat?

I wish I lived closer to La Taqueria, but then again it would be dangerous because I would probably be a rolie polie from eating it all the time.

Tip: If you plan on devouring your food there, one person should scout for a table while the other waits in line to order.
author: Allyson Y.

description:
I had high expectations prior to coming this place and sadly believed the hype.

I had a super burritos con carnitas, which was okay, alongside with chips com salsa fresca, which was awesome.
The salsa was really fresh and the chips were crispy and nice.

As for the burrito, I was very disappointed.
It barely had any meat in it and the burrito itself was very thin compared to my boyfriend's carne asada burrito, which he thought was "mind-blowingly good."

I probably won't come back to the Mission solely for the burrito - just not worth it.
