Bottom line at the top: hands down the best tacos I've ever had. Get them dorado (crispy).
--
Literally the best tacos I've ever had, anywhere. Had a chicken and a beef which was too much food but so worth it.

La taq foreva.
author: Dahlia S.

description:
Having a favorite Mission burrito in SF is a very polarizing subject. Some friends swear by La Taqueria's superb meats, others wax poetic on the burst of flavor of El Farolito. Any other taquerias are not on my radar, #SorryI'mNotSorry.

I tried La Taq for the first time this weekend, being a hardcore El Farolito fan myself. I heard of the magnificent carnitas (or any proteins for that matter) at La Taq and their elusive "dorado" secret menu option. How could I not be enticed out of my El Farolito cave to try this so-called delicacy? I was in.

Yes, anticipate long wait times. Yes, stop at the ATM first. Yes, you could wait awhile to find a seat. This is to be expected. I will note that the cleanliness is on-point. More so than others in the area.

Our party of three each got a different burrito. I had to capture the whole spectrum of our visit! We ordered: a vegetarian super burrito, a chicken burrito (w/ avocado and cheese) DORADO style, and a carne asada super burrito. 

My friend w/ the vegetarian burrito said it was good, not great. They only offer pinto or refried beans here. NO BLACK BEANS (sad face) or other veg option. My bf had the carne asada super burrito and said he clearly prefers El Farolito over this one. Not as much flavor and was missing the rice. My chicken burrito missed the mark. I had to nix the pico because of my onion intolerance and I think that having it would have added so much more flavor to the otherwise juicy, but flavorless chicken. The dorado style didn't impress me, as it made my burrito into a greasy mess that left my stomach in a greasy mess yadda yadda. 

Overall, a solid choice. Maybe the tacos are better, idk. For now, will continue being Team Farolito for the ultimate Mission burrito.
author: Liz G.

description:
A super burrito for $8.95 here or one up the block at El Farolito for $6.75? The burritos at EF are larger and flat out better. You do the math.

LT does excel at tacos, but they're extremely pricey. $3.95 for a regular taco, which is basically two corn tortillas w/ meat and pico de gallo or cilantro and onions. A super taco is $5.95, which is a regular taco w/ guac and sour cream. Let's put this in perspective - a pescado taco w/ all the fix-ins at Nick's Crispy Tacos is the same price, but it's a larger portion and it's a seafood taco. The tacos are solid for the most part, but just way overpriced (relative to what you can get elsewhere).  

If you want a burrito or suiza, stick to EF. The dorado burrito (grilled exterior) is just a gimmick. If you want a gourmet taco, then you'd probably want to venture here. Just remember you'll be paying $6+ after tax for a super taco.
author: Jeff S.

description: I don't come here anymore but had friends visiting from east coast and specifically said they wanted to come here. Yes, the food tastes great but food is overpriced. Chintzy with the carne asada, beans and salsa. Almost $10 for a regular burrito? I think not!
author: Review L.

description: Home sweet home!!!! No disrespect to any of the other restaurants I have Yelp. I grew up one block away from La taqueria  and I guess you can say it's the next best thing to mom's home cooking....Keep up the good work guys. You should definitely expand the place....
author: The Truth V.

description:
I think they've maybe gotten a bit big for their britches. If you are going to eat here, you should budget about a half an hour wait time. They were somewhat recently voted "best burrito in America" and that's driven the popularity sky high. 

I also feel as though it may have contributed to a downfall in quality as the burrito I had, while not bad by any stretch, was not even in my top 5 in terms of Bay Area burritos. 

I don't hate it but I would never bother with it again. There are tons of other places that are, in my opinion, much better that don't require you to stand around for ages and ages.
author: Jen K.

description:
I have eaten many a burrito in San Francisco. One may say I am a San Francisco burrito connoisseur. This burrito ranks among the best of the best that SF has to offer--- tied for 1st place with Gordo Taqueria in my opinion.  Other Yelp favorties--- Taqueria Cancun, or El Farrollito, are greasy crap in comparison.

The quality is what really sets this place off.  I always do their Carne Asada burrito, although I've been told they make a mean taco (fried with cheese), and plan to do that one next.  The Carne Asada is fresh, flavorful, and quality cuts.  The simple ingredients make a big deal--- like the guacamole.  My other favorite spot, Gordo, I sadly forgo the guac because it's cut with sour cream-- and will sometimes opt for fresh avocado (which they reluctantly provide me, as it's off-menu, and they can be dickheads with customer service). Here, the guacamole is 100% pure, 100% fresh, and it makes a huge difference in the burrito.

My only compaints are that they do not use rice.  I know they claim rice is a filler, and takes away from the flavor, but I like it-- so there.  Second, I suspect it might have lard in it. I know that's authentic and all, but I can really do without the aftertaste of lard.  Gordo gets my vote, as they grill their meats rather than put on a flat grill with grease.  As you get to the end of the burrito, the tortilla is dripping.  Never a problem at Gordo.

I'd give Gordo #1 spot for the lack of grease, bu La Taqueria gets points for the fresh guac, and authentic flavor (with it's goods and bads)
author: James M.

description:
It was a good burrito. I heard this is the place to go to for tacos and well seasoned meat. Well, I offered a vegetarian burrito and it was alright. They don't have rice or black beans, both things I really like to have in my burrito. I'm sure it's great to have more meat instead of rice but my vegetarian burrito was a little blend with just beans, avocado, salsa and sour cream. 
Chips are an additional charge but come with a really good salsa. 
I'd probably order something different next time or just go to a different taqueria for my vegetarian burrito. 
Place got really crowded, I however still found a table and the service was fast. Not overly friendly but well.
author: Caroline K.

description: La Taqueria is undeniably good, but is it the best burrito in SF? I am not sure. I tried both the meat and vegetarian burrito yesterday and they were both tasty, fresh, cheap and filling. They were pretty basic with the ingredients and I tend to lean towards a more complex burrito. Peppers, corn and greens take burritos to the next level for me, and they were missing at La Taqueria. The guacamole and salsa were scrumptious and very high quality. My boyfriend and I did not leave a scrap of food behind, so clearly we enjoyed our meal. La Taqueria was pretty crowded even during the late afternoon on a weekday. The line was long and the people watching was divine.
author: Alexandra R.

description: Definitely a busy little spot that has a great niche worked out for themselves and for a good reason! The line was so long with so many people standing around we couldnt figure out where to begin. But eventually with some guidance we ordered. The wait was about 15 minutes and well worth it for the quality of the food! The meat was perfect! Tender and flavorful not grissely or oily. Hubby had a super burrito and I had tacos, both were awesome! I really liked that the burrito was lightly fried, kicked it up a notch!
author: Amber U.

description:
I don't know what else to say about this place that hasn't been said already?  

Yes, the line can get long.
Yes, get the tacos dorado style.
Yes, it's worth the wait.
Yes, it's really that damn good.

5 plus stars for this place!!!
author: Eddie F.

description:
You almost have to endurance train to go to La Taqueria. How badly do you want tacos?! How much are you willing to suffer for them?! You know those videos of commuters on Tokyo subways? Where conductors literally shove them in there to close the doors? That's pretty much how it feels inside La Taqueria. You are in everyone's way, it's loud, crowded and stressful.

Obviously, you won't find seating in there. That being said, have a game plan for where you're going to eat your tacos. I walked all the way to Dolores Park and by then my tacos were not so great. In fact, let me help you: Garfield Square on Treat and 25th is 2 blocks away and is also your best bet.

Their super taco is a very clever creation. A hard shell tortilla with a soft tortilla over it. It's like a taco bell gordita, but you know, actually good. They load it up with beans, salsa, guac and sour cream, so it's somewhere between a burrito and a taco. Their carne asada is the best I've had. I normally don't even order it because it always comes to me with the consistency of dried rabbit terds. You can watch them pull massive hunks of meat off the grill and chop it up. Come here for the carne asada.

They are cash only, so come prepared with some cash in addition to a zen-like state of mind, which will buffer the intensely hectic vibe in there. 

They are also significantly more expensive than anywhere else in the Mission District. It's probably because Travel & Leisure named them one of the best tacos in America. My 2 super tacos and horchata were over $14. Whoa.

For me, I get stressed out easily. El Farolito is just as good and I can stand in there, so I will continue getting my taco fix there.
author: K M.

description: Long lines, limited seating & cash only doesn't stop San Franciscans from devouring their delicious burritos, me included. I usually go for their super carne asada burrito and a side of chips & salsa. Everything tastes fresh and burritos are always warm upon arrival. Know what you are getting before the walking order takers get to you, no one likes a newbie who takes forever to order.
author: Cindy G.

description:
I..... don't know. Best burrito in America? Probably not.. at least not the one I had. Veggie burrito, grilled. The veg burrito has an insane amt of pinto beans... like more than any one person could eat in 1 sitting. The salsa, sour cream and guac ratio was very good though. 

The seating areas leave a lot to be desired, but I understand this is just the type of business this is. If I had to wait for more than 20 min for the burrito I ate, the rating might be lower. It's not worth the wait.
author: Nancy A.

description:
'Tis nothing to be said about this place that hasn't been said...it's REALLY fuckin' good!
The carne asada is fresh and badass.  Chorizo is greasy and awesome...it will drip down your arm.  The carnitas is perfect and juicy.
The burritos are what brought the place fame...and yes, they rule.
The QUESADILLAS are what really kick ass here.  They are not flat, but they are fat.  They serve them stuffed full of awesome stuff, and you eat them like a burrito ( squirt the chile verde on top...oh, and get a Tecate with it)
The lines of those waiting to order, and those who have already ordered and are now waiting for a piece of Heaven become a mess of food-horny people all dazed in confusion for the Mexican orgasm that awaits them.  All of this is worth it.  Best bet: grab a spot outside, and have a few beers while you devour one of mankind's most precious creations.
author: Evan M.

description:
First off: the tortilla chips with salsa! Absolutely incredible way to start the meal. The chips were not too salty or greasy (like most tortilla chips usually are), but they kind of had a toasted feel and went great with the really fresh salsa. 

I had a grilled steak burrito with guacamole, and I still distinctly remember this burrito even now, two weeks later as I'm writing this review, because it was the best burrito I've ever had in my life. The hype is real - La Taqueria is amazing. I just wished they accepted card!
author: Melissa D.

description: this place is so worth the wait!!!!  anything you order will not be a disappointed..... closes at 9 sharp on saturday nights.... get there early!!! we would be there every day if we could.....
author: Cat C.

description: Extremely disappointed!!!!! Lines out the door. Unsafe atmosphere; fire hazard with all the people waiting inside for a table. ordered our food. No Rice, No Beans served with food other than inside the burrito. We had chicken taco, carne Asada burrito, chips and salsa. The chicken taco had broiled meat not grilled. It was not seasoned and bland. The carne Asada was also not seasoned very bland. Chips were stale. Salsa was ok. Expensive!!! Tacos were 3.50 a taco more then the normal 2.60 per taco. Save your time and money and go on Valencia that have plenty Great taquerias with flavor.
author: Shar I.

description:
The best tacos ever! Love the basic carne asada or carnitas. Get it with everything on it... Guac, salsa, sour cream and amazing chile verde sauce. And ask to make it dorado (one of two tortilla is cooked til it's crispy) Amazing! It's not some cheap dollar taco but one is big and filling. For some reason, even if it's the exact ingredients in a burrito... It's nothing compared to the taco... So taco all the way! The fresh strawberry juice is also delicious! 
And just FYI... It's cash only!
author: Cherry S.

description:
as recommended by folks, we got the carnitas super burrito.  It was definitely very good - but at this point, it's hard to tell, distinguish between all the good burritos. 

The only negative, is that it could have been warmer/hotter. The sour cream and guac were cold (as they should be), but the meat could've been warmer to counter it, but it wasn't and so the burrito was lukewarm all around.

The carnitas were delicious though - a little bit of crunch on the outside and very flavorful.
author: Madison W.

description:
Their chicken in red sauce burrito is delicious! 

I've notice when they are not so busy they make my burritos bigger. Huh?


Great place to grab a bite however parking SUCKs!
author: Abel S.

description: This is the best Taqueria in the city! I've tried hundreds of tacos in the city and this place has the best carne asada tacos ever...you have to order the crunchy ones. there is melted cheese in the middle and the toppings are super fresh! Enjoy!
author: Michelle L.

description: Honestly this place is so hyped up for what is really is. In 2011/2012 I believe was the first time I went there, before it totally blew up. Maybe it's just me, but proportions seem to have gotten significantly smaller than what I remember it being. Don't get me wrong, the meat is still very well seasoned and the service is great, but why am I paying $10 for a burrito that leaves my belly unsatisfied + one that's also pretty mediocre? For that same price, I might as well go the Chipotle and get a meatier and thicker burrito with more ingredients. Tacos here also range from $4-$5, but again, why am I paying such a high price for something that's more expensive than the tacos at Paul Martin's? Personally speaking, the $1 tacos from taco trucks and smaller taqueria's are definitely much more worth while than this place.
author: Karissa K.

description: This place lives up to the hype! Very busy place, prices are a bit higher but well worth it! Had the carne asada burrito. Didn't look as filling as other burritos but when you bite into it, that makes all the difference! All the ingredients played its part in contributing to the flavor. From the char seasoning of the steak, to the accents all of the veggies, this was the making of the perfect burrito!
author: Chris E.

description: Absolutely sensational taste in the spicy carnitas burrito supreme.  As we got there I was wondering if the food would be as good as advertised or if it would have gone downhill with all the accolades.  I was happy to find that it was the former!  I'll be back that's for sure.
author: Ted B.

description:
The Secret to LA TAQUERIA's Crazy Delicious Tacos:

1)  Fat. 

2)  Fat

3)  More FAT

(And in other late breaking news, the sky is blue and water is wet.)

1)  First, a tortilla is tossed on the grill and liberally doused with oil. 

2)  Once it has crisped up a bit, a slice of cheese is added on top. 

3)  When the cheese has melted, a second tortilla is added to the bottom and is filled to the brim with perfectly cooked meats, beans, chunky guacamole, and homemade salsa.  Try the rich and flavorful carnitas or if you are feeling less gluttonous the chicken. 

Add a hefty dose of the amazing green chili sauce for some heat and then dig into one of the best tacos in the Mish!

Oh and don't forget to go across the street to Mission Pie for a slice of Banana Cream.  Or two. 

PHAT.

Note:  This review is dedicated to Marc D. who shares my love for taquerias but not my proximity to them.  But luckily, I eat enough for the both of us!
author: Amy C.

description:
Did not know of this place until it was labeled as having the best burrito in america. Being a SoCal native I had to see what the craze was about. Ever since moving to SF in 2013 I have not really been impressed with the Mexican food here.

Ok so the article blew this place up and the lines are freaking long. Be prepared to wait a while and get your better half or one of your group members to table stalk while you wait in line.

Ordered a carne asada burrito(dorado style), various tacos , chips and guac, and a water melon fresca.

Burrito was pretty good and I liked the dorado style. Tacos were tasty as well. The guac was probably the best thing there. Water melon fresca was great.

For the price and wait I don't think it was all that great, but it was decent.

I would only come back here if there is no line otherwise you can find me at the other Mexican place on Mission and 24th.
author: Jerry H.

description:
I've been here plenty times and none of them dissapoint. I always get the tacos de carne sada with the crispy tortilla and cheese, beans and guac, + salsa verde. ohhhhh damn!! All the ingrediants are fresh to order and WOW!! hands down the best tacos! 

I travel from Redwood City to SF every so often to get my La Taqueria fix... I dont mind driving because its TOTALLY worth it! 

Just a heads up.. take cash its cash only.
author: Daisy R.

description:
All you need to know is you should order the following meal:

A fresh agua fresca to wash down your amazing taco with half carnitas, half choriza, crispy - with guacamole, sourcream and hot sauce. And pour more hot sauce on it while you're at it.

It hits three very important factors. It's messy, it's crunchy, and it's spicy. The sour cream and guacamole even out the hot sauce but you'll be too busy devouring it to notice anyways.

I love their guacamole because it's just so fresh tasting. Order a side of chips and guac and you're set.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I was dragged here many many years ago by a few friends who insisted that I try the "mission style" burrito and were raving about this place.  Having been a denizen of a state where Mexican food abounds, I was not too keen on the idea of trying to consume a burrito with rice in it (seriously! f'in rice!) and neither did I like it.  But over the many years I have been sold on the tastiness of the components of the food they serve and the fact that you can get burritos and tacos as dressed down as you like.  The carne asada is perfectly cooked with bits of chars enhancing the tasty marinade.  Squeeze of lime, a smattering of cilantro and voila! excellent taco ready to have their delicious salsa's squired on them on the road to the mouth.  The beef tongue is just a prefect cut of meat for a burrito and well complimented by the accompanying beans and guac that i get in it.  I have also come to appreciate the awesomenss of the assembly line in this place.  It is almost worth it to be able to hang in the front and watch the making quesadillas, assembling burritos or throwing together tacos for consumption.  

Lines are always long, but don't freak out about the lines. ..they move fast and all it does is give you a chance to exchange notes on other places to eat with people who obviously appreciate well cooked meats.
author: Sunay P.

description:
So disappointing! Been dying to come here from all the hype and the place wasn't nearly as good as El Farolito a block away. Over priced, small portions, and forgot part of my order. Then no apology but rather a scowl for pointing out their mistake. 

RUN! Go to El Farolito!!!
author: Sabi M.

description:
The regular veggie burrito is pretty much your standard bean burrito for $3.75 (if I'm recalling price correctly). But if you want a proper veggie burrito, which I think was still missing rice it's gonna cost you more than that. Everything else you would want needed to be added on.  

It would have been helpful if the menu stated what comes in the burrito so you would know what you would like to add. And it's gonna cost you if you want to omit the "magical fruit" from your order. The menu states "sin frijoles/no beans" under Extras at I think it was $1.25. My husband usually request to leave out beans but he left them in for this order. 

$15 flat for a veggie (bland) and a chicken burrito (un-memorable). Both were loosely wrapped and thin. Mediocre.
author: Esther A.

description:
Stop #9 on our trip took us out to lunch after a hike in the Marin Headlands.  We knew we wanted to get some Mexican food on this trip and the research said that there was good Mexican in the Mission.  Since we were staying in the Mission it was a no-brainer.  Mitchell took us to one of his favorites and it is now one of ours.

So many reviews for this place.  I'll just give you my quick take.  It is a dive, but sometimes dives are the places that make the best food.  Really good burritos here.  That was Mitchell's suggestion and he was spot on.  A burrito sounded like a good meal after a hike.

You won't find a burrito stuffed with rice here.  They don't use rice.  It is all meat and beans.  No filler.  I had the Carne Asada and we watched the guy slice up the meat on the counter.  Beans and meat.  Meat and beans.  I added avocado to the mix as I like the smoothness of the texture and the clean taste it brings.  The meat was so juicy and flavorful and the green hot sauce at the table gave it just a bit of a kick.  I had a fresh Mango juice to drink and that bit of sweet gave the whole meal some real depth.

I now know where to get a good burrito in San Francisco.  Rest assured that I will be back someday.
author: Dan H.

description: Oh. My. God. This is the taco magic I've been dreaming of since I moved away from San Francisco. Amazingly flavorful pinto beans, fresh fresh perfect avocado, exquisite balance of toppings. The corn quesadilla was wonderfully greasy. And, if I'm perfectly honest, I broke my vegetarianism to eat a bite of a carne asada taco. The juiciness of that taco will not leave me for a very very long time. Oh, and don't miss the watermelon agua fresca. It was a bit on the overly sweet side, but the chunks of watermelon made up for it. Just go, eat everything and be very happy.
author: Neera J.

description: How come You're not gonna have grilled chicken, wheat tortilla nor rice in a taqueria what a shame i have no idea how this place have so many awards. Did they pay somebody to rate them ?
author: Felipe G.

description:
This was our first ever burrito and taco in Mission. Boyyy were they delicious.

I got a regular-sized vegetarian burrito which was monstrous. Nearly exploding with warm bean paste, melted cheese and fresh salsa. My husband and I could've shared one alone but I'm glad he ordered a beef soft-shelled taco because it was equally as drool-worthy!

Disclaimer: We're from Vancouver (Canada) and authentic Mexican fare is extremely rare. We're not experts on latin cuisine by any means.

Five fat stars from the burrito layperson!
author: Najin T.

description: Just drove here and it is no longer open.. What a bummer, was just open 9 days ago according to someone's review.
author: Sean P.

description: Enjoyed the carnitas super burrito, agree that this place does have the best burritos and tacos! Burritos went down smooth as butter, yet you could still experience the flavors.
author: Anil L.

description:
It took me a while to come try this place after I heard about it from 7x7 but gosh it was worth it. I have only tried the crispy carnitos taco so far and haven't tried any other kinds because it's been so tasty every single time. The tacos are quite large and for a small person like me, one taco was enough for lunch. The chips with serrano peppers are delicious but beware of the heat. I thought I could handle spicy peppers but the last pepper I ate did me in and I was literally crying. 

The owner is hilarious and loves to flirt with the ladies, young and old. He's given freebies to my friends on occasion like drinks or the mini quesadillas as well as roses. Service is quick and tables free up quickly so I never had to wait for a table so far to date. There are a lot of alternatives to Mexican food in this neighborhood but their tacos are top notch.
author: Kai C.

description: Finally got around to trying it. At just over $10 for a super burrito, it's a bit pricey. The burrito was good. One demerit for no chips and salsa bar. Another demerit for a couple of pieces of carne asada that had fat/gristle. Major no-no in my book, especially when there are so many great taquerias in the Bay Area. I wouldn't call it overrated, but it definitely isn't anything special. Worth checking out if you're in the area. Otherwise, skip the long lines and crowds and stick with your current favorite.
author: Benny L.

description: Believe the HYPE! Best tacos ever, you should order them dorado style. We were visiting from Puerto Rico and had to try SanFran Mexican food, didn't disappointed! Everything was so good, I was so full and wanted to eat more. Tacos, burritos, carne asada, chorizo and fresca water (I think)... It was kinda full and still the service was personal and very friendly, they did some recommendations and we were very happy with our food. Everyone should try them before dying!
author: Melvin R.

description: Oh man, the line can get long as hell but it's worth it. The burrito isn't human baby sized like most burritos you find in the area but what it lacks in sheer quantity it makes up with in quality.
author: John B.

description: Went to SF for the weekend and were told we HAD to try burritos here. Fortunately we did because apparently they are the best in existence! They had a man playing authentic Spanish guitar and singing around the tables. Another man came around and brought all the beautiful girls (the children) roses. My 8year daughter old was thrilled. The gentleman asked why I didn't order a burrito, I told him I couldn't eat the flour tortilla. He left and came back a few min later with a burrito bowl (everything but the tortilla) and an amazing strawberry drink, on the house.... In a town so busy and seemingly unfriendly, this was a fresh of breath air. Welcoming, kind and authentic. They genuinely appreciate their customers and show it! We will be back next time we visit the city, and definitely recommend this to anyone who likes amazing burritos and awesome people!!!
author: Tresa B.

description: Love their carne asada burritos. I recommend this place to all out of town guests. The place and the folks who work here are nice. The hubby always does a to go here because of the quick service and quality of food as far as fast food joints go.
author: Divya P.

description:
Last time we were in SF, we tried to check out La Taqueria. Well, not this time - place was pretty busy for a Monday evening. We already had ate dinner but my flight back home was ridiculously early the next morning so we decided to get a few burritos to go.

We ordered two pork burrito ($6.75 each) - we ate one and then I had the other one the next day. The burrito was tasty but I wasn't a huge fan of the addition of beans. The burrito was a decent size but I remember when we went to El Farolito, their burrito was massive compare to La Taqueria. 

Anyways, I would definitely have liked to try out their tacos and other dishes but we were just too stuffed. Still a cool spot and busy always means good things.
author: Jonny M.

description: A must try! The staff is friendly, cashier is sweet and makes all the girls feel special lol. Got a carne asada burrito with avocado, dorado style. Bomb!!! Will definitely come back on my next trip to SF. Don't forget to tip!! :)
author: Cara B.

description:
Five Star Food! I have been coming here since the week they opened ( at least 35 years ago). They are the best in the Bay! 
Their carne asada burritos are fabulous; their chorizo tacos are fabulous. I always order an agua fresca, usually horchata or watermelon but they're all great. I choose this place 50% of the time I eat out! And Dianda's Bakery is next door! I highly recommend La Taqueria and it has been chosen the best cheap eats by the Chron forever so it's now permanently a #1.
author: andrea g.

description:
Came in here expecting the best burrito in the nation, which means my standards were set very high given it's a taqueria in the Mission. Alas, I was disappointed. There was nothing special about my burrito, except that the contents were evenly distributed as mentioned by a piece of NPR. I will be returning to my beloved burrito joints in San Jose (no, not La Vic's). 

However, if I were to stumble upon La Taqueria again, there are a couple of things I would do differently, as learned by watching the burrito assembly line behind the counter for 30 minutes:

1) Get a taco. Those huge tacos look amazing and they grill the tortillas in lard for 5 minutes.

2) Ask them to put the burrito on the lard grill for a crunchy outside. I saw some people do this. Why it's not the standard baffles me.


Next time, I'm getting pulpusas next door.
author: Khanh T.

description: The carne asada is a delight. They give you good chips and salsa included with the meal. Horchata reminded me of a churro. Not bad place good atmosphere.
author: Yessirthanks ..

description: I came by and really wanted mexican food, by the looks of how packed it was I knew it had to be good. By the way, CASH ONLY just be ready. I got the super quesadilla with carne asada and the first bite had me sold. It tastes amazing! Looks like my new spot for lunch now :) You gotta try this place if you are in the area. AMAZING
author: Azizah T.

description: Many friends recommended this spot and it did not disappoint. Absolutely delicious tacos. I had chicken and beef, both hard and soft shell. Both were delicious. Upgrade to the super, guac is excellent!
author: Alex B.

description: I've been coming here since the early 90's, long before the hype. I always go for the chicken burrito. It's simple but so well executed with high quality ingredients. Steamed tortilla, juicy shredded chicken, fresh pico de gallo, lightly fried pinto beans, and that's it! With no rice, it's the perfect size and won't leave you wishing you didn't eat the whole thing. The aguas frescas are great too - strawberry (fresa) and horchata.
author: Laura B.

description: This place is the only one where I eat burritos! It is so delicious! I usually get super burrito with carne asada and I eat the whole thing in less then 3 minutes because it's so good! Must try!
author: Margaret T.

description: Ordered the super chicken burrito. It's smaller and pricier than many burritos that you can find on the mission corridor, but pretty good. Big deal about this place is no rice in the burrito. This was definitely the juiciest one I've had in a while. One comment is that I asked for refried beans but got whole ones which I don't care for as much, but still good enough. My favorite burrito is still el castillito on church.
author: Kam L.

description: I came here for the first This place can have a reallllllyyy long line, but the burritos are great. Another customer mentioned that you can call ahead and pickup, so next time I come I will probably do that. I ordered a carne asada burrito with avocado and ate it after walking to Dolores Park. Sadly, it was a bit cold after the long walk, but it was still really good. Next time, I'll eat it right away. The cashier was really nice and handed me a rose after I paid! A nice touch after waiting in line for a while.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
There's a reason why the wall is plastered with accolades that declare La T's excellence.  These tacos are divine.  

I just got back from a massive 5-day food trip with fellow yelper, Rachel A.  She's got a pristine palate that is discriminating towards tasty treats and authentic food.  And she brought me here for the best tacos in town.  

We spent an entire day at the Mission, witnessing the cultural similarities of what I am used to seeing in my own hometown of Queens.  The landscape mimicked the look and feel of Corona and Jackson Heights (minus the 7 train)!  Of course, special and unique in it's own right, Cali's Mission brought to light my experience with Mexican street fare which bore high standards as the food you find in Queens is pretty top-notch.  Especially in a place throbbing with cultural transplants bringing only the best and trustiest of their motherland's traditional staples of tacos, tortas, horchata, and more.  

My order was simple.  Una taco de pollo, and a horchata to wash it down.  My food was served up quickly and warm, and my ice cold beverage with that delicious nod of cinnamon brought me much joy.  This chicken taco was outstanding.  The meat was tender and juicy, the corn tortilla was magically soft yet crispy both at once, and my salsa, as fresh as day.  It not only rivaled the beloved taco trucks on Roosevelt Ave, but may also have, in my regard, have surpassed them.  I had decided two things at the end of that vibrant meal, a) this was the best thing I'd eaten in San Francisco yet, and b) I admitted to Rachael that La Taqueria would be my very first yelp review upon my return back to New York despite all the yummy places we'd visited.  

So, here's to keeping my promise.  

There are many places to grab a taco in the Mission admist all the gorgeous and fun murals and street art lining Balmy and Lucky streets, you may just feel inclined - for convenience sake - to stop into the nearest one you see in your vicinity, but don't make the mistake of skipping out on La Taqeria.  Make that stop to 2889 Mission St., and you too, will understand why they justly deserve every 8.5" x 11" wooden framed praise it has and will continue to garner.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I had two carne asada tacos with avocados. I enjoyed the meat, but all in all, I wasn't blown away.

I know it's not really fair to compare my experience at La Taqueria to my experience at El Farolito (at El Farolito, I had the super prawn burrito, so this is like comparing apples to oranges), but I'm going to do it anyway -- my vote goes to El Farolito for best Mexican food in the mission.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Hands down, the best Tacos in San Francisco. 
The B-E-S-T! 

They are a little pricey, but they are so worth it. 
Go at an odd hour to avoid the long line. People from far and wide come here because of all of the attention this place has gotten on TV. shows (No Reservations and others). 

Get the crispy ones with everything on it. Your choice of meat. And bring some back to Chicago for me. I won't mind eating them cold.
author: Ari L.

description: Great burritos and probably in my top 3 of all time, but probably not worth the "5-stars" nor "best burrito in America" hype. Perfect balance of moisture and cooked tenderness on meats. Asked for spicy, and flavors were somewhat muted and no heat. Be prepared for a 30-35 minute wait during lunch time on weekends due to other glowing reviews.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Their burritos are delicious and some of the best flavor in the area, but they are expensive and small. This place is a banner for the gentrification of the area. Three important aspects of Mission taquerias are large quantities, cheap prices, and being open late. Unfortunately this place falls short in all three. 

The burritos are small enough that I leave still hungry if that is all I order. And after adding up extras like sour cream, cheese, avocado, and extra meat (to make it not anemic) the burrito is $11. They are also a little stingy with the salsa from behind the counter. 

Don't get me wrong, they are very good, but there is a lot of competition for burritos in this neighborhood. And being able to get something 50% larger and 30% cheaper makes it an even harder sell.
author: Michael S.

description: This place is incredible. I've only had one burrito and I'm hooked. I came on a Sunday the last day before they were closing for two weeks for the holidays and it was packed. The line went across the room and wound through the bathroom in the back. We waited for a good 20 minutes before ordering. There are lots of seats, but you have to vulture them, so it's best to come here with at least two people. I had the "super" carnitas burrito that comes with everything. It was incredible. We also had the chips and guacamole (amazing) and two sodas. So two burritos, chips and guac, and two sodas for around $28. And it was the best burrito I've ever had. Super juicy and a wonderful meddling of flavor. I really want to go back right now.
author: Soren N.

description: Place fucking rules because they can give two shits about rice. Rice is for pussies and I'm glad this place feels the same. Been going here for 20 years and can say it's one of the best Mexican meals you're going to get in SF. Awesome salsa and quick service equals pure bliss.
author: brad s.

description: Even at the busiest of times we got our super burritos without much of a wait, and they were damn good! Can't vouch for the healthiness, but would definitely go again :)
author: Adam M.

description: It was the best burrito I've ever ate. Honestly I'm so happy coming from LA I had to try this place. BEST!!!!
author: Ani S.

description: No question. This place is simply the best. Spend less time arguing about that and eat more tacos!
author: Nate M.

description:
Good but not wow
The guacamole was nice but hey its mission I have had better tacos from trucks
author: Maya J.

description: Carne Asada Taco Dorado style. Best tacos I've ever had. Carnita was also good. Tacos are a generous size and two is plenty filling.
author: I Fan L.

description: So had to check out all the hype, ordered a Carne asada and carnitas super burrito. I seen lots of reviews suggestions to add extra sour cream and avocado so I ordered double on both I also ordered a side of jalapeños. When I got my burrito it was so skinny thus made me sad, but I was like whatever let's taste it. It was good....not epic or anything and I was kinda bitter I paid for extra sour cream and guacamole and they didn't put it. I wasn't gonna wait in the Super long line again I just chopped it up as a loss. I also ordered the chips and salsa, salsa is more of a Pico de Gallo, I suggest ordering it with the guacamole that's how most people ordered it. I'm go back and just order my stuff as it comes seems like that's what I will get anyways. Total bill was $46 2 burritos x2 in sour cream and guacamole 2 Pacifico's and one chip and salsa. Think burrito ended up being almost $15 each it's like $7 worth of burrito tho :-(
author: Daisy O.

description:
I'm all 'bout that Taco!

Being part Mexican from NYC, I found it difficult to find tasty authentic Mexican food in the City.  Yes, it has the best Caribbean food and Cuchifrito around but, not Mexican.

After moving out West, I was delighted to find that most Mexican eateries were on the money when it came to flavor and authenticity.  However, I recently found out that all taquerias are not created equal and that taste is not subjective when it comes to La Taqueria.  It is a foodie's oasis amidst the bustling Mission district.  The outside is a typical unassuming façade that belies the epicurean pleasure inside.  The lines are long but, the wait is well worth it.

The best taco is no longer an illusion (for me) and can be ordered by uttering these three words "Carnitas Tacos Dorado"...(cue the choir of angels).  I kid you, not!  The carnitas were flawlessly seasoned and agreeably flavorful.  Who knew hard/soft was a savory oxymoron you could bite into without a contradictory thought. The unfussy blend of ingredients: a soft and hard taco, carnitas, beans, salsa and guacamole were the perfect combination that was anything but, simple. Best burrito in America?  I'm not sure.  Best taco in America...Oh, Yeah!
author: Schimen S.

description:
4 stars. Something about that guac...

If you gettin' anything burrito related - get it el dorado - grilled. Some people say socal has the best mexican food, but La Taqueria...got me feelin' some type of way.
author: Anthony L.

description:
After hearing so much about La Taqueria I figured it was time to give it a try. Unfortunately I came away sorely disappointed. The tacos are a good choice for a light meal and on this trip it was carne asada and carnitas for me. 

The carnitas did not taste very fried or have any crunch, while the carne asada was very bland. The tacos are a good size and very filling because they stuff them with beans, but the beans also mask the flavor of the meats. Added, the Salsa they top the taco with is not very spicy and adds little to the flavor dynamic. 

These were some of the most expensive (3.75 each) and blandest tacos I've ever had. Definitely not coming back.
author: Vince E.

description:
Came here twice to give it a second chance. They seem to be pretty popular, because the line was out the door the first time I came here. I'm not a fan of beans, so the fact that they don't have rice throws off my burrito game. I opted for a Carne asada quesadila this time, but it was drenched in oil. The flour tortilla was very crispy and crunchy, not like how other places make it on the grill. I barely noticed any cheese on it, which totally makes it just a dila. My friends both got burritos and they looked pretty small compared to other ones I've seen. 

This place is definitely catered to a different audience, as the burritos are  $10.50 and incomparable to authentic taqueria food. 

They were out of melon, so I got the horchata. It was poured out of a milk jug, and I thought they were going to add something to it right there because it looked like plain milk, but the horchata was already made and put back into the jug I guess. It lacked flavor and it was awkward telling my guests from out of state to try it and then finding out that the horchata here wasn't that great. It just tasted like sweet milk. 

Next time I'll take a guest to El farolito down the block or san jose across the street.
author: Jessica W.

description:
When I was little, I loved this place for it's mural and rustic seats and the veggie burrito with avocado. As an adult I love their carnitas dorado with cheese, avocado, and sour cream, with drizzles of the green sauce on every bite. I have literally drank their green sauce, it's so good.

It's pricier than other taquerias, but it's still my favorite.
author: Ben G.

description: This place is excellent. It may look slightly sketchy on he outside, but fear not- the food is great. Order your burrito refried for sure. I don't recommend the chips too much though- they're rather mediocre.
author: Tejas M.

description: Love this place! ! Always pick this as my first choice in the mission.   It is crowded all the time,  so if you are on a time crunch,  this isn't for you. It is CASH ONLY,  but there is an ATM in the back if you don't have any on you.   Portions are big,  and everything is made to order.  The burritos dont have rice in them,  but you don't miss it.   I've never been disappointed with anything I've eaten from here.
author: mindy r.

description: Carne Asada burrito super (dorado style) with a side of jalapeño is heavenly. A wonderful spot with incredible food & authentic energy. This is my new spot when I'm in the Bay Area. Truly amazing!!
author: Cleve A.

description:
This is a tourists review. 
The Carne Asada Burrito, El Dorado style, is hands down the best burrito I have ever had. Authentic Mexican food served quickly. The restaurant had flare, life and energy. Gorgeous stuff. I did;nt give it 5 stars simply because it was packed and very loud. but the food was beautiful.
author: Neil B.

description: This place is so clean & their food is delicious!! Great customer service. Even didn't mind refunding my money back because my daughter only likes bean & cheese burritos but made with only refried beans. They do not have refried beans. Nor do they have rice but their portions are giving & so delicious! Their tacos are so good too.  They deep fry their taco shells so it's crispy then add another corn tortilla to the outer layer. We will be back soon!
author: Royal H.

description: In my opinion the best burrito in San Francisco (A popular opinion). Not as greasy as farillito but just as bad for you(meant in the best way possible). The burrito is what I usually go for but the whole menu is legit. Outside of the great food the hot sauce they have is awesome, don't know why they don't sell it. Prices aren't bad but they are cash only which is generally annoying as hell ( tacos a little expensive for what you get). If they can have an ongoing Twitter feed about how much they like the food they can take credit cards. Line is also not too bad, they get the food out quickly. Unfortunately it's a small restaurant so like most SF locations your going to be shoulder with your fellow resident/tourist.
author: Virel P.

description: The carne Asada super tacos are our faves. They are authentic and you have the choice of ordering your tacos regular or "dorado" which means one of the tortillas on the taco are fried and has a nice crunch to your taco. Plus they have all my favorite aguas fresco; watermelon, pineapple, strawberry and Horchata
author: D G.

description:
Five stars just for their special TACOS!! Two stars for the damn price...let me explain the food first...So good, all these years in the mission and I never went for the tacos until a friend of mine invited me to taste his version of the "best tacos" he's ever tasted. And you know what? I HELLA agree! I'm not a very big taco fan but this place just won me over. The special tacos they made had crunchy and soft tortillas with cheese in between them. And they don't skimp on the meat. The carne asada and especially the chorizo where delicious! The green sauce they have at each table is a great combo to the taco. I have yet to taste the burritos but reading the reviews they don't have beans or rice in them... Ummm naw...I'll stick to El Farolito as my burrito choice. 
Ok, so the price..it's like WOW!! DAMN!! WHAT!?? I understand the cash only approach but they charging almost $8 PER TACO! ( and don't count on getting full on only one) You almost may just want to go for special occasions. I may be picky but I grew up in the mission paying less that $3/4 for a taco. This place is charging burrito prices for a great tasting taco. 
But at the end. I would recommend at least tasting the taco once in your life, and if your one of the rich mission heads ( hipsters) you see now a days I'm sure you can afford your daily dose of the mission taco at La Taqueria! PEACE!
author: Jaime P.

description:
You know it's bad taqueria if there's too many white people eating in there. If there's a Mexican Chipotle, it would be this.

Note:
I got hate messages from anons for this review ;) FYI for SF transplants, us peeps who live here long enough (have to) do the white people to non-white people ratio test to see if an ethnic restaurant serves quality food. Usually, it's an indication that the food is bland.
author: Colleen J.

description:
The number one burrito in AMERICA!!!! Question: would you trust 538.com by ESPN to judge an ethnic food like a burrito? If you're answer is yes, then don't read this.

What can I say? Analyzing 538.com and how people might perceive them if they did not meet the general populations fix on a "mexican" burrito then their next ranking will be void. With that said, after consuming the carnitas burrito at the restaurant, it reminded me of a very very very verrrryyyy widely known taste and concept: Chipotlé!!!! It's taste is safe, it's not greasy, it taste fresh, taste good, AND I can also get the same exact taste from a small mexican restaurant chain around my neighborhood or known n the fast-casual world as Chipotle. 

As an avid mexican food truck, mexican restaurant, mexican everything food lover, I look for very distinct tastes. The taste that no one else can re-engineer. A stamp of authenticity that can only be recognized by its own fellow race and to those that know. But for La taqueria's carnitas burrito, it is simply a political correct statement to cover 538.com's butt. If they chose "Jose's Taco Truck", for example, then of course the majority of the people will never tune in to 538.com. ....Have to cut it short... Yeah. I'd rather go to Chipotle. La Taqueria is alright. The line is to damn long. And it's way OVERHYPED!!!!
author: Mike D.

description: I was excited to try this place, but it doesn't even come close to El Farrolito (which is like a 2 minute walk down the street).  The super burrito was really bland and cheap tasting not to mention about $2 more expensive than El Farrolito.
author: Alexander T.

description:
My friends and I have an ongoing debate over which place is better - la taqueria or el farolito. They're right next to each other, and they're both pretty awesome. La taqueria just won an award for best burrito in america, and several of my friends believe the burrito here is second to none. As a vegetarian, I don't find the burrito to be all that special - but most people come here for the meat, so there you go. This place doesn't have that much variety, its pretty much burritos, quesadillas, and tacos - but that's mostly what people are in the mood for, so its worth a go.

Some comments: their pricing is really strange. There've been several times I've order the same thing and it almost always comes out to different prices, sometimes with $1-2 swings for something that averages between $5-7. It's really confusing. Also, they usually have a line and some of the staff can get kinda snappy.
author: Amaresh S.

description: Call me bias but la taqueria ain't got nothing on San Diego burritos!!!! Taco shops are suppose to be cheap/filling but this place is around $11 bucks for a weak and lack luster burrito, I'll pass. Although both the carne asada and chicken was tender it lacked in flavor. I also ordered a pineapple agua fresca that tasted artificial and loaded with tons of sugar. Sorry SF but your burritos just doesn't do it for me, I like my burritos loaded with fries.
author: Julie C.

description:
Not the best burritos since they looked super small so I didn't even go there. But then again burritos aren't even Mexican so.. 
Anyway, almost $7 for a super taco is not bad at all! One taco is just enough, they are HUGE and the steak is the best I've had!! Their agua de fresa is amazing! My bf had to go back for seconds and we even decided to take some back home to our parents and siblings. They loved them also. 
We spent about $100 today on food and it was so worth it.
author: Rosa O.

description:
Disclaimer: I usually write yelp reviews like this  when I'm either exceptionally happy or exceptionally disappointed but that's not the case here. Im giving this place 3 stars but the food is not bad by any stretch nor is the atmosphere or service. The food and service were good. AND the bathroom was very clean. 

Im giving them 3 stars because this is nowhere near the best burrito in all of the USA. Like I said, it's not bad at all. I wouldn't go here again if I wanted a burrito but if I was out w/some friends and they wanted to come here, I'd have no problem buying another burrito from this place. 

Would YOU consider it an exceptional burrito? It depends on a few things. If you're more or less new to CA and/or never really had much experience with  mexican-american food, you'll probably really like it. 

But if you've had lots of experience from various taquerias and taco trucks then you'll be disappointed. I've had some really awesome burritos in my life so I was really expected to be blown away by this place but it just didn't happen. 

So if you're in the area, I definitely wouldn't be against checking it out. But if you're from far away and you want to make a trek out here to try the supposed best burrito in the country, I wouldn't come all the way over here.
author: Awesta K.

description: One of my favorite places in the Mission for a vegi burrito.  Long lines, but they move fast!
author: John C.

description:
Decent (not amazing) tacos and burritos but the price kills it.

We ordered lengua & cabeza tacos, and a chicken burrito with sour cream and guac.  Even though I didn't order guacamole and sour cream on the tacos, they put them on anyway & charged us for it.  Anyway, guac or not there is really no way that two tacos and a burrito should cost $20.99!!!  They are NOT that big.  They're bigger than the $1 tacos that some places have but $3.75 pre-guac (& $5 after) is about 40-50% too expensive. 

Anyway, onto the taste.  Between the lengua and the cabeza, one of them was pretty darn good and the other one was just "meh" but they were both cut the same way so I couldn't tell which one was which.  I think the lengua was the better one.  The chicken burrito was, apparently, good, but nothing out of this world either, and also pretty scrawny.

For how samey this place is as just about every other Mission Taqueria, you'd be better off going to just about every other Mission Taqueria and paying less.
author: David A.

description:
- $11 super burrito with carne asada that was small
- drowned in crema
- no al pastor
- no chips
- did I mention $11 small burrito?

Pure hype.
I'll be going back to Farolito.
author: Boner J.

description:
Meh. I've experienced better.. El Faralito, Taqueria Guadalajara, or Taqueria Los Coyotes just to name a few. 

- Closes early, usually around 9:00pm most days.
- CASH ONLY. Square, Paypal, ApplePay, etc. Get to the 21st century, bro. 
- No California Burritos.
- I thought my Super Carne Asada Burrito (~$8-9) was wrapped by a small child with no thumbs because it was so bad and tasted like that same small child dumped a crap ton of salt in it. 
- The burrito was also really, really wet.. so wet that the bottom of my tortilla was soggy by the time i got down there (~7-10 min later). It was more of like a Washington burrito cause a California Burrito would be extra dry.. You know.. bc we have a drought. 
- Portions are smaller than the above mentioned fine establishments. I had Mission Pie right before La Taqueria and I could have easily eaten to of these so called Super Burritos.
- Parking in the area kind of blows but it gets less bad at night.
- The line was a complete mess. There's orderly, there's unorderly, and there's whatever the hell La Taqueria has. 
- I didn't order a taco but.. who the hell puts beans in a taco? That's not something you see everyday in Mexico.. or Texas.. or LA.. or Taco Bell.. okay, practically anywhere. 
- They have a lot of awards.. I have no idea who they fooled to get 'em.

I REALLY hope this was just a bad experience because this place completely blew. This would be a great place to bring someone you really dislike. Just drop em off on your way to El Farolito (or Mission Pie if you're going the other direction).
author: Chris W.

description: Believe the hype. This place was AH-MA-ZING. Seriously, best burrito I've ever had. The steak inside the burrito was so tender and delicious, and everything else inside was scrumptious as well. I ate every bite of my meal, and even though I was incredibly full, I still wanted more. I can't recommend this place enough!
author: Audrey H.

description:
Found this place featured in Sunset Magazine - this is Michael Mina's go-to place for tacos! His favorite taco is the Carne Asada tacos, and I knew I had to try it too.  

I love the retro feel of this restaurant, it's homey and comforting. The cashier was nice too, he was patient with my boyfriend and I being that it was our first time. I knew I wanted the Carne Asada tacos, but then he asked how I wanted the shell cooked. Soft or crispy? He recommended both - one inner crispy shell, and one soft outer shell. IT WAS AMAZING!!!!!!!! I was surprised that tacos could taste so yummy - it was literally the best of both worlds. Pork, juices and flavors came together perfectly. They were cheap too, my meal came out to ~$10 for two tacos (left stuffed) and a Mango drink, which was also yummy and not watered down.

Can't wait to return, maybe one time I'll get to see Michael Mina!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I am a fan of the food but $11+ for a burrito is a bit much. But as long as all these hipsters keep coming in like sheep, they will be fine.
author: Tommy C.

description:
We waited an hour for an expensive mini "super" burrito that barely had any meat in it. Save your time and money and just frequent your current favorite spot. I wish we had just stayed on our side of the bridge and eaten an actual burrito. 

The ingredients were fresh. 
But there are hardly any ingredients.
author: Mara R.

description:
COMPLETELY SCREWED UP THE ORDER!

WHAT I ORDERED:
1. Burrito#1: carne asada w/avocado and cheese
2. Burrito#2: carnitas w/avocado and cheese and extra meat
3. Chips & Salsa & Avocado (Guacamole)
4. Strawberry Agua Fresca
5. Sprite
6. Dos XX Amber

WHAT I RECEIVED:
1. Burrito #1: carne asada w/avocado (NO CHEESE)
2. Burrito #2: carnitas w/avocado (NO CHEESE, NO EXTRA MEAT)
3. Chips & Salsa (NO GUACAMOLE)
4. Strawberry Agua Fresca (they ONLY thing they got right)
5. NO SPRITE (they gave me a horchata mistakenly)
6. NO DOS XX AMBER

They have become so popular since the 538 write-up that quality has crashed.

This level of incompetence, 538 should take back the award.

Based on visit 2014/11/22 at 6:00 PM.

There's no email address on the website to contact the owner.
author: Edward S.

description:
GET THE BURRITO DORADO STYLE, you won't regret it.

Basically, they grill it. And it's sooo crispy.

The burrito itself isn't an over flowing burrito, but it makes you feel better about yourself if/when you finish it.

The line inside is not that efficient - it kind of snakes around sitting people, but the inside is actually quite nicely decorated and -- JUST GET THE BURRITO DORADO STYLE!
author: Adele Z.

description:
The thing about their burritos.... they're a food experience. The flavors are perfect, nothing needs to be added nor taken away. I can't fathom a more delicious burrito. 

But they are quite small. It's not going to fill up most people, and this is for about the same price as a burrito that would do that. It has no rice, adding to the not-going-to-make-you-full thing. The lack of rice also means this burrito doesn't sit well. If you can't go to the restaurant and eat the burrito right away, get something else there (like the tacos! The tacos are SO GOOD). Sitting will just make the tortilla soggy from the juices.

This burrito may not even be a "true burrito" to some people... but it DID win the Fivethirtyeight Burrito Bracket for the best in the U.S....
Regardless I can safely say their carnitas super burrito is hands down the best tasting burrito I've ever had in my life. Not even questionable. It's flavor nirvana in my mouth. 

You might not agree, and that's okay, many people don't. But it's worth giving it a try.
author: Lydia S.

description: I ate a carne asada burrito and it was the best burrito of my life! This is the best taco place you could ever go to! I loved their hot salsa, too! This is a must stop, a must try once in your life time. Add this place to your bucket list.
author: Deanna G.

description: Came here in recommendations from a friend. We showed up and the place was busy but not packed so that was good. I got the super burrito with beef and patiently waited to my order. Having won best burrito in the country I had high expectations. When the burrito came out it was a little messy (not that I really cared) but it was delicious. The beef was very flavourful and overall it was great. I would go there again if I could while I am here. Does it win best burrito in the country? It was good but those awards are very subjective and after eating it I don't think this is the best burrito in the country but I was definitely up there. Definitely recommend stopping by!
author: S H.

description:
Came here b/c it was considered the "Best Burrito" by 538.com,but i think NOT!!

Ordered the carne asada super burrito dorado style. When I finally got my order, everything from there was just a disappointment...
(1) Both my bf & I asked for dorado,but both did not come out grilled
(2) For a "super" burrito, it was pretty damm small. I've eaten "super",& the first thing I think about is how I am going to hold this massive deliciousness & eat it w/o looking like a pig
(3) Burrito was already ripped & beans were already falling out before I even ate it
(4) Pretty pricey burrito w/ barely any carne asada & other sides in it

Both my bf & I were not full and satisfied,& that's one of the first things we feel after eating a really good super burrito. Overall, really disappointed & would prefer El Farolito or Taqueria Cancun.
author: Trina N.

description:
La Tacqueria's chorizo tacos are the best I've ever had. The long line was worth the wait. The chips were mediocre but the salsa was delicious. 

I felt rushed by the staff when I was ordering. It was frustrating when the woman taking my order messed up my request and I received l one taco instead of two like I ordered. The line was so long I just let it go. Overall, my food was tasty and the restaurant was bustling. I had a good experience but hope to come again during a less busy time.
author: Jamia W.

description: Besides the lady who was rude at the counter the food was so bomb and made up for it.  I will be returning if I ever head back up that was from So. Cal.  The Carne Asada had the best flavor, we do not have that kind of flavor down here.
author: Andrea L.

description: So I am from soCal and its kind of difficult to find a mexican place up here that can compare or seem even suitable to enjoy because many of the places in the Bay area are kind of watered down in flavor, but La Taqueria is pretty good! I wouldn't make the mission to go there because 1, it closes early 2. it's cash only. ITs definitely a place I go to when I spend the day in the Mission area tho. Plus it get cool point because it was the first place my boyfriend and I went to together.
author: Analeigh F.

description:
People please.. Don't wait in a long line at this joint.
The food is not that great and it is expensive by 'Taqueria' standards..
Funny they call themselves Taqueria but their tacos are mediocre, and people mostly order their burritos. 
I can't give Taqueria a low rating, because the food is 'good' at best.. But I would not wait in long lines and spend this kind of money for the food they serve. 

You can easily buy some tortillas, cook some beans, and grill some meat to make the same thing at home..
Trust el cien..
author: Marcus A.

description:
I love this place, but I think they're starting to rest on their laurels. I ordered a burrito, but I forgot to ask to have it done "dorado". The server did not ask me. If I worked at this restaurant, I'd make sure to ask everyone if they wanted their burrito "dorado" or not, since that's what makes their burritos special. 

Next time, I'll make sure to ask for it that way. Or I'll try some of the other excellent burrito places very close by, where you don't have to fight the mobs to get food.
author: Jim M.

description: My friend wanted to try the mission style buritto.  It's rated the best in a bunch of food things.  when I lived here, I pretty much refused to try mexican food in the bay area.  All I heard was it wasn't as good as SD mexican food.  This was our first stop during my food adventure when I visited.  I was starving so I was ready to eat anything.  I just got off the plane and was ready to hang out and have fun!  I think it was pretty small.  I normally can't finish half but I almost was able to finish the entire thing.. but I was hangry so that could be it..  I ordered the carne asada with sour cream.  I had no idea they put beans in their burittos so I had to pick that out.  I didn't see salsa on the menu and was surprised they didn't put it in the buritto.  Just meat and beans?!  Geez.  It wasn't the greatest buritto but it fulfilled my hunger.
author: Chrissie O.

description:
What the cuss, all the fuss, Durango burrito a must, what a bust...oil smoking when frying burritos, tacos, quesadillas, tortillas...grasshopper, the oil is on fire...cancerous, young one, patience grasshopper...

Weak beef, 2-3 beefy level, OK, 10% char for 10% character... just burnt oil smell on tortilla overwhelming...did not enjoy.

Salsas green & red in containers look tired, dull canned color, not alive vibrant color...

Chips too dense/brickish...thin bricks, maybe lighter masa technique, nice blisters though, close but no chip...keep up the blisters, ballon chips!

Proper beans tender skin, creamy, burst of warm stick to yo ribs goodness coating tongue, throat, tummy...warmmy, yummy! Enjoyed beans with fresh generic pico de gallo, just wish had some beefy beef to bring it home, & crisper chips! Not cruchy chipy, ouchy...mouthy...
author: Burger B.

description: The burritos used to be perfect, but the "best in America" award seems to have overrun the production.  They have not been number one for some time.  The quality has really diminished.  And the last couple of times I went, the burritos were not even wrapped properly so that several people at my table were complaining that they were not holding together and falling apart.  Chicken burrito was particularly tasteless.
author: Maureen K.

description: IMO ... this place is way over-hyped. Small burritos at a large price. Over $10 for a chicken burrito with sour cream and guacamole?? On top of that,  the flavors weren't anything to write home about.  For my money, this Bay Area native heads to El Farolito by 24th Bart or to Alameda Taqueria for some hometown love. There you get a good value and they know what they are doing. All you newbies to SF, don't get sucked into the reviews; there are plenty that are better. It's bad enough you are getting ganked so hard on rents ... so save a dollar when you eat. If you like it .. cool ... but  I won't be going back. paz y adios!
author: Jakey B.

description:
Best burrito in America? It was hella delicious but I don't know.... Didnt blow my mind. It was also a little small...? I'm used to a massive in your face halibut burrito from burrito boyz in Toronto and that shit blows my mind nearly every time. 

Flavor was good though, Carnitas seasoned well and great sauce ratio.
author: Samson T.

description:
This was my first visit to this establishment and my last. I do not know why this place was reviewed so highly and known as one of the best burritos in the city. I live by the beach and often frequent Gordo's and La Playa taqueria, both of which are inexpensive and delicious. But I happened to be in the Mission, so I thought I would get a burrito far superior than my local go-to places, but I was dead wrong. Even Chipotle (which I refuse to eat) is better.

 I ordered a super burrito and a horchata to go. It came to be $13. Overpriced.

The burrito was very small, extremely liquidy (to the point where you cannot even put it down without it oozing out), and quite bland. How can a burrito be so bland? It blows my mind.

I would not recommend this place unless you have no taste buds, want an overcrowded place, want to leave still hungry, and overspend.
author: Max R.

description: The food is great! Hands down one of the best Mexican places to eat at . Love the beef man, and always opt for the Super
author: Sian C.

description: Yet another testament to the ubiquity of sloppy Mexican food in San Francisco. Call it what you will, but slop is slop.
author: Inigo M.

description:
What? WHAT?!?!

I came here on a day when i was craving a burrito. It started raining, and La Taqueria was the closest place, so I went in. The line was actually not as long as usual.

First disappointment: No rice. You can't even get a side of rice. It is a no rice establishment. Weird.

Second disappointment: No al pastor. I really wanted some al pastor.

Instead, I got carnitas, which I just found out is what they are known for. I had heard about the 538 business, but I didn't bother to look it up until now.

Third disappointment was when i ate it. Really, it didn't taste bad. All the ingredients tasted very clean. But that's what I didn't like about it. If you're going to eat a burrito, you want a buuurrrriiiiitttttoooo. Grimey. Something that might give you a stomach-ache.

Really, the carnitas wasn't even that good. It just tasted like pork. Some carnitas is really tender and melts in your mouth. Or they make it was a little crunch on the sides. This, really just tasted pork.... not overly tender, but not chewy, not crispy. Just pork.

I was in El Farolito's today, and noticed the clientele are hispanics, hipsters, and rejects and good old plain every day people. La Taqueria's is tech people,  bro's and people who goes hiking every weekend..

Hmm, I wonder which place is better.
author: Bonnie H.

description:
I have been getting my burritos here for over 20 years, loved the place and kept coming back. Unfortunately, for the past six months, I felt the quality of the food and the experience of eating there have gone down quite a bit.  It seems like La Taqueria is a victim of its own success.

Several times we came on weekday for lunch, the line is so long and the dining room is so crowded with people standing in between tables waiting. The prices have gone up and the burritos have been downsized.  What really got me was that we had burritos that were barely lukewarm several times. Maybe the line is long, the cook has decided to shorten the time it takes to warm up the burritos? Not good at all and nothing like it used to be. 

Too bad, I am now skipping the line and going across the street to Tacqueria San Jose where there is never a line and lots of tables to sit at. It has much better salsa and the burrito is hot!
author: Eleanor C.

description:
This place might be crazy. A simple menu and a crowd that won't stop. I was however disappointed (San Francisco taco snob) with the tacos. They were great, maybe just not my style. I don't mind paying for chips, especially when they are good. I didn't go with the same thing on the menu that everyone raves about. I had a chicken taco and a lengua taco. The lengua was amazing, the chicken was alright. One of my dinning companions got the veggie burrito ($3.75) and it looked good. For the price I think its the best deal there. He said it was great.  
Its simple and the menu is limited to tacos, burritos and chips. It's all tasty. Cash only.
author: Ben M.

description: I'm new to SF and have been hearing about this place for awhile, even before I relocated. It did not disappoint. I got the super pollo burrito and a Modelo, and it was exactly what I needed after a long hike around the city on a sunny Sunday. I will definitely be back!
author: Rachel L.

description: Yummy tacos! Totally lives up to the hype. At $4 per taco (regular, the loaded version is extra) it's more expensive than average, but worth every penny. I recommend the carne asada and lengua tacos. They are super tasty and I love the crispy shell inside the soft shell. Really good stuff.
author: Becky L.

description: This place has some of the best tacos you will find. Green salsa on top of the tacos with some strawberry aqua fresca to drink makes an awesome meal. Even their mints are way better than other places. Man do I miss the San Jose location!
author: James S.

description:
Those that know me know I like, nay, love my tacos. This place has the best tacos I've ever had. 

These ain't your normal corn tacos. These are corn tacos that have gone on a drunken bender and crashed into cheese and a grill, and gotten crispy AND soft. And the filling, well, it's legit. Carne sada's what I always get.
author: Bobby C.

description: High price burrito with only meat bean n salsa.  No cheese or rice in a regular burrito.  Don't even include chips. What worst is that they screwed up my order. Ask for refried bean and hot sauce which I did not get . Not a great way to try this on ur first visit..
author: dave w.

description:
Burrito's are way over rated. Meat (carna asada) was tasty but minimal. "Hot" salsa was weak and wet pico de gallo. Off ratio burrito. Also extremely over priced for the amount of foog... AND NO CHIPS INCLUDED?

Taqueria Cancun is worth the walk from here.
author: Nick O.

description: My favorite burrito joint. Huge portions for a great value. There's usually a line but I don't mind. That just says what kick butt this place is. My go to for a burrito fix.
author: Brian W.

description:
For years, I walked past this place but never went in.  A friend dragged me in and I had a chicken burrito, I thought it was just o.k...actually I thought it was terrible. Because there was no rice I found it too soggy and ultimately it made my tortilla taste like a dumpling. 

I mentioned this to another friend who swears by this place and she told me I had to try the tacos.  I am so glad she made me go back!  I have a major love affair going on with their Carne Asada Tacos El Dorado style!  I cannot get enough. 

The flavors are amazing, the steak is perfectly seasoned, and the combination of the soft and hard shell tortillas really do it for me especially cause I hate the mess that comes along with eating a soft taco. 

I know they were voted best burrito but I dont agree!  The magic is in the taco!
author: Keisha N.

description: I love this place. I've been eating here for the last 5 years. My sister asked for a extra salsa and the lady told here "go to the cashier if you want an extra". Like helllllloooo are you serious?
author: Mona A.

description:
Found out about this through a Ch. 5 late night news segment.  The group, I was with, wanted a quick lunch we could simply pick up and go.  Someone suggested burritos and I decided La Taqueria.  Calling in with large, very specified orders, the lady, on the phone, seemed to be on top of it.  Carpooled with someone and went in during the lunch rush.  What was interesting was, while waiting patiently to pick up my order, I heard a live trio of trumpet, guitar, accordion started playing and while in line for food.  As if the place wasn't small enough, they had to play their music in line.  Hmm...trying not to be one to judge, I will assume that is the norm since no one said or did anything.  

Anyways, their burritos: love it; zero rice makes all the difference.  At other Mexican/Hispanic joints (i.e. El Farolito, El Burrito Express), burritos contain a lot of rice, which makes up a larger percentage of the burrito.  Here at La Taqueria, you get the actual filling: meat, guacamole, cilantro, sala, onions, etc. all without the extra rice filling your stomach.  And for a very filling portion, the price is quite inexpensive.  I'm returning for another burrito run next time!
author: Jessica S.

description:
No rice? No problem!
I came here for lunch with my team and ordered a chicken burrito. I didn't want beans...but then I found out there is no rice here either! So basically...my burrito ended up being loads of chicken, cheese and salsa. I'd complain normally but I have to admit, the burrito was pretty darn good. 
They do charge EXTRA if you do not want beans- probably b/c they load more meat in there so overall my burrito came to $9. Yes, its a bit steep but the burrito was really juicy and tasty and thats what my rating is for.
This place was crowded but we were able to snag a large table. Service was fine here also, seems alot of regulars/locals come here. 
The menu is small and choices are limited but the food was good- I'd return again.
author: Miss H K.

description: Ever since La Taqueria was recently named America's Best Burrito, it's been PACKED. And it's usually really busy here anyway, but I mean, there's an even longer line and a battle for a table to eat at. This has been our all-time favorite burrito place though. I'm proud that this place has this newly won title, because they damn sure have amazing food! It's worth waiting in line.
author: Kristina B.

description:
Yes. So much yes. That is all.

Oh, and get your burrito "Dorado" style and they'll put it on the grill for you. It's crispy. It's delicious. It's... I'm drooling.
author: Gabriela K.

description:
Best burrito in the world? Only if "the world" in that particular block of Mission St.  

Ok, it is pretty good. Worth the wait in line? No. Worth all the hype? Not really. Im from LA and there is no shortage of very excellent Mexican food near me. So maybe Im spoiled. Maybe if youre from Ohio and have never had real Mexican food you'd think this is the best, but you'd be settling for just on par.
author: Joseph F.

description:
Good ass burrito

We got the roasted beef with all the fix ins with cheese, avocado, and crispy shell (you have to order the cheese and crispy shell bc they're not gonna do it on their own)

This was one of the best expenditures of 6 dollars one could make in San Fran. THere are a million other taquerias in the mission alone, you would be doing yourself a disservice if you miss this one.

BTW, it was enough to satiate two ppl
author: renje g.

description:
THE BEST!!!! 
They had one of these in San Jose and when they closed it, it was one of the saddest days.  It's been so long since I've been able to have the delicious carnitas tacos.  I'm so excited to go and try their Mission Street location.  I would literally go here day after day after day.  Couldn't get enough.  
- You will not be sorry.
author: Andy C.

description:
I freaking love this place. It's always a treat to come here! Their burritos are fucking amazing. I mean there aren't a lot of places where they pack the burrito with meat and vegetables and don't really use rice. Rice is nice in a burrito but I feel like it usually takes up half the burrito and that kind of ruins it. I always get camera and lingua and the meat is just so tender! The burrito is reasonably priced at a reasonable size!( I normally never get to finish a burrito because it's just so large) and then it gets soggy when I eat it later. And the green sauce - - Oh Ho let me tell you. Just try it for yourself. 
It's a little bit annoying that they do cash only because I'm someone that doesn't like to carry cash. But I mean theyre doing well as a business so there's no reason for them to change.  
It's so worth it if you haven't tried La Taqueria yet!
author: Nancy W.
