I had the sausage and beef burritos and the pork and chicken tacos, they were really good. I wasn't a big fan of the guac, I have had better.

Side notes; method of payment is cash only.
author: C A.

description: Legit Mexican tacos. Bigger than traditional but that's a good thing. The green salsa they come with is spicy and taste good (finally!). The carne asada was good, but the real star here was the carnitas! (But isn't it always)...cash only. Long lines, but they seemed to move quickly. Seating seamed plentiful, and it helps that no one takes that long to eat tacos...fattys...me included!
author: Kris Marie D.

description: $4 for ONE TACO IS A LOT!!!! And a line with always 30+ people yet.....somehow worth it when you taste the juice steak in your tacos and a hefty serving at that. Still plenty room for improvement such as more room to sit and eat, Ravanos, Sevollitas, RICE IN THE BURRITOSSS!!!! and maybe a house Michelada since they already have beer. Still highly like and recommend this place is a must for good tacos.
author: Alfredo G.

description:
If you come here, you should be getting SUPER tacos. And the word "cheap" in relation to mexican food does not necessarily apply here.

I do not understand the hype with their burritos. Yes, it is good. But I paid almost $10 for a "super" burrito not much bigger than a bean burrito at Taco Bell. In my opinion, it was a waste of money. Absolutely nothing special about it at all.

For a little more than $5, you get probably the manliest taco you have ever seen. This is what the lines out the door should be for. It is amazing. Stuffed with all the mexican goodness you can imagine. $5 a taco doesn't seem cheap, but if you have one of these with the green salsa they have, good luck leaving after just having one.

A few things to note about this place:
1. Forget parking. Seriously, you'll have a better chance rolling here than finding parking. 24th and Mission Bart is less than 2 blocks away.
2. TACOS ONLY. If you're not digging tacos, go to El Farlito (even closer to 24th and Mission Bart). They got the quesidilla de suiza which in my opinion is better and more unique than the average burrito here. And cheaper.
3. Be prepared to wait, and wait, and wait. But if it is for their super tacos, I guarantee it is worth it.
author: Justin L.

description:
Very good cabeza, tacos, and burritos. I wasn't as impressed as I hoped with the carne asada, but it wasn't too bad. To get a gigantic burrito (double meat) for $10, one cannot complain too much. I did think El Farolito had a better carne asada burrito though. 

The tacos were perfect. The right amount of onions and beans really complement the large portion of meat they provide. Biggest complaint is the wait time and the high prices of tacos, but I really thought the quality was good.
author: Neal C.

description: This place was completely awful. If you like the taste of undercooked dog fesis, this is the place to be!
author: Edson G.

description:
I can see why this place is winning awards. For under $7 I had a delicious veggie burrito (ask for it "dorado" to get them to put it on the grill) and chips with great salsa and guac. The interior is functional but cramped, but who cares!

Only reason this isn't five stars is because they don't have any seafood offerings. Throw me a fish burrito and I'll be there every day!
author: Marcel M.

description:
Surprisingly good. Bit skeptical and wanted to see what the hype was about.

I got a quesadilla because I like my cheese melted and was surprised to learn they do this for their tacos and burritos, too! There's something about melted cheese that just makes things taste better. And they were very generous with how much these stuffed into the tortilla. Tortilla itself was a nice crisp golden brown and went well with lengua.

My friend got some tacos (one with lengua and one with carne asada). He says he preferred the lengua one.

We also shared some chips and salsa that had a bunch of avocado scooped on top. Chips were different and did not seem like they came out of a bag. I think they deep fried their own chips or something?

All in all, a pretty good place for a bite. Lines were a bit long and costs were slightly higher than what I could get elsewhere.

I'd probably come back again if I'm in the area.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Delicious Delicious Delicious!!! Hands down the best burritos in San Francisco! Yes they have long lines, but once you start eating you forget all about that, because its just so good! Make sure to order your burrito deep fried. Makes it even better! La Taqueria is amazing!!!! See you again soon...
author: Alex M.

description:
If you have not been to this place, you are missing the joy! I love the Carnitas Tacos Dorados.. my mouth waters every time i think about it. I love this place and i would wait hours just to get a taste of it. If you have no patience then you should be there in the morning, also you can call ahead and get your order in.

bests most amazing food ever!

Love it!
author: Anai S.

description:
We live in So. Cal and make it a point to visit La Taqueria at least once or twice when we visit Nor. Cal.  They make the best damn tacos, they are so tasty.  And they are advertised as the best tacos in the world.

They are more on the "wet" side with sour cream & guacamole, and then I drench them in their salsa to complete the tacos.  This would be a weekly regular spot if I lived up here.

BOTTOM LINE - YOU MUST TRY THESE TACOS
You will not be disappointed.
author: Mike H.

description:
Dorado style super carnitas burrito is simply the best burrito I have ever had. 

Living in a neighborhood that offers variety of burrito options, I single out La Taqueria as the best one. Most of the other places nearby have good burritos as well but they overstuff with rice and beans. Not doing this, is probably the most important thing that La Taqueria is doing right, so you can taste what makes this a burrito. 

That being said, I am not suggesting that you should wait in its ridiculous long lines. Come on, there are probably 10 other burrito places within 2 blocks from here. When I feel like having a burrito, I first start with La Taqueria and if there is 30+ people in the line, I make my way to El Farolito, save 20 minutes and still have a decent burrito. Probably you should do the same. If you are bold enough to wait, don't forget to order Dorado style.
author: Gokhan T.

description: I had a vegetarian burrito and it was fine, but it seemed there wasn't much "love" put into making it. It was sort of basic. Still, I would probably come back if I were in the neighborhood. Seating is difficult for large crowds but not impossible with a little patience--seating turnaround is fairly quick. The mints were delicious and a great touch.
author: Marigold O.

description:
This is by far my favorite place to get tacos in san francisco. My favorite are the tacos dorados with carne asada and the fresh juice drinks, especially strawberry . Sometimes I get the flour quesadilla, which is delicious. The cheese is melted so perfectly.  Everytime i got to san francisco, I arrange to have lunch there. 

The only down side is that the lines can be long, they only accept cash and the prices are a little high, but its worth it. I have never left disappointed.
author: M.J. S.

description: I absolutely am in love with the tacos here!! They are delicious, hearty and packed with flavor.  I will be stopping here every time I'm in the area. The people are friendly and welcoming too. I would have taken a picture of them but I devoured them lol... next time
author: Griselda F.

description: This is a true story: My grandmother, rest her soul, once smuggled La Taqueria's Dorados Tacos into Lompoc Federal Penitentiary when a relative was doing time there. She was wheelchair-bound and had them in her lap with a blanket layed across her. It's called 'La Taqueria,' because it's not A taqueria it is THEE ... taqueria. Inside is a sign that reads "The Best Tacos And Burritos In The Whole World." Truer words were never spoken in neon.
author: Tybalt X.

description: I was in the area and wanted to taste the flavors from my once-favorite dorado taco from La. It's now almost $7 for one taco. Bland carne asada, bland guac. No way I'd come back for their now famous, hyped up burrito.
author: Mimi L.

description: Not as good as el faro in my opinion, but is a close second. I enjoyed their chips and guac. I ordered a carne asada quesadilla and it was a tad messy for me.
author: Fernilla S.

description:
I decided to come here on a whim, after hearing about La Taqueria in Five Twenty Eight's Burrito Bracket.

The carnita burrito (super) is as delicious as advertised. It's refreshing to have a burrito without rice, which reminded me of my days in San Diego. The carnitas savory, if a little salty, but combined with the rest of the ingredients, it made for a perfect bite.

I've removed a star because, compared to the glory of the carnitas, the chicken and carne asada couldn't compare. If I go here again, I'll simply go for the carnitas and skip experimenting with other meats. (For the record, my favorite carne asada is at Papalote.)
author: Amy L.

description: I can't believe I had never heard of the "Best Burrito in the U.S." (According to Nate Silver). A friend brought me here for lunch and it was packed. After navigating the line, we were able to put in our orders. Rather than standing around waiting for our order, I hopped over to the Italian bakery next door, and then came back for our burritos. I got the super burrito with chicken and it was great! Very moist, no rice and super flavorful. I was surprised at the cost of each taco, until I saw how big they area. Normally I get tacos at Vallarta, but those are smaller street style tacos. The tacos here are huge and packed with meat - you could probably make a meal out of just 2 of them. I'll definitely be back, because next time I want to try the grilled burrito.
author: caroline y.

description:
No rice in the burritos. Yes. That is the best because it tastes better and you get more meat/beans, etc. 

No black beans but the pinto beans are great. 

Food is sooo tasty. 

El dorado tacos, burritos and quesdillas all tasty delish
author: Charles S.

description:
Grabbed a Carne asana burrito with sour cream, avocado and cheese. Was happy to see this place much cleaner than El whatever-it-is just down the street that folks seem to love, but that made me very ill and still feeling it more than 24hrs later. 

Short line at 3pm, had my food in hand less than 5 minutes later. Staff asked me if I wanted it "spicy". Yes! Sadly, there was zero heat, and I should've asked if they meant flavorful or or hot. 

Lots of meat and toppings, and while really tasty, it didn't wow me at all, this the four stars.
author: Bonny A.

description: Pork taco with avocado and cheese were amazing. Also get a fresh fruit shake. I asked the lady at the counter for a recommendation and she said strawberry and mango. EXCELLENT choice. Fresh fruit pieces in the drink which I love!
author: Janice J.

description:
So I would really give this place 3.5 stars, but I'll round up to 4.

Maybe it was just because I was carrying a heavy bulky bag and was cranky, maybe it was because we had just eaten so the burritos we bought had to be re-heated later and eaten not at their freshest, but I didn't think this place was out of this world. It is a TINY place (like people packed everywhere. If you manage to get a seat, there will be a person sitting next to you and standing next to you as they wait in line to order food).

We did try the taco fresh, and that I have to say was very good, though very messy too! I think I got guac and sour cream all over my face! The burritos, as mentioned we ate re-heated in a toaster oven and they just didn't blow me away. It was nice that they put guacamole in their burritos (normally places charge you extra for that), but does that offset a 20 minute wait? Perhaps I just need to try a fresh burrito. I also saw a lot of people eating their chips, but we didn't order any. Next time.
author: Siri C.

description: This place oozes hype. First off, order management process was amateur. As a result, our order came out incorrectly, missing a pivotal requested ingredient: cheese. I had no way of forecasting this mistake because the order-taker wrote my ticket in hieroglyphics. Couldn't find a seat for 15 minutes because everyone hawks open spots like it's their job. Ended up not being an issue though because they took so goddamn long to prepare my meal. The food itself was good but nothing to call home about. Furthermore, our meal was interrupted by a wanna-be mariachi band who made the eating area even more cramped and inconveniently spaced. To top it all off, there was no clearly marked area to dispose of our trash. Taco Bell FTW.
author: Devin E.

description:
1600 reviews and a solid 4 star rating, must be hella good.........SIKE

I had high hopes going in to La Taqueria but I was also a little skeptical because of the recent mixed reviews. The amount of people there on a Thursday afternoon was a promising sight but everything went downhill from there.

I begin to order my burrito. $5.75 for a carne asada burrito, ok not bad. Then I add cheese, avacado, and sour cream. Total is just shy of $10 -____- really??? For a burrito??? Whatever, it must be good for $10...

We receive our burritos and you can immediately notice the disappointment on our faces. We are all thinking "WOW, we just paid $10 for this TINY burrito". I was still trying to be optimistic but after my first bite I was ready to scarf down the burrito real quick so I can go outside and have a delicious cigarette. The carne asada wasn't bad but I've definitely had better. Some pieces were too chewy and it lacked in the flavor department a little bit. I noticed everybody around me had ordered chips and salsa/guac too so my curiosity got the best of me. Big mistake...$3 for stale chips and salsa/guac when most taqueria's have complimentary chips and a salsa bar. 

La Taqueria has disappointed big time. Cancun has my hear
author: Harry T.

description:
The best Lengua tacquito!

Queue is unbelievably long and the crowds do not seem to mind. 
Amidst the chaos, there's anticipation as you wait for your order and seeing people enjoy their food.

Off hours may be best bet for a better dining experience .
author: Nelce S.

description:
Carne asada burrito, chicken taco & Negra Model combo worked perfectly. I'm not saying it was alone worth the trip from Finland but certainly worth the trip via foot from Union Square! 

Both burrito and taco were very tasty & original, size of the burrito was perhaps slightly smaller than some other places but after eating that combo I was completely full. 

I will keep this place bookmarked in Yelp for the next trip in S.F. whenever that may be. I shall return!
author: Tero J.

description: This was my first time trying la taqueria it was good just not as great I kept hearing about. I ordered two super carne asada tacos. The tasted fresh and definitely had kick. I thought the price was reasonable for the food.
author: Paul D.

description: I've only had one better burrito in my life. Worth the wait in line (which wasn't even that bad - the building itself is just small so it makes the line look longer than it is). Would eat this for every meal
author: Nicole C.

description: The best taco I ever had In my life!!! And am Mexican lol I had the steak dorado taco and my boyfriend had the chicken burrito super dorado style too it was amazing it was defiantly worth the wait if u are ever in your little chicken style life in sf go there please it's amazing the best taco ever
author: melisa r.

description: Because of the popularity from all the media hype they significantly raised prices. I got the super burrito dorado style and it was tasty but undersized. There a lot better values in the Bay Area.
author: Kris S.

description:
Haven't a clue why this place was voted best burrito, it's mediocre at best. I went there today with some European friends who read about the award, and wanted to try it. Sure, why not? I'm often getting burritos in the Mission, and hadn't tried this one before.

As I said, mediocre at best. Squishy and bland (homogenous comes to mind), it reminded of a microwave or 7-11-type burrito, where there's no great distinction between ingredients, it's all just one-note pasty in your mouth. Their salsa selection is non-existent, just the pico and some green hot sauce. The agua frescas were 80% ice, other places served chilled and the ice is minimal or absent. There's only one bean choice (pinto), and even the non-mashed are really mushy.

The burritos weren't cheap, neither were the drinks, and the overall meal wasn't anywhere close to a number of other Mission taquerias, my favorites being Cancun and Pancho Villa. PV is probably my favorite: tasty meat, a choice of beans, TONS of free and different salsas such that you can tailor the chips and the food to your liking. LT offers nothing over PV except an undeserved award.

And to add insult to injury, the burritos are small. One from PV or any one of a number of other places are two meals for me, in fact I plan on one for lunch and dinner later, but the LT burrito is so small I gulped it all down.

We had 4 different burritos, and 2 tacos.
author: Rob C.

description: Finally got a chance to go to the mission district and of course I had to go to La Taquiera. I ordered 3 tacos (carnitas, carne asada, and pollo) I found it weird that they put pinto beans on the tacos but it worked, they made the tacos a lil better than your everyday street taco.
author: Colby S.

description:
I would not have thought it possible to do sub-par Mexican. In fact, I thought it SO impossible that I was actually worried I'd be unable to distinguish between the swarms of Mexican restaurants in SF - an unfounded concern though, as La Taqueria has proven, being the first Mexican restaurant to have ever served up bland dishes to me.

I get a simple cabeza burrito ($6.50), while my roomy orders two of their tacos for $3.50 per. Yet, somehow, I end up with a tacorrito, while he finds himself faced with two burracos. What on earth are these you ask? Well. As we dig in to our food, we realize that La Taqueria's tacos and burritos seem to be faced with an identity crisis. Their tacos, rather than being the small, simple ones you'd normally find, are large handfuls brimming with meat, salsa, and beans. Their burritos, on the other hand, only contain meat, onions, cilantro, and beans, as one would expect of a simple taco. Thus the terms tacorrito and burraco are born - the former, a burrito that is more taco-like than burrito-like, and vice versa.

This, in itself, would not be a terrible thing, if not compounded by the fact that they were both surprisingly bland, necessitating that I drown my tacorrito in obscene amounts of their spicy green salsa - the highlight of the meal, really. So while yes, you're slightly more accessible, cleaner, and less crowded than El Farolito, I shall opt for the latter's tastier, and cheaper (really? $1.20 to leave the beans out?) meal options next time.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I came here with a couple of friends and was immediately overwhelmed by the sights and noises of this restaurant. For starters, the line to order food (dinnertime) was extremely long and extended towards the back of the restaurant! However, there is a lady who stands at the front of the line to start taking orders to facilitate the process. There generally are a lot of people seated either eating their meal, or waiting for their take out -- overall noisy but fun. The decor is also pretty standard -- bright white lights, small seating area. One thing I particularly enjoyed were the vases of roses placed along the ledges. My friend told me that generally when the manager is here, he would hand out the roses to the ladies. I have yet to see this, but what a sweet gesture!

The food itself is scrumptious, despite the higher price. Perfect amount of grease, authentic homemade salsa and guacamole dip! The chips are also wonderfully warm and crunchy. I ordered the carne asada taco, Dorado style (crunchy shell + soft shell combined). Amazing! I am from southern California originally, so I have had my fair share of awesome Mexican food, but this is the best I have had so far in the Bay Area. Definitely will come back!

Tips: bring cash! They do not accept credit cards.
author: Hurnan V.

description: Don't know what's the whole fuss about. Seems like the "gringos" love this place lol. These tacos aren't all that. I make better tasting tacos than the ones they sell here. Did I mention they're overpriced :P
author: Oskar D.

description: Every chance I get to go to the city I eat here I love the tacos with cheese crispy also best aguas frescas around. I've been coming here for 16 years. Price justifies the quality of the food
author: Angie E.

description: Wow, now I am in a bit of a pickle because for the longest time El Farlito was the best burrito to me. But, damnt that burrito at La Taqueria is arguable just a hair better. It a preference thing, and I just can't say one is better than the other. The main difference is La Taqueria does not have rice in there burrito, and they grill there steak on an open flame. El Farlito does there meat on a flat top griddle with rice. Both burrito's are well worth the stop. Now go!!! :-)
author: Goodguy M.

description: Got a super chicken burrito grilled. Fantastic, size is good. Its not hugely overwhelming, but more than enough to be a serios meal
author: Chris W.

description: All I can say is get two tacos, an Agua Fresca--(Eat it there) and get a burrito(to-go!)....Any questions!!!? This place is Legit, it's a one stop shop for some great mexican food. Grab a bite there and you'll see!
author: Jesse C.

description:
SF food is expensive and La Taqueria has met that standard. $3.75 for tacos, and $5.75 for a burrito - which according to reviews only comes with meat and beans. While the tacos were larger than street tacos, they contained pinto beans. Sob. With the exception of the lengua taco - now that was excellent and chalk full of meat, onions and cilantro. I would come back for that. Chips and salsa were $1.30 - chips were tasty, as was the green salsa that was at every table. Watermelon agua fresca was delightful. We stopped in around 8pm and there were a few free tables and spots at the picnic tables. 

But beans in a taco...nooo...
author: Lisa H.

description: It's the best. Order off the menu Taco Dorado Super ( carne Asada is my fave) comes with guacamole, cheese, sour cream & your choice of meat ( or veg if u can't do meat) inside homemade crispy corn tortilla, wrapped again inside a home made flour tortilla so u can hold it. Food Network named it among the 5 best tacos in the country. I can see why.
author: Scott F.

description: My favorite Mexican restaurant in the world. Had a chance to meet the owner, such a nice gentleman. Everything on the menu is amazing. I had 4 of the carnitas tacos, Amazzzzinnngggg!!!!!
author: Telvin M.

description:
Because La Taq needs another review...

I initially wanted to give La Taqueria 4-stars, but realized that was unsupported by how often I eat here. The 5-stars is for the carne asada, which is all I get now. It's tender, juicy, and really flavorful on its own... even better once you add some extras and green salsa. Not sure if they use a different cut of meat, but it lacks the nasty gristle you often find in carne asada. Their flour tortillas also seem thinner and more pliable than other taquerias', and I love love love that they don't put rice in their burritos! 

I've also had the vegetarian tacos/burrito, the quesadilla, and the chips / salsa.... The veggie stuff is great, the quesadilla is too small for what it costs, and the chips are atrocious.
author: seema s.

description: I was watching an episode from food network of top 5 mexican restaurants and this was one of their top 5 after watching it i had to go and try! First off let me just say i love mexican food and my boyfriend and i try every mexican restaurant and this beats all if them! Recently we visited la taqueria and ordered what i seen on tv which was their super taco. Crunchy tortilla with melted cheese on the inside with a soft tortilla on the outside with fresh avacados, sour cream, beans, pico de gallo, and asada. The asada was so tender and juicy i never had anything like that! The price for one super taco is a bit pricey but well worth it if you love tacos like myself and when you take a bite out of it omg u can taste every thing in the taco and you can tell everything was made fresh. Even 3 days after having it &when we came back home to fresno  i bragged about to all my friends how delicious it was &recommended to them whenever they are in sf and wanted delicious mexican food that will leave your mouth watering for days just thinking about it.
author: Jasmin B.

description: Long long line, barely any place to sit, servers very rude, but the food was AMAZING... Literally worth the wait and the shitty attitude cuz the food was awesome and authentic!
author: Zainah A.

description: So confused about this place. ALL I kept hearing is how great this place is and almost 2200 reviews with 4 stars... this tastes like absolute crap. Sorry. Got a carne asada taco... it was LOSDED with sour cream when I said light, then a bunch of Pico de Gallo and guacamole on top... maybe 5 identifiable pieces of beef,a few beans. Nothing had any flavor. Not one component of it.  Watermelon Agua Fresca was good. That's about all.
author: Arpie A.

description: Chorizo burrito is on point. This place seems like chaos due to the sheer amount of humans trying to get their fix. The chaos is tightly controlled and do your part by knowing your order ahead of time. The good news is you can't go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: N A.

description: Ate here for the first time.  It is not what I would consider your usual Mexican taco/burrito place and here is why.... The food actually taste fresh and less greasy than most places.  Because of this the flavors are a bit different but good very good!! Had the carne asada burrito and tacos. A bit over priced but portion are big. I wish I would had read some of the reviews before ordering because the quesadilla looks great.  If you like a healthy feel to your Mexican food then this is the place for you!!
author: Maria V.

description: So unorganized. Everyone is all over the place. Not sure which line belongs where. I wanted to like them so bad since my cousin said its really good. But that was already strike one. Then we get to the front, cashier isn't rude but he isn't friendly either. Its cash only as well but thats fine, aren't most burrito joints cash only anyway? Waiting for the food, 20 orders a head of us. The 2 stars are solely for the wait time, with so many people they tend to serve pretty fast. But thats it, I figured the reason why when I ate the burrito. I come get my order with my cousin & I see its for here so i ask the short guy making the food if i can get it togo. He grabs the food and furiously starts wrapping it & starts talking shit in spanish to the fat lady next to him who then peeks through to look at me? Like wow is it too much to ask for a bag that you have to say shit about me in another language? That was so rude. No other business has ever done that. Very unprofessional. We get home & we open the food. Very sloppily made. So loose all the ingredients are all over the place. Horchata was basically water & sugar. Everyone just goes here for the hype..
author: Diane Y.

description:
I'm giving this place a 3 star because I was not very satisfied with the service the ladies at the counter provided. The food was actually great! Let me tell you, I am a girl who can EAT! 
My friend and I ordered 4 tacos each, the lady at the counter just gave us a look as how she couldn't believe that we could eat that many. She quickly recommended we stick to only 2 tacos each because of the size. I then changed my order to 3 tacos instead. She asked if we were sure we wanted 3 each and kept insisting we stick to 2 each....Um hello? If the customer wants 10 tacos, give the customer 10 tacos!! This is a business after all, right ? 
Overpriced? Perhaps it is. 6 tacos and 2 Modelos, our total was around $40. I usually do not add all the guac & sour cream, because it just makes my tacos messy and soggy, which I'm not a fan of. I was satisfied with the flavor and we did not wait too long for our food and found seats right away. They tacos were actually really good and we were satisfied. 
Funny thing is the ladies we're watching us to see if we really could eat what we ordered. We did. We left bothered by the way we were looked at and felt uncomfortable most of the time there. Don't underestimate the ability of a girl eating her tacos, because we can! Anyway that's all, thanks for reading. It's actually a great place to eat, so whatevss!
author: Crystal M.

description: I pretend to be no expert at mexican food, but I would somehow imagine this place to exist in Mexico. Pretty bare boned but the food is good, the portions are large, it is quick, and unbelievably cheap. I tried the beef tongue... checked it off the list, probably would never order that again. The shrimp tacos and the chorizo were delicious! Stop in for a quick bite as you explore the rest of mission neighborhood.
author: Kelley D.

description: La Taqueria definitely lives up to the hype - definitely the best burrito I've ever had.  The restaurant itself is a "no frills" hole in the wall, and the line snaking out the door can be intimidating - but I assure you it is worth the wait.  The line moves pretty quickly and once we ordered the wait for our food was only about 15 minutes.  Burritos are "traditional style" which means there is no rice, and absolutely melt in your mouth. Make sure to order your burrito el dorado style or crispy, and the outside of the burrito will be perfectly fried. I had the carnitas burrito and the people I dined with had the chicken and we were all delighted with our food.  The only thing that I didn't love was that none of the people preparing the food were wearing gloves and there were piles of raw meat sort of hanging out, which seemed like it could be a health code issue...as long as you're not a germaphobe you'll love this!
author: Julia G.

description:
We sat at the communal picnic table and ear hustled on the family next to us:

Mom: Wow, I'm going to go home in 10 minutes and write a YELP review about this place. 

Daughter: They already have like 1200 reviews on YELP.

Son: Yeah, YELP said they don't put rice in their burritos.

Daughter: Yup, everyone on YELP says they load it up with meat.

Mom: Well, YELP got that right.

YELP, YELP,  YELPITY YELP YELP... OMGG im gonna hurl if I hear YELP one more time. No offense to you, Yelp, but I'm just trying to enjoy this crazy delicious taco without hearing from the Yelp peanut gallery. 

Lucky for me, however, YELPITY YELP YELP did not disappoint with empty promises of belly-gorging good eats. 

La Taqueria delivered on both quality and quantity. But I guess authenticity also comes at a sweet price. 

The base price for a regular taco is about 3 and some change. You want guacamole/avo, sour cream, or cheese?? Say yes and just know this ups your taco to about 5 and some change, which may sound like a lot for the Mission where any given taqueria is within throwing stones distance, but it is well worth it for flavor and size. 

One taco is almost equivalent to the size of a regular burrito!!!.. esp when they're replacing carb-filling rice with MORE MEAT!!! Carnivores get your fill on!! One can feed a hungry lady and two can put a hungry bear into a bear coma. Regular tacos are comparable to "Nick's Ways" at Nick's Crispy Tacos or the Taco Shop at Underdogs-crispy shell wrapped with a soft taco but simply and truly more fatty and delicious. 

MMMMmmmm..
author: Angela W.

description:
Came here pretty late on a Friday night, which may have altered the experience for the worse, but fortunately the food was a standout above all other BS going down. 

To the chagrin of my meat-eating comrades, I ordered the veggie burrito ($3.50) and a horchata, and was in no way disappointed. Great tortilla, cheese and beans that melted into a magnificent mariachi symphony. The horchata was neither watery nor the texture of cement. There were some hyphy douches smashing their bottles of Corona all over the ground/ my legs/ my bag, but to hell with it. Nothing comes between me and a solid burrito. 

Despite my best interests, I'll probably be back.
author: Laura B.

description:
My parents introduced me to this place. This is their favorite and a pretty good one for me as well. Their meats are fresh and have a ton of flavor, as well as their salsa and beans. 

One thing to note about this place is that their burritos do not have rice, which gives it a more authentic taste but may be too drastic of a change for folks used to rice in their burritos.

It's always busy, which is a sign of how universally appreciated the place is. Workers are friendly, music in the place is good (they have a jukebox you can select songs from). 

Two downsides: parking can be difficult since it IS the Mission and a block down from 24th; the establishment is cash only, but they do have an ATM inside should you forget your cash.

The bottom line: check this place out! There's a reason why it is always highly rated for Zagats as well as top 100 restaurants on a yearly basis!
author: Jasmin B.

description: I cannot figure out what they hype is all about -- it's a fairly middle of the road taqueria, with none of the amenties (salsa selection, extra chips, limes, etc) available at other, cleaner, faster, quieter places. But I'll come back to see if maybe this was just an off day. I had a carnitas burro. The carnitas were "OK', underspiced and too finely cut. The guacamole was scarce and the 'crema' was that fake chemically tasting stuff. It's an assembly line of ingredients, and the one-size-fits-all  tomatillo salsa isn't that interesting. For the time being, Can-Cun is at least 50% better, but Taqueria La Favorita at Harbor Blvd in West Sacramento is El Rey de las Taquerias
author: Roland S.

description:
It's good enough to eat, but there's nothing really remarkable about this taqueria. Just one more moderately good taqueria in the mission. I'd go back, but I'd not go out of my way to get here. I'd eat here again if I were hungry and standing in front of it. 
Again, nothing really wrong with it, but nothing exceptionally right, either.
author: Sam Z.

description: THIS is THEE best damn Taqueria I have ever been to!!! Never in my LIFE have I had a taco THIS good!!! No wonder it is simply known as "La Taqueria"...Because it is MORE than worthy of that name, as it is the center of the Taqueria food world, hands down!!!
author: Spike D.

description:
Best burrito I've ever had cold. First off I do not normally even like burritos. I LOVED the carne aside burrito from here. (I got it without beans and it doesn't have rice inside which I don't like either)

Okay okay why did I have a cold burrito? I was hungover as hell, one of those I knew if I attempted to eat I would hurl it all back type hangovers but I was here with a friend who always raves about this place so I knew I had to try some. I had a taste of his carnitas taco and mannnnn was it a taste of heaven even in my hungover stupor. I had a bite of his burrito too and I was SOLD. I had to get my own to go and even if I couldn't enjoy it right away I knew I'd be sad if I didn't get one myself. 

The burrito is the truth, because even cold it is bomb.com and their chili verde is the TRUTH, like crack so addicting but for sure has a strong kick to it of spicy ness.

Normally I'd get tacos but anything here is good. A little pricy but well worth it. I'll be back next time I'm home la taqueria!
author: elena t.

description:
La Taqueria, huh?  That's what you call the place.  Well, I guess that means no one is rolling in expecting crepes.  

Honestly though it's hard to improve on this taqueria.  Mostly just basic items are offered (taco, burrito, quesadilla), but these items are DONE WELL.  

Every component in the I had burrito tasted FRESH.  Pico, guac, carnitas, all stood out without too much rice/beans filler.   The quesadilla as terrific.  Don't miss out on the table salsa verde. That stuff is special...a perfect blend of serrano and tomatillo flavors. 

This place is a machine cranking out food for lines of people.  You can see the workers, busy bees making big bowls of pico de gallo and the like.  I dunno what else to say.  Get some!!
author: David O.

description: The bad reviews for this place are hilarious. These are the best tacos, but you must order dorados style which will have crunchy shell and chesse melted on the crunchy shell. STOP being a Damn women people and order asada, carnitas, or chorizo for your choice of meat. I love hearing people say this place isn't good. Reviews like, "there's grease in my chorizo burrito." LMAO chorizo is greasy get over it, the flavor of the chorizo here is AMAZING! Oh you didn't like your taco? Yea, probably because you're a picky eater who didn't get everything on it. Taking an ingredient off these tacos is like running a car without a major part! YOU NEED IT ALL !!!! Oh your burrito doesn't have rice? LMAO real burritos don't have rice anyway .. Take your broke ass to the taco truck and get a burrito that's filled with all rice for $4.00!!!! ANYWAYS, I usually only order tacos anyway because they are just too damn good to get anything else! Price is not an issue when eating AMAZING quality!! Some of the people who wrote a bad  review really need to reconsider their look on life. I mean there is a million places to get a burrito or taco in the Mission. Yes, I understand some customers are there for the "hype," but most have had it before and continue to come, so there is a reason why when you walk down the mission you notice every place with empty tables everywhere! Maybe you should give yourself a 2 star rating on your judgment of Mexican food. BOO BAM BITCHES !!!!
author: Michael V.

description:
I gave five for the food. I dream about their tacos. Even writing now I'm thinking, when can I go back there. 

It gets busy so get there early or you'll be standing around enjoying your taco.
author: Ashley W.

description: Hands down the best burrito I have had in SF.  I was a bit apprehensive after I read all the hype (538 blog) but this definitely lived up to it in my opinion.  Get it dorado style if you know whats good for you (wrapped and grilled), you can justify it since there is no rice.
author: Reh M.

description:
Tacos tacos tacos...

I'm usually known to inhale a super burrito but lately I've been all about the taco...

It started at the original Nick's Crispy Taco on Broadway...

Then it was Nick's Crispy Taco @ Underdogs on Irving...

Now it's all about La Taqueria...

The tacos here are like a street taco on steroids because they're MEAT-HEAVY with a tad of beans and pico de gallo...

The taco is packed into a crispy shell taco and then wrapped in a soft tortilla for reinforcement... 

Two tacos here usually do the job. The carnitas and carne asada set the bar...

Forget the burritos, enchiladas, quesadillas, etc. and stick to the tacos...

Sorry Nick... you're crispy tacos are good but La Taqueria's are great...
author: Brian L.

description:
Never had a burrito still.. I hear they're amazing.
Saving that for round 2 in a few years... 
Been sticking to Dorado style Carne Asada tacos for as long as i can remember...

Staff is great...especially the owner Miguel.
author: Crumbs C.

description:
The rumors are true. This place is the best. I've had El Farolito, Taqueria Cancun, and many more up and down the Bay area. This is a QUALITY burrito.

I'm an al pastor fanboy and felt like I was settling when I chose the carne asada super burrito (added jalapenos). The carne asada wasn't the most tender I've ever had, but it was packed with good beef flavor and had good texture. What sets this burrito apart from the rest of the pack was the fact that I could distinguish (and relish!) each individual ingredient (cilantro, avocado, beans, etc.)  in every bite.

My only complaints: no late night or al pastor

TLDR: Tops in ingredient quality and flavor, no late night, menu is slightly limited
author: Jesse L.

description:
There's a reason the carnitas burrito has received accolades in the likes of Sunset Magazine and beyond. It's that good. Also tasty was the veggie burrito. 

Cash only
author: Lee H.

description:
At last, I've found it:   AWESOME Mexican Food in the Bay Area that equals what you find in SoCal!!

I just had lunch here after searching for what Yelpers voted best Mexican food in San Francisco.   When I read that they had crispy quesadillas, I knew I had to check La Taqueria out.   Boy am I glad I did!

We came here with my wife and son and we ordered a sick amount of food:  One Flour Quesadilla with Chorizo, Guacomole & Sour Cream, One Chorizo Soft Taco, One Chicken Soft Taco, Chips & Guacomole, and one Cheese Quesadilla for el bebe.    The owner asked my wife what had brought us there.  When she told him we found them on Yelp, he gave us a crispy carnitas taco to try for free.    To repeat, we ordered a *sick* amount of food!

My favorite was by far the chorizo quesadilla.   I just had a crispy quesadilla down in San Diego last week and the one I tasted today was just as good as the one I had 500 miles South of here.   My wife's favorite was, incidentally, the carnitas crispy taco.   I thought it was awesome as well!

Service was friendly and food was Booya!  Good...   I'm so coming back here and I'm definitely adding La Taqueria to my list of top Mexican joints in California.
author: David O.

description:
Hi, yes, is this thing on?!

:::get's down on one knee:::

La Taqueria... Will you marry me?

#nomnomnom
author: Lauren B.

description:
ordered a carne asada super burrito with all the fixings (standard for the course). enjoyed it greatly, but found myself wondering if i should've opted for a quesadilla or torta instead. the burrito is not quite as fat as i'd hope for $10.

pro tip: call and order ahead, then swoop right in at the designated time for pickup. you'll avoid a long, completely unnecessary line.
author: Cyrus L.

description: I'm from LA and I was expecting this spot to not be so good, but! It was actually a very good burrito, I ordered a steak burrito and I had no complaints, I definitely recommend this spot to anyone looking for burritos.
author: Dre s.

description:
I have no idea what the people who say the food here is not amazing are talking about.  I've been eaten tacos & burritos all over the Bay Area (mostly in SF) for over 30 years and there are few places that even come close to being as good as La Taqueria.  Sure you can go to places like Pancho Villa or El Faro & get much larger burritos for a little less but they don't have even half the flavor of La Taqueria.  

First La Taqueria burritos have no rice in them which everywhere else uses and is usually bland & causes the burrito to be too dry.  Yes I know I could have other places just not put rice on it, but they don't replace it by putting more of something else on it making their burritos smaller.  Yes La Taqueria's burritos can be a little smaller than other places but it's because of that lack of rice that their burritos are juicier and more flavorful.  It's a case where less is better.

Second ingredients.  Everything is always super fresh especially the pico de gallo & guacamole.  The meats are all top notch and the sour cream is the best of any please I've ever been.  Some many other places use watered down sour cream, add fillers to guacamole or can/jarred salsas.  To me Mexican food is like Italian... It is at its best when using very few ingredients and making sure what they do use is fresh & the best there is.  That is what La Taqueria does.  

Third their tacos.  The amount of meat they put in their tacos is unreal.  Again just real good ingrediants and tons of them.  A little bit of pinto beans, a ton of meat, a huge scoop of pico de gallo and add some of their salsa verde.  Yes at $3.50 they can be a little pricy but for me two of their tacos for $7 is more filling and tastes way better than a $7.50 burrito somewhere else.

Fourth the price.  I won't argue that it is cheap, but for me I'm happy to pay for what I get.  Yes a burrito with everything on it is $9; however most other places are charging $7.50 or $8 for a super burrito which doesn't taste nearly as good.  For me I'd rather spend a little more to get something that to me tastes way better.    

Let's compare prices between La Taqueria and another Mexican place a ton of people swear by, Papalote.  For a burrito with everything at La Taqueria it's $9 & at Papalote it's $10.10 for a fully loaded chicken, steak or pork burrito.  As for tacos at La Taqueria it is $7 for two tacos which is cheaper than $7.95 at Papalote.

Just about everyone is biased to like what they grew up with yes there is some of that in this case.  For me though, La Taqueria always uses freshest ingredients, always has flavorful, juicy, tender meat & gives you more meat than other places & for me has the best salsa verde anywhere.  Also the aguas frescas are the best!  The Fresca (strawberry) is one of the best drinks I've ever had.
author: Tim B.

description:
Likely I will never return to La Taqueria, not because I got food poisening, its just that there are other places (close) that do a better job at serving up Taqueria fare.

Yes the joint was packed, but the carnitas burrito wasn't packed. Carnitas & some pinto beans wrapped in a cold flour tortilla. Taqueria food - basic - not complicated - quickly assembled - south of the border comfort food.   Burrito was smallish compared to American versions which are pregnant with burrito-ness ingredients.   On the other hand (and to some folks a positive), much closer to the renditions found in Mexico. One star for cultural connectedness. Want rice in it...more peso's, want avocado...more peso's, want black beans...outa luck.  Want more than the annointed green hot sauce... bring your own. Want a condiment bar with the pickled jalapenos etc., go somewhere else. Almost as if they have wrenched out every peso out of their cost of food. I am surprised they don't charge to use the restroom.  Ok, maybe I shoulda ordered their "super" version or requested the ingredients I wanted ... but didn't know they were not included with the "base" model. Maybe the "super" upgraded version woulda made me super happy.

Where I would go with Taqueria pangs (which don't appear very often):

Los Coyotes: http://www.taquerialoscoyotes.com/  which proclaims: "The best burritos, tacos, nachos in San Francisco, California." Which if not completely true, is within a modicum of true, which is sorta a rounding error.  

I kinda felt there was nothing to draw me back to La Taqueria. The name is as stark as their food. Not a particularity persnickety person, gotta pay to play but gotta expect the value meter registers whether you be laying down poquito or grande amounts of dinero.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Came here one night wanting to try something new. 

I found the place to be expensive compared to all the other burrito places and it's no frills. When I order Mexican I always expect the works! Salsa, sour cream, guacamole/avocado and cheese. They only serve the basics and everything was additional.

I do feel like the meat quality is a bit better compared to the other places and the quesadilla was really good, but I'm still loyal to Taqueria Guadalajara.
author: Zu W.

description: Southern California has the best Mexican food without any real competition. However, this place did not let me down. Also caught a low rider show one time here. This is a regular spot when im visiting
author: Marco L.

description: Its just a hyped up Taqueria. Nothing really special about this place. The burritos have no rice and i guess that is why this place has this hyped up image  of being so great. C'mon any taqueria would do that if you ask them. Personally my burrito was cold and i was kinda dissapointed after shelling out $13 on meal that was less than filling. The only good thing i liked was that they fill their salsa bottles halfway so it gives me a sense of salsa being fresh. Oh and another thing chips are not free, so dont expect them to come with your food if you don't order them prior. Wait time is a drag. The line is crazy long. I give it two stars because their bathrooms were cleaned and they have tables outsid where you can eat.
author: John W.

description: Great tacos. I like how the cheese is melted on the lightly fried tortilla. A little overpriced.
author: David R.

description: omg this place was amazing there burritos and tacos are amazing and they have the best drinks ever definitely would recommend this place!!
author: Aksh V.

description: $20 for two small soggy burritos?!?!  Bullshit. Only comes with meat, beans and rice. They charge you extra for sour cream, avocado and cheese. Asked for chips and they said that was extra too. WTF??!! Burrito was ok, nothing special. Will never ever go back again!
author: Nadia G.

description: Mediocre tortillas kill the good flavored meat. At over $6 per taco if you want guacamole, these are way overpriced for what you get
author: Tommy C.

description:
Was so thrilled to see that this place took the #1 spot for best tacos in the country, according to some dude on some website. 

http://www.thedailymeal.com/50-best-tacos-america-slideshow

But seriously, this has always been my favorite Mission taco spot. Food is always super fresh and delicious. I love a bit of tongue once in a while (heh), and believe that the mark of a good Mexican place is a delicious lengua taco. Theirs is my favorite - the meat is unbelievably tender and the flavors complex - it tastes homemade and simmered for hours with all kinds of goodies in the pot. The carnitas (cooked in vats of lard- how can you go wrong?) and carne asada are also great. 

Service is super fast. Love loading up on the green squeezy bottle sauce. And yes, I'm 98% sure that's the actual name for it. Cash only is boo, but I'll live.
author: Selina K.

description:
I want to apologize to La Taqueria and my boyfriend (who is heartbroken by this) in advance. But here we go.
_____

I am very upset. And it upsets me to write this post because I love what Taqueria stands for and I love supporting local eateries. 

That said, I just wrapped up an awful Taqueria experience. I'm a taco salad girl. I hate myself for it, I want to be a steak super burrito girl, but (as basic as it is) I'm a taco salad girl (at least I admit it). 

Tonight, however, I was feeling wild. Tonight was burrito night. I was stoked. I ordered a veggie burrito, dorado style. Again, I know that (the veggie) was my first mistake. But 1) I thought dorado made up for it and 2) I usually get "veggie" related dishes at other Mexican establishments (El Metate, Papalote, etc.) and the vegetables are delicious. So I figured I would go for it. 

Get home, unwrap the first half, see the burnt dorado edges, start salivating, take my first bite. Delicious. Take my second bite...where are the vegetables? Frantically unwrap the burrito...no vegetables.

Now this is false advertising. How can you make/sell a "veggie burrito" with 0 vegetables in it? It was beans, and salsa. Again, I realize not ordering a meat was my mistake but still. This should be advertised a bean, or vegetarian burrito. Not a veggie burrito. Big distinction. 

So half a flour tortilla, some oil, and some pinto (not black...another bummer) later I am far from satisfied. Accusingly emotionally charged, but I think it's justified. 

Side note: The salsa was also very spicy (which I'm all for) but with no flavor. 

El Metate wins my heart.
author: Morgan B.

description:
Absolutely one of my favorite places to eat outside of the Mission. I've been coming here for years and it never has disappointed me and they're open late which is great cause I'm always out late. The portions are decently sized, I always leave full and most of the time I finish all my food so it's perfect. 

I highly recommend this place if you're downtown and are looking for some good Latin food. 

Small hole in the wall restaurants win my heart over large chains any day. Keep up the good work La Taqueria!
author: Krishna V.

description:
Fantastic tacos. Enough said!

The line can get pretty nuts in the late afternoon, but table turn around is good. Definitely need to check out the crispy next time though :)
author: Jason K.

description:
I expected more from a place which is supposedly the best Mexican restaurant in San Francisco.

Burritos here were tiny compared to what I could get somewhere else for the same price. They're tiny because they charge extra for basically every other thing in the burrito other than the meat. I know some people would argue that pound for pound, this place would beat out any other place, but this was just not true for me. When I can just walk two minutes away and find another place of equal or better quality for less money, you need to step up your game.

I'm not saying the food itself was bad, quality-wise it's just not anything special and quantity-wise you certainly don't get a whole lot of it.
author: Allen C.

description:
I live 2 blocks away and am an avid taqueria visitor.
They have my favorite carne asada burrito in the whole mission- very juicy meat very flavorful.... their chicken burrito...not as good-the chicken is very bland, but not dry at least. 
Their "crispy tacos/special tacos" whatever tacos with the soft shell on the outside and hard shell on the inside...I was extremely disappointed. Just something about that hard shell really threw me off. Tasted stale and over powered every other flavor in the taco...literally could only taste the taco shell and the sour cream...subtle hints of the carnitas and none of the carne asada. And it's very expensive- over 6$ each one. I wouldn't care if it actually tasted good. Waste of money. 
I will return for my favorite burrito and that only!
author: Gen G.

description:
Came because I was in the area and the reviews, but a little disappointing.  For almost $9, I was expecting the burritos to be bigger, and maybe come with chips, or at least a well stocked salsa bar, but the Super burrito was pretty regular sized, and no chips, and no salsa without paying extra....  taste good, but just not as filling as I expect from a good Mexican taqueria... 

Maybe them city folks are watching their weight more than us East Bay people, and make more money than I, but I can definitely get a better deal and same good tasting burritos elsewhere.
author: lawrence l.

description: Good ingredients. Overpriced for the size of the burrito you get. Large crowds waiting for seating and they only take cash.
author: Karla C.

description: Hyped? Yes. Life-changing? To-die-for? Not if you eat at taquerias regularly. But what they do here, they do very well. Their longevity and reputation is due to their consistent quality. Please do get the crispy taco or crispy burrito, that extra texture coupled with the fresh flavor of their food makes for a tasty meal.
author: Andrew L.

description: Best tacos in the world. Their sign doesn't lie. Julietta and Miguel are the best, actually I really love the whole crew but don't know all of there names. Been coming here since 1987. Order a fully loaded crunchy taco and a strawberry fresca!
author: Monique M.

description: I dream of this place on the regular in NYC. It is the best mexican I have ever had. Plot twist... Pork quesadilla is insane and my number uno, really couldn't believe it. Worth the wait and still feels like your in San Francisco, not rich tech land.
author: Dustin H.

description:
La Taqueria was pricier than what I expected for a taqueria in the Mission ($5.25 for a burrito), but compared to the real world where you're paying $6+ at Chipotle, it's not a bad deal.  The carnitas burrito is moist and delicious, but very drippy, so beware if you don't think tomato juice looks good on a pair of khakis.  

The mango agua fresca is more a thick juice than an agua fresca, which is not a bad thing at all.  They don't put much ice in it, and there is a thickness and pulpiness to it, but it is wholesome and refreshing!
author: Christina G.

description: Even as a vegetarian, this place his the spot! The tacos are crunchy and full of fresh guacamole. Line can get long and the seating is often tough to get.
author: Mia F.

description: Fine burritos, but - hey, Nate Silver! - hardly the best in the country. Far better options in the Mission, even. The line moves fairly quickly. But CASH ONLY, which is enough of a reason not to waste your time.
author: John D.

description:
GREAT GREAT GREAT PLACE 

Came in yesterday for lunch with interns and Robbie. We were gonna go to el faro, but there wasn't any space to sit. We quickly got a table and got in line. The line was long, but moved rather quickly so don't be too intimidated by it! They had a ton of different meats I want to try, but I decided on the carne asada since that seemed to be the most popular. They had cabeza and lengua too!!! I really want to try those.

The burrito was a really good deal. It came piping hot and was huge. It was the size of my forearm, maybe larger. The burrito itself was amazingly delicious. There was no rice in it, but Robbie explained to us that rice is just a filler for the burrito, so instead of rice you get more meat and salsa and beans...the good stuff. The carne asada was excellent. Savory tender and very meaty. There was so much meat juice in the burrito. Sooooo good and they had green salsa at the tables to squeeze over it to give it another salty salsa kick. Yummmm. They even had a dude playing a guitar for some live entertainment! They also had strawberry soda which Robbie says is tasty.

5/5 I'm definitely coming back to try their other meats and their strawberry soda!!!!!
author: Ernest C.

description: This place deserves 3.5 stars but Yelp doesn't allow it not sure why. The food here is ok not bad or anything special. I would have given them four stars but not with these prices. Also, first time I had a carne Asada super burrito with no rice. Which is customary at La Taqueria. I would only come back here if I had to. I definetly feel there are much better places in the mission for Mexican food.
author: Khalid R.

description:
yessssssssssss....

perfect for those late night munchiess.
author: Shana B.

description:
If you have eaten in the mission for the last 15 years as much as I have-- you already know this is the place to EAT!

I work in all sorts of places doing beverage installations, meeting with customers, etc. You dont want to know the things I've seen in the kitchens!  

This is not one of those places!  Clean, organized, and some of the best food you can get-- and for a good price.

I need a burrito.
author: Sky P.

description: Dorado taco is the bomb! Burritos are yum too but dorado burrito is also a must! The line here is always long and the service is fast-- t'was worth the wait & worth the price! Location is Mission St & parking is the challenging part. It's worth to eat here coz this place is the BEST Taqueria in SF! If u haven't been here yet, you are missing out!
author: Bhonz Z.

description: This place is every bit as good as the hype.  You do have to stand in a long line which on a hot day is tough. But it is oh-so-worth the deliciousness waiting for you at the end.  Get the burrito, el dorado style (which means grilled after assembly).  It just kicks the fabulousness up an extra notch.  Pair it with a beer and you have the most perfect meal.  I'm a burrito snob (who are we kidding, I'm an everything snob) and this place is heaven.  Better than sex. Treat yourself.
author: Discretio ..

description: The crispy tacos are the best.  They have a vegetarian too! Sooo good. The vegetarian is filled with salsa, beans, cheese and option to add avocado or sour cream. Tacos are large, 1-2 is usually enough.
author: Jenny G.

description: Definitely a really great carne asada burrito.  Their watermelon agua fresca was also delicious.  This place was packed though, so we ordered our food to go, and the ladies taking orders were super quick.  Overall we were in and out in 15 minutes.
author: Sofya P.

description:
Occasionally, I have the most bizarre cravings. For awhile, guacamole and authentic Mexcian food has constantly been crawling in the back of my mind. So when my friend and I were in the mission district, we both insisted on satiating ourselves with some real deal Mexican food. To our luck, La Taqueria was still open and so we quickly took a seat and ordered before the kitchen closed. And HOMG, their food tasted AMAZING. I'm partially torn between whether we were just hungry and cold or if the food was as heavenly as I had imagine...probably a combination of both. 

We ordered the chicken burrito, tacos and chips with salsa and guacamole. Their salsa was ok, there was a little bit of onion overdose, but the guacamole was fresh, chunky and flavorful. And let me tell you, their burritos are no joke. It was just straight up stuffed with freshly stewed and shredded chicken with beans...none of that chipotle stuff (don't get me wrong, I like my chipotle too!). I thought it was awesome that it oozed deliciousness when my friend cut open it. I ordered the vegetarian burrito, because there weren't any fish tacos. However, I was disappointed to find that it only contained beans, cheese and salsa...guess I expected grilled vegetables. I didn't complain because it was still well made. Overall, La Taqueria is a wonderful family own restaurant, filled with authentic, soulful mexican food and a happy hip crowd. Moreover, the owner really cares about his customers, he nearly went by every table to chat and joke with everyone!
author: Jenny Z.

description: Their quesadillas are to die for!!!! My fiancé and I recently moved to SF and were told that this place is a must try, so we did and it did not disappoint!! Although it is a little too pricey for Mexican food... So until we find a place that is cheaper and is just as good. Otherwise it'll be hard to stop coming here.
author: Yan H.

description: I've been coming here since the late '80s.  The burritos were only less than $5 back then and the lines were much more manageable. Now, the price is more than double and it is teeming with tourists and newbies to SF.  Still love the food though.  The ingredients are fresh.  The staff is very organized handling the volume.  Definitely would give this 5 stars if it weren't for the lines.
author: somel y.

description: My favorite mexican spot in all of San Francisco. I have been eating here since I was a kid and this place is legit. Get the crispy tacos, just do it and thank me after. SO GOOD.
author: Silvio S.

description: Dear, Burrito Jesus in Heaven! Please grant us your deliverance and a La Taqueria franchise in South Bay.
author: D P.

description:
Yummy tacos which mucho (dare I say demasiado?) meat. Two tacos is more than enough given the ample meat. Speaking of meat, get the lengua. It is muy delish and you will not regret it. 

According to a friend, La Taqueria is #1 on a Best Tacos in the U.S. list. I'm not sure I believe that nor have I investigated this allegation, but I definitely have enjoyed my visits to La Taqueria and look forward to going back.
author: Kate P.

description:
WHAT? SO GOOD. C'MON!!!

This is DEFINITELY on my whisper list: Soooo good that once you eat it,  you close your eyes, tilt your head and whisper...oh..my..gosh. 

I do not eat beans in my tacos so I can't comment about that BUT their tacos are delicious.  I am a big fan of hard shell tacos and carne asada.  

Their carne asada is seasoned so tasty and is completely juicy.  What is really interesting that completes all the juices is that they they fry the tortilla to make it  a hard shell taco and then wrap a soft shell taco around it to keep in all the flavors.  I love the chips as well and man that salsa is flavorful.  The green salsa is really spicy for me, but it is one of those salsa's that i have to continue eating my food with because it makes everything so much more damn delicious even with all that heat.  

MUST TRY.
author: Kristina L.

description: Located in a great neighborhood and seems to be constantly busy. The beef that they use on tacos, quesadillas, etc is a perfect balance of tender texture and salty. The chorizo was pretty greasy but had a great flavor and decent spice. The pico that went on the tortilla chips was ideal, and the horchata was quite delicious with the perfect amount of cinnamon in it. Portions are quite generous and food is always hot. The lines are out of control and seating can be hard to find unless you're alone or with one other person. You won't be disappointed that you visited though. It is absolutely worth the wait.
author: Preston S.

description:
There are so many places to get tacos in the Mission - I feel like the taco bar has been set high. That, or maybe I have no taco taste buds because not many places in the Mission have wow-ed me. La Taqueria was no exception.

I stopped by La Taqueria at around 2pm on a Tuesday for the free taco deal on Scout Mob. I was surprised to find a line (albeit, a line of 3 people) given Rosamunde's had NO line at all; I hoped it was an indication of the food caliber. Scout Mob did in fact have a free taco deal, but it's tricky since it includes only a regular taco no toppings (no guac, cheese, sour cream). The deal includes a $3.50 carne asada taco with beans and salsa. Strangely, it costs $1.20 to remove beans from your order. Did I read that right?!?!

2 stars for a mediocre taco with dry carne asada.
author: Jess C.

description: I was in town visiting and wanted to see if it was as good as I remember. It is.
author: Dean K.

description: Finally made it here over the weekend and it was crowded!  Not so shocking since they have the #1 burrito in the nation.  I hadn't been in years, probably even a decade.  I used to always get tacos and douse it in the hot salsa at each table.  This time I had to try their burrito.  I got the regular carne asada with avocado.  It's no frills but pretty  good.  It definitely hit the spot but I can't say for sure it's the best burrito in town, let alone the nation.  Remember no rice.  I may opt for the tacos next time.
author: Meredith K.

description: Saw this place featured on food network as having the best burritos in America, I am in town for the weekend for the Nike Womens Marathon so decided to try it out. The line was out the door but moved pretty quickly!! I ordered the super veggie burrito and my hubby got the carne asada burrito and chips and salsa!! We both loved it!! My hubby loved the flavor of the beef and complimented its tenderness numerous times!!
author: Kesha I.

description:
There's a sign outside La Taqueria which reads, "The Best Tacos and Burritos in the Whole World". In this town, them's fightin' words. Every corner of this city has their signature something that they defend, and saying we have the best anything (the best coffee, the steepest hills, the dirtiest hipsters, etc.) is bound to invite ire.

In La Taqueria's case, it just might be true.

They've got a simple menu, mostly tacos and burritos, not even a salsa bar. I stopped by midday on a Monday (not a holiday) and the place was packed. I lucked out with a seat, and chowed down on a chicken, a carne asada, and a carnitas taco. All were good, carne asada was probably best. Service at the register was friendly and chatty, saying goodbye and thank you to everyone who stopped in.

With easy access from the 24th & Mission BART station, this should be your go-to spot when you're having a taco craving. I know for sure it's mine.
author: Kevin B.

description: I don't understand how this place was awarded the "best burrito in the country". I'm not sure who was actually voting on that website. First of all they don't have Al Pastor which is a telling sign about a taqueria. After learning they don't have al pastor, I made the mistake of still getting a burrito here (chicken) that was SMALL, overpriced, no rice, bland, and not even all the sour cream and guacamole could disguise the fact that the meat had no flavor. To top it off they were borderline rude. Incredibly bewildered at how this place is so popular. I suggest going to Taqueria Vallarta on 24th.
author: Patty G.

description:
Man I love this place, been going here for ten years! 

Would be 5 stars easily, but they've cut their portions in half and expect us to pay the same price?! 

The burrito is literally half the size it used to be :(
author: Colby C.

description:
Did not disappoint. Had to come here after a big let down at craftsman and wolf.  Tacos were moist and portioning was very generous -- a little too generous so don't over order!  One taco here is probably equivalent to 2.5 tacos at tacolicious.  Green sauce was amazing but could take a little more heat and less acidic.

We got the carne asada, lengua, chorizo, and carnitas taco.  The lengua and chorizo were amazing.  The other two were pretty standard.

Tamarindo was on the sweet side but its so awesome that it basically tastes like Chinese plum juice you get at hot pot places.
author: Koalie W.

description: Okay burrito. Came in with high expectations, and was underwhelmed by the carne asada super burrito. First off, as of October 1st they no longer have avocado for the foreseeable future, which is crucial for a great burrito. Second, the steak did not have much flavor, third, the beans were bland, and forth, not much hot sauce/salsa variety. Not impressed at all.
author: Rahim H.

description: Came here with a friend to eat while we waited for the Dia de Los Muertos parade to get there. Although the line waa so freakin long and they are a bit unorganized when people get there food, the tacos I had where the best that I have had in so long. I will come again and this time take another shot of their salsa.
author: Rosa A. F.

description: Not authentic tacos. Meat was dried and flavorless. No comparison to the Tijuana and Mexicali street tacos.
author: Noe V.

description: Literally Awesome tacos. Better than tacos from San Antonio. Pork taco I thought was better than the beef.   Come hungry.  One taco was enough for me.  Service was fast and a bit impersonal.
author: Lis M.

description:
This place has some crazy amount of reviews and I finally decided to give it a try over the weekend. My friends and I came here at night and the place was crowded. The line does go faster than you expect but but still took a while for us to get our order in and get the food going. 

The food was okay. I don't see the hype.
author: D. G.

description:
Really?? Such low scores??? Really??

This was THE burrito before Poncho Villa. This was THE burrito before any other burrito. This is a classic. No fuss. No muss. 

A true original in the Mission and what every burrito aficionado should try at least once...because this is where the burrito was born. 

Dont expect the place to spic and span. Because thats not what it is. 

Your there fore the yumminess and authentic flavor. Not the decor. 

A tru classic and tru favorite!
author: Michelle I.

description: Despite the hype, I had a very mediocre burrito here.  The taste was very bland and seemed to cater to the other folks who looked like me. For $10, the super burrito was not substantial enough to fill me up.  Finally, the guy chopping meat in front of the customers was doing so without gloves.  For a better experience, try Taqueria Cancun or (gasp) Chipotle.
author: Robert Z.

description: This place is the bomb. Cheap, fast, tasty...always. I love the veggie taco which is so simple (pinto beans, cheese melted in the double corn tortilla, hand cut tomato-onion-cilantro salsa) and I always add avocado and the table-top tomatillo salsa. It's delicious and filling and keeps me going all afternoon.
author: Sandy G.

description: Upon looking up best burritos in Sf this place actually is ranked #1 in the nation according to ESPN. I decided to give it a try over El Farolito today and was not disappointed. I entered the store thinking card was accepted but found out it's not. This was disappointing because I hate touching money before eating and don't like having to wash my hands and deal with a restroom. I had no cash so had to get cashback next door. I returned and like I planned ordered a carne asada super burrito. The taste started off slow, but I could tell the tortilla was better than most places, way better than chipotle. The taste really got delicious a quarter in the burrito, a medley of meat, sour cream, beans and salsa all came together. I do not remember if there was rice inside, you should ask for rice to be sure. Also, there was meat juicy bursting out the burrito. I liked the authenticity this place has and know there is a connection between culture with the food. This would have to rank in the top of my list for best Mexican food in the Mission. (I'm still in the process of trying a few more).
author: Dan G.

description: This is an old school taco place in the Mission. There is always a line that wraps around the store so tip is to order outside on the phone and they'll have your order ready so you can avoid the line. The tacos are pretty good and prepped quite readily. But watching them make the food, I question the cleanliness a bit. Also I think it's a rip off that they charge you for Almaty all the toppings that you want on your taco. It's a bit deceiving because you think your taco will cost around $3 but with the toppings it comes to about $6.  But one plus is you can enjoy your tacos at Dolores Park.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Probably one of the best burritos and definitely the best chips and salsa I've ever had. I had just touched down in SF and this was the first place we were taken to by our local friend. I got a burrito the size of my forearm and proceeded to chow down. The salsa was super fresh and vibrant with tons of flavor. 

Cheap, delicious and well made meal. Recommend it to anyone in the area. Cool murals too.
author: Ana R.

description: I came here with the best friends on a warm Saturday afternoon. We walked along Mission looking for a lunch place. Beware: it's cash only! That nearly put us off, but we scrounged some cash and waited in the line. It went much quicker than I thought it was, and even though the place was super crowded, we actually found a table really quickly as well. We were just going to eat outside somewhere. Between the three of us, we had carnitas, carne asada, and pollo tacos, all with avocado. Honestly, one taco each was enough for us - it was the size of a small burrito. I was happily full afterwards. Also I was impressed that despite the organized chaos at the cashier, she still called out the homeless guy that came around asking for change. Would definitely come back here!
author: Jennifer J.

description:
I was born and raised in San Francisco and la taqueria and I go way way back. It's my favorite taqueria in the city; tasty, fresh and just so so so good. Been coming here since I was a kid and it definitely lives up to the hype.

Tips/words from a native:

1. They don't put rice in their burritos. Why? BECAUSE IT IS WRONG TO PUT RICE IN A BURRITO. Don't ask for rice. They will judge you, rightfully so.

2. It's not cheap, but it's worth it. If you want cheaper mixed contaminated food and some rice with peas in it, walk a couple blocks down and stand in line at La Corneta (This place has the same rating at La Taqueria on Yelp and this is just baffling to me)

3. They charge you to take out beans. This could be because they put more meat or because anyone who doesn't like black beans in a burrito deserves to be charged extra. 

4. They have great ice here. Strange to say, but I used to love to eat it when I was a kid. Even the ice here is delicious. 

The most important thing about la taqueria is that the name of the place is "LA TAQUERIA". Not "La Taq" or even worse "La Taq in the Mish". Saying any of these means you're asking to be punched in the throat. 

And let's be honest, you'd totally deserve it.
author: Xochitl C.

description: Went for authentic Mexican food it was good but wasn't very flavorful. I had the regular beef burrito but the mango drink was very fresh and good
author: Jessica N.

description: Maybe it was the hype, but my burrito was NOT good.   It was wet, small and for me, it really boils down to the quality of the meat.   I was not impressed.   Maybe I'll have to give it a second chance, or get something else.
author: Edgar C.

description: This taqueria was way too expensive with way too long of a line for the food we got. I ordered a chicken quesadilla that was ridiculously messy and was only wrapped in tin foil and didn't even have a box to hold it in. I got three hard pieces of chicken bone or cartilage I had to spit out. My boyfriend got a super carne asada burrito. The carne asada didn't have any flavor and was too chewy. The tortilla was cold and falling apart. Both items were very messy. I do not recommend this place.
author: Julia A.

description:
This is probably the best Mexican food I ever ate, and probably ever will eat! I had the chicken quesadilla with sour cream and avocado, and it was amazing! The flour bread was really juicy. I had to come back the next day for one more. 

It can be a bit hard to find a place to sit, but if you are ready to jump in when someone leaves you usually get a spot before you get the food.
author: Stian J.

description: Hands down- the best burrito I've ever had. Not filled with rice- but beans and meats and veggies! They are super nice and no matter how crowded will answer your questions and make things special. It is always packed and hard to find somewhere to sit, but man it's worth it!!!
author: Katherine J.

description: If you're from LA or San Diego, this place just doesn't do it. It's okay, not bad. I know most ppl would love all that meat piled onto their tacos, but there is such a thing as too much. Needs to be balanced. The hot sauce in the squeeze bottles at the table is pretty good.
author: Mimo L.

description: Great place in the mission. The name is so simple. The food is so great. The staff are friendly. The lady who have me some water was very sweet. I got the Carne asada burrito and it was delicious! The place gets super crowded so I had to wait a while for my food, but it was worth it!!! I also saw the chicken tacos that my friend got which looked amazing and had a huge piece of breast meat in them. Yuuum!!!
author: Rozay F.

description:
As I sit here stewing in the wake of my half finished lunch, I realized that something was desperately missing. A La Taqueria burrito.

Who knew that they put hard core drugs in this stuff to make you addicted and now you can't live without it??? I'm just joking. But seriously.  It's so good it's gotta be bad for you somehow.
