description: Holy carnitas burrito.   While the burrito is flatter than usual and doesn't provide rice or lettuce,  I really enjoyed the moisture of the tortilla.  I just wished they added fries to it and make it a California burrito.  That would be tasty!
author: Nho C.

description:
super duper busy place.  we were greeted with a long line both to order and to get our food.  not the best place to take two small kids.  

the food was great.  the carnitas; YUMMY!  The tacos lived up to their reputation.   

We also had a burrito which was a bit odd.  All meat and beans.  They don't have rice.  For most this isn't a problem, except my kids live for rice in their burritos.  In fact we usually don't get beans.  Nonetheless, the burrito still tasted great (to me).
author: Mike L.

description: This place is packed...the line stretches across the place, every seat is full, the music is lightly in the air because your neighbors conversation is in your ear. You know...the way its supposed to be! Food was good...tacos are double the price of other places but the tacos are 2.5 times bigger! Cash only...bring a lot because you might not wanna leave!
author: Gabriel C.

description: Over-hyped? Really people? You guys obviously don't know real Mexican food.  I am not from SF so I miss my mom's Mexican cooking a lot and when I do miss her cooking I ONLY come to La Taqueria.  Yes, I have tried other taquerias in the Mission and none of them taste homemade to me, they just taste greasy to me.  Burrito is too small? They aren't suppose to be huge! (it's not like burrito's even exist in Mexico... and if you have had one there you were at a touristy spot).  And yes they only have pinto beans because you know what, in Mexico they cook with one certain bean depending on which state you are in.  And they also don't have rice, but as my super Mexican dad says "Rice is a filler, that does not belong in a meal" ***but he says this in Spanish of course. The chicken tacos & burrito's are the best.  My brother gets the carne asada or carnitas and he loves it. Simple and perfect tasting. This is as close to Mexico Mexican cooking as you can get in the U.S.  Maybe it's a little expensive but I say it's worth it to eat REAL Mexican food.
author: Dyvi M.

description: Mexican food in the Mission - supposedly one of the best locations where one can find some good mexican food.  Out of the long list of restaurant, a friend recommended this place.  I really wanted to try beef tongue (lingua), and my friend said the lingua quesadilla is a must try, and I must add in salsa and guacamole.  Sure, I love quesadilla, except I didn't expect it to be deep fried when I got my order.  Bc it was deep fried, it was on the oily side.  The beef tongue was good though: soft and tender!  Also, it wasn't as cheesy as I expected.  Will I go back again?  Yes, but I will probably skip the quesadilla and order either a taco or burrito instead.
author: Lillian T.

description:
Oh La Taqueria...I love you, I hate you...

Delicious, but how did you become such a tourist destination and why oh why is my burrito $6.75 bare bones and and almost $9.00 with everything that a burrito should just come with?

I've been coming here over 20 years, and it had been awhile since my last visit...oh how things have changed
author: C. S.

description: I wish I was a songwriter so I could write a happy song for La Taqueria.  When I eat their burritos I want to sing.  Order anything and everything.....its allll good.  Use green sauce and order a fruit drink.
author: Lily N.

description: Good carnitas taco but a bit overrated. Not worth it if you have to wait awhile and have no place to sit.
author: Elaine N.

description: I've been searching for the best taquerias for a while and this seems to be on everyone's list . We ordered a carnitas taco which you can order crispy so one tortilla is fried and gas melted cheese on it. That was pretty awesome. We also got a Carne asada burrito.  I liked the food but it's not my favorite taqueria in the mission.
author: Julie B.

description:
**LOOK NO FURTHER** **NO COMPETITION** 

La Taqueria is by far the "BEST TAQUERIA IN THE BAY AREA AND BEYOND". 

Can't go wrong with any of the meats....The burritos are juicy and do not have all the fillers. NO RICE....can you believe it? What a wonderful idea! You do have to pay for all your extras, guac., sour cream, etc....which brings your price up to around $10 a burrito but trust me, you get what you pay for. Also, do not pass up on trying the green chile salsa. It is AMAZING and makes an already perfect burrito, out of this world. 

Tacos are also very good but I can't just can't go to La Taqueria without getting a burrito...sometimes one to go as well. 

Staff is friendly and get you in and out as quick as they can. The lines can get extremely long. 

Cash only but they do have an ATM. 

So next time you are in San Francisco, be sure and take a trip to the Mission and dine at La Taqueria.
author: Seamus H.

description:
Hands down best tacos in the Bay!

My choice of food from their menu is Beef Tongue Taco with no addition, just onions and cilantro with marinated Lengua, maybe a hint of their green hot sauce.

I've had the pleasure to experience their chicken tacos as well but I'm the kind that likes to eat the rare items on any menus. Chicken was moist and tender, not dry like most taco places.

Chips and salsa is a must as well since their salsa is always fresh. Services are great even when they are pack, sometimes finding a seat can be difficult but it is worth the wait.
author: C Y.

description: Best mexican in SF so far (other than the food trucks)... Got to love the crispy style burritos.
author: Y S.

description: Softest burrito this side of the coast! A little hairy getting in & out of the place, their line is confusing & when I went to pick up my order, she handed me an empty bag! But I would go back for their burrito alone. Super yummy, super worth it & they know it!
author: Yodlee Y.

description:
deeeelicious tacos and burritos. Make sure you get it with everything on top (avocado, salsa, etc) and you won't regre it.

There is seating at small tables as well as long picnic-table-type setups where you can rub elbows with strangers (we didn't mind it at all). The line can get very long and a little confusing, but moves decently quickly.
author: Joy X.

description:
#3 On The Big Eat SF - Carnitas Taco

Carnitas = wonderful
Taco = tooo beany. Get less beans if you can!
author: S V.

description:
good stuff...  coming from LA, this is pretty decent Mexican food... 

Lengua taco: meat was moist, shredded, but a bit bland.. seemed like the meat was just boiled.. could have used a bit more seasoning

Quesadilla on corn tortilla with chorizo: AMAZING... basically like Tito's Taco's from Los Angeles...  a nice grease puddle in the plastic tray when you're done, but, oh, so tasty.

Carne Asada taco: meat was very nicely flavored, but didn't seem to have that grilled flavor to it... moist enough, but I can use more char on my carne asada.

Overall good, but WAY too expensive.  I spent almost $20 for the three items and 2 beers.  Quality is good, but I'm thinking there are other Taquerias that will serve a comparable meal for much cheaper.
author: Mac L.

description:
Took BART from the Embarcadero to eat lunch at this place.  It was worth the trip.  A reg chicken burrito without guacamole, cheese, etc. was $6.50.  Of course, I paid for the extras.  My girlfriend had three huge tacos.  All that plus water and oj, came out to about $24.00.  

Yes, pricey for lunch, that's why the four stars.  As for the quality of the food, it was absolutely delicious!  I enjoyed the burritos 10 times better at this place versus the burritos at El Farolito.   The food tasted soooo fresh!  I also enjoyed the ambiance.  It was a nice, clean, open space type of restaurant.  There was a crowd at lunch but we didn't have to wait very long for a table.  

I'm happy to recommend La Taqueria to my friends and family!
author: CynCub C.

description:
Their burritos, tacos and the salsa you find at each table are delicious.

The Mission has so many taquerias to choose from, but this place stands out because of the simple menu and their approach to assembling a complete burrito or taco where adding extras can make your burrito or taco expensive. On the good side, they don't fill your burrito with rice. 

I have been going there off and on for over 15 years. I only go there on occasion because it can be an expensive meal, however, they have the best burritos and tacos in The Mission. I just wish I could afford to go there more often. 

Don't forget to visit Dianda's Italian American Pastry next door for some of the best pastry in The Mission.
author: Buddy M.

description:
This is my favorite place to get a taco ! 
No question about it. La Taqueria is the best anywhere.
If you add all the extras the taco will cost you about $6.00 but it 
is well worth it. And you will not be disappointed. 

Took me over a year to do a taco crawl on mission and this place rocks.
They are so good that I am going to go get one now.
Well not now  I just had one today,but real soon. 

Simon the Cat
author: Simon The Cat -.

description: it was whateva.  I was expecting the most flavorful, or giant burrito from all of the reviews.  It was small, and just standard.  The carne asada burrito I had was probably the smallest I've ever ordered, however, I'm from San Diego so I guess the farther away from the border the different it is.
author: Anna S.

description: amazing carne asada tacos! the carnitas is pretty good too. usually pretty crowded. guac is a bit bland.
author: Xing L.

description:
Solid but not yet my favorite... tried the Carnitas and Chicken Tacos... and they were pretty good but not raving off my charts like some of the other Yelp reviews.

Boo enjoyed the fact there is no rice in the burritos although we think it's kinda weird they charge you to NOT have beans in your burrito although if you do order that they just have salsa... and meat. Huh! Also, it was long and skinny (insert your own crude comment here). This place definitely likes their salt though... the food was on the saltier side (but I have the salt gene so I liked it) and there were salt shakers on the tables!

The corn quesadillas were realllllly tasty though and that is what would definitely have me coming back next time! With meat! The chips were light and delicious too.
author: Salina Z.

description:
The burritos are really good
Dam tasty good
Quality ingredients
Expensive - $9.46 with everything, base burrito $6.50
author: Po L.

description: These tacos are delicious! I got a carnitas taco and a lengua taco. At first I thought the tacos were kind of pricey, but they are large and do not disappoint. The lengua taco was really good, very tender and flavorful and is topped with cilantro and onion. I had only had lengua once before and felt like I could feel the tastebuds as I was eating it (eww), but this lengua was perfect! The carnitas taco was delicious too! Juicy and covered in some delicious pico de gallo! The only thing I thought it could do without was the beans, I would rather have more of the delicious meat! Overall, this place is pretty delicious and authentic! Yum!
author: Kayleigh B.

description: We were on a quest for the best burrito in the Mission.  We'd heard disparaging reports, but as we walked past the facade of La Taqueria, we knew that this was going to be our place--and it was.  A burrito sans rice?  These burritos were packed with flavor; the carne asda is perfect.  Perhaps what I respect most is that these burritos are simple, but done well.
author: Andrea P.

description:
It's good, but I can't rate it better than 2 stars, especially since I have La Tapatia in south city.

Why?  Price...

a plain taco is $3.50, and you have to add $1.50 each for guac, cheese and sour cream.  That makes a $8 taco...  A super taco loaded with whatever you want at Tapatia is $3.25.

$8 vs $3.25...  is there cocaine included in the tortilla for the $5 difference??? WTF...
author: Roni L.

description: The burritos are small for the price. They have a limited menu ( they couldn't make nachos fort sob) also their burritos did have rice in them. The steak is good but the chicken is boiled and has no flavor
author: Tabitha F.

description: The tacos here are delicious!! I wouldn't order guacamole here again, since it's really just mashed up avocado without anything else. They also could be better about being on top of cleaning off tables after people are done eating -- looking for a spot to sit, most of the tables were pretty dirty. I considered docking a star, but, tacos trump all.
author: Olivia P.

description:
When people say try the Mexican food if you're ever in California, I think La Taqueria is what they mean. The carne asada burrito was soooo good! I want to buy another plane ticket to SF just to eat it again. Seattle doesn't know Mexican food. The beef was perfectly seasoned and super tender. I know it was freshly made too because I saw the guy take a big slab of beef off the grill and cut it up. I generally avoid ordering steak/beef at non-hamburger establishment because they usually taste and feel like rubber, so I was very surprised. 

The burrito was also the right size, not too big and not too small. I didn't leave feeling heavy afterwards. 

On the downside, it is a bit pricey and sour cream and avocados are extra.
author: Yoeun P.

description: I would have given this favorite spot 5 stars, but they recently changed their tomatilla sauce recipe...which had been the best in the city....and made it so hot you can't even taste it anymore. Let's hope they change it back, and soon! It's too spicy for me to eat there now, sorry to say!
author: Brian H.

description: Best tacos in the Bay Area so far. Most expensive as well. I order 3 tacos - El Dorado style (double decker at Taco Bell for the gringos) with everything (Sour Cream, Guacamole, and salsa) a large horchata and it came out to over $22! Cash only too. I had to cancel a taco and borrow money from a friend. They were amazing! and I was hurting after eating so much. Will be coming back for sure.
author: Jeff B.

description: The best taqueria in the Mission, hands down.  Go for the crispy style tacos.  The food is premium and very tasty.  The only taqueria that I will go to in the Mission.
author: Ron C.

description:
Yum. The burrito is pretty BOMB!

Some cons though:
1.) No Rice
2.) Gotta pay extra for avocado and sour cream when burrito itself is pricey.
3.) The size. It's pretty thin and small.

Thumbs up:
1.) Service: quick and easy (To make the service even faster they have somebody at the register taking your order and another person taking other people orders in line)
2.) The store itself is pretty roomy and clean compared to others.
author: Pearl V.

description:
This used to be one of 2 of my favorate burrito spots in San Francisco, but their service and food is nothing like it used to be.  The Carne Asad was bland and not cooked enough for that grill flavor and they forgot our cheese on all 3 of our burritos even though we paid extra for it.

The cooks were very rude snatching the order sheet from the cashier and they all don't seem to take pride in the food they prepare for their customers.  Not to mention the burrittos are small.  

Sadly, this will be the last time I eat here.

Disappointed.
author: Robin A.

description: Get the tacos super and use the green salsa you will not regret it. This is hands down the best tacos I've ever had
author: Desiree B.

description:
Let me start by saying my dream burrito needs two pieces of tinfoil to wrap and is a day's meal in one tightly-bound tortilla. So when La Taqueria came highly recommended by someone with a similar love, I expected nothing less. However, this rice-less and seemingly healthier burrito left me feeling hungry and unsatisfied. Sure, it was good, but not great and definitely not filling. Plus, the place is no bargain as far as Mission burritos are concerned. 

Summary: I'm not sad that I went there, but I won't be going back.
author: Greg G.

description: Tasty burrito, but not much meat, mostly guac and sour cream. Left hungry.
author: Xeres D.

description: Goddamnit la taqueria. 6.75 for a taco, but holy fuck is it good. The service is chilly, and the tacos are expensive, but goddamnit they are so good. I wouldn't normally drop a star on a place like this, but 6.75 for a taco is fucking insane, no matter how super it is. However, that taco is goddamn primal, enough said, go buy one and jam it down your face, while simultaneously regretting every previous taco experience you've ever had.
author: Joseph O.

description:
This use to be a favorite burrito place for years, but we were very disappointed when we picked up our food to go. We ordered a pork and beef burrito with extra avocado and sour cream.  It was $9. each burrito.  $20. for 2 burritos.

Since I live out of area..we took it home for lunch and to our surprise it was such a skinny burrito, but I knew it was going to be delicious...NOT! it was quite bland and it was skinny on top of that for $9.   we use to be long time customers whenever we came to San Francisco.

Their prices have definitely gone up.  For $9. a pop with everything.....they don't even give chips or salsa with the orders.  Such a rip off!

I'm sad that they don't provide the good feeling and good food from what we remembered of the past.........and we been coming over 15 years.  Maybe it's been a gradual decline as we don't get to the area too often.

I can go to La Costa in Alameda, CA and get a fat burrito with everything for under $4.00 and it's delicious!

I won't need to come back to this place anymore for burritos.
author: Nanana A.

description:
Pros:
- The ingredients were incredibly fresh, the only Mission burrito I've ever had which tasted farm fresh and actually healthy. 

Cons:
- Everything costs extra. $1.65 to add guacamole or cheese to a taco. That's more than most places charge for a whole taco. It costs something like $1.20 to NOT have beans or sour cream added to your taco. Charges for any substitutions. Chips and salsa are for charge. 
- The burrito was very small for the price.
- The salsa was average, was expecting much better.
- Not open late.
- The burritos are poorly wrapped and fall apart after the first bite.
- The meat is not well-seasoned. 
- No choice of beans. (No refried or black, only pinto.) 
- No seafood.
- Very good chance they will get your order wrong.
- Nonsensical and inconvenient layout. 
- The ordering process is unnecessarily time-consuming and complicated because every ingredient that Mexican food places will typically include have to be ordered separately, and then there's the time it takes for the cashier to explain all of the additional charges...
- The ingredients are too runny (not drained of excess water and juices, causing the tortilla to get soggy) and are unevenly distributed (not blended together well enough inside of the tortilla). 
- Burritos are served too cold. 
- Insanely long lines. Not worth the wait considering El Farolito is just across the street.
- The service is arrogant.
- They don't bus the tables.
- They do not provide receipts.
- SF Health Score / Food Rating is a little concerning.
- Far too loud an atmosphere. 
- Cash only.
- Not nearly as good as El Farolito, and a whole lot more expensive.
author: N I.

description:
I went here last night for the first time and had their Carne Asada burrito spicy with queso. 

The flavor was really delicious, however, there was no spiciness whatsoever happening with my burrito. I like my Mexican food with some kick to it, but it wasn't happening. Honestly, I told my bf it was "white people" spicy. You guys know you can't handle the kick. lol Plus, it was really wet from bean juice, and they didn't have limes only lemons. Completely different flavors and effects from each, so it wound up being so so. I also ordered jamaica and tried their strawberry fresca which was really yummy! BUT, I was confused when we got our chips and salsa and the salsa was served on top. I've never seen it served that way at ANY Mexican place. I mean I don't want my chips dripping in salsa. Chips are for dippin. 

So, I debated between giving them 4 stars based on the flavor, but settled on 3 because I'm not a fan. I've had better but this will suffice.
author: Eclectic C.

description: Vegetarian taco & salsa was good, but the tangerine juice was amazing!!  Seriously, amazing.
author: Lynn M.

description:
the husband and I drove all the way here from San Jose to try "the worlds best burrito"... we totally regret fighting all the traffic to get here. 

I was so excited to know we had a restaurant with so many awards and recognitions here in the bay area but was quickly disappointed when we tasted our food. we ordered 2 super asasa burritos toasted on the grill. they were soggy, all the juices from the beans and the salsa started drizzling down almost soon as we picked them up.. the size was not super at all and although the meat was very tender it was flavorless.. nothing from this burrito stood out.. all very basic, sadly I've had way better food at taco bell.. I'd like till believe that at one time this place actually had tasty food, but due to mass production and only one Guy behind the counter they've lowered they're quality standards.. "nations best", I don't think so. definitely not coming back.
author: Brenda R.

description:
The lengua (cow tongue) burrito here is AMAZINGGGGGGGGly juicy and tender!  I absolutely hate beans, so I ordered mine without, and my burrito still came out the same size as my friend's! No rice fillers either, just meat, meat, and meat!  MMM, I'm in carnivore heaven!

The lengua made me melt to the ground when it melted in my mouth! Forget all that dried out carnitas crap from other tacquerias, this is the place to go! Even my  mexican roommate said he hasn't had lengua like this since he last went south of the border. 

My burrito was $6.50. Minus half a star because they charge you extra for cheese, avocado, and other condiments. Parking at the mission was a b****, but that's no surprise.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Dear Yelpers,

The La Taqueria is a cute name for the San Francisco city dump between 24th and 25th streets on Mission. Upon entering this trough i was barraged with a strange smell I have never come across in my entire life. The only comparable smell was probably desert storm. For those of you who have never been in a war zone, the smell of a bosnian outhouse might make a better analogy. After hearing the rave reviews about La Taquerias famous carne asada, I was excited to finally reach this "mecca" of Mexican dining. I proceeded to the counter and almost thought I was back at the hometown buffet with my late grandma in Bakersfield. I ordered the carne asada burrito like a good soldier and what I got was a microwaved diaper crammed with diarrhea. The innards could be in a Chunky Soup commercial, except the soup would look like its been eaten and regurgitated and the mother and son would be vultures spitting it into each others mouths.

I sat down at my "table" and gently unwrapped what seemed to be jabba the hutt's stunt double. After one lukewarm mouthful I set down the flaccid eight dollar bag of mud to abate my suffering and wash the salt out of my mouth. It seemed to be affected by gravity more so than any other object Ive come across since the war. Maybe it was like the camel curry I tried to contain in stale pita bread in Kuwait. This thing dumped over pathetically. The burrito was rejecting its own contents. The best bites were the ones with only sour cream. Luckily, this was half of the burrito. 

After finishing the burrito, I felt the urgent need to evacuate myself from both ends. I was pleasantly surprised to find that the bathroom smelled better than my food. i wonder what scent they use. id like to have it in my personal bathroom. 

The salsa bar has four choices of nail polish remover. You could probably lacquer a bench with the pickled jalepeno juice. 

I felt crushed that I had to pay for this experience. The food is sloppy, small, unsophisticated and confusing. My sexuality is bigger and more understandable and thats not saying much at all. I wonder how many cows on the I5 have died for this place but they all died in vain. I cant even imagine a worse restaurant. The presence of this place in the mission is audacious and oppressive. I have to pretend that the building is vacant when I walk by it so that my rage doesn't get out of control. They should include a gun with the food. The perfect dessert. except you should first shoot the cooks and then shoot yourself for being so gullible. 

Frankly,
Frank Peralta
author: Frank P.

description:
The bomb.

As a mexican food-starved Bostonian visiting San Fran, this place is heaven. 
Great burritos, great service, great atmosphere. No reason to go anywhere else.
author: Ken C.

description: I had the Carnita Crispy tacos and Asada Crispy tacos....Tacos are tasty...beans could of done without and I usually like beans...but what is the bomb is the Carnita....super tender and tasty.  The Asada was good but only reason I would come back for is the Carnita.
author: Geno L.

description: We ordered 6 tacos (3 carne asada, 1 chicken, 1 lengua, 1 pork) @ $3.75 each. They were great tacos but the lady that was taking our order asked us "if we want everything on it with avocado?" We said yes. Once we were ready to pay the tab it came out to $35 for 6 tacos. They charge $1.65 for avocado per taco. So be careful as they won't disclose that to you upfront. $1.65 is usually how much tacos cost anywhere else, so to charge that amount for avocado is a bit overpriced.
author: Rico P.

description:
I just finished the last bite - of a CRISPY saucy little veggie taco with gaucamole to boot.  Now I'm a happy, satisfied yelper.  All this for $3.78.  Plus, the charismatic cashier who knows everbody, says hello to all the children, and flirts with all the women made me smile.  This little taqueria is truly a special place - for flavor, quality, and warmth.  They deserve the multitude of plaques, magazine articles, and honors wall-papering their walls.

ps. the line moves fast!

pss. even though it's not on the menu, a little known secret is that you can order burritos "crispy" if you want them toasty, golden brown yummy (-:
author: Heather W.

description: The expert team at 538 has just selected their burrito as the best in USA http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/Americas-best-burrito/
author: Eugene L.

description:
Tacos and burritos were OK. This place seems to have gone to the tourists and is kinda expensive ($6.5 for a burrito and $3.5 for a taco). 
There are cheaper, better places to be found in the Mission.
author: Saul E.

description:
Good tacos - we got the carnitas and the carne asada. While they were well flavored, we both agreed that we have had better carnitas at other places before. The carne asada was good, but nothing out of the ordinary. 

Also, we have never seen tacos that go for $3.50 - the extra money you spend to eat here is SO not worth it. A taco of that size should never be more than $2.50 at most unless it is absolutely spectacular. 

I liked the agua fresca (strawberry) that I had here, but my boyfriend thought it was too sweet. I liked all of the strawberry pulp in it - quite satisfying!
author: Yvonne W.

description: OMG!!! This has been my all time favorite taqueria.  I used to go often to the location they used to have in down town SJ. Oh boy, how I miss that location so much. Now they only have the SF one,  which I am so thankful they still have that one. Any who,  I love this place. Their carne asada is so delicious, soft and full of flavor. Their green salsa is what I die for. Every bite I take must have a dab (well lets be real here, more than a dab lol) of that green salsa. I always order carne asada taco ( which is big for your usual taco,  cause they use the reg tortillas), the flour quesadilla (which is also finger licking good,  specially with the green salsa) and as a beverage mango water (agua fresca or fresh water as some will call it). I have to say, I have never tried anything else from their menu, but everything looks delicious and my family members have never complaint about anything else on their menu.  I love this place, I wish I live closer to go more often.  They try to give you good and fast service. The restaurant is kind of small and and often crowded because of how good it is. You find yourself hunting for the next available seat hahaha.  But this has not stopped me nor will it ever. It's worth trying.  I give it a 3 thumbs up!
author: Jeanine G.

description:
Their carne asada, chicken & carnita (pork) are all amazing.
You *MUST* order their "Tacos Dorados" (Fried taco shell wrapped with a soft corn tortilla) with everything on it (salsa, avocado, etc). They are to die for. 

I am Mexican and this is the best Mexican food I have ever eaten outside of my moms kitchen.
author: I. A.

description: If we were rating on a 10 star system I'd give La Taqueria a 9. If I'm going to get a Mission burrito by myself I don't go here but if we're ordering for more, or bringing around friends who might get weirded out by the cramped hole in the wall feel of the Mission's best taquerias we go here. The space is a bit easier to visit with a group and their Agua Frescas are a legit 5/5 or 10/10 stars.
author: Ames B.

description:
$3.50 a taco = overpriced to hell. Hate to break the news to you folks but taco trucks sell them for $1-1.50 each. Corn Tortillas are La Rosa and can be picked up at any legitimate mercado. Don't believe the hype, La Taqueria is laughing their asses to the bank. I'll edit my post if you can prove me wrong, walk to 10 different taquerias and let me know if you find a $3.50 taco. In the meantime, I'll be enjoy "legit" ones at Taqueria Cancun.

I will give credit where credit is due, their Carne Asada burritos are good but carnitas, c'mon, Baja Fresh called and they want their recipe back.
author: KGB R.

description: Not quite Socal quality Mexican but better than El Farolito.
author: Snuffles B.

description: chorizo/ chicken taco combo is to die for !! this was my first meal after moving to San Fran and certainly won't be my last !
author: Allee C.

description: La Taqueria has the best mexican food in the whole word! I have grown up eating their tacos and burritos and of all the places I have ever had mexican food nothing can ever top their perfect ingedients and flavors!
author: Mary K.

description: Ate lunch here today as I was killing time waiting for my 1:30PM appointment at Timbuk2 headquarters. Had the Lengua and Chicken tacos.  The service was great and the chicken taco delicious and full of meat; however there was something about the lengua taco. Maybe is my stomach? Well the place was packed and people kept coming so obviously they must be doing something right!
author: Frank B.

description: best veggie tacos out there!  soft yet crunchy---cant beat it.  although dont get it to go--- it'll be soggy in 5 mins!
author: Nisha K.

description:
I'm all across the street yelping La Taqueria to see what it's like. I get urgent taco cravings, sometimes too urgent for me to finish reading the reviews. 

Shoo. I'd never been so glad to hear 'number 60!' called out before in my life. My carnitas and carne asada tacos came out topped with avocado n crema, so good, nearly made me cry. I inhaled that stuff standing up and yes, I'd do it again.
author: D'arcy N.

description: This place has amazing food.  You absolutely have to order a carne asada burrito.  The meat is juicy and spiced perfectly.  The portions are smaller than other restaurants, but it also doesn't give you that "why did I just eat that" feeling.  Their spicy green salsa is quite good as well.  This place has been packed every time I have been, so have someone scout a table while waiting in line.
author: Joel F.

description:
+ the veggie taco was pretty tasty
- it was not filling
- kinda expensive
- not that many options
- no free chips

in conclusion, their taco is pretty unique and thats about it.
author: Jen Y.

description: I think it's all a mind game on why they get so many good reviews. Of course with all of their achievements hanging on the wall they obviously earned them and that's great. But those achievements can have an effect on how people think of this place. Of course if you hear and see 5 stars about a place you automatically think good about a place. My visit though was alright. We live in the bay so I'd expect to have better from La Taqueria. It used to be good back in the day but damn my recent was bad. I ordered a burrito which was more like a taquito. Extra charge for rice? I thought that was standard in a burrito. My burrito was skinnier than a crack heads wrist. With the carne asada grilling on the grill I thought I was going to have some top notch flavors but it wasn't even close. Maybe next time I'll just buy the carne asada fresh off the  grill and eat that alone to get the true flavor of the meat. I'll probably give it another shot but again with the many taquerias in the city I think La Taqueria needs to step up their game. Before I forget it's cash only. It's 2014, what business is cash only? Even food trucks now take cards.
author: Philip O.

description: La Taqueria is beyond delicious! You will not regret making a trip to La Taqueria. We travel more than an hour just to have their delicious tacos and burritos. Price is a bit high compared to other taquerias in the area but they're worth every penny!
author: Maria A.

description: This is the best taqueria I've been to in all of San Francisco. Everything here is superb but I highly recommend the pork burrito with avocado. Don't forget to smother everything in the magic green sauce they have on the tables!
author: Aaron W.

description: I saw a fairly good sized line at this place so I thought I'd check it out. Upon entering I saw multiple awards on the walls from places such as Zagat so I thought this had to be pretty legit. Let me tell you this Carne Asada Burrito I'm eating right now is to die for whatever they put on the meats is delish, I very highly recommend this place.
author: Nicholas A.

description:
What's the big deal on this food? I'm Mexican and this is not great Mexican food, it tastes mediocre. 
Who ever said it's Great Mexican food they must be American people, as usual. 

The service was TERRIBLE to begin with, except for two guys behind the counter who noticed how rude was the girl taking my order. Only because of them I thought about not rating it on yelp. 

My friend went there TWICE to try the " Famous" tacos and both times he said there was nothing better about the food than the usual taqueria food everywhere and his didn't like his tacos.  

So I did some research, and supposedly they are famous mainly for their " TACO"  the one with TWO tortillas, one crispy and one soft. That's new to me too... so I told my friend he needed to ASK for it. 

When I finally went, there was nothing on the menu about these tacos, ok whatever, I ask the girl with the nicest attitude (so happy to finally eat these tacos!) to tell me the different variety of tacos they had. 

She rudely just mentioned what's on their MENU (and those tacos are NOT there) what a way to sell! Ok, whatever I guess its a secret
so I ask about them... and she said ahh yes, we have those too.. but you have to ask. 
I said, well what if I'm a new customer and I don't know? she said well then you don't get them and even people who know about them and don't ask, we give them regular tacos. 

ok, whatever...her attitude was bad, the rest of the food mediocre.. 

The tacos were good (because of the innovative idea of using both crispy and soft tortilla) but that's it.
author: Geena T.

description: Their carne asada regular burritos are the bomb, but they tend to be too wet with their boiled beans, try draining them before inserting into burrito please. I wouldn't order a bean & cheese quesadilla or you'll get a big wet mess. Again, please drain the water out of the beans. There is no refried beans choice. I used to love this place but it is getting run down and dirty, try cleaning  the outside of the bottles of salsa and refill them often too. The restaurant could use a good clean from ceiling to floor.  Throw on some new paint and the patio can be replenished too.  I hate to say this, cause I love the authentic Latino community, but walk over to Valencia Street and see how they have it going on.
author: Susan S.

description:
Some of the best tacos in San Francisco -- the meat is tender and has a ton of flavor, the tortillas are amazing, and the overall taste can't be beat.

4 stars simply because the prices are a little steep -- $3.50 per taco, and extra for things like cheese, sour cream, guac, etc. There is a ton of meat in that taco for $3.50 though.
author: Evan B.

description:
I visited a friend in San Francisco and she thought it would be good to get food at La Taqueria.  She and all of her family raved about this place and said it was the best taqueria around.  I'm not a huge Mexican food fan and had never had a burrito, but this experience was great!

It was very crowded when we entered and the line was long, but we didn't spend much time waiting.  One thing I found to be a bit silly was that they charged a pretty hefty amount to REMOVE items.  It cost $42 for four of us to eat... that's a lot of money for a burrito.  However, the burrito that you get is packed with food.  I got chicken and cheese.  The cheese was a bit spicy (expected, but just a warning) but the chunks of meat were big and were very juicy, though I did find a lot of dark meat pieces in there which I wasn't a fan of.  The burrito was piping hot and I could only finish half of it.  It was extremely messy though, so beware!  When you take a bite, juice just comes pouring out of it.  My friend had a pool of juice at the bottom of her basket by the time she was done.

Also, if you're expecting to get rice in your burrito, you can go somewhere else.  They just don't have it.  My friend, who ordered for us in Spanish, asked the girl TWICE about the rice because she was so bewildered!

All in all, this is a pretty good place to eat.  For someone who had never had Mexican food before, I enjoyed it.
author: Kaella C.

description: This is hands down my favorite taqueria the best TACOS ever! the crispy tacos are amazing, the only issue with this place is that it is a bit pricey for a taqueria beware everything is additional so if you add sour cream, avocado and cheese you are going to pay for 3 extra items! I LOVE this place I wish i can eat here once a week.
author: Claudia H.

description:
Skeptical about a mexican restaurant that doesn't have rice, and only one kind of beans, but alas my friend said it right; it's good!

I had a chicken burrito and it was very fresh and yummy! One of those word of mouth places for sure! Also had a cheese quesadilla which was a guilty greasy pleasure but oh so good. I think their speciality is their tacos, so next time I'll be trying some of those. 

Good authentic Mexican food at good prices. Clean place too. You never know in the Mission... Kidding (-:
author: Ryan B.

description: Always heard good things about this place and finally decided to give it a try..... Big mistake. The burrito had no flavor, was small, had no bite to it (kinda mushy), and was reminiscent of a microwaveable burrito. I would rather eat at Chipotle than this place. Poncho Villa is still the best on The City.
author: Joe D.

description: I just ate the best taco de lengua I've ever had in my life. Goddam son!!!
author: Dan R.

description:
If you get a chance out of all the Mexican taqueria's to try - try this one.

La Taqqueria has been around for as long as I can remember.  Their food is fresh, authentic and delicious.  Order the chicken soft tacos or a full-on burrito of your choice.  

I go out of my way to eat at La Taqueria every time I get near San Francisco.  Great food.
author: Timothy A.

description: Bland meat (chicken and beef) and not recommended. If you're in the neib, go to Taqueria Vallarta, the tacos there are soo much better.
author: Amy F.

description:
I think if you eat at a place more than a 100 times it should get 5 stars

If you haven't tried your tacos crispy style (dorados) then you haven't really eaten here. If you have only had burrittos and not ordered the tacos then you REALLY haven't eaten here (see the name). And this said by someone who has never ordered the meat version only the beans, cheese, salsa and avocado--crispy style! 

They grill-fry the first corn tortilla with cheese and then put a steamed one over that so it's easier to eat. Yum. The avocado is fresh, whole and not turned into a bad, snotty rendition of guacamole.

There is absolutely no rice. Odd, I know, but just the way it is.

Order an agua fresca, too-- the perfect accompaniment--fresa, melon, mango, or pina.

this review  is in honor of Dia de los Muertos because that's where I plan to eat tonight ~ and possibly in honor of the 100th or so visit.
author: Liza B.

description:
I went there last night. 

I paid 8 dollars for a burrito. 
It didn't include chips.
It didn't include cheese.
Avocado cost one dollar.
The tortilla was soggy.
They don't have refried beans.
It was kind of small.

My friends really loved it. 
They're from Boston and Canada.

I'm from Texas.
I would like my 8 dollars back.
author: Chelsea T.

description:
$2.50 large cantaloupe agua fresca and $6 carne asada burrito = one of the best lunches I've had in a while. I actually liked that there wasn't any rice, nothing but carne asada, whole pinto beans, and pico de gallo. Normally, I feel like a bloated whale after eating a burrito but felt okay after this one (I still waddled home, though.)

So, for a more manageable burrito, give La Taqueria a try!
author: Nathalie L.

description:
This is truly Taco-Heaven. 

Mission Street between 24th and 25th.

But not the glitzy and glamorous Taco-Heaven that your mom used to always talk about. 

It's usually ALWAYS busy with fellow Taco-lovin' folk, and as you get into the regularly busy and long-ish line to order, you start jockeying for position to grab the first open table (which you sometimes have to clean off yourself, I've been tempted to bring some handi-wipes with me, but then my friends might start calling a clean freak).

It's well worth it to plan your urban hike with this being your lunch destination. 

And with the fairly cramped dining area and small-ish tables and stools, you invariably get to know everyone around you. You can't be shy in this place, nice people watching and great conversation.
author: Mickey A.

description:
A bitter cultural battle has been waged over La Taqueria's burritos. Some think they're the apogee of hand-held food; some think they're undersized, overpriced and oversold; yet others won't even think of them as burritos because they don't have rice. Well, they are fine burritos, and I, personally, tip my hat to their ricelessness -- but they're just a stalking horse. 

You'll find the real heart of the place -- nay, the soul of San Francisco Mexican culture itself -- in La Taqueria's soft-shell tacos. Specifically, the vegetarian soft-shell taco with avocado. It is the single finest manually-operated food item of Mexican origin available anywhere in the United States. I brook no argument on this point.

Nowhere else, but nowhere, are soft-shell tacos assembled with anywhere near the structural integrity and complete gustatory synchrony -- of flavors and textures both -- found in these gems. Unlike soft-shells elsewhere, indifferent, unorchestrated assemblages that devolve on contact into a basketful of component parts, La Taqueria's tacos are robust and well thought-out, fireplugs of flavor and soul satisfaction. Two corn tortillas are lightly sizzled on the grill before being overlapped just so, steamed with jack cheese, laden with beans, tomato salsa and chunks of avocado and wrapped deftly in wax paper -- all by the same guy who's been performing the same task, in the same spot, for over 30 years.

It's the Aston Martin DB9 of fast food.

Futher thoughts on the soft-shells: they don't absolutely have to be veggie, but you'll find their veg tacos' balance of ingredients so finely calibrated you wouldn't want to disturb it with even a chunk of meat. Oh, and don't get 'em with the green tomatillo hot sauce added -- it's so good you'll want to use one of the squeeze bottles at each table to personally slather it on each bite.

Two of these with a strawberry or mango agua fresca and you're eating the meal of the gods, all for well under ten bucks.

Go now. Get two. Thank me later.
author: Douglas G.

description: This spot's a good change from my staples...metate,farrolito & papalote. Their carne asada is pretty tasty. Burritos are standard but a little pricey.  the tacos are the way to go...bang for your buck & they use a hard & soft taco shell stuck together for crunchy textured goodness...dorado style! The place always seems to be slammed, so be prepared to line up & scope out your seats.
author: Ramon L.

description:
In an attempt to garner more 'useful' votes, I have decided to cut the jokes and give you a well-thought out review of La Taqueria.

The burritos are really good. You should eat here.
author: RJ A.

description: Come on, THIS PLACE HAS NO FRIGGIN' RICE!!!  And, THEY CHARGE YOU FOR FRIGGIN' CHIPS AND SALSA!!!   My compadre and I were still hungry after this burrito and had to walk down to El Faralito to get a second burrito just to fill up!!! And we're not pigs! (yes we are) And after that, we went into McDonald's for a sundae with hot fudge and nuts and on our way out, we were having a chuckle and some homeless dude says to us "what are you so happy about?" !!!
author: Rick H.

description: Did the owner really give us roses out his window after serving us the most bomb ass aqua frescas? And then constantly check up on us during lunch and make the funniest comments? YES HE DID. Wonderful man and a wonderful restaurant he takes care of.
author: Cristal G.

description:
Why it sucks ???

#1  They charge for chips
#2  Weak ass salsa bar 
#3  No rice
#4  Only flour tortillas


I guarantee that everyone that like this place is from the Mid-West.
author: Joe G.

description:
My girlfriend has a very good friend who lives in the Mission, and we go to her house a few times a month.  Whenever we go, I make sure not to wear red or blue so we don't get caught in the crossfire of those Norteno and Sureno scumbags.  Or is it cowards...it's probably cowards.  Most times that we go, we grab a quick burrito at Tanqueria Cancun.  Each time we finish our meal, my girlfriend says we should try La Taqueria because it may be her favorite burrito in the city.  On Tuesday night, we found ourselves in the Mission, and my girlfriend suggested we drive down to La Taqueria.  My reply, "ok, but you know that's Norteno territory right?"  So, I zipped up my black fleece to cover the shirt I was wearing, but like a moron, I pulled on my Red Sox toque.  Well, that's red AND blue, so those stupid gangbangers won't know what to do.

When we walked in, I was little confused by the set-up, and I was not sure were we should place our order.  We soon figured that out because a very nice girl behind the counter by the cash register asked us.  I went for the Veggie Burrito because I am a pansy who does not eat meat.  As we waited for our dinner we looked around.  The place was packed.  I saw a small pack of St. Ignatius kids eating a meal.  What the hell were these kids doing in gang territory at 8:00 on a school night?  Luckily they were wearing red, so the Nortenos would not shoot them up.  

Anyway, our food came and we were off.  When we sat down to eat, I was a little disappointed.  I asked for "everything" on my burrito.  This did not include rice or cheese..or anything except beans and runny sour cream.  I guess the definition of "everything" is different at La Taqueria.  The bottom of the burrito was soggy by the time I got there...which was about 8 minutes.  One of my pet peeves is soggy bottomed burritos.  A burrito should never have so much liquid in it that it gets soggy.  Another pet peeve?  No chips.  

Not sure why this place gets such rave reviews.
author: Chris I.

description: This place is amazing !!! Sure, the lines are extremely long but it's worth it, makes it seem very popular ( which it is ), and the food comes very fast once you order it. I really enjoyed the burritos and the fresca !!!!
author: Lilah B.

description:
Get ready to pay around $10 for a medium sized "super" burrito. I say "super", but that's not really an option here. If you want sour cream, avocado, and cheese it costs $1 each on top of the $6 price of the regular burrito. Also, you can pay for chips. I asked for a cup of salsa on the side and was given one, as well as a dirty look. Sorry I wanted my food to go! Jeez.

But onto the burrito itself. It has already been established that they don't put rice in it. Fine. I order burritos like that sometimes anyway. But without rice, the soupy stewed chicken has nothing to absorb the juices, so they wind up squirting out when you bite into it and dripping all over my hands. Way too messy and not worth the mess for the taste. Also, not big enough for the price. Tacos must be the way to go here, but I can't say that I'll be back anytime soon.
author: Jennie H.

description: Need a quick snack... One carnitas taco and one carne asada taco and I am one satisfied man. Love it!
author: Steve K.

description:
I literally stumbled in here after an Ben R's afternoon of drinking group meeting. I needed to sober up before hitting the road so I decided to walk it off. BAD IDEA... drunk walking in the Mission with hundreds of cars rushing by is like a blind person playing Frogger. So like when I saw La Taqueria it was like God parting the sea..except I never got to see the burning bush after wards unless you count the dude wearing a weird speedos thing which I'm still trying to forget. 

So I love Mexican food. I'm a total Nachos Grande fan because 
1. When you're drunk you can eat only with you hands. 
2. When you're drunk and drop your food it's only one chip rather than an entire taco. 
3. It's cheap Mexican food..so when you're drunk and throw up you still can afford to go back and get seconds. 

So the Nachos Grande is huge. When I say huge I'm talking about a large plate overshadowed by the towering amounts of lettuce, cheese and guacamole. I seriously think that it came with a gallon of guacamole.. because that's how much ended up on my shirt. It was a pretty solid meal. I still prefer El Balazo but this place is a close second. 

Also since I'm Asian I'm always trying to get my Mexican street cred so I got the Limon drink and flan. The limon drink was excellent! But when I ordered the flan they gave me the look like I was crazy. Maybe it was old or no Mexican really orders flan from there but it was nearly $3 and probably the only time I'll get it. 

This is a fast food Mexican restaurant so there's not much I'm going to expect from decor.  I do love the ladies that work there. They are so nice and make such good food I'd marry them. Actually I think I did ask one of them to drunk marry me... but they were so nice they didn't put a well deserved cockroach in my nachos.
author: Dan T.

description:
UPDATE *****1/20/08*****
crispy tacos, not on the menu but the best in norcal!!


this is now my favorite taco shop stop in san francisco. salsa choices are a bit skimpy but i do really like the green salsa in the bottle at the table. hot too. a couple piled high tacos for lunch here at la taqueria will hold me over till dinner.

i don't eat burritos that much anymore but the meat is the same tacos or burritos. i have had the carne asada, carnitas, and chicken tacos. the meat has a nice flavor from being chargrilled except for the chicken which was stewed style. the carnitas have the requisite crunchy pieces along with the moist bites. 

the tacos are loaded with meat and whole pinto's topped with pico de gallo. $3.50 might be a little high but it hasn't stopped me from ordering them time and time again. they are big tacos.

i don't understand the low ratings of the last few reviews recently. la taqueria is well known to charge a bit more since they are sans rice. but $60 more is embellishing at it's finest. i wasn't charged extra for the beans or the salsa. they are standard equipment on these tacos. 

i like my tacos simple so i don't have the problem of extra charges for all the extras. kinda like cream cheese on sushi. WTF people. why is it we always have to add all kind of shit to our tacos, sushi or whatever. the food here is already super sized. keep it simple and enjoy these tacos and burritos as they were meant to be eaten.
author: roger b.

description:
grab a seat quick this place is popular for good reason.

carne esada, all day long. 

they dont serve rice, but their chips are muy bien so i recommend stuffing them into your giant burrito, it's delicious, and so is their green pepper sauce.

love the live band and you will too.

cash only !
author: Stephanie D.

description:
I was just treated to lunch at La Taqueria both literally and figuratively by a co-worker that swears by the place...

I won't write a long review, I think it can be best summed up by a simple phrase - 'And it was good!'...Definitely will be back when I can have a beer with Burrito.
author: Todd E.

description:
Tacos and Burritos for the purists. No rice baby! 

I love rice - I live for rice...rice is a staple in my diet:

My three meals in any given day look like this: 1) Eggs, bacon/veggie burger patty/chicken apple sausage, rice 2) Chicken, salad, rice 3) Piece of grilled steak, asparagus, rice.  RICE. RICE. RICE. There is really very little room for any other starch in my life. 

There is only one time I do not like rice - when I am eating a burrito or taco!  La Taqueria - I love you, you are the best!
author: Clarice V.

description:
lately, I have been time traveling and teleporting to different locations while simply dining in SF. the wonders of living here!
walking into La Taqueria mission street in SF could have been stepping into a taco stand in Puerto Vallarta or Ensenada. 
i ordered a beef tongue taco and a fried pork taco. 
These two items hit the spot like nothing else could have.
chased it down with a Coke and i was more than satisfied.
the atmosphere here is fast paced and the food turns over quickly. 
you are eating freshly prepared Mexican fare with flavor and authenticity. 
the other diners here are total SF melting pot. young and old.
Latin and non-Latins.
next go round here, I will try the burrito which looked delicious from a distance.
author: Jeff W.

description:
YES

Whenever I go home, this is one of the first places I eat.

I don't care that a taco can come out to $8, it is absolutely worth it. The meat and all the ingredients are delicious. 

I am also cautious about what steak I consume, but La Taqueria has always been an exception

The staff is wonderful but also no-nonsense. They are sensitive to crows and servers will make their way down the line taking your order in advance.

When friends are in town, this is where I tell them to go
author: Molly L.

description:
Woke up and rolled out of my bed in Fremont this morning feeling a little down. I'm definitely in need of some comfort food to lift my sorry soul. The first thing on my mind the moment my feet hit the floor is one of the fine burritos turned out by La Taqueria. 

Taking BART to work in downtown San Francisco, the craving won't leave me alone ... destiny calls. The doors open at Embarcadero, I almost get off but stall out. Screw it if I'm late, this is a friggin burrito pilgrimage!!  24th St Mission station it is then...

The beans, the rice, the cheese, the sour cream, the carnitas and oOOoOoohhhhhhh the guacamole - this is burrito making elevated to an art form. Nothing fancy here, just pure burrito mastery. Get involved.
author: Nate R.

description:
OMG, Taco's so good you will bite your fingers off ! Haven't tried the pastor but love the chicken, steak, and probably the best carnitas I have ever had too! 

You must have the Cantaloupe Drink to accompany your meal!
author: Ron W.

description:
We were on the way from a meeting in Menlo Park back into downtown San Fran and my co-worker suggested this place. I am always down for trying new authentic food.

We came in at the prime lunch hour and as such the place was very busy and the line stretched the length of the counter. While the line may look daunting at first, they are very quick to get people through, and actually have someone taking orders and writing you up and handing you a slip to save time.

I waffled between the burrito or tacos. I ended up getting the tacos. They are soft tacos, and you can get them with a variety of toppings and fillings. I went with the carnitas and carne asada. I recommend getting two; while they have a lot of meat, it's not quite enough for a meal. Also, one other tip, I recommend getting the green hot sauce on the side. The sauce is extremely good, but if you ask them to include within the taco, there is a lot included, and ends up making it very hot.

The food is extremely authentic and very tasty. The staff is also very friendly, and it's a great authentic place to grab a quick bite.
author: Anuj G.

description:
Convenient location, flexible menu, and a relatively wide variety of agua fresca are the 3 things that stood out to me here. The quality was solid, but didn't strike me as anything special.

The mural that runs the length of one wall was a nice touch of culture in what's otherwise a pretty standard counter and prep-line eatery. They've got a very strong and loyal following, as evidenced by the plethora of strong Yelp reviews and the fact that they've apparently been in business for over 30 years. 

Cash only, but they have an ATM on-site. They're also on the "no rice" side of the debate over whether burritos should contain rice or not.

Trivia: While "taqueria" translates as "taco shop", in many areas (including San Francisco) it actually refers to a restaurant focusing on burritos.
author: Bill B.

description:
Ok as of 08/08/07 this place has 312 reviews, including mine.
169 have 5 stars
82 have 4 stars
38 have 3 stars
14 have 2 stars
11 have 1 stars (including my review)

Here is my conclusion...

169 have no taste buds & must have been drunk when eating here
82 must of had the tacos and not the burritos
38 have not been to a "decent" taqueria
14 have the right concept on the chips and salsa
11 have exceptional palates and should be expert culinary critics on Mexican Taqueria's

I recommend you filter the reviews and only read the 1 and 2 stars.  You will get the truth from those reviews. Here is a summary if you do not feel like reading all 25 true reviews.
1. No free chips and salsa
2. Any substitution on a burrito you get charged
3. No rice No refried beans
4. Bland food
5. Long lines for bland food
6. Over priced
7. Small burritos
8. Crowded (don't take this as a sign that the food is good)
9. Over Hyped
10. The guac does not look fresh when its sitting on the back counter for hours on end.
author: David P.

description:
A taco shouldn't cost nearly $5. And if I pay same for same, I'll expect the chips to be complimentary. But here at La Taqueria, where They Do and They Aren't and you stand in a line to order and are given a number and then proceed to uncomfortable benches, the normal rules don't apply.

Vegetarians know this: ye should run for the hills 'fore ye eat here. Honestly, save a $5  Quesadilla, there don't seem much here for ye.
 
Opportunarians know this: meats here are of very high quality here, but if things as described in paragraph have been known to make you grumpy, move along. Or if you like rice in your burrito. Or salsa roja. Mostly what they've got here is salsa fresa, which though fine, costs extra. I'm getting grumpy just thinking about it.

Rats! And Bah! Yeah, the food here IS good. But phooey!
author: Jeremy W.

description:
I thought that I could walk to pretty much any taqueria in the mission and I couldn't really go wrong. Well...I was wrong. My first indication should have been the taco price tag - $3.50. I thought - "surely that means they do tacos in orders of 2 or something." Sorry folks. That's $3.50 for ONE taco. Granted they do give you a lot of meat, and I was full after one taco. I would even let it pass if it was a good taco, which it was not. 

So I was expecting a true street taco, taco truck style taco. While it was in a corn tortilla, that was about the only similarity. I ordered a carne asada taco, and the carne asada was less on the steak side and more on the beef side. It was a like a weird mix between steak and ground beef. No wonder their menu options for meat say "Carne Asada - Beef". They're not the same thing but apparently La Taqueria has found a magical way to blend the two. That was strike one. Strike two - to my horror, the taco had PINTO BEANS! When the hell does a true taco have pinto beans?! Not that I'm the expert on tacos but I think this is the first time I've been served pinto beans in a taqueria taco!!! I asked to have them redo the taco without the beans - it was an offense to the taco! Strike three - no cilantro, lime, etc... Instead the taco was topped with some pico de gallo. 

Side note - the pico de gallo was actually some of the best I've had. And the green salsa on their tables is pretty kick ass. So basically I'd come back here for the chips and salsa, but that's about it. The tacos here blow. Oh - and I had no problems with the service here, they seemed pretty nice and redid my taco without grumbling about it.
author: Humaira M.

description:
UPDATE 2/22/06:  
It's 8:45pm @ Shine and our stomachs decide it's time to bounce (after yet another SWEET Yelp Elite evening of merriment and sparkling conversation...cheers to the Yelp boys and girls, Oronoco and Sauce!).  So the 4 of us hightail it down  Mission to La Taqueria only to arrive on scene precisely at the same time 3 large ghetto-fied men exit out of a shiny black suburban.  I was still glowing from having so much fun at Shine that I didn't notice them roll in and step in line before us.  I tap this good looking brothah's shoulder in front of me, who is outfitted in a hooded sweatshirt and camo gear, to ask, "Hey, are you guys in line?" thinking to myself he looked insanely familiar...to which he politely replies that they already ordered.  I smile, nod my head and make my way up to the register when my (real) brother behind me barely stammers:

"I can't believe you just asked MOS DEF if he's in line?!?! I would have offered to buy all his tacos! Geez!"  

The guy from "Italian Job"? Dude, I knew he looked familiar!  Haha!  Anyway, I wanted to Yelp about my celebrity run-in with the Hip-Hop God & his entourage, and update my rating from 3 to 5 stars (definitely order the carne asada w/ the works)!  Mike (the owner?) was super friendly, comically flirtatious and gave our table free tangerine aqua frescas on the house! (Must have been my YELP shirt that merits all this attention. Now THAT'S celebrity status.)

--------
02/06/2006:
The mango agua fresca is like straight up drinking the fruit whole. 

I opted for the chicken taco (crispy, of course) and am sad to report that it was dry. I'll have to order the carne asada next time. Redeeming qualities: fresh guac and melted cheese in the center.
author: Irene S.

description:
I was there last week for lunch and had the crispy taco.  It was delicious.  The place is clean and well run.  My only problem is that they don't offer any combo dishes - everything is a la carte.  And some taquerias have a salsa bar; I missed that here. 

But for solid Mexican food this place is fine.  You probably pay a little more, but it's just about worth it.
author: Robert N.

description: I'm the proud son of a Mexican Mother and La Taqueria has the best tacos I have ever had. The lines are long at lunch for a reason this place is the best!
author: Leon P.

description:
Point breakdown... Let's start with the food:

Four stars for the burrito - it wasn't quite up to snuff for the Mission, but still tasty. The carnitas was a little dry. Overall decent, though.

Minus .5 stars for cash only

Minus .5 stars for a crowded, confusing restaurant layout

Minus 1 star for asking for $1.40 for chips! I know the economy sucks, but if I'm giving you $9.50 for a super burrito (also, this is a bit expensive for what you're getting, which is smaller than some of the other Mission burritos), I expect some chips. This place must be the only taqueria in the Mission that doesn't include chips with your order.

Ultimately, I'd say if you are in the area, go to Taqueria San Jose or El Farolito.
author: Paul B.

description:
The whole place is kind of weird to me. They are the lone wolf of the mission taqueria industrial complex. I don't think anything good has come of it except for amazing meat flavors but whatevs.

I'm pondering:

Why am I paying a dollar extra to not have beans?
Why are your burritos hit with a shrink ray to make them 25% smaller than a standard issue mission burrito (SIMB)?
Why are your chairs tiny thatched stools?
Why are chips $1.30?
Where is the rojo salsa?
Why does the carne asada smell/taste so good I order/eat/leave semi-satisfied but wondering what could have been???
author: Morga n.

description: This place dishes out mediocre tacos and burritos. Nothing memorable about this joint. Tacos come with beans? I don't know if it's a regional thing, but it sure takes time to get use to eating this style tacos.
author: Mary A.

description:
If you're coming to SF and you want authentic.. if you want the best.. you come to la taqueria. i've been coming here for ages and it's always the same: just plain good..

get the crispy taco and get the carnitas burrito. 498 reviews can't be wrong. 

also, when you're done, be sure to head next door to dianda's for some italian coffee and dessert.

::burp::
author: Dave S.

description: I had their vegetarian buritto, and it is by far the best vegetarian burrito I've ever had. The only bad thing is that parking (metered street parking) in that neighborhood is a pain. But other than that, I will definitely come back if I am ever in that neighborhood. I definitely would love to try their other food. And the horchatas, by the way, is the way I like it. Not too sweet.
author: Christopher R.

description:
The first time I came here was during the recovery stage of my bout with food poisoning. Taking me to a taqueria (let alone THE taqueria) when I can barely eat is just cruel, but I had been keeping food down for a few days and figured I should go big or go home.

I ordered a single taco and it was probably the greatest meal I ever had. It was the first thing I had eaten in a week with any flavor. The combination of crunchy and soft shells, the carne asada and the flavorful salsa made me orgasm in the high chair outside the restaurant. Luckily there was a festival happening on Mission St. so my screams of pleasure were drowned out by a mariachi band.

I went back a week later to make sure it wasn't just a fluke; to ensure that the tastiness wasn't a result of having only rice and toast in my system for a week.

It wasn't a fluke. This place is fo' real. Or as they say in Spanish, "La Taqueria come mi estmago a pedazos."
author: Jared S.

description: Simple, affordable, and a great place to hog out. One of my favorite tacos joints in SF.
author: Linda G.

description:
I didn't know that the burrito came without rice until I took a couple bites. I like a thick burrito, and I missed the filler. The cheese tasted good and plastic, which worked well in the burrito somehow, but the corn quesadilla was not as good because the cheese stood alone and exposed. I liked the chips and salsa alright, but I believe those should come with meal, unless the chips have been freshly made and are sickeningly good. I don't mind paying for a nice, fried tortilla chip, but these weren't the best. And the tomato juice in the salsa kept the chips soggy, so I couldn't even finish most of them. The more I think about this place, the more I don't really like it. I just like beans and any place that sells horchata. 

About the price, we spent about 12 bucks between the two of us, but we split everything and don't eat meat. So I guess that would add up if my boyfriend and I ate our own separate meals.

The green chile sauce in the tube squirter is the shining light in this place. Very good.
author: Brittany L.

description:
I will do (almost) anything for good tacos.  

La Taqueria poses a dangerous threat.  

'Nuff said.
author: A W.

description:
I dont' know why the local papers keep highly rating this place. it is overpriced and overrated.  

first the burrito's are weird, go there if you're not a fan of rice or beans. compare it to the other taquerias nearby and you'll see that they have equal if not better food.

sure their tacos are good, but I say everything else is average at best. 

leave this place to white people and tourists. laugh at their overpriced food. and walk over to el farolito on 24th. 

and why do they close so early?
author: John L.

description:
There are two kinds of people in this world.  People who eat rice in their burrito and people who know better.  You can guess which camp I fall in to.

Being firmly of the opinion that rice does not ever belong in a burrito (a great way to ruin a perfectly good burrito if you ask me), this place rocks.  The veggie burrito, carnitas burrito or the carne asada taco are my go-to menu items, add a corn quesidilla and a watermelon agua fresca and you just might achieve nirvana.

Besides, my parents have been going to this place regularly since 1972, it's a family institution.  When I was a little girl I used to beg my dad for a dollar to play songs on the juke box, this was way back when the owner used to work the cash register, I'd head up to the counter, ask him for quarters for my dollar and he'd always count out five quarters, as he handed me the fifth one he'd always smile and say "Play one for me".  Yummy food and a healthy heaping serving of nostalgia, it doesn't get much better than that.
author: Renae H.

description:
Okay so, let me get this straight. In a world where tacos contain meat, pico de gallo and cilantro you want to charge me $1.20 for NO BEANS? No wonder this place stays in business, they make money hand over fist with all the add-ons. It's like a Mercedes - yeah it starts at $29,999 but you're pushing $50K with the options. But I'm trying a new place for the first time, I should order a taco how I like it, irrespective of anything else, right?

So a carne asada taco, a carnitas taco (wanted Pollo Asado but all they had was boiled chicken, gross) with guacamole, sin frijoles and I got it crispy, meaning, a slightly cooked corn tortilla with a regular tortilla on the outside. Not a bad taco, pretty good carne asada, well seasoned and no noticeable gristle or fat. Carnitas was pretty good but not the best I've had. The taco is loaded with their tomato/onion cheap version of pico de gallo. The guacamole is very good - I always get that warm feeling in the cockles of my heart when I see a lady cutting up avocado. 

But was it $11.50 good? Not really. I'd go back and try a burrito...but not anytime soon. I complain a lot about how super burritos cost a lot, but this was tending toward ridiculous. It's definitely worth a try though.
author: Ross R.

description: Really disgusting food handling and cleaning practices. Used to love coming here for the tacos. Then one day i sat outside at the bar and watched the guy assembling the tacos wipe his knife with a dirty rag that hung on the garbage can. My husband and I were sick that night. We never went back. Check out their health department score. Yuck.
author: Jo M.

description:
There are hundreds of taquerias in San Francisco...but only one La Taqueria.  This place is an institution,  the real deal and has been dishing up tasty tacos and burritos in the Mission since I was a kid. Decor has not changed, guy behind the counter grilling the meat has not changed and the fact that they serve up one of the best burritos in the city hasn't changed.

This is not your run of the mill overstuffed rice and refried bean burritos. You will also never find anything called a "wrap" on their menu.  This place does two things and does them well, tacos and burritos.  

Order a burrito and what you get is flavorful fire-grilled meats, fresh avacados, and lard-free beans wrapped in a no-nonsense white flour tortilla.  No, it's not quite as large as the burritos down the street, but it's all quality ingredients.  So, if you're looking for a 5lb burrito, keep on heading down the street, but you'll be missing out on one of the best damn burritos/tacos in the city.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
This is the unassaible king of Mission taquerias.  Personally, I avoid the burritos here, I think better examples abound on Mission Street (though they're certainly more than passable here).  Rather the taco, specifically the carnitas taco, is the specialty here, and a more juicy and flavorful example is not to be found, period.  

Order a couple of these on a Sunday afternoon, with avocado and an horchata, the Mission district alive, boisterous and colorful, have a seat on a stool on the small outdoor counter and watch all the magic happen.  You won't have a better Mission meal.
author: Todd E.

description: Restaurant was clean. I had lengua and carne asada. The meat quality of the lengua was really good and very well-prepared. The carne asada was fair. The tacos themselves are not your average size tacos and are pretty hefty.  The agua de melon was also very refreshing. The only drawback to this location was that it was a little overpriced. Our party had a total of 6 tacos, 1 burrito, chips and salsa, and 3 beverages for a total of $45. The food was good, but not your average taqueria bargain.
author: Aaron V.

description: By far one of my favorite spots to get a burrito. I tend to order the carne asada grilled burrito and I love to add sour cream and cheese. There are usually a lot of people, but they tend to make the food quickly so you aren't waiting long at all. Very lively atmosphere. The chips they offer are deep fried and pretty greasy, not my favorite, but the burritos are great!
author: Jessica D.

description:
If I could eat at only one taqueria in the entire Bay Area, this would be a front-runner.  Order a carnitas corn quesadilla and a carne asada burrito, both with guacamole, and you will be a very happy person.

I grew up eating at Gordo Taqueria in the Richmond, and that has always been the measure by which I grade other taqueria establishments.  I also went to school in San Diego for eight years, and ate at all of the Roberto's establishments and spinoffs (Royberto's, Alberto's, Albierto's), and the tiny places along the coast (La Bahia, Dos Hermanos, ...), and apart from the holy grail that is Gordo Taqueria, this place is better than all of them (though admittedly a different varietal from the more SoCal-esque burrito experience, e.g., La Bahia in Bird Rock has lobster and shrimp).

The agua fresca is great here, the hot sauce is the green yet flavorful sort, and the staff are friendly, take your order while you're in line if possible to get a head-start on things, and you won't leave hungry or dissatisfied.

One of the tough things about this place is that, to get to it, you have to pass about five bazillion other restaurants that also look great.  There's a pupuseria place next door I always want to try.

Anyway, take your friends, significant others, mom, dad, or yourself here any time you want a special treat.  You can't go wrong.
author: Walter K.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place.

Probably because in my head this is a given. This is IT in terms of burritos. 

I grew up in Bernal Heights and this was where we always, always, always got our burritos. I have a very vivid memory being 12 and coming here around that awful period near Christmas time when they annually close down for a few weeks. This vivid memory includes seeing the sign that they were closed and CRYING. Lots of TEARS. Tears that were then fed with an El Toro burrito (which was good, but no comparison). 

I always get a chicken burrito with guacamole. Nothing else - never any need to order anything else. Quick service despite the long lines and if you're really impatient, go next door to Dianda's and grab some almond cookies.
author: haley d.

description: Yum... great carnitas taco. I'm not that into Mexican food but this place has awesome taco. The pork is tender and flavorful! I love their salsa and everything inside that taco is just a bomb. I'm hooked. I may never crave for Mexican food before but this place can be the first.
author: Cliff T.

description: The ordering process can be confusing depending on how crowded they are.  I don't consider the prices to be high because the portions are big in my opinion.  One taco with avocado is more than enough for me!
author: David H.

description:
The last 3 times I've been there (over the last 4 months or so) the carnitas have been REALLY salty - as in too salty.  What gives?
I still think La Taqueria is awesome, but I hope this is an anomaly.
author: Colin S.

description: Grew up three blocks away from this place and was spoiled by it all my life. Now that I live in Hayward I haven't found a Taqueria that is as good as this place. It is probably one of the more pricier taquerias but it is well worth it. The burritos from this place are great and I love the fact that it doesn't come with rice like some of the other taquerias in the mission. The tacos are great too pretty much everything in this place is pretty bad ass.
author: Bernard M.

description:
Going against the grain here....

So the man and came here on the overall ratings based on the need for a good burrito. We should've saved our money, damn this place is expensive. How can a place with "Taqueria" in the name be pricey? Yes, $6 for a burrito without the works is expensive, and hell yes $1 extra for guac is damn expensive.

I do admit their carne asada is grilled to perfection right in front of your  eyes, but like I said... damn its overpriced. 

PLUS, I swear I saw the Mexican family in front of me get free chips and salsa, I'm not one to discourage the use of "hooking up" your fellow people but I'm Filipino, which is basically saying I'm Mexican but was born on an island instead. SHARE THE WEALTH and help your fellow Spanish-conquered person out.
author: kate r.

description:
Dorado...what is "dorado"? Well, I don't really care what it is because it's good!! 

La Taqueria is a medium sized restaurant with not that great decor or tables/chairs, but the food definitely makes up for the aesthetic. They also have tons of awards hung up on one side of the restaurant, Zagat/7x7/San Franciso, which shows that they really know Mexican food!
