I went to La Taqueria on a Friday night around 7ish and it wasn't crazy like I was expecting it to be. I heard it was REALLY good and I was definitely not disappointed. It was pretty damn good. I got a carne asada burrito "dorado" style...amazing. Except that I don't really care for beans. Did you know that you have to pay extra for NO beans???? That's what I heard, so don't quote me on that, but that's crazy!! I also had some of a carne asada quesadilla which was good too! Cheesy and carne asada-y...awesome. They have the usual drinks, horchata/fruit drinks/cerveza, which only complimented the great food.

I would give them that last star if they were closer to downtown and took card. Still, it's worth the short commute to the Mission and to the ATM.
author: Maureen B.

description:
Fresh, simple, cheap!

Authentic Taco (ie. La Taqueria) = Corn tortilla, meat, beans, salsa!  

Fake Taco (ie. Taco Bell)  = Flour tortilla, ground beef, cheese, lettuce, tomatoes, sour cream, and guac from a caulking gun!

Not much else to say, but it beats flying to Mexico to get a real taco!!
author: James C.

description:
Best burrito ever!!

I have been coming to La Taqueria ever since I was a child, it was great then and is still great now.  The carne asada burrito  is the only thing that I ever get there- the meat is so juicy and perfect.  I'm not sure what they do to it, but it is so delicious!!  The fact that they are more expensive than other taquerias is worth it for the superior freshness, tastiness.

For the yelpers who don't understand why the burritos are not loaded with rice, beans, lettuce, sour cream, here is your answer: true Mexican burritos are simple, meat and hot sauce only, no fillers. As a Latina, I know this from first hand experience.  So... don't go to La Taqueria expecting a "California style" burrito, meat is the name of the game here!!

Anyone who doesn't like this place is absolutely crazy!!
author: Michi R.

description: Best chorizo EVER!  Can't find comparable chorizo anywhere else.  So bummed that the downtown San Jose location is closed.  I try to get my La Taqueria chorizo burrito fix whenever I can when I'm in SF.
author: M C.

description:
I'm sorry, but tacos should not be that expensive. For $3.50, I should be getting something with the works, not have to spend another $60 to get what I really want. 

that's all i have to say.
author: Marisa S.

description:
I grew up in SF, and I remember when La Taqueria was King.  

But... those days are OVER.   

La Taqueria is OVER PRICED, and perfect for people who like to pay a lot for very little.

If you like food thats expensive but very skimpy, then this is the place for you!  

But if you're like normal San Franciscans, then eat at another Taqueria spot.  

La Taqueria was great in the past, but I think since they became one of the premier food spots, they decided to skimp on their customers, while even charging more!   

Take a PASS on La Taqueria.
author: Samurai J.

description: BIG hype and a BIG disappointment!!! What can I say, all the great reviews posted all over their walls cant hide the fact that there are so many much better examples of Great Mexican food than this sad excuse for a restaurant. I took my mom and my wife there and all three dishes were just of bad/cheap quality ingredients. Bland, gristly low quality meat, and WAYYY overpriced tacos and everything else. What? you want chips and salsa? I don't even think they offer those. This place, IMHO was a complete Ye1p hype, and a ripoff.
author: Joe P.

description: Hands down the BEST taqueria ever!!! This place is so delicious that I drive about an hour just to eat here! I love the cow tongue tacos, corn tortilla carne asada quesadillas and to drink i will have their fresh rice water yummmm!
author: Ria L.

description:
Here's the breakdown on my first visit to this place:

Positives
1. The service is fast and efficient even when the place is packed.
2. Easy to read menu with basics: tacos, burritos, quesadillas, etc.
3. Fairly clean - employee goes around cleaning up the long tables that folks share in the tiny little dining area
4. Taste - there's nothing "americanized" about this place at all; the food is served hot and tasty

Negatives
1. Price - the basic taco is already $3.50 without extras and the extras are pretty hefty in price: extra cheese = $.50; extra sour cream = $.50; extra meat = $1.00; extra avocado = $1.00 and the strangest extra of all, No Beans = $1.00 (what's with that?)
2. Parking - if you drive, parking is pretty awful on the weekend (we went mid-afternoon today) and I can't imagine it's better on the weekdays or nights; better to take the muni if you live in the city
3. CASH ONLY - that's right folks, they do not accept credit cards/ATMs so you'd better drain the ATM before you head here.

There were three of us that went today.  We ordered three soft carnitas tacos and three crunchy/fried carnitas tacos plus one medium coke, one pineapple agua freshca and one mango agua freshca.  We also ordered extra cheese,avocado and meat on all and extra sour cream on two tacos. The three drinks amounted to $6 total with our overall late lunch bill totaling almost $40.00 ~ pricey for a taqueria!

While we liked the overall flavor of the carnitas (loved the fried taco version best), this place rated three stars for being overpriced.  Up by the cash register, there were business cards, of which I took one so that I could yelp about this place.  It turns out the cards were of their 15 South First Street location in San Jose, CA....might try it out!
author: Beth W.

description:
Here's the deal: tacos are decent but I am trying to figure out whether $12 for two of them and a small fresa (strawb. drink) is reasonable - maybe these days it is.

The people who work here are nice but given the volume of eaters that descend here I wonder whether they get to share in the profits? Tortillas, chicken and beans are not expensive things, especially when bought in bulk. Whoever owns this place is probably laughing all the way to the B of A. Did they charge this much in 1975 dollars?

Natural Light: Excellent
author: Mark G.

description:
the long awaited visit to La Taqueria took place last night. I kept it simple and got a chicken burrito.
fresh, easy, no rice :), juicy and soft. done and happy.
did i mention it makes a wonderful breakfast the next day as well?

highly recommended when you don't want the fancy shmancy condiment driven American burrito, and just want really good fresh meat with no fluff.
green sauce= hot.
author: Helen N.

description: My, how the mighty have fallen.  Believe me, it brings great pain to amend my once glowing review of this my once favorite taqueria but all good things must come to an end. I proudly brought my boyfriend here during a visit to San Francisco having talked it up for some time. They were out of lengua so we both ordered carne asada tacos. I was partly in denial for the first half of my taco but then couldn't ignore that the steak was both chewy and tasteless.  I continued to silently eat my taco filled with a sense of defeat akin to finding out Santa Claus doesn't exist and hoping my boyfriend wouldn't notice how inferior these tacos tasted. I left and I don't plan on going back again.  I'll have to find another favorite taqueria in the Mission.
author: Adrienne M.

description:
An ex-girlfriend told me about this place, claiming it was the best taqueria EVA. Not "ever", definitely "EVA", which means it must be true. I told her she was just exaggerating and that there's no way it can compare with previous taqueria's I've been too. 

I was wrong. 

I don't know what they do to their meat but goddamn it is good. I remember the first bite of my burrito like it was yesterday. I was sitting there with the aforementioned ex, getting ready to rip into her about how over hyped this place was but instead, my eyes suddenly lit up and I said aloud "Holy shit, this is fucking delicious. How did they get the meat to taste like this? It's like they chopped up real Mexicans and put them in the meat!"

Yes, it's so good you'll swear you've just found out why your buddy Pablo went missing last week.
author: Sol V.

description:
After my third trip to La Taqueria, I feel obligated to write a review, although everything that needs to be said about this place has already been said.

The place looks and feels authentic.  Come to think of it, so does the entire area around Mission and 25th.  Every time I find myself in the area, I feel like I am south of the border.

La Taqueria's burritos may be the best in the City, and the long wait and the crowded dining area are a small price to pay for a quality burrito.  Well, that and $6.50 + fixin's.  Cheese will cost you 50 cents more, sour cream - another 50 cents, and avocado - another $1.

The lady with a notepad was taking orders before people would get to the register.  She greeted everyone with a hearty "Hello, Sir" or "Hello, Ma'am."  I was the only one in line greeted with "Hola, Senor."  I am often mistaken for someone of Hispanic descent - must be my dark Jewish hair, brown eyes, a 3-day stubble, and a Giants hat.  I always smile politely and answer in English.  I wish I spoke Spanish, I really do.

The chicken and beef are tender and high quality (they only use white meat and flank steak, respectively).  The flour tortillas are soft, fresh and full of flavor.  Salsa verde is relatively hot, so warn them if you are a hot sauce lightweight.  I am not the expert on tongue and cow head burritos, but the traditional ones are unbelievable.  Burritos here come with beans, but no rice.  They're still very, very filling, believe me.

400+ Yelpers can't be wrong.  Try a La Taqueria burrito and you won't be disappointed.  Sure, the wait is long.  Sure, parking in the Mission sucks.  Sure, you can get a cheaper burrito.  But you'd be hard pressed to find a better one.
author: Yan G.

description:
Their food is good, and that is why they're getting four stars.

But their burritos? For their size ... I mean ... seven dollars? =/
author: Thea G.

description:
Ah what can I say about La Taqueria; it's about the best authentic food I've ever tasted always fresh, tender, unique! 

My relationship started back in the early 80's in both locations (SJ/SF) and I've been visiting La Taqueria ever since; La Taqueria esta la bomba! Speaking of La Bomba, my second favorite is Taqueria La Bomba, but rarely do I make the trek to Mt. View, so sadly it's been a while. 

In each, I've taken many friends and office mates and with both, all walk away saying the same, "that's the best Taqueria I've ever been to, how did you know about this place?"  And trust me, all go back. 

La Taqueria makes the perfect burritos and tacos --- using fresh ingredients such as avocado, cheese, sour cream and has the most amazing salsa and succulent beans.  Move over Poncho Villa - La Taqueria esta la bomba!
author: Cris B.

description: I love this place. As a Mexican I can say that they have the best tacos in the city! It taste just like home! REAL MEXICAN FOOD! lo mejor de lo mejor!
author: K M.

description:
So La Taqueria is consistently rated as the best place for cheap burritos and tacos in San Francisco... They MAY have been at one point, but after years and years of getting blind praise in "best-in the-bay" type lists , they have really really let themselves go. The food is decent, but not anything that would rank it over 20 other Taquerias in the Mission.  Plus with the all the praise comes the overpriced menu, you gotta pay extra for EVERYTHING even the chips and salsa...I've never seen that, heck even crappy Chevy's hooks you up, and I hate that place!

There is a phenomenon that these yearly awards create that really bugs me. All the Marina douche bags bring people here singing it's praises. "Dude we gotta go to La Taqueria, it's the bomb" "What you've never been? We NEED to go!" all these ass-munchers thinking they discovered this little "unknown gem" in the mission and they are little less lame for being so cultured when all they did was read SFWeekly's year end best of list on a cab ride home one day! Uuhhhh!
author: Adrian H.

description:
3.5 Stars

I'm definitely a fan! 

*Authentic Mexican Food
*Great Food 
*Great Taste
*Good Value
*Recommendation:
Carne Asada Quesadilla, Carne Asada Burrito, Sausage & Beef Tacos :)
author: Christina D.

description:
I agree with everyone regarding the price...La Taqueria has been raising it's prices for a few years now and it's becoming expensive to eat here! Also true is that for their burritos---there's no rice. However, I don't like rice in my burritos! I think it takes the juice out of the carne asada! If you decide to go here, here's my recommendation:

1. carne asada burrito (with sour cream and guacamole)- ask for "dorado style' and they will grill the burrito for a crispy shell
2. melon drink

Here is the best carne asada in town in my opinion!

Enjoy!
author: Rod L.

description: THE BEST steak super quesadilla! I don't understand who can write 2 star review for that place. To be hones for all these years I never tried anything else on the menu, but the place is clean, people are nice and did I mention-- the steak quesadilla is amazing!
author: Rositsa K.

description: The food here is excellent. I love their beef tacos and also their carnitas burrito. This isn't your stereotypical SF taqueria mainly because they don't put rice in their burritos. Minus one star because they are overpriced and the occasional bad vibe from the cashier.
author: Oliver W.

description: love their tacos, hate the sometimes super long lines
author: Virginia M.

description: Great carne asada burrito in the mission.    A bit pricey for a divey joint, but good.
author: Dave C.

description: This place is so-so. I went their a few times. They don't put rice in the twinkie-size burrito. Meat is well-cooked to perfection ( I like that).Have to eat 3 of them to satisfy my hunger.The restaurant is always packed with other patrons who likes this place. Sgt. Neville Gittens and Maria Oropeza,who are the spokesperson of SFPD, are frequent loyal customers. It is their favorite.
author: Matt G.

description: The Taco Crawl Crew hit La Taqueria on crawls #1 (Dec 2004) and #2 (Jan 2006).  It was an easy fan favorite not only for its festive vibe, but also for its tacos, which were slightly fried, mammoth in proportion, and featured beans and super-chunky guacamole.  Not a traditional taco, but it didn't matter in the slightest.  Taco Crawl rating = 9 of 10.
author: Laurence W.

description: I first found this place in 1992. A friend of mine that travels the world said that with out fail he always comes here when he is in town. My favorite is the carne asada quesadilla with everything, a Tecate with lime and salt. Anything on there menu is hit. This is one place that day after day is consistent. I have never had a bad meal. Don't let the long line fool you the food comes up quick. Well worth the wait. If you go trust me, YOU WILL BE BACK!!
author: Frank O.

description:
Alright, so after spending a month living on a Siberian Island, in a tent no less, what is the first thing a girl desires upon her return to SF? In fact, when anybody travels abroad from this region of CA, what is the most commonly missed type of food? It's the taqueria of course. How many nights did I lay in my tent dreaming of salsa? A lot. 

So my fellow researcher and I wanted to meet over some proper tacos to rehash battle stories from the field. I chose La Taqueria for its consistently high quality carnitas taco. I know I used to boycott this place for its annoying foodie raves, higher prices, and the fact that you have to pay for chips (which is near blasphemy in my world), but I've come to realize it is a taco above many in SF. I won't say it's the best taco around, but it comes close. Squeezy bottle of salsa verde on the table is a little thin for my liking but is decently spicy. I'll say 3.5 stars. Mission accomplished.
author: Candice L.

description: Came here with my uncle the other day for a quick bite to eat and it was DELICIOUS. The line was out the door, which is always a good sign, and they had a ton of awards hanging from numerous magazines and different ratings around San Fran! And they definitely lived up to expectations. The burritos are fantastic and the horchata was the bomb. I would definitely come back!
author: Anne B.

description:
Is this place really serving tacos?  The tacos I would say are the size of two mini $1 tacos and are double the price ($6+/- FYI).  The last time I went here I had three of these puppies but was sticker shocked because to be honest who looks at the price at a taqueria.

The quality is by far awesome.  Take it from me I am fat.  I have sampled both the carne asada and the carnitas.  Carnitas hands down the clear favorite.  Typically carnitas can be known for there dryness but not this place.  The meat is moist and supple, like me.  Anyhow go for the sake of tasting one of the city's best taco shop.

-1 star for the price but to a foodie what is cost when it comes to delicious food.
author: andres c.

description:
I have a scant three criteria when evaluating a taqueria.  The first is choice/quality of ingredients, followed by quality of chips and salsa, and lastly the service.  Unfortunately, La Taqueria gets a low score in all three of these categories.  

There are very few choices of ingredients, for example, there was only one choice of bean. Other toppings, such as cheese and avacado, while available, require a significant price upgrade as does removing a topping($1 extra for NO beans!). Strike one. 

The chips were...well...I'm not entirely sure, because they don't come automatically with your order. You have to pay more to upgrade with chips, and I wasn't exactly aching to do so because the chips were obviously not made in-house. Strike two.

Lastly, they don't bus your table for you. Call me privileged and selfish if you must, but I've come to expect to be able to stand up and leave directly after finishing my meal. I don't want to navigate my way to the back of the restaurant  with a load of stuff to dump in the garbage.Strike three.

These things combined with a high price point (for a taqueria in the Mission), and a poorly wrapped burrito ensure that I will probably never return here again. 

On a positive note, however, the burrito I ate was actually okay as was the green salsa. The food is okay, but with so many other outstanding choices so close by, I wouldn't bother with this one.
author: Joseph B.

description: Awesome lengua and cabeza tacos.  Holy crap!  Generous serving, basic, moist, nice fresh small tortillas, lots of finely chopped cilantro and onion, one salsa (spicy green).  Like home (Mexico)!  I wish I lived 2 blocks from it.
author: Jen C.

description: To everyone who complains about there not being rice in the burritos: good! Don't come here! More for me! No offense intended but these are the most legit, truly authentic, tacos and burritos in the whole of Sf. Easily comparable to the Mexican fare in SD  This is a place for the locals, not a tourist trap. Yes it's pricey, but worth it.
author: Yvonne Q.

description:
Good tacos but maybe next time I won't panic and just say "with everything" because otherwise I'll end up with an expensive, sloppy taco and the alleged magic of their carnitas was overshadowed by all the stuff on top of it. 

Don't get me wrong, it was a tasty taco, but I need to remember that sometimes less is more. 

Even in Mexican food, believe it or not.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Solid Mission Mexican tacos & burritos.  Really tender meat for both the chicken and pork we had.  Nothing to complain about, but not the best in the 'hood.
author: Alison L.

description: Couldn't agree more with the bad reviews. What is the big stinkin' deal about this place that all the gringos have to eat there??
author: Lisa T.

description:
The carnitas is very tasty, but overall the tacos are average. I think people just get excited by the overflowing fillings in these ginormous tacos. But size isn't everything boys and girls.... 

The salsa is bland - its for all you Gringos.... 
No marinated jalapenos and carrots sitting on the table to grab - you have to ask specifically for them - Gringos don't eat them, thats why they aren't out on the tables.

Overall decent, but definately for Gringos....
author: Karen C.

description:
This is not your typical taqueria, as the emphasis is on the meat, not rice.

Food:  5 stars.  Excellent food made with fresh ingredients at a cheap price (well it is a taqueria).  

Service:  3 stars.  How am I supposed to rate a taqueria?  At least they clean up the mess you leave behind.

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  There's a few rows of tables with benches and some smaller tables lining the walls.  It's a bit cramped, but what do you expect from a taqueria?

Hits:  Carnitas and chicken burritos and tacos.

Misses:  Not a place to take a date

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  El Faro, El Farolito
author: Keith C.

description:
I went to learn what all the fuss was about, and I learned that it was good. Damn good. 

Very refreshing to see a burrito without rice since it's usually a filler ingredient that seeps out the flavor from the real burrito stars - meat, guacamole, salsa, and beans.
author: John B.

description:
La Taqueria came in 3rd out of 7 in my little best of SF burrito off the other night, but it was dragged down only by yours truly.  I didn't care for the sauce-heavy approach to it.  I prefer a lighter burrito where you can taste alll the ingredients and distribution matters.  

I've heard their tacos are unbelievable, so i'll have to go back.
author: Matt S.

description: the Best all-around Mexican food my family and I have EVER had! no kidding :-/ only downside...too crowded and cash only
author: Scot S.

description:
Like the neon sign says on the wall, "The best tacos and burritos in the world". The taco part, for sure, though the burritos are good too, done non-Mission style without rice. It's the tacos that kill though, with double tortillas, one soft and one deep fried. Yum, yum, yum! 

I have been going here for 25+ years now!

Don't pass up the aqua frescas either. 

Who goes to a taqueria to fill up on free chips?!? WTF!
author: Leef S.

description: I just went here last week for the veggie tacos.  Wow - amazing.  A must for any Mission lover.
author: Jeni S.

description:
My Favorite Taqueria!

Taquerias are as ubiquitous in SF as pizzerias in NYC.  How do you find the best one?  Luckily I found La Taqueria.

There's always a long line at this taqueria and I can see why.  They have the best TACOs and AQUA FRESCAs in town.  The carne asada and carnitas tacos are delicious, especially with their hot sauce.  It's a bit messy but who cares.  

They also have amazing aqua frescas.  My favorites are the strawberry and watermelon.  Very refreshing and you'll need a spoon to eat the fresh fruits at the bottom of the cup.

Tip:  Get the carnitas taco.  There's a reason why it's one of the '100 Must-Eats in SF".
author: Lis A.

description: This place has the best tacos on this side of the border!!!! My family and I drive almost two hours to enjoy tacos at this place! I love their carne asade tacos with everything, ask for them to be crispy and they are even better! I also love getting their strawberry drink, as it is made with fresh strawberries!
author: Kay H.

description: This place used to be amazing about 10 years ago, but it lost its touched unfortunately
author: Cesar F.

description:
La Taqueria is like the Muhammad Ali of San Francisco taquerias. Simply, the greatest of all time. This place is the standard  which I hold all taquerias to. 

I wouldn't usually say this but... I have to have you understand the adoration I have for this place. As I slowly unwrap my foiled covered carnitas burrito, I'll, sometimes, caress it for a few moments. Because, I know that when I take my first bite it'll make sweet love to me in return. And afterwards, I feel so dirty that I bathe myself in the cantaloupe drink.
author: Rodney V.

description:
I had their carne asada burrito along with a large horchata.  The burrito was in the lower brackets of worst burritos I've ever had.  The horchata was in similar rankings.  

The meat in the burrito was watery and just not attractive taste-wise or aesthetically.

The horchata was too watery and not very flavorful.  

I may go back as I've heard raves about the deal for their tacos.  But I doubt I will ever buy anything else from them again.
author: Pickles T.

description: Why do people like this place? Menu sucks, super small and pricey, the burritos look like $1 frozen burritos from Safeway, it's crowded, and El Faralito is one block away. No brainer. Stay away from here.
author: Alfredo A.

description: This place is one of the best Mexican food joints (if not the best) in the neibirhood. The tacos are about 4 bucks a pop. Seems alot for a taco to the untrained eye but, for me is a good price for the size of the taco. You can see then grill and cut the meat right in front of you. The sour cream, rice, beans, guacamole are all made fresh. like a said, its a great spot to eat. The only thing I don't like is the long lines and the influx of all these hipsters kids.
author: Hector R.

description:
I've been working in the Mission for the past six months and had resisted going here until this past week.  During my tenure, Farolito has been my taqueria of choice and I felt a kind of loyalty to the place.  But La Taqueria has some strengths.
In terms of price, size, and simplicity, Farolito has an edge.
However, La Taqueria is arguably more delicious.  The crispy tacos are money, as are the burritos.  Carnitas, everything on them, spicy is the way to go.  I actually don't even mind the lack of rice which was sort of strange to me.  Maybe not as much of a staple as Farolito but a place I'll frequent.
author: Matt S.

description: I don't know what it is that makes these tacos so incredibly delicious... But... Wow.  Maybe it's the cheese they melt onto the fresh and deliciously greasy crispy tortillas, or the homemade pico de gallo they put on every taco, or the perfect texture of the pintos (this is for the veggie tacos), or, how could I forget, the green salsa that is on every table. I put it over every bite. So good. No wonder it's always packed around lunch time! Also... The cashier (owner??) is always so friendly to everyone and was even giving out roses before Christmas! Favorite taqueria by far.
author: Marie W.

description: One of the best burrito joints in the city! It's pricey if you ask for all of the toppings but it's well worth it. Their carne asada burritos are far from disappointing, ESPECIALLY with the salsa verde. The strawberry fresca is also the best way to quench the heat because it gets pretty dang spicy. Everything about La Taqueria is amazing.
author: Mirabella C.

description: It's not cheap here, and its cash only but well worth it. Never disappointing guacamole, friendly staff and even if they do give you a little shit about taking so many hot sauces to go, they will give them to you. I eat here three times a week at least. I live a wonderful taco filled life.
author: Lauren M.

description: Mission District San Francisco this experience is a must!!! They make some of the best Mexican food I have ever had. The Burritos and Tacos are amazing. This is one of the best spots in San Francisco.
author: Jay N.

description:
This has been my fav burrito spot since the early 80's...YES the early 80's and it is still just as good(only more pricey lol)..the beef is so fresh and the green sauce is the ultimate compliment. The fruit drinks are the best...Let me stop now! 

Jamal
author: L Jamal J.

description: This place gets a lot of hype, and I get it. The tacos are tasty and the fried ones are just plain amazing. However, it's fucking expensive. If you're willing to pay $20 bucks or more for 2 tacos and a drink then go for it, but I'm not. What makes me sad is that their prices weren't as expensive before, but in order to please the masses they have had to raise their prices. I say try it once and see if you're willing to pay for it again. Tacos are street food and known for being cheap. I'm just sayin'.
author: Brenda S.

description:
It took me 9 years to appreciate this taqueria. 
It still breaks my heart when I pay almost $25 dollars for me and my girlfriend to have a quick dinner there (3 tacos, 1 drink, and chips and salsa).
But I have to admit, I really like the fresh pico de gallo on the chips.
I like the tacos with everything including super hot sauce (which always makes my lips burn).
It just tastes like fresh Mexican food. 
And for the no rice deal- I'm ok with that- Mexican rice is hard to make.
So, if there's not a line in there and you're feeling a little rich, stop by and have a taco:)
author: Valarie A.

description:
Man, those tacos were like the size of a small baby!

Well, okay, I'm totally over exaggerating!  But really, those were some pretty friggin huge tacos!  I ordered 2 chicken tacos with cheese.  I had a really hard time finishing them...but I took one for the team and finished every last bite.  Two corn tortillas filled with delicious stewed chicken, beans, lettuce and salsa.  mmmmmmm!

The best tacos in the city!  They were a little wet, but holy frijole they were good!

As a side note, I found it quite humorous to read on the menu that they charge $1 extra for NO beans.  What's up with that?
author: Christy L.

description:
Best taco ever!  Coming from San Diego (and spending a lot of time in Mexico), I thought I would have a hard time finding good Mexican food in San Francisco.  Then I discovered La Taqueria.  The chicken taco with all the fixins was one of the best meals of my life.

Btw, it's called La Taqueria, not El Burritoria, so get a taco and don't waste your time with anything else.
author: Julie C.

description:
Older SF natives always talk about how this place has the best burritos in town, its been there for 50 years, yada yada yada.  So I finally got around to going down there and I felt it was... O.K.  

I had a Chicken burrito which had some decent flavor and the avocado was by far the tastiest I've ever had.  I'd never seen anything like it, it had this delicious bright green color to it.  I also liked their hot sauce.  

BUT

The burrito had no rice, which was different but left me hungry - which should never happen after eating a burrito.  Not to mention they charge you $7 plus and they don't give you free chips.  C'mon man!

Time for the older generation to try some new places.
author: Justin O.

description:
They may nickel and dime you here on the extras like guacamole and sour cream so that a couple tacos with all the trimmings amount to about $8, but it's all worth it.

It's what "fresh-mex" wishes it was.  La Taqueria is unintentionally fresh, due to the high turnover.  The carne asada doesn't have time to shrivel in a steam tray, avocados don't even have time to oxidize, and the guy making your taco or burrito doesn't have time to use a spoon for the meat.  But don't worry about that last one, at least 33% of the flavor is coming off that guy's hand.

Rice lovers beware--they don't put rice in the burritos.  They don't have any rice in the entire place.  All killer, no filler.
author: Suo L.

description:
What? A burrito place on sfgate's 100 best restaurants (yes, I know it's not on this year, but I noticed it because it was noted that it just lost its  spot, so that was a good thing - for me, that is). That can't be right. *Checks out yelp* Seems to be a consensus - good to very good. Hm, maybe I'll try it one day. Worst mistake ever made. 

Came here after a day at ocean beach with my fearless dog. Pleasantly surprised that there was outdoor ordering and seating, though the register was always busy so I had to tie up the pooch and come in regardless. Came in on Sunday at 2:30-ish, one person in front of me in line and plenty of seating. I order my standard carnitas burrito with avocado, sour cream and cheese, hold the beans and chips and salsa. As I'm putting my change away the guy behind me orders his burrito and says "crispy please". "what's this?" I think. I ask the cashier and she points to the grill as if some type of explanation. The guy informs me it's extra good and I have to try it. I heard that they did this for the tacos, but for a burrito? Is it a chimichanga? How does that work? 

It works like magic. 

The burrito is fried on the grill (I assume with extra oil) to make the tortilla crispy on the outside. So good. They put the avocado on the side flap thingy (you know what I mean) of the burrito so it doesn't get mixed in with all the other stuff. Carnitas was soft and tasty. They got my funky order down. It was relatively fast. I am normally a eat-half-a-burrito-and-save-the-rest-for-a-wonderful-next-meal kind of person. But this burrito isn't as large as those crazy ones, and it's so good, I'm not sure how you would stop eating it. I'm calling this size, perfect. Give me a smaller better made burrito any day over a processed massive una mas/baja fresh one. 

The atmosphere was better than normal shady looking taquerias, or the taquerias which were obviously once mcdonalds. I'm not sure what they do when it gets cold. I loved the outdoor area for poochie. 

Only con was the chips weren't that great. The salsa was good and that hot sauce really is hot (you never know what you get when it's green). And even for the chips, I'm a flour chevy's style chips lover, so I'm sure to most people these are good chips. 

Food: 4
Atmosphere: 4
Price: 5
Parking: 2

Overall 4.5 stars. 

Extra credit: Pooch insists I note that it is puppy approved. 5 paws.

I can see parking being a pain here. I was lucky that a big ole tacoma came out of his spot right when I turned onto his street. 

I will be back. Many many times. As long as I can find parking.
author: Tray I.

description:
I always hear folks praising La Taqueria.  I was first brought  to the Mission haven on a pseudo date.  He favored the carnitas tacos with the works, so I naturally ordered the same as I'm a carnitas fan myself.  I definitely recalled loving the taco and the cheese stuffed corn tortilla we ordered, and I wish the same could be said about the company (his mind was a bit preoccupied to say the least).  

Flash forward four years later, and I'm at La Taqueria with my boyfriend (not the pseudo date guy).  I ordered the carnitas again, but this time a burrito and my boyfriend ordered the carne asada straying away from his usual bean and cheese.  I LOVED my burrito.  Well, first I was surprised that there was no rice.  (Do they just not serve rice in their burritos?)  But realized it's fine by me cause I'm trying to limit my carb intake at dinnertime.  The carnitas was so tender and flavorful.  The sour cream and guacamole were a great addition to the carnitas, so I'm glad I remembered to order them.  The burrito was basically a well stuffed carnitas filled tortilla...I loved it!  The chips and salsa were decent.  I actually prefer my tortillas on the thinner side.  

La Taqueria is definitely going to be my Mission taqueria...and next time I'm going to ask about the rice....
author: Marie B.

description: My first Mission-style burrito... although I have no basis for comparison, it was delicousness wrapped into a little bundle of joy that I promptly inhaled. Been craving another one ever since my visit!
author: Yasmin M.

description:
Definitely one of the best. I kept away from la taqueria for years because it was always such a madhouse inside (especially in the late 90's) and the burrito prices are about double the norm and half the size. But hey, this is the best carne asada--no gristle..fat..and unknowns.. Thank god, no rice filler.

ORDER TWO BURRITOS FOR YOURSELF
author: chris r.

description:
Since moving to the Bay Area in the early 90s, my favorite place to get burritos has been Mario's La Fiesta in Berkeley.

Mario's got dethroned after my first visit to La Taqueria.  I've had the carne asada, but my burrito of choice has got to be the carnitas.  I'd say I've probably ordered carnitas the last 10 times I've been here.  Simply awesome guacamole gushing out from every bite.  Awesome.

As drinks go, add a refreshing fresa to your meal.  This will cost you a little under $24 for two people.  Which reminds me- 3/4 star less for the kind of steep price.  (LT, you know you're doing it because you can, and not because you need to)
author: LibbyMcLibface _.

description: Me and my family have been going here for years. We love this place! No one else makes carne asada tacos and burritos like they do. It's definitely worth the drive from Hayward.
author: Natalie G.

description: First time here, I ordered the carnitas taco and my husband ordered the carne asada taco, both crunchy. They serve the taco on two tortillas, one soft and one crunchy, add sour cream, guacamole, and salsa. One is enough to make you full because they are huge! My only complaint is that they don't offer Pastor meat. Tacos are pricey compared to other places, but then again portion is very generous. Will definitely go back!
author: Gris G.

description:
We stopped by La Taqueria one Saturday for lunch so that the hubby could satiate his burrito craving.  According to him, the burritos here are pretty tasty, but not as good as the ones at Taqueria Cancun, but he couldn't really compare because the Taqueria Cancun burritos are smothered in cheese & some sort of sauce.

Since I don't appreciate the goodness of a burrito (I'm not a big fan of all my food touching each other or mounds of cheese) I got a carne asada taco instead.  It was no different than any other taco that you could get at a hole in the wall Mexican restaurant, but my tummy was satisfied.

I don't know if we would venture out to the Mission again to eat here, but it was worth trying it out.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Very excellent crispy tacos.  Although carnitas is always great, the vegeterian are actually the best.  

Order guacamole and chips separately rather than avocado on the taco for a better value.  

The owner is also very generous friendly guy.
author: Bruce M.

description:
2 stars for flavor which is still good after all these years. It is other factors that bring their rating down. I've been coming here since I was a kid in the early 80's. They were famous even WAY back then. What has happened is sad. They've gone the way of the typical capitalist. Higher price, less food, shittier service. Why? Because until people stop settling for these shortcomings they can get away with it.

First of all, the burrito I got last time resembled a lumpia. I couldn't believe it wasn't a baby burrito. Second, I paid over $6 for this skimpy excuse for a burrito. And of course, there is the absence of personality behind the counter. As I observe the staff's handling of the customers I get the feeling I am like a log with money in it being pushed through a mill after they take the money out.
author: Pete M.

description:
Could be the best burrito I've had in the city, but:

1. very expensive, over 9$ for the extras/equivalent of a super burrito somewhere else
2. no complimentary chips and salsa
3. way too small and lacking girth
author: Mark A.

description:
best damn taco.

You better believe it. This is THE place to get your taco-on.

When eating here, just stick to the taco's, you'll be glad you did.

FYI- cash only.
author: Anthony A.

description:
BEST TAQUERIA IN CITY.... HANDS DOWN!

One thing I love about this place is if you order with no beans.  THEY CHARGE YOU A DOLLAR!  This goes against every economic theory out there.  SO WEIRD. 

FYI....  they don't show it on the menu but order the burrito CRISPY.  It's the best!

UPDATE........................................................................................


THE TACO TRUCKS ARE BETTER AND CHEAPER.  I GUESS THIS IS AN ETHICAL ISSUE
author: Justin C.

description:
I have been going to La Taqueria since it open in 1979.

The O.G. familia sold it once in the 80s, and just like Ronald Reagan's policy in Nicaragua, it sucked.

But the O.G. familia bought it back, and has been making tacos and burritos forever! My family and I have eaten there more times than anywhere in the Bay Area. (Think about it, this place is so good, they give their workers a month off for the holidays; now that's thinking about the proletariat!)

The reason for La Taqueria's success: sweat. 

Yes, I said it. Sweat, oil, corazon. Look at the two men who make your tacos and burritos, look at how much love they put in it.  Look at the team of men and women working to make the BEST tacos (con beans) and Burritos (without rice) in the United States. 

Only you can make it better. But you would have to make them with corazon!

Now, the prices have risen with the price of real estate, so La Taqueria is one of the most expensive places for a burrito, but I argue...what is the price of comida con corazon, good people!!!

If you go, get your veggie tacos dorados con queso. Y get a veggie burrito con aguacate y cheese.

Melon drink is good, but tap water is fine.

Check out the poster of A.T.M. and realize La Taqueria is old school; it ain't no hipster taqueria!

Que Viva La Taqueria!
author: mero cocinero k.

description:
Very tasty burritos. I've had the Carnitas, Carne Asada, and the Chorizo. They were all delicious. They don't add any rice in their burritos, but I didn't miss it. 

The restaurant itself is characterful, and very casual. Along with the other colorful sights and sounds of Mission St., I almost feel like I'm transported to another place. 

Oh, and the green salsa that sits at every table in a squeeze bottle is so damn good, I think I consumed a quarter bottle with my burrito the last time I was there.

The menu itself is quite small, and the prices are surprisingly high, but after eating there, I can understand why the place is always so crowded.
author: Adrian L.

description:
Yup...this place is the real deal.  I was in town on business and headed down to Mission for some tacos. I walked past/checked out a bunch of joints in the area, but this one was by far the busiest (and most inviting).  I ordered two tacos (carne asada, carnitas) with avocado, salsa & cheese.  They were f'ing good!!!  I also really liked the atmosphere of this place.  Very authentic without making you're in a Tijuana slum...

Definitely recommend.
author: Derek S.

description:
Great burritos!  Not too many places are as good... 

Other menu items, like the tacos and quesadillas, are just average though.
author: Shanan A.

description:
First off, you have to realize that this is an institution,  so the great thing about this place is its consistency, This from a guy who has been going here for over 30 years.  

However, the only thing I ever order at this joint are the regular tacos and on occassion a corn quesadilla.  If you are looking for a great burrito, i would find another place.
author: Will C.

description:
This place is average:

Average decor, average tacos (I had the carnitas and chicken tacos with avocado) and average service.

The only thing that is not average is the prices. $4.70 for a tiny chicken taco with avocado?!  Crazy.

Fall for the hype at your own peril.

Better yet, head over to Taqueria Vallarta a few blocks away for a much better experience.
author: Ruben G.

description:
Despite what all the reviewers said, when I checked out this place EVERYONE spoke English. And I'd bet that none of the patrons spoke Spanish. The Chicken burrito was fine, but bland. No real spice and hardly any fixin's. Worst of all: They charge extra for chips. CRIME AGAINST HUMANITY. This is perhaps white peoples' idea of what a taqueria is really like.

Two stars because even still, you can't really go wrong w/ Mexican food.
author: James K.

description:
Was dying for a quick fix of Mexican before I jumped back on the plane to head back to NY.... and a friend dragged me to this place.

I ordered a Carnitas burrito crispy (not on the menu).. and it was FANTASTIC!  I'm told this is one of the best Mexican meals you can get in the Mission.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Sergio R.

description:
You must only order the tacos here...

When you do, specify "dorados" so you're ordering "un taco dorado por favor."

It's one of the best experiences I've had in a long time. If you get the taco loaded with everything it come to $6.50 per taco which is super expensive but well worth it! I only get mine with salsa and cheese; for 3 tacos dorados it cost me $13. So not too bad. And the atmosphere is a typical taqueria in the Mission, nothing too special.
author: Kyle L.

description:
With one hundred thirty some odd reviews, I feel a little redundant but La Taqueria by a landslide serves the best burritos in the state. 

Before I lived in the city I used to visit often and La Taqueria was a place where the food was never bad and every friend I took there loved it.  It has always been a big hit, even with the pickiest of eaters. 

Now that I live in the city it is a bi-weekly event to travel from the panhandle to 25th and Mission for two of the worlds yummiest burritos(because one fills you up and you always want more later).  The salsa is amazing and the NO RICE (*yeah*) burrito is chalked full of yummy goodness. 

Okay so they charge extra for the cheese, guac, and sour cream, but come on folks! We live in San Francisco where the average meal is $20 a person.  So let your coin purses go and spend an extra $2 to make it even better.  Plus you are paying for the scrumptious meat that they generously pile on, I don't mind paying a little more for cheese and sour cream.
author: Brea C.

description: Great tacos, perfect burritos with no rice used as a filler! A bit pricey for a regular taco @ $3.75 but quality is there
author: Jason B.

description: this is the best taco place in the mission and therefore the West coast.  Fully loaded taco with the  fixings will run you $5.50 a little steep but worth every penny. i usually get 2 so that and beer is close to $15 bucks. Check it out.
author: Robert L.

description: I love the Lengua Taco.  It is quite expensive for a Taco.
author: Jim J.

description: There is excellent and then there is very excellent, this place is that. Same crispy and soft shell combo like nick'c crispy just a lot better. Chips and salsa are danky and when the mariachi guy is there it reminds me of dirty times in Rocky Point, Mexico.
author: Phillip B.

description:
I'd heard a lot of good things about this place but left utterly disappointed. The best thing about La Taq is the neon sign in front.

I had the corn quesadilla and a couple of the tacos. The quesdailla shell was dripping in grease. The tacos were slightly better, though the beef was way overcooked. 

The menu is fairly simple, so you would think they'd do better. You can get tacos, quesadillas or burritos.

Things like cheese and avocado are extra here.
author: Rocky A.

description: OH MY GOODNESS! I traveled all the way from Illinois for this burrito and BOY WAS IT WORTH IT! I came back home from our road trip to California and have been searching non stop for the name of this place! FINALLY my friend and I found it after a long 3 hour search online. I immediately logged the address in my contacts as BEST BURRITO ON THE PLANET! I am counting down the day's until we meet again! Loved the atmosphere at the location. Everyone was so friendly. We stumbled upon La Taqueria by sheer luck when I asked a local what the best burrito place was he was quick to reply La Taqueria and pointed me to a beautiful white gated building a block away from where we stood. We arrived around 10:30 to find out that they open at 11 am =[ we were quick to realize that this was the real deal when a LINE started to form outside the gates before the restaurant even opened! 11 came and we were 8th in line! I couldn't wait to see what this place had to offer. You start off by ordering taco burrito ect... I chose a burrito, obviously, and tried a special meat combination that a local recommended half carnitas (special blend) and half steak with everything on it including sour cream and quac....the end result was HEAVEN IN MY MOUTH! What I enjoyed most about the burrito was how well everything was packed into them. It was thin and long unlike the regular burritos I was used to Thick and short...and yes we're still talking about burritos here...I'm straight fyi...Form factor was 10/10! The best put together burrito I have ever had! Anytime you're visiting San Francisco or if you're one of the few lucky people that are living there GO TRY LA TAQUERIA for yourself! You will be AMAZED! They had other types of dishes as well tacos enchiladas ect. Fast Food type serving Best Burrito Ever....DONE and DONE!....the funny thing is I only made myself write this review so that it saves a review for this place in my yelp account so that next time I'm in San Francisco I just open my Yelp app go to My Reviews and BAM! Here she is....my La Taqueria Love...I honestly can't live without you...#firstworldproblems... I'm done =]
author: Dan M.

description:
I have been going to this place since I was a kid since the late 70's.  The parents would bring us here on Sundays after a day of going to church and running family errands to Gemco (pre-Target Days) and Serramonte.  This was were we would go when we wanted Mexican food, when mom did not want to cook.  Back then burritos were $1.50 and tacos were 50 cents.  

Fast forward 2006, very little in terms of flavor has changed.  Sure the prices have gone up, a little adjustment for inflation here and there, but the place still looks the same.  Down to the wooden seats with the leather strap tops and the cast iron table bases reminiscent of the 19070's.

Whatever you get make sure to ask for it "dorada" that means grilled. I had the carne asada burrito grilled and Wayne had the chicken taco grilled...both were great!

This place doesn't need the kudos, especially after being highlighted in San Francisco Magazine as best Mexican for under 10 bucks, but I'm giving you my 5 cents anyways.
author: A P.

description: It was okay, but nowhere near as good as El Farrolito.  And I agree with the reviews that it was a little pricey in comparison as well.
author: Susan A.

description:
Yum yum yum! Taco! Taco Taco!

Second time there and I love it even more! The CHICKEN taco is my FAVE! Then I splash some green hot sauce on the baby and it's to DIE for!

The menu consist of Tacos and burritos, no dinner plates.  The Taco are a bit pricey for Tacos, BUT these are not ordinary Tacos!

This place is MUST if your near the Mission. Depending what time you go, parking can SUCK.

I wish they stood open late, that would be great.
author: Jorge D.

description:
Very disappointing experience. Maybe this happened because I ordered in English, but there was no spice whatsoever in my burrito. In general the food was very bland, including my quesedilla. The agua fresca was pretty decent but not mind-blowing by any means.

You can get cheaper food other places in the Mission, too.
author: Alexander G.

description:
There are so many Mexican joints to chose from in the Mission, I was in Heaven! But I had heard this was a must  and Oh WOW --Delicious! 
I went with the chicken burrito -amazing-but after trying everyone elses... I highly recommend Carne Asada -OMG melt in your mouth! -this burrito would make me more of a meat eater. (Tacos were equally amazing). 
This is a little pricey for a taco joint and this is so weird:They charge more if you DON'T want beans --like if you ask for less ingredients in your order it cost MORE??
author: LaLaLolita D.

description:
Sometimes meat really grosses me out-- I am not someone who likes steak, or prime rib, yadda yadda yadda. But just the SMELL of this place makes me salivate!

Everything is so juicy it's impossible to eat one of their tacos or burritos without looking like a dribbly 5-year-old. No rice  which doesn't help the situation. Usually drippy Mexican food bothers me, because it means it's less flavorful and more watery, but here-- not the case! Uber flavorful, moist, tender meats.

My favorite is the carnitas. I would go for the tacos over the burritos. And definitely order the agua frescas-- I've only had the melon, but it almost tasted like eating a fresh cantaloupe. Heaven.

Unfortunately, I can't take any of my veggie friends here. Their menu is so lacking in good vegetarian options it's almost discriminatory. Good thing for me I eat meat!
author: Amy D.

description:
I got 2 carne asada tacos with avocado and a small soda - $10. My friend got a carne asada burrito with no beans, small soda and chips - $11.  What's wrong with this picture?  

I think the food was great as everybody has already stated, especially the avocado that looked and tasted super fresh.  However, the woman at the register had some serious attitude and they were really rude about actually giving us the sodas or extra avocado.  

I think the kicker was when I noticed they charge a dollar extra for NO BEANS.  Um, what?  Are you serious?  I'm paying more for less?  Brilliant.

Bottom line - I can get the same quality of food at Papalote but for a lot less attitude and money.
author: l c.

description: Just came here for a casual lunch and must say.. this is one of the most popular taqueria's in the mission district of san francisco!!  The thing to get here is their TACOS.  At $3.50/ each they are pretty large.  They have meat, salsa and beans wrapped in two tortillas (corn).  I got the carnitas which was delish and pretty filling already.. but Anyway, I also got their chips and guacamole.  Their gauc is pretty decent with whole chuncks of avocado and a load of fresh salsa on the side.  Their chips were obviously freshly fried as well!  Delicious !  Minus 1 star for bad seating arrangements, a little stinky due to homeless people sitting outside and extremely drippy taco that led to my paper soaking through to the basket.
author: Margie C.

description:
One liner:  Any place where you see homeless guys pooling their change out front to get a burrito is pure win.

Carne Asada burrito with everything.
I'm sure they make other things, but there really is no need.
author: Anthony T.

description:
to date, my favorite burrito place in the mission. this is saying something, since i live here and eat more burritos than anybody needs to know.

came here when i had hardly an appetite, so i decided to skimp on the sides (e.g. sour cream, avocado, etc - which cost extra). as i ordered i was mentally scoffing at my burrito that i already decided was going to be both puny and tasteless. 

i'm still trying to figure out how a burrito with ONLY chicken, beans, salsa, and a tortilla (no rice, even) could taste so good. i think it was the chicken that was oozing the most flavorful juice (more a broth-juice than an oily grease-juice) that doused the rest of the burrito in its amazing juicy chickenness.

so yeah i ate it all. 

i did see them squirting some unidentified sauce on my tortilla though, so that could be the secret.
author: cecilia y.

description:
La Taqueria is the most overrated burrito joint in the city. 

The first time I went here, I ordered a quesadilla con carnitas. I paid too much for a portion that would have left the rats roaming around there still hungry, and then I paid an entire week for it afterwards. Yeah. But that is to be expected occasionally-- taquerias are like tequilla, every once in a while they'll make you sick. But I was bound to give La Taqueria a second chance, after all, they make the best tacos right? Horseradish.

Five dollars for a taco? Plus tax. I'd rather make a road trip across the border and get three for $1. Want some chips? Break out the wallet! How about some chunky salsa? None of that here. Oh, need a drink to wash it down? Horchata will cost you $2.... for a small. That's up there with the price of beer. 

A midnight snack here (two tacos small horchata) cost me over $13. That's an abortion of a price.

I'm ready to boycott La Taqueria. Who's with me?
author: John M.

description:
Great food and fast service.

I only been there once, but I enjoyed my meal tremendously.

I had one of the dinner plates (wish I could remember what it was).

I'm sure I'll be back, prolly with a girl on a date...LOl

Hallelujah Holla Back!!
author: Mike V.

description:
Go.  Don't let all the white people in the Taqueria scare you.  It's really good Mexican food.  

The tacos are delicious.  Two layers of corn tortillas.  The inner layer is crispy and has cheese baked on top of it.  The crispiness helps absorb the juices from the beans and meat and forms a great texture and contrast to the steamed corn tortilla on the outside.  

Such a great reprieve from the local, no-name taqueria in my neighborhood!
author: Tom K.

description:
One of the great things about Yelp is that it gives me everything I need to feel like a regular before even stepping foot in places like La Taqueria.  And after reading a few comments, I know that a regular wouldn't necessarily order burritos or quesadillas.  A regular would order a taco from La "Taqueria."  And that's just what I did.  

I had the pollo and carne asada tacos.  Both were extremely juicy (not greasy) and piping hot.  The flavor was on the delicate side, which balanced out perfectly with their green sauce (standard at every table).  My day went just swimmingly after only two tacos and a melon juice.  

La Taqueria does not accept credit cards; but don't worry, local street vendors will gladly exchange a few bucks for that shiny watch of yours.  That or you can use La Taqueria's ATM.  And for those distinguished reviewers who are upset at the lack of rice in the burritos, may I suggest El Bell de Taco.
author: Dennis J.

description: Really high quality meat, but I just can't give more than 3 stars given the price and the lack of rice in the burrito.  It's just not my style!
author: Jori P.

description:
I am reading the reviews and it seems that I cannot really judge this place since I have not eaten tacos, but I have to say one thing: do not go there for burritos! 
They are small and overpriced especially if you consider that you have to pay for each item (cheese, guacamole, etc.) plus you have to pay to not have beans! 
The beers are kind of expensive too: $ 3.50 for a can of Tecate!?
What else? I asked for a very spicy burrito and it was not spicy at all meaning that they did not add any sauce to make it spice as I specifically asked. 
I give two stars only because the beef was tasty but maybe too greasy.
author: Laura C.

description:
In a neighborhood boasting countless taquerias, this one has assumed the correct name. (Kind of like if The Band had kept their name but replaced their personnel with the Rolling Stones.) All the authenticity of El Toro and Pancho Villa without the omnipresent proprietor sporting a bad rug and hovering lecherously above his undocumented, under aged female staff. 

Try the carnitas or chicken taco with fresh avocado. A slightly strange ordering system - you place your order at the register, pay, get your ticket and wait for your number to be called. Crowded during peak hours and closes somewhat early. Proportions large but slightly more reasonable than aforementioned local spots, but still plenty of food. A bit more pricey as well, but worth it.
author: R M.

description:
Chicken taco = YUM.
Cloroxy-smell = minus one star.
author: Cary M.

description:
Sure, La Taqueria loses a star because the burritos keep getting smaller (or am I just getting bigger?)... They charge extra for any extras (avocado, cheese, or cream) and you need at least 2-3 extras.... But, who can beat the taste?!

I've been going to La Taqueria since I was a little kid visitng my great grandparents on South Van Ness. I love the carne asada burritos with avocado and cream.  The meat is juicy and the burrito has no rice... Don't forget to get a aqua de fresa.
author: Aya I.

description:
I've been coming here for at least 8 years and I WILL NEVER STOP
what I get:
crispy carnitas taco with everything
everything= guac, salsa, frijoles, sour cream

and EVERYTHING about it is delicious

by the way, they're huge, so don't order 3 because even though you'll be stuffed after 1, you'll keep eating them.  trust me.
author: Josie A.

description:
First time here the other night with some friends of mine for extremely good tacos!  YUM!

Parking is difficult, of course, but it is so worth the visit.  The best carne asada tacos.  Really fresh guacamole.  Can tell it's homemade.  

Not a fancy place just good quality mexican food.
author: Annette J.

description:
I love their TACO's and have been spoiled now 4-Ever.  The melted cheese on the corn tortilla's with beans and a choice of meats, guacamole or veggie style, and the salsa that tops it off....aiyiyi I must maintain Taco composure. 

Good STuff!!!  You will be ruined for other Taco places 4-Ever!
author: Angela R K.

description:
I'm a picky eater, especially when it comes to burritos. (Though really, I prefer "particular" to "picky".) When my friend told me that he knew the best burrito in town and described it as "an orgasm in his mouth" I decided to jump on the La Taqueria train myself. Definitely post-coital-cigarette worthy.

The Carne Asada burrito is heavenly. No rice, just a ton of fresh steak, beans, guac, sour cream, and of course cheese. OH, the glorious cheese. While I don't come close to finishing one in a single sitting, it's definitely leftover-able, as even your basic microwave will return it to its cheezy, orgasmic tastiness...kind of like that Marina guy you're too embarrassed to tell your hipster friends about. But that's another story for another time.

In short: go here. Get burrito. Walk around with a post-coital glow all day. You'll thank me later.
author: Aubrey S.

description:
Plain and simple, this is the best burrito in the city. 

It has all the characteristics of an authentic taqueria including a killer juke box, old school leather seats, no credit cards, superb meat, and a line of people salivating while they could the seconds unitl they're number is called.

Sometimes you think about going back for more. Is that not the sign of a mind blowing meal?

Top order: carne asada burrito with cheese, salsa, and sour cream. 

Victory.
author: Tim F.

description:
When I think of tacos, I immediately think of La Taqueria.  Their tacos are crispy, crunchy and more satisfying than any taco I can remember to date.  They don't put rice in their tacos, or their burritos for that matter.  They get you quite a bit in price for the extras, but I guess with the food crisis we're having, I can't blame them that much.

Their burritos aren't the best, but that's why they're called La Taqueria in the first place.  The white facade out front also reminds me of the adobe house of the Mexican family in The Good, The Bad and The Ugly, which only adds to the flavor of the establishment.

5 stars.  Eat the tacos, and enjoy yourself.
author: Eric S.

description: I love the carne asada with avocado burrito.  Make sure you must get it crispy/grilled, where they grill your burrito to perfection.
author: Gary F.

description: The best crispy carne asada tacos ever!!!! I've had their shredded chicken and not a fan. I live in Sacramento and if in the Bay Area will drive all the way to SF to get the tacos. Absolutely amazing! Totally recommend this place.
author: Nadia J.

description: Hands down, this place has the best hot sauce. Also, their carne asado tacos are tender and delicious. I've been going to this place for 17 years and I have always been satisfied.
author: Candice F.

description: Yum yum yum! Holy carnitas taco with everything. Every savoring bite was mmm. I just happen to stumble upon this resturaunt and decided to go in since it was packed with people. I've only tried their crispy tacos and the pork one is my favorite, though probably not the healthiest. Kind of pricey if you add all the extras. Also, just noticed on the extras list: NO BEANS $1.20??? Anyway, this place will definitely be one of the occassional regulars on my list.
author: Lotus L.

description: My first meal here 33 years ago was love at first bite.  Veggie burrito with extra salsa.  Perfectly supple beans bathed in warm cheesy ecstasy, accented by piquant tomato salsa and torrents of the best spicy tomatillo sauce I've ever had.  You can go all out for a meat burrito with the extras, but why pay extra when you can have a large helping of bean bliss for just over $4.  So delicious I often assess my budget in burritos.  $20 for a new t-shirt or five burritos at La Taquería?  The burritos inevitably triumph.
author: L B.

description:
Dioses del Olimpo... Ay, Que Rico!
bean and cheese taco with avocado and hot sauce!!!
carne asada burrito... avocado... hot sauce!!!
carnitas?
pollo?
order up! it's ALL good! better than good, it's f-ing GREAT!!!
I walk past this place everyday... 
I always look in to see all the happy munchers... 
happy to be eating something real... 
cuz that's what it is... real, simple, and delicious food!
burritos like mama used to make!
tacos, even better than mama's!
sorry mama!
author: M V.

description:
I first visited La Taqueria twelve years ago. Their carnitas taco is the gold standard,  is what brings me back to this place, and is what I would recommend to anyone trying La Taqueria out for the first time. Order one with cheese, guac, and spicy or mild salsa. One taco is filling and more than two is too much. Pricey, but worth it. Be sure to bring cash.

Their mango agua fresca is also very good when the mangos are ripe.
author: John S.

description:
I'm not a big fan of Mexican food, probably because I haven't had any really good Mexican food since I was a kid growing up in East Los Angeles.  It's rare that I pop into a Mexican joint, but I was hungry and was in the neighborhood, so I visited La Taqueria.

I was impressed.  I had a chicken taco and a beef taco.  And a carnitas quesadilla.  Hey, I said I was hungry.

All great, all authentic.  And the place was spotless, which is a small miracle considering how busy the place was and how much food they serve.

I take away one star because of the sneaky "add-ons" that make a cheap taco into an expensive feast, but all in all I have no complaints.
author: Nickolas M.

description:
First off, there's a reason why the name of this taqueria (La Taqueria) when translated into English means "THE TAQUERIA" - cause IT IS the taqueria.  The burritos are juicy and solid as opposed to dry and skimpy.  The hot sauce they have their is off the hook although I wouldn't mind something hotter than the ones they have there.  Their tacos are bomb and their meat is pretty good quality and seasoned quite deliciously.

The burritos can get pricey as anything additional will cost ya (ie, guacamole, sour cream, cheese etc). 

Feel like grubbing on satisfying and delicious tacos and burritos?  Go to La Taqueria on Mission!

FYI: Parking sucks out there.
author: Nancy P.

description: Came in for my first time the other day craving some mexican food, and was in the area. Ordered the chicken burrito and it was absolutely delicious. Had it spicy with their 'home-made' sauce as well that i loved. great atmosphere, reasonable prices, fast service. Winner in my books.
author: Erik K.

description: Delish! I highly recommend the chorizo quesadilla or chorizo burrito. The owner is super friendly and makes everyone feel welcome!
author: Maricela C.

description: Carne Asada burrito had very nice steak and guac was incredibly fresh and chunky.  Nice amount.  I like the open air seating.  Guac and steak could have been a bit for spicy and flavorful, though.  Price of $7.90 is a bit steep, but this was primo quality stuff, so I can accept it.  Extra $1 for no beans meant extra meat.
author: Marc S.

description: A friend of mine said La Taqueria is better than El Farolito (a favorite of mine), so I decided to go try it today. I had the carne asada burrito and was surprised that I finished one by myself considering I get full off of half of El Farolito's. I was disappointed that cheese and avocado came at an extra cost (50 cents for cheese and $1.20 for avocado). Basically the burrito comes with meat, beans, and salsa that drips out of the wrap for $6.50. Maybe I'm just used to having rice in my burritos, but I was not used to not feeling completely stuffed after finishing my burrito. It didn't hit the spot, but nonetheless pretty good meat + salsa!
author: Cindy L.

description:
It's a huge claim to say they have the best tacos and burritos in the world! We shared a chicken burrito that was quite good. The chicken was moist and they include guacamole at no additional cost. The place is very clean and the service is efficient. I noticed they brought out another person to take orders at the counter when a line started forming. 

I may be an outlier, but I was disappointed with the mango aqua fresca I ordered. The flavor was top notch, but I got two sips of aqua fresca....the rest was ice. For $2.44, I could have fared better buying several mangos and blending them myself. That is if I carried a blender around.
author: Mary R.

description: This taqueria regularly gets written up in the "Cheap Eats" sections of the newspaper. On occasion, you can see tourists clutching guidebooks waiting for a table. Mostly, it stands above local taquerias because of the apparent quality of the ingredients (and perhaps the flirtatious server/worker who gives out flowers?). The guacamole is  clearly recently made from good avocados, not like some adulterated or watery versions lurking elsewhere in the Mission. I order carnitas tacos dorados. The aquas frescas are good, but often extremely sweet.
author: Heather D.

description:
Ah, not impressed. They use the big corn tortillas, not the little mini ones. No al pastor spit gryating spiced pork meat into a deliciuos frenzy ;-(

I had one al pastor, one lengua, one carne asada and one chicken. They were all ok, but nothing special. The chicken taco had good intentions. I mean they use white meat, but it was one big chunk of turkey-dry white meat. The carne asade was the tastiest of the bunch.

Maybe they are not really a taco place and more of a burrito place. I think I'm going to start a new thread...tacos suck, but burritos are good. There are quite a few places like that. These place usually have pretty tasty plates too. I may go back for a plate or burrito soon. Stay tuned.
author: isaias J.

description:
seriously amazing.  get it extra spicey, extra crunchy and you won't be disappointed.

the mango fresca or whatever is also delish.  

i miss this place
author: Pcake l.

description:
Carne Asada tacos w/guacamole. Fresa (strawberry) licuado

Te quiero!

I don't know about anything else on the menu because even though I've been here dozens of times these damn tacos are so delicious I've never ordered anything else.

Hands down the best taqueria taco in the Mission. I think a lot of yelpers are hating on this place because it doesn't serve the traditional Mission style burrito, where you are jamming every possible food item into your burrito, rice, beans, lettuce, tomatos, etc. etc. 

Don't get me wrong, I like that style too, but this is closer to authentic Mexican tacos where the focus is on great, succulent meats prepared simply so the flavor of the meat really comes through.

Anyway, I love these tacos even if they are damned expensive.
author: Bart C.

description:
Great taqueria on Calle Mission.  Quality is always well done-- i like someone taking my order and a feeling less like a cafeteria and more like a restaurant.  the Carne Asada is delicious and is tender-- this is a tough dish to make successfully--it is not easy to get tender Carne Asada.  

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Here's the deal. I went to this place before going to see an interpretive dance thing...so I wasn't in a good mood to begin with. Then I thought, man, I'm hungry. We walked up and down the street and looking for some kind of busy, good looking Mexican restaurant. Anyway, it was weird because I didn't know how to order until this lady holding a pad of paper asked what I wanted. She took my order for two burritos both with extra cheese. So after waiting for 10 mins, our food was ready. When I began to eat my burrito, it tasted really good. I kept eating and eating and then it occurred to me. There was no cheese! I ordered extra cheese and in fact received no cheese! And worse yet, the other burrito had cheese on it, but probably not an extra amount. Anyway, this place was on its way to getting four stars, but instead had to take a one star penalty due to poor execution of extra cheese. 

Anyway, I'm willing to give it another chance if I'm in the area. 

Oh, good price I think. I forget.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
2 stars only because it made me full-ish and I didn't get sick.  -3 for taste, price and hype.  

I really can't believe how much people rave about this place.  What did I miss?  One of the Top 100 Restaurants in the Bay Area?  I actually thought I walked into the wrong place after I ate the food.  THIS is the place people rave about?  Really?  The food is bland as hell and an already overpriced burrito or taco costs extra with anything beyond meat and beans.  I think I could get a better and cheaper taco or burrito almost anywhere else in the city.  In fact, just about every mexican place I've been to in the city serves up better food and service.  

No thanks.
author: M M.

description: The Best Burrito I have ever had. I met a friend in SFO who is  from Mexico originally and I asked him to take me to the best Mexican place in the city. And boy ! was I amazed. Their Burritos are so good, I ended up eating 3 of them ;-) There was a Mariachi band playing that day, it was one of the best experience. High on good food and Music ! There are some movie posters which were pretty cool too. All in all, a great experience !
author: Thameem K.

description: This was one of the best burritos I've ever had...so far. I have yet to really do a thorough tasting of various mission burritos. But these burritos were so fresh, and the meat was flavorful. They're pretty small (relatively speaking), so good for quick lunch.
author: Eliana D.

description: I check this place out every so often and since they close for the holidays and let the whole staff take a vacation, today was my first time back in 2007 and well they don't disappoint -- still the best taco stand in the Mission -- why folks go for the burritos I don't know (their beans are bland and kill the taste of the meat) I suggest that you go for the "crispy" tacos, one of the corn tortillas is fried and cheese added then a soft tortilla is wrapped around it then filled -- yum!
author: G R.

description:
The prices wouldn't necessarily stop me from coming back to this taqueria again, but it might make me think twice (or three times) about it. OK, I might go back.

This was some of the most excellent carnitas I've had in a long time. I like the simple ingredients, sans rice, but I should be paying less for this smaller-sized meal. 

Cozy atmosphere, efficient service, better burritos and more options within a taco's throw.
author: paul c.

description:
So the first five or six times I went to this place, I was NOT into it.  Like, you're going to charge me MORE money for a burrito with LESS in it (no rice.)  WTF?  I was thinking raw economics, just follwing an algorithim that the size of my burrito to size of my wallet ratio was all that mattered in a taqueria, and letting this distract me from the delicious tube of beans and stuff in my hands...

Well, folks, less is more, it's true.  Maybe I'm getting all buddhist and shit, but these burritos just taste better WITHOUT the rice.  You don't get all bloated and tired feeling after you eat them.  You're pumped up, you can like, go ride your bike, or if you're feeling lucky maybe even play some tennis.  Try playing tennis after eating at like El Metate or La Corneta, there's so much rice in those things it could give you narcolepsy.  And you don't want to be narcoleptic up against my 22 mph serve, ummkay?

I was also turned off by their lack of boutique-y vegeterian options for people like me.  But you know what, Fuck People Like Me, Ok?  Shit, sense-of-entitlement-a-mile-long-expect-tofu-on-every-streetcorner-because-"it's california"-motherfuckers.  Check it: these folks have been selling burritos in the Mission years before living in San Francisco was even a twinkle in my eye.  Who are they to have to change their style, to accomodate me, some gringo douchebag driving up everyone else's rent, like, the people who are making my burrito.   They got a good formula are are sticking with it, you gotta respect that.

So yeah, their burritos are simple and taste really good.  And I get the sense that this place is a sort of Mission District institution based on all the cops and old people who go there.  I kind of like that feeling.
author: Ben V.

description: I am new to town and have been looking for a Mexican Restaurant to replace my favorite down south. Well, the food was delicious but this is NOT a sit down restaurant with waiters and waitresses! You go to the counter to order and pay, and then they call your number out once your food is ready. The prices cannot be beat...for me and my husband it was only $23 dollars.I felt like a margarita, but the only alcohol for sale is beer. I ordered a chicken taco and a chicken quesadilla. The shredded chicken was great, although but I preferred the quesadilla on a fried corn tortilla (even though it was only stuffed with chicken and cheese). I must say the pico de gallo was superb along with the guacamole and homemade chips. I have been to Mexico multiple times and have learned to love authentic Mexican food. I think this is pretty authentic but it was not my style. I would rather eat at a sit down restaurant that is cleaner and more upscale. If I go back again, it'll be to run in and pick up a to go order.
author: Kelsey K.

description:
BEST BURRITO IN SF!!!!

If you think you have a burrito that compares BRING IT BI&%HES!!!!

There food is fresh and tastes incredible. I actually saw the owner insist on throwing out a whole grille full of chicken once because he didn't like how it looked. There salsa is also very fresh and very good.

Burrito and taco's dorrados are the best... if you think otherwise..well you're just wrong.

The only knock I have is that they are sooooooo busy that if you order to go and try and ad something to the order, they have go to the back of the line and start over. Then again if I was more prepared I wouldn't have this problem...
author: JR H.

description:
Mind you I haven't eaten here in probably 7 years:

Having spent a lot of time in Mexico and much of it involving great  tacos, I learned how to make great carnitas (basically just a confit of pork) and easy yet incredible carne asada. 

The real key is the tortilla, every one that I've tried in SF doesn't cut it.  Most problematic there is no place with a decent Al pastor. Yeah, tasty barbequed pork tacos but no real al pastor, but I digress.
