Throw that into a burrito with some simple mashed avocado, soft, pillowy pintos, and gorgeous homemade salsa, and you've got my favorite burrito in SF.  The green sauce in squeeze bottles at the table is essential, as is a dash of salt every so often.  You can also grab a salsa roja from the counter to take it into a different direction.  

The Jamaica drink is killer too, as is the Horchata.  And after reading Liza B's review, I'll have to check out the tacos dorados - if they're anything like Gordo's crispy corn quesadillas, or like Cactus Taqueria, then I'm in for a treat!
author: Pedro, aka Burgundy M.

description:
This is my favorite taqueria, in fact, if I don't eat there in two weeks, I start to go through withdrawl.  Many people are shocked when they learn there is no rice - get over it, you'll be glad you did.  

I only eat casadillas here - with avocado, sour cream and salsa.  It's almost like having an orgasm, but your adding calories instead of burning them.  Bummer, but it's so worth it!

Their strawberry fresca is the best in town.
author: Tori F.

description:
This is the place you MUST visit if you're around the upper Mission streets and hungry.

The crispy taco here is the best taco available in SF.

Just delicious. Get everything on it and cool off with a beer.

Real deal cantina charm, bangin' food. 

Make sure you hit the ATM before, cuz' they don't take the plastic.
author: Andreas T.

description:
Love it , love it, love it, love it.  

I've been going since '79... and the menu has changed very little.  The staff has very little turnaround too.  The guy at the grill has been there since the beginning and he hasn't changed a bit ... maybe La Taqueria is the fountain of youth!!  

Back in '79 I was getting the carnitas burrito with cheese and avocado.  The flavor combination is delectable and the hot sauce they serve completes the burrito package.  

Somewhere along the way I gave up meat and and now I go for the veggie burrito which is really just beans cheese avocado pico de gallo and cheese.  There is something about the way they flavor their beans that makes the burrito special.  I hate to suspect it's lard.  The pico de gallo is also perfectly balanced.  The avocado is just that, yummy delicious ripe smashed avocados... divine.  I also appreciate that they don't use rice.  I think that is more authentic.
author: Wanda P.

description:
Best Chorizo taco ever!  

I usually dont eat tacos much less hard tacos. I am more of a burrito fan.  I have eaten tacos all over, from Novato to San Diego, even in Mexico, but in SF La Taqueria is superb. 

What I loved was the size.  They packed so much stuff in this taco!  They had fresh avacado instead of guacamole; lots and lots of chorizo, sour cream and salsa... it was so huge i couldnt even fit it in my mouth.  Maybe it was because I was really hungry but I swallowed 4 in the same time my female friend ate 2.  I recommend eating the Chorizo Taco if you want guaranteed goodness..  I must come back and soon!
author: ed c.

description:
5 Stars All the way...

I go back and forthe between the burrito and the tacos. I think both are good but I agree that the crap inside isnt evenly distributed...which does affect the overall flavor. The tacos are crazy good, I just dont get them with beans (never heard of a toco with beans....thats just me). 

The place gets packed and you need to be a god damn sniper to find a table but Ive always gotten a table right as my food comes so it works out pretty nice. 

I'm gonna keep comming here whether you like it or not.
author: Scott H.

description:
My favorite thing about La Taqueria is the place next door. It's another taqueria. You would think that if La Taqueria was so great it would just drive the other place out of business. The case is, however, that La Taqueria is SO great that it gets crowded enough that spillover customers are able to keep a whole other restaurant afloat. Damn I love this place.

I've been coming here since I could eat. This was the first Mexican food I tasted, and when it is my time to ascend to that big taqueria in the sky, I intend to make it the last. The walls are lined with plaques and plaques for a reason.

It should be noted that I have never had a burrito from this place. In fact, I believe the only entree I've ever had here is the chicken taco w/cheese. But there is no reason to eat any other item once you have tasted this pinnacle of culinary achievement.

Maybe I'm going overboard with this. These are good tacos though. Strawberry drink is bomb too.
author: Jackson G.

description:
The horchata was sweet and tasty here, but not as cinnamon-y as I prefer.

Somehow I spent $20 here, which was not to my liking. At least my food was good.I had three tacos with everything on them (salsa, beans, avocado, sour cream, cheese, spicy)--chorizo, carne asada, and carnitas.

It was definitely greasy as hell (I felt like I consumed a bucket of oil after my meal, but at least I was stuffed and happy), but oh my god. The meat was delicious. The carne asada wasn't as grilled as I usually like it, but the meat was tender. The carnitas was awesome (but not crispy like at El Metate). The chorizo was delish! The filling inside was perfect, and just the right spiciness (it wasn't bland, but did have a kick to it, but the horchata cooled it down for me).

YUM. If only this meal cost me like $12 bucks, I'd be a deliriously happy 5-star customer. Oh, and cash only. =(
author: Angela H.

description:
This place is the best hands down!

My father used to bring me here as a kid and even now I still sit on those old rustic wood and leather chairs happily eating my burrito. This is one of the few places that is consistently GREAT. As a starter I'd recommend a plain flour quesadilla with lots of their green sauce they have on the tables. (I have never had a salsa verde anywhere else that compares.) For the main meal I'd either order two tacos (one carne asada, the other carnita) OR a carnita burrito. The reason why I love this place is because they DON'T use lettuce and rice as fillers. Everytime you bite into a burrito, it is JUICY and dripping. If it ain't messy you ain't in the right taqueria. Top it off with an aqua fresca (cantaloupe is my fav, strawberry close behind) and you've just had a perfect meal. Satisfying in every way.
author: Vanessa T.

description:
I've always believed that burritos didn't have rise, they'd be too heavy with beans.  Now, I know differently.  I went there as a New Yorker on a Honeymoon in San Fran.   So, let's face it, I don't know from burritos.  Still, it's the best I've ever had.  Second place goes to frozen Amy's burritos.  So take it for what it's worth. 

What I don't understand is this: I've lived on Ave. de Puerto Rico in Brooklyn, which would now be more aptly named Ave. de Mexico.  Why are there no places this good?  It's one of several reasons I'm envious of those smug San Franciscans.  Damn them and their high-quality foodie burritos!
author: Daniel O.

description:
MMmmmm...La Tacqueria!

La Tacqueria is one of the reasons why I will never move from San Francisco. I crave their veggie tacos and frescas. Strawberry and Pina are my favorites but the Cantaloupe one is really good too. 

I wish they were open later is the only thing I can say about this place.
author: Adrienne C.

description: Hands down best tacos in the Mission. Carnitas - check. Carne Asada - check. Chorizo - check. Only gripe is the extra charges for everything make your taco cost a mini fortune when tacos shouldn't cost that much. Granted it is fresh ingredients and packed to the gills...a mini meal in itself. If you only have time to try one Mission taqueria then this is the spot.
author: Anthony V.

description: Good burritos, bright, clean and spacious.
author: Tiff W.

description: I've been a patron of this restaurant for 25 years. (By the way, I'm not yet 30!) The main cook has been there all of that time. There is nothing else like this spot in the Mission -- believe me I've tried scores of other local taquerias. The chicken quesadillas (with guacamole and salsa) are my favorite. The chicken is juicy and so flavorful! Only downfall are the prices, but obviously it's worth it.  Also, they only take cash.
author: Becca D.

description:
oh no!! mannnnny la taq burritos into my face-stuffing career, today's burrito was yelpably bad. 

underwhelming, disappointing, and leaving me feeling a little sick to my full belly. scrappy carnitas - chewy, fatty parts with little flavor... really runny beans... messed up the order...
author: who k.

description: High quality meets stuffed in fresh tortillas, drenched with authentic tasty salsas...what else is there to say?
author: MTBer I.

description:
Worst Taqueria ever, it reminds me of Taco Bell.
Guac, sour cream, etc. all costs extra ($0.50/ea), and your $6.50 super burrito only consists of beans ($1.20 extra to get NO beans), a tiny amount of low quality meat, and some salsa that was actually pretty good.
This place is a rip off and avoid it at all costs.  I'm puzzled by why this place can get 4 stars- oh yeah- its filled with filthy white hipsters with trust funds with no problem paying $10+ for a proper burrito.
author: Johan E.

description: Carne Asada tacos were outstanding - two corn tortillas stuffed with meat, beans, and pico de gallo.  If you like your food a little spicier throw the red salsa on and you're set.  I could barely finish the second one, but they were so damn good that there's was no chance I wouldn't.  Washed it down with a cold Bohemia...cheap, fast, and delicious!
author: Andrew Z.

description: When I was a kid, taquerias and McDonald's served yummie food, now  I only eat at two taquerias: Pancho Villa's and La Taqueria..  Clean spot and good selection of garnishes and salsas.
author: Maria del Carmen M.

description:
I am always in search of the "best" taco in San Francisco and
I have found it at La Taqueria. The place always has a line, but
 it moves really swiftly!

Juicy soft tacos filled with beans, meat and tasty salsa.  You'll
need several napkins. I highly suggest you add avocado to your
order,  big slices.......yum!  They don't skimp on the ingredients
here. 

Enjoy!
author: Kerry H.

description: The crispy tacos here are the best, and I mean the best. The price sucks big time. For two of them, it's like $20 -  But they do taste so damn good. If you have never been, you definitely have to go try them. For your first time, it is definitely worth the cost.
author: John G.

description:
how haven't i tried this place until now? it took me until i saw it on the show America's Best as the best burrito in our country before i made my way to La Taqueria.  the carne asada burrito is indeed delicious. somehow the tortilla isn't chewy, it's more like soft and pillowy but i still found myself liking it. 

but seriously, the prices are kinda ridic, don't you think? for two burritos and two tacos i paid $32.
author: Regina C.

description: Haven't been here in a while but before it was only meant for carnivores ( I was once into meat) and they charge for every little item in the burrito such as the guac and sourcream!  I'm currently faithful to La Corneta!
author: R C.

description:
and still, the taco truck reigns supreme

so my food adventures led to me to this mexican restaurant.

again, with rave reviews from Yelp, I felt obligated to try it out. I absolutely love mexican food and feel that its appropriate to have any time of day (especially at 3 in the morning). And yet again, the taco truck reigns supreme in my book.

this place is in San Francisco in the i-have-no-idea district. To be honest, i am seriously geographically dumb. I can't tell north from south and if you ask me anything about directions, i'll probably give you the most confused look ever. so don't ever ask me where something is. The answer will most likely be "i don't know"

anyways. My friends came up from socal and we decided we had to try this place out. it took a little bit of driving but finding parking was quite easy (although we did have to pay for metered parking, but isn't that just all of SF these days...). We had just eaten not too long beforehand so all of us simply just got one taco. We got our orders almost right away which was awesome but the moment i got it, i knew it was just not going to be as good as it should be. It was bigger than the taco truck tacos I was used to (but it also costs more too since taco truck tacos are $1.25). It was nice and hot, but with a ton of diced tomatoes. I bit into it and it was average. The meat was sorta dry and not as flavorful as I would have liked it to be. I'm not quite sure why it has such rave reviews on Yelp but it was definitely misleading and the tacos are totally average. I would not come back here again knowing that it's a long drive for me to get there (it's in San Francisco and I live in the East Bay) and I can get MUCH better tacos from a taco truck.
author: Laura L.

description: I like eating tacos and Mexican foods.  I hear people brag about how amazing tacos are in California and I finally got to try one....the verdict I really liked it, but not much different than the tacos I get at authentic Mexican restaurants in Indiana.  I missed my side of fresh limes.  I was also disappointed that there was no Al pastor taco.
author: Megan C.

description: Did I mention to go to Mitchell's after and wash down your tacos with Macapuno ice cream? My instant de-crab method/feel good place.
author: Kristy H.

description:
I have been going here since I was 5. As I child I mostly frequented their San Jose shop. In high school I would go any day I could after school  and play shakira on the juke box and eat tacos till I couldn't move.



Their chorizo grease brings tears  to my eyes.

Their crushed ice makes me so happy its like my 8th birthday. 

Don't complain. You are an ass if you do.
author: maxwell c.

description: Dunno, I'm unfortunately not as high on this place as everyone else is. It's not terrible by any standards, but there's simply too much competition around it, and given the choice, I would almost certainly go to Cancun or Farolitio instead. For the price, the burrito was kinda small. I had the carnitas, which were a bit salty and not as crispy as I would have liked. I also like my burritos on the dry side, so that I don't get juices running down my hands. This burrito was definitely on the juicy side. Again, not terrible, but it just doesn't hold up to the competition.
author: Albert L.

description: I basically have been eating here ever since I  was in my mom's tummy. My go to order is usually a yummy carne asada burrito with guac, but I finally decided to give the carnitas taco a try. I'm usually not one for pork, but boy, i devoured that taco in a few minutes. The pork was very moist, juicy, and flavorful. I got everything on it, sour cream, cheese, and avocado, and so should you. I also like their flour quesadillas with carne asada; the tortilla always comes out so crispy and delish. i also really enjoy their strawberry and mango drinks!
author: Katrina L.

description:
Love the tacos. The meat is simple and well cooked, the corn tortillas are flavorful and the salsa cruda and salsa verde are the right stuff.  Top them with a little aguacate and I'm in heaven.

On the other hand, the burritos are kind of bland and the prices are somewhat steep for the south end of the Mission.
author: Yogi B.

description:
Ok, I am biased.
As a native SF and having grown up on La Taqueria, I have to give my 2 cents.  
Spells of having eaten here once or even twice a week without ever getting sick of it? Yes
Is it an expensive taco in taco terms? (after adding cheese and avocado) Yes
But it really is the best.  Two tacos with avocado, cheese and  salsa and I am a happy camper.  Good carnitas and carne asada. Pure, real avocado, not that adulterated stuff.  Good agua frescas.  Their burritos are good too, but different from most places because they don't come with rice.  If it's early, go to Dianda's next door to buy cookies for dessert.
author: Jackie C.

description:
All the guide books mention this one though it doesn't come across as a tourist trap. It IS in the Mission, after all. 

The reviews are deserved -- one of the better taquerias with quality ingredients used in their tacos, burritos and quesadillas.

Another one to try, and also close to a BART stop, is Pancho Villa near 16th and Valencia. Good stuff!
author: Mark K.

description:
I have been coming  here since I was a young child. My parents grew up in this neighborhood and would take me here often as they loved the food  so much. 

What can I say, the burritos are spectacular. While you may be used to rice in your burritos, you've gotta give these a chance if you're on the fence. The meat is grilled to perfection and always tender, beans and salsa are the only other ingredients that go into them. I normally go for the carne asada, but the lengua (beef tongue) is oh so good.

When I like to change it up, I go for the tacos which are superb as well. Their horchata and aguas frescas ain't bad either.
author: Alson L.

description:
Spending my formative years in San Diego has made me a true "taco snob".  I've spent hours trying to convince my Nor Cal friends that they've never tasted "real Mexican food".  Then I met my now-husband, and on our third date he challenged my "taco hypothesis" and took me to this Mission hole-in-the-wall.  Well, I married the guy....so now I can admit that he proved me wrong.

The tacos here are crazy-delicious.  They fry up the tortillas so that they're semi-crispy, then fill them with the kind of meat that you don't have to pick through to pull out the nasty parts.  Seriously....the chicken is pure white meat, huge chunks of chicken breast.  The beans taste like the kind you get in Mexico from the locals that run the taco stands, not the watered-down CA version.  My only issue with these guys is that now that they're more "famous", they've been skimping on the fillings and hiding a few measly bites of meat underneath a mountain of cheese.  Tsk, tsk...don't be posers La Taqueria...you're our only hope north of the border!
author: Kim S.

description:
Taco dorado.Taco dorado ... Carnitas or chicken the best ..
order a taco dorado w/ everything ...Amazing. You will be quiet ...you will not want to talk ...you will only want to eat....notice how everyone is into there food there...
author: mary k.

description:
Yes, the burritos are expensive. And yes, the burritos aren't very big. But DAMN, they taste awesome! Without rice filler, the other ingredients of the burrito taste vibrant, aggressive, colorful. Sooooo gooood. 

If the prices were lower, I would give La Taqueria 5 stars. I feel a little sad paying $10 for lunch at this place (because I need two of their smallish burritos to be sated).
author: Steve K.

description:
Lately I've been coming here for lunch, since they can produce a fairly large serving in reasonable time even when its busy.
The food is decent, for a Mexican restaurant in the Mission, but the menu lacks options you might expect to find in other places like enchiladas or fajitas.
Sometimes they screw up your order on account of it being so busy, and its nearly impossible to find parking. They charge $1.50 for chips and you are looking at paying over $7 for a burrito that doesn't even include rice (they dont have rice for burritos).

They have loads of plaques and past awards etc. on the wall behind the counter, but this golden age for la taqueria is obviously a bygone era that came before 2008. Since then the prices have been jacked up and service has become like a factory assembly line.
author: Richie S.

description: Oh I love this place! I have been going to La Taqueria my whole life and it's still the BEST taco joint in SF. I now live in Brooklyn New York and I bitch all the time about the lousy crap they call Tacos over here.
author: Kristle D.

description: The tacos are pricey but are large and delicious. Chorizo and carne asada are my favorites. This place closes earlier than you'd expect- like the place might be full no seating left and people trying to get in when they close.
author: Justin L.

description: Been coming here for 3+ years now during the weekends when I visit SF. By far the best burritos I have ever had almost every time I have gone here. I get it pretty plain but its still the best I have found in the area.
author: Kevin A.

description: With the most descriptive name in the world, this place also has a sign on the back that pretty accurately states, "The best tacos and burritos in the world."  I don't think they are far from the truth.
author: Andrea K.

description: Overrated. I had the carne asada taco which was at an expensive price of $3.50. The meat was tasty and in large quantities but the tortilla was not soft and the beans were cold. It definitely did not live up to my expectations after seeing it touted as one of the best Mexican joints in the country on the Food Network. Most expensive? Maybe.
author: Chris W.

description: Hmmm...La Taqueria seems to keep raising their prices but the burritos seem to keep getting smaller.  I am a petit gal and I just don't think there is enough stuffin' in the burr!  Like the flavors and the salsas though.
author: moodyfoodie m.

description: Closes thing to So Cal mexican food I could find on the city.  But they did have horchata that was excellent!
author: Justin F.

description: This review is for the burritos.   I ordered the carne asada but it was just not good at all.  It lacked flavor or that charred/grilled taste.  Their burritos come with meat, salsa, guac, sour cream or cheese.  Are we missing something?  Rice!!!???!?!!  Apparently they don't sell rice at all.  A taqueria without rice.  I couldn't fathom it.  Mine had meat, salsa, and guac.  It was just a tasteless wet mess.  I think rice is an essential ingredient in a burrito (except for a breakfast burrito).  It soaks up some of the juices of the meat or salsa.   Considering the countless taquerias in the Mission, I'm probably not coming here again.
author: Kristy L.

description: I have to say this is one of the better Mexican places in the Mission.  I came here because of the 7x7 magazine's 100 Best Things to Try Before You Die list and they were right.  Their meats are very juicy and tender.  I always come here for their Carne Asada.  They cook it just right where the meat doesn't become to dry and harsh like other places do.   Their Aquas Frescas are AMAZING!  Their fresh and tasty =D  Although their prices are a  little bit steep, it's well worth the trip and price to the Mission. Expect to pay extra for sour cream, cheese, and gucamole.  The only things that's are included in the price of the taco or burrito are the salsa, rice, meat ,and beans.  Oh and if you say no beans they charge you more because they put more meat in to make up for the missing beans.  Why they can't just put more rice in... I don't know.
author: Bertie Y.

description:
i love you. i will pay the $2 atm fee on top of the $3 wells fargo fee for using a non wells fargo atm to make sure i can have you, cash only, taco dorado de carnitas con todo.

p.s. thanks roomie - this was our first meal together ;)
author: Jean K.

description: Over $30 for four tacos and two drinks? And people bitch that eating out in NYC is expensive?! It had been years since I had eaten at La Taq and I forgot that it doubles the price of the taco when you get the extras but of course it doesn't say that on the menu. The tacos are good, but not $24 good.
author: Troy B.

description:
don't believe the hype.  not sure why everyone raves about this spot.  forget about it being overpriced, crowded and impossible to find parking.  the big question is: where's the flavor?  

i had 2 carne asada tacos with guac, looked tremendous but zero flavor.  my friend had the carnitas taco and she agreed that there was so little flavor.

the guac was nothing but mashed avocado.  no salt, lime juice, onions, cilantro, nothing.  if that's authentic mexican guac, i'll stick with the amercian shit.  even the tortilla chips had no salt.  is this the hub for the anti-salt movement?

bottom line is this place is beyond overrated.  only reason why it's 2 stars is the meat at least looks good.  too bad it taste like a rice cake.  one last note: no latinos were dining.  all americans and asians.
author: boner time j.

description:
Best tacos I have had in the U.S.  I had mine with no beans and no extras.

Price is a little steep, but you get more meat than in two tacos anywhere else.

If you ask for it hot, be careful, the hot sauce is HOT, but that burn is so wonderful.  

Oh, and cash only.
author: S. H.

description:
geez, this place blows...

$6 for a meat quesadilla, and that's literally all you get.  meat, cheese and a tortilla.  you want salsa?  crema?  guacamole?  that's another $3.  

oh, and if you're getting a burrito sans frijoles (beans), they'll charge you an extra $2.50.  yes, they'll charge you for a situation where they save money.  wtf?

i'm sorry to say, but it's an ethnic establishment that totally exploits their yuppie clientele.  on the one hand, they have to pay rent and make a living.  on the other hand, it's just plain wrong to charge for extras that should be included.

i give them 2 stars because the food still tastes okay.  after living in new york for 3 years, it could be worse.
author: rachel r.

description: Just go all-in on the taco. Beef tongue w/ everything!!!  Don't forget to squirt some extra hot sauce on it. Best taco ever
author: erik w.

description:
OMG - the best tacos in San Francisco
Burritos are great and with no rice the food gets even better
the owner knows how to make food with love and no filling unhealthy processed crap.
This is truly good mexican food that deserves all the abundant amount of awards it received.
author: Michael C.

description:
This place has a cool take on the burrito: NO RICE!  Nothing against the asians they just do it that way.

When their carnitas burrito hits the mark it is divine.

The family that started this place is from the original SF Burrito "Corleone"s old world family clan.

The price is so high  because there is a built in protection fee
.
 This place is like that Seinfeld episode with the Soup guy.  Cash only! or....NEXT!
author: Tyler D.

description: The best burrito in San Francisco, it really is true.   No rice - you won't miss it but it's better to know in advance.
author: Amy E.

description: My favorite taqueria in San Francisco. They don't put rice in their burritos which makes them so flavorful. Everything is SOOO good here. Tacos tacos tacos!
author: karla m.

description: I'm still dreaming about the "la carnita" tacos -- and it's been 3 months since I left San Fran. Juicy, tender pork... does life really get any better?
author: J M.

description: Beware - reviews questioning their food safety are true. The food is fresh and tasty, but everyone in my party got sick not long after eating there. We had chicken and beef tacos. Eat there at your own risk!
author: Paul O.

description:
So someone I used to work with in Calgary came to visit SF, and I was like lets go to La Taqueria, it's good.  To be honest with you there is not that much good mexican food in Canada (I did not find any in 25 years), so he was understandably like meh okay.  He spent the rest of his trip eating as many burrito's and taco's as he possibly could, he would disappear at night to go get a burrito if we were not having mexican for dinner.

So ya 5 star's for the place that can turn a non believer into a burrito crack head.
author: Nolan E.

description:
Get your taco and burrito fix here.   Good for vegetarians too.  Best place in the Mission. Yummmmmm

Friendly service and they care about their customers.
I'll go back again and again.
author: Katy F.

description:
The carnitas just melts in your mouth. I wouldn't say it's my favorite mission place, but it's close.

I usually get a burrito that I can't finish, but I end up eating all the meat inside :)
author: Shipra K.

description:
I am not usually a taco fan, but I make a huge exception for La Taq's beef and pork (carne asada & carnitas) versions, with soft (not crunchy) corn tortillas layered with cheese, so divine, and fresh, generous toppings of sour cream, avocado, and salsa. Hands-down the best taco I've ever tasted. 

The agua frescas are good too. Be sure to bring plenty of cash to indulge your tastebuds!
author: J. B.

description:
My best friend Beth introduced me to La Taqueria in the 80s.  Back then, this place was the bomb.  For years, I would make the trip from the burbs to the Mission just to feast on the burritos and quesadillas.  The last few times I stopped by, however, I thought the food seemed to be going down hill.  Finally, the food not only reached the end of that hill, it rolled into a bottomless pit and continued falling.  

My last visit was in October 2005.  On that day in October, I stopped by La Taqueria on my way home from picking up a dog I had adopted.  The meal was to be a treat for me.  It turned out to be a treat for my dog.  The quesadilla was so greasy it went straight to the trash bin.  (I didn't want my dog to puke up a greasy glob in the car.)  The burrito was utterly tasteless, but harmless, so I fed it to the dog, rather than waste the calories on crap.  That was the last time I ate at La Taqueria. 

WTF happened to this place?
author: Caisa S.

description:
As good as a taqueria gets.  The Chronicle was on the money when they wrote that the meat is the star at this restaurant.  It's true, perfectly seasoned, tender yet slightly charred carne asada.  Does it get better than that?  

The crispy tacos are made of one crispy taco shell blanketed inside of a soft taco.  This does two things; it creates a non greasy shell and it provides for one of the best textures that I've ever enjoyed when eating a crispy taco.  Guacamole, cheese and sour cream can leave you with a $4-$5 taco.  Not sure where you're from, but I order tacos by the couple... which can lead to a $10-$12 dollar taqueria outing (including drinks).

The prices are steep, the parking sucks, and the line that forms during busy hours is some what dysfunctional (line does a kind of L shape around the counter, the same place where people pick up their food).  However, all of this is well worth the food and a small price to pay if you really want to enjoy the one of the best taqueria's that the Mission has to offer.
author: bayani p.

description:
La Taqueria in the Mission serves the most tasty tacos in the city. They are so good that you won't mind how your hands smell of taco for the following two hours, after washing. Get your tacos done "dorado" to reach cloud nueve of taco heaven. Yes they are a expensive but the quality leaves little room complaining. Don't forget to watch their main taco cook work his magic. He's basically the Mr. Miyagi of taco making. 

They also have a location in San Jose on 1st St. if your are ever stuck downtown.
author: Eric F.

description:
I don't buy Starbucks and then try to sleep, ask bums for change, or look for stimulating intellectual conversation with DPT meter-maids. As such, I go to La Taqueria for what they do best: steak/taco/burrito/cheese/avocado/beer. Looking for rice-stuffed burritos, or fajitas, or delicious rock cod tacos at La Taqueria is like becoming a Scientologist and being surprised by the ensuing lobotomy: you're dumb.

For the uninitiated: La Taq is kinda pricey; they have the best steak tacos and burritos in SF; they have great salsa; the portions are kind of *delicately* sized; you're gonna want to get cheese and avocado on everything and they're going to charge you extra for it. (See: kinda pricey.)

Newsflash: McDonald's has shitty vegan food.
author: Cole M.

description: The cabeza and lengua tacos are great. Very flavorful and tender. Can't wait to go back.
author: Yelp R.

description: Omg!! They have the best beef burritos!! Overall their food is fantastic!! :)
author: Jamillah R.

description: I fear change and, as an avid burrito consumer, it's a big deal when i get a taco, especially if it's at a venue that is not a taco truck. however, la taqueria remains one of the few places that I would go to, without severe stress about veering from my normal burrito-oriented course. the tacos are crazy good and moist and have generous portions of guacamole and all things delicious. they make me wanna change, be a better person, etc. they're a little pricey, but my usual minute of shopper's remorse flies out the window when im caught up in the ecstasy of the taco moment. you should just be honest with yourself and reality and eat a taco there.
author: Sam R.

description: A solid place for Mexican food, though I've tried only an admittedly limited portion of the menu.  The chicken super burrito was quite good, with well-proportioned amounts of chicken, avocado, cheese and beans.  Washed it all down with a good, while not authentically good, horchata.
author: Victor R.

description: I have traveled extensively, including Mexico, and La Taqueria serves up the best burritos I've ever had. This is by far my favorite food to have when I visit home. I recommend their carinats burritos with everything or an "el dorado" taco.
author: Miguel C.

description: Mmmmm this burrito was so tasty!  I didn't exactly know what to expect when I walked in the door, but it sure did help me with my burrito craving.  I ordered a chicken burrito and added cheese and avo.  The tortilla was so good and so warm and the chicken was so flavorful and moist.  I think the chicken is what really made this burrito so good!  I can't wait to go back and try their tacos!
author: Cara D.

description: I love their lengua and cabeza tacos and burritos. Pure, unadulterated MEATFEST!! Love it!
author: Chummy S.

description: This place is the real deal.  Nothing too fancy and not tons of options, but the food is really tasty.  I especially like that it doesn't feel heavy--the chicken isn't greasy, the pork is lean, and the salsa is fresh.  I went here for the first time a month ago, and it's already on heavy rotation for me.
author: Nathan A.

description: Solid Mexican fare.  Had the lengua and carnitas tacos.  Tacos were in the chalupa style with the inner taco shell having been fried.  A solid amount of meat, beans, guacamole, sour cream, and salsa verde.  Not very seasoned in the end.  The guacamole was okay but could have used a bit more cilantro and citrus.  The place was hopping and people seemed very satisfied.
author: Dimitri S.

description:
Really more like a 3.5 stars. This is specifically for the Tacos, because I really can't get behind the burritos.

I would say the Tacos were tasty, not extremely filling (I ate 2 and was still hungry). Specifically the carnitas taco was quite good. 

Not as much better than Nick's Crispy tacos in Russian Hill as I expected. I guess with the reviews I expected something revolutionary and got a good Taco, but nothing incredible.
author: Andrew D.

description: Wow . . . that was an amazing taco.  Double corn tortilla, the inner one a little crispy and the outer one soft, creating a beautiful symphony of contrasting textures.  I ordered the carne asada taco, but also tried a bite of the carnitas.  Carnitas was better.
author: Jenny R.

description:
dear la taqueria carnitas tacos with cheese and avocado,

you are TO DIE FOR. 

love,
kristen

seriously...best effing taco I've ever had, it totally hit the spot as I was walking home in a daze from a work day from hell.  that may skew my review, as almost anything would be better than eating another meal out of an office vending machine at that point, but seriously, it was amazing.
author: Kristen K.

description:
great taco...price sounds steep for a taco ($3.50) but for the amount of meat, its worth it

cabeza taco...tender meat...nothing special in terms of flavor...just tasted like salt and pepper but good texture...fresh salsa is ok but slightly too dry...i prefer a crisp edges on the taco shell but none of that here despite using much oil when frying up the tortillas on the flat top...overall package is good though....tasty and definitely worth eating if around the mission

good atmosphere, good taco...hits the spot...

bottom line: one of the biggest tacos i've ever eaten...size is more like a mini burrito than a taco...good taco done right...isn't mindblowing but will satisfy your mexican food craving
author: Simon L.

description: A friend told me what I've heard a 1,000 times: "let me take to eat the best burrito in SF". Suurreeee...well, this time it was the best burrito in SF, sooo good.
author: Diego E.

description: I ordered the carne asada and cabeza burritos to go. It was eh...ok. Not the greatest burrito I've ever had, but not bad. But I have to say, it's one of the better ones around SFGH, where I work. I still prefer La Corneta at Glen Park though.
author: L C.

description:
Pretty damn good if I say so myself. The food is fresh and made right in front of you. 

I'm glad I hit up this place when I was in San Fran. Wish there were places like this in St. Louis.
author: Mike V.

description: If you want a taco... you HAVE to come here. My parents grew up in the Mission and went to Mission HS...so growing up when we wanted tacos.. .this was our spot. To this day... its still my spot for tacos. This is absolutely the BEST place in SF to get a taco. Burritos are also really good here. Something to note is that no rice exists here... just delicious beans and fixings. The rice would only fill you up and not allow you to eat every last bite of your delicious order.  Another thing to note... be sure to be specific about what you want on your order... if you want cheese and avocado you have to tell them at the time you order. Also, if you want a hard taco as opposed to a soft taco... be sure to say that up front.
author: Sarina U.

description:
My favorite taco (not burrito) in SF, hands down.

Taco (chicken and carnitas are favorites) + avocado + cheese. Sure, it's not as cheap as other places. And I've had tacos various places in mexico, so I know this isn't fully authentic, but it's delicious.
author: Max D.

description: A great place for a mission style burrito or taco. I had a tongue burrito and it was pretty damn good. The area has many Taqueria and there are probably others that are decent as well but we were only in town for a few days. I love the vibe of the mission as well and you can grab a negra modelo and your taco or burrito and sit out the front in the sun and watch life in the mission pass you by. Also this place is deeper into the mission and a little bit further away from the seedier end.
author: Alex D.

description: The best Tacos ever!!!!! The Taqueria is the place to be for the best tacos in the Bay :D ! Definitely is a MUST Go restaurant. We love it!!!!
author: Sam R.

description: Zero stars is not an option. This place completely rips you off, the chick at the counter is a conniving b, and the food is not even that good. ALWAYS ask for and check your receipt. I would check out Papalote as a far superior alternative.
author: Clementine J.

description: Excellent Mexican Food.. A little noisy/busy, but worth the wait-- also, great price!
author: Lee D.

description:
This place is fantastic!  There are dozens of taqueria's in the Mission and this is definately the best!  They don't put rice on their burritos which I find to be a very strange San Francisco thing.  Their meats are very well seasoned, the carnitas are out of this world!  I would also recommend the crispy tacos!  
Friends of mine who are from San Diego definately prefer this place over other SF taquerias as La Taqueria is more So Cal style.
author: Tim H.

description:
La Taqueria is THE taco place, hands down. (Sure, every San Franciscan has their own taco joint that they will defend to no ends, but La Taq is the winnner, too bad). 
I've grown up on La Taqueria, honestly sometimes eating there about once a week, never getting sick of the food. You can order anything and be thrilled, and after several visits most people develop their staple order. None of their orders are made with rice, and in fact, I am actually thrown off now when I eat burritos with rice. Seriously, this food wins at life.
Any time I have a visitor to SF, or a friend who wants to go eat, La Taq is my number one destination. Wonderful, quick staff, FANTASTIC FOOD, delicious frescas, and great communal eating setup (long tables and benches where you can get down with other customers). 
Now im craving a taco. Damn.
author: Molly C.

description:
Best tacos ever!  While it may be a little on the pricey side, one taco = one meal and the fresh friggin salsa daily and REAL guacamole, that's right folks, real avocado thick and chunky and delicious. 
No rice, big whoop! Its a filler anyway, the frescas are to DIE FOR! They  have so many flavors all year round!

And this place is down the street from my house. Yessssss!
author: Zenaida H.

description:
La Taqueria is probably the best Taqueria in San Francisco. They are also one of the priciest, but worth every penny. Basically all their tacos and burritos comes with your choice of meat, beans, pico de gallo and chile (hot sauce). If you want guacamole, cheese and sour cream, its about a dollar more per item.

They use marinated chicken which is simmered in seasoning instead of grilled chicken, also known as pollo asado. Their carnitas is almost prepared the same way so it comes out hella moist and juicy. I usually like the crispy carnitas like the style La Tapatia in South San Francisco makes, but this one is pretty slammin'.

I have been eating tacos and burritos at La Taqueria for over 10 years and have never been disappointed.
author: Francis A.

description: This place is so popular it doesn't need yelp but in my opinion it's the best burrito in the mission, which puts it in the running for best on earth. Not a huge burrito so if you're into that I'd head to Cancun but their carnitas are great. The super burrito is on the pricey side but it's worth it for their guacamole.
author: Ian W.

description: Wow, the food here is great.  My g/f loves the cheese in the tacos, and my burrito was spectacular.
author: Steve F.

description: Love this place. A bit expensive compared to other taquerias but well worth it. Try the Carne Asada Tacos, Dorado style! Put a little of the green sauce that's on the tables and you're good to go! Excellent!
author: Roy K.

description: Best Vegetarian burrito I have ever had. Been coming here for years and still love it ever time. Love that they have plain smashed avocado instead of guacamole. Perfect every time.
author: Abby Z.

description: I LOVE LA TAQUERIA!  Everything here tastes great; the tacos, quesadillas, and burritos are excellent. I also like the horchata and strawberry drink. Come here if you are hungry, cause the food is filling!
author: H. A.

description: Carnitas burritos yum. Finally found a taqueria in sf that doesn't taste like shit! Yay!!!
author: Christopher L.

description: Been going there since the early 90's although much less frequently in the last 10 years since I moved to the East Bay. Their carnitas tacos, with "everything" (crema, avocado) is so good. It's by far my favorite Mexican food ever. Another thing I love is their agua frescas, especially the mango and the pineapple. It's thick and not sugary and watered down like so many others.
author: Yumiko A.

description: This cash only place was packed so I would say most people love it. I went with a couple friends that love this place. For how busy this place is they serve the food very quick and they are large portions. The only reason I gave it 3 stars is because I grew up in San Diego where they have the best Mexican food and it's just not the same. If you are from any other part of the country you should try it and you will like it.
author: Mike H.

description: The place is the BEST! Authentic Mexican burritos, tacos, etc.  Been going here for over 20 Years.  Super fresh, everything on the menu is great. Always packed - try going at off peak eating times.  Never had a bad meal or experience here!
author: B c.

description:
LENGUA BURRITO:

Doesn't get as much love as the Carnitas....
Shame...it was heavenly. 
Tender. 
Bursting with flavor. 
Dreaming about it in far, far away Manhattan...
author: S Y.

description: I mean, the buritto's are pretty big, but they put way to much flower than  meat. It is probably one of the better Mexican eatery's left in the Mission. The neighborhood is in the heart of gentrification, which means the Mexican- American population is rapidly declining, while the white commie vegan pop. is inflating by the hour.
author: Marty F.

description: This is the absolute BEST taqueria i have ever been to!  I grew up eating at this place, and still have not found one taqueria that tops it.  The carne asada is deelish!  and everything always tastes fresh and just oh so good!! Burritos, tacos, aguas frescas... u name it, it's good!!
author: Vanessa M.

description: Didn't understand the hype when my grandparents took me there.... what no rice... everything is extra?? Now that I am older, it makes sense.High quality ingedients served the way it should be!  The place is the bomb! Moist chicken burritos, amazing asada tacos! Sure the chips and salsa are extra but how about a mound of salsa on some chips.... with a refill! Quesadillas....mmmmmm!!! Oh yeah salsa verde on the table!!! Homerun!!!
author: Chi chi R.

description: Holly Cow! I'd never eaten a very good burrito. From all the places, most of them has all the works with the sauce or the salsa over powers it. My brother had mention this place from watching the food network. And Alton Brown had mention to try out the carnitas or the lengua. I ended up trying the carnitas. It was very delicious and on the table has a bottle of their chilli verde sauce to add it on as optional. Yet, I ended up trying their verde sauce and it wasn't too bad. The restaurant do get very crowded though and if you don't want to drive...take the Bart to visit this place. It's worth the trip.
author: Julie V.

description: The aquas frescas at La Taqueria are money. I recommend the sandia (watermelon) or Jamaica. Yeah it's a bit pricey and yeah it can get insanely crowded but at least I know my food's gonna be good and my agua fresca won't be some jenky-ass watered down nastiness like some other taquerias in the Mission.
author: Vivienne L.

description: there are far better taquerias out there, but i only go here for 1 thing... carnitas tacos (or carne asada if you prefer), dorado style with everything on it. that alone keeps me coming back.  it's very very good.  other than that, i feel that the menu is outrageously overpriced, especially for a taqueria in the mission. some great alternatives include guadalajara, el farolito, la corneta, cancun & la cumbre.
author: Laxme G.

description: Soooooo good.  I had the carnitas tacos and the strawberry agua fresca.  I think they fry the tortillas so it was warm and a little crisp.  But not too crisp.  Just right.  I liked that there was just pinto beans, carnitas and salsa.  Very flavorful.
author: Julie D.

description:
For me it's the best burrito in the city! Loaded with meat.
The carnitas are great! Even in the busy hours all the employees try to get your order as soon as possible.
Great tacos also.
author: k. J.

description:
Oh my.  I'm speechless. Ok 2 words, Chorizo Taco. Ok 2 more, Carne Esada!!

That's it.
author: danny w.

description:
Best Carne Asada in the City!!!  Their meat is so tender. 

Order a Carne Asada Taco Dorado with Cheese and Avocado.  The best!
author: Hector C.

description: Larry and I each had a carne asada burrito with beans and pico de gallo.  The meat was cooked well, of decent quality and tender, but overall it lacked flavor.  I saw cilantro, tomato, onion, and chile, and they looked fresh enough in there, but couldn't taste them.   Could have used some acidity and salt, too.
author: Karen K.

description: Holy taco heaven! Best tacos in the city BYFAR. I get the worst (best?) cravings for La Taqueria. Great carne asada and tender carnitas topped by all that yummy cheese, sour cream, salsa, guac...MMmmmm. JUST GO, is all I'm gonna say :)
author: Sarah A.

description: My favorite place to get a burrito! The line for this place can get pretty long and it gets really hot in there, but it is definitely worth the wait.
author: Stephanie C.

description: How good can a burrito get?  It's all meat with no filler that is.  None of that overfilled with rice and a small layer of meat.  One bite is meaty goodness, I'd give it five stars, but my carne asada burrito was cold.
author: A L.

description: I was so disappointed by this. After hearing all the good reviews I decided to check it out. The burrito is already not that cheap, and to add cheese and avocado was an extra $1.70. In the end I paid about two bucks more than I would somewhere else for a burrito that would be bigger. It tasted fine, but nothing exceptional. I just can't believe how expensive it is for something so small. I rarely get a burrito in the city where I'm still hungry after.
author: Jonathan G.

description: Best tacos in the city!!! Order them crispy and you won't be disappointed :) Every ingredient is so fresh and taste so good. I have been coming here for years and I crave it all the time. Keep doing what ever it is you are doing cause I will keep coming back!
author: Kristen J.

description:
Hate to sound all competitive ... but the folks who don't recognize these as the best tacos on the planet are, well, factually wrong. 

With cheese, carnitas and lots of that green stuff -- simple order, but oh so top notch. I've been going here or its San Jose brother regularly for 30 years and it's maintained the quality year after year.

Oh yeah, grab the cantaloupe drink while you're there.

And no, this isn't a burrito place. They have them, and they're good enough, but it's LA TAQUERIA ... I don't speak Spanish but it sounds like that means "The Taco Maker" or something close.
author: Shawn L.

description: I came here with my client and he ordered me two tacos and a beer.  The tacos are huge and I was almost full already after the first one but had to show my guy respect, that I wasn't a wuss and could finish the 2nd one.  The 2nd one was special, not sure what it was called but it was the works; meat, salsa, sour cream, guacamole wrapped in a fried and a regular tortilla, reminds me of Taco Bell's Gordita Crunch.  The chips are thick and crunchy and everything is super fresh.
author: Jona C.

description: There is no better soft taco in San Francisco. I mean it. The only-and I mean ONLY-reason they don't get 5 out of 5 is because they close so early. I really wish I could give them another 1/2 star, actually. And, the counter staff has always been pleasant every time I've gone for the past 11 years.
author: reverend d.

description: Rather mediocre all round. So so service, so so food, ambiance nothing to write home about either. Definitely overpriced and under seasoned. I feel that the bridge and tunnel crowd is rather inflating the rating.
author: Dave C.

description: This place is seriously overrated. The menu is very limited (what? no tostadas at a taqueria?)  The burritos are big but bland. My dining companion said she makes better chorizo at home. There are some great taquerias in the Mission, but this isn't one of them.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Went with my SO on a 10 day SF trip.  Got burrito carnitas (x2), taco carne asada, quesadilla and chips+salsa.  Got cheese, sour cream and avocado toppings.  The avocado/guacamole and quesadilla were under-seasoned.  The salsa was mild, but fantastic---very tomato-ey.  The burritos were best, with a soft, flavorful tortilla (best I've ever tasted) and yummy fillings.  All good fillings, no rice.  Tacos were more difficult to eat (messy, dripping juice) but also good.  Very casual---order at the bar, pick up yourself and find a table.  Service was fast and friendly.  Salsa verde (spicy) was in bottles on every table which allowed you to control the heat as you wanted.  Overall definitely worth a trip but not *quite* good enough for 5 stars :)
author: Jason R.

description: Alright, so it was actually my mom who introduced me to La Taqueria cause she used to eat there as a child growing up in the Mission. The food IS good, however, its simply not what many people make it out to be. The tacos are good, but over priced and Americanized. They dont have an authentic taste at all.
author: David D.

description:
I go here only for the tacos. They are bigger than your average taqueria's 
They can get pricey for a taco it you like to orders extras on it. 

I LOVE THEY SOFT TACO'S 
I order it with meat, avocado, sour cream, whole beans and cheese. I think that alone is like $5.50

Pay the price its worth it. 

This place is always crowded they have an outside seating area as well.
author: Ana A.

description: Taqueria fare at its finest, and its most expensive.  I considered taking off a star for the price issue, but I couldn't do it.  La Taqueria is too delicious.  The carne asada is the best.  The lengua tacos are awesome and worth trying if you have a little bit of an adventurous palate.  I'm ok with the serving size, it's appropriate.  No rice here.  Chips cost extra.  Everything costs extra.  Worth it though.
author: Erin b.

description:
Got a carne asada burrito 12:30pm on a Wednesday afternoon.
It was crowded inside, but the line moved quickly and we got our food fast but it wasn't sloppy.  The owner/manager working the register is super nice and funny knowingly speaking to my friend and I in Spanish even though we couldn't respond very well.

The carne asada burrito had very good flavor with every bite. They don't skimp on the meat and the pico di gallo.  It was a little runny with the juices from the meat and the salsa but it was delicious and just the right amount of spicy with the salsa verde in the squeeze bottles at the tables.

The service is quick and also the turn of tables, you seat yourself, but it's worth waiting a couple minutes inside because a lot of people work around the Mission so they can't stay long anyways. I will make another trip there for one of their tacos maybe, but the toppings add up and make the order pricey for 1 taco.  If you get it plain $3.50 a taco. $6.50 for a burrito will keep you full quite a good while.
author: Jocie M.

description: I am mexi-converted b/c of this place. I used to think Taco Bell was the highlight of mexican food, which now I understand isn't really mexican food at all! This place has some of the best tacos I've ever had. I came here at 3 in the afternoon and the place was still busy! It seems as though they have a strong cult following.
author: Dave H.

description:
grab a modelo and squish into a chair to wait for your food. when said food is ready, indulge and enjoy. repeat if necessary. 

i am a fan and made it a point to bring people here when i lived in the bay.
author: Jenn B.

description: The best carnitas in the West. Hands down. Even my Mother in Law loved La Taqueria!
author: Scott S.

description: Simple, fresh, tasty food. Cash only. The chicken is just unbelievably moist and delicious. And they serve chips with  fresh avocado and salsa fresca. It's all perfect. Gets kind of crowded sometimes and you may end up sitting at a table with strangers so if that's not something you are into then you may want to get it to go.
author: Amanda M.

description: Unfortunately they do not have black beans, but the pico de gallo is sooooo good. The only downside is that it makes the burrito a bit watery, so be careful that it doesn't spill while you're eating. The burrito doesn't have any rice, not sure if that contributes to the wateriness, but if you're a big fan of rice in burrito, take heed that it won't be here!
author: Pringles C.

description: The carne asada and veggie burritos are great at La Taq. There is NO RICE in the burritos, which is awesome! They are not the cheapest Mexican place (about $8 for a loaded meat burrito,) but they are the best in the Mission!
author: Jet V.

description: Best Mexican food in the Mission -- hands down.  The crowds are there to prove it.  Best to go at off times if you can.
author: Richard L.

description: The carnitas tacos are seriously to die for. I lived in the Mission for years, and this place was always one of my favorites.
author: beatrix l.

description: La Taqueria's carnitas crispy taco with cheese and green salsa is one of the best tacos I've had anywhere. They quite simply rock. I have no comment on burritos or anything else for that matter since I cannot and will not stray from my crispy taco habit. They're incredible.
author: margot b.

description: Burritos for novices. They taste great but the tortillas are steamed not grilled. The burritos lack rice for internal structural integrity key to eating a burrito with a single hand whilst hold a beer in the other. This is a prime virture of the good burrito that La Taqueria misses by a mile. However the place is large and inviting and good for groups of five or more.
author: George M.

description:
Long has La Taqueria been on my list, but always have our paths failed to cross. Until now. Tormented by the crowded ill-prepared Street Food Festival, and thusly unhappy and extremely hungry to the point of vicious anti-social behavior, I made a bee-line for La Taqueria a few blocks away, barely beating out the following throng of fellow disappointed festival going hipsters.
The two fatty tacos I had at La Taqueria... delish, especially after my ordeal, but a deal for lunch bliss cost me a pretty penny--such a pretty penny that I have to strip La Taqueria of what would have been it's fourth star. For condiments of luscious sour cream and guac and other such fixings, each taco came to about $5. As filling and as magnificent as they were... $10 plus for two tacos is a serious offense. They were great, but I've had more mind-blowing, equally savory and filling tacos at the dozens of other Mission taquerias and littered taco trucks in the city, and not once did it cost me a cool $10--with that $10 I could have probably bought at least 5 tacos at my favorite truck, El Norteno.
So no bueno... I'm even tempted to strip yet another star for this crime but, I have to say, it was indeed very good and the day was saved by La Taqueria, so I will forgive them this one time. Still, when I'm in the mood for tacos, La Taqueria... not even on the list.
author: Jessica L.

description: Pretty alright; nothing particularly exceptional springs to mind. Another trip could easily push this to four stars.
author: Brian S.

description: This is my favorite place for tacos in the Mission. I love those little dudes so much, I've never dared to order anything else (Cancun and Gordos hold down the burrito corner). They stuff the tortillas at just the right amount and then wrap them up in paper like chubby sushi hand rolls. The carne asada is very tasty, though I usually scan the grill and then order whatever the most recently cooked meat is. It's not cheap, especially when one feels compelled by the mandate of the nutrition pyramid to add avocado ($1 extra! eep!) and order a strawberry agua fresca, but the tacos are so filling, one is usually enough for a S-M appetite (L-XL's should order two). The open-air archways at the front make it an especially happy place on a sunny day.
author: Katrina D.

description: Beastial burritos, fast service, juicy junk wrapped in tantalising tortilla, and great design add to a great lunch in the Mission. Super cool!
author: Haz O.

description: Hands down - Best Carne Asada Super Burrito in SF.
author: Joel L.

description: Its just not good.  Maybe if you like pounds of steaming beef, but i don't.  Struggled through my bland unexciting burrito and the only thing redeeming was the amazing fresh pinapple juice, unfortunately it was about three dollars a cup...
author: amy b.

description: Not so impressed with this place. Some friends hyped it up, but my burrito was sub par. I hear that the tacos are way better. I will try them out next time. Taqueria Cancun has much better burritos.
author: Emmanuel P.

description: This is really a 3 star taqueria in terms of taste and quantity (yes, its true, size does matter), but they get 4 stars for not putting rice in their burritos. I dont know what sort of influence we had on the Mexicans who immigrated farther north than SoCal, but we should be ashamed. Take a trip south of the border, you wont find rice in your burrito at any self respecting taqueria. I'm glad there are a few places in SF that honor the authenticity!
author: Drue C.

description: AMAZING BURRITOS!!! I've been going to La Taqueria  all my life. It is THE burrito place in the bay area.  I LOVE LOVE LOVE their beef burrito with sour cream and avocado. The burritos are HUGE and the prices are good. And those fruit drinks are marvelous. My favorite is the watermelon drink.  I'm in heaven when I'm at La Taqueria. There's always a line. But I don't care if I have to stand to eat my favorite burrito. I LOVE LA TAQUERIA.
author: Isabella L.

description: La Taqueria makes the most perfect taco ever created. I truly don't understand how anyone can say otherwise. As for the people that insist this place is overrated and for tourists only- bull. I've been coming here since I was a baby and my parents have been coming here since they were teens. I'm a native Missionista and I'm saying this place is worth every penny.
author: Cassandra C.

description: This taqueria is the best I've ever had!!!!!!! The meat, is marinated, tender. Everything is fresh, delicious. I've moved from San Francisco, but ever single time I'm here, I make sure to get their steak burrito and I have em' toast it for me. Their guacamole is outta this world too, as well as their agua fresca. Man, I'm seriously wanting some of this taqueria when I get into town next. By far, hands down no other taqueria has even come close!!!! LOVE IT!!!!
author: Noemi R.

description: Tacos here are pretty legendary. I've had the lengua and the steak here, and both are extremely good. You can't go wrong with this place, I'll be back soon!
author: Matt F.

description: One thing is for certain, you can't get tacos like this where I'm from.  La Taqueria is delicious.  The chicken is succulent and moist, the carnitas are flavorful and tender, and I just can't get enough of that green sauce.  It's a solid lunch spot and you won't find a better taco anywhere.  I love the hard shell/soft shell combo.  The only thing keeping it from getting five stars is the overwhelming amount of sauce and sour cream that they heap on the tacos.  Reign that in and we're good for a five star review.
author: Jillian T.

description: Some people are complaining that this place is more expensive than Papalote??  HOW?  Though not the most authentic place around, their meats are WAY juicier and tender.  They also have cabeza and lengua.....  I really don't see this as daring/gross...  I prefer it at times and they do it right.   They are a litte pricey... but no where near Papalote...  A triple threat Burrito at Papa's is 20 bones!!!
author: Demanding T.

description:
i love tacos. ever since my trip to playa del carmen, mexico and ate tacos every single day from the local cart.  i love the meat in it. i love the salsa. i love the cilantro.

but... beans?!  i don't want beans in my taco.

granted, the meat is tender and delicious, which is what usually distinguishes good tacos from bad tacos, but ... beans?  and it costs $1.20 to NOT get them?  that doesn't make any sense.

and the "guac" is just smushed avocado.  no onions, no spices, no ... anything.

i duno. is it just me? i wasn't really a fan.
author: Linda T.

description: Hands down best burritos in the mission. The hot sauce is amazing, the meat is just perfect and the service is great. I love this place and i love it even more that is it 2 blocks from my house.. Oh La Taqueria... you are so wonderful... :)
author: Samantha R.

description:
La Taqueria...well, walking into La Taqueria, there were several indications that I was in for a real treat: numerous awards (recent) on the wall, packed with people, smoke everywhere...however, this place just didn't carry with it the weight that I was so anticipating.  In fact, I don't think I've ever had such a 'flavorless' burrito.  The worse part of the experience was I had to 'pretend' this was as delicious as everyone had hyped it up to be.  How sad...I know, I should of held to my guns and taken a 'firm critics stance' , yet, what can one say when their friends are looking at them with excited anticipation of my response and I then suddenly belt out 'yuck, this sucks'?  I mean, come on, principles before personalities, right?  
In any case, I ordered a 'carne asada' which is to me the standard 'getting to know the feel of a place' order.  You can get a sense of who they are by 1) how they wrap the burrito 2) the size of the burrito 3) what they pack inside the burrito 4) how do they season their meat and finally, 5) are the beans whole, refried or black?  In this case, the wrap was traditional (albeit slender) with a fairly tasty tortilla, however, this is where the good stuff stops (cold).  The burrito was on the light-side (as in girth), the contents were runny and not well represented and the most upsetting piece...the meat...carne asada - the staple of the mexican tradition; grilled and flaring with seasons and flavor, was absent.  It tasted like nothing.  I mean it, absolutely nothing...swing and a miss.  It only added to the already building disappointment that the whole beans (the ONLY choice) were runny and made a mockery of the whole 'carne asada mindset'.  
I was depressed, let down and confused about what all the hub-bub was about.  Is this Zagat thing really that prestigious?  Perhaps they ordered something different or in a wider array...or maybe, just maybe, they were a little heavy on the cervezas and not enough on 'la comida'...
author: Scott H.

description: Everyone gushes about this place and it's highly rated in Zagat, but it doesn't live up to the hype. WAY overrated. Who the hell DOESN'T want rice in their burritos?!? I can't view that as a plus. I had a chicken burrito and agree with others - bland pretty much sums it up. Not very cheap at about 7 or 8 bucks. Not very big either. It is fresh though. Not terrible, just not as great as everyone raves.
author: Matt M.

description: Best Damn  carne asada Taco's in the mission... Even better because they are authentic unlike "pancho villa"... don't be alarmed when they don't put rice in your tacos/burritos.. In my former life of a vegetarian/pescetarian I do recall their veggie tacos being pretty good too...
author: Penelope S.

description: Best burrito in the city. When you first get your burrito, its just a tad smaller than your everyday SF burrito until you bite into it. Maybe beans, but no rice. ALL MEAT. Its pricier than other tacquerias, but cripes, youre getting like 2 a pound of freshly grilled steak dripping with juices. Highlight - Carne asada burrito with extra cilantro.
author: Mick F.

description: Screw all their other food, it's all about the GOLDEN TACOS! F'N AMAZING GOLDEN TACOS! I would totally take a golden taco shower from La Taqueria any day... yeah I said it, Golden Taco Showers.
author: danny e.

description:
The Captain goes in and orders take out at La Taqueria, pays for it, then promptly loses his ticket while waiting for the order.   This can't be the first time that's ever happened, but the seniorita at the cash register acted like it was.  She tells the cook, in Spanish, that he lost his ticket and the cook responds, in Spanish, "Tell the bitch he's gotta pay again."  The Captain doesn't look like he understands or speaks more than enough Spanish to order tacos so the cook was probably surprised when he shot back "I already paid for it, asshole."  They both laughed, not a big deal by itself, but here's the thing, I went in a week later and watched the same thing happen to someone else!   The cooks are talking about this guy who looks like he just came off a safari (like Brian Fellows, not like a yeti) and got lost on his way back to Kansas (shorts, knee socks, hat...Brian Fellows), but just happens to understand every word they're saying and isn't too happy about it.

I could eat the carne asada burrito every day (get it with avocados) and I LOVE their pico de gallo.  Yeah, the best taqueria in town, but come on - stop treating your customers like shit.  This isn't Tijuana, but it isn't Idaho either.  Anyone know if Michael Bauer speaks Spanish?  Just another gringo to the cooks.  What I wouldn't pay to see that scene play out!
author: P J.

description:
I used to love this place years ago. After many years away I went tonight for takeout burritos. Never again.

Watch out, queers. HOMOPHOBIA reigns here! My butch girlfriend gave our order to the very gracious young woman at the counter. Then the men behind the counter ridiculed her, laughing and pointing fingers. All while she stood there calmly waiting for our order. Taking the paper bags, she dropped one, but nothing spilt and all was OK. However, there was again, more ridicule in Spanish! When she requested salsa, the attitude continued. 
Lots of other places nearby make equally tasty burritos for less money WITHOUT the HOMOPHOBIA. I will NEVER go back there.  I encourage you not to, also.
author: franny s.

description: Busy, but good (my fav taqueria).  One pork taco is enough for lunch.
author: Dan D.

description: Hands down, my favorite place for a burrito or tacos. I dream about their carnitas. La Taqueria is also one of my favorite places to take friends and relatives who visit SF; it's cheap, tasty and something they're not likely to find in their hometowns.
author: Beth T.

description: If you are a swine lover like me, it doesn't get any better than carnitas at La Taqueria. With avocado & cilantro & I'm practically creaming in my American Apparel undies. Only drawback is it's expensive & doesn't have the character of El Farolito. But still, it's on all of those lists for a reason.
author: Maria D.

description:
Quite possibly my favorite of all the wonderful taquerias in the city. DO NOT miss the chicken or the carnitas. In fact, I think the chicken here is one of my favorite items anywhere. Seriously, the tomato-y sauce it's stewed in is not to be believed. So, well, tomato-y. And salty. And buttery even? I will crack this recipe! Mix that with some of the fresh 'n' tasty and avocado - oh my. Oh my oh my oh my.

Also some of the best carnitas in the city, whatever item it fills. The burritos are sans rice, just how I like them, and the guacamole is actually unadulterated mashed avocado. The only way the burritos could be improved would be if they steamed the tortillas. I also think the beans are just a little less tasty than Gordo's, but still quite excellent. The chicken burrito is so juicy it introduced me to the "burrito suck" method of consumption (you burritophiles know what I'm talking about). The method still grosses me out a bit, so I tend to opt for the messier method of just allowing all the juicy goodness pouring out of the burrito with every bite to just stream off my chin. The quesadillas (flat flour or crispy taco-like corn) are wonderful alternatives to the burrito, if you're in the mood for something else, and are arguably the best of their kind in the city (rivals: for flat flour quesadillas, La Palma Mexicatessen - but it's a close call; for crispy corn quesadillas, Gordos is still tough to beat).

Don't forget to order agua fresca (basically pureed fruit juice in a cup). Watermelon (sandia) is my favorite, but the others are equally refreshing. The method of a server walking down the line taking orders and putting them in before you've even made it to the register means you never have to wait long before your salivating mouth is satisfied.
author: Veronica L.

description: This place sucks...they actually charge you extra  if you ask for "no beans" ! and "no sour cream". what's up with that? More money for less food? I don't get it! And then, the burrito didn't even taste good. I couldn't finish it. I'm not kidding you, even the horchata wasn't that good. So when we finished (or rather, didn't) we walked down to El Farolito and got our favorite burrito that was twice the size for $2 less! and it was GOOD! I always think that El Farolito couldn't be the best place so I always try other places.and I am always wrong. wrong wrong wrong! I thought this place looked nice to dine in because of the open air seating, but I was highly disappointed!
author: Michael T.

description: Overpriced, overhyped.  Tacos for yuppies, I would say.  Why don't they have al pastor, the benchmark of taquerias?  Cheese in the tacos was a bit much.  I like mine plain and simple.  Meat, onions and cilantro, just like in Mexico!
author: Derrick V.

description: The reviews don't lie-- this place is pricey.  Add-ons (sour cream, avocado, salsa) will cost you dearly.  But I have to give it 5 stars on basis of one dish-- the crispy tacos.  They're not on the menu, technically, but they exist and they are delicious.  Basically they fry the inside tortilla, which sounds simple but results in taco nirvana.  They may cost you $6 a piece but they're worth the splurge!
author: Kristin P.

description: crap! I just heard the SJ  branch close this January!  ALlthough my favorite branch is the SF one cause it's in my old neighborhood, I grew accustom to SJ's branch cause I've been living in SJ for the past 3 years. Thank GOD I got a got my typical regular burriton with mas carne asade and avocado and a steak taco in late Dec 2008.  They never mentioned that they were closing...oh well...I guess I have to ndrive to SF then...
author: Michelle E.

description: This place has the best meats for tacos and burritos if your are looking for quality mexican tacos and burritos this is your place very clean and great service highly recommend this place
author: doreen c.

description: Great price, good tacos, and good people watching.   The old cashier winking at the ladies was great.
author: Nick V.

description: The beef is well seasoned and cooked. It's the best in S.F. I give it four vs. five stars  only because I've had yummier Tacos in L.A. and San Diego.
author: Yelp T.

description: La Taqueria is da shiznit. Really fresh ingredients. They were a choppin' the steak right in front of us. I could use a little rice in mine, but it'll do for most of my late night burrito cravings.
author: Mango D.

description: They are still the best tacos in SF.  Fresh and crispy beef tacos.  Dianda's next door had the best strawberry short cake too.
author: remy m.

description: I don't care what anyone says, these are the best burritos in the city.  I've been coming here since I was a baby (I have the pictures to prove it!)  I hate that most places put a ton of rice as filler so typically you can't tatste the juicy meat which equals a dry, heavy burrito.  Our parents still come in to take me and my sis there somewhat frequently.  They are also the perfect size, not oversized like most where you feel forced to finish it and then feel terrible afterwards.  Check it out if you happen to be in the mission looking for a solid burrito.
author: Kirsten M.

description: One of the more expensive Mission burrito joints--$6 chicken burrito, $1.30 chips & salsa, etc.--La Taqueria nevertheless makes some delicious and authentic food.  For those of you who prefer your burritos without rice and on the healthier side, La Taqueria is THE place to eat.  This is wetter, lighter, and slighty less hefty Mexican food; pretty much the opposite of what you'll find over at Farolito.  The horchata selction makes me giddy.
author: Karin H.

description: My reasons for loving La Taqueria seem a bit irrational to me.  I usually love my burritos containing rice.  But La Taqueria's ingredients are amongst the best quality I have ever had at a Taqueria or Mexican restaurant.  Being a Vegan, I found the quality of the beans perfect.  And that is a major reason why I adore their burritos.  The other reason is their guacamole - absolutely fresh with nice chunks of avocado.  The tortilla and salsa just rounds out what I find to be the most satisfying burrito I have ever had - closely followed by Taqueria Cancun, El Castillito, Poncho Villa's and Puerto Allegre's Vegetarian/Beans and Rice/Tofu Ranchero burritos.
author: Roy J.

description: Best carnitas burrito around.  Just don't attempt to eat the entire thing in one sitting unless you don't plan to eat again for the next 3 days.  That's a serious burrito, that's all I'm sayin'.
author: Erica G.

description: I think this is the place i went to. They have lots of weird drinks and deserts that make this place interesting to visit. Food was similar to gordos but not as good. Place was big and had a big line.
author: Keit K.

description: Always behind the curve a little, I had my first meal at La Taqueria on Friday.  It deserves all the stars that the 138 reviewers before me have handed out.  The best carnitas.
author: T-Bone L.

description: This place is the boom!!!  I love their tacos de carne asada! their salsa spicy but to delicious! this place is a must stop. i do every time im in san francisco.
author: Yolanda C.

description: Yes, I know that two tacos and an aqua fresca here can set you back about $15, but I would take a second mortgage on our house and my unborn kids to continue eating here for the rest of my life.  The carnitas tacos (with everything on them) are what my dreams are made out of, and their burritos are, well, perfect.
author: Julie H.

description: I used to really like La Taqueria.  I'm not sure if I changed or they changed, but my burrito today was much less than satisfying.  It was so wet that I had to eat it with a fork.  Seriously!  I've never eaten a burrito with silverware (or plasticware) before in my life.  And it wasn't even that good with the plasticware.  No refried beans.  No rice.  Chicken was bland.  Lame! And way more expensive than better burrito places in the mission.  This used to be where I went for cheap burritos.  No more!
author: Jenn M.

description: I felt that it used to be 5 stars, but after eating there year after year, I've brought them down to 4 stars because they're lacking in some areas.  Burritos and tacos are hands down one of the best.  Personally, I go with carne asada burrito with guac and cheese.  It bugs me that they charge for you to have your burritos without beans, but it's still delicious.  Salsa here is not good...it's very watery. The drinks are a joke in the back - you wish they'd at least have one flavor of fresh agua fresca or horchata (boo on the machine drinks).  It's easy to get caught up in the hype of this place - I used to think this place was Mexican heaven - but after some deep introspective and objective realization, it's not complete enough of a joint to be 5 stars.  If this review seems negative, just realize that the burritos are just that good to make this pessimistic review 4 stars.
author: Tsubasa O.

description: This is for the veggie burrito.....could be tastier. Too many pinto beans. Next time I will try a taco since I guess it's not a burrito-ria.
author: Kelley D.
